HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES;
Pout or Shout, They're Coming to Town, in Force

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
LISTEN TO THE SOUND OF HOLIDAY CHEER IN Hollywood.
"Unbelievably nerve-racking," said Sherry Lansing, chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, which has five films opening over the holidays. "There's so much competition this year, so many choices, that good, quality films can get lost. We're literally cannibalizing each other." 
 "It's insane -- a ridiculous amount of movies are coming out," said Scott Rudin, a prolific producer who has three movies opening this season: "Ransom," "Mother" and "Marvin's Room."
"I'm leaving town," said Stephen Herek, director of the forthcoming live-action version of Walt Disney's "101 Dalmatians." "It's too nail biting."
And Steve Golin, the producer of "The Portrait of a Lady," observed, "If you're not terrified, you're an idiot."
In the real world, the holiday movie season begins on Thanksgiving weekend. In Hollywood, the season began on Friday with the opening of the thriller "Ransom," in which Mel Gibson plays a rich man whose young son has been kidnapped.
The strategy for the season sounds simple: start the race early, before the rest of the mob. It doesn't always work, of course. Last year the first studio hopeful was Jodie Foster's "Home for the Holidays." It didn't make it.
The holiday movie season is always an anxious time in Hollywood, even scarier than summer, which is terrifically scary. This year the seasonal anxiety is particularly acute because so many films will spew forth. At least 25 major films will open across the country in November and December, and at least 23 more will be seen briefly in a few major cities like New York and Los Angeles. Last year, the holiday was equally crowded. Darwin could have used these seasons in Hollywood as a testing ground.
Part of the explanation is economic. The five weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas account for as much as 15 percent to 20 percent of annual ticket sales. Each day between Christmas and New Year is, according to exhibitors, like Saturday at the movies. And in contrast with 1995, the holidays this year fall in midweek, making the weekends potentially even more lucrative. So from a financial point of view, the glut makes sense.
But the issue is more complicated. In addition to the desire to score big at the box office, there is the desire to cram as many potential Oscar candidates -- whether for best picture or best actor or actress -- into that little envelope before year's end, when Oscar voters will presumably have the best chance of remembering possible nominees.
Christmas-themed movies are, of course, a natural for this time of year, as are movies that simply feel all snuggly and warm, whether or not they have explicit holiday themes.
Finally, the frenzy seems to beget its own frenzy, as movie makers simply pile in, as if driven by some lemminglike urge to compete. The studios are seemingly indifferent to the fact that there may be such a thing as too many movies in too short a time.
Every holiday needs to have an action film. Whatever the quality of "Daylight" (opening Dec. 6), in which Sylvester Stallone saves a bunch of New York motorists trapped in a tunnel beneath the Hudson River, it is the only big special-effects action movie of the season.
"We've got a built-in audience with a big star and a great concept," said John David, the producer of "Daylight." "And there's nothing on the market quite like us."
Similarly, Barbra Streisand's "Mirror Has Two Faces" is the only romantic comedy arriving before Thanksgiving, giving it a clear opening for predominantly women's audiences before a tide of comedies opens around Christmas. (Other films that are aimed at specific audiences and that seem to have a clear field include "Star Trek: First Contact" and "Beavis and Butt-head Do America.")
At one end of the spectrum are holiday films intended for children, like "101 Dalmatians," starring Glenn Close as the wicked Cruella De Vil; "Jingle All the Way," an Arnold Schwarzenegger comedy, and "Space Jam," a $100 million extravaganza that pairs the basketball star Michael Jordan with the Looney Tunes animated gang about which Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner, offered an amazingly candid description: " 'Space Jam' is not a movie. It's a merchandising event." Also in this category is Tim Burton's "Mars Attacks!" with Jack Nicholson and Ms. Close, which might be seen as a children's movie for adults.
At the opposite end of the spectrum are films considered Oscar-worthy. In December, just before the awards season, comes a surge of serious Hollywood movies in limited runs. The rationale? Good movies that opened much earlier in the year will somehow be forgotten by the academy voters and that odd group of journalistic hangers-on called the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, whose raison d'etre is to award the Golden Globes in January.
Is it really necessary to set off a flood of quality films after five or six arid months? Of course not. Academy Award winners like "Silence of the Lambs," "Forrest Gump" and "Dances With Wolves" were released earlier in the year without losing Oscar momentum -- or suffering at the box office. In fact, only one of last year's nominees for best picture, "Sense and Sensibility," came out during the holidays. The others -- "Apollo 13," "Babe," "Braveheart" and "The Postman" ("Il Postino") -- were released much earlier in the year. "Braveheart," the big winner, was released in May.
Similarly, this year the academy may remember earlier entries, like Frances McDormand in "Fargo," Denzel Washington in "Courage Under Fire"; Samuel L. Jackson in "A Time to Kill," John Sayles's film "Lone Star" and fall movies like "Michael Collins" with Liam Neeson, Stanley Tucci's "Big Night," Mike Leigh's "Secrets and Lies," and perhaps Brenda Blethyn from that movie.
But Hollywood persists, however illogically, in loading Oscar candidates into the last five weeks of the year. This year's Oscar buzz surrounds films like "Shine," an Australian film about a troubled pianist; "The Crucible," the movie adaptation of Arthur Miller's play; Milos Forman's "People vs. Larry Flynt," about the pornographer; "The English Patient," which opens on Friday; Kenneth Branagh's "Hamlet"; "Evita," the movie musical about Eva Peron and Jane Campion's "Portrait of a Lady," which stars Nicole Kidman.
In addition, Oscar hopes are being pinned on certain performers in holiday movies, among them, Debbie Reynolds in the comedy "Mother"; Shirley MacLaine in "The Evening Star" (the not-quite sequel to "Terms of Endearment"); Emily Watson in "Breaking the Waves"; Helen Mirren in "Some Mother's Son"; Lauren Bacall in her supporting role in "The Mirror Has Two Faces"; Joan Allen for her supporting role in "The Crucible"; James Woods for his supporting role in "Ghosts of Mississippi"; Diane Keaton in "Marvin's Room"; Woody Harrelson and Courtney Love in "The People vs. Larry Flynt"; Kristin Scott Thomas in "The English Patient"; Madonna in "Evita," and someone (maybe Goldie Hawn) in Woody Allen's musical, "Everyone Says I Love You."
Sometimes studios and film makers seem to go out of their way to maneuver their movies into the holiday season, despite the horrendous traffic jam, on the ground that their movies feel so, well, Christmasy. Take "One Fine Day," a romantic comedy starring Michelle Pfeiffer and George Clooney as single parents who collide in New York. "We were thinking of next year, maybe late winter or early spring," said Peter Chernin, until recently chairman of Fox. "But audiences loved it, and we thought if there's such a thing as a holiday mood, this plays into it."
Another movie that got wedged into the end-of-the-year sweepstakes is "Jerry Maguire," in which Tom Cruise plays a slick sports agent who loses his job and finds his soul. "I knew we were heading into heavy traffic," said Cameron Crowe, the writer and director. "But I just felt this movie had a December feeling. This time of year people take stock. They think about their lives. I do. There's a happy-sad kind of hoping for the best. It was just -- right for December. Of course it helps to have Tom Cruise."
ALSO BIG THIS YEAR ARE films featuring angels, among them "Michael," a Nora Ephron comedy in which John Travolta plays an unlikely and unshaven angel, and "The Preacher's Wife," Penny Marshall's remake of "The Bishop's Wife," about an angel who comes to help a troubled ministry, starring Whitney Houston alongside Mr. Washington.
Another movie with a hopeful message is the widely anticipated "Shine." "The summer would have been inappropriate in terms of how this feels as a movie," said Ruth Vitale, president of Fine Line Features, which bought the movie at the Sundance Film Festival. "This is a serious but a feel-good movie, and releasing it at the end of the year, when it's fresh in people's minds in terms of the Oscar, is perfect for us."
Finally, there are films like "Marvin's Room," based on the much-praised Scott McPherson Off Broadway play about a family coping with terminal illness. It ended up in the holiday rush whether or not anyone had intended it that way.
"At one point we thought of September for 'Marvin's Room,' " said Mark Gill, president for marketing at Miramax, which is distributing the film. "But then Diane Keaton came out in 'First Wives Club,' and it became inappropriate to release it then. We also thought we'd have better luck if we went later." In addition to Ms. Keaton, the ensemble cast of "Marvin's Room" includes Meryl Streep, Robert De Niro, Leonardo DiCaprio, Gwen Verdon and Hume Cronyn.
Although official numbers show that Christmas really is a bonanza for movie makers, it still feels as if Hollywood is overdoing things this time of year. But the competitive mind-set endures.
"It's like saying my child is better than your child," said Mr. John N. Krier, president of Exhibitor Relations, a company that monitors box office and film trends.
Or, as Ms. Lansing added, with some bewilderment, "Who's going to see 10 films in one week?"

HEADLINE: Just Speculating

BYLINE: By John Rothchild; John Rothchild is a financial columnist for Fortune magazine.

 BODY:

THE HIGH-RISK SOCIETY
Peril and Promise in the New Economy.
By Michael J. Mandel.
227 pp. New York:
Times Business/Random House. $25.
 
THE TROUBLE WITH PROSPERITY
The Loss of Fear, the Rise of Speculation, and the Risk to American Savings.
By James Grant.
348 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $30.
 These two books are so completely at odds, it's remarkable that they were published in the same month by the same house. "Americans are angry and worried" is the "Call me Ishmael" that leads off "The High-Risk Society." With pink slips flying and Social Security in doubt, says Michael J. Mandel, the economics editor of Business Week, the meek will not inherit the condo at Lake Tahoe. To get anywhere in this high-risk society, we all have to run risks: take the demanding job over the cushy one, put money in stocks instead of a bank. 
 The author of "The Trouble With Prosperity" couldn't agree less. As far as most stocks are concerned, James Grant, the author of "Money of the Mind," prefers money in the bank. His first line might as well be "Americans are giddy and deluded." In particular they are deluded about stocks, which these days are being snapped up at crazy prices. As Mr. Grant describes the rise of speculation in the 1990's, it sounds as though he's talking about Mr. Mandel: "America was becoming financially bolder. It was coming around to the philosophy that there was more to be feared in not making money than in risking its loss. Such, of course, is the psychological hallmark of every boom."
 According to Mr. Mandel, before we became the high-risk society we lived in the Age of Security, where jobs were here today, here tomorrow, and where people could get ahead without taking chances. But in Mr. Grant's view, there never was an Age of Security, because in every economic cycle fortunes are made and lost, industries are started or shut down; what's good for the Farm Belt may be bad for the Rust Belt, and while they're popping corks in the Texas oil patch, they're circling the want ads in Silicon Valley. The risk in every era is the same. A euphoria develops around a certain kind of investment, and people end up overpaying for whatever it is: stocks and Manhattan real estate in the late 1920's, bonds in the 50's, gold in the early 80's, commercial real estate in the late 80's and so on. Large chunks of capital are foolishly deployed, resulting in large losses to the owners of the capital and a misallocation of resources.
 Mr. Mandel's notion that inhabitants of the high-risk society should automatically invest in stocks is to Mr. Grant's way of thinking too popular not to be dangerous. He reminds us that in the 50's, during the Age of Security Mr. Mandel writes about, the average investor preferred bonds, which everyone knew was a risk worth taking, while stocks were disparaged as something to bet on when the horses weren't running. Because of their popularity, bonds were selling for crazy prices, so they yielded a pittance (3 percent) at a time when inflation was on the rise. Not surprisingly (at least not to Mr. Grant), stocks produced many happy returns in the 50's, while the bondholders got clobbered. Bonds lost roughly 80 percent of their value from 1946 to 1981.
 Neither book is an investment guide per se, but this reviewer can't help noticing that whenever Mr. Grant finds people paying unreasonable prices for whatever's popular, the least popular alternative (stocks in the 50's, gold in the 70's, bonds in the 80's) becomes the source of great wealth for the oddballs who invest in it. Today, the oddball choice would be raw materials, because in the 14 years during which stocks have gone up, commodity prices have gone sideways or down, which to a Grant disciple means they'll make up lost ground in the next cycle. Naturally, Mr. Mandel predicts the opposite: because commodities have done nothing for 15 years, they will continue to do nothing.
 In the high-risk society, Mr. Mandel sees government in retreat: less regulation, less consumer protection, big holes in the safety net. He is alternately thrilled and disturbed that people are being left to succeed or fail on their own. But what irks Mr. Grant about today's high finance is that the financiers aren't allowed to fail. By lowering interest rates in the early 90's and providing the easy credit that saved the likes of Citicorp and the Bank of America, the Federal Reserve created the flood of cash that has lifted stocks to a precarious height.
 On the readability scale, Mr. Mandel's book is low-risk and low-gain, short on anecdote and long on generality and annoying repetition. In one painful stretch of 30 lines, we find "uncertainty," "high levels of uncertainty," "far less certainty," a "rise in uncertainty," "the certain career paths," "increasingly uncertain alternatives," "such uncertainty," "economic uncertainty" and "the uncertainty," along with "the old rules for success do not work in an economy where the sources of growth are also the sources of uncertainty." Mr. Grant's book is demanding in spots, because it requires a working knowledge of Wall Street mechanics, but witty and informative throughout. Readers of his popular newsletter, Grant's Interest Rate Observer, will recognize the prose. In recent years, Mr. Grant's chronic bearishness on stocks hasn't helped his readers get any richer, but who else can make interest rates interesting, not to mention downtown real estate, the bond market, Federal Reserve policy and other subjects dear to Wall Street?
 A recurring theme in his narrative is the skyscraper Mr. Grant can see from the window of his own office. Built in 1929 during the lower Manhattan boom, 40 Wall Street was expected to produce $3.9 million in revenues, a yield that didn't materialize until the mid-1950's. Mr. Grant's account of the owners, the tenants and the debts at 40 Wall is 67 years' worth of cyclical history crammed into one building. There was never an Age of Security at 40 Wall.
 Mr. Grant notes the astounding popularity of mutual funds -- 7,773 and counting -- making the fund industry as overbuilt and overcrowded as lower Manhattan before the great crash of '29. "Like the Manhattan skyscrapers of the 1920's and the Texas oil rigs of the 1980's, the white elephants of the 1990's," he writes, "will bring grief to their sponsors and drama to the next recession."

LENGTH: 1232 words

HEADLINE: Habitats/64 Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn;
A Former Convent Becomes a Co-op

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
IT is an imposing building, on Havemeyer Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a former convent made of mellowed brick piled four stories high, complete with turrets and enormous windows.
For years, this 100-year-old building was derelict, bought from the Sisters of the Order of St. Dominic in the late 70's by the caretaker of the Church of the Annunciation across the street -- originally the Catholic church with which the convent was affiliated -- who allowed the building to fall into the city's hands for nonpayment of taxes. 
 It is a familiar drama, seen acted out across the city with slightly different characters. Some magnificent building, its original use part of the neighborhood's nostalgia, no longer useful, allowed to crumble and become an eyesore; impossible to think of a new use; too expensive to even tear down.
But this building is different, thanks to the efforts of Katie Kirwin and a group of other hardy home renovators, who persevered since 1982, when they asked the city to declare the old convent at 64 Havemeyer Street between North Fifth and North Sixth Streets a homesteading site. Two weeks ago, the 4 who are left from the original group of 11, joined by 7 others, started to move in.
When they petitioned for the city's permission to homestead the building, the vaulted ceilings and the decaying murals in the second-floor chapel -- now someone's studio apartment -- were still there, but most of the other original details were long gone. It took three more years for approval from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which needed complete financial documentation from all the original homesteaders.
It then took another three to four years for demolition, which Ms. Kirwin said consisted of tearing out the old plaster and replacing some of the joists with structural steel. At that time, the group had very little professional help. The People's Firehouse, a neighborhood redevelopment group named for its initial battle to keep a local fire station, offered to help.
"But we were so arrogant," Ms. Kirwin said. "We thought we'd get it done so much quicker -- and here we are, 11 years later and only four of us made it through to occupancy."
Ms. Kirwin herself has an interesting story. When the project began, she was living in Greenpoint, in another old building, fighting the landlord in a buildingwide rent strike. "One of the criteria for acceptance into the homesteading program was that you had to be in a 'difficult' housing situation," she said. "Well, talk about going from the frying pan into the fire."
About a year after the group began the demolition, Ms. Kirwin began to notice she was a bit unstable on her feet; it took another year to diagnose her problem as multiple sclerosis. Diagnosis, she said, is not always easy; she would be very unsteady, then the symptoms would disappear. But soon after the initial diagnosis, the disease affected the whole right side of her body. She began using crutches in 1989, a wheelchair two years later.
"The diagnosis came right when I was changing jobs -- you can imagine how stressful," said Ms. Kirwin, who went to work for the city's Municipal Archives, where she still works part-time. "So after a year of demolition, I basically became the group's record keeper."
ALTHOUGH the group initially worked as a team -- each person pitching in on the whole building -- after a while the homesteaders progressed to their own spaces: The members of the group with more time and money got more done. A few homesteaders even got home improvement loans.
"The quality of the work was erratic," said Karen Ansis of the New York Landmarks Conservancy. "By the time we got involved, they were kind of at a stalemate; they'd run out of money and the place was only 40 to 50 percent finished."
Ms. Kirwin credits the Conservancy with being "a lifesaver."
"We applied for the first round of the Conservancy's City Ventures Fund in 1988," she said. Eventually, the homesteaders received a series of grants and low-interest loans: from the Astor Foundation, from the National Trust, from Con Edison and more from the Conservancy.
There were also services donated: Although the building's architect, Judith Saltzman of Li/Saltzman, was paid for some of her work, more was donated, according to Ms. Ansis, who manages two of the Conservancy's various grant and loan programs.
The convent homesteaders had found themselves in deep trouble.
"By 1991, 1992, it had become apparent that if we went for a conventional mortgage, our maintenance fees would no longer be affordable," Ms. Kirwin explained. Aided by the Conservancy, the group applied for and received a "recoverable grant" from New York State's Housing Trust Fund for $776,210 -- a sum that will remain a grant as long as the homesteaders comply with the state's low-income regulations, which mandate that occupants make no more than 80 percent of the city's median income, currently $42,000 for a family of four.
Major work was stalled until March of this year, when the project hired a general contractor, R and R Contracting, supervised by Brian O'Connor, and things really started to move.
But during the interim, the homesteaders kept paying their monthly dues, which rose from $50 to $125 during the long wait; the money was necessary to pay for insurance and other services for the partly gutted building.
When the contractors came in, several of the apartments were already sheetrocked, with electricity, but others were little more than shells.
"My unit wasn't as far along," said Ms. Kirwin, "because I couldn't do the extra work."
Last week, Ms. Kirwin's ground floor unit, which was adapted for people with disabilities and was part of the convent's refectory, looked spiffy, and Mr. O'Connor was consulting with her about the slope of the ramp he was installing alongside the building.
Back in 1989, the convent became a co-op, and the homesteaders bought their derelict floor space for $250. Since then, Ms. Kirwin estimates she and her fellow owners have put in a significant amount of money -- it is difficult to figure exactly how much -- in materials and sweat equity. Although the maintenance fees of the homesteaders are still being calculated, Ms. Kirwin estimates she will pay between $150 and $200 a month for her studio; if there had been no subsidies, the projected maintenance would have been $487.
The market value of the space is also tough to determine because it's hard to find comparables for a studio in a convent in Williamsburg. But even if the apartment is worth, say, $100,000, it is unlikely Ms. Kirwin could ever sell it for that much. Part of the restrictions on the state grant say that the apartment must be sold to another low- to moderate-income purchaser -- and that limits the sale price.
Regardless of the financial details, she said she is thrilled to finally have a home -- and she has a handsome one.
All the 11 units -- most of them studios -- have high ceilings, from the chapel studio to the three-bedroom garret loft on the top floor. Hers is no exception; she has 11-foot ceilings and 7-foot windows. Her studio -- a large living room and a kitchen -- overlooks the rear garden, now laid with turf and accented with paving stones.
"It used to be a parking lot," said Mr. O'Connor, the contractor. "Suddenly, it's a garden."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 14; Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1175 words

HEADLINE: Plan for an Access Road Upsets Stony Brook

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of the towns of Brookhaven and Smithtown say they are on edge over development, road work and diminishing open spaces. Even a land-use study is raising concerns.
One study, financed by Brookhaven and called "Transportation Link Between SUNY Stony Brook and the Flowerfield Property," examines the need for an access road to an industrial zone, Gyrodyne Flowerfield. The site straddles the Smithtown-Brookhaven line south of Route 25A and west of the State University at Stony Brook. 
 "This study was initiated by Brookhaven's Industrial Development Association and paid for by a grant that organization received from New York State Economic Development," the Brookhaven Engineering Director, James Graham, said. "It was considered necessary, because Gyrodyne is a property viable for multiuse development. Gyrodyne's continued development over the next 20 years is dependent upon proper road access to the site."
The link would connect Route 25A and Nicolls Road, crossing Stony Brook Road.
"We are worried by the highly detailed nature of this study," said Lance Malomo, who lives on Route 25A in St. James. "The town has gone through a lot of effort and money to examine something that is just 'a possibility.' " A group that Mr. Malomo is associated with has protested at the entrance to the 320-acre site, owned by the Gyrodyne Company of America Inc., at Route 25A and Mills Pond Road.
Open since 1917, Flowerfield became a commercial site related to military technology in the 1950's and was later rezoned for light industrial use. Gyrodyne has been a public company since 1951. Today the complex features biomedical and electronics manufacturing, offices, a catering site, fairgrounds and the largest day-care center on Long Island.
"It would be unrealistic to think that an area like Gyrodyne, comprising hundreds of acres of commercially zoned land, would never be developed," said the Smithtown Community Development Director, Frank DeRubeis. "When it does, transportation will ultimately become a crucial point. It's more prudent to examine those possibilities now, before they become a major problem."
Gyrodyne's president, George Papadakos, said that among the possibilities were a day camp, an arts center, one-family houses and apartment complexes. Another use might be offices and manufacturing space for companies that have passed through the so-called high-technology incubator at the university.
Also considered was closing the Long Island Rail Road station in nearby St. James, to clear the way to reopen the Flowerfield station, which closed in 1958.
The Brookhaven study also reviewed the State University's plans and the potential effects on traffic. SUNY is planning 22 projects, including a 12,000-seat stadium, that would increase the building space on the campus by 48 percent.
The study predicted that fully developing the Gyrodyne site and the university plans would generate 23,000 vehicles by 2015. The last State Transportation Department study, in 1993, reported 18,800 vehicles a year.
A planning group in the department indicated that the projection followed the yearly growth of 1 percent for the last 10 years.
"Given the current and past traffic volumes on that portion of Route 25A, the route is already insufficient," Mr. DeRubeis said. "We know that we need transportation alternatives there already. What would happen if Gyrodyne was further developed? Even if they pursued low-residential usage of the grounds, it would present a further traffic problem. Hence the need for this study."
The Brookhaven Highways Superintendent, Harold Malkmes, agreed, saying Stony Brook Road was his main concern. "The study talks about an overpass at what would be at the Gyrodyne Road and Stony Brook Road intersection," Mr. Malkmes said. "I would agree with anything that takes traffic off Stony Brook Road. Life for residents along that route has become unbearable because of the increased volume of SUNY traffic."
A SUNY alumna, Jill Smith, said, "From what I understand, an overpass from Gyrodyne over Stony Brook Road would intersect the university's South Drive, a road with already unbearable traffic."
Mr. Malomo said he first heard about the road plan as a rumor, adding: "When I went to officials here in our Village of Head of the Harbor, which begins across 25A from Flowerfield, they claimed to have not seen the plan and couldn't comment. It was my feeling that any plans for Gyrodyne or roadways around it would affect our community, and our representatives should be in on the research phase before it was too late.
"When the study came out those same village employees that claimed ignorance were interviewed and had not registered protest of any of items registered in the study. I was shocked and stunned."
Valerie Vignona, president of the Long Hill Civic Association, representing a nearby community, said her group was also unaware of the study. "We've known that Gyrodyne has wanted to develop its property for over three years," Ms. Vignona said. "In fact, based on that desire, the company put in a proposal into the state for an access road to the university and its high-tech incubator. But it was voted down."
That proposal was presented in the Cuomo administration's Jobs Bond Act, but did not pass the Legislature. "This time around," Ms. Vignona said, "we haven't heard anything as yet from Gyrodyne or McLean Associates, the company hired to do the study. No calls, no letters. Long Hill residents are concerned that they were not part of the interview process. They feel it is a sign that they won't be part of the planning process if that time comes."
Features on the study in The Smithtown News have prompted anger at local legislators, Gyrodyne and the university.
The president of the university, Dr. Shirley Strum Kenny, wrote in an open letter on Oct. 3 in The Smithtown News: "SUNY Stony Brook has no need for this road. The existing roadway network surrounding our campus is more than adequate to handle our existing needs, as well as whatever growth might be contemplated in the future."
"I feel that public outcry is premature," Mr. Papadakos said, "especially since the study only speaks about possible uses for Gyrodyne, and then only at a projected date 20 years into the future. Our record here over the last 70-plus years has shown our positive commitment to the local community. For example, we have planted over 10,000 trees and shrubs on our property since the 1960's."
Mr. Papadakos also pointed out that the company had not applied for building permits.
The regional director of the State Transportation Department, Edward Petrou, said no firm plan had been presented.
The Long Island Rail Road also appears to have problems with the plans. "Of the possible uses studied at the Flowerfield property, the reopening of an L.I.R.R. station at the site is not currently feasible," a spokeswoman, Susan McGowan, said.
Ms. McGowan also said the railroad did not intend to close the St. James station in the near future.

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Massage Therapy Gains Sign of Acceptance

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
WHEN Loretta Filippelli of Holtsville received her diploma in massage therapy from the New Center for Wholistic Health Education and Research and passed the state examination to become a licensed massage therapist, she never expected a college degree, too.
In September the New Center became the New Center College, after the Board of Regents approved four-semester associate's degrees with a major in massage therapy. The program is the first in the nation to offer a degree in massage therapy. 
 "For massage therapists, this gives us more recognition and greater respect," Ms. Filippelli, who has started her own practice, said. "It's a first step toward having the medical profession see us as more credible."
A study in The New England Journal of Medicine in 1993 by Dr. David Eisenberg, director of the Harvard University medical education programs on alternative medicine, reported that 12.6 million Americans used massage therapy in 1990, making 77 million visits to therapists. That year Americans spent $14 billion on alternative medicine, often referred to as holistic medicine, and made a total of 425 million visits to alternative therapists, exceeding the 388 million visits to primary-care doctors.
The president of the New Center College, Steven Schenkman, said: l "Many disillusioned individuals are looking beyond a Western medical system that relies heavily on invasive treatments like surgery and medications with many possible side effects."
The new status, he said, "is part of the evolution of a profession that has been recognized in Eastern cultures for 5,000 years, but is just first becoming recognized and respected in the West."
For students, he added, graduating with associate's degrees is a jump from receiving a trade license at a vocational school to obtaining a professional degree.
The program, which has 350 students, started in 1981. The center also has programs in acupuncture; herbal medicine; Oriental medicine; amma therapy, or specialized massage therapy, and holistic nursing. Mr. Schenkman said the center was planning for bachelor's, master's and clinical doctorate degrees.
At the start of the semester, massage therapy had its largest enrollment, 105 new students. The four-semester program requires 63 credits, leading to an associate degree in occupational studies, with a major in massage therapy. The academic dean of the program, Dr. Robert Borzone, said the curriculum combined courses in Western medicine and Oriental medicine and included clinical internships.
The public is becoming more open minded to complementary medicine, Mr. Schenkman said, adding:
"One of the biggest changes is the realization that this is not a threat to Western medicine, as researchers have found that most patients who seek holistic health care do not abandon their mainstream providers."
Changing attitudes are created new demands on insurance companies. Last month Oxford Health Plans Inc. announced plans to create an alternative-medicine network in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, starting in January.
The manager of alternative medicine for Oxford, Dr. Hasaan Rifaat, said the plan would have four components, a network of providers, insured benefits, education and information and mail-order products.
Oxford said it was recruiting six types of providers, massage therapists, chiropractors, acupuncturists, yoga teachers, diet and nutrition counselors and, just in Connecticut, naturopathic doctors. Customers would receive a list of the providers who would charge a special rate, without referrals from primary physicians, said Dr. Rifaat, who added that the fees would be announced in January. Employers would be able to buy benefits for alternative medicine, for a 3 percent increase in premiums. That would cover chiropractic and acupuncture treatments, with employee co-payments of $10 to $20.
Oxford is expanding to alternative medicine because of customer demand, Dr. Rifaat said. A marketing survey found great interest in alternative therapies, he said, adding, "Our goal is not to have alternative medicine replace conventional medicine, but to expand the choices for our members."
The senior vice president for marketing at Vytra Health Care in Melville, John Kaegi, said Vytra had been considering alternative medicine. "We are trying very hard to build strong relationships between our members and the doctors in our network," he said. "We feel that there is a great need for holistic medicine. But at the same time we feel that the personal physicians are the best judges of treatment for their patients and we'll support whatever the doctors feel is appropriate for their patients. We'd rather defer to the doctors than dictate to them what we feel is necessary for their patients."
The Oxford move will increase demand for holistic therapies, Mr. Schenkman said. "It shows that a major insurance company has carefully studied these healing modalities and validated them," he said, "as well as recognizing that there are standards for education and certification bodies for licensure. This will not only bring more patients to holisitic practitioners, but more people will be interested in pursuing careers in these fields."
Massage therapy has been gaining recognition, Dr. Borzone said, and research shows it has many positive physical and psychological effects.
Dr. Noah Finkel, an orthopedic surgeon and the chief of staff at Huntington Hospital, said he often prescribed massage therapy as part of rehabilitation for patients who had sore necks and backs from car accidents. Aside from being relaxing and soothing, massage releases endorphins, he said, relaxing the muscles.
"Massage can really help you function better," Dr. Finkel said. "There is no downside to massage therapy, except as an economic issue. This has been the conflict for organized medicine and insurance companies. Who's going to pay for it? For how long? And for what indications? In physical therapy there are ways you can define improvement, but in massage therapy, it is more difficult to define an endpoint."
There is no endpoint in massage therapy, Dr. Borzone said, because it not only involves treating a condition as does physical therapy, but also helps maintain health. The effects can be measured, he said, quantitatively and over time, in terms of range of motion and blood pressure.
Patients have reported added energy, better sleeping and improved breathing and digestion. "There are many levels of massage therapy," Dr. Borzone said. "For some people, it's a one-hour vacation, while for others it's a therapy that treats medical conditions."
At the Long Island Jewish Pain and Headache Treatment Center in New Hyde Park, massage therapy is one method to treat chronic pain, said Dr. Robert Duarte, a neurologist at the center.
Physicians have many ways to help with chronic pain. "Many traditional methods," Dr. Duarte said, "have not worked or have not worked to a degree of patient satisfaction. Massage therapy has proven to be very beneficial for headaches and back pain. It not only feels good, but helps to alleviate muscle tension and increase circulation."
Doctors are frequently skeptical about holistic treatment, Dr. Duarte said, but are becoming more open-minded as they hear from patients. "They are starting to become aware that these techniques could be, and should be, used along with traditional modalities," he added.
Therapists from the New Center College have been treating people with Alzheimer's disease who suffer from agitation and anxiety at the Broadlawn Manor Nursing Care Center at South Oaks Hospital in Amityville. The staff of the home reports significant improvement after treatments, said Anneke Young, a practitioner at New Center College, who directs the program.
One patient, a frequent pacer, was found snoring peacefully in her bed after a treatment of massage therapy, Ms. Young said.
The Island Park Medical Care Practice, an outgrowth of the Long Beach Medical Center, is scheduled to open this month. A group of doctors and practitopmers from the New Center College formed this practice to integrate traditional and complementary methods, said Dr. Myles Gombert, medical director of Long Beach Medical Center. The practice will include internal medicine, adolescent medicine and pediatrics, as well as podiatry, midwifery and massage therapy.
For massage therapists, changing attitudes among doctors and insurers, along with the opportunity for an associate's degree, means additional career opportunities, said Tiffany Nixon of Uniondale, a student in the last semester of the massage program. "People graduating are going in all different directions," Ms. Nixon said, "from opening up their own practices to sports medicine to massage therapy in the theater."

HEADLINE: Once Again, Downtown's Attraction

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
IN East Hartford the town green is only six months old. A vacant office building was torn down to make space for it. In downtown Stamford, efforts to create an entertainment district have attracted a dozen new restaurants and a half-dozen nightclubs in the last year and a half. In Milford this summer, a city marina opened -- bedecked with a rose garden, walkway and patio -- beckoning customers to downtown businesses.
Around Connecticut, communities are paying more attention to their downtowns or Main Streets. Some started a few years ago, and are seeing results. In downtown Manchester, for example, there were about 25 commercial vacancies in 1993; now there are 3, said Robert Turin, the downtown manager. 
 Many towns are still at the talking stage, trying to determine what direction to take to fill vacant retail and office spaces, attract more people and improve deteriorating buildings and streetscapes.
"What's happened in Connecticut is some of the downtowns have deteriorated so much, a sense of urgency has developed," said Mary Ellen Brigham, who teaches retailing, marketing and strategic selling at the University of Connecticut.
Other towns, like Simsbury, have not deteriorated but are looking for ways to retain their charm while nurturing small businesses that could be a draw for visitors.
The realization among local officials is that with malls and big stores attracting behemoth crowds, most downtowns will never be the epicenters of society they once were. But many are working to maintain or improve the economic vitality and quality of life of their town centers, because they see the entire community linked to their success.
Mr. Turin, of Manchester, said "this is a town that 20 years ago, on a Thursday night, you couldn't move downtown. It was the place to go." He said it wasn't likely to be like that again but he added, "it's mostly leased and it looks pretty nice for a town of 50,000."
The trend is to try to capitalize on existing attributes, such as architecture and waterfronts, as well as to offer goods, services and conveniences that malls do not.
Danbury officials, for example, believe that the days of major retail anchor stores in their downtown are gone; as a result they are negotiating to develop an ice skating arena, says Susan E. Affleck-Childs, executive director of the Danbury downtown business district organization called CityCenter. The ice rink and the Danbury Railway Museum, which opened last April in a former train station, would function similarly to large anchor stores, attracting large numbers of people, she explained.
Ms. Brigham, of UConn, who is also a consultant to towns and retailers, said "What I'm seeing now in Connecticut, and it's just a reflection of what's being done elsewhere in the country, is a more grassroots look at downtown, from the standpoint of what they're unique at, what is their character. And, downtown groups are trying to create an environment that works for that character and customers they already have, or those that are close by that they might not be capturing."
She said that in the past revitalization was often tied to massive structures like malls, coliseums and civic centers, with the hope that they would become magnets for downtown areas. (The Stamford Town Center, the Hartford Civic Center and the New Haven Coliseum are examples.) For the most part, however, people who went to those attractions didn't patronize businesses outside of them, she said.
Now, more towns are attempting to find their centers' niches. This year, five communities are getting help from the Connecticut Main Street Center program. It is part of the National Main Street Center project affiliated with the National Trust for Historic Preservation. East Hartford, New London, Simsbury and Torrington were the first Connecticut municipalities chosen to participate. They don't receive money, but they get assistance that would cost them money to purchase on their own. For instance, consultants in specialties like architecture, design, planning and retail sales help towns devise strategies for their communities. Information and contacts are provided from towns with similar problems and characteristics that have improved their town centers.
Interest in the Main Street Center program, which is supported by Connecticut Light and Power, is growing. Last year, nine Connecticut municipalities applied, said Lisa Bumbera, the program director. Last month, representatives from 30 towns attended a workshop on the program, she said. Up to three towns will be chosen to participate in 1997, she explained, adding that participating towns are in the program for five years.
East Hartford, a participant, is trying to overcome massive competition from the Buckland Hills Mall and surrounding commercial development in Manchester, as well as from West Farms Mall in West Hartford, said Tana M. Parseliti, coordinator of Main Street Plus, the downtown program in East Hartford. A former school is being renovated for use as a community cultural center. The Sage-Allen department store, which closed in 1989, has been rehabilitated to house new businesses. The first tenants are a health club, an executive awards company and a security firm.
Among strategies being used to rejuvenate town centers is the establishment of downtown taxing districts. In those areas, businesses agree to pay a surcharge on top of their local property taxes to finance revitalization of a downtown area. The hope is that they receive a return on their money in the form of more customers and more business.
In Middletown, businesses rejected a proposal to have a special taxing district there. But New Haven downtown businesses recently voted to establish one.
Danbury has had one since 1988. Its budget is about $130,000 a year, said Ms. Affleck-Childs, its executive director. After six years, she said, "the challenges remain, the opportunities are still there. I think what this says is the downtown revitalization process is not a short-term, quick-fix kind of deal. Downtowns didn't get in trouble overnight. They're not going to come out of it overnight."
Stamford, where downtown businesses long complained of not reaping benefits from the Stamford Town Center, has had a special taxing district since 1992 with an annual budget of $650,000. (The town center is the largest financial contributor.) Sandra Goldstein, the district manager, said streets are cleaned seven days a week, bulbs in street lights are replaced as soon as they burn out, flowers are planted, graffiti is removed -- all in the interest of creating "a safe, secure, pedestrian-friendly downtown."
"We still have miles to go," said Mrs. Goldstein, who pointed out that the next challenge is attracting more retail businesses.
Housing is seen as important to a downtown's success because it creates built-in customers for businesses as well as an atmosphere of vitality. Condominiums built in downtown Norwalk have helped the business climate there, Ms. Brigham said. In Stamford, a 400-unit housing complex is under construction on Broad Street, and another 600 units are planned for downtown, Mrs. Goldstein said.
In many places, returning buildings to their original facades as well as creating old-fashioned streetscapes have become popular sprucing-up techniques. And improving traffic patterns and parking are viewed as paramount to being customer-friendly. In Manchester, shoppers get free parking; there are no meters downtown. Long-term parkers -- business owners and employees -- pay a monthly fee for parking-lot spaces farthest from the stores, leaving the close spots for customers. The parking revenue goes to the special taxing district, Mr. Turin explained.
Events like festivals and concerts, are ubiquitous because they are considered essential to introducing people to businesses they might not know exist downtown.
The point officials involved in downtown revitalization stress is that when there are successes, such as new businesses opening, the job has just begun. A flow of customers has to be not only created but maintained.

HEADLINE: SLAMMING THE DOOR

 BODY:
No matter how modest the house or apartment, the two generations of children who grew up in postwar economic prosperity in the United States and in my case, Canada, assumed they would return from school each day to the predictable familiarity of home: a place to eat, do homework, reconnect with siblings and parents and generally get on with growing up, secure and fairly well satisfied with life. But as DeParle wrote, how do you do all that for a child when you live on $4.75 an hour?
 
GILLIAN NORRIS-SZANTO
St. Davids, Pa.

HEADLINE: More Electrified Track on Way

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
A CONTROVERSIAL $1.7 billion railroad electrification project has been approved by the State Department of Environmental Protection, with construction work expected to begin in the next few weeks.
Connecticut was the last state to approve the project, which will electrically power 156 miles of track between New Haven and Boston. Sixty-eight miles of rail will be electrified in Connecticut. When the project is completed in October 1999 it will allow electric trains to travel from Washington, D.C., to Boston, and reduce the trip time between New York and Boston from 4.5 hous to 3 hours. By 2010, 34 electric Amtrak trains able to travel as fast as 125 miles per hour are expected to travel the route daily. Presently only 18 Amtrak trains travel between New York and Boston each day with maximum speeds of 90 M.P.H. 
 This project will make Amtrak profitable, said Thomas M. Downs, president of Amtrak, and show that American passenger rail transportation is the future.
Not really, say its critics. After squandering millions of taxpayers' dollars, Amtrak will still be unable to compete with other modes of transportation, says Christopher Percy, of Waterford, a marine environmentalist. The Amtrak right of way that runs right along the coastline of southeast Connecticut will be a more dangerous obstacle forever impeding people from reaching the waterfront or going between Long Island Sound and local embayments, he said. Since first being proposed in 1991, the project has faced stiff resistance from coastal residents and businesses.
Coastal residents and local marine environmentalists said earthen and concrete railroad causeways had blocked the circulation of water between Long Island Sound and local coves and embayments and environmentally degraded waters that were important habitats for shellfish and fin fish. They said the railroad corridor needed to be fixed before it was electrified.
In 1992, $100,000 of Federal and state money was appropriated to study the environmental impact of coastal transportation corridors. But none of the coves or embayments adjacent to railroad causeways were included in the study. The study concluded in 1993 that the Amtrak railroad corridor did not pose a significant environmental problem.
Recreational boaters and marina owners led by the Connecticut Marine Trade Association then became the most significant opposition to the project.
They said the operation of five moveable bridges over the Connecticut River, Niantic River, Shaws Cove, Thames River and Mystic River impeded boat traffic between Long Island Sound and embayments. They said that if Amtrak increased the number of passenger trains traveling daily between New York and Boston from 18 to 52, as was originally planned by Amtrak, marine businesses and the state's coastal economy would suffer.
In addition shoreline businesses dependent on rail freight service said they were concerned the planned increase in rail passenger service would disrupt rail freight service.
Gov. John G. Rowland campaigned against the project, but later changed his position, after Amtrak addressed the concerns of Connecticut residents and businesses, said Governor Rowland's press secretary, Dean Pagani.
Instead of 52 trains each day between New York and Boston, Amtrak will only have 34 trains, said Mr. Pagani. Instead of keeping the bridges closed until sailboats or larger motor boats request an opening, the bridges will remain open from Memorial Day to Columbus Day, until trains are approaching. Five rail sidings will be built to minimize the impact of increased passenger service on existing freight service, Mr. Pagani said.
In response to concerns voiced during hearings in September, Amtrak also agreed to the installation of deflectors and diverters on power lines to lessen the danger of birds being electrocuted. Amtrak will also provide an inspector, acceptable to the State Department of Environmental Protection, who will oversee construction in Connecticut.
Amtrak seems to have addressed recreational boaters' main concerns, said Walter L. Shieferdecker, owner of the Essex Island Marina, and a member of the Connecticut Marine Trade Association.
The hope for David Hersant, president of Citizens for a Sound Environment Inc. (a group composed of coastal residents opposed to electrification), is that Congress may still withhold funding, deciding not to waste the taxpayers' money.
Congress must still appropriate $500 million over the next three years to complete the electrification.
The citizens' group is awaiting a decision in Federal District Court in New Haven on an injunction that would halt construction on the project. The group says that Amtrak did not consider more sensible and less environmentally damaging alternatives such as creating a passenger rail corridor in less environmentally sensitive areas inland, or using trains with gas turbines rather than electrical engines.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

VICTORIAN WOMEN
 A symposium on Elizabeth Colt, Harriet Beecher Stowe and other artistically focused Victorian women is scheduled for Saturday from 9:30 to 4 at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. It is related to the exhibition of Sam and Elizabeth Colt's material possessions and the cultural, economic and political influence they wielded.
Connoiseurship, literature, philanthropy, the civic uses of art and the arbiters of taste will be discussed in 45-minute talks by various experts. 
 Reservations, including admission to the Colt exhibition, cost $25 and a box lunch is available for $13. The number is 860-278-2670, extension 3049, for more information.

RUDE, BUT FUNNY
"Ubu Roi," Alfred Jarry's jarringly vulgar play of a century ago has been revived by the Oddfellows Playhouse Teen Repertory Company, to be performed on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M.; next Sunday at 3; Nov. 22 at 8; and Nov. 23 at 3 and 8. All performances will be at the Playhouse, 128 Washington Street in Middletown. Jarry was a teen-ager when he and two classmates created the piece. Constructed in Punch and Judy style, but using live actors, it began as a parody of one of the boys' unpopular teachers. Eight years later it was presented in Paris as an outrageous farce, rebuking contemporary French politics. This production, called "Ubu Rex" is recommended for older teen-agers and adults. Tickets for the preview on Thursday are $4, thereafter the prices are $6 and $8. The number is 860-347-6143 for reservations.

'ROMEO' RELOCATED
A multiracial production of "Romeo and Juliet" imported from Britain will have two performances in Connecticut this week: on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Garde Arts Center in New London, and on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Lyman Center for the Performing Arts at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven.
Produced by the Haworth Shakespeare Festival with a cast of actors from the Royal Shakespeare Theater and the Royal National Theater of Britain, the play's text remains intact, but its venue has been moved from 16th-century Verona to contemporary South Africa. The protagonists are no longer Montagues and Capulets but Zulu families.
The Haworth Festival has specialized in revitalizing Shakespearean plays as 20th-century dramas, having done so with an all-black "Macbeth" prior to the "Romeo and Juliet" production.
Danny Carrick, one of England's young directors, put "Romeo and Juliet" on stage, and Francis Gallop, the production designer, has costumed the cast in regal African fabrics.
Tickets in New London are priced from $16 to $30 and may be reserved by calling 860-444-7373. The theater is at 325 State Street. New Haven ticket prices are $16, or $14 for people over 65. The number is 203-392-6154 for reservations.

NEPTUNE'S JOURNEY
In 1796 the 350-ton, full-rigged Neptune set sail from New Haven for the Far East. Two years and 8 months later it returned with a treasure trove of tea, silk, porcelain, 80,000 South American sealskins and other luxury goods.
A new exhibition at the New Haven Colony Historical Society traces that journey and the daily lives of the 36 men in the crew, their 30-year-old Captain, Daniel Greene; his mate, 26-year-old John Hurlbut, and the 21-year-old ship's doctor, David Forbes. Five men died during the voyage, from scurvy, flu and drowning.
Their ship, which carried 20 cannons, rounded Cape Horn twice and called at a number of ports including the Falkland Islands, Patagonia, the Sandwich Islands and Macao. The historical society's display of porcelain, sea chests, medical handbooks, engravings, paintings, items of clothing, albatross eggs, a stuffed penguin and a grass skirt has been drawn in part from relics of the voyage, and from museum collections appropriate to the period.
The historical society is at 114 Whitney Avenue in New Haven and is open Tuesday through Friday from 10 to 5, Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 5. Admission is $2, $1.50 for adults over 65, and $1 for children 6 through 16. A guided tour and Chinese tea-tasting at no extra charge is scheduled for Nov. 24 at 3 P.M. The number is 203-562-4183 for more information.

PROVOCATIVE ART
A provocative exhibition of contemporary art by Hachivi Edgar Heap of Birds, a Cheyenne Arapaho from Norman, Okla., is at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.
Works by Mr. Heap of Birds may be seen through Nov. 24, the outdoor portion displayed on the lawn facing Main Street. Titled "Dunging the Ground" it refers to the massacre of the Pequots in 1637, when Capt. John Mason wrote in his account that "this was God crushing his enemies, burning them in fire, dunging the ground with their flesh . . ."
Mr. Heap of Birds first learned of the war that all but destroyed the Pequot population last summer during a visit to Foxwoods Resort Casino, where a presentation celebrated the rebirth of a Pequot cultural identity.
Indoors there is an installation called "16 Songs/Issues of Personal Assessment and Indigenous Renewal," conceived and executed by Mr. Heap of Birds and artists from the Boomali Aboriginal Artists Cooperative in Sydney, Australia, and the Tandanya National Institute of Aboriginal Art in Adelaide.
Sixteen works by the Australians and several abstract paintings and drawings by Mr. Heap of Birds are involved with words -- resistance, new growth, patience -- pointing up a common bond of travails concerning sovereignty and civil rights at opposite sides of the globe.

CIVIL WAR DIARIES
The nature of civil wars tends to be more heartbreakingly personal than those fought in foreign lands by strangers. And America's Civil War is brought up close, personal and in meticulous detail in five diaries kept by a soldier from Stamford named Noah Webster Hoyt.
His notebooks have been reproduced by the Stamford Historical Society in one volume that also contains biographical and bibliographical information. The price is $14.95. A reception for the book will be held at the society's headquarters, 1508 High Ridge Road, today from 3 to 5 P.M. when the originals, stored in the society archives for years and yellowed with age, will be displayed under glass.
Noah Hoyt was a 26-year-old carpenter when he answered the call for volunteers in 1862 and enlisted in Company A of the 28th Regiment Connecticut Volunteers, the unit credited with helping gain control of the Mississippi River for the Union. He was joined by 177 fellow-townsmen, many of whom were school chums and co-workers; 37 never returned. For more information the number is 203-329-1183. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: With Help From the Top, Democrats Gain

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
WHEN James H. Maloney, a Danbury Democrat, was campaigning for the Fifth District Congressional seat, he attended 32 candidate forums. In all but one, he was the only major party candidate there because the Republican incumbent, Gary A. Franks, of Waterbury, declined the invitations. Mr. Maloney attributed his victory in last Tuesday's election partly to just this difference: his presence at such events and his opponent's absence.
"The irony is, had he participated in the dialogue, he may very well have ended up winning the election," Mr. Maloney said of Mr. Franks, a three-term Congressman. 
 With his victory, Mr. Maloney became the first Democrat to represent the Fifth District since William R. Ratchford held the seat from 1979 through 1984. And Mr. Franks became the first incumbent United States Representative from Connecticut to lose since Mr. Ratchford was defeated in 1984 by John G. Rowland, now the Governor.
For Mr. Maloney, the focus now turns to working in Congress, where he said he plans to concentrate on education, economic development and providing services to constituents in his diverse district, which includes the cities of Danbury, Meriden and Waterbury, blue collar Naugatuck Valley towns, and wealthy Fairfield County suburbs.
Mr. Maloney's victory gives Democrats a 4-to-2 majority in the state's Congressional delegation, the first time since the 1982 election that they have held such an edge.
In the General Assembly, Democrats took a 19-to-17 majority in the State Senate, pending expected recounts in two districts, and expanded their majority to 97-54 in the State House of Representatives, pending any recounts. For the last two years, Republicans held a 19-17 majority in the Senate and Democrats had a 91-60 margin in the House. For the remaining two years of his current term, Governor Rowland, a Republican, will be facing Democratic majorities in both houses of the General Assembly.
In the Congressional races, the surprise was that the closest contest was in the Sixth District where the incumbent seven-term Republican, Representative Nancy L. Johnson of New Britain, squeaked by her Democratic challenger, Charlotte Koskoff of Plainville.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, who won re-election in the Second District by only 21 votes two years ago, had a much more comfortable margin of about 12,000 votes this time around. He defeated his three-time Republican challenger, Edward W. Munster, of Haddam, who said he will not run again.
Two other Democratic Representatives, Barbara Bailey Kennelly of Hartford and Rosa L. DeLauro of New Haven, easily won re-election in the First and Third Districts, respectively.
Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Stamford, defeated his Democratic challenger, Bill Finch of Bridgeport, in the Fourth District which extends from Greenwich through Bridgeport.
Voters on Tuesday also approved an amendment to the State Constitution guaranteeing certain rights to crime victims. Among other guarantees, victims may make statements before approval of plea bargaining and sentencing, and be notified of court proceedings and status of the defendent, and receive restitution. Members of the Connecticut chapter of the organization Survivors of Homicide have said they will propose increasing these rights in the future.
As for the new General Assembly, which takes office in January, Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, Democrat of West Hartford, who plans to seek the Senate position of President Pro Tempore following his election to a sixth term, set a conciliatory tone for the relationship between the Democratic legislators and the Republican Governor.
"Let's discover what we can agree on. Let's discover what we can work on," said Mr. Sullivan, adding, "Our goal would be to find very few opportunities where there would be bills vetoed by the Governor."
State Senator George Jepson, a Stamford Democrat who was re-elected to a fourth term, has said he will run for the post of Senate Majority Leader. He previously served two terms in the House.
In the House, the incumbent Speaker, Thomas Ritter, Democrat of Hartford, is expecting a challenge from Representative William Dyson of New Haven for the presiding officer's post.
Both Democrats and Republicans said Democrats got a boost from President Clinton's overwhelming success in the state. The Republican State Chairman, Chris DePino, called it remarkable that so many Republican candidates did win in the wake of what he called a "Clinton tidal wave." He also said that many Democrats were successful because they ran on what he called Republican issues -- cutting taxes, reforming welfare and reducing the size of government.
"We're going to hold their feet to the fire to make sure they not only talk the talk, but walk the walk," said Mr. DePino, who was uncontested in his own race for re-election to a State House seat from New Haven.
Mr. Gejdenson said he was helped in his eastern Connecticut district not only by the Clinton plurality, but also by the way Mr. Clinton articulated the Democrats' positions on such issues as Medicare, education and the environment.
This, he said, helped voters "see the differences much more clearly this time" between him and his challenger. "We won by more than 21 votes," the elated Democrat joked in an interview. Mr. Gejdenson, who won re-election to a ninth term and is the dean of Connecticut's House delegation, said he will focus on campaign finance reform, student loans and trade issues in the next two years.
Mr. Maloney acknowledged that he benefited from Mr. Clinton's performance in his district. It was the first time that a Democratic Presidential candidate carried the Fifth District since 1968 when Hubert H. Humphrey was the Democratic candidate.
According to the Secretary of the State's office, 1.97 million people were registered to vote. The number of unaffiliated voters has grown 21 percent since 1988, while Democratic and Republican registrations have dropped. The Secretary of the State's active voter list shows 727,381 unaffiliated voters, 668,247 Democrats, 470,774 Republicans and 3,511 minor party members.
Mr. Franks attributed his loss to negative television advertising waged by his opponent. He said he had the lead in the race until Mr. Maloney ran an advertisement featuring a rat. It was meant to show that Mr. Franks had run-down rental properties in Waterbury. Mr. Franks said he no longer owns the properties. But Mr Maloney contended that the Republican sold them to a corporation in which he owns stock.
"We had him as the incumbent accountable on a whole range of issues," Mr. Maloney said. "I think it's the job of a challenger to hold an incumbent accountable for his tenure in office."
Mr. Franks, who was one of two black Republicans in the House, also complained about allegations by Mr. Maloney that a $100,000 advance Mr. Franks had received for his autobiography from a publishing company owned by Rupert Murdoch was a quid pro quo for votes that would benefit Mr. Murdoch.
"All is fair in love and politics," Mr. Franks said after his loss. The Republican's re-election campaign was marked by a low-key style in which he declined a number of invitations for speaking engagements and press interviews, as well as the forums mentioned by Mr. Maloney, and was slow to respond to Mr. Maloney's criticisms.
On election night, he described himself as a victim of "six years of personal smear campaigns," saying that personal attacks "have all been lies." His first comment to his supporters on election night was, "To a degree, I feel relieved." He has talked of running for the United States Senate.
In the State Senate, in a closely watched race in the 28th Senatorial district, the Republican incumbent, Fred H. Lovegrove of Fairfield, overcame a well-financed challenge by Thomas G. Ganim, Democrat of Easton. Mr. Ganim, the brother of the Mayor of Bridgeport, Joseph P. Ganim, raised more than $175,000, compared with average spending of $17,074 by State Senate challengers two years ago, according to Common Cause of Connecticut.
Nearly 20 percent of the incumbent state legislators were unopposed, the largest number in at least 20 years, said the Secretary of the State, Miles S. Rapoport. The Democratic State Chairman, Edward L. Marcus, said that trend is not healthy.
"Uncontested elections can make the office holders feel they are kind of invincible and why should they care," he said. "They can create a group of pretty cocky, self-important people."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Rezoning Commercial Land to Meet Housing Needs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR half a century a 65-acre site in the middle of the Essex County suburb of Nutley was home to ITT. But over the last few years the sprawling building that once housed the company's avionics and military and electronics division was torn down, including its 325-foot research tower.
The vacant site, bounded by River and Kingsland Roads and Washington Avenue, has since been rezoned for housing. And now a developer is advancing plans to reshape it into a residential community of up to 615 homes. The project would cost more than $50 million, including the price of the land. 
 In Hanover Township a 41-acre site off Route 10, approved for 500,000 square feet of office space that was never built, also has been rezoned. There, plans are moving forward for a subdivision of 40 single-family detached houses that would cost more than $13 million, including the cost of the land.
The two projects, along with a spate of others in various stages of the approval process in such towns as West Orange and Fort Lee, underscore developer interest in turning commercially zoned land into housing.
Most of the sites are in North Jersey where large chunks of vacant land are in short supply and the demand for housing, at this time at least, is greater than for office or industrial space, developers, local officials and industry analysts said.
It is an important new trend because "there are no alternative uses for most of these sites," said Robert Burchell, an urban planning professor at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
The sites are appealing for residential use for many of the same reasons they were appealing for commercial use: They are sizable and near highways and job centers.
Still, their commercial potential was never realized, despite an improving office and industrial market. The office sector alone "is at a break point with Class A space in short supply," which could be depleted by next year leading to new construction, said Donald P. Eisen, senior managing director of the New York area at the East Rutherford office of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage.
Companies will look to be on superhighways, like Interstates 287 and 78 and farther west and south in the state where the labor markets are, said Mr. Eisen. Closer-in sites can work if they are near highways and developers are creative, he added.
Rezoning them to housing, however, also raises a number of issues for towns that are grappling with ways to expand their tax base while preserving residents' quality of life. A key concern is that such development not overburden municipal services, particularly roads and schools.
Those are concerns of officials in Mine Hill. After years of litigation that ended in a 1991 settlement the Morris County township rezoned 240 commercially zoned acres on Canfield Avenue for 800 town houses and condominium and rental apartments.
"There is a demand for start-up housing in that area," said Jeffrey Freireich, of the $60 million project that still must be approved by the township. He is executive vice president of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, which owns the site and sued Mine Hill.
MEANWHILE local officials, worried the project would double their community's population of 3,300, are exploring the possibility of buying the property. "That question goes to the electorate this winter," said Joseph J. Bell, the Mine Hill Township lawyer, noting there would be a special referendum early next year.
But Dr. Burchell said switching to housing could make sense for some municipalities because of market trends. He said up to 75 percent of the housing demand for the next 15 years will be from baby boomers -- empty-nester and childless couples -- as well as single people. Providing zoning opportunities for housing catering to this "mobile middle class" could put the land into productive use, generate a reasonable revenue stream and have limited impact on local services, he said.
To work, Dr. Burchell said, such projects should be upscale gated communities. They would also offer many recreational amenities and someone else to do the maintenance for buyers as well as a low bedroom count for towns, he said.
That is the direction of the residential community proposed for the former ITT property. Nutley officials found the site held no promise for commercial use now or in the near future and rezoned it for housing last February. The decision came after months of heated discussions and deliberations over the potential impact of putting housing on the site, among the last large developable tracts in the community. (Indeed, a residents' group has filed a lawsuit against the rezoning.)
The project, which still must be approved by the township planning board, represents the first sizable residential development proposed in Nutley in decades. As now envisioned it would be a gated community of up to 615 units -- from single-family homes to luxury town houses and condominium apartments. Among the amenities planned are a clubhouse, swimming pools and fitness trail. It would be built by Town and Country, a division of Whiteweld, Barrister & Brown, a real estate investment company with offices in Woodcliff Lake and Manhattan. The company is under contract to buy the site from ITT contingent on approvals, said Joseph L. DiBernardo, senior vice president of Town and Country.
Mr. DiBernardo said his company became involved in the site 18 months ago because finding so large a tract so close to Manhattan in a "sweetheart" of a residential suburb was rare. He said the mix of housing and prices -- in the low $100,000 to $300,000 range -- would appeal to "multiple markets," from empty-nester and professional couples to the elderly and some families, which would keep the number of school-age children in check. He said he was hopeful construction would start this spring.
"The objective now is to make sure everything that the developers promised is realized and that Nutley comes out with the best project" with the least amount of impact on services, said Mayor Gary J. Furnari who took office after the rezoning.
In Hanover, township officials rezoned the 41 acres off Route 10 after seeing the office developer go bankrupt and the site sit idle for 10 years. Deputy Mayor Sal Iannaccone said the reason was simple: "There is a glut of offices on the market nearby and though the site was approved for offices that use was incompatible with its residential neighbors."
Housing also "is the best ending" because it will generate less traffic, Mr. Iannaccone said, noting that it would have limited impact on schools. And because the homes will be clustered, 26 acres will be left as public open space, some of which will turned into a soccer field, he said.
THE project, which still must be approved by the township's planning board, is to have 40 homes, averaging 2,400 square feet in size, and set on one-quarter-acre lots. Prices are expected to be in the $300,000 range, said Joseph Forgione, a principal at Sterling Properties Group of Livingston, the developer. The company purchased the site last year from Citibank, which took it back through a foreclosure in the late 80's.
Mr. Forgione said his company had purchased the site because "there is a pent-up demand for new housing in the area." The site's location in a desirable town and close to major roadways, including I-80 and I-287 was another factor, he said, noting that construction would begin once the approvals were granted.
A similar story is unfolding in Fort Lee. There Avalon Properties, based in New Caanan, Conn., with offices in Princeton, has been pursuing a rezoning since 1992 for 13 acres off Route 4 that could accommodate 850,000 square feet of offices. Instead it wants to build 350 high-end rentals in six four-story buildings at a cost of $53 million, including land. The design was modified from 525 units in three taller buildings, to meet neighbors' concerns.
"We see an enormous gap in the rental market in Fort Lee, where rental housing hasn't been built since 1972," said Jeffrey B. Albert, an Avalon vice president. "Properly zoned sites for multifamily housing just do not exist, they have to be created; and some of the best sites around are those zoned for office." He said he was optimistic construction would start next summer.
Fort Lee Administrator Peggy Thomas said that, while the option was that the site remain undeveloped, community concerns over the project's impact on schools still must be addressed.
And in West Orange township officials are considering a developer's request to rezone 55 acres off Route 280. The site is approved for 900,000 square feet of office space.
Roseland Property Company of Roseland together with BNE, a Livingston-based development company, wants to build a community of six single-family homes and 198 town houses. It would cater to the empty-nester market in the area, which is strong, said Marshall B. Tycher, a Roseland principal. He said the project would cost more than $45 million, including the cost of the land.
Murray L. Palent, president of the West Orange Township Council, said he supported the rezoning. The housing project, would put a dormant site to use and though it would produce less tax revenue than the commercial project it would produce less traffic and, like the community's other town-house projects, not have an impact on municipal services, said Mr. Palent. "It could be a win-win for West Orange," he added.
