SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3130 words

HEADLINE: Retailers Have Harlem on Their Mind

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
LONG past its legendary prime, the great crosstown thoroughfare wheezed with decay. Mammoth projects intended to stimulate redevelopment were announced by Mayor after Mayor, Governor after Governor, while news reports conveyed assurances that a rebirth of the fabled strip was right around the corner. But the corner was never turned.
Then, major retailers woke up to the fact that there was still a lot of pedestrian traffic on the street. Consumers, in other words. Momentum began to build; not through massive state intervention but a patchwork of smaller-scale private investment. Soon, the area had even attracted the Walt Disney Company. 
 No, this is not another tale of 42d Street. But those involved with the latest attempts to rebuild 125th Street (officially Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard) are mindful of the mid-Manhattan success story, which followed years of inertia and skepticism.
"If they can get 42d Street under way, we can certainly get 125th Street under way," said Barbara Norris, president of the not-for-profit Harlem Commonwealth Council, which controls several key properties along the street, including the site of the $56 million Harlem U.S.A. shopping and entertainment center.
Gov. George E. Pataki sounded a similar theme, saying: "You don't succeed in moving forward if you rebuild Wall Street and 42d Street but ignore 125th Street. We think we're going to find success with all three."
Some modest success is already evident, as three big retailers who have recently discovered 125th Street -- Duane Reade Drugs, Rite Aid Pharmacy and Blockbuster Video -- all report brisk business.
"Something's getting ready to happen, as opposed to the constant paralysis, analysis and talk, talk, talk," said Deborah C. Wright, president and chief executive of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation, which is to share $300 million over 10 years in Federal, state and city funds with the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation.
"The important signal to send to the private community is that we're getting started," said Ms. Wright, who was formerly the city's housing commissioner.
Two weeks ago $11.2 million in financing was authorized for Harlem U.S.A. by the New York Empowerment Zone Corporation, which oversees the Federally designated zone in Manhattan and the Bronx where redevelopment projects can qualify for government aid and tax credits.
Charles A. Gargano, the state's Commissioner of Economic Development and chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said the goal was to "give the private sector the confidence they need and then move out of the way."
"I can think of no area facing as intense development activity as 125th Street," said Randy Daniels, senior vice president and deputy commissioner for economic revitalization at the Empire State Development Corporation, who has lived in the Sugar Hill district of Harlem since 1980.
For all of the hopeful talk, however, there is no firm timetable yet for any of the major projects. And 125th Street can be as daunting as it is promising. African Square, at the intersection of Seventh Avenue (Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard), rivals almost any mid-Manhattan crossroads for crowding, bustle and energy. But 125th Street has more than its share of shuttered storefronts, vacant lots and deferred dreams. A sign at the corner of Old Broadway, for example, announces an impending renovation sponsored by the City of New York -- Edward Koch, Mayor.
"Sometimes," Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields said, "the gap is too wide between announcements and a readiness to do something. That leads to discouragement."
Speaking of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, which was dissolved and reconstituted as the Harlem Community Development Corporation, Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th noted, "There were too many projects on the drawing board and too few bricks were laid."
So what makes the current prospects any different from all the false starts of the past? For one thing, Ms. Wright said, "There's a readily identifiable and real pool of capital that can make some of the projects a reality."
CHARLES MILLARD, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said a reduction in crime had allowed stores to stay open later. He also said the Giuliani administration's crackdown on street vendors had cleared away what had been a pedestrian hazard.
"All over the neighborhood you see revitalization," said Phillip Morrow, the president of the South Bronx development corporation, who lives in Harlem and was formerly development director for the Harlem Urban Development Corporation. He discerns a confluence of events, beginning with the reopening of the Apollo Theater in 1983 and leading to "more home ownership, middle-class blacks moving back, renovating buildings and buying condominiums.
"You've got people with money to spend in their pockets on 125th Street," he said.
That has not escaped the attention of national and regional retailers, who have begun to settle in on the street.
"The suburban marketplace has become saturated," said Darren Walker, director of development and public affairs at the Abyssinian Development Corporation, an independent offshoot of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and co-developer of the $15 million Pathmark project on East 125th Street.
"Let's be frank here," Mr. Walker said. "It's not altruism that's driving it. It's the bald fact that there's money to be made in urban communities."
Ms. Wright noted that there were more than 500,000 people in upper Manhattan. "The real question is why did it take the Gap so long to figure that out?" she asked. "That having been said, the thing that is going to push this strip over the top has not yet happened. It's going to take something like Harlem U.S.A. to take the cover off."
Harlem U.S.A. would occupy an L-shaped parcel on the south side of 125th Street, between St. Nicholas Avenue and Eighth Avenue (Frederick Douglass Boulevard). The project is being developed by Grid Properties and the Gotham Organization, in association with an affiliate of the Harlem Commonwealth Council, which owns most of the land. The building has been designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and the Simmons Design Group of Brooklyn.
On the first and second floors of the glassy 275,000-square-foot structure would be a Disney Store of 6,000 square feet; Gap, 6,000 square feet; Chase Manhattan Bank, 6,000 to 7,000 square feet, replacing the branch that is now on the site; Showman's Cafe, 5,000 square feet, replacing the club that is now on the site; Radio Shack, 2,500 square feet and Watch World, 500 square feet.
A 15,000-square-foot book store and a 15,000-square-foot music store are also expected to be part of the project, said Drew Greenwald, president of Grid Properties.
Ms. Norris said the board of the Commonwealth Holding Company, a for-profit subsidiary of the council, "did not want a strip of discount retailers who were going to compete with existing businesses."
Above the stores would be a nine-screen Cineplex Odeon movie theater, with as many as 3,000 seats. Above that would be a 2,000-seat mini-arena with an ice-skating rink, operated by Recreation World.
Mr. Greenwald hopes tenants will be found for 75 percent of the space by year's end, with leases signed for as much as 50 percent. The developers expect to meet 10 percent of the cost with their own equity, 10 percent through the state's Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund and 60 percent through conventional bank financing. The other 20 percent would come through the Empowerment Zone Corporation.
One key parcel on St. Nicholas Avenue is owned by the city, which intends to sell it to the Harlem U.S.A. project through a sole-source contract, rather than going through a request for proposals. "We want a fair price, but mostly we want their project to be completed," Mr. Millard said.
The city's economic agency is also lending $1.5 million to the Pathmark project, which would include a supermarket and a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in a 53,000-square-foot structure between Lexington and Third Avenues. There would also be an underground parking garage. The project is being developed by the Community Association of the East Harlem Triangle and Abyssinian. It was designed by Garrison McNeil & Associates.
The bulk of the financing is an $8.3 million loan from Chase. "We have put our financial resources and influence behind this so other private-sector investors would be able to see that it is possible to make a successful investment in the Harlem community," said Carol Parry, the bank's managing director for community development.
Other financing consists of a $2.5 million equity investment from a real-estate fund known as the Retail Initiative; a $1.1 million loan from the Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund; a $1 million loan from the Local Initiatives Support Corporation; a $700,000 grant from the Empire State Development Corporation and $400,000 grant from the Federal Government.
The developers are now reviewing design elements on a line-by-line basis, Mr. Walker said, since the general contractors' bids came in higher than expected.
Also in the pipeline are more tentative projects like a Magic Johnson Theater, with at least 10 screens and 3,000 seats, between Third and Second Avenues. The Magic Johnson chain is being developed nationwide as a joint venture between Sony Theaters and the Johnson Development Corporation.
Councilman Powell said the theater could be the anchor for a mall that would occupy the entire block. "This could be the biggest economic development project in the history of Harlem," he said.
The president of the Los Angeles-based theater chain, Kenneth Lombard, was a bit more restrained. "We're very committed to making the project happen," he said, "but as with all projects at this stage, there are a lot of loose ends we need to tie up."
Still evolving is the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Diagnostic and Treatment Center proposed at Morningside Avenue, which would be developed by the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and the Commonwealth Holding Fund. The building would include an 18,000-square-foot primary care center and 13,000 square feet of retail space. But the overall size of the building has yet to be determined, said Maureen Connelly, a spokeswoman for the project, as that would depend on the needs of potential commercial tenants in the upper floors.
Councilwoman Fields has voiced her concern that the building be more strongly oriented to commercial and retail uses, in keeping with the nature of 125th Street.
Even more tentative are the state's plans for the site on Lenox Avenue (Malcolm X Boulevard) that had been set aside for the 22-story Harlem International Trade Center, an office tower and hotel that was scrapped last year by the Pataki administration. Mr. Daniels would say only that he was working on a "significant retail and commercial project."
As nebulous as these undertakings may be, there have been tangible signs of progess on 125th Street. Earlier this year, Carver Federal Savings Bank moved into its new $5 million headquarters, a four-story, 25,000-square-foot granite-clad building near Lenox Avenue, designed by the Simmons Design Group. Its earlier headquarters were destroyed by a fire in 1993.
"We could have put this building somewhere else," said Howard Dabney, vice president and chief lending officer at Carver. "But that's not our commitment. That's not our mission. We think Harlem is a viable place to do business."
Elsewhere on the street, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad is currently rebuilding its station above Park Avenue. New windows have been installed throughout the 13-story Theresa Towers office building on Seventh Avenue. Leonard Goldman, whose family owns the Theresa, said an elevator modernization was also in the works.
The gleaming structure is known in the history books (and on a fading sign on its western facade) as the Hotel Theresa, once renowed as the "Waldorf of Harlem." It was designated an official landmark in 1993.
There are two other official landmarks on 125th Street: the Apollo Theater, near Eighth Avenue, and the former Mount Morris Bank, at Park Avenue. The Apollo has had its problems -- state officials have written off as unrecoverable about $11 million in loans for its renovation. And the bank has been abandoned so long that small trees are growing out of its cornices and windows.
THESE are not the only trouble spots. Having constructed a new building at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue, the National Black Theater finds itself without the $1 million needed to bring an adjacent older structure up to code. Moreover, state officials want to install a real estate firm to manage the property, which includes commercial tenants. The building was designed by Gerard Paul and its facade includes reliefs by Ade Bisi, a Nigerian artist.
Barbara Ann Teer, founder and director of the theater, resents the state's intrusion. "We're the only building that has no graffiti," she said. "The tenants are satisfied and we are 100 percent rented. Yet we need professional management?"
City officials have transferred management of the 10-year-old Mart 125, a two-level indoor market with vendors' stalls, to the Masjid Malcolm Shabazz Mosque, which operates the lots on 116th Street to which street vendors were relocated. "The mart was supposed to be an incubator for small entrepreneurs but became tainted by politics," said Mr. Daniels. "You didn't have to pay rent if you knew the right person."
But Councilwoman Fields still believes the mart offers a "real opportunity to help stabilize 125th Street" if it is turned over to a cooperative composed of the merchants.
Another disappointment is the Ben & Jerry's Homemade ice-cream parlor at Fifth Avenue, which opened with much fanfare in 1992. "It has not been one of our more profitable stores," said Lee Holden, a spokesman for the company. Although the store is still open, its future is unclear because the building is for sale. "Definitely, we want to maintain a presence in Harlem and are looking at options," Mr. Holden said.
More recent arrivals in more heavily trafficked locations have fared much better.
Cater-corner from the Harlem U.S.A. site, is a 7,000-square-foot Duane Reade drugstore. It opened in May 1994 and is now "one of the fastest-growing" outlets in the 60-store chain, said Anthony J. Cuti, chief executive of Duane Reade.
"We wanted to be in Harlem because we felt that the community was underserved," Mr. Cuti said. "We felt that this was an opportunity for us and would be a welcome contribution." He said a "significant effort" had been made to hire the store's 35 employees from the neighborhood.
Four months after Duane Reade arrived, Rite Aid opened a block away. It moved to its current location, a 7,000-square-foot store directly across 125th Street from the Harlem U.S.A. site, in January 1995. About 25 people work there.
More prescriptions are now filled there than in any of the 110 other Rite Aid stores in the city, said John Lewandowski, the market manager for the New York metropolitan area. Business at the store exceeded projections and expectations, he said.
Last March, a 3,500-square-foot Blockbuster Video store opened near Lenox Avenue. The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation is "very pleased at the reception the store has received," said a spokeswoman, Mariesa McClafferty. She said the store was receiving an average of 150 membership applications a day.
At the corner of Eighth Avenue, the city's second Krispy Kreme Doughnut franchise, a 1,200-square-foot shop, is to open next month, making it the northernmost outpost of the famed Southern chain. The first New York store is in Chelsea, on 23d Street.
The choice of the second location was easy, said Jonathan E. Faber, vice president of operations. "We drove to Harlem, we saw the volume, we saw the rejuvenation going on," he said. "Krispy Kreme, we figured, would be perfect up there. It was pure instinct. We just saw a future."
The building into which Krispy Kreme is moving is owned by the United House of Prayer for All People. It gained national notoriety last year when one of the commercial tenants, Freddy's clothing store, was set ablaze by a gunman who killed eight persons, including himself. The incident followed a dispute between Freddy's white proprietor, Fred Harari, and a black subtenant, Sikhulu Shange of the Record Shack.
"That's past history," Mr. Faber said. "It could happen anywhere. We saw it as a totally isolated incident."
WHETHER coincidental or symptomatic, the fire at Freddy's reminded New Yorkers that racial tension has long been part of the streetscape, as residents chafed at the dominance of white businesses and landowners. That is not likely to abate as more large corporations move in, driving rents up.
"One camp would prefer that all the businesses on 125th Street remain or be community owned," said Kevin McGruder, chief operating officer of the Abyssinian Development Corporation. "But I don't think that's realistic. When you look at the demand, people are going out of the community to get the things they want; a lot of times to get things these retailers are going to bring. The businesses aren't being universally welcomed, but my sense is that a majority of people want that. They're leaving the community to go to the movies."
Or to go to a good drugstore, Mr. Morrow said, until Duane Reade arrived. Some people even cross state lines to buy groceries. "Anybody who's mobile uptown goes to New Jersey or Westchester to shop," Mr. Daniels said. "Until you get a Pathmark on 125th Street, you're not going to keep those dollars in the community."
To judge from an informal survey, uptown customers think there is room and need for both local merchants and larger operators. "Across the board, we're hearing people say they want more black-owned businesses," said Barbara Askins, president of the 125th Street Business Improvement District. "But they also want a Modell's, a brand-name clothing store, a Conway, a Tad's steakhouse."
Ms. Askins's office has been distributing questionnaires asking, among other things, what businesses people would like to see on 125th Street. One respondent said he wanted to see an African market -- and an airlines ticket office. Another wish list reflected the fact that Harlem residents are hard-pressed to find the most basic amenities.
The respondent, a young teacher who lives on upper Madison Avenue, hopes to see a Gap on 125th Street, as well as Domino's, Parade of Shoes, TCBY, Staples and Wendy's. But there is something else, she said: "A nice clean deli and fruit stand."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Where the Memories Outnumber the Men

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: ORADELL

 BODY:
One thing could be said for this day. At least Fred Hansen didn't know the guy now resting in a box.
Mr. Hansen, 84, a World War II veteran who is food chairman for American Legion Post 41, was trying to make a little bit of money for the post by renting out the lodge for a stranger's wake. But the process brought up something most uneasy. And as Mr. Hansen prepared the coffee and set up the food trays for this man's remembrance in Oradell's Veterans Memorial Building, he was overcome with thoughts of other veterans who had recently succumbed to age. 
 "My post commander died last week and we had two others go out last month," said Mr. Hansen, a 52-year Legion member who was an Army corporal in North Africa in World War II. "We're trying to keep this place going but I fear the handwriting is on the wall. We're dropping like flies."
As they gather Monday to observe Veterans Day, members of the Legion and the nation's other leading veterans' group, the Veterans of Foreign Wars, may well wonder who will lay the wreaths and march in the parades when they no longer can. The Legion and the V.F.W., products of the first World War and the Spanish-American War, respectively, are facing the prospect of a sharp membership loss as their mainstay, World War II veterans, die off.
This is certainly true in Oradell, where the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars share a lovingly self-built meeting hall. On the walls are names or portraits of their dead friends, most prominently Staff Sgt. Thomas H. Cordes, a blue-eyed radio operator and gunner in a bomber squadron who was one of the first hometown boys shot down in the air war in Europe. In cabinets are their helmets, ribbons and other mementos of combat, while behind the bar and flanking the rickety meeting table is the flag for which they fought.
The groups' meetings are a bittersweet remembrance, half taken up with talk of the recently dead, otherwise wondering how to keep their organizations afloat. While each lodge can boast more than 120 members, many are men already in their 80's who have joined both groups in an effort to artificially increase their numbers. And a good meeting night still brings out only about 15 of the faithful.
After opening prayers, the pledge of allegiance comes with a sharp salute, minutes are read and it's down to business at a recent V.F.W. meeting. "Is there a comrade or a family of a comrade in distress?" asks Bill H. Wassmann the post commander, to a flurry of response and follow-up questions about who gets a fruit basket. (Only the bedridden or the families of those who died are eligible.)
Commander Wassmann, at 67, is the spring chicken of the bunch. A Korean War veteran, he joined up in Oradell after his own post in nearby Emerson closed for lack of members and he has been re-elected president nearly every year since. He'd love to pass the torch, if only there was a young man ready to take overe. So far, there isn't.
"We had a wake a while ago and we have been having a lot more lately," says the commander, searching his men for an answer to their future. Motions are made for a Christmas recruitment party and there is discussion of forming a group involving both the Legion and the V.F.W. that brings in families and sons. But the moments are filled with more hope than solution.
The problem is perhaps that all wars are not created equal, nor have combatants always come home to a ticker-tape parade. These social organizations grew strong on the euphoria and camaraderie that came out of World War II, and their original members carried the same sense of unity that the whole country felt at the time.
Though wars continued, with Americans being called on to fight in Korea, Vietnam and the Persian Gulf, that defining togetherness has never been re-established, neither on the battlefield nor at home.
"In general, we are no longer a nation of joiners," said Col. John Dwyer, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Military and Veterans Affairs who, along with two brothers, was drafted for Vietnam.
"When we came back, the time was different than after World War II, and we were different," he said. "We were not like our fathers. We had mustaches, long hair and wanted fast cars. We weren't joiners and there was little outreach to us asking us to be a part of things."
Vietnam veterans account for only 25 percent of the V.F.W.'s national memberships, while more than 45 percent come from World War II, said Walter Merklin, the organization's state adjunct quartermaster and a Vietnam veteran.
"I got involved after going to a bowling league sponsored by the V.F.W.," said Mr. Merklin. "Then slowly I began to realize how important these organizations were to protecting veterans rights and entitlements, and I became more heavily involved."
To other veterans who have so far resisted joining the groups, he says: "Look at the U.S. Congress, we're losing more and more vets there, and that means there's less protection for our rights. The V.F.W. has to stay strong in order to keep what veterans deserve."
Combined, the American Legion and the V.F.W. still have about 5 million members nationwide but the numbers are getting smaller, with posts like those in Oradell losing 15 to 20 members a year.
When the men of the Oradell Veterans Memorial Building were young, things were different. The American Legion and the V.F.W. were strong lobbies, championing the rights of those disabled while fighting for their country and of the orphans and widows so often left behind.
They helped bring about the Veterans Administration in 1930 and wrote the G.I. Bill of Rights, which gave education and economic assistance to a generation of young men following World War II.
Now these posts survive on meager budgets of a few thousand dollars and age has slowed their community work. In Oradell the members take pride in doing things that they say the younger generation doesn't; providing 280 pairs of socks to paraplegics at the Veterans Memorial Home in Paramus and buying special wheelchairs for people with Alzheimer's Disease. They also coordinate Boy Scout activities, help out as school crossing guards and sit on the boards of the local charities and historical societies.
These men in their twilight years say they often are the only regular visitors to go down to veterans' hospitals.
"You'd be surprised how many of them are sitting in their wheelchairs with no socks and things," said Dan Ryan, 75, a former Navy sailor on an Atlantic minesweeper. "Sometimes I think, but for the grace of God, I could be there like that too."
John Farrell, a 74-year-old former Seabee, leaned over the post bar to add: "Some people think we just sit around here like a bunch of drunks. But we're out there in the community, we're doing our part."
Over beer and pizza, Oradell's veterans often now discuss why time has chosen to pass by both them and their mission of remembrance. Some figure younger veterans are afraid they would be dominated by this tough older crew. Others suggest that the young might think they are stodgy, a belief they counter by noting that several of "the boys" are voting for President Clinton because they don't like Bob Dole's tax cut idea or his stance on abortion.
Every year they send out invitations to join up during their Memorial Day poppy drive -- a commemoration of war dead stretching back to World War I -- and they always encourage the Vietnam veterans to join their ranks at parades on Memorial Day and the Fourth of July, parades that have gotten shorter every year.
"But I can't think of a one that has joined," Mr. Farrell said.
As posts close, he believes, the country will lose more than just meeting places for some aging soldiers. "We are the conscience of what the country has gone through," he said. "We are there to remind people and Congressmen that there are still veterans lying in hospitals, that there was a Pearl Harbor and a death march. It's like the Holocaust, we need to recall these things to make sure they don't happen again."
Before the Oradell meeting breaks up, there is another prayer, a way to close with just such a remembrance. Like most things, it doesn't always go without a hitch, laughter erupting in the final moments when the Bible is opened to the wrong place, a passage that would be more appropriate at a funeral.
"You sure this is the right page?" Ray LaCour, 80, a World War II radio operator, said jokingly to his friends. "I don't think this is the one we want."
He turns to "suffer thy children" and it has a much better ring.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Behind the Good News, a Patchwork of Reasons Why Taxes Rise and Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
When Governor Whitman sliced state income taxes by 30 percent, her critics predicted that a resulting freeze in state aid to schools and municipalities would send local property taxes soaring. Last week, the Governor shared some happy news with the taxpayers (and with fellow Republicans preparing for next year's elections): it hasn't happened.
At a news conference in Trenton on Monday, she announced that total property tax collections had risen just 3.66 percent statewide from 1995 to 1996. The average tax increase during her term (4.2 percent) has been smaller than in those of her three predecessors: James J. Florio (5.4 percent), Thomas H. Kean (9.6) and Brendan T. Byrne (6.5). 
 But as rosy as the overall picture may be, it obscures some important details.
Mrs. Whitman did not mention that in 282 towns and cities, nearly half of those in the state, property taxes went up more than the statewide average; 43 had double-digit increases. While many towns have benefited by tightening their fiscal policies and attracting new taxpayers -- offices, stores and industries -- the less fortunate are struggling with flat state aid, increasing school enrollments, declining property values and shrinking budget surpluses.
Generally, these municipalities fall into two categories: growing towns in counties like Hunterdon, Burlington and Monmouth, where a surging population is putting heavy demands on local schools and municipal services; and older cities and blue-collar suburbs in the state's long-settled northeast corner, where taxpaying employers are shrinking or closing their plants.
What follows is a closer look at 13 communities, to show why some have seen taxes go up and others down. Often, it turns out, the answer has less to do with statewide tax policies than Governor Whitman and her critics would have you believe.
 
HOBOKEN: DOWN 4.09 PERCENT New revenue helped, including $5 million from United Water of New Jersey, which has begun managing the city's water system, and $7 million from the Port Authority, which is developing a commercial and residential site on the waterfront. The city is collecting taxes more aggressively, and a new pay scale requires police officers to work eight years, rather than three, to reach the top pay grade.
 
ATLANTIC CITY: UP 10.06 PERCENT As the Governor has urged, the city is tightening pay for municipal workers and improving tax collections. (Casinos pay 74 percent of local property taxes.) But officials say such belt-tightening will take time. Last year, $8.9 million in budget surplus was used to keep property taxes down, but the surplus fund has about dried up. In addition, Federal aid has dropped $4.5 million.
 
ROXBURY: UP 6.15 PERCENT Of Morris County's 39 towns, only Roxbury and four others have increases over 5 percent this year. State funds provide about a third of the money for its schools, but Trenton's aid has been flat for three years and school enrollment is growing. Catherine Cross, the school business administrator, said the tax increase was "strictly a function of state aid."
 
WILDWOOD: DOWN 4.70 PERCENT Officials used surpluses and reserves to cut taxes. The retirement of old municipal bonds cut expenses by about $200,000, and a reorganization of several city departments reduced salaries by about $145,000.
 
RARITAN: UP 10.04 PERCENT This once rural Hunterdon County township is one of many on the outer ring of suburbia struggling with rapid increases in the number of schoolchildren. School taxes, which account for 71 percent of township taxes, jumped about $2.1 million to help pay for a new elementary school and additions to three others.
 
MILLBURN: UP 6.94 PERCENT A big culprit was a $2.2 million increase in Essex County taxes. A $250 million expansion at the Short Hills Mall increased Millburn's total property values; at the same time, values dropped in some other Essex towns, shifting the county tax burden in Millburn's direction.
 
BERNARDSVILLE: UP 7.69 PERCENT As in Millburn, development here made the total value of property rise faster than in the rest of Somerset County. Other factors included a rise in the town budget and new wings for an elementary school and the middle school.
 
WOODCLIFF LAKE: DOWN 1.38 PERCENT For the second year in a row, officials used $600,000 in budget surplus to keep municipal taxes stable, helping make Woodcliff Lake one of only 5 of Bergen County's 70 towns to lower taxes. School taxes also dropped because of a $1.8 million budget cut at the regional high school. A new A&P and some new homes came onto the tax rolls, helping reduce tax rates for other property owners.
 
BERGENFIELD: UP 0.75 PERCENT Officials put the brakes on years of tax increases by dropping health insurance benefits for the Mayor, the Council and some part-time workers, cutting sewer expenses by installing storm drains to prevent runoff from seeping into old sewer pipes, and increasing the use of surplus funds.
 
WALL: UP 8.09 PERCENT A New Jersey Natural Gas propane storage tank was removed, denying the township about $1 million in taxes. And pension costs for the police jumped about 50 percent, to $120,000, because the state reduced payments to the fund.
 
CHERRY HILL: DOWN 0.38 PERCENT Taxes stayed essentially flat because of a $500,000 increase in investment income; reduced health benefits for police officials, public-works employees and some other town workers; a reduction in teachers and larger class sizes, and a crackdown on delinquent property taxpayers that pushed the collection rate to 99 percent.
 
SAYREVILLE: UP 16.21 PERCENT The increase in this blue-collar industrial borough underscores the risk of relying on surplus funds to stabilize taxes in a given year. Last year, $3.3 million was used. This year, only $1 million was available, and taxpayers had to fill the gap. And general municipal expenses rose $1.3 million.
 
HILLSIDE: UP 7.71 PERCENT Long gone are the steel and pharmaceutical mills that once paid most of the tax bill. Now homeowners, many of them aging, face a rising burden. "We're landlocked, with no new space left to build and no new ratables coming in," said Rosemarie McClave, the township treasurer. "A new mall would be wonderful."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;
Right-to-Play Turf War: Kids vs. Dogs

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
It's not much to look at: an empty, blacktopped space next to Public School 234 in TriBeCa. But the 9,000-square-foot lot on Chambers Street is at the center of an intense conflict between school and community board officials, who have permission to use it as a playground, and local dog owners, who have been using it to exercise their pets.
Formerly weed-choked and strewn with garbage, the space was first rented by Community Board 1 in May 1993 for $1 a month from the city's Economic Development Corporation for use as a "community playground," said Paul Goldstein, the board's district manager. Parents and other school volunteers cleaned it up, and the city spent roughly $70,000 to pave and fence it, Mr. Goldstein said. Soon, pet owners who had used the lot when it was derelict began to use it again as a dog run. 
 A dispute quickly arose, and it has grown. Officials first tried to cut off the dog owners' access by locking the gates of the fence surrounding the lot, but the locks were repeatedly broken. Bob Townley, a neighborhood man who has two children in P.S. 234 and who runs an after-school program and a day camp there, said that this summer the smell of dog urine and feces in the lot had been so overwhelming that children at the camp could not play there at all.
At a raucous Community Board 1 meeting last month, the school's principal, Anna Switzer, and the board's chairwoman, Anne Compoccia, offered to allow one-fourth of the lot to be used as a dog run if a group could be organized to clean and maintain the run. But many dog owners at the meeting refused, bristling at the suggestion that the school and the children had greater rights to the space than they and their pets did. "I will always use it," Jeff Cohen, a dog owner, said last week. "I don't believe anyone has the right to divide it up." The day after the meeting, copies of a bitterly worded flier were posted near the school. "Dog owners are not anti-school," the fliers said. "Why then is the school anti-dog-owners?" Similar themes were scrawled on the school's back wall facing the lot.
Other dog owners have been more conciliatory. About 20 recently established Dog Owners of TriBeCa to accept the board's offer as they search for a permanent solution. They are drafting a proposal for the community board to consider. Yvonne Fox, a local pet store owner who helped get the group together, said members hoped a permanent dog run could be created nearby when the reconstruction of West Street was completed. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Caution: Economic Statistics Are Wrong

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Imagine you had spent much of your professional life trying to explain something, only to learn that it was all a mistake. What you thought had happened was simply an illusion created by faulty statistics.
As Gilda Radner used to say, "Never mind." 
 That is the position in which more than a few economists, pundits and politicians are likely to find themselves when Congress's Advisory Commission to Study the Consumer Price Index, chaired by Michael Boskin, reports on just how much the index overstates inflation.
That report, having been delayed until after the election, will provide ammunition for those who want to save the Government money by holding down the inflation-indexed increases in Social Security benefits.
But the implications of substantial overstatements in inflation go much further than that. It may be that much of the economic debate of the last few decades has been based on the wrong premises, and therefore is simply irrelevant.
If you have studied, and believed, the economic statistics issued by our Government in recent years, you know the following: Economic growth in the current recovery is the slowest in memory. Real wages in this country have been falling for years, and living standards have stagnated.
Some part of that litany was used successfully four years ago by Bill Clinton when he ran for President. Bob Dole tried to use some of it this time, but most voters seemed ready to trust their own impressions, not numbers cranked out by economic statisticians.
As Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company, points out, all of those statistics are vitally influenced by inflation estimates. And if you use lower inflation figures, then the other statistics look much better.
Consider productivity gains -- essentially how much output per worker is growing. The figures bounce around with economic cycles, but if you average the figures over longer periods, you see a steady decline. Last week the Government reported that year-to-year growth in productivity was just two-tenths of 1 percent for the third quarter. For the 90's, it is averaging just under 1 percent a year, one-fourth what it used to be.
If that were true, it would be hard to see how American business could make any money, or could be competitive. All that money spent on computers, all that downsizing, all that reorganizing accomplished nothing.
Why are the numbers wrong? The Government starts by measuring output, from which it subtracts inflation to get real growth. And that is the figure used to compute productivity. But if inflation is overstated, real growth is understated. And if that happens for a sustained period, the differences can become substantial.
In fact, America's companies have accomplished a lot in terms of productivity and competitiveness, as investors know quite well. Patricia Chadwick, the chief investment strategist at Chancellor Capital Management, cites those gains in recommending shares of European companies, which she says are just starting to follow the American path toward increased productivity and competitiveness.
It has been no secret that inflation numbers were overstated, but most analysts have ignored the wider implications. Those who watched the Dow got a better picture of the economy than did those who studied the Government's misleading statistics.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN;
Park Slope Boom Spreads South

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Eugenio Duval is poised to rise with, or be crushed by, the good times descending on his lower Park Slope street corner. The problem for the 39-year-old bodega owner is deciding what to stock his shelves with.
In a 30-minute period last week, Mr. Duval's store near the corner of Seventh and Prospect Avenues sold a lottery ticket to a middle-class Hispanic woman, cigarettes to an elderly white woman, baby formula to a young black father and two pints of malt liquor to a white working-class couple. But he was stumped by the request of a long-haired young man in his 20's. "Do you have any organic eggs?" the man asked politely. 
 Mr. Duval, a Dominican immigrant, was stumped. He and the owners of the other new businesses opening up in the South Slope are eager to ride the tide of commercial growth spreading down from the North Slope, but none is quite sure how to do it. The same area started to grow in the 1980's but then bottomed out. Now, trendier businesses, drawn by rents that their owners say can be half that of North Slope properties, are moving in, following the influx of higher-income tenants to apartments south of Ninth Street.
While real-estate brokers in the neighborhood predict that a boom in the area will draw more upscale businesses with a wealthier clientele, owners of both old and new businesses say the situation right now is a gamble. For Mr. Duval and other merchants who cater to working-class customers, the danger is they will fail to adapt and be driven out of their suddenly prime locations.
For Adiz Fernandez, a 23-year-old who along with her boyfriend turned a boarded-up storefront into the stylish Computer Caffe, the danger is that she is too far ahead of the neighborhood. "I see it as a developing area," she said as a customer ordered a cappuccino. "Four new businesses have opened here."
In the last few months, a hair salon called Bohemia has opened up on Seventh Avenue and 15th Street next door to the Computer Caffe, where customers can use computers while sipping coffee. On the other side of the avenue, Sanctuary, a gay and lesbian bar, is opening, and an abandoned storefront is being turned into a French restaurant. A mountain bike store and cigar store and smoking salon have also opened nearby.
Across the street from the Computer Caffe, V & E Beverage's cash register is still encased in floor-to-ceiling bulletproof glass. After surviving the neighborhood's bad times, Enrique Torrellas, manager of the family-owned liquor store for the last seven years, fears being forced out of business. If he increases his prices, he predicted, his customers will turn to discount liquor stores. "We'll see what happens next year," Mr. Torrellas said. "Maybe we'll leave."
Lori Falco, the 35-year-old owner of See-Gar, a cigar store, smoking salon and gift shop that opened last month, fears the same rising rents, but hopes gentrification is not inevitable. She said she opened the store on Seventh Avenue near 13th Street because it was a growing area, but also because of Park Slope's diversity, which she said she would hate to see disappear. Her cigars range from 80 cents to $13 each.
"I have a 70-year-old man who comes in here and loves his 89-cent cigars," she said. "It's just nice when you go from an old man like that to a dad with a kid to a doctor to a construction worker to a woman who wants to try cigars." DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
For Government Workers, Safer Roads to Retirement

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
FOR years, many government workers have put their money into tax-deferred retirement plans that were less secure and more limited than the plans of many private-sector workers.
But an obscure provision of the new Federal minimum wage law has erased many of the drawbacks of these accounts, which are called 457 plans and are offered to 8.3 million employees in 10,000 state and local governments. (Federal workers have their own version of these plans.) 
 The most important change in the statute, which was signed by President Clinton in August, requires employers to put employees' money into a custodial account, a trust or an annuity contract, where the funds cannot be reached by anyone but the participant. Before this change, 457 funds were the property of the governmental body that created the plan. As such, they were subject to creditors if the entity ran into trouble.
"This change is going to increase participation and confidence in the plans," said Joseph G. Metz of Buck Consultants in New York, which specializes in employee benefits. "We will have more public employees saving because they won't be so fearful."
Taking the money away from the employer has long been the rule for 401(k) plans and 403(b) plans; the latter cover workers at public schools, universities and other nonprofit organizations. The difference in rules may help explain why participation rates in those plans are higher than in 457 programs. About 78 percent of the employees eligible for 401(k)'s contribute to them, according to Access Research of Windsor, Conn., but only 20 percent, or 1.7 million, of those eligible for 457 plans are enrolled.
No money in 457 plans has ever been lost because of a government insolvency, but the recent bankruptcies of Orange County, Calif., and of several small water districts elsewhere in the country showed the plans' vulnerability. Money in the Orange County 457 plans would have been used to pay off creditors were it not for a special arrangement worked out by county officials, lawyers, investment bankers and others.
"The counties, cities and states are pretty solidly heeled, but then came Orange County, and a light bulb went on," said Arthur N. Caple, president of the National Association of Government Deferred Compensation Administrators. "People got concerned."
The law requires existing plans to end employer ownership by Jan. 1, 1999. New plans must incorporate the change when they start enrollment.
To account for inflation, the law also permits increases in the maximum annual contributions to 457 plans. Ever since the plans were approved by Congress in 1979, the limit has been 33 percent of salary or $7,500, whichever is less. In contrast, 401(k)'s, which are indexed for inflation, had a maximum contribution this year of 25 percent percent of salary or $9,500, whichever is less.
Like all the 457 provisions except for employer ownership, this one takes effect on Jan. 1.
Under the new law, employees can also borrow money from their plans. Previously, they could only take money out of a 457 account for a medical emergency or other financial disaster. The new provisions, which generally allow people to borrow half their account balances, up to a maximum of $50,000, mirror the loan options that 401(k)'s have long had.
Also, workers will no longer have just 60 days after leaving their jobs to commit to a date for the first payout from their plans. Many public employees, like police officers, leave their posts at relatively young ages after 20 years; picking a starting date for payouts in such cases can be difficult.
The new law still directs participants to choose a beginning payout date upon leaving employment. But it allows them to change their minds once, as long as the new date is later than the first one.
"A lot of people don't think about this until they leave, and then they find that the law is very cumbersome," said Georgette Gesterly, director of pretax benefits for New York City, which has 75,000 members in its 457 plan. "So, a change like this is helpful."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
The High Cost of Muni Bond Peace of Mind

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
SMALL investors and their big fear of losses are fueling the insured muni bond fund business.
Comfortable with the tax-exempt status and the diversification provided by the national municipal bond funds, but jittery that the next Orange County will pop up in their portfolios, customers increasingly want the guarantee of good credit that insurance confers. As a result, the volume of insured municipal issues coming to market has nearly doubled, from 25 percent in 1990 to 46 percent this year, said David Litvack, a senior director of Fitch Investors Service. 
 Never mind that even in the 1994 bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., insurers didn't pay out a dime.
In fact, "the actual losses by all bond insurance companies over the last five years have been $130 million, and that's on bonds with a par value of $507.2 billion," Mr. Litvack said. "So we're talking about a percentage default rate on the order of 0.026 percent."
That makes insurance on a municipal bond look very much like suspenders on a well-belted investment. Even in Orange County, reserves were adequate to cover interest payments until the county itself resumed paying them. Susan Keenan, manager of the municipal bond department of Alliance Capital Management L.P., is blunt in her opinion that insurance isn't really needed.
"Frankly, insurance is a marketing gimmick," she said, adding that insurers "write policies to a zero-loss standard, meaning any security they're willing to insure is one they're convinced is not going to default."
 Still, the demand is there.
MUNICIPALITIES like insurance because it can cut their borrowing costs. Insurance replaces New York City's A- credit rating, for example, with the insurer's triple-A.
But equally if not more important, small investors are transforming the marketplace through their purchases of mutual fund shares.
"Mutual fund investors are different than the traditional customers for municipals," said Neil Budnick, director of public finance for the MBIA Insurance Company of Armonk, N.Y., the muni industry's largest underwriter. "They tend to be people who have less money. They care about credit quality more because they can afford to lose less."
The surge in insurance parallels the growth in municipal bond mutual funds. In 1980, muni funds accounted for only 1.1 percent of municipal bond ownership, according to the Federal Reserve Board. By 1990, that was up to 9.5 percent, and in 1991, funds shouldered aside insurance companies as the municipal market's No. 2 player, behind individuals. Currently, funds account for 16.2 percent of the $1.3 trillion municipal bond market, trailing only households, which own 35.5 percent of tax-exempt bonds.
The appetite for insurance on these bonds can be expected to grow, said Joe Mysak, the editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer. He said the insured-bond business would get a lift in coming years as defaults rise among issues that came out in the late 1980's and earlier in this decade to finance economic-development projects like stadiums, convention hotels and even civic aquariums.
"There are just rafts of this kind of thing out there, and a lot of them are going to blow up," he said. "These are not insured bonds, and that's why insurance will probably become even more popular, as these things default."
Owners of insured municipal bond funds do, however, pay two -- and possibly three -- prices for the elimination of credit risk. Their first cost is lower yields, currently about 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, less than the yields on funds that own uninsured bonds of comparable quality.
They also pay through increased volatility. "An insured municipal bond is definitely more volatile than a comparable bond that isn't insured," said Mark Wright, an analyst for Morningstar Inc.
This is so because, with the credit risk removed, the bonds tend to respond more rapidly to interest rate swings, in the same way as the safest government investments, United States Treasuries. Investors thus face a drop in the value of their insured holdings when interest rates rise. Uninsured bonds react more to concerns about the ability of the issuer to pay on the bonds.
Indeed, many investors could get higher after-tax returns with even greater safety in the Treasury market. The spreads between taxable and tax-free bonds are so narrow at the moment that in many cases, small investors would be better off owning Treasuries.
"Right now, in the one- to five-year maturity range, U.S. Government bonds are more attractive on an after-tax basis for people in the 28 percent and 31 percent tax brackets," said James F. Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a monthly newsletter.
The triple-A muni bond yield last Monday, for instance, was 4.2 percent for a three-year bond, which is equal to 5.83 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.09 percent for those taxed at 31 percent. The comparable Treasury note is yielding 5.91 percent. Even for the taxpayer paying 31 percent, Mr. Lynch said, "you'd probably go with the Government bond if you were conservative."
To Mr. Wright of Morningstar, there is little gain from having the insurance.
"I don't think that under normal circumstances most investors need bond insurance," he said. "Given the current market environment, however, I can see why insured bonds would appear to be very attractive."
THAT environment reflects civic difficulties like those in Orange County and the recent downgradings of the bonds of Miami and Pittsburgh, as well as the fact that, as underwriters have talked small investors into believing that insurance matters, it has come to matter. The avalanche of insured bonds has created "a glut of high-quality paper," said Cadmus Hicks, the manager of credit research for John Nuveen & Company of Chicago, a leading manager of municipal debt.
Insured bonds are so abundant that they yield, on average, only 10 basis points or so less than lower-quality bonds, about half the spread of five years ago. "What that tells an investor is you can have insurance for very little additional price," Mr. Hicks said.
Sophisticated investors typically spurn muni bond insurance. Institutions rely on their own credit research, and well-heeled individuals are urged by their advisers to seek the higher yields of uninsured bonds. "We have always advocated buying noninsured municipal bonds," Mr. Lynch said.
It is the mutual funds that have fueled the demand for insurance. "This is for mom and pop, who don't know too much about what they're buying," said Steve Bauer, manager of the Safeco Insured Municipal Bond fund. "It's a lot easier for a broker to make a sale when he can say this thing is guaranteed."
But among broker-sold funds, the uninsured type continues to be favored. Nuveen's Municipal Bond fund, now yielding 4.65 percent, has assets of $2.8 billion, dwarfing the Nuveen Insured Municipal Bond fund, which has $820 million and yields 4.54 percent. At Alliance, the National Portfolio of the Alliance Municipal Income fund has $650 million in assets, more than twice the $310 million of the Insured National Portfolio.
Among direct-marketed funds, however, the reverse is often true. The Vanguard Group's Municipal Insured Long-Term Portfolio has assets of $2 billion, or nearly twice the $1.1 billion of the noninsured fund, Municipal Long-Term Portfolio. "We don't think it's idiotic to offer insured-type securities," said Ian MacKinnon, head of Vanguard's fixed-income group.
"Insurance provides you with a triple-A rating, but the marketplace doesn't price them that way," Mr. MacKinnon said. "It prices them at a double-A yield, so in a sense you're getting the insurance for free." The market ranks insured bonds below other triple-A credits mostly because of their overabundance.
Because of their strict underwriting standards and the intense competition among the largest bond insurers, the fees being charged are extremely low. Mr. Litvack of Fitch said a typical premium on $10,000 worth of insurance -- the $5,000 face value of a bond plus a like amount in interest over its life -- was $30.
That fee is implicitly paid by the issuing state or locality, but it is quickly recaptured when the higher rating achieved through insurance produces a lower coupon. New York City, among the biggest issuers of insured bonds, currently pays interest of 5.6 percent on insured long-term debt. An A- rating would require it to pay more than 5.7 percent for uninsured bonds. About half the savings are used to pay for the insurance, with the other half accruing to the city and its taxpayers.
Localities with stronger credit ratings don't need insurance and are deaf to the funds' demands. Wisconsin is rated double-A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's, and double-A+ by Fitch, and its bonds trade "as almost cheap triple-A's," said Larry Dallia, the state's assistant capital finance director.
When his office recently issued $30 million of general obligation bonds, it instructed underwriters not to insure the issue.
'OUR bonds don't trade a dime more expensively because they've got insurance," Mr. Dallia said. "They would probably trade at the same price. So why should we shell out the premium and get no economic benefit for it?"
Many observers think that insured bonds can be important in state-only muni funds, where geographic risk cannot be diversified away. All of Vanguard's long-term state-only funds are insured, for example. But in national portfolios, shareholders seldom receive any reward for their caution.
And then there are those downsides, the lower yields and the volatility that can be costly whenever rates rise.
"Insureds trade off more in a down market," said Ms. Keenan of Alliance. They make it up when rates decline, but in the meantime shareholders who bought such funds for peace of mind will find themselves missing out on that, too.

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Tickets on Sale! But Is the Show a Dud?

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
THE Ticketmaster Group is about to make an offer that the company hopes will become one of the hottest tickets in town -- shares of its own stock. But unlike a World Series game or a Hootie and the Blowfish concert, this show may not be worth waiting in line for.
That thought may surprise many investors. After all, Ticketmaster, based in Los Angeles, is the nation's largest seller of automated ticketing services, with as much as 85 percent of the market, by some estimates. Among its more than 3,500 clients are 73 professional sports teams, including the Chicago Bulls and the Atlanta Falcons, as well as theaters, stadiums and arenas, like Madison Square Garden in New York. 
 The company sold 53 million tickets in its fiscal year ended Jan. 31 and 30 million in the first half of the current year. And with every ticket sold, Ticketmaster receives a "convenience charge" of $1.50 to $7.
What's more, the company is planning to broaden its business to museums, zoos, amusement parks, state and county fairs, golf courses, ski resorts and trade shows. It also hopes to expand to Australia, Canada and Latin America.
Just last week, Ticketmaster introduced an on-line service that lets Broadway theatergoers check lists of shows and seating locations and to buy tickets on the Internet.
Given such a record, investors might understandably jump at the chance to buy some of the 7.25 million shares -- 32 percent of the company -- that Ticketmaster expects to put on the block tomorrow in its initial public offering. The estimated price is $13 to $15 a share.
Nevertheless, this deal may flop. For one, Ticketmaster has huge debts, largely a result of acquisitions in its expansion effort. After the offering, the company will be $138 million in the hole, a sum equal to about 90 percent of its total capitalization. A range of 25 percent to 50 percent is more typical, said Ryan Jacob, director of research at IPO Value Monitor. And while Mr. Jacob said he was more tolerant of higher debt levels at companies with particularly stable cash flows, like Ticketmaster, several analysts said the heavy debt was still a red flag.
IN fact, in the offering papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company acknowledged that debt could be a danger. "There can be no assurance," it said, "that the company's operating cash flow will be sufficient to cover its debt service obligations." The company said the "high degree of leverage may make it more vulnerable to economic downturns."
Although Ticketmaster has had a stable cash flow, the company's performance has faltered recently. In the six months ended July 31, the company lost $2.4 million, or 16 cents a share. And in the last fiscal year, the company had a loss of $8.1 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with a loss of $6.7 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier.
These troubles are largely due to the huge interest payments on debt. But, while revenues have picked up in the last few months, they too have been a problem for Ticketmaster. In the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, sales fell to $161 million, from $183 million the previous year. The company attributed the declines to the effects of the Major League Baseball strike and the National Hockey League lockout, as well as fewer concerts by popular musicians in 1995.
Investors also might be put off by the fact that two-thirds of the $92 million the company hopes to raise from the offering will be used to pay down current and future debt. That means that few dollars will be available to improve cash flow, noted Robert Mescal, an analyst with New Issues, a newsletter of the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield Beach, Fla.
Of course, the shares may well command an initial premium because of Ticketmaster's well-known name. But Mr. Jacob and several other analysts are less optimistic about its long-term prospects.
"I'm not standing in line for this one," said David Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network, which projects opening premiums on initial public offerings. "Companies with worldwide and nationally recognized names have essentially garnered much of the attention in the marketplace. But I don't think we have the same type of operation here because of the losses they have been sustaining."
Mr. Mescal said Ticketmaster's financial performance was particularly troubling given its domination of the market. "Their losses are increasing in each fiscal period, yet their claim is that they are the leading factor in the sale of tickets," he said. "If they control ticket sales in the major urban areas in most U.S. cities, why can't they make a buck?"
There are other entertainment-ticketing operations, like Moviefone, but none are large enough to compare to Ticketmaster. In some ways, however, the company is similar to Sabre Group, American Airlines' hugely successful reservations service that went public last month. Like Ticketmaster, Sabre charges fees to book tickets, and it is also the far-and-away leader in its market.
Unlike Ticketmaster, though, Sabre has positive earnings -- and they rose 15 percent last year. At a Friday close of $27.375, Wall Street values Sabre stock at a multiple of 19 times estimated earnings.
But with Ticketmaster's losses and debts, many analysts are balking at the estimated share price of the offering. "On a cash-flow basis, we do feel it is being priced a bit rich," Mr. Jacob said.
What is the hard lesson for Ticketmaster? It must take its cue from the actors and athletes whose tickets it sells: Perform well, and the crowds will follow.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Old Jockeys, New Horses

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Give them an inch and they will, of course, want a mile.
Now that mutual fund managers can use prospectuses to promote their previous track records when they join other companies or set up their own shops, there is a push to permit adding those records to their advertising, too. 
 In mid-August, the Securities and Exchange Commission permitted Elizabeth R. Bramwell, former manager of the Gabelli Growth fund, to continue to use her Gabelli record in the prospectus for her Bramwell Growth fund, which she started when she struck out on her own in 1994. In effect, the S.E.C. was dropping the one-year limit it previously placed on any mention of past performance in a prospectus.
The National Association of Securities Dealers then weighed in to make sure its members understood that past-performance data could appear only in a fund's prospectus and not in ads. The N.A.S.D. did not issue a formal ruling because Ms. Bramwell's firm is not registered with the agency. But it made clear that portable track records were not to appear in fund advertising.
Its decision was grounded in previous policy, said R. Clark Hooper, senior vice president of the Office of Disclosure and Investor Protection of N.A.S.D. Regulation. In several instances, the agency has looked at putting past performance into supplemental sales literature but has been stymied on "how to make clear to investors what the performance means and, more important, what it doesn't mean," Ms. Hooper said.
As a result, it was relegated to the prospectus, where the accompanying disclosure put the data in context. The Investment Company Institute, the fund trade group in Washington, gave the arrangement its blessing.
The pressure, however, appears to be building as more managers switch firms and want to promote their previous records.
As of the end of October, the N.A.S.D. had received two formal submissions and several informal inquiries about the policy, although it would not identify from whom. In light of this interest, Ms. Hooper said, the agency will reconsider its policy at its next committee meeting, which has not yet been scheduled.
Likewise, the S.E.C. has been petitioned to take up the matter.
"Historically, the investment company division staff has taken the position that performance data of other accounts shouldn't be included in stand-alone mutual fund advertising," said Jack W. Murphy, associate director and chief counsel in the S.E.C.'s division of investment management. "However, in the wake of the Bramwell letter, we have been asked to reconsider the issue."
 
Dividing the Pie
New England Star Small Cap is the third fund in a series sponsored by New England Funds to be jointly managed by successful managers at several companies outside the firm. The fund will invest mainly in companies with market capitalizations below $1 billion, as well as in overseas companies and fixed-income securities. Overseas issues are limited to one-quarter of the assets.
Management responsibilities are divided among four subadvisers, each of whom will receive 25 percent of new cash; redemptions will also be allocated equally. Spreading the money among the four managers, each with a somewhat different investing style, is intended to help reduce risk in small-stock investing.
The managers are John Wallace of Robertson Stephens; Michael Carmen of Montgomery Asset Management; Steven Reid of Harris Associates, and Christopher Ely, David Smith and Phil Fine of Loomis Sayles. The fund levies a 5.75 percent sales charge.
The two New England funds that are already being jointly managed are Star Advisers and Star Worldwide.
 
New Funds
The Montgomery Emerging Asia fund is intended to capitalize on long-term economic growth predicted for China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, India and other Asian markets. It will not invest in Japan.
Pioneer First, managed by a Russian subsidiary of the Pioneer Group, in Boston, is the first mutual fund approved for Russians by the regulatory agency there under a pilot program established in November.
New Manager
Tim Keefe, former manager of Federated American Leaders and Capital Appreciation funds, has joined the John Hancock fund group. He takes over John Hancock Growth and Income from Ben Hock, who now heads equity research for the firm. Mr. Keefe will also lead the team managing John Hancock Special Value.
 
New Identities
Twentieth Century International Emerging Growth has been renamed Twentieth Century International Discovery. In developed markets, it can now own companies with market capitalizations of up to $1 billion, up from $800 million. A cap of $1 billion has been added for companies in emerging markets.
 Keystone Strategic Development was renamed Keystone Global Resources and Development and will own mostly stocks of companies involved in natural resources and energy. Keystone Fund of the Americas retains its name but will invest at least 65 percent of its assets in Latin American securities and at least 20 percent in securities issued in Canada and the United States.
 
In Brief
The Vanguard Primecap fund reopened to investors on Oct. 31 after closing to new accounts in March 1995.
The minimum investment in the Benham funds has been increased to $2,500 from $1,000.
