SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3587 words

HEADLINE: Bad Cop

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
TOWARD the end of 1993, just before Michael Walsh's world came crashing in, he took a graveyard shift job as a security guard at McDonald's. Sure, it was degrading, but the lunacy at the 30th Precinct was wearing him down, he says. As rumors of stings and informers swirled around the Harlem station house, he found it increasingly difficult to eat or sleep, and his wife started to worry. Moonlighting at McDonald's, he figured, might keep him out of trouble.
It had been a while since he had robbed a drug dealer, and to keep himself from temptation, Michael Walsh, then 32 years old and a seven-year veteran police officer, had stopped making arrests altogether. His last "job" had taken place a few months earlier at a dingy pool hall on West 140th Street, where, responding to a radio call of shots fired, he bumped into a kilo of cocaine in a storage closet. "Never again, so help me God," he remembers telling himself as he stuffed the shrink-wrapped brick in his coat pocket. But later that day, when he asked another officer, Jorge Alvarez, to sell the loot, he sensed something was wrong. 
 For months now, the buzz around the precinct had been pointing to Officer Alvarez as a possible informer. There was no doubt he had changed. No longer outgoing and chatty, he was always on edge and often drank on the job, his bloodshot eyes full of fear, say those who worked with him at the time. One Sunday morning in February 1994, just after roll call, an officer named Stephen Morrissey taunted Officer Alvarez with accusations he was wired. Officer Alvarez took out his revolver and in the scuffle that followed, Officer Morrissey was shot in the foot, prosecutors say. Although the incident was covered up by precinct commanders, the officer's breakdown confirmed Officer Walsh's fear that his friend and frequent partner in crime was working for the other side.
"At that moment, I knew my ship was sunk," Mr. Walsh recalls.
Almost two months after the Morrissey shooting, on the evening of April 15, 1994, Officer Walsh, as usual, was too restless to sleep. Maybe he'd seen too many bad cop movies, but he couldn't shake the sorry image of himself being led away in handcuffs. He cursed himself, his greed and the times he had lied to juries. "And for what?" he thought over and over again. "So I could blow wads of cash at the race track?"
When he turned on the 11 o'clock news, he felt his gut tighten. The top story was about an impending crackdown of rogue officers at an unidentified upper Manhattan precinct. He grabbed the phone and paged Blake Struller, a former partner who was on duty. When the phone rang five minutes later, it wasn't Officer Struller but a strange voice asking for Mikey. No one ever called Michael Walsh "Mikey." Then the line went dead. A moment later, the doorbell rang. He threw on jeans, and woke up his wife.
"Becky," he recalls saying to her, "I think I'm in trouble."
Indeed, Michael Walsh was in more trouble than he had ever imagined. As one of 33 officers arrested in the scandal at the 30th Precinct, Officer Walsh became known as one of the Dirty 30, a uniformed thug who robbed drug dealers, dealt cocaine and lied about his arrests.
"Officers like Mike Walsh broke the very laws they were sworn to uphold," said Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, whose office prosecuted most of the officers. "The damage he did to public trust of the police cannot be overstated."
To fellow policemen, Officer Walsh also violated a cardinal rule. He ratted on his buddies, shattering the so-called Blue Wall of Silence. The decision to tell all, to testify against former friends, may have reduced his sentence -- from as much as 15 years to 3 -- but it has left him a haunted man. Most of his friends from the precinct have abandoned him, and his wife recently moved back in with her parents. He says he is $60,000 in debt.
In September 1994, Steven Laski, a former partner and one of his closest friends, put a gun under his chin and killed himself shortly after his own arrest. When Officer Walsh showed up at Officer Laski's funeral and encountered the accusing glares from former colleagues, he got back in his car and went home.
"Everyone tried to put the blame on me, but if I hadn't made a deal, someone else would have," he said last week, sitting in the kitchen of the house in Woodside, Queens where he grew up. "I did what I had to do."
The scandal at the 30th Precinct may have been the darkest moment in Police Department history. One-third of the patrol force was caught in its web, a grim testament to the transforming power of drugs and the havoc it has wreaked in New York's most desperate neighborhoods.
"These were guys making $30,000 a year being confronted with car trunks full of hundreds of thousands of dollars," said Daniel Castleman, chief of investigations for the Manhattan District Attorney. "The temptation should not be minimized."
A common thread among those arrested was their low level of education: none held a college degree, and most had been cashiers or store clerks or were unemployed before they entered the Police Academy.
"The bottom line is that the majority of these guys were losers," said Gerald W. Lynch, president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice.
 
Saying Farewell In Working-Class Queens
 Last month, after Michael Walsh was finally sentenced, a bunch of friends decided to throw him a "going away" party. About 30 of them showed up at Joey's Place, a restaurant on Astoria Boulevard in Elmhurst. There were childhood buddies and a handful of police officers who stood by him through tough times. They ate family-style at a long table, quietly downing plates of roast beef and trying to avoid any talk of what lay ahead for Mr. Walsh. It was an awkward gathering, and the guest of honor was clearly unnerved by all the attention.
"This feels like a cross between an Irish wake and a Sweet 16 party," one friend joked to another.
The last two years have taken a visible toll on Mr. Walsh. Once built like a linebacker, he has gained 30 pounds since his arrest and lost his easy smile. No longer the hard-drinking hell-raiser who would stay out until last call, Mr. Walsh has pulled back into a shell of sadness and shame, his friends say. Because he dreads running into other officers, he usually stays home when he is not driving a cab, his only source of income since being thrown off the force.
"It's not always easy to get Mike to go out," said his friend Keith Pope. "He wears this mask of remorse wherever he goes."
Once, while Mr. Walsh was at a Rangers game, he was recognized by a knot of officers who started calling him a rat. Mortified, he fled the game, telling his companions he felt ill.
On another occasion, he drove to Saratoga Springs, with his cousin. He assumed no one would recognize him there. But while at the race track, he spotted an officer from Internal Affairs who had arrested him. Within minutes, Officer Walsh was in his car racing back to Queens.
With thick arms and an intimidating swagger, Michael Walsh is easy to imagine dressed in blue, twirling a nightstick. He speaks the tough talk of working-class Queens, and while every other sentence is peppered with an expletive, his manner is never gruff, rude or boastful.
"When you first meet Mike, he's surprisingly shy," said Mr. Pope, a taxi dispatcher who gave Mr. Walsh a job driving for the Woodside Garage. "It takes a while before he feels comfortable with people." To his friends and family, Mr. Walsh's slide into crime was more about recklessness than guile.
His mother, Catherine, said: "Mike has always tried to be one of the boys, to not rock the boat. In my view, it was peer pressure and his naivete that got him in trouble."
Michael Walsh never planned on being a cop. Growing up on 65th Street just off Queens Boulevard, he was surrounded by police officers -- uncles, neighbors and family friends who would drop by the three-story Walsh home, hanging their holsters on the downstairs coat rack. But he never dreamed of being one of them; if anything, he looked down on the profession. As a teen-ager, he cursed the local beat officers who would break up the beer parties he and his friends held in a nearby park.
"I can't tell you how many times the cops would tell us to go home, but not before they put our cases of beer in their trunk," he recalled.
He lived across the street from his Irish-born grandparents and rarely strayed far from the tree-lined block of modest, vinyl-sided homes. In those days, everything you wanted was in Woodside, a close-knit, blue-collar place filled with Germans, Italians and plenty of Irish. These days, Mr. Walsh's neighbors are strangers who speak languages he can't understand. "I used to know everyone on the block," he said recently, sitting in front of the large-screen television that dominates his living room. "Now I can count the old-timers on one hand."
Michael Walsh was the third of four children born to Catherine O'Neil, a legal secretary, and Thomas Walsh, who ran a tavern on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. When Michael was 7 and his parents separated, his father moved just two blocks away. Mike was no A student at Power Memorial Academy a Catholic school on the West Side, and playing ball always took precedence over homework, he says. As an adolescent, he sometimes got into trouble with the priests who ran the school.
"Like most of us, Mike could be mischievous, stealing gum from the candy store or jumping turnstiles," recalled a longtime friend, Ed Wiley. "But Mike was basically a good kid."
After graduating from high school in 1979, Mr. Walsh moved to Bedford, Tex., where his mother had relocated several years earlier. After two semesters at a community college, Mr. Walsh dropped out and began working as a hotel banquet manager. Former hotel employees remember him as hard-working, solicitous and honest during his six years there. Michael Walsh, they say, was someone you could trust.
But Mr. Walsh grew tired of the hospitality business and never felt entirely comfortable in Texas. In 1984, encouraged by a New York City detective staying at the hotel, he applied to the Police Department back home, and after a year he received word that he had been accepted.
Six months later, he found himself in the 30th Precinct, which at one square mile, is one of the city's smallest but busiest precincts. By then, the emergence of crack was turning the picturesque blocks around City College into one of the city's most dangerous neighborhoods. In the mid-80's, the precinct's homicide rate began to soar and the nightly pop of gunfire became more common than the blare of car horns.
To a wide-eyed rookie, it was a great time to be a cop, and Officer Walsh embraced his job with zeal, former colleagues say. "There was always action and lots of arrests to be made," Mr. Walsh said. "I wasn't the kind of guy who wanted to stand on a street corner watching the traffic go by." In his first few years on the job, Mr. Walsh took part in more than 100 arrests and received eight citations for outstanding police work.
It was not long after his assignment that Mr. Walsh realized something in the 30th Precinct wasn't right. On the street, tensions between the police and local residents were high and it wasn't uncommon to be called "ladro," meaning thief, by the young men hanging around the pay phones that sprouted like weeds on the avenues. One summer day in 1987, during a raid on a drug-infested row on Edgecombe Avenue, Mr. Walsh says he overheard some veteran officers shout "Payday!" when they found a black gym bag full of cash and drugs. When they realized he was within earshot, they playfully thrust the bag his way and said, "Want some?"
That night, as evidence from the raid was laid out in the muster room, Mr. Walsh noticed the bag's absence. "I was shocked," he said, "but when I mentioned it to some other cops, they just brushed me off."
It didn't take long, however, to cross the line between law enforcer and lawbreaker. According to Mr. Walsh's account, it began with a gift from a colleague, a brown paper bag filled with cash. On a blustery December evening in 1987, Mr. Walsh and his partner responded to a radio call of shots fired, a routine occurrence in Harlem. They arrived at 736 Riverside Drive to find a 21-year-old man in his underwear, splashed with blood, a bullet hole in his thigh. As medics tended to the wounded man, Mr. Walsh made a cursory search of the apartment and found a red suitcase stuffed with money. But before he could turn over the bag to a nearby sergeant, another officer, Fred Novoua, snatched it.
"Don't worry, I'll take care of this," he told Officer Walsh.
A few hours later, while Officer Walsh was changing in the station house locker room, Officer Novoua passed him the bag with $1,500, explaining, "This is your share." Before he could utter a response, Officer Novoua was gone. In retrospect, Mr. Walsh understands his comrade's generosity. It was a test to see if the rookie patrolman could be trusted within the precinct's cabal of wayward officers.
Officer Walsh passed the test.
At first, he contemplated returning the bag, but his desire to fit in, he says, convinced him he was better off doing nothing. "For weeks afterwards I was terrified of getting caught, but the idea of being a rat was even more terrifying," he said. "I guess it was the easy way out."
It wasn't until a year later that he started stealing on his own, he says. Usually he would just grab a fistful of dollars when the opportunity came his way. Once, while responding to a domestic dispute call in an apartment on 153d Street, he spotted a shoe tree in a closet stuffed with hundred-dollar bills. While his partner interviewed the tenants in another room, Mr. Walsh filled his pockets with cash. As time went on, Mr. Walsh says, he got greedier and began searching out known drug spots to rob.
"Everyone seemed like they were doing the same thing, so I thought, well, if they're enriching themselves, why shouldn't I?" he said. "I figured it's only drug money. Who's going to miss it anyhow?"
Beginning in 1989, when he was moved from day tours to the midnight detail, Mr. Walsh found himself among the precinct's most voracious thieves, including Officer Alvarez, who investigators say did little more on his shifts than steal. Officer Alvarez introduced him to the idea that stealing drugs was no different than taking money. An uncle of Officer Alvarez who lived in the neighborhood would sell the goods, and after taking a cut for himself, Officer Alvarez would turn the money over to Officer Walsh.
"I always swore to myself I'd never touch narcotics," he said. "But then somehow I convinced myself that I wasn't really dealing, because Alvarez was doing the dirty work."
Around the same time, he committed the first in a series of perjuries, falsely testifying about arrests he made, often to cover up his thefts. The perjuries were part of the cat-and-mouse games between marauding officers and the dealers, who by the late 1980's, had learned not to leave valuables around and had devised elaborate ways to hide their stashes. Frustrated by the dealers' increasing wiliness, the police began to frisk jittery-looking men on the sidewalk looking for what became known as "felony keys." Because most of the neighborhood's poor residents had inexpensive locks on their doors, anyone carrying high-quality keys was assumed to be a dealer and fair game.
Felony keys often yielded handsome rewards, but in time the dealers outsmarted the police again, installing dead bolts that could be opened only by remote control. That didn't stop the more brazen officers from crashing through apartment doors with sledgehammers, a practice known as "booming." Sometimes Officer Walsh would arrive at a notorious drug location to find a dozen doors smashed in, usually a sign that Nannery's Raiders, a group of eight young officers supervised by Sgt. Kevin P. Nannery, had already passed through.
On one cold February night in 1991, Mr. Walsh and his partner at the time, Blake Struller, broke into an apartment on 140th Street and found a bag with $115,000. It was believed to be the largest single heist ever made in the precinct. Even Mr. Walsh was intimidated by the take. For a week, he was afraid to remove his share ($57,000) from the trunk of his Chevy Blazer.
He says he stole 34 times. Unlike other officers who used the proceeds of their plunder to buy flashy cars or expensive clothing, Officer Walsh spent most of his money, a sum he says totaled $120,000, on alcohol, gambling and loans to friends. After finishing a midnight tour, Officer Walsh would either join a group of officers who drank until dawn at the Blarney Stone in Washington Heights or go alone to Belmont Race Track.
"Sometimes I'd lose $3,000 in one day," he recalled. "Money just didn't mean anything to me."
Family and friends outside the force say they never had any idea Officer Walsh was on the take. "Mike was incredibly generous, but I never thought anything of it," said his mother, who remembers his spending an easy $500 on each of his four nieces and nephews at Christmas.
By the early 1990's, the precinct had descended into a frenzied state of wanton thievery. At one point, Mr. Walsh recalls, someone was stealing weights from the station house gym. Twice, the cable boxes in the television lounge disappeared. Even rolls of toilet paper began vanishing from a storage closet. In 1993, the Mollen Commission began hearings on police corruption with a star witness known as Officer Otto. Testifying in disguise, the officer described an unnamed renegade precinct in which officers ran roughshod over the law, shaking down dealers and pocketing large sums of cash.
Mr. Walsh remembers the nervous banter in the precinct lounge as a group of officers watched the hearings on television. "Everyone was making wisecracks, saying, 'I bet you're Officer Otto,' but deep inside, I think we were all a little worried about what might be coming down."
Officer Otto, in fact, was Barry Brown, a 30th Precinct officer. That fall, as the paranoia peaked, officers began patting one another down for wires. Rumor had it that one or more officers had already been arrested and returned to the precinct wearing bugs. The rumors, it turned out, were true. By late 1993, around the time Officer Walsh began working at McDonald's, three officers, including Officer Alvarez, were gathering evidence against him.
 
'We Got You, Mike, And We Got You Good'
On the night of his arrest, the night the doorbell rang, investigators from Internal Affairs drove him across the Brooklyn Bridge. Michael Walsh remembers thinking there might still be a way out. But when he got to 26 Federal Plaza, he knew the game was over. Plainly visible on a reception desk sign-in sheet were the names of a half-dozen officers with whom he had committed the bulk of his crimes. Later, as Officer Walsh sat under the glare of fluorescent lights, an investigator delivered the punch line he was afraid to hear: they had him on tape.
"We got you, Mike, and we got you good," the officer said. "Think of your family."
Within an hour, Officer Walsh had agreed to cooperate. He didn't cry, beg for leniency or try to explain, prosecutors say. He never even requested a lawyer. William Burmeister, chief of the corruption unit for the Manhattan District Attorney, who was with the officer after his arrest, described him as stoic.
"But beneath the blank expression, you could still see his agony," Mr. Burmeister said. "He had hit rock bottom."
By the time he was released on $250,000 bond the next night, television cameras were already waiting outside his home. Over the next month, he went outside only to see his lawyer or to speak with prosecutors. One frustrated reporter warned his wife that if he didn't come to the door to talk, his newspaper would "rip him to shreds."
During the worst moments of his arrest, his testimony and his betrayal of fellow officers, Mr. Walsh says, he often contemplated suicide.
"Every time it entered my mind, I just thought of Laski and what his death did to everyone around him," he said. "I decided to stick it out."
 
3 Photos, 3 Addresses And an End to Freedom
On Friday, Michael Walsh went to prison. He had a hard time filling his last days of freedom. He made long-needed repairs to his house, got a haircut and said goodbye to a few friends. But mostly he sat in front of the television and paced around his living room like a caged animal.
"I'm trying to think of this as a three-year vacation," he joked on Thursday, the eve of his surrender to Federal marshals.
Although he had asked to be sent to a prison near his mother's home in East Texas, he was dismayed to learn last week that his time would be spent at a minimum-security jail 14 hours away. Counting time off for good behavior, Mr. Walsh will have to serve at least two and a half years.
On his last night, after he had lemon chicken for dinner with his Aunt Lucy at a Queens restaurant, he went out drinking. There was not much else to do: besides the clothes on his back, he was told he could bring only three photographs and three written addresses. At one point that night he sat at his kitchen table, running his fingers through his hair. He did not have much to say.
"Listen," he said, smiling weakly, "you play in life, you pay in life."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2576 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Germany's Phone Giant Is Bracing for Invaders

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
IT is a telephone company that managed to overcharge 11 million customers last New Year's Day, thanks to a computer glitch. Its prices are among the highest in the world, with long-distance charges more than double those in the United States. It has 207,000 employees, about 37,000 more than it wants, and a hobbling burden of debt. Now, its Government-sanctioned monopoly is about to end, and potential rivals ranging from the German national railway to the electric companies are circling hungrily for a piece of its market.
Would you buy shares in this company? 
 Next week, you'll have the chance. Deutsche Telekom A.G., Germany's state-owned telephone company, is going public in one of the largest stock offerings ever. Investors from America to Asia will get a piece of the action, and shares will trade on the New York, Tokyo and Frankfurt exchanges. Thanks to a saturation advertising campaign and a last-minute decision to offer a rich dividend, the shares are expected to be wildly oversubscribed here in Germany.
The offering of just 20 percent of Deutsche Telekom (the Government will retain the rest and still run the show) should raise about $10 billion, making it the second-largest initial public stock offering in Europe's history, after British Petroleum's $12.4 billion transaction in 1987. That would value the company at $50 billion, not far from the AT&T Corporation's current market capitalization of $56 billion. And that won't be the end of it. If this offering goes well, the German Government is planning to sell another $10 billion worth of Telekom stock two years from now.
So much for the numbers. For long-term investors, the overriding question is how Deutsche Telekom can adapt to a more competitive environment. In Germany and throughout most of Europe, telephone customers are begging if not screaming for alternatives to the state monopolies. And they will soon get them: All 15 members of the European Union have agreed to throw their telephone markets open to full competition on Jan. 1, 1998. The economic confederation's new policy, which will be enforced by antitrust authorities at the European Commission in Brussels, will abolish monopolies in both local and long-distance service in one swoop.
In Germany, Europe's biggest and richest economy, at least three multibillion-dollar consortiums have already been formed to attack Deutsche Telekom head-to-head. One is being led by Deutsche Bahn, Germany's national railway, and Mannesmann A.G., an industrial conglomerate, with AT&T as a junior partner. A second is being orchestrated by Germany's biggest electric utility, RWE A.G., in alliance with Veba A.G., a diversified conglomerate and Germany's fourth-largest company, and with Cable and Wireless of Britain. Yet another challenger is British Telecommunications P.L.C., which teamed up with Viag A.G., another electric utility that controls the electric market in southern Germany.
At stake is more than just Germany's $50 billion telephone market, big as that is. With Europe dissolving its protective telecommunications boundaries, any company with global ambitions must fight for the upper hand in Europe. Already, Deutsche Telekom may be dangerously behind.
British Telecom, which has been cutting costs and streamlining operations since it was privatized in 1984, is pumping billions of dollars into partnerships in almost every country of the European Union. And when the company announced a $22 billion merger this month with MCI Communications, the No. 2 long-distance carrier in the United States, after AT&T, its global reach suddenly looked even more formidable.
With British Telecom nipping at its heels, Deutsche Telekom must do more than just sell stock. It must reinvent itself, and quickly, to ward off a horde of competitors at home and position itself for a global power struggle that is heating up almost by the day. It is certainly fighting ferociously to protect its turf. If it can hold the line, analysts say, it might yet become a global force like AT&T and Nippon Telephone and Telegraph and justify the price that its underwriters are asking of 25 to 30 Deutsche marks ($16.53 to $19.83) a share.
Even so, for American investors, the European field of battle looks almost chaotic. The market remains fragmented and overregulated. Governments are torn between their sworn goal of promoting competition and their responsibility as owners to promote the monopolies they are trying to undo. Industry alliances shift so quickly that it is hard to predict which ones will endure and which will collapse tomorrow.
ONE of the oddest aspects of European deregulation is the specter, in country after country, of one government monopoly battling another still-existing or former government monopoly: Just as mostly Government monopolies are going after Deutsche Telekom in Germany, the top challenger to France Telecom is Compagnie Generale des Eaux, the French national water company; in Spain, the Government is expected to grant a license to the country's biggest television-transmission station to go head to head with Telefonica de Espana.
British Telecom's recent experience in Germany reflects the turbulence of the competitive scramble. This year, it announced a $2.7 billion deal to link up with both RWE and Viag to lay fiber-optic cables along the utilities' far-flung rights-of-way. The partnership would have all but guaranteed the British company a huge chunk of the German phone business.
But RWE defected, agreeing to pay $1.66 billion for a 22 percent stake in the alliance between Veba and Cable and Wireless. The ground may be shifting again. Given the huge price tag for MCI, some analysts wonder whether British Telecom has decided to reorder its priorities and pull back from Germany. Other analysts say it may attempt to exploit its MCI connection to attract other partners in the German market.
Deutsche Telekom is pulling out all the stops to overcome the legacy of its bureaucratic past. Two years ago, it recruited Ron Sommer, president of Sony Europe, as its new chairman. Mr. Sommer, who is 47 and holds a Ph.D. in mathematics, declined to be interviewed for this article, citing American restrictions on commenting about public offerings. But in Germany he has been a Technicolor whirlwind, giving countless interviews to talk up the stock and masterminding a dazzling advertising campaign that he boasts has created "stock fever" among Germany's citizens, who are ordinarily conservative investors.
Mr. Sommer, of course, faces enormous challenges, not the least of which is slashing nearly 40,000 people from Deutsche Telekom's payroll, to 170,000 by the year 2000. Because he is forbidden by the company's contract with the union to lay off workers, he will have to meet that goal through attrition or early-retirement incentives, which have already cost $2.25 billion since 1994.
For all its problems, though, Deutsche Telekom holds almost insurmountable advantages over its potential competitors. In 1995, it had revenue of $43.6 billion and net profit of $3.48 billion. With that kind of financial power, it would have to do a lot wrong to leave itself vulnerable in 1998.
Instead, it has been working hard to drum up business. It has all but completed an entirely new phone system for the former East Germany and a second huge project to modernize its network in the west. During the last year, it has spent $85 million to subsidize the introduction of snappy digital telephone lines that allow customers to hook up to the Internet or to on-line computer services at about three times the speed of traditional phone lines. Not stopping there, the company rolled out a relatively cheap and jazzy Internet service called T-Online, which has signed up 1.1 million customers, far more in Germany than its biggest rivals, Compuserve and America Online.
All told, Deutsche Telekom spent about $87.5 billion on new digital technology between 1990 and 1995, and its network is now considered one of the most modern in the world. Even though the company still has a mountain of more than $60 billion of debt, it has reduced capital spending sharply, from $13 billion in 1993 to $7.5 billion in 1995 and about the same level this year.
Though Deutsche Telekom has been much more inward-looking than British Telecom, it has invested about $4.4 billion overseas in the last few years. Its highest-profile move was a three-way alliance with France Telecom and Sprint, in which the two European companies each paid $1.8 billion for a combined stake of 20 percent in Sprint.
Deutsche Telekom also joined forces with Ameritech, one of the Baby Bells, to buy a controlling stake in the Hungarian national phone company, and it has acquired minority stakes in the telephone companies of Malaysia and the Philippines, as well as in an Indonesian mobile-phone satellite company.
What is most striking, however, is the company's apparent lack of interest in expanding its base in Europe. The contrast with British Telecom is stark; the British company has formed major partnerships in about a half-dozen European countries, including Italy and France, aimed at competing with established telephone monopolies on all fronts when the European Union's regulatory barriers come down in 1998.
British Telecom, of course, has had an enormous head start, thanks to the free-market policies of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The company went public during her administration with the same sort of hoopla that Deutsche Telekom is generating now. Like Deutsche Telekom, British Telecom had to transform itself at the time from a bloated Government monopoly into a profit-oriented company.
It more than succeeded, transforming itself over the years into a competitive powerhouse. The British Government opened up the market gradually but steadily, with Cable and Wireless moving quickly to build up a rival local and long-distance service. American telephone companies and cable television operators moved in, too, including Tele-Communications Inc., U S West and Nynex.
As a measure of how well British Telecom weathered the competitive storm, it retains almost 90 percent of the British telephone market. By contrast, AT&T's share of the American long-distance market slumped to just over 60 percent in 1990, from 90 percent at the time the seven regional Bells were spun off, also in 1984.
Hans Ehnert, a Deutsche Telekom spokesman, acknowledged that the company had been slow off the mark -- but that it had no choice because it was prohibited by law from foreign investment until two years ago. "We were late and we are newcomers to the scene," Mr. Ehnert said. "But if you look at what we've done, what is surprising is how much we've done in such a short time."
That may be so. But as national barriers come down just 14 months from now, companies like British Telecom clearly believe that the name of the game is having networks across the Continent that can then be connected in a broader international net. If it is right, Deutsche Telekom could be left with its own market under siege and few offsetting advantages outside Germany.
In the interim, the Government in Bonn has moved vigorously to promote the interests of its telephone monolith -- coddling, its critics call it. Last January, the company sparked a public uproar by announcing plans to increase its prices for basic local telephone service and cut prices for long distance. Consumer groups cried foul, and Germany's Minister of Telecommunications angrily ordered a review of Deutsche Telekom's costs. But the plans were eventually approved, on the promise that the company would come up with a discount plan akin to MCI's "Friends and Family" program in the United States.
BUT the matter did not end there. Deutsche Telekom also won Government support for a plan to offer corporate customers rebates of up to 40 percent. This proposal infuriated fledgling rivals as well as the European Union's top antitrust regulator, Karel Van Miert, a Belgian.
Veba and others protested that letting Deutsche Telekom offer big rebates in the only area in which it faced competition would make it far more difficult for them to get off the ground in 1998. Similarly, Mr. Van Miert objected that the plan would allow the company to undercut rivals in the only niche in which they can now do business: private corporate networks.
But those arguments fell largely on deaf ears. Germany's Minister for Telecommunications, Wolfgang Botsch, not only sided firmly with Telekom but flew to Brussels several times to make his case with Mr. Van Miert. And, in a blatant breach of the Government's supposed impartiality, Mr. Botsch was joined by Deutsche Telekom's chairman, Mr. Sommer, on the last of these trips on Oct. 23, industry executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity said. According to the executives, Mr. Sommer initially waited outside the meeting room but was later invited in.
One week later, Mr. Van Miert approved Deutsch Telekom's plans on the condition that the German Government push through tough regulations to let rivals connect into Deutsche Telekom's network.
The rivals are still angry, complaining that Mr. Botsch showed favoritism in flying to Brussels time and again on Deutsche Telekom's behalf, but never on theirs. "One big problem in Germany is that Telekom is going public at the same time as liberalization," said Peter Mihatsch, the head of Mannesmann's telecommunications business who is supposed to head the Deutsche Bahn group that includes Cable and Wireless, AT&T and Mannesmann.
Mannesmann and Veba are now worried that Mr. Botsch will not honor his promise to push through tough interconnection rules. Though arcane, these rules are crucial for competitors because they determine the prices a rival has to pay an established phone company to connect with its network.
For all the financial and political power of Deutsche Telekom, its smaller challengers aren't conceding a thing. William Coleman, an analyst at HSBC James Capel in London, said they had a built-in advantage over their bigger rival because the latest technology made the cost of entering a market significantly less than the cost of maintaining an outmoded infrastructure.
In Germany, they are also attracting top talent. For example, Mr. Mihatsch, the man anointed to take charge of the venture led by Deutsche Bahn, was the architect of Mannesmann's successful challenge to Deutsche Telekom in cellular telephones. Mannesmann, which obtained a nationwide cellular license for Germany and started service in 1992, racked up 500,000 customers by the end of 1993 by rolling out a digital network that offered better service than Deutsche Telekom's old analog network. Deutsche Telekom was so surprised that it rushed out its own digital network.
And Ulf Bohla, the head of the Veba-led consortium in Germany, was a top lieutenant of John F. Akers, the former I.B.M. chairman, and was later assigned to a senior I.B.M. post in Europe. Mr. Bohla says Europe is facing a far more traumatic adjustment to open competition than the United States had. "In the U.S.," he said, "you let the regional Bell companies keep their monopolies intact for years, and you are only now moving toward competition in the local exchange. Here, it's full competition from Day One, and it's much, much less regulated. As a result, it will be a much harder market in which to compete."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "World-Class Offerings" shows the biggest foreign stock offerings in which a portion was offered in the United States. (Source: Securities Data Co.)
 
Charts: "The Raiders for Europe's Phone Market"
The European Community is scheduled to open up its phone markets fully to competition on Jan. 1, 1998. In many countries, state-owned monopolies will find themselves fending off incursions not only from foreign telecommunications companies, but consortiums within their own borders.
 
Sweden
Tele Norda, the Norwegian phone company; Tele Danmark A.S., the Danish phone company, and British Telecom are teaming up to challenge the Swedish phone company.
 
Netherlands
British Telecom and Nederlands Spoorwegen, a Dutch railway operator, plan to use the rail network as a basis for a communications network.
 
France
BT and Compagnie Generale des Eaux, the dominant French water distributor and the owner of the nation's second-biggest cellular network, plan to take on France Telecom. BT will pay $1.8 billion for a 25 percent stake in the joint venture, which will build a full service network along water pipelines.
SNCF, the French national railway, is taking partnership bids from Generale des Eaux, which is already aligned with BT, and STET S.p.A., the Italian phone company.
 
Spain
Retevision, Spain's state-owned television transmission service, plans to challenge Telefonica de Espana S.A. BT and Banco Santander, the big Spanish bank, have a joint venture and may well team up with Retevision, which will get the first license to compete with Telefonica de Espanan.
 
Italy
Italian Railways is taking bids from potential partners to compete against STET. Bidders include Albacomm, a joint venture of BT, Banco Nacional del Lavorro and Mediaset (controlled by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi). France Telecom and Livetti S.p.A. are also bidding.
 
Germany
Deutsche Telekom A.G. controls the $50 billion German telephone market, but three consortiums are preparing a broad challenge.
 
Deutsche Bahn A.G., the German national railway; Mannesmann A.G., a diversified company and owner of the D2 Cellular network covering German; AT&T, and others.
Deutsche Bahn, which already operates a private communications network along its 40,000 kilometers of track, will build a network throughout Germany. Mannesmann will run it. Unisource, a consortium owned by AT&T and several smaller European phone companies, will provide international connections.
 
RWE A.G., Germany's biggest electric utility company; Veba A.G., a conglomerate that also owns electric utilities, and Cable and Wireless P.L.C., a British telecommunications company.
RWE and Veba will build networks alongside electric lines and gas pipelines. Cable and Wireless will provide the international connections.
 
British Telecom Viag A.G., which owns electric utilities in southern Germany. It is unclear how this venture will work, since another partner, RWE, recently defected to a rival consortium. (pg. 5)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1262 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE STOCK MARKET
Condemned to Repetition?
Rats in a maze -- the more adept ones, anyway -- don't keep smashing into the same wall. By all appearances, today's investors don't share the rats' reverence for history. Four times since World War I, the Dow industrials have risen more than 50 percent in the two years between elections. The first three -- 1926-28, 1934-36 and 1984-86 -- were followed quickly by a market crash, a recession, and another crash. The fourth was 1994-96, when the Dow soared 59 percent. History, in short, says sell. Investors, in short, bought. The day after the election, the Dow leapfrogged 96 points, to -- need one say it -- yet another record. The logic, it seemed, was that the status quo -- a Democratic President, a Republican Congress -- had worked so well that investors rejoiced at continued gridlock. The flaw in the logic: Nothing ever stays the same. The past two years are history (you know, the stuff you learn from).
 
OTHER VOTES
Let Business Be Business
And on the morning after, business smiled. Not necessarily at the big-ticket election results, but at the results of state ballot initiatives, which for the most part came down on the side of letting companies operate as freely as they have been. Californians refused to make it easier to sue companies, and Maine voters chose not to ban clear-cutting of forests. H.M.O.'s averted some efforts in several states to limit their ability to set their own rules. Oregon, though, drew the line at tobacco, with voters approving a 68-cent tax on a pack of cigarettes to help out with the state's health care. Does that mean the little people are the losers? Not necessarily. California business leaders say that a few big lawyers were churning out the flood of suits against companies.
 
LANDMARKS
If Grand Central Were a Beer
The world adores new stuff, the sleeker the better, but balances that with a craving to protect old stuff. But while venerable buildings get the protective embrace of landmark status, there's no such haven for, say, treasured symbols, civic images. Take Milwaukee. A city, of course, dripping with beer. Can you imagine it without Pabst, without Schlitz? Unthinkable. Since German immigrants started brewing here in the 1840's, the image of a city built on beer has been imprinted on the nation's identity. Yet Schlitz closed in 1982, and now the Pabst plant is also closing by yearend, with the beer to be made at the Stroh brewery in La Crosse, Wis. Hmmm. Pabst, the beer that made La Crosse famous? Not even with Schlitz would that sound right.
 
AUTOS
Used Cars Galore
Today's endangered species: people who actually buy new cars. Many people who drive off in new models lease them, and more and more just buy used ones -- an estimated 73 percent of buyers this year, up from 64 percent six years ago. And if proof were needed that this is big business, last week Republic Industries, led by H. Wayne Huizenga, agreed to buy Alamo Rent-a-Car. The point, clearly, is that Alamo, like any other car renter, turns out a stream of used cars. And as it happens, Republic just bought Auto Nation, a chain of giant used-car lots, so it has a near-bottomless demand for auto makers' day-old bread. The next possible step: an alliance between Auto Nation and General Motors, which supplies up to 75 percent of Alamo's fleet.
 
CORPORATE WOMEN
The Picture-Frame Ceiling
It comes down to the family picture on the office desk. If a man has it, that fits the corporate image perfectly; if a woman has it, she'll be stuck on the Mommy track. At least that's what's being heard from those who say women aren't moving up fast enough on the corporate ladder. "To be successful in a lot of companies," said one specialist on gender issues, "a woman has to conform to the image of someone who doesn't have an outside life." Two recent studies seem to back that up. One shows that just 61 of the nation's largest 500 companies have a woman among their top five earners. Interestingly, though, not many of those 61 appear in another study, which lists companies with the best work and family policies. One possible conclusion, as another expert put it: If women make it, they "are making it in the old-fashioned way" -- in a male world.
 
TELECOMMUNICATIONS
New Muscle for MCI
All phone wars are local, Tip O'Neill never said. Yes, yes, the British Telecom-MCI merger announced last week is yet another sign of a shrinking planet -- it is expected to speed the opening of overseas markets and could lead to an overhaul of trans-Atlantic long-distance rates. But what does this deal -- the largest foreign takeover ever, one that creates the world's first trans-Atlantic phone company -- mean on the local front? Simple: MCI will now have the resources to step up its assault on local markets in 25 American cities. This could mean lower rates, not just for calls to London but for calls around the corner. AT&T isn't happy about the merger, but there is probably little it can do to block it.
 
TOBACCO WARS
5 Million? Not Necessarily
The Government had a message for teen-agers last week: smoking will kill more than five million of you prematurely. But for adults, who have it in their power to change things, it also had a message: those five million don't have to die. States have widely different smoking rates, it said, and Massachusetts and California, which have put real effort into cutting smoking by raising taxes and using some of the proceeds for anti-tobacco ads, have made clear progress. California ranks just above Utah, the least smoky state, where the rate is held down by the anti-tobacco Mormon Church. An election footnote, by the way: according to one poll, 53 percent of smokers voted for Bill Clinton, a determined tobacco foe, versus 36 percent for Bob Dole -- a result decidedly more lopsided than the overall vote. What's up? Do they think he'll help them quit?
 
EUROPEANS
Altered Soybeans? No, Thanks
So what if the F.D.A. and the European Union have given their blessings to genetically engineered soybeans? That's not enough for many Europeans. They don't want them, period. And when the first shipment arrived in Hamburg last week, they said so in no uncertain terms, vowing boycotts and other protests. With memories fresh of Britain's mad-cow disease, they rebelled against this tinkering with food -- all done in that never-ending search for the grail of higher yields, of squeezing out the extra soybean. This is no small matter, for soybeans are a big American farm export, finding their way into everything from margarine to livestock feed.
 
LIQUOR ADVERTISING
'Open Season on Kids'?
The ban on liquor ads on television and radio has always been unusual, for a simple reason: it was voluntary. In other advertising battles, each side fights bitterly over every inch of turf, but the liquor industry apparently decided decades ago that it wasn't appropriate to lure people to partake of demon rum -- or demon whisky or demon vodka. But Seagram recently broke ranks and started running liquor ads, and last week the industry officially scrapped the ban -- perhaps spurred on by the nation's 29 percent drop in liquor consumption since 1980. There was some noise about not aiming ads at minors, but the sad fact is that youngsters respond more to ads. "This is a bad day," said one public-interest advocate. "The liquor industry has declared open season on kids." Not that liquor ads will suddenly flood the airwaves, though: the four networks have no intention of accepting them.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1659 words

HEADLINE: Middle America;
Coming Home From the Revolution

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
WHAT happened to the anger, the boiling discontent, the hunger for change? How did the country end up with a split-the-difference Government after four years of a Great Upheaval that destroyed a Republican President in 1992, shattered a Democratic House in 1994 and upended 60 years of social welfare policy in 1995?
This was supposed to be the era of the big political crack-up. Of a conservative realignment. Maybe even of an emerging third party. Yet here we are, at the end of it all: divided government, again. A President who hugs the center tighter and tighter, having campaigned on appeals for school uniforms and the V-chip, the protection of Medicare and increased family and medical leave. A chastened -- and much narrower -- Republican House majority that spent much of this campaign running away from its revolutionary image. An electorate whose dominant image was an army of soccer moms driving to the polls in their mini-vans: pick up the kids, drop off the dry cleaning, move the Government to the center again. 
 If the political tumult of the 1990's has indeed come to a close, it may be that the politicians simply overestimated all along how much change the voters wanted, and forgot that the country is a lot more like Mayberry R.F.D. than Paris 1848. Yes, voters were anxious and discontented in 1992, buffeted by a recession and the anxieties of a shifting global economy. But that didn't mean that they wanted the greatest expansion of the social welfare system since the New Deal, as Mr. Clinton attempted with his plan to remake the health care system, or the greatest contraction of it, as Newt Gingrich attempted with his Contract With America.
Another possibility is that the era isn't over. Tuesday's election results could signal that the voters, wielding the blunt instrument of elections, have collectively begun to figure out how much change they want and to calibrate their message. They may have lowered their expectations a little. They may have recognized that the system has, in fact, responded to some of their yearnings. At the same time, as Stanley Greenberg, the Democratic pollster, put it, "if the economy faltered, I have no doubt that the anger would rise fairly quickly and it wouldn't take much for the underlying anxieties to come out."
The election of 1996, in other words, may turn out to have been less an end to the national upheaval than a mid-course correction.
Well before last Wednesday morning, the conventional wisdom was that much of the tumult of the last four years was due to the hubris of politicians, spinning elaborate mandates from raw election returns. Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Clinton seemed to have taken that lesson to heart; by the end of last week, the two were declaring a mandate for nothing more controversial than a search for "common ground."
 
'More Realistic Electorate'
But their overreaching, in hindsight, may have been necessary to effect any change at all. The Framers made it hard to accomplish big things in the American political system, even when the voters want them. The power of interest groups makes it hard to accomplish even little things. Maybe Mr. Clinton had to try for national health insurance to set the stage for the incremental changes that were to come, like the new law protecting health insurance for people who change jobs and perhaps an effort in the next Congress to expand coverage for children. Maybe Mr. Gingrich had to declare a revolution to bring about a commitment to a balanced budget seven years from now, another long-running concern of the voters.
Along the way, the voters clearly learned something about the costs and the difficulties of change. "This is a much more realistic electorate, I would argue, than we had in 1992," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. Many voters learned that universal health insurance would cost more in upset, regulations and risk than they were willing to pay. Many learned that they could not roll back the Federal Government without hurting the programs they liked, such as Medicare.
How else to explain why Bob Dole's proposal to cut taxes by 15 percent fell flat? The last two years have been one long and bitter tutorial on how hard it is to balance the budget, let alone provide a huge tax cut.
There is another way of understanding the last four years: a lot has changed since 1992. The voters did, after all, get a redesigned Democratic Party, retrofitted for the slightly right-of-center 1990's. Mr. Clinton's repositioning since 1994 is often dismissed as a series of short-term tactical maneuvers to ride out a difficult moment in political time. But some historians argue that this redefinition, if it holds, is not a small development. Most analysts agree that the country has grown more conservative over the last 30 years. Mr. Clinton may have succeeded in moving his party toward the new center of political gravity.
"He made it possible for the Democratic Party to identify itself as moderate, responsible and non-frightening, but marginally more progressive than the Republicans," said Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University. Even in the House, where the liberal wing of the party still holds sway within the Democratic caucus, Democrats have nonetheless followed suit; "Families First," their campaign manifesto this year, was a model of Clintonesque incrementalism, offering tax credits and other modest gestures to help people educate their children, hold on to their health insurance and protect their pensions -- in small ways.
Voters also ended up with a reconstituted Republican Party, stronger than 1992's but humbler than 1994's. Here, too, it is easy to dismiss the much-heralded Republican realignment of 1994 as hype, given the party's spectacularly unsuccessful Presidential campaign. Yet a brief look back to the 1980's suggests how much has changed. The Democrats not only held the House through that decade but had an average margin of nearly 80 seats.
At the very least, the voters have put the two parties at rough parity and allowed the conservatives to set many of the terms of the debate: The importance of a balanced budget by a fixed date. The focus on values. The almost universal get-tough attitude toward crime. The bipartisan decision to scale back basic welfare programs and turn them over to the states.
Walter Dean Burnham, a political scientist at the University of Texas, says the country may not be in the midst of a classic realignment of the kind it saw in 1932, but it is in the midst of a great shift toward "a new equilibrium very, very different from the old order." He added, "I don't know where this leads us."
Many others in politics agree that much remains unsettled from this period of upheaval. There is still a hunger for political reform, given new force late in the campaign by the disclosures about the Democrats' fund-raising practices. There is still alienation among many voters, a feeling that the two parties are simply not enough. And, most important, there is still a profound disagreement and conflict over the role of government.
"Regardless of the partisan balance, something about the shift in debate that was registered in 1994 is going to stay with us," said Theda Skocpol, a professor of government at Harvard and an expert in social policy. "There's just a sense that you can't use the Federal Government for big initiatives even if the national problems are big."
Yet while the public sides with the small-government camp in the abstract, the Democrats' defense of Medicare, education and environmental programs hit a powerful chord, particularly with women.
Surveys of people leaving the polls on Tuesday showed a sharp divide on the role of government, particularly between the sexes: 35 percent of the men thought the government should do more to solve problems, while 60 percent said it was already doing too many things better left to business and individuals. Women were evenly divided on the question.
The coming struggle over Social Security and other entitlements will be a test of how much conservative philosophy the voters are actually willing to live with. "I don't think it's at all settled that the privatizers will have their way," said Ms. Skocpol.
Scholars like Mr. Burnham say this debate was almost inevitable when the cold war -- and the prime rationale for a strong Federal Government -- ended. The mistrust of Washington began to climb in the late 1960's, amid riots, assassinations and the Vietnam war, and fed the anti-government politics of the Reagan era. Yet pollsters say it coexists, even among the same voters, with a desire to see some action out of Washington.
Many analysts believe that the Republicans saved their majority when they began cooperating with the President and producing legislation last summer. Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster, said, "The message of this election is not that people are content with divided government; actually, their vote was for productive government."
 
 
 
Unsolved Problems
 After all, as Mr. Greenberg, the Democratic pollster, argues, the underlying problems that many analysts believe triggered the upheaval of the early 1990's persist: the long-term problem of stagnant incomes and fear over the breakdown of the family. "The good economy has muted the anger, and we've been through a period of repeated, dashed expectations, which makes people cautious about calling on government to do big things," he said. "But that doesn't mean that the problems aren't still real and the potential anger isn't still real."
When the inevitable downturn comes, so, too, might the desperation and fury of the primaries of 1992. The basic question will be the same: Can't the Government do something? The competing fear will be the same, also: Can voters trust their Government to do the right thing? And the calm of 1996 may, in retrospect, look like the eye of a storm.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 9; Column 2; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1534 words

HEADLINE: Perspective;
Swifter, Higher, Stronger . . . Gender

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

 BODY:
The Israeli was chatting with the Palestinian in a neutral nation. But the conversation in Lausanne, Switzerland, had very little to do with tenuous peace agreements or tunnels under the Temple Mount.
The primary topic on the north shore of Lake Geneva was women and sport. 
 The Israeli was Yael Arad, the judo star who became the first athlete from her nation to win an Olympic medal when she took silver in 1992. Her interlocutor was Oreib Araf-Aryan, a young woman from Ramallah who was recently named manager of her would-be nation's underfunded and understaffed women's sports department.
"I have to say that I've lived in Israel all my life, and I've never met a real Palestinian," said the 29-year-old Arad. "All of a sudden, here I am sharing the same hotel and drinking coffee with one. It is very positive interaction. I was telling her: 'I am famous in Israel. I can come over the border, and I can help you with developing sport.' "
So it went for three days last month at the Olympic Museum, an idyllic spot conducive to idyllic thought.
When the International Olympic Committee decided to organize its first world conference on women and sport, the hosts were uncertain who would make the journey to Lausanne. They ended up greeting 220 participants from 96 countries with problems and experiences that were often as disparate as the physiques of the gymnast Kerri Strug and the basketball player Rebecca Lobo.
There were delegates from Senegal and other West African nations, where sport is widely considered an activity that damages a women's ability to bear children and where corpulence in women is encouraged as a reflection of their parents' and husbands' ability to provide. There were several delegates from Iran, where Islamic dress codes and mores mean that women do not compete internationally in sports like basketball, swimming and track and field. There were also representatives from the United States, where few major barriers remain and where new opportunities -- both competitive and commercial -- are emerging for female athletes at a heady pace.
"I think there's a real hesitancy on our part to make the assumption that what works in the United States is necessarily going to work in other countries," said Marjorie Snyder, the associate executive director of the Women's Sports Foundation. "The cultural differences are so vast that to take what we do and slap it onto the rest of the world would be a bit of hubris, I think."
Margaret McGregor, executive director of the Canadian Association for Women and Sport, said: "We're focusing on issues like self-esteem, eating disorders and sexual harassment in sport, and others here are worried about economic survival."
The most prominent and potentially volatile cultural gap in women's sport remains the divide between traditional Islamic nations and the Occident. But one of the conference's coups was that both perspectives were well represented, which had not been the case in 1994 when the first conference on women and sport was organized, independent of the I.O.C., in Brighton, England.
The Iranian delegation came to Lausanne in chadors, the hooded robes designed to hide the female form, and wielding stacks of public relations brochures. Leading the way was Faezeh Hashemi, the 33-year-old vice president of the Iranian Olympic Committee and daughter of the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani.
It was Hashemi's idea to organize the first Islamic Countries' Women's Sports Games in Iran in February 1993: an 11-nation competition that allowed women to compete against each other in eight sports in accordance with Islamic codes. Men were permitted at the opening and closing ceremonies and as spectators at events such as shooting, which could be performed in chadors. At events like basketball, men were excluded from the arena as women competed in less restrictive outfits.
The second Islamic women's games are scheduled for Pakistan next November. What Hashemi wanted to take away from the Lausanne conference was greater international awareness and tolerance for her brainchild. Last year, Atlanta Plus, a Paris-based group of feminists and academics, called for the I.O.C. to ban countries from the Olympics that discriminate against female athletes. But the I.O.C. rejected that tack as politically motivated, and Atlanta Plus was not represented in Lausanne. Though the I.O.C.'s charter precludes it from sanctioning events that are religious, rather than regional, in scope, the emerging policymakers in women's sport have chosen the path of constructive engagement with Hashemi's segregated games.
"If these games are the only way for women in these countries to compete in sport, then they must take the opportunity, and perhaps over time things will change," said Anita DeFrantz, the influential American I.O.C. member who was the driving force behind the Lausanne conference and who chairs a new I.O.C. working group on women and sport.
The I.O.C. hardly has been in the vanguard of the women's movement. Its founder in 1896, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, was a staunch opponent of female participation in the Olympics, and the I.O.C. did not admit female members until 1981, Juan Antonio Samaranch's first year as president.. Samaranch was present for the first session of the conference, and there are now 10 women among the I.O.C.'s 113 members. At the last I.O.C. session, in Atlanta in July, the membership resolved that all national Olympic committees and international federations should ensure that 10 percent of their decision-making officials will be women by the end of 2000 and that 20 percent will be by the end of 2005.
The conference attempted to build on that modest and potentially quixotic platform (DeFrantz conceded that the I.O.C. had no current plans for sanctions if nations and federations do not comply by 2000).
"I'm not sure everybody will abide by the 10 percent unless the I.O.C. puts a gun to their head and says 10 percent or else," said the American George Killian, president of basketball's world governing body, FIBA, who was one of more than 30 men to attend the conference.
FIBA exceeded both I.O.C. quotas last month by adding five permanent seats to its 15-member, all-male executive board and stipulating that all five be filled by women. But such moves remain the exception. The ceiling in the American corporate world might be made of glass, but in international sports, the ceiling is sturdier and opaque. Of the 31 permanent Olympic sports federations, only two are headed by women -- badminton and equestrian -- and most have no female officials in high-ranking posts. The same is true of national Olympic committees, and -- unlike Iran -- the United States, Japan, the Netherlands, France, Italy, Germany and Britain have no women in top national Olympic committee positions.
Considering that 34 percent of the 10,750 athletes at the last Olympics were women, females are also grossly underrepresented in elite coaching. Even Sweden, with a government and national Olympic committee made up of about 40 percent women, sent only one female coach to Atlanta. The solution proposed most often in Lausanne is a familiar one: affirmative action.
"The pattern of male domination in sport is institutionalized; it's not going to go away with time alone; we need intervention from the I.O.C.," said Elizabeth Darlison, executive director of the Australia-based WomenSport International.
Much was asked of the I.O.C. in Lausanne: much more than it can realistically deliver, even with millions of dollars from NBC at its disposal. In a sense, the value of this conference might have been more symbolic than tangible. The 17-point resolution agreed to on the final day of the conference was a mild blend of solid planks and platitudes. When paired with the list of recommendations produced earlier by the I.O.C. working group, the result was a timid yet cogent manifesto.
Among the proposals are a call for the I.O.C. to work toward having the same number of Olympic disciplines and events for men and women (men currently hold a significant edge) and a request that the I.O.C. help finance the promotion of women's sport, particularly in developing nations. The delegates at this conference also called for the I.O.C. to discontinue its current gender testing procedures and suggested that cities bidding to host the Olympics be judged on their "demonstrated ability to serve the needs of women and sport."
"I think many of these ideas are doable, and all of them are reasonable," said DeFrantz, who nonetheless cautioned that it takes time for the I.O.C. to effect change. "I ask you not to be patient, but to understand the timetable," she told the delegates.
Of course, the truth, as this conference made clear, is that nearly a century after women first competed in the Olympics in 1900, the timetable depends very much on one's address. In the United States, a women's professional basketball league was launched to considerable fanfare last month. Meanwhile, back in Ramallah, Oreib Araf-Aryan was worried about simply being able to afford a few basketballs.
"Right now, on a scale of one to 10, we are at zero," she said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Want Ads

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
HELP WANTED: Secretary of State. Salary $148,400, plus yearly C.O.L. raises. Perks: Three weeks annual vacation, unless Iraq invades Kuwait again in August. Own Boeing 707 jet (1960 vintage). Pilots and crew included. Black limousine, with driver. Oak-paneled office with view of the Potomac. Must enjoy international travel, particularly to Syria. Must enjoy spending time with Senator Jesse Helms. Must be able to brief reporters "on background," "on deep background," "on deepest background," "off the record" and "on the record" all in the same conversation, if not sentence.
The successful applicant for this job will understand just how much the world, and therefore this job, has changed since the end of the cold war. Historically there have been two kinds of foreign affairs: the commercial foreign affairs conducted by the Secretaries of Commerce and Treasury -- leading trade missions and managing the dollar -- and conflict-resolution foreign affairs conducted by the Secretary of State -- negotiating everything from arms control with Russia and China to peace between Arabs and Israelis. 
 The distinction between these two is no longer valid. We have moved from a world dominated by superpowers to a world dominated by both superpowers and "supermarkets." In this new world, the bond and stock markets of Wall Street, Tokyo, Singapore, Shanghai, Paris, London, Frankfurt, Zurich and Hong Kong can be as influential in shaping the behavior of states as the traditional foreign-policy engines -- like border wars, nationalism and ethnic strife.
Nations that want to thrive today must transform their politics, open up their economies and streamline their legal systems along the lines dictated by the supermarkets and their investors. Those countries that get their politics and economics right are rewarded by the supermarkets with investment capital to grow and those that don't are left as road kill on the global highway. This pressure on nations to improve their airports, roads and telecommunications, to upgrade the skills of their workers and to downsize their deficits to attract the supermarkets is recasting the domestic politics, and therefore foreign policies, of one country after another.
The successful Secretary of State will understand that one of his or her biggest challenges will be helping countries like Russia, Mexico, China, Egypt, Turkey, South Africa or even Spain make the transition from where they are now to full-fledged members of this global economy, without destabilizing under the pressure. How well these nations make that transition, and what sort of cultural, economic and ethnic backlashes this transition triggers at home from those who want to resist globalization (labor unions, fundamentalists, traditionalists or others) will affect very much how these nations behave abroad. If the new Secretary of State cannot get under the hood of these countries and help influence their direction inside, he or she will never influence their direction outside.
To do that the next Secretary of State must be able to think in 3-D -- he or she must not only understand the political, military and market pressures being brought to bear on countries, but also be able to manipulate all three to serve U.S. diplomacy. After all, it is impossible to influence China today without mobilizing the resources and pressures of the U.S. business and investment communities, which are pouring billions of dollars into China and now have more leverage there than the State Department. And the only way to advance human rights abroad is by enlisting U.S. corporations. They have to be made to understand that business rights and human rights are just flip sides of the same coin: the rule of law. Ultimately, if there are no rights for Wang Dan there will be none for Ronald McDonald. And no Secretary of State who doesn't understand the politics of oil pipelines will ever be successful in dealing with Turkey, Russia, Iran or Afghanistan. What does Bosnia need today if it is going to be stabilized? Bosnia needs big tanks, big roads and Big Macs. It needs tanks to keep the armies separated, roads to bring the civilians together and McDonald's -- that is economic magnets -- to induce people to come down those roads.
The next Secretary of State has to be as comfortable shuttling inside countries as between them, as comfortable in a taxi as on an airplane, as skillful at manipulating the balance of power as the balance of briefcases. To apply call (202) 456-1414. Ask for Bill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Foreign Danger Zones

 BODY:
As President Clinton assembles a new Cabinet and looks ahead to his second term, he has a rare opportunity to review America's interests abroad. The relative tranquillity of recent years has obscured the real risk that one or more countries vital to American security could quickly slip into turmoil. It does not take a seasoned diplomat to see the high danger zones. The potential for long-term instability is considerable in Russia and China. Collapse of the Middle East peace effort would have wrenching consequences, including the prospect of renewed armed conflict. Iraq remains unpredictable. Turkey, pivotal to American interests in the Persian Gulf region, faces powerful internal divisions. 
 But the greatest threats to American interests could come from three other countries. Severe turbulence within Saudi Arabia or Mexico would swiftly undermine the economic security of the United States. A convulsion in North Korea might lead to a military confrontation on the Korean Peninsula that directly involves American troops.
To head off trouble in these countries, Washington should vigorously press their leaders to make internal reforms and move toward greater political pluralism. Holding Saudi Arabia and Mexico in a tight, uncritical embrace, or cutting off contact with North Korea, is exactly the wrong approach.
Recent Administrations had a bad habit of underestimating the risk of foreign upheaval, particularly when allies were involved. The failure of American foreign policy in Iran, where Washington tied itself to the corrupt and dying regime of the Shah, must not be repeated in Saudi Arabia.
The Saudi monarchy is formidable and resilient. For decades it has been a reliable supplier of oil to the West and a moderating influence on oil prices. It was America's partner in the Persian Gulf war and serves as the anchor of American influence and military strategy in the region.
But Saudi Arabia is under increasing stress. Disillusionment with the monarchy is growing as economic hardships hit an expanding population and Islamic preachers complain about excessive reliance on outsiders, especially the United States. Home-grown terrorism is developing. King Fahd is ill and the royal family is divided over succession.
There may be no serious threat to the monarchy for years. But President Clinton should not bet American prosperity on that hope. As soon as a new Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense are in place, Mr. Clinton should conduct an unsparing review of America's relations with Saudi Arabia.
Mexico is a political and economic crisis waiting to happen. Decades of one-party autocracy have stunted its politics. Its economy is still staggering under the consequences of the artificial prosperity choreographed by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and the devastating devaluation and austerity measures that followed it. President Ernesto Zedillo's reforms are welcome but belated.
With living standards eroding and crime soaring, and armed resistance to the Government in several states, Mexico is a combustible country of 92 million people next door to the United States. It would not take long for an economic or political calamity there to sting American financial markets and propel a tide of illegal immigrants northward.
The danger on the Korean Peninsula is acute. The cruel and erratic dictatorship of Kim Il Sung, who died two years ago, has been followed by famine and unclear lines of authority under his son, Kim Jong Il. Tensions between North and South Korea remain high, leaving Seoul so suspicious of its neighbor that it is reluctant to cooperate with Washington in preventing an implosion of the northern regime. But it is imperative to bring the North peacefully out of its long isolation. As long as North Korea is ostracized, hungry and heavily armed, it is a serious threat to stability in Asia.
Developing realistic and unflinching policies toward these nations will require both the sustained attention of Mr. Clinton and his new team of advisers and the support of Congress. Most of all, it depends on America's political leaders' recognizing that complacency in the handling of volatile and vital foreign countries invites misfortune.
