HEADLINE: French-American Ties Mostly Untied, for Now

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The French mood these days is a sour one, and French-American relations, never better only six months ago, have soured with it.
Things were threatening to get so far out of hand that President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, slipped into Paris on Nov. 1 for unpublicized talks with President Jacques Chirac and other officials to try to limit the damage. 
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher will continue the discussions Wednesday and Thursday during an international meeting here on aid to Bosnia. He is among the American officials said to be most acutely annoyed by recent French sallies into the Middle East and sarcasm about his trip through Africa last month.
The biggest dispute between the allies, but hardly the only one, centers on a French demand that a European officer take over a NATO military command that has always been held by an American admiral before France will rejoin NATO as a full partner.
French officials say that Mr. Chirac does not want a "showdown" with Mr. Clinton and that at worst, France would continue to stay out of the NATO military structures it left 30 years ago.
Mr. Chirac tried to get things off to a fresh start Wednesday with an effusive message and a telephone call congratulating Mr. Clinton on his re-election. "Jacques Chirac is a friend of the United States," one French official said. "His ambition is to build Europe with the United States, not against it."
But the potential for friction, a constant of French-American relations since the days of de Gaulle, remains.
Alain Lamassoure, the French Government spokesman, said this, for example, about Mr. Clinton's victory: "It makes progress toward European unity more necessary than ever, so as not to leave American power alone like some kind of gendarme or judge over the affairs of the world."
With French unemployment at 12.6 percent, the highest since World War II, and with Mr. Chirac's popularity rating barely over 30 percent, he and his even less popular Government have been seeking a higher profile in foreign affairs since last spring.
"We've been through this many times before," an American official in Washington said. "Whenever the French are insecure, they take it out on us, and they have a lot to be worried about these days."
French officials have reacted to Washington's criticism on the NATO issue by conciliation in other areas.
The French want significant American participation, for example, in the international force of 4,000 to 6,000 soldiers that they want to send to Zaire's border with Rwanda and Burundi to help more than a million refugees. They are willing to make important concessions to get that participation.
Authoritative officials said this week that if the United States insisted on commanding the whole operation before it would send in ground troops, that would be all right with France. American officials, regarding the offer as something of a poisoned chalice, pointed out that the reason for it might be Rwanda's vehement objection to any French military role in the region.
But France's emollients toward the United States contrasted markedly with its criticism of Mr. Christopher's attempt to rally support for an American-sponsored African intervention force during his trip to Africa last month. That trip was viewed here as an unwelcome intrusion onto traditional French turf.
Mr. Christopher was also annoyed during a diplomatic shuttle mission to the Middle East in April that the French had insisted on sending Foreign Minister Herve de Charette to the region at the same time.
White House and State Department officials feared interference with American mediation efforts between Israel and the Palestinians when Mr. Chirac set off on his own trip through the region last month.
He clashed with Israeli security officials during a visit to Arab East Jerusalem but carefully urged all the officials he saw, Arab and Israeli, to continue to talk with one another. French and American officials here agree that Mr. Chirac never challenged the position of the United States as the mediator most trusted by all the disputants.
He also sent a long letter to Mr. Clinton after the trip explaining what he had tried to achieve and got an answer thanking him for the constructive European involvement, according to French officials.
They added that despite frequent American criticism of the European contacts with Iran, the American mediator, Dennis Ross, had asked them recently to pass on a warning against terrorist attacks in Israel to the French contacts in Iran and Syria. They were in a position to do so within hours, the officials said.
France will remain critical of recent American laws aimed at punishing European companies that do business with Iran and use expropriated property in Cuba, French officials say. And Mr. Chirac has never concealed his disagreement with American opposition to re-electing the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
The greatest potential lost opportunity in the French-American relationship, however, is the French military reintegration into NATO, which Mr. Chirac announced a year ago.
In August he wrote to Mr. Clinton asking that the United States surrender an important NATO command, Allied Forces Southern Europe in Naples, Italy, whose main muscle is supplied by the United States Sixth Fleet. He asked that French and other European officers take turns running it.
Germany and Italy have backed the French, but the United States has ruled out giving up the command. If Washington does not yield, French officials say, France will not move back into the military structure.
"If they don't want to come in then, that's fine with us," said an American diplomat in another European capital. "If the French think we will give in on this, they're crazy."

HEADLINE: A Chilling Change in the Contraband Being Seized at Borders

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Nov. 7

 BODY:
Since this summer, a new contraband has been running second only to marijuana in the Customs seizures made here on the Mexican border. It is more profitable than cocaine by some estimates, believed to be bigger business these days than gun-running, and illegal to import for a futuristic reason: it harms the planet.
It is that old staple on car-repair shop shelves, Freon. And it is taking on a sinister new role as the contraband of tomorrow. 
 Virtually all production and importation of the ozone-destroying refrigerant has been banned in the United States since January, but the continued demand for it among American owners of more than 80 million older cars whose air conditioners use it has sent black-market prices spiraling, Federal officials say.
Concerned that market forces will undermine a landmark global agreement to stem the use of ozone-eaters, those same Federal officials are waging a "war on Freon" with some of the same seriousness as the war on drugs.
In recent months, they have been training hundreds of border inspectors and prosecutors to crack down on the thousands of tons of Freon that enter the country illegally each year and add a bit more to the holes in the protective ozone over the Earth's poles.
Beginning with a Miami-based task force known as "Operation Cool Breeze" nearly two years ago, tough-on-Freon Federal prosecutors have won at least 18 convictions of major smugglers, accompanied by millions of dollars in penalties and sentences of up to 57 months for the biggest violators. A Freon case brought the first-ever extradition for an environmental crime, officials said, and the first United States felony convictions based on violations of the Federal Clean Air Act amendments on ozone-depleting gases.
Prosecutors and inspectors believe they have deterred some of the larger shipments of Freon, which is the commonly used Du Pont brand name for a coolant belonging to the class of chemicals called chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's.
But not the smaller ones, and not for long.
"The profits are tremendous -- people pick up a 12-ounce container in Mexico for $2 and sell it here for $23," said Steve Solow, assistant chief of the environmental crime section of the Justice Department. "And we anticipate there will be another surge in attempts to smuggle in large quantities; that's why the department has developed a national enforcement initiative."
The street price for a 30-pound cylinder of Freon has more than doubled since last year to well over $500, said Thomas A. Watts-Fitzgerald, the United States Attorney who has spearheaded Operation Cool Breeze.
He calculates that buying cocaine, converting it to crack and selling it brings a 4-to-1 profit ratio; buying a canister of Freon in another country for $42 and selling it here for $550 produces a 13-to-1 profit ratio.
"It doesn't take a math genius," he said. "It's basic economics."
A typical air conditioner on a car built before 1993 that uses Freon takes two to three pounds of the odorless compound. It is legal to sell and use existing stashes of Freon, but they are expected to run out in two years.
The most recent cause for worry, Federal officials say, is indications that serious Freon smugglers have taken to crossing the loose United States border with Canada.
"We're beginning to see some instances of smuggling routes that go back to the days of Prohibition, using islands in the Great Lakes," said Michael Penders, special counsel to the director of criminal enforcement at the Environmental Protection Agency.
But the authorities are also concerned about an increase in the small-scale smuggling most common here on the California-Mexican border, where Customs officials confiscate six or seven illegal loads of Freon canisters a week, and often the cars of the smugglers as well.
Gregory Schulte, a Customs investigator, said that since this summer, "rat-packers" -- small-scale smugglers -- have been caught with 5,320 pounds of Freon in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.
Since Freon is still legal to manufacture and export in Mexico, "What we're seeing here is that you could almost drive around aimlessly there and find some, throw it in the trunk and hope you get lucky," Mr. Schulte said.
The Government is taking Freon smuggling with such gravity in part because it undermines the 1987 agreement known as the Montreal Protocol, in which more than 140 countries agreed to curb ozone-depleting gases.
The ozone layer serves to veil the planet from ultra-violet radiation, which is harmful to plants and animals and has been shown to cause skin cancer, cataracts and other damage in humans. Government scientists have reported worsening ozone depletion in recent years over both poles.
Because the exact quantities of smuggled Freon are not known and the science is sketchy, it is unclear exactly how much the illicit chemical could delay the healing of the ozone holes, which is expected to take decades even with full compliance with the Montreal plan.
If estimates by a private group called Ozone Action that about 10,000 tons of CFC's are smuggled in per year are correct, then the smuggled Freon's impact is likely less than that of the thousands of tons still being produced and consumed each year in India, the former Soviet Union and elsewhere.
The Montreal agreement lets developing countries continue producing CFC's 10 years longer than industrialized ones, which had to stop last year.
In addition, under a loophole in the agreement, hundreds of tons of Freon are still being produced for export in the United States as well this year.
But even a small impact is too big, said John Passacantando, executive director of Ozone Action. "We're already in a danger zone," he said. "We're already drunk and shouldn't be driving that car, and another beer means just that much longer that you shouldn't be driving."
Ozone Action plans to issue a sequel to last year's report on Nov. 19 identifying Mexico as a major source of illegal CFC's entering the United States, Mr. Passacantando said. And the Montreal signatories are expected to meet this month to decide how to stop the export from one country to another.
The planetary damage that the ozone-depleting gases wreak makes the Freon smugglers, in the eyes of some, the classic villains of the post-Cold-War world, polluters for profit who value money in their pocket over the health of the Earth.
"The damage that can be imposed by UVBV" -- the harmful radiation that ozone blocks -- "goes down to the genetic level," Mr. Watts-Fitzgerald said. "It literally has the capacity to affect life on Earth as we know it," but "We have a hereditary inability to take the long view on some things as opposed to the short economic view."
Mr. Watts-Fitzgerald helped convict several Freon smugglers over the last two years who brought in hundreds of tons of the compound. Now, he and others said, would-be big shippers seem to be deterred, in part because the method most of them used -- pretending the Freon was only passing through the United States in order to avoid stiff excise taxes -- will no longer pass muster now that the full ban is in place.
But all predicted that Freon smuggling, large and small, will continue until the last old-car owners cough up the cash -- more than $100 and sometimes several hundred dollars -- to convert their cars to less-polluting air conditioner coolants. Or until Freon gets so expensive and its replacements so cheap that it is foolish not to convert.

HEADLINE: At College, Many Learn How to Plunge Into Debt

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: COLLEGE PARK, Md.

 BODY:
Melissa Allen, a psychology major at the University of Maryland, cannot count on her parents for help with tuition. But rather than go deeply in debt with student loans, she is giving up much of the fun of college life by racing through in three years while working 40 hours a week at three jobs.
"I don't want to get out of here with a whole lot of debt," Ms. Allen said recently, on a break from one of her jobs. 
 Even so, she has fallen into a credit trap. After charging part of this semester's tuition on her MasterCard, she cannot pay more than the monthly minimum. At 17 percent interest, she said, the balance is "never going down."
But while Ms. Allen is at least worried about being in debt -- and has made sacrifices to avoid it -- college officials say that for too many students, the certainty of owing large loans after graduation is combining with banks' marketing of credit cards to them to provoke another response: spend now, worry later.
 More than any generation before, this one is weighed down by debt -- and increasingly debt of its own making. And sympathy is short for those whose unchecked consumerism brings them to financial crisis before they are out of college.
A Smith College administrator, Myra Smith, said of students who come to the financial aid office saying they cannot pay their bill, "I suspect part of the reason they have trouble paying Smith is because they are paying somebody else." If their requests for more aid are not firmly denied, she said, "then we're financing their life style."
Financial aid officers say a growing number of young men and women are leaving college with large debts and ruined credit ratings because of credit cards. Not thinking of a college loan as real debt until after graduation, when repayment begins, is one thing, the aid officers said, but students learn too late that using credit cards like cash, rather than regarding them as high-interest loans due now, is quite another.
"I was forewarned to get just one credit card and not go crazy, but I did go crazy," said Melissa Raaff, who ruined her credit by charging $5,000 on credit cards while a sociology major at the University of California at Santa Barbara. "I didn't worry about working because I thought, 'Oh, I'll just put it on my credit card.' It's unfortunate that it affects your credit in the long run."
Spurred by Federal requirements, colleges routinely conduct advisory sessions with new students getting financial aid and interviews with those about to graduate or leave college. But the warnings to freshmen, at least, often fall on deaf ears.
"I don't think we make a big impression," said Barbara Tornow, Boston University's executive director of financial aid, who was instrumental in persuading her alma mater, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, not to offer a credit card. "I think we need to have more responsibility for warning students about getting in over their head."
On some campuses, the credit cards available to students include cards sponsored by the college or university, and that may explain part of the students' lack of concern about borrowing.
Banks are bombarding college students with credit-card offers, with minimum requirements, and sometimes send them unsolicited cards. Even some high school seniors get repeated solicitations.
There is no question that many students cannot avoid debt these days. Tuition increases are still outpacing inflation, while colleges are allocating a greater share of financial aid packages to loans. Since 1993, student borrowing has almost doubled, from $18 billion then to $33 billion in 1996, according to the Department of Education.
Most of this is under the widely used student Federal aid plan, the Stafford program, under which student loans from private institutions are guaranteed and subsidized by the Government. This year the average Stafford loan balance for students leaving four-year colleges jumped 15 percent from the 1995 average to $10,146, according to USA Group Loan Services, an organization that administers a $10 billion educational portfolio.
Frederic W. Gilbert, the USA Group's president, said, "Student debt has grown because of the rising cost of attending college, higher loan limits, expanded eligibility and the growing proportion of Federal student aid offered in the form of loans rather than grants."
Yet the number of students working while in college actually appears to be declining, said Ted Freeman, president of the Boston-based Education Resources Institute. And the more serious problem for students is credit-card obligations, which, unlike student loans, cannot be deferred.
The stakes are high for the banks: students represent the only large group of uncommitted consumers, and studies show that brand loyalty won early is often won for life.
Borrowing limits on student credit cards start low, typically at $400 or $500, but issuers quickly raise them as a card is used. While some cards for students require a parent to cosign, many do not.
Beth Kobliner, author of the self-help book, "Get a Financial Life," said she not only didn't have a credit card when she graduated from college 10 years ago, she could not qualify for one for some time afterward. "Today it's just entirely different," she said, not only in the numbers of young card holders but in their attitude toward using the cards. On promotion trips, she is repeatedly reminded that many regard their credit card limit more like a balance to be drawn against than a loan that must be repaid.
Federal law limits the information that issuers can elicit from credit card holders, so there is a scarcity of data for specific age groups. A survey of college students by Tahira K. Hira, a professor of family finance at Iowa State University, found that 76 percent held three or more credit cards and that 40 percent -- twice the rate of the population at large -- had six or more.
Researchers say young people are also more likely than older people to be delinquent on loans, even if the amounts they borrow are often less than those of older card holders. How many young people actually get over their heads in credit-card debt cannot be accurately gauged because parents often come to the rescue.
Greg Mathis, a sophomore art major at California State University, Los Angeles, is not worried about the $3,500 a year he is borrowing for college, but he has come to see his three credit cards as "dangerous."
Even working part time as a teacher's aide for $9 an hour, he said he cannot pay more than the monthly minimum on the $1,400 he has charged for clothes, shoes and books.
In discussing personal finance in a senior-class project, Professor Hira found that even many of her brightest students had little knowledge of the subject. "I was just amazed at the ignorance," she said.
Some credit-card issuers, under pressure from consumer groups, are trying to educate the public about personal finance. MasterCard International, for example, offers a series of brochures under a program called "Spend Wisely, Pay Wisely," and also conducts college seminars on credit-card use.
Consumer advocates, however, belittle these efforts. "Their aggressive marketing overwhelms any consumer education," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America.
Jennifer Benjamin, 26, said of her circle of friends at the University of Massachusetts, where she ruined her credit rating: "We all probably spent more than we earned. It wasn't real money. It was play money."
Now a graduate student at Boston University, Ms. Benjamin restricts herself to what she calls "a loser's card": a credit card that allows her to charge no more than the balance in her savings account.
Even so, she uses it frequently. "I paid for something with cash the other night," she said, "and my boyfriend said, 'What's that?' "

HEADLINE: Guam, a Spoil of War, Seeks More Autonomy

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: GUAM

 BODY:
The beaches on this jewel of a Pacific island are like powdered milk, but it is American milk, and the people here are American citizens who every four years are the first ones to go to the polls to cast ballots in the Presidential election.
Yet while a tropical location on the edge of Asia guarantees coral and coconut palms, as well as an Election Day that begins 15 hours before New York's, it also means that votes cast here for President do not count. Here in America's military outpost in the Pacific, the vote for President is simply an extra question on the local ballot. It is a straw poll as ineffectual as any in a school classroom. 
 "We are a colony, and we have to break out of that," said the locally elected Governor, Carl T. C. Gutierrez. "This goes against the grain of what America was founded on."
Mr. Gutierrez and a broad range of other local officials are demanding a new deal from Washington, warning that unless the Federal Government gives local people additional political rights it will no longer be able to count on using the island as its garrison in the Pacific.
It is not clear how seriously one should take that warning, for there is no specific threat to back it up. But there is no question that Guam is a strategic and valuable chunk of real estate. It is America's westernmost possession, due south of parts of Japan, making it an ideal base from which to project military force in Asia and beyond.
When the United States bombed Iraq in early September, the two B-52 bombers flew from Guam, saving the Pentagon from seeking permission from another country. Then when the United States evacuated 2,700 Kurdish refugees from Iraq beginning in September, they were flown to Guam, where they are being processed for resettlement elsewhere.
The military owns almost one-third of Guam, a banana-shaped island about 30 miles long. But the economy depends less on the military than on the throngs of Japanese tourists who fill the beach resorts.
While the Pentagon and other Federal agencies are trying to block Guam's demands for greater autonomy, people on the island are fighting back by asking harsh questions rooted in the American ideals that are taught in Guam schools.
Those are questions about American values, about whether the United States is willing to practice at home the anticolonial and democratic message that it preaches abroad. By quoting from the Declaration of Independence and appealing to principles of self-determination, people on Guam seek to embarrass Americans into yielding greater autonomy.
"The relationship of Guam to the States is very similar to the relationship of the 13 colonies to King George," Tyrone J. Taitano, director of policy development in the governor's office, said with a gleam in his eye. "That's very disturbing to us."
American diplomats have been embarrassed that Guam is still one of a dozen colonies on a list of colonies kept by the United Nations, and the United States last month criticized the United Nations for the way it applied the concept of decolonization to American territories. Governor Gutierrez promptly protested to American officials and asked for help in "eradicating colonialism in Guam."
A majority of the 145,000 residents are not seeking independence, for they are fiercely patriotic Americans who sign up for military duty in greater proportions than from any state. Many in Guam would like statehood, although they acknowledge that is impossible for now.
So people in Guam are asking for the island to be made a commonwealth, under a proposal drafted by local officials and approved by voters in the 1980's. The proposal has largely gathered dust in Washington, resisted by the Pentagon and other Federal agencies that raise constitutional objections and warn that greater local authority would impair the military's ability to react in a crisis.
Commonwealth status still would not allow people in Guam to vote in Presidential elections or to have their own voting Congressman, for both would require statehood or a constitutional amendment. But the plan would give the local government more authority to rule the island and control local land.
America obtained Guam as a spoil of war after the Spanish-American War of 1898. Technically, Guam is owned by the United States, but is not a part of it. That makes it American soil. But in a sense that rankles many people on the island.
"It's exactly the same relationship someone has with a car or a house," said a senator in the local legislature, Mark Forbes. "It's property rights." Mr. Forbes is a Republican, and the Governor is a Democrat. But local officials in both parties broadly agree in their yearning for greater self-determination.
A bit fewer than half the inhabitants of Guam are Chamorros, descendants of the original inhabitants. But the island feels like America, with its Kmart and traffic-clogged highways and Colonel Sanders statues, all washed by a hot sun and tropical showers.
To be sure, Guam is just one of a handful of American territories that fall short of statehood. Puerto Rico is the best known. There are also the Virgin Islands, American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands, all held under separate arrangements.
"America is going to be the last colonial power in the world, and in 1776 it was the first to fight against colonialism," said Richard H. J. Wyttenbach-Santos, a former Navy officer who is a scholar at the University of Guam.
Residents are particularly indignant over how military officials hold on to vast tracts or resist efforts to develop private property. Pedro Artero stood the other day on just such a spot, a gorgeous beach that he owns in northern Guam, as he complained that the military authorities would not let him build a hotel.
"Our family owns this, but we can't do anything with it," Mr. Artero said as a half-dozen relatives nodded. "Uncle Sam's holding us back."
The commander of United States Naval Forces in the region, Rear Adm. David L. Brewer 3d, disputed the idea that the military was ruling in a high-handed way, noting that the armed forces were indeed giving up some land.
"Our relationship with the Government of Guam is one of equal partners," Admiral Brewer said. "It's definitely not colonial."
Some residents of Guam agree. When eight University of Guam students sat around a table to talk about the island's status, most grumbled about unequal treatment. But one, Jorgi Strandhagen, tossed her head and noted that Guam had done much better economically than other Pacific islands that were independent.
"I don't feel like a second-class citizen," Ms. Strandhagen said. "I think the Federal Government has been pretty good to us."
Although people in Guam pay the same Federal taxes that they would if they lived in a state, the money is all used in Guam. And it is supplemented by hundreds of millions in subsidies from Washington.
"Is this a colony?" asked one official who insisted on anonymity partly because his views are unpopular. "Well, it depends on your definition of a colony. Historically, mother countries have milked colonies of resources, and that's not the case here."
Most people on Guam apparently acknowledge that they enjoy some advantages. But they say that what they are asking for is not subsidies, but rather respect and political and civil rights.
"The Chamorros say it's like slavery," Mr. Wyttenbach-Santos said. "You have the best slave owner in the world, and he's not going to break up your family. But you're still owned by someone else."
Some Guam officials are optimistic that Mr. Clinton will push for adoption of a commonwealth act for Guam, and people here this year raised more than $600,000 for the Democratic National Committee and for his re-election. There are discussions with the White House to have Mr. Clinton, perhaps, stop off in Guam this month on his way to or from the meeting of Asia-Pacific leaders in the Philippines.
Governor Gutierrez said when he discussed Guam with Mr. Clinton this year, he received a sympathetic hearing. "It hit the right buttons for him to know that we are disenfranchised," Mr. Gutierrez said, "and that American democracy is not practiced out here."

HEADLINE: California Town Hopes Eye-Catching Murals Will Put It on Map

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif.

 BODY:
This tumbleweed town that took its name from an act of nature has come up with a plan to revitalize itself with man-made creations. City leaders want to make Twentynine Palms the "Mural Capital of America."
On the side of the Break and Run Billiards parlor, an artist is painting the city's eighth mural, this one commemorating two archeologists who searched the arid dunes and desolate canyons near here for Indian artifacts in the 1920's, about the time this place got its start around an oasis with 29 palms. The mural's lush acrylic flourishes of a shirt in periwinkle blue and a face in deep violet seem like enormous cactus flowers against the sun-burnt sagebrush of the Morongo Valley. 
 It is scene that is difficult to miss in a passing car. It is so eye-catching, in fact, that residents recently put up bleachers nearby so they could comfortably gaze at the work in progress. And that is the point.
Tourists have had little reason to stop here, other than for gas. But by creating an outdoor art gallery, residents hope to transform this economically suffering city of 15,000 people into the Paris of the Mojave Desert.
"We're not a gritty blur from a car window anymore," said Mary Jane Binge, one of the mural organizers. "There isn't a day that goes by when you don't see people taking pictures of our murals."
The source of life for Twentynine Palms, halfway between Los Angeles and the Arizona border, is the nearby Twentynine Palms Marine Base, a desert training ground for 25,000 marines. During the gulf war, many of the troops there were sent to the Middle East, which compounded the recession of the early 1990's and bankrupted many businesses here.
But residents believe they have found the answer to their problem in verdant British Columbia. When Beth Wiederhold was president of the Twentynine Palms Action Council, a revitalization group, she saw an article in the Smithsonian magazine about the once-depressed Canadian logging town of Chemainus, which lost its sawmill, but later became a popular tourist destination after covering building walls with murals.
"I saw similarities in how Chemainus and Twentynine Palms looked, except for the palm trees," Ms. Weiderhold said, who later visited Chemainus to get a more detailed view of its 32 murals.
Soon afterward, city leaders rallied for their own mural project in Twentynine Palms to attract some of the 1.5 million annual visitors to Joshua Tree National Park, four miles to the north. After some fund raising, the first mural was painted on the Plaza Furniture store in 1994.
Muralists from around the country have been selected, based on their work and proposals. The murals cost about $15,000 each and take as long as two months to complete. They focus on the history of this city started by miners and ranchers.
On a wall of Twentynine Palms Liquors, Cahuilla Indians gather around the tree-lined Oasis of Mara (it now has fewer than 29 palms), weaving baskets near their huts. At Twentynine Palms Gemcrafts, "The Flying Constable," the Mojave's first sheriff, dips his airplane's wing at a waving woman while patrolling the scrub.
The paintings have turned some previously art-apathetic merchants into connoisseurs of sorts. Victor Hull, owner of the Twentynine Palms Thrift store, stood proudly in front of his shop recently and disclosed some little-known, "inside" features in the mining scene, "Dirty Sock Camp."
"You see that guy there," he said pointing to a grizzled prospector. "That's the face of the artist's father-in-law."
Downtown, the center of the mile-long mural district, has recently become a popular site for new businesses like the Finicky Coyote cafe. Jeff Bowers, the owner, said the murals and potential out-of-town customers prompted him to open up shop in a boarded-up building. In a hopeful sign, he said, tourists sometimes drop by to eat.
"When you talk to them, they ask for mural information," Mr. Bowers said. "I think the plan is working."
But other merchants, though keen on art, said the murals had had no effect on their balance sheets. The only really negative view voiced was by a man in a bar who complained about the flood of "flatlanders" invading his tranquil desert.
For the time being, Twentynine Palms is planning to raise money for three murals a year from donations and by selling $125 limited edition prints of the murals it already has. The immediate goal is to surpass the number of murals in Lompoc, 60 miles north of Santa Barbara, which Twentynine Palms officials learned has 23 outdoor wall paintings. But that revelation, plus the fact that Los Angeles has more than 1,000 murals, has not dimmed the enthusiasm of mural advocates here.
Larry Briggs, the current president of the Twentynine Palms Action Council, said of the Lompoc paintings: 'I've checked out the competition and there is no competition. They have a hodgepodge of artists and styles and methods and its not as quality art work and wall preparation as our work."

A Los Angeles artist, Richard Wyatt, right, has painted a mural -- one of eight in the town -- of Campbell family members who were among the early settlers of Twentynine Palms. HEADLINE: Taking Stock, but No Guff, Mandela Talks of Democracy

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 9

 BODY:
It is the midpoint of Nelson Mandela's five-year term as South Africa's first democratically elected President, and he settled into a chair in his living room ready to face reporters. It was 7 A.M. He is still an early riser.
"I'm going to kick off, if I may," said one reporter. 
 "As long as you don't kick me," warned Mr. Mandela.
His tone was only half-joking. Mr. Mandela was clearly ready to cross swords.
At 78, he is recovering from a knee operation and walks with difficulty. His hands and ankles look swollen. Photographers cannot use a flash because it bothers his eyes, which were injured by dust during years of breaking rocks in prison.
But Mr. Mandela is as regal as anyone who rose from Xhosa prince to political prisoner to state president can be -- and if he is a bit irritable, he perhaps has reason to be. It's not the aches and pains of age that bother him, but the nagging criticism of his young Government that he hears constantly at home and that filters overseas, discouraging investors and tourists.
The euphoria of the peaceful transition from white supremacist government has worn off, and South Africans are beginning to carp, like citizens of any other democracy.
Whites, fearful of crime and affirmative action, are continuing to flee the country. Blacks, disappointed that few new jobs have appeared and that squatter camps still spread for miles, are showing some signs of disenchantment with Mr. Mandela's African National Congress party. A recent poll showed that its support had dropped to 53 percent in July from 66 percent in 1994.
Everyone worries about the fall of the rand, charges of petty corruption, squabbling among African National Congress officials and whether the new Government has enough competent civil servants.
Mr. Mandela finds these complaints unfair. In an hourlong interview on Friday, he talked of success "beyond our wildest expectations" in creating a South Africa based on democratic principles and an array of checks and balances.
Last year, he said, even he was overruled on a voter registration issue by the country's Constitutional Court.
"What can be more democratic than that?" he asked.
On occasion, his temper flared. Responding to a question citing black critics who weren't even in the room, he vehemently defended the contributions of whites, construing the critics narrowly to be senior black editors, whose "ignorance" he attacked.
Reaching for a folder full of statistics, Mr. Mandela -- a man revered as a saint and feted all over the world as a statesman -- for once sounded less like Gandhi and more like an American Congressman boasting of what he has done for his district.
He told of the bacon his administration had brought home, beginning with the respectable 3.5 percent economic growth rate achieved last year.
"As far as water is concerned," he continued, "700 water supply projects are under way, which will give 6.4 million people access to water. Already 600,000 people have been supplied with water. This is in rural areas where people have never had clean tap water.
"On health, we say, over 5.5 million schoolchildren in poor areas are benefiting from the primary school nutrition program. Four hundred new health clinics have been completed since after 1994.
"Then we deal with housing and we say by the end of the year, 500,000 subsidies will have been released. At the moment 170,000 houses are in production.
"And electrification: in the last four months alone, 400,000 homes have been hooked up."
Lacking in the statistics are facts that might shade these victories. There is no mention that the school feeding program has been marred by corruption or that the housing starts fall far short of the promises made in the administration's heady early days.
But Mr. Mandela did acknowledge some problems, most notably the country's continuing difficulty remaking its police force. Under apartheid, the force was largely used to protect whites, contain riots and spy on political activists, or torture and murder them.
Now it is being asked to protect and serve the populace -- but it has little experience in fighting crime and precious little understanding of individual rights. It is also bedeviled by corrupt officers. "There are rogue elements, some of them in key positions," Mr. Mandela said, "and while they are a tiny minority, they are doing a great deal of harm."
But he had statistics on this subject as well. He pointed out that in the province of KwaZulu/Natal, no fewer than 278 police officers had been arrested on such charges as corruption, murder, robbery and thievery since 1994. In the province of Gauteng, which includes Johannesburg, he said that the state was investigating 8,300 cases against police officers and that 434 officers had been arrested.
"We have done that in almost all the provinces," Mr. Mandela said. "We are getting on top of that."
His administration has tangled openly with the country's news organizations, attributing negative perceptions to bad local journalism. Asked about criticism that he spends too much time worrying about the concerns of whites, Mr. Mandela erupted. Such remarks, he said, come from "superficial" senior black journalists who do not appreciate that white skills and money are part of the country's strength.
"They assume," he said, "that we have defeated whites on a battlefield and that the whites are now lying on the floor helpless and begging for mercy and that we can impose conditions on them."
That is hardly true, he continued, and it is best to keep whites from joining the right. In addition, he said, large white-controlled companies are helping the country's transformation, sometimes building schools and health clinics simply because he asks them to.
His priorities for the coming year include stabilizing the rand, and he said he might be willing, for the first time, to borrow from the International Monetary Fund to do that. But he said he hoped that money raised by selling state assets like radio stations and part of the telephone company would obviate the need for that.
Asked about possible roles for the nation's strong and disciplined army in policing African conflicts, he expressed reluctance to get involved, because of South Africa's history of destabilizing its neighbors. He said he might let troops join a mission organized by the United Nations or the Organization of African Unity. But he took a dim view of anyone who expected him to solve the continent's problems.
"If I have any moral authority -- and I say 'if' -- moral authority doesn't solve world problems."
As he learned after criticizing President Sani Abacha of Nigeria, moral authority doesn't change policies. "They're changed by those countries who trade with the country, such as the United States, which imports 52 percent of Nigeria's oil."
Mr. Mandela deflected several questions during the interview, including one about the certainty that Deputy President Thabo Mbeki will succeed him and one about whether he believed former President F. W. de Klerk had directly ordered atrocities against blacks.
"I'd like to avoid that if you don't mind," Mr. Mandela said, leaving little room for appeal.
He denied recent speculation that he would step down before the end of 1999, saying only that he would cede his post as party president next year to open the field to younger people, "who are really more energetic, more assertive and who are deep thinkers with better vision." It has been widely acknowledged by African National Congress officials that Mr. Mbeki, 54, will be elected to the post.
"In any case," Mr. Mandela said with a grin, "a leader who doesn't know when to step down will really come to grief, because he may be humiliated. I must step down whilst there are one or two people who admire me."

HEADLINE: In Vermont, Milkmen Are Leaving The Scene

BYLINE: By SALLY JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WEYBRIDGE, Vt., Nov. 9

 BODY:
In his day, Harold Bigelow kept the keys to the town. Six days a week for 25 years, he delivered Monument Farms milk to as many as 400 homes in Weybridge, Middlebury and Cornwall, a sizable portion of the population at the time. And always he carried a large ring loaded with house keys.
"His wad of keys must have been this big," said Monument Farms' Stephen James, forming his hands into a ball the size of a grapefruit. "Harold's customers trusted him. He'd water their plants when they were away, do all sorts of things for them. And believe me, at Christmastime he was well taken care of." 
 Mr. Bigelow, who drove the route for 25 years, died in 1975. The dairy's home delivery service hung on for another two decades, until last month, when it became another victim of the social and cultural changes that have all but erased doctors' house calls and Fuller Brush salesmen from the landscape of everyday life.
For several years now, Monument Farms, a dairy and bottling operation owned by Mr. James and several members of his extended family in this small western Vermont village, had been one of a few dairies in the state still offering doorstep service. But in October, the family decided that the house-to-house milk route had to go, for financial reasons.
Now, in a state that is synonymous with dairy farms, where years ago practically every town had more than one farmer who would drop off milk door-to-door, there are only three dairies that still make home deliveries.
"We had a general sense that it was time to stop traveling all those country roads for a few quarts of milk," said Mr. James, whose dairy also supplies all the groceries, restaurants, convenience stores and schools in town, not to mention the 1,500 quarts delivered each day to Middlebury College.
The history of home milk delivery reflects social and economic change in the nation over the years. It began in the last century, after Americans moved off farms and into villages.
Fred Webster, a retired dairy specialist with the University of Vermont's Extension System, explained that before the turn of the century, milk cans would be loaded onto a horse-drawn wagon. At each house, he said, "the milkman would scoop the milk out of the can into a glass bottle provided by the customer."
Growing up in the central Vermont town of Randolph, he recalled "at least 9 or 10 farmers making home deliveries."
"I don't think anybody has exact numbers," Mr. Webster said, "but when I started at U.V.M. in 1956, there were 230 milk dealers in the state, and most did home deliveries. Going back to the 1920's and 30's, you could probably multiply that number by a factor of 10."
Theron Wolcott recalled that his father, Guy, had gone into the home delivery business in 1918, just as World War I was ending. The family started making the rounds with a horse and wagon, twice a day in the summer.
His father's dairy, G. F. Wolcott, sold pints and quarts in glass bottles with a waxed pasteboard cap; milk was delivered to the fraternity houses at Middlebury College in cans. Theron Wolcott, now 85 years old, said he and his sister had been responsible for running the full bottles to the customer's doorstep, picking up the empties and washing them out back at the farm.
In 1921, his father bought a Chevrolet truck to do the milk route, but a few years later, the Wolcotts returned to using the horse-drawn wagon for village deliveries, replenishing the wagon at fixed points along the route. "It was more economical," Mr. Wolcott said, "than starting and stopping a truck."
The Depression hit, and his father "furnished milk to families with children even though they couldn't pay for it," Mr. Wolcott recalled.
After World War II, pasteurization -- heating milk to destroy bacteria -- became universal, Mr. Webster said, but its cost drove thousands of small farms out of business.
It was the Federal food program for women, infants and children, known as W.I.C., that extended the life of home deliveries by at least a quarter-century. Because Vermont state regulations require that W.I.C. participants receive their dairy products, orange juice and cereal at home, most of the dairies still doing home deliveries are also the W.I.C. suppliers for that region. Monument Farms had the regional contract from 1972, when the program began in Vermont, until last month.
That was when the dairy lost the contract to a lower bidder, a couple who do only W.I.C. deliveries.
At that point, "we dropped from 720 customers to 120 customers overnight," said Robert James, the son who handles marketing and distribution for Monument Farms. "I was driving 70 miles a day, five days a week on dirt roads, just to deliver a few quarts of milk. We couldn't justify it anymore."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: THE POLICY MAKERS;
Assembling A New Team On Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Surprised by the speed of a rash of post-election resignations that have claimed all but two central players on its economic team, the Clinton Administration is scrambling to rebuild that side of the Cabinet before it has to confront three major challenges next year: a potential slowdown of the nation's economy, change in entitlement programs and growing tensions with China over trade policy.
By the end of this week, it appeared that only two Cabinet members at the center of economic policy making -- Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the acting United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky -- planned to remain for Mr. Clinton's second term. 
 The other major players, who were credited with merging domestic and foreign economic goals more successfully than past Administrations and helping Mr. Clinton take credit for a remarkable period of economic expansion and low inflation, have all signaled in recent days that they plan to return to the private sector or to academia.
And from the White House to the Treasury to the Commerce Department, there is already a palpable sense that the energy and balance of the Administration's first economic team will be enormously difficult to replicate in a second term -- and that the economic and Congressional conditions in the next four years are likely to be far messier to manage.
"The real test will be the degree that the new team can hang together," said Gene Sperling, the deputy head of the National Economic Council and one of the most influential behind-the-scenes operators of the Administration's economic initiatives. "The thing about the initial team is that we were born by fire," cast together in the ferment of Mr. Clinton's tumultuous first term. That bonded us together, and it's not something that is easy to create a second time."
But Ms. Tyson was optimistic, saying today: "There is now an existing process and a clear agenda that the President laid out in the campaign. And a new budget is a way to focus the new team."
Most of the Cabinet members and other important economic players who said they were leaving Washington were the authors of Mr. Clinton's "Putting People First" theme in the 1992 campaign -- and the Administration's subsequent retreat from that agenda. Among them are Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, the campaign manager in 1992 who became the Administration's outspoken advocate for free trade, and Robert B. Reich, who was the champion of far bigger commitments to education and training and then of "corporate responsibility."
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, an economist who was head of the Council of Economic Advisers and then head of the National Economic Council, where all the Administration's economic issues are supposed to be worked out, said she will return to California. Her successor at the council, Joseph Stiglitz, is widely assumed to be headed to the World Bank.
Another of the central figures in the Administration's economic team in the first term, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, was killed in April in an air crash in Croatia that also took 34 other lives.
That leaves Mr. Rubin, who previously ran the economic council and is usually the most fiscally conservative of the lot, as the chief source of continuity. With Secretary of State Warren Christopher also leaving, "Bob becomes the grand old man of the Cabinet," a senior Administration official said. "His influence will grow simply by virtue of the fact that he's been around the longest, in the two most important positions. And that will certainly change the nature of debate."
It was Mr. Rubin who pressed Mr. Clinton to abandon the grander plans for his first term in favor of deficit-cutting, betting that the financial markets would ultimately reward that effort. That strategy soon became the centerpiece of the Administration's economic plan, and as Mr. Rubin moved in early 1995 from the newly created National Economic Council to the Treasury, his influence as Mr. Clinton's chief economic sounding board grew.
For the next term, Mr. Rubin has already made his priorities clear: a long-term plan for curbing the growth of entitlement programs, especially Social Security and Medicare; a renewed focus on urban policy, one of Mr. Rubin's chief interests even when he was an investment banker in New York, and a renewed American commitment to using the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as instruments to develop the third world.
The question White House officials say they cannot yet answer is whether there will be a more liberal counterweight to Mr. Rubin's market-oriented approach to national economic policy. In early 1995, for example, Mr. Rubin was among those opposing a significant increase in the minimum wage, while Mr. Reich argued fiercely for one. His argument -- that an increase would not slow job growth -- ultimately won the day, though the size of the increase was reduced. Congress passed the increase just before the election.
Mr. Rubin also opposed efforts within the Administration to give tax breaks to companies that avoid downsizing and that offer workers a greater equity stake. That effort was quickly squelched. Instead, the White House settled for a less controversial -- and less effective -- conference celebrating companies that it considered model corporate citizens.
Perhaps the most critical appointment facing Mr. Clinton in the economic arena is the post that is least talked about and least understood: the head of the National Economic Council, which has been held by Ms. Tyson. Like its counterpart, the National Security Council, the National Economic Council was created by Mr. Clinton to to resolve economic debates within the Administration, and to merge domestic and foreign issues.
The issues the council tackles -- and thus the agenda that reaches the President's desk -- will depend in large part on who is placed in charge. Among the candidates are Samuel R. Berger, the deputy chief of the National Security Council, who has played a large role in policy toward Japan and China over the last three years, and Lawrence Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, who made little secret of his disdain for the two biggest trade battles the Administration entered into: one with Tokyo over automotive trade, and another with Beijing over the piracy of software and videotapes.
Mr. Sperling, who has been in charge of domestic policy issues in the council, is also considered a possible successor to Ms. Tyson.
Whoever is appointed, Administration officials agree that two major economic issues are likely to dominate the next year. The first is keeping the economy growing with low inflation, though that decision may depend more on the judgment of the Federal Reserve Board than any of the officials Mr. Clinton will appoint over the next few weeks.
The other issue is China. Its trade surplus with Washington is rising as Japan's is leveling off. And there are continuing debates in Washington about how to handle China's economic expansion and its refusal to play by world trading rules.
Mr. Clinton appears to be retaining one of the Administration's strongest China hawks, Ms. Barshefsky, the acting trade representative. But before she can be given Mr. Kantor's old title, the Administration must negotiate a way around a legal restriction that bars those who have represented a foreign government from holding the job. As a trade lawyer in the early 1990's, Ms. Barshefsky briefly represented Canada in a case involving lumber.
Should she become Trade Representative, the Administration could continue some of its high-profile confrontations with countries it says are blocking entry of American goods or violating American copyrights.

HEADLINE: W.R. Goodwin, 72, Former Johns Manville Chief

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
W. Richard Goodwin, a former president and chief executive of the Johns Manville Corporation, died on Oct. 24 in Denver, where he had lived for many years. He was 72.
He died of a stroke, said his son, Douglas Goodwin. 
 Known for his flamboyant style, Mr. Goodwin brought an atypical background to the executive suite.
After serving in the Army in World War II, William Richard Goodwin received bachelor's and master's degrees from Reed College in Portland, Ore., and in 1955 earned a doctorate in experimental psychology from Stanford.
For the next decade he worked for the Rand Corporation and the Systems Development Corporation helping to develop a large computer-based control system for the Strategic Air Command.
After a few years as a management consultant, he joined Johns Manville, one of his clients, in 1968 as vice president of corporate planning.
A little over a year later he was named president and chief executive. He resigned at age 52 in 1976. In accepting his resignation, Manville's board cited differences "related to the style of management" rather than conflict over direction of the company.
It was a clash many in the financial community knew would inevitably occur.
"Where the directors wore three-piece Brooks Brothers suits and had short hair," one analyst said at the time, "Goodwin wore flashy sports clothes and let his hair grow."
Manville's board of directors was also reportedly displeased when Mr. Goodwin spearheaded a bitter, public fight to bring the Olympic Games to Denver in 1972. The effort ultimately failed in a Colorado referendum.
Still, in Mr. Goodwin's tenure, Johns Manville's sales more than doubled, to $1.1 billion. The company, a manufacturer of asbestos fiber, changed its name to the Manville Corporation in 1980. It filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982, facing millions of dollars in claims over asbestos-related health problems. It is now called the Schuller Corporation of Denver.
In addition to his son, Douglas, of Denver, Mr. Goodwin is survived by a sister, Barbara Wood, of Vancouver, Wash., and a daughter, Barbara Goodwin of Menlo Park, Calif.

HEADLINE: Neighbors Mourn Loss Of Hospital In Queens;
Health Care Shift In Jackson Heights

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A lone guard watched over the lobby at Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens, detachedly pointing the infrequent visitor to two slow elevators. Behind him, the hospital's one telephone operator sat in a small office. They were the only people on the first floor, where in room after room, green beds were empty, eerily appropriate symbols for a hospital that is closing.
Upstairs, in a starkly furnished office, Dr. Muhammad N. Ali examined a handful of the patients who remained, including a diabetic woman recovering from an appendectomy. The 75-year-old woman, who spoke only Spanish, was typical of the patients Dr. Ali has seen in his six years at the hospital. Almost all live in the neighborhood, and many receive Medicaid or Medicare. 
 For generations, this small community hospital at 34th Avenue and 73d Street was what residents in Queens and the other boroughs outside Manhattan expected -- not a world-class teaching hospital married to an Ivy League school, but the corner hospital, where bones were reset after a fall from a jungle gym, and sisters and cousins were delivered by familiar doctors.
But to hospital administrators and government health officials, hospitals like Jackson Heights are indicative of the problems in what some consider to be the nation's most inefficient health care system. New York City's hospitals have merged feverishly, forming Byzantine networks to cope with price deregulation and growing pressure from health-maintenance organizations to cut costs.
And so, many experts say Jackson Heights is merely an early example of what will become an increasingly common occurrence: the disappearance of neighborhood hospitals in New York City, especially outside Manhattan.
Where local residents and hospital employees see only loss, outsiders see the elimination of excess fat. So it was perhaps no surprise when Jackson Heights' owners recently announced that it would be shuttered on Dec. 6, the first hospital in the city to close since Parsons Hospital in Queens in 1988, according to the State Health Department.
"It's not always glorious to be the first," said Stephen S. Mills, the president and chief executive of the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens in Flushing. The center was bought in 1992 by New York Hospital Care Network, which last April acquired three more hospitals in Queens: Jackson Heights, Flushing Hospital Medical Center and Little Neck Community Hospital. The network's flagship is the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
In the last few weeks, local politicians, union leaders and residents have lashed out at a series of announcements expected to reshape health care in Queens: Little Neck will close as a hospital on Dec. 3 and become an ambulatory care unit, serving only outpatients, and Jackson Heights will close. Flushing has already lost beds and staff. In all, about 700 jobs and 190 beds will be eliminated.
Cynthia Banton, a registered nurse who has worked at Jackson Heights Hospital for five years and has lived in the neighborhood for 13, was one of the hospital's 259 employees to lose their jobs. Her anxieties, though, went beyond work.
"I'm very sad not only from the standpoint that I will be unemployed, but also because I am a resident of Jackson Heights," she said, adding that most of her colleagues lived in the area. "The only other hospital around here is Elmhurst. It's going to be pretty congested, and that bothers me. People might be forced to wait for a long time there, or they'll have to take a long trip to see a doctor. It's like double trouble."
For Both Sides, A Case of Necessity
A confluence of economic forces makes the cuts necessary, Mr. Mills said. Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements have been reduced, and H.M.O.'s are forcing New York State hospitals to cut costs, as they have elsewhere in the country for years.
What is more, hospitals will enter the new world of the free market on Jan. 1, as price controls on medical procedures are lifted. All of this is occurring, health experts say, in a city with too many hospitals competing for too few patients.
This year, before the announcement that it would close, Jackson Heights' 83 beds had a 54 percent occupancy rate, according to hospital documents. The institution needed $20 million in renovations to comply with health and safety codes, said a hospital spokeswoman, Spencine Laster-Hendricks.
"It's beyond the scope of anyone's ability to put forth that kind of money," Mr. Mills said.
Doctors and nurses at Jackson Heights, while acknowledging the empty beds, said the current and previous owners never seriously tried to attract patients.
They said theirs was a true community hospital, drawing almost all of its patients from the neighborhood. Although some older European immigrants still come, most of the patients belong to Jackson Heights' new groups: Ecuadoreans, Colombians, Dominicans, Indians, Bangladeshis, Chinese and Koreans. Dr. Ali described them as the working poor, people who are self-employed or who work at small companies with no benefits -- in short, people with few health-care options besides the corner hospital.
Shortly after Dr. Ali arrived at Jackson Heights in 1990, about 20 people a week came to the clinic, he said. Recently, the number was about 30 a day, said Dr. Ali, who is now the director of clinics.
"If they didn't have insurance, we said, 'Pay what you can,' " said Dr. Ali, whose interview was interrupted every few minutes by unscreened phone calls from patients. "These people, they're like my family."

Trying to Replace Tradition and Trust
Jackson Heights Hospital was founded in 1990. Physicians Hospital, its predecessor in the building, opened in 1935 after the subway line first reached the area and Jackson Heights grew into a real community.
It is not yet clear what will happen to the building, which occupies one block in a residential area.
Jose Ortiz, 21, grew up a block away from the hospital after his parents immigrated from Colombia. On a recent visit to the clinic with his wife, Emily Tan, also 21, he rolled up his right sleeve to reveal an old scar on his wrist, the result of tripping on a broken bottle at the age of 13. A Jackson Heights surgeon had closed the gash with five stitches. "This is really going to be a loss for the community, especially the emergency room," Mr. Ortiz said. "You knew the place and the staff."
Later, he went to visit his sister, Eliana Ortiz, 20, who worked for a podiatrist across the street and who was six months pregnant. "Where will I go now for an emergency, with the baby?" Ms. Ortiz asked.
To assuage such anxieties, New York Hospital Care Network has been placing full-page ads in community newspapers. They do not mention Jackson Heights or budget cuts, but focus on the three institutions that represent the network's medical base in Queens.
Mr. Mills said New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, which was formerly Booth Memorial Medical Center, will become the network's second nerve center, to coordinate care for patients there as well as for some of the Flushing and Little Neck patients. (The network's chief center is New York-Cornell.)
Mr. Mills added that the network is also interested in acquiring Elmhurst Hospital Center and Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, two municipal hospitals that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to sell. The board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation approved a lease last week for a private company to take over Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn, another institution the Mayor sought to put in private hands. Should the Queens hospitals be sold to New York Hospital, the network's hospitals would form a triangle at the heart of Queens, for the most part a solidly middle-class area.
For now, Mr. Mills said, the network is trying to improve care and efficiency at its Queens hospitals. The New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens and Flushing Hospital, which are less than a mile from each other and which had begun separate renovation programs, will be meshed so that medical procedures now offered at both will be consolidated at one. Those and other savings will eventually make Flushing Hospital profitable, Mr. Mills said, adding that the hospital is expected to lose $17 million this year.
Because of the Queens hospitals' affiliation with New York-Cornell, patients will also have local access to procedures they have traditionally sought in Manhattan, Mr. Mills said. For example, the expansion of the cardiac surgery site at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens will mean that most heart operations will be handled in the borough. What is more, Mr. Mills said, the network plans to develop an intensive pediatric care unit for extremely sick children, who now have to travel to Manhattan or to Long Island Jewish Medical Center on the border of Queens and Nassau counties.
Dr. Barbara DeBuono, the State Health Commissioner, said: "The residents of Queens should expect more of these specialty services will now be based in Queens, but they won't be duplicated in Queens."
Dr. DeBuono said Queens still had an excess of a few hundred beds. In the first quarter of this year, the borough's 5,284 beds had an occupancy rate of 79.4 percent, according to state figures.

Back at the Hospital, Wounds to Heal
Perhaps because the elimination of beds is the most visible sign of a shrinking system and usually entails job losses, Queens officials and union leaders have condemned all cuts.
"I believe Queens has always been underbedded and underserved," said the Borough President, Claire Shulman, who worked as a registered nurse before entering politics. "It's going to be especially hard on Queens. I have the largest number of senior citizens in New York City, and they usually require more medical care than younger folks." According to the 1990 Federal Census, 286,248 of the borough's 1,951,598 residents were age 65 or over -- about 15 percent, a higher ratio than in any other borough.
Dennis Rivera, the president of Local 1199 of the Hospital and Human Service Employees Union, which he said represents about 2,000 workers at three of New York Hospital Care Network's sites in Queens, accused the network of trying to create a monopoly in northeast Queens.
"It is now an area dominated by New York Hospital," Mr. Rivera said. "And they have these very aggressive tactics of buying up and shutting down community hospitals so that they can take those patients to their main campuses. They're doing what's already happened all over the country."
At Jackson Heights Hospital, new patients have not been admitted for the last few weeks and, with only about 10 of the 83 beds occupied, most of the hospital is "like a ghost town," Dr. Ali said. Patients recently began receiving fliers advising them of the closing and referring them to three other hospitals.
Ms. Ortiz said she had started going to Flushing Hospital for prenatal care. Her brother and his wife, who had not heard of the impending closing, said they now understood why they had been referred to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Instead of a two-minute walk, a visit to Wyckoff had taken the couple an hour on two subway lines.
Dr. Ali, who is disgusted with the health care industry's increasing focus on the bottom line, said he had rejected several job offers from other hospitals. A few weeks ago, Dr. Ali, who lives in Jackson Heights, opened a private practice in a basement office a few blocks south of the hospital.
As the 75-year-old diabetic woman left his office, Dr. Ali told her, a little hopefully: "You have to stick to one doctor. Take all the medication as directed. After the hospital closes, you can come to me. Or you can go somewhere else."

HEADLINE: U.S. Leaves Its Mark On Politics In Britain

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The leading candidate is talkative and telegenic, he likes rock music, and his wife is a lawyer with a lucrative private practice. He promises a "covenant" with the public in a tub-thumping style that has been likened to revival-meeting preaching, and he has made a concerted election-season move to the middle, co-opting positions of the more conservative rival party.
The governing party is campaigning to gain the credit it feels it is due from voters in exchange for nearly four years of economic growth, and party leaders hope that this will impress voters more than the ongoing legislative investigations of "sleaze" in government. 
 Both parties vie to be identified as the champions of morality and family values, and the candidates are pressed to declare themselves on the issue of abortion.
To a degree that is provoking much comment and some dismay from Britons, the campaign for the British general election is following many of the trends and employing many of the techniques of the campaign that ended Tuesday in the United States.
Among the issues that John Major, the Conservative Prime Minister, and Tony Blair, the Labor Party leader, are debating are welfare reform, gun control, medical care, education and school safety, tax cuts, crime, drug use, and school dress codes. Of course, this is still Britain, so they are also debating whether or not the country should bring back caning as a punishment for delinquent students.
In the last week both parties have moved vigorously to respond to an appeal made by the widow of a London headmaster killed by a student -- for an ethical renaissance. In one attempt to address that issue, the Government began discussing how to reduce the level of violence shown on television and in film.
Mr. Major must call an election by May and will probably wait until then, even though two recent deaths of Tory members have reduced his party's majority in Parliament to one seat. He can rely on the nine members of Parliament from the Ulster Unionist Party to keep the Conservatives in power even if he loses his majority, and he needs as much time as possible to overtake Mr. Blair, whose lead in the most recent Marketing and Research International poll is up to 28 points.
Much is being made of the resonance of the American race in British politics. When Mr. Major and Mr. Blair interrupted their party conference speeches with confessional stories about youthful hard knocks, commentators promptly termed the tactic "American style."
When they appeared on stage, kissing their wives at the festive conclusions of the party gatherings, comparisons were immediately made to the similar practice in the United States. "You never saw that kind of public cuddling at party conferences before," said Anthony King, a professor of government at the University of Essex.
Norma Major has in recent months emerged from the private, suburban housewife's life she had maintained to give interviews and make public appearances. The Prime Minister has called her his "secret weapon" in the race against Mr. Blair, whose wife, Cherie Booth, is a high-powered London lawyer with a sparkling academic background and roots in Labor's socialist past.
Well-worn phrases from American public life abound. Mr. Major told his party that "the buck stops here." Mr. Blair told his that "we have little to fear but fear itself."
When Mr. Blair accused Mr. Major of introducing class differences into the race, he called it "totally American-style negative campaigning." The people behind the candidates here are now being referred to as "spin doctors."
None of this is accidental. Both parties actively study the practices they are busy disparaging. Brian Mawhinney, the Conservative Party chairman, and Danny Finkelstein, the Tories' chief strategist, have been frequent visitors to Republican Party events in the United States, and Philip Gould, the Labor Party's director of polling, has just returned from Washington, where he hobnobbed with his counterparts in the Clinton campaign.
Professor King, a Canadian who has been here 40 years, was dubious. "Every British election is described as more Presidential than the one before, and it's always untrue," he said. "One hundred years ago people were making judgments based on the personalities of Gladstone and Disraeli."
But if American notions of marketing political candidates haven't taken over the British political debate, how then to explain what The Financial Times, probably Britain's most serious newspaper, put on its front page Wednesday. The paper reported that as a result of a recent poll showing that Mr. Blair's electoral appeal to women was lagging, the candidate was changing his hairdo.
