HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: THE CONSTITUENCIES;
The Expanding Hispanic Vote Shakes Republican Strongholds

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: GARDEN GROVE, Calif., Nov. 9

 BODY:
The results of Tuesday's balloting around the country made clear that the Democratic-leaning Hispanic vote is becoming an ever larger factor in American politics, nowhere more so than here in Orange County, the sprawling suburb south of Los Angeles that has traditionally been an icon of conservative Republicanism.
In Orange County, as elsewhere in California, and in states like Arizona, Texas and Florida, Hispanic voters showed up at the polls in record numbers, giving President Clinton 72 percent of their ballots. They also gave many other Democratic candidates in Federal, state and local races strong support and, in some cases, the edge needed for victory. 
 At scores of polling places, election officials reported a surge in the number of Hispanic voters, compared with the number four years earlier. Their ranks swelled close to 30 percent nationwide because of citizenship campaigns, registration drives, get-out-the-vote efforts and fears about tight new immigration strictures being advocated by Republicans.
In many states -- Connecticut, Indiana, Nevada, New York and Wyoming, to name a few -- as well as in any number of cities, towns and counties, heavy Hispanic voting helped dozens of Hispanic candidates win election, or, in many cases, re-election, to legislatures, councils, committees and boards.
"It was a watershed day," said Cecilia Munoz, a leader of La Raza, a group based in Washington that pushes Hispanic causes.
For example, in Orange County -- the fifth-most-populous county in the nation, with 2.5 million people, and a county in which Republican Presidential candidates usually must get at least two-thirds of the vote to carry the rest of the state -- a heavy Hispanic vote on Tuesday helped Mr. Clinton hold Bob Dole's winning margin to just a hair over half the vote.
The President won California easily, his big majorities in the Democratic strongholds of Los Angeles and San Francisco never threatened by the diminished Republican numbers from Orange County, which once had few members of minorities but is now 25 percent Hispanic.
Also in Orange County, the heavy Hispanic vote enabled a Hispanic Democrat, Loretta Sanchez, to come within a mere 233 votes of unseating Representative Robert K. Dornan, one of the most conservative Republicans in Congress.
What is more, with 10,000 absentee ballots to be counted in Mr. Dornan's district, Ms. Sanchez may yet oust Mr. Dornan, a nine-term legislator whose hard-right, often bombastic ideology had made him one of the county's most entrenched officials.
In Arizona, a state that had not gone Democratic in a Presidential election since 1948, a heavy Hispanic vote helped Mr. Clinton eke out a narrow 47 to 44 percent win over Mr. Dole.
In Florida, which has been Republican country for the last two decades of Presidential elections, a heavy Hispanic vote -- helped by a switch to the Democratic column by many of the usually conservative Cuban-Americans -- pushed Mr. Clinton to a victory of 48 to 42 percent.
Over all, Hispanic voters account for about 5 percent of the voting population of the United States; that figure rises to almost 10 percent in Arizona, about 12 percent in Texas and nearly 15 percent in California. But until this year, Hispanic voters lagged well behind most of the American population in election participation, being only about 80 percent as likely to register to vote as most other Americans.
According to election specialists and students of Hispanic affairs, the increased number of Hispanic voters on Tuesday resulted from a sharp increase in the number of Hispanic immigrants becoming citizens and a push by Democrats to get them registered and get them to the polls.
The big presence also resulted, the experts say, from deep concern among the Hispanic population that Republicans are intent on cutting Hispanic immigration and reducing civil rights protections and welfare benefits for immigrants already in the country, including those who arrived legally. That concern ran especially deep in California, where a ballot initiative, Proposition 187, proposed immigration strictures so severe that it drew attention well beyond California's borders.
As for the raw numbers of Hispanics who voted on Tuesday, surveys found that in Texas, the Hispanic part of the vote increased almost 60 percent this year, compared with the the fall of 1992. In California, the increase was 40 percent; in Florida, it was 10 percent.
Equally important, the surveys found that while the Republicans had sometimes picked up as many as one of every three Hispanic votes, and sometimes more, in earlier elections, Mr. Clinton got roughly three out of four Hispanic votes this time around, a good 15 percentage points better than his 1992 showing.
"The Republicans once could compete for our vote, but now it's clear that they're facing a powerful and united bloc of opposition from us," said Antonio Gonzalez, the president of the Southwest Voter Research Institute of San Antonio, Tex., a group that tracks Hispanic political participation. "And since 1992, we've done more than just increase our raw numbers of voters by close to a third. Our voter turnout rate also increased this fall."
Election Day poll surveys by the institute and other organizations found that although Tuesday was, over all, one of the worst voter turnout days in modern American political history, there nevertheless was a notable increase in Hispanic turnout, from about three-fourths of the national turnout rate in 1992 to close to par with that rate this year.
Still, Hispanic turnout continued to lag seriously in some areas, even in parts of Orange County.
For example, in Representative Dornan's district -- which has become almost 50 percent Hispanic in recent years, with many members of the community struggling economically -- the Hispanic turnout rate was only about two-thirds that of non-Hispanics. Had Hispanic voters turned out at the same rate as non-Hispanic voters, Ms. Sanchez would probably be on her way to Washington.
"But even with this kind of lagging turnout, there's no getting around the increasing Latino power here and elsewhere," said Ken Khachigian, the Orange County lawyer and political consultant who directed the Dole campaign in California. "They came close to getting Dornan on Election Day, and if they had turned out like they should have, he'd be gone for sure by now, however the absentee ballot count might go. Hispanics are something Republicans are going to have to come to grips with."
Bob Mulholland, one of the California Democratic Party's top political planners, argues that Tuesday's voting made clear "for all but the blind" that the Hispanic vote is now an important part of the Democratic base, especially in California.
"And it'll stay that way as long as Democrats respond to Latino concerns," he said.
On Wednesday, the 43 newly elected and re-elected Democrats in the 80-member California State Assembly -- which now has 14 Hispanic members -- responded in a big way.
Having just regained control of the Assembly, they made their first order of business the election of a Speaker. And in so doing they also made Golden State history, choosing the state's first Hispanic Speaker: Cruz Bustamante of Fresno.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ELECTION: THE NUMBERS;
Portrait of the Electorate

BYLINE: By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
As in 1992, Bill Clinton won re-election without a majority of the popular vote. He was able to hold on to the support of many of the demographic groups who elected him President in the first place and, in some cases, increase his share of their votes. Women, blacks, young voters, Democrats and liberals all gave Mr. Clinton a majority of their votes. He did well with swing groups, like independents and suburbanites. Bob Dole's best showing was with conservatives, Republicans and white Protestants. Ross Perot received only 8 percent, down from 19 percent in 1992.
This table, based on surveys of voters leaving polling stations throughout the country, shows how 120 demographic groups have voted for President since 1972. The political equivalent of sports box scores or stock market listings, this table can help readers make their own interpretations about what happened on election night. 
 The exit polls used to draw this portrait of voters are based on large numbers of respondents, making it possible to measure the preferences of some groups, like Jewish and Asian voters, or young women or conservative Democrats, whose portion of the voting population makes them too small to examine in typical telephone surveys.

The Gender Gap
The gender gap, the difference between a candidate's votes from men and his votes from women, was first noted in 1980, when men were 8 percentage points more likely to support Ronald Reagan than women were. Since then, the gender gap has ranged from 4 to 7 points in magnitude.
This year there is an 11-point gap among Mr. Clinton's voters. A gender gap is seen in all age groups, from 17 points between men and women under 30, to 8 points for those aged 45 to 59. The gender gap persists even among black voters, who supported Mr. Clinton very strongly over all.

Party Identification And Ideology
In the 1996 election, Mr. Clinton was more successful at holding the votes of self-described Democrats than he was the last time around. In the end Mr. Dole was supported by most Republicans. But while Democrats who described themselves as conservative strongly supported their party's ticket, Republicans who characterized their political ideology as liberal were closely divided between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole.
Independent voters in 1992 split their votes evenly among the three candidates, but this year only 17 percent of them supported Mr. Perot, while Mr. Clinton's share of their vote increased to 43 percent. Mr. Clinton did particularly well with liberal and moderate independents, while Mr. Dole was favored by independents who described themselves as conservative.

Pocketbook Concerns
Incumbents usually win the support of voters who say their own finances have improved during a President's tenure. Four years ago, for example, George Bush was backed by voters who said their family's finances were better than four years earlier, and Mr. Clinton won the support of those who characterized their situation as declining. This year, the reverse was true. Mr. Clinton, the incumbent, got two-thirds of the votes from those who said their personal economics had improved, while Bob Dole won the support of people whose economic condition had deteriorated.
Over all, the number of people who see their economic situation as worsening dropped from a third of all voters to a fifth, and those who perceive their finances in a positive fashion increased from a quarter to a third of all voters. MARJORIE CONNELLY

HEADLINE: Close to Panama, Dreaming of Rival 'Canals'

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
From the moment it opened in 1914, the Panama Canal has been the envy of nearby countries. For centuries, their governments dreamed of waterways of their own across the Central American isthmus and of the prosperity and power that so busy and vital a trade route would surely bestow on them.
Now, a century after the intrigue among great powers that enabled the United States to elbow out France and Britain as the builder of the magnificent "path between the seas" -- which generated $486 million in tolls in the last year -- Panama's neighbors think they have a second chance. 
 Seizing on political and technical uncertainties about the canal's future once the United States transfers it to Panamanian control three years from now, they are once again dreaming.
But this time, because of cost concerns and environmental restraints, they imagine not a gigantic waterway but a series of "dry canals" -- light rail lines for container traffic -- that would be cheaper and easier to build. And though foreign powers are once more actively involved in the maneuvering, this time the principal players are China, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea, not the United States or Europe.
Just as in the 19th century, Nicaragua has quickly emerged as Panama's main rival.
In August, the Government there signed an agreement with an international consortium, backed by East Asian and Nicaraguan interests that argue that shippers are hungry for cheaper, quicker and more secure alternatives to the Panama Canal. The plan envisions a privately built $1.6 billion rail link across southern Nicaragua.
"You cannot look at this project isolated from its geopolitical context," Juan Carlos Rivas, general manager of the Consortium for the Inter-Oceanic Canal of Nicaragua S.A., as the group is formally known, said in an interview.
"The world's great powers are looking to Central America as one of their bases to compete in the 21st century, so this is not just an economic issue. There are large political and strategic interests here too."
For the immediate future, the Panama Canal, which handled 198 million tons of cargo and more than 13,500 ships in the last year, will clearly remain the main trade route in the region.
But with commerce and container shipments booming, especially between East Asia and North and Latin America, the search for choices other than the canal and container shipments by rail across the United States is already under way.
"It's all going to depend on the economics, but we feel there have to be more and better options to move global trade from Asia and Europe to both coasts of the United States," said J. T. Keegan Jr., vice president and director of Latin American operations for Sea-Land Service Inc., the giant American ocean freight company that pioneered the use of containers. "There's been tremendous growth in trade in the region, so yes, we are looking for alternatives."

The Existing Canal Has Its Drawbacks
Pointing to toll increases and "recent instances of delays in the canal" because of congestion, Mr. Keegan said his main consideration was being able to "transit between the Atlantic and the Pacific as efficiently and reliably as possible." He also mentioned the Panama Canal's "engineering limitations and maintenance problems."
Those problems include the supply of water, sedimentation and the need to build a new set of locks early in the 21st century, an estimated $7 billion investment, compared with the original $380 million cost of the canal's construction.
Then, too, there is the issue of the new generation of cargo vessels that are simply too wide to fit through the Panama Canal but might find a Central American port and light-rail project attractive.
"Obviously the ships we are building today cannot transit the canal," said John Urban, vice president for Latin American services at American Pacific Lines, a large shipper based in Oakland, Calif. "They're too large, and the operators who are commissioning these ships are planning around that, assuming that they will serve trade routes that don't require transit of the Panama Canal."

Panama Intends To Be Competitive
Alberto Aleman Zubieta, a Panamanian engineer who became the Administrator of the Panama Canal in August, said he was very much aware of those concerns among shippers. For that reason, he added, the canal commission has begun an $895 million improvement and modernization program to increase the canal's capacity by 20 percent and allow it to remain competitive with any potential rivals.
"We understand that we do not have a monopoly in this business," said Mr. Aleman, who studied industrial and civil engineering at Texas A & M University before returning here to head a construction firm. "We understand all too well that the Panama Canal needs to remain efficient, safe and reliable for shippers, and that we need to give high-quality service to our customers."
But for the East Asian countries that are increasingly large users of the canal as their trade with Latin America and the United States expands at a double-digit annual pace, the issue is more than just one of dollars and cents. Eager to gain a foothold in the region, China in particular has strategic and political interests at stake.
Its archrival, Taiwan, has diplomatic relations with all of the Central American countries and has forged a particularly close relationship with Panama.
Taiwanese companies, for instance, have signed agreements to build an industrial park outside Colon, near the former United States submarine base that Taiwan's flourishing Evergreen Shipping Group is converting into a container terminal.
"Other shipping lines worry that when the canal goes over to Panamanian control, they are going to be second fiddle to Evergreen, or at least that is what I hear," said Don M. Bosco, an American lawyer who is president of the Nicaraguan consortium. "Whether that's real or imagined, I don't know, but I do know that shipping from mainland China has expanded tremendously in the last 10 years."
Lee Teng-hui, the President of Taiwan, is among the leaders who have been invited to take part in a conference here next summer about the future of the Panama Canal, and has already indicated he will attend. China, though the third-biggest user of the canal, has not been invited and has managed only to get Panama to agree to open companion trade offices here and in Beijing.

Concern From Asia At Taiwan's Clout
In what was seen as an effort to match Taiwan's influence in the region, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea made official visits to Central America this summer.
In addition, the Japan Container Association, the Port of Tianjin Authority, China Merchants Holding Ltd. of Hong Kong and the China Marine and Seamen Service Corporation are members of the "operations consortium" supporting the Nicaraguan rail project, for which a feasibility study is under way.
An Asian diplomat in the region said: "In today's world there is no real difference between the political and the commercial. Taiwan has $100 billion in foreign reserves and has used that to gain political leverage and advantage. Beijing can see that, doesn't like it and worries that it will be frozen out of the picture unless it has allies."
With the corruption and repression of the Noriega era in mind, Panama's rivals also appear to be playing on concerns about political stability here. Since the signing of the Panama Canal treaties in 1977, the canal has been run as a nonprofit American Government agency, with a binational board of directors approved by the United States Senate.

A Debate Over Use Of Canal Income
But at noon on Dec. 31, 1999, control of the canal and the last of the American military bases in the former Canal Zone are to pass to the Government of Panama. Already some Panamanian politicians have suggested that part of the canal revenues should be diverted into Government projects rather than reinvested in the canal, and that the watershed and surrounding jungle be made available to poor Panamanians.
Mr. Aleman vowed that would not happen and promised that the canal would be run as impartially and efficiently as it always had. "This is an ongoing operation," he said, "and we are not going to be stopping in the year 2000 and shifting gears."
Nevertheless, how Panama intends to administer the canal "is a source of concern as we go forward" toward the turnover, Mr. Keegan of Sea-Land said. "We are hearing all the right things" from the Panamanian Government, he added, "but time will have to show us."
Hoping to take advantage of that transition and the uncertainties that it has begun to generate among shippers, every country in Spanish-speaking Central America has floated at least one plan to build an alternative to the Panama Canal.

'These Are All Very Old Schemes'
In Costa Rica, the Parliament in 1992 approved construction of a 250-mile rail line to run near the Nicaraguan border -- but has done nothing since. In El Salvador, the port commission has recommended construction of a 225-mile container rail system with neighboring Honduras, to run between the Gulf of Fonseca and Puerto Cortes on the Caribbean.
Guatemalan business interests have come forward with a $1 billion plan to revive moribund trans-isthmus rail lines in that country, first built for banana producers.
Colombia, which fumed helplessly when Panama seceded as part of a Washington-sponsored rebellion 93 years ago and continues to resent that loss, has even more ambitious ideas. President Ernesto Samper has called for construction of a full-scale, navigable interoceanic canal through the Darien region in the country's isolated and sparsely populated northwestern corner.
Even in Mexico there has been talk of building a "dry canal" across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in the southern part of the country.
But the eruption of two leftist guerrilla insurgencies in that region and natural geographic barriers make potential investors and rivals as skeptical of the prospects of that proposal as they are of most of the others.
"These are all very old schemes, and no, I don't really take any of them seriously," Mr. Aleman said during a recent interview in his office here, overlooking the busy waterway.
But when pressed, he acknowledged that Panama could thank an accident of history for its advantage over Nicaragua and that the competition this time might yet prove equally fierce.
In the late 19th century, American business executives actually began building a canal across Nicaragua, and a Congressional commission favored that route because it would require less digging than a canal across Panama. The Panamanians eventually won the day, though, by arguing that their route was safer and by producing a Nicaraguan postage stamp showing an erupting volcano as proof.
"We beat the Nicaraguans by a stamp," Mr. Aleman said with a smile.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Green Light Caper

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Returning from Richard Nixon's funeral on Air Force One, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott told National Security Adviser Tony Lake that Croatia had asked our ambassador for approval to smuggle Iranian arms into Bosnia -- thereby breaking the embargo foolishly agreed to by the U.S. and its allies.
State's notion was a deniable double-cross, kept secret from the oversight committees of Congress: give the Croats a green light, and never mind the influence Iran would gain on the European continent. 
 Lake circumvented the Defense Department and C.I.A. by going into the President's cabin and getting Clinton's personal approval to instruct our ambassador to pretend he had "no instructions."
This put the President in the position of telling the American public that we could not break the embargo for fear of endangering the lives of our British and French allies -- while encouraging a third party to endanger their lives.
Maybe Talbott, Lake and Clinton naively thought the green light could be kept secret from our allies, our own Government and the press. But the C.I.A. officials on the scene soon detected the widespread smuggling, and worried -- quite properly -- that a covert action was under way.
C.I.A. asked and was misled by State. The Joint Chiefs were kept in the dark. When The L.A. Times broke the story this spring, Mr. Clinton slipped past his tacit approval and held that "there was absolutely nothing improper done."
Congress investigated. House Intelligence oversight last month condemned the end run by State as having "recklessly endangered American lives" and asked that Justice examine false testimony for criminal action.
The bipartisan Senate Select Intelligence Committee waited until the election was over before issuing a report agonizing over whether the knowing deception of our allies, the world press and our own armed forces constituted a "covert action." That would have required a "finding" signed by the President and transmitted in timely fashion to Congress.
Most senators on the committee tut-tutted about the Administration's public lying. They were irritated at the Intelligence Oversight Board's refusal to share its internal report, and criticized the bureaucratic infighting and Administration trickiness in putting no deliberations on such a serious matter in writing. But was the green light a "covert action" or merely "traditional diplomatic activity"? The committee was ambivalent.
The one dumb line in the Senate committee report was that the consequences of the secret green light were "on one level, a complete success" -- that is, the flow of Iranian arms discouraged the Serbs from attacking the Muslims.
Some "success": to this day, the U.S. has been constrained from taking over the arming of Bosnian Muslims because Iran's friend is their deputy Defense Minister. Our strategy of sending $400 million worth of weapons to preserve the Bosnian balance of power has been stymied by this "complete success."
What is bad about this intelligence argument between our branches is that it is about legalities and not realities. Forget about criminality here. Ask instead: In Clinton's covert flashing of the green light, was "absolutely nothing improper" done, as he insists?
If that is what Talbott, Lake and Clinton believe, the necessary nonpartisan comity between the branches on intelligence will give way to further mistrust, tighter laws and insistence on prosecution.
Diplomacy is not missionary work, to paraphrase a devotee of deviousness. But to betray allies, to lie to the American public, to deceive the Pentagon and to mislead Congress in one fell swoop is wrong and counterproductive and must not be repeated.
Trust counts. The New York Times's Chris Hedges reports now that Muslim nations are smuggling heavy arms into Bosnia; does anybody believe the State Department denial?
And the President says post-election "it is conceivable that we could participate" in keeping our forces in Bosnia long beyond the promised year. Does anybody believe that is not a done deal?
Breaking faith has its consequences.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Whitman Stresses Trade, Planting a Tree in Israel

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: MODIIN, Israel, Nov. 10

 BODY:
As Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey planted a tree here this afternoon that she said symbolized life in the rocky soil of a new forest here, Israeli soldiers faced angry Palestinians just three miles away in the West Bank after a deadly clash over disputed land.
The coincidence was symbolic of the undertones accompanying Governor Whitman's six-day trade mission to Israel, which has taken her beyond the problems of state government and into the raw conflicts of the Middle East. 
 Since arriving in Israel last Friday as the head of a delegation of business leaders and university officials from New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman has said that she had come to encourage trade and investment between New Jersey and Israel, and to strengthen economic, scientific and cultural links between the two governments.
In public statements and appearances before Israeli business leaders, the Governor and her aides have repeated that Israel is New Jersey's sixth largest trading partner, buying almost $750 million worth of its products, especially transportation and electronic equipment and indusrial machinery. Thirty Israeli companies have invested in New Jersey, the two sides have a sister-state agreement and a New Jersey trade office operates in the Israeli town of Raanana, north of Tel Aviv.
Today, the Governor discussed further business ties in a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and signed the first of three economic memorandums of understanding with Israel -- an agreement with the Minister of Trade and Industry, Natan Sharansky, to promote joint research and development projects in high technology fields like computers, software and medical tecnhology.
In a series of planned business meetings, the New Jersey delegation will try to market, among other goods, telecommunications and security technologies to the Israeli army.
But for all the economic activity, Mrs. Whitman also seemed to be sending a distinct political message of support for Israel that could not fail to resonate with Jewish voters back home who gave her relatively few votes in the 1993 gubernatorial election.
The Governor has acknowledged that her interest in Israel stems not only from economic ties but also from the sizable Jewish population in New Jersey, two of whose members have died in bombings in Israel and the Gaza Strip. She plans to visit a memorial in Raanana to Alisa Flatow, a student from West Orange, N.J., who was killed in an attack in April 1995.
But Mrs. Whitman has studiously avoided depicting her trip as an attempt to court the Jewish vote.
Sitting next to Prime Minister Netanyahu against a background of Israeli flags today, the Governor was asked by a reporter whether she was sending a signal to her Jewish constituents. "Anything I do and anywhere I go is, I guess, a signal to somebody somewhere," she replied to the applause of the delegation.
However, Arab-American leaders in New Jersey have voiced concerns over the Governor's plans to visit the Israeli-held Golan Heights and an Israeli archeological tunnel running near Muslim shrines on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. The opening of a new exit to the tunnel by the Israelis in September set off three days of deadly clashes between Israeli and Palestinian forces in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Today, Governor Whitman said she had not yet decided whether to go ahead with the visit to the tunnel, which she has characterized as a purely private tour of a historic site. Her aides now say a back ailment, diagnosed as a herniated disk, nd a tight schedule may prevent Mrs. Whitman from making the trip.
As for a planned army-escorted tour of the Golan Heights, a plateau captured from Syria in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war and later annexed by Israel, the Governor appeared to have no qualms. "It is part of Israel at this point in time," she said. "It is, yes, a part that is being negotiated, but the facts of the administration of the Golan are very clear right now, and it certainly is important to understanding the whole future and what is being discussed right now for the State of Israel."
The Governor and her aides have also had to explain the absence of any planned meetings with the Palestinian Authority, now a common stop during visits here by foreign dignitaries. They reply that New Jersey has no history of trade with the Palestinian areas, while Israel is a major export market, but they promised to meet Palestinian Authority officials in the United States.
Other elements of Mrs. Whitman's agenda have been carefully balanced to reflect the diversity of opinion in Israel. After meeting Mr. Netanyhau, she made a pilgrimage to the grave of the assassinated prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and went on to meet the leader of the opposition Labor party, former Prime Minister Shimon Peres.
At Mr. Rabin's grave at the Mount Herzl cemetery in Jerusalem, Mrs. Whitman and her husband, John, stood for a long moment of silence, gazing at the basalt-and-limestone tomb on which she had placed a stone in keeping with Jewish custom.
This, the Governor said, was "a symbolic gesture, being one with earth, and one with the past and future of Israel."

HEADLINE: A 10,000-Year-Old Site Yields Trove of Data in Florida

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
Finding what they are calling a 10,000-year-old underwater time capsule, scientists at the University of Florida think they have caught a rare glimpse of how people in North America responded to the last catastrophic climate change, at the end of the most recent Ice Age.
With the onset of warmer temperatures, their world changed all around them. As distant glaciers melted, the sea rose and encroached on their land. The savanna they once knew in what is now the Southeastern United States turned to thick forest, depriving them of familiar resources and offering new ones. And the mammoths and mastodons they hunted vanished. 
 Forced to give up big-game hunting, these Paleo-Indians looked for other food and settled into less nomadic lives. They began living in villages, developing new stone and bone tools and a variety of wooden implements. Adversity seemed to have stimulated innovation.
This moment of transition from the Ice Age to today's climate is unusually well preserved at a site in the Florida Panhandle, at the Aucilla River south of Tallahassee and near the town of Perry. The site was discovered by paleontologists and archeologists led by Dr. David Webb, an anthropology professor at the University of Florida in Gainesville.
Dr. Webb said the site appeared to have been a village by a pond, where people lived for only a few generations about 10,000 years ago. Then rising water levels probably flooded the village and sealed the remains under a protective layer of clay. There they remained undisturbed until now, and the clay seal was so tight that a surprising number of wooden artifacts survived.
These pieces, including what appear to be tent stakes, building poles and part of a canoe, are among the earliest preserved wooden artifacts. At most archeological sites of this age, such wooden materials have usually decayed long before.
"We are especially impressed by the density and diversity of all the artifacts," Dr. Webb said in an interview on Saturday.
Mark Muniz, a graduate student excavating and analyzing the site, said that radiocarbon dates showed that the settlement's existence was confined to a few generations and was never reoccupied later.
"Having such a short time period gives the rare opportunity to reconstruct how a specific group of Paleo-Indians in time were living and what they were manufacturing," Mr. Muniz said. "And this is such an extraordinarily rich accumulation that it feels as if we're excavating right on their front porch."
Dr. Dennis Stanford, an anthropologist at the Smithsonian Institution, who specializes in Paleo-Indian cultures, agreed that the site could provide an incomparable picture of people adjusting to severe climate change, moving from Ice Age big-game hunting to a more settled life and diverse economy. Similar patterns have been detected in excavations in Texas, though those remains are not nearly as well preserved.
The new discovery, Dr. Stanford said, "sounds pretty exciting" and should yield many new insights into this critical period.
At the time, Paleo-Indians on the North American plains were still hunting large game like bison. In the Middle East, people were also beginning to settle into villages and experiment with growing crops and domesticating animals for food.
The Flordia archeologists found the new site by excavating the west bank of the Aucilla River at a water depth of about 15 feet. Before the end of the Ice Age, the Florida landscape was much drier, as determined by pollen samples, and the peninsula was nearly twice its present size. The village site was nearly 100 miles from the coast then, compared to its present distance of five miles from the Gulf of Mexico.
So far, the archeologists have found that a large but uncounted number of people lived close together in the village, in contrast to the nomadic ways of only a few generations before. Around an intact hearth were remains of past meals, including a roasted turtle bone. Arrowheads and spear points made of flint -- but unlike the Clovis-style points of earlier big-game hunters -- were uncovered, as well as stone tools.
Dr. Webb estimated that the artifact density at this site is at least 20 times greater than in lower layers representing occupations by earlier people. The excavations are supported in part by the National Geographic Society.
Brinnen Carter, another graduate student studying the site, said the evidence showed these people to be learning how to survive on smaller animals and different plants. "Essentially, they were the first humans that weren't big-game hunters," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two University of Florida researchers, Brinnen Carter and Mark Muniz, with artifacts that were found preserved in a layer of clay in the Florida panhandle near the town of Perry, south of Tallahassee, in the Aucilla River. The 10,000-year-old implements revealed details about life at the end of the last Ice Age. (Ray Carson)
 
Map of Florida shows the location of Perry.

HEADLINE: New Approach to Overhauling Health Insurance: Step by Step

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Mindful of lessons learned in the last four years, President Clinton and his aides are developing incremental proposals to fill gaps in health insurance coverage, Administration officials said.
The proposals, to help provide coverage for some of the nation's 10 million uninsured children and to help pay premiums for workers who are between jobs, look more feasible now because medical costs are coming under control. 
 The initiatives are part of what promises to be a full agenda of health care legislation in the next Congress.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview last week that the Administration would try to expand coverage step by step, rather than by proposing a grand scheme to redesign the health care system. Mr. Clinton suffered his biggest political defeat when Congress in 1994 rejected his plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans. The Administration has not decided how ambitious its new proposals will be, so it does not know how much they will cost and has not decided how to pay for them.
But Chris Jennings, a White House aide who coordinates health policy, said in a recent interview that the efforts would be carried out "in the context of a balanced budget."
The proposals on coverage for children come in response to recent studies showing an increase in the number of uninsured children and a gradual decline in the proportion of youngsters covered by private health insurance in recent years.
The Administration is considering two approaches. One is to make sure that all eligible children enroll in Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for low-income people. Nearly three million uninsured youngsters are entitled to Medicaid, but not enrolled.
The other approach is to help families buy private insurance for children who do not qualify for Medicaid.
A sharp reduction in health care inflation and in the rate of growth of Medicaid makes these and other proposals look financially feasible.
Pamela G. Bailey, president of the Health Care Leadership Council, composed of top executives from the industry, said: "Health cost increases have come under control. Filling the gaps in access to care will be a more affordable proposition in 1997 than it was in the 1980's, when employers were seeing health costs increase 20 percent a year."
The Administration will also propose legislation to control Medicare costs, by curbing payments to doctors and hospitals. In his re-election campaign, Mr. Clinton repeatedly accused Republicans of trying to destroy Medicare and said he would preserve it without increasing costs for the beneficiaries, who are elderly or disabled.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said Republicans would wait for the President to submit a detailed proposal before they take action on Medicare next year.
The President's efforts to expand coverage build on a new Federal law that will make health insurance more readily available to millions of people who change jobs or lose their jobs.
The law, pushed through Congress by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum and Edward M. Kennedy, does not regulate the price of insurance, which can easily exceed $300 a month and may reach $700 a month for a family of four in New York City. Accordingly, the Administration has devised a proposal to help pay health insurance premiums for up to six months for workers who are between jobs.
Mr. Jennings, the White House aide, said this "worker transition initiative" could help three million people a year, including 700,000 children.
Administration officials say they have been astonished by the slowdown in Medicaid costs. Medicaid grew an average of 17 percent a year from 1990 to 1995, and the Congressional Budget Office had been predicting growth of 10 percent a year from 1996 through 2002.
But in the fiscal year that ended six weeks ago, Federal Medicaid spending grew just 3 percent, perhaps because of greater use of managed care. Medicaid is so big, with Federal costs exceeding $90 billion a year, that even a modest reduction in the rate of growth produces huge savings, and the Administration wants to use some of those savings for its new health care initiatives.
A grab-bag of other health care issues will be waiting for the new Congress. The White House is working on a proposal to make it easier for small businesses to buy health insurance for their workers through voluntary purchasing coalitions. And the Labor Department is developing proposals to protect retiree health benefits, which many employers have cut or tried to cut.
In addition, health care executives expect numerous efforts by lawmakers from both parties to regulate health maintenance organizations.
Administration officials said they would renew their effort to prevent H.M.O.'s from limiting what doctors may tell patients about treatment options. Mr. Clinton recently denounced such "gag rules."
Some lawmakers also want to outlaw outpatient mastectomies, just as they required insurers to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care for new mothers and their babies.
"Congress is going to continue its march toward becoming the nation's benefits manager, following the precedent of the mandates it imposed this year," said James A. Klein, president of the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group composed mainly of Fortune 500 companies. "Congress has rejected the idea that employers must provide health insurance to employees. But if employers do provide coverage, Congress will specify how it should be designed."
President Clinton has said he will appoint a panel of experts to recommend ways of protecting consumers against changes in the health care industry that threaten the quality of care. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the panel would examine "the rapid growth of managed care and H.M.O.'s."
Labor union leaders said they would submit evidence to the panel showing that cutbacks in nursing personnel had damaged the quality of care at many hospitals. "We can provide dozens of examples of the human toll" of such cutbacks, said Kit Costello, president of the California Nurses Association.
The effort to help children is buttressed by a recent report from the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.
"The number of children without health insurance coverage was greater in 1994 than at any time in the last eight years," the accounting office said. "In 1994, the percentage of children under 18 years old without any health insurance coverage reached its highest level since 1987 -- 14.2 percent, or 10 million children who were uninsured." In addition, the report said, the proportion of children with private coverage decreased every year from 1989 to 1994.
The situation appeared to improve slightly last year. Preliminary data from the Census Bureau show that the number of uninsured children dipped in 1995 to 9.8 million, or 13.8 percent of all youngsters. But the increase was less than might have been expected in a strong economy, with more than a million new jobs, because many companies cut back coverage for children and spouses of employees.
The General Accounting Office said there were several possible explanations for the fact that eligible uninsured children were not enrolled in Medicaid:
*Some parents do not realize that their children may qualify, even if the parents work full time.
*"Getting enrolled in Medicaid is difficult for low-income families," many of whom are turned down because they fail to comply with procedural requirements.
*Some families see Medicaid as a welfare program and do not want to be stigmatized as relying on welfare.
For their part, state Medicaid officials want to be able to require the use of H.M.O.'s without getting permission from the Federal Government. Many states have received Federal approval, but state officials resent having to go through lengthy negotiations with the Federal Government.
Efforts to provide insurance for children, like many health care issues, raise complex technical questions.
Under current law, the Federal Government and the states share the cost of Medicaid. States have discretion over eligibility. Some deny coverage for children under the age of 6 if their family income is more than 33 percent above the Federal poverty level, while other states cover children with family income up to three times the poverty level.
Federal officials say they want to be sure that states do not cut back Medicaid eligibility if the Federal Government offers new forms of assistance to uninsured children. Through such cutbacks, states could substitute Federal dollars for state money.
Some state officials express concerns about the fairness and equity of any new program. It would be unfair, they say, for the Federal Government to provide more generous subsidies for the purchase of health insurance in states that have chosen to be stingy in spending their own money on child health and Medicaid.
Just three days before Congress adjourned, Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Kennedy introduced a bill to provide Federal money to the states to subsidize premiums for children with family incomes too high to qualify for Medicaid. The amount of the subsidy would be reduced as a family's income increased.
"The problem of uninsured children is getting worse, not better," Mr. Kerry said.

HEADLINE: The Harder Struggle to Make and Market Black Films

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
On Wednesday, "Set It Off," a bank-heist caper starring Queen Latifah, opened across the country. The story of four black women who clean office buildings by day and rob banks by night, it did $9 million at the box office in its first four days.
The film got strong reviews in newspapers, including a four-star rave in The Chicago Sun-Times and a favorable review in Entertainment Weekly. But if the film, which cost $9.5 million to make, brings a strong profit to New Line Pictures, it will be the exception rather than the rule. 
 "Set It Off" was directed by F. Gary Gray, who is black and whose crew was roughly 40 percent black. Moreover, it is what Jesse Rhines, author of "Black Film/ White Money," calls "a film that comes out of the African-American culture and presents a point of view that is a product of that culture."
 Mr. Rhines defines black films by saying their "director, writer and producer should be black, but certainly the director."
Despite the fact that black actors are moving increasingly into leading roles in mainstream movies, and the fact that blacks, while only 12 percent of the population, buy 25 percent of movie tickets, some experts agree with Mr. Rhines: "It has not gotten any easier than it was a decade ago to make culturally authentic films."
The casualty rate for all films is high -- 7 of 10 lose money. But executives who have tried to raise money for films that come out of the black culture say it remains especially difficult to get financing for those films, and so the chances of even getting that viewpoint before the public are as slim as they ever were.
Dale Pollock, producer of "Set It Off," said it took five years to raise the money for the movie, which was written and directed by blacks. In his view, studios resisted an action film that featured four black women. "Studio executives worried that women would not come to see an action film and the urban male audience would not go to a women's action film." He and the director persevered because, he said, "we believed it was a universal story that ultimately transcended race and a female buddy movie."
Bob Johnson, chairman of BET Holdings Inc., which owns Black Entertainment Television, the cable service, said he believed that both the culture and the economics of the film business were still serious hurdles to black film makers.
"Films are made by people who want to tell a particular story," Mr. Johnson said. "If you go to the studios with a story about blacks, often the white guy may say that is not a story he wants to tell. People tend to get involved with stories they know. A studio says: we are going to make 25 films a year. Take 15 off the table for bread-and- butter films, then there are 10 films left, and a guy may make some films with people he has cut deals with before." The number available for black movies is reduced further by "projects he wants to make," and so when the last choices are made, the decision is often limited to the one that "sounds like it will work better for a white audience."
Another problem has been the difficulty in recouping production costs from foreign markets, which account for roughly 50 percent of all box office dollars. As Robert Shaye, chairman of New Line Cinema, explained it, "For niche films, the international market has been harder to crack."
Despite those problems, there are now signs of change that may make it easier for films stemming from the black culture to find a broader audience.
One important sign of change was the recent effort that Mr. Johnson himself participated in, the financing of the $2.4 million production of "Get on the Bus," Spike Lee's film about the Million Man March. All 15 members of the group were black, including the actors Will Smith and Danny Glover, as well as less prominent figures, like Lem Daniels, a Merrill Lynch stockbroker.
Despite stunning reviews, that film, which opened Oct. 16, has proved somewhat of a disappointment at the box office, having taken in only $5.5 million through last week. Reuben Cannon, who heads his own production company and arranged the fund-raising meeting for "Get on the Bus," believes that "black audiences support films in which they are represented, but the young people like broad comedy or excessive action."
"If you make a straight drama about the black experience," he continued, "it is outside that normal portrayal, and that audience is less likely to see the film."
Spike Lee said he felt that people mistakenly perceived his latest film as a documentary rather than entertainment. He is also upset that the soundtrack, a key marketing tool, was released only a week before the film opened.
In general, marketing for most films has been a problem, in the view of Ivan Juzang, the founder of Me Productions, whose company handled "Set It Off" and specializes in marketing films to the black community. He said that studios often did not understand that "the decision-making for black audiences to go to a movie is entirely different than for mainstream audiences."
"Word of mouth, and activities in the community, have more credibility than TV advertising with kids, who are crucial in opening a film and generating the word of mouth," he said. "Mainstream media, like TV, is discounted because ultimately young black people know they don't control that medium."
Despite the obstacles, investors in "Get on the Bus," who put up their money last March, recovered their investment plus interest by October, when Sony bought the rights to the film. Now Mr. Cannon hopes the group will finance more films. "There are stories that we have to tell, and we have to pay for it ourselves," he said.
To be sure, some films have already broken the action-comedy mold. The most dazzling example was "Waiting to Exhale," the story of four black women searching for romantic happiness, which took in $67 million at the box office. Though the film did have some crossover audience, the vast majority of viewers were black women, according to an executive at 20th Century Fox, which distributed the film. The executive, who declined to be identified, said, "The reaction shows that if a movie interested the audience, they would come out en masse to it."
In the future, it may get somewhat easier to reach that audience. Ken Lombard, president of Magic Johnson Theaters, a partnership with Sony Pictures that builds movie theaters in predominantly black neighborhoods, said another major problem for black films has been distribution.
"Certain communities are underscreened," Mr. Lombard said, adding that his group hoped to change that. So far the partnership has built theaters with 200 screens, including three 12-screen multiplexes -- in Harlem; in Jamaica Hills, Queens, and in Baldwin Hills, Calif.
"Our philosophy is to play everything, but obviously we feel that there is certain product geared to the minority audience," Mr. Lombard said.
A similar strategy prompted Mr. Johnson of BET to begin a pay-TV movie service aimed at the black market. "The way you get more black films made," Mr. Johnson said. "is if there are more revenue streams that can benefit those films. If Magic Johnson can put more multiplexes in the core inner cities, you will find a revenue stream coming off that market."
BET's service will carry films that feature a black actor in a leading or dominant role or try to address black life styles.
"We would like the films to be produced and directed by blacks, but the universe of such films is still too small," Mr. Johnson said. As to his potential pay-TV audience, "there are 25 million pay cable homes," Mr. Johnson said. "Our numbers show that 20 percent of the pay universe are black homes. That is our target. We think they will pay between $5.50 and $7.50 a month for the service. That is a significant revenue stream."
But for Mr. Lee, there is still a long road ahead. "We are really not going to get power in this industry until we are in the positions where the power lies -- that is, the people who green-light pictures and the people that market them."

HEADLINE: Computers Help Unite Campuses but Also Drive Some Students Apart

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H.

 BODY:
Through a plug in his dorm room, Arthur Desrosiers, a Dartmouth College sophomore, pursues all the preoccupations of undergraduate life without leaving his chair: he questions professors, fishes for dates, browses the library catalogue, orders in pizza and engages in 2 A.M. bull sessions on the meaning of it all.
Using the campus E-mail system, known as Blitzmail, he sometimes trades a series of back-and-forth messages with his two roommates -- even though they are sitting just a few feet away. 
 "I guess you could say you're pretty addicted if you're having a long Blitzmail conversation with your roommate, and you happen to be sitting right there in the same room," Mr. Desrosiers said.
Anyone who has not visited a college campus lately might be in for a jolt. Across the country, computer networks are cinching even tighter the already inward-looking communities typical of campuses, transforming the social and academic life of today's students.
Dormitory lounges are being carved up for clusters of computers, student unions are declining as gathering places, and computer-wired dorm rooms are becoming, in some cases, high-tech caves. Some scholars say "plug per pillow" campuses are undermining the ideal of a residential college as a melting pot where people from different social and regional backgrounds meet.
Prof. James Banning, an environmental psychologist at Colorado State University who surveyed some 100 university housing officers last year, remarked: "Universities are saying: 'Oh, my God, they're in their rooms. How can we ever build a sense of community in this building if they don't come out?"
Dartmouth, one of the most academically competitive colleges in the country, has long had a reputation for encouraging computer use by students. It now has the distinction of being one of the most E-mail-intensive, delivering about 250,000 electronic messages a day to 5,000 students and 3,000 faculty and staff members, or more than 30 messages apiece.
At public terminals all over the campus (to keep students from having to return to their rooms), 5 to 10 students line up as if at a cash machine, observing rules of Blitzmail etiquette like not reading over the shoulder of the person at the screen. In the Thayer dining hall recently, Stephanie Waddell, a senior studio art major, read a Blitz request from a male friend that began, "Need a date."
James Hunnicutt, a junior English major who was next in line, received five messages from his mother in Charlotte, N.C., asking about his law-school plans, a note from a high-school girlfriend at a college in Oregon and a message from his roommate vetoing the idea of a party in their room.
Most students say Blitzmail is convenient and indispensable on campus and gives them an easy way to stay in touch with family and high school friends. But Mark Shahinian, a junior history major, complained that it encouraged on-line electronic bantering while inhibiting meaningful communication.
He compared Blitzmail relationships to the brief encounters typical of those at fraternity parties, which play a big role on the isolated New Hampshire campus. "Blitzmail has a bit of that casualness -- knowing a lot of people but not all that well," he said.
Computer technology has come to higher education in many forms, including World Wide Web sites where art professors create digitized galleries; custom software for teaching human anatomy, and "smart" classrooms with a computer for each student to teach engineering or writing.
After building momentum for a decade, the wired campus has reached critical mass, said Kenneth C. Green, the director of the Campus Computing Survey, which collects data annually from 650 colleges and universities.
More than half of all residential campuses in the United States have network connections in dormitory rooms, according to the latest survey, released this year. The number of classes using E-mail to supplement academic discussions and professors' office hours grew to 20 percent in 1995 from 8 percent in 1994.
Mr. Green, a visiting scholar at the Claremont Graduate School, said that even though there were "a lot of questions about the pedagogical value" of computer technology, academia had largely accepted it, and that there were apparently no efforts to counter any antisocial side effects.
Paradoxically, it is electronic mail, one of the most mundane and least-examined of computer applications, that is probably having the most profound effect on campuses.
"E-mail is like the god of every college student," said Abigail Butler, who graduated from Vassar College this year with a major in French and political science. "People probably spend easily three hours a day sending and receiving messages. It's the No. 1 way that romances go on at colleges. It's like the dating game on line."
Jeremy Edberg, an undergraduate at the University of California at Berkeley who said he spent 10 hours a day on line, said that almost all his conversations with professors were now by E-mail. Just about the only time he visits them in person, he said, is to try to persuade them to change a grade.
"Students don't meet at rathskellers and hamburger joints and in dorm rooms anymore," said Clifford Stoll, a former researcher at Harvard University and the author of "Silicon Snake Oil: Second Thoughts on the Information Highway" (Doubleday, 1995.) "Instead, they poke their heads into computers."
"We're turning colleges into a cubicle-directed electronic experience and denying the importance of learning to work closely with other students and professors, and developing social adeptness," Mr. Stoll said.
Professor Banning, the scholar studying dorm life, said that since going to Colorado State in 1978, he had noticed that students were spending more time in their rooms. A once-crowded restaurant across from the residence halls closed three years ago and has not reopened.
But the image of students sitting trancelike in front of computers, cut off from life, is exaggerated, other experts say. "A certain sector of undergraduates, especially adolescent males," has always focused obsessively on narrow interests, said Steven W. Gilbert, the director of technology projects for the American Association for Higher Education. "Sometimes it's fixing hot rods. Sometimes it's the Internet. I would bet you wouldn't find any more doing it now than 20 years ago."
To judge by a recent Friday night at Dartmouth, Blitzmail has hardly killed off rathskellers and other gathering places. There were good crowds at Queer Club, a dance presented by the campus gay and lesbian alliance, and off campus at the Dirt Cowboy Cafe, where students sipped carrot juice and cappuccinos.
At the same time, many dorm room windows emitted a bluish glow, the light of a computer screen with a student's head buried in it. A few students said Blitzmail contributed to a feeling of alienation.
Enthusiasts of E-mail praise it as a virtual office system in which students can question professors about courses at any time.
David G. Brown, the provost of Wake Forest University and a professor of economics, said that E-mail had not isolated him from students.
"Because we're in communication every day," he said, "we feel that we're a group ready to help one another, not only over the network but in person."
This fall, Wake Forest, a private university with 3,700 undergraduates in Winston-Salem, N.C., distributed I.B.M. laptop computers to all its approximately 940 freshmen, paid for with part of a $3,000 tuition increase. It is part of a sweeping Wake Forest plan to use network technology to change the ways students work and communicate.
Professor Brown's freshman economics seminar is already a paperless course that students attend with their laptop computers, which are all linked together. The professor might ask them to write a one-sentence summary of an economic topic like opportunity cost, what is given up when a choice is made, then electronically forward it to the others.
For homework, he might have students search the Internet for a news article demonstrating opportunity cost, write a short essay about it and then send it to him by E-mail with a picture obtained from the Louvre museum Web site demonstrating opportunity cost. Back in class, essays and pictures spark discussion.
There is concern that the unequal distribution of technology between rich and poor campuses will create a system of computer haves and have-nots. Public universities and two-year community colleges are typically less wired because of the high costs. Bringing fiber-optic cable into dormitories and faculty offices for a network can cost millions of dollars. Fitting a classroom with 20 computers and a projection system costs as much as $100,000.
But the highest-tech learning of all -- the delivery of lectures over computer screens or cable television, called distance learning -- is the subject of the most serious experimentation at cash-strapped public universities. The American Federation of Teachers, in a report this year critical of the sterility of distance learning, noted, "All our experience as educators tells us that teaching and learning in the shared human spaces of a campus are essential to the undergraduate experience."
The nature of those shared spaces seems to be changing.
At Vassar, students using screen names chat electronically with software called Broadcast.
"One woman, an English major, met a physics major who quoted Shakespeare to her, and it was love at first Broadcast," said Ms. Butler, the recent Vassar graduate, who was known on the network as Snow White. "I've also known people who sat home Friday and Saturday nights, Broadcasting back and forth to people they know only by nicknames, while the rest of the world was going by.
"After a while, it starts to be really unfulfilling," she said. "Every Broadcast conversation with someone new is the same for the first 20 messages, finding out who they are. It's easier to just meet someone. You learn how much of a difference it makes to see someone in person and actually talk to them."
