HEADLINE: WALL STREET WITHOUT WALLS -- A special report.;
Slow Transition for Investing: Stock Market Meets Internet

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Despite the millions of dollars that Wall Street spends each year on computers and high-tech gadgetry, in many ways its business has not changed much since the 18th century, when brokers gathered under a buttonwood tree to buy and sell shares.
But all of a sudden, innovations in technology, particularly the linkage of computers known as the Internet, are bringing profound changes to Wall Street that hold a lot of promise -- and a lot of peril -- for the powerful firms that make their money in the securities business. 
 And these changes -- in everything from how a new company raises money to how an amateur investor buys a share of stock -- will affect, for both good and ill, the pocketbooks of millions of Americans who participate in the financial system simply by saving for retirement, starting a small business or switching among mutual funds.
For many people, the Internet could replace the functions of a broker, whose stock in trade is information, advice and execution of transactions, all of which may be cheap and easy to find on line. The technology also is prompting some business executives to wonder whether they really need a high-priced Wall Street investment bank to find backers for their companies when they may now be able to reach so many potential investors directly over the Net. And ultimately, the Internet's ability to bring buyers and sellers together directly may change the very nature of American financial markets.
For Wall Street and investors, the Internet is bringing "great benefits and opportunities," said Steven M. H. Wallman, a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "But it also has real potential pitfalls and disadvantages."
The most obvious of these pitfalls is fraud. Con artists are already finding the Internet to be a cheap, easy way to promote fake "investment opportunities" or to promote stocks in which they have secret stakes. But there will be even more important consequences, including greater volatility in small stocks that attract on-line fan clubs and easier access to investments that may be on the level but are nevertheless ill-advised.
To be sure, the "Internet revolution" has been subject to so much promotion that skeptics are starting to dismiss it as an electronic fad.
And no one is suggesting that the rise of the Internet means that securities firms will close their offices, disconnect their telephones and do business only in cyberspace. Wall Street's suspender-clad movers and shakers will continue to strut through the corridors of Manhattan -- although behind the scenes, ponytailed computer programmers will probably increase their power.
The reason the Internet has the power to revolutionize Wall Street lies in the technology's very nature. By intricately linking millions of computers, the Internet allows individuals to find information -- and each other -- quickly and directly, without employing traditional middlemen. And Wall Street is nothing if not the ultimate middleman.
"A lot of what we do on Wall Street involves matching buyers with sellers or exchanging various forms of information," said David E. Shaw, chairman of D. E. Shaw & Company, who has made a fortune using computer technology to trade securities and is viewed as a high-tech guru inside the industry. "The Internet could make a lot of these functions faster, cheaper, safer and more accurate -- if Wall Street and its regulators can move quickly enough to take advantage of it."
Already, information that people once had to get from a broker, or that was available only to professional investors, is easy to find on the Internet. Prices, analysts' reports, even the filings companies must make with the S.E.C., can be had quickly and at little or no cost. Last month, investors checked stock prices electronically and got other information from the National Association of Securities Dealers' Internet site 2.1 million times -- in a single day.
And thousands of people trade investment advice and stock tips on the Internet. "People used to have to call a broker and ask, 'What's up with my stock?' " said David Gardner, who with his brother Tom runs the Motley Fool, one of the most popular investment sites. "Now this revolutionary information resource has popped up and liberated them."
It became possible this year to buy or sell stocks and mutual funds over the Net through brokerage firms like Charles Schwab and the upstart E Trade. Investors have already opened more than 100,000 electronic trading accounts, according to Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., which predicts there will be at least nine million in five years.
More radical experiments are springing up, especially in California, where many people work in high-tech and have been quick to embrace the Internet. Consider the following :
 *Almost a dozen small companies are trying to sell their stock directly to the public using Web sites like those run by Direct Stock Market and IPO Data Systems.
*An entertainment company and a computer company have just started selling shares electronically through IPOnet, an affiliate of the Pasadena, Calif., brokerage firm W. J. Gallagher & Company.
*And two small California companies, Real Goods Trading and Perfect Data, have set up electronic bulletin boards that allow their shareholders to trade stock without a broker, dealer or market maker.
Though these efforts are tiny, "I can see the day coming when the people who run General Motors or I.B.M. decide to do themselves a favor and provide a service to shareholders" by allowing their stocks to trade on their own Internet sites, said Junius W. Peake, a former Wall Street executive who is now a professor at the University of Northern Colorado in Greeley.

The Business
A Slow Shift Is Under Way
The Internet allows securities firms to serve their customers electronically from anywhere, and so its impact may be felt most severely in New York, where the economy is heavily dependent on the concentration of financial firms. Real estate prices and taxes are high, and the city government has given big tax breaks to firms like Morgan Stanley to keep them in the city. While there are a number of reasons for financial enterprises to cluster closely together, the Internet may make it economically more attractive for firms to put some operations elsewhere.
For all the Internet's promise, much of Wall Street has been slow to take advantage of it, even for its most basic function of advertising (the World Wide Web functions in some ways as a gigantic Yellow Pages). Even firms that have been quick to embrace the technology, like Schwab, say it is just another avenue to serve customers -- though one, like automated teller machines, that may eclipse traditional approaches.
A N.A.S.D. survey last summer found that only 15 percent of its members had a home page, though 31 percent planned to add one soon. And while 20 percent of the firms said that the Internet would be highly important in the future, a larger group of more than 30 percent rated its future importance as low.
The New York Stock Exchange is keeping secret the results of a similar survey it did early this year. But for many of its member firms, the Internet is little more than an advertising vehicle or a communications gadget, "like the telephone but less efficient," Edward A. Kwalwasser, executive vice president of the exchange, said.
People who are paid to study the future of the brokerage industry, though, say that writing off the Internet as a fad or the domain of a small number of computer-crazed do-it-yourselfers would be a big mistake.
The people who are quick to adopt the Internet "represent, over a lifetime, your highest profit opportunity," said Gary B. Meshell, director of electronic financial services for Price Waterhouse, the accounting and consulting firm. These people are "two-income families, very time pressed, self-directed investors who want information and to make their own decisions."
The number of such people is big enough that the American Express Company has started a new venture, Financial Direct, to serve them over the Internet. Competition will also come from technology companies like the Microsoft Corporation and Intuit Inc., maker of the Quicken money management software.
And Forrester Research is predicting the rise of what it calls midtier brokers, which could grab 60 percent of the on-line investing market by 2001. These firms will offer competitive but not cut-rate pricing and personalized guidance from investing assistants who will help investors with technology and investment problems but not be sales representatives. They will also make less than half as much as the average stockbroker today.
"Firms are really protective of stockbrokers, but if their 11th Commandment is, 'Thy broker shall make $100,000,' they'll be gone," said Julio Gomez, a Forrester analyst.
But not without a fight. Merrill Lynch & Company, the biggest firm on Wall Street, is embracing the Internet, which it says does not pose a threat to its brokers. Merrill has just introduced an on-line service that gives customers access to their accounts and will eventually permit them to do transactions electronically. But the firm is counting on the Net to link its customers more tightly to its brokers, which Merrill calls financial consultants.
"We view the whole information explosion as an opportunity," said Howard Sorgen, a senior vice president at Merrill. "People will still want to make one stop for advice, help and wisdom."
Improving the quality of advice they give is "the holy grail" for financial services firms, said Siddharth N. Mehta, vice president of the Boston Consulting Group. Firms will also try to develop a brand identity, and, for those with institutional clients, perform increasingly complex analysis and create increasingly complicated financial instruments.

The Obstacles
Fear of Fraud And Overloads
So far, all the financial activity on the Internet hardly rates as a blip on Wall Street's computer screens. And there are some hurdles to broader acceptance and influence.
Some are simply technical. The Internet is already overcrowded and is becoming slow and cumbersome to use sometimes -- techies refer to this as the bandwidth problem. And there is still no totally secure way to spend money over the Net. But solutions to these problems seem likely to be available in the near future.
Then there is fraud, which is expected to grow worse as it becomes easy to move money around on the Internet. The S.E.C. has brought nine enforcement actions against people trying to sell unregistered securities over the Internet. Adding to the regulators' challenge is the Internet's international nature, which makes it possible for foreigners outside of the regulators' jurisdiction to try to sell fraudulent investments to Americans.
"The other thing, which in the long run is more damaging, is the hype of thinly traded stocks," said Gary N. Sundick, associate director for enforcement at the commission, which has halted trading in eight stocks so far this year, twice as many as all of last year. Many were the subject of thousands of messages on Internet bulletin boards, some of which, regulators suspect, were posted by people trying to push up stock prices, either because they owned shares or were in the pay of people who did.
In the most infamous case, regulators are investigating messages posted last spring on electronic bulletin boards praising the Comparator Systems Corporation, which said it had developed a new technology involving fingerprint identification. Amid an Internet-generated outburst of enthusiasm, investors traded hundreds of millions of shares in just a few days in May and sent the market value of this tiny, obscure and money-losing company up to $1 billion. Those who sold the stock at the height of the madness scored big profits; those who bought and held the share now own paper that is almost worthless.
While stock manipulation is a chronic problem, "the Internet makes it much less expensive, they can reach a bigger audience, and, for much of that audience, the computer lends credibility," said Mary L. Schapiro, president of the N.A.S.D.'s regulatory arm, which oversees the Nasdaq stock market.
Legitimate companies can also be profoundly affected by investors' chatting up their stocks on the Internet. Shares in the Iomega Corporation, which makes computer storage devices, zoomed from under $4 to over $55 in less than a year as its devoted cyberfans sang its praises; it has since retreated to $24.375.
Indeed, Ms. Schapiro said, the N.A.S.D. now checks the Internet when a stock starts acting oddly.

The Future
Buy and Sell In Cyberspace
Despite the worries over the possibilities for stock manipulation, distributing products over the Internet -- in particular, new stock offerings -- is starting to look like a plausible business. Investors are clamoring to participate in these deals, which now usually go only to brokers' best clients, mostly institutions.
The Internet makes it relatively inexpensive and easy to let small investors participate in such offerings, said Russell M. Frandsen, a California lawyer who helped develop IPOnet, which last month helped sell what may be the first true public offering using the Internet, for a company called Javelin Systems.
Moreover, Internet distribution can cut the costs to the issuing company by 50 percent, contends Christos M. Cotsakos, the ebullient president of E Trade, the all-Internet brokerage firm that went public (the traditional way) this summer. The firm plans to get into underwriting, first as a distributor and then as an investment banker.
Companies too small to attract investment bankers are already using the Internet to publicize their offerings, which they sell directly to investors. The best-known deal was done in February, by Spring Street Brewery, a little New York company that raised $2.1 million. Andrew Klein, its founder, has started a business to assist other companies to do the same.
"If done correctly, it can eliminate brokers largely from the picture and cut costs considerably," John Perkins, chairman of the Small-Business Capital Access Association, said. But Mr. Perkins, a former state securities regulator, notes that simply putting an offering up on the Internet will not guarantee that a company will actually attract any investors.
And a lot of deals may not be good for investors, David Menlow, who describes himself as a staunch opponent of direct public offerings, said. "Many if not all of these companies should not be coming public -- it is too early in their time line," Mr. Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network, said. Moreover, investors who need to sell their shares may find it difficult to find buyers.
Probably the most significant but least predictable changes the Internet will bring to Wall Street involve trading. Because it allows traders to find each other easily, the Internet may ultimately make it possible to have a stock exchange that exists only in cyberspace, with no trading floor, directly open to every investor with a computer and a modem.
Institutions are already hooked on electronic trading systems, like Instinet and Posit. And next month, Jack White & Company, a discount broker, will introduce an Internet site that it hopes will give amateur investors a similar chance, allowing buyers and sellers to meet directly, several times a day, effectively forming their own mini-markets.
While practically everyone with a computer is trying to dream up a new trading system, or so it sometimes seems to regulators, there are problems that have yet to be overcome. One is the lack of immediacy, which means that a buyer may not find a seller right away, and vice versa. Another is that as the same stock trades in several places, it becomes extremely difficult to determine its actual price.
And then there is the amorphous thing Wall Street calls the back office. "The problem for new entrants has nothing to do with the simple issue of trading," said Alfred R. Berkeley, the new president of Nasdaq. "The real issue is credit and collection." How do you make sure that the person you are dealing with is creditworthy and really owns the securities?
Perhaps because the Internet's ultimate effects are so hard to predict, many Wall Street executives view it with "discomfort -- or a little bit of fear," said Elaine La Roche, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company and the chairwoman of the Public Securities Association, the trade association of dealers in government and municipal bonds.
"The Internet is more than a new market," she said. "It's a whole new ball game -- and one that has serious, possibly ominous, implications for the financial services industry." Why? "It allows end users to bypass the middleman. It allows them to bypass us."


GRAPHIC: For investors, the Internet promises to deliver some big benefits -- but with some significant risks.
 
INFORMATION
 
Pro:
Chart: "On-Line Trading Pros and Cons"
 Easy access to corporate information (through the S.E.C.'s Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis and Retrieval site, known as Edgar).
 Availability of research and analysis previously limited to brokers and institutional investors.
 Advice from on-line investors untainted by stockbrokers' need to make sales.
 
Con:
Source and accuracy of some information is hard to evaluate.
 Promoters and other who are trying to drive up stock's price may pretend to be disinterested experts.
 Investor enthusiasm for some stocks can drive prices to unsustainable levels.
 
EXECUTION
 
Pro:
 Low cost of buying and selling stocks and some mutual funds.
 Orders can be placed any time, though they are fulfilled only when markets are open.
 
Con:
 Continuing technical concerns, including security.
 Slowness as more and more people use (and overtax) the Internet
 
INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERINGS
 
Pro:
 Small companies can sell their stocks.
 More likely that small investors can buy shares.
 
Con:
Regulatory scrutiny of direct offerings is much lower than for underwritten deals, making fraud easier.
 There may not be a market if investors need to sell their shares.
 
TRADING
 
Pro:
 Buyers and sellers meet electronically, eliminating the costs of middlemen (stock exchange specialists or dealers).
 
Con:
 Without a middleman, there is no guarantee investors can buy or sell when they want, or in the amount they want.
 Markets may become fragmented, making it difficult to determine a stock's true price. (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Taxing Rentals for Tourists

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: OCEAN CITY

 BODY:
Tourism drives Ocean City's economy. Each summer, the beach resort's population swells from 15,000 to 125,000. But tourists, some city leaders have noticed, use a lot of city services and do not pay property tax -- not directly, anyway -- in a city where taxes have been increasing an average of 9 percent per year for several years. 
 So on Thursday, the City Council will vote on a proposed $4-per-night tax on all tourist rentals, whether hotel rooms or beach houses. Proponents say the tax would raise about $3 million a year, which would trim $180 from the annual tax bill for the owner of a $200,000 house.
Many business owners oppose the measure, however, arguing that one type of merchant should not be singled out for a tax, said Joann DelVescio, executive director of the Greater Ocean City Chamber of Commerce. Furthermore, she said, in the few communities that charge a room tax, the money is used to promote tourism, not stabilize taxes.

HEADLINE: Budget, Welfare and Rent Rules Point to a Lively 1997 in Albany

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
With the election over, the stage has been set for a 1997 legislative session likely to be every bit as confrontational and protracted as the 1996 version, which dragged into mid-July and produced the latest state budget in the country's history, legislators and political analysts say.
In one stroke, voters last Tuesday strengthened both Gov. George E. Pataki, by passing his $1.75 billion environmental bond act, and his Democratic rivals in the Assembly, by increasing their already large majority by one seat; they now control 95 of the 150 seats. The Governor and Assembly Democrats clashed on myriad issues last session, and there is no reason to think they have been chastened by the election results. 
 The Legislature is also facing a host of contentious issues that would be difficult to resolve even in an atmosphere of bipartisan cooperation. Those issues include extending the state's rent regulations, revamping welfare, closing a projected $3 billion budget shortfall and toughening criminal penalties.
"I don't expect it to be an easy session," Mr. Pataki said in an interview last week.
Though the 1997 legislative session begins in January, the legislators may return for a special session in December to consider welfare legislation, extending a personal income tax surcharge in New York City and raising their own pay, currently $57,500 a year.
Among the thorniest issues facing the Legislature next year will be what to do with the state's rent regulations, which expire on June 15. Those rules establish rent control and stabilization for one million apartments around the state, about 90 percent of which are in New York City.
Three years ago, Republicans in the State Senate succeeded in ending rent protections for certain wealthy people by threatening to allow the rent laws to expire, which would have exposed thousands of tenants to sudden rent increases. The resulting change, known as luxury decontrol, removed protections from households that earn more than $250,000 a year for two years in a row and pay rent of at least $2,000 a month. The change removed 9,000 apartments from rent regulations.
The Senate Republicans, who have received hundreds of thousands of dollars in contributions this year from landlords' groups, have vowed to follow a similar course of brinksmanship this year to try to weaken, if not abolish, rent protections. In a prelude to the impending fight, the Senate Republicans, with the support of Mr. Pataki, almost allowed rent regulations for New York City loft tenants to expire last session as a means of extracting concessions from the Assembly Democrats on other issues.
With rent stabilization, which affects slightly more than one million apartments in New York City, allowable increases are decided by the Rent Guidelines Board. This year, the Board has granted increases of 5 percent for one-year lease renewals, and 7 percent for two-year leases.
With rent control, which affects slightly more than 100,000 apartments in the city, a maximum base rent is established, which is then adjusted every two years. Generally, the maximum collectible rent is less than the maximum base rent. By law, however, owners who certify that they are providing essential services and have removed violations may raise rents by up to 7.5 percent each year until the maximum base rent limit is reached.
In a recent interview, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said he would push for legislation to abolish all rent protections, either gradually or immediately.
"I don't see any good reason why government has to tell landlords and others how much they can charge," Senator Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican, said. "I think government has to, more and more, get out of people's lives. And this is a perfect example of where government has overstayed its welcome, to the detriment of the public."
Though in the past he has signaled a willingness to abolish all rent regulations, Mr. Pataki said in an interview last week that he thought some protections should remain for the elderly, the disabled and people on fixed incomes. But he said he would push to reduce regulations.
Though he declined to offer details of the type of legislation he would support, Mr. Pataki indicated an interest in expanding luxury decontrol, perhaps by lowering the current thresholds of $250,000 household income and $2,000 a month rent.
"It's one thing to have a law that protects someone who makes $250,000 and subsidizes their rent through various protections, it's another thing for a senior citizen on a fixed income to be told a week from now your rent could go through the roof," he said. "We do need to have some control in place. But we do need to change the law also."
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who has been the Legislature's major defender of the rent laws, declined to say what kind of changes, if any, he would accept, but insisted he would be flexible.
"I'm not knee-jerk on anything," Mr. Silver said in an interview last week. "I'd like to see a system that makes housing attractive and affordable in New York.
"And if somebody can show me a good way to keep working people here in New York City, I'm very much amenable to it."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is up for re-election next year, will also be a major player in the debate. In 1993, when the rent debate also came up in the middle of a mayoral election, Mayor David N. Dinkins accused Mr. Giuliani of not being a forceful advocate for tenants. Tenant groups are vowing to make rent a focal point of the 1997 mayoral campaign, so Mr. Giuliani will be under intense pressure to find ways of preventing his Democratic challengers from raising similar charges against him.
"My sense is he is very satisfied with what exists now and will support what exists now," said Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for economic development and planning. "He hasn't advocated any modifications."
But Ms. Reiter did not rule out the possibility that the Mayor could support expansion of luxury decontrol. "I can't answer that," she said. "And he can't."
Landlord groups, which have argued that rent laws make buildings unprofitable, have been girding for the battle by pumping thousands of dollars into candidates' campaign coffers. Three major landlord groups, the Rent Stabilization Association Political Action Committee, the Real Estate Board and the Neighborhood Preservation Political Action Fund, together contributed more than $700,000 to state candidates in 1996, most of them Republicans.
The Senate Republican Campaign Committee, which is controlled by Mr. Bruno, received the most: $174,000. The landlord groups also gave more than $50,000 directly to incumbent Republican state senators. And they contributed at least $55,000 to the Republican State Committee and $25,000 to a committee, Renew New York, controlled by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Welfare also looms as a major battleground in 1997, as the Legislature changes New York State's laws to conform with new Federal welfare rules. These set time limits on cash grants, limit benefits to immigrants and give states the authority to set numerous types of other restrictions.
Mr. Pataki, who in the past has proposed cutting welfare grants by 26 percent, declined to provide details of the plan he is expected to release this week. However, he has said that he will probably seek time limits of 60 to 90 days on the state cash benefit program, known as Home Relief, which goes mostly to childless adults. Mr. Bruno also supports such limits.
Mr. Silver said last week that he was inclined to support a five-year limit on Home Relief benefits to match the five-year limit on Federal benefits to families that is set in the new Federal law. "There has to be some equity between how you treat families and single adults," he said.
Though Mr. Pataki has said that he wants the Legislature to come back in December to begin working on welfare issues, most state officials say privately that they do not expect to accomplish much until next year. Mr. Silver as well as many Republicans want welfare to be part of the overall budget debate, since most welfare policies have major fiscal implications.
The fight over the $64 billion budget, which has been enacted late for 12 consecutive years, is also likely to be divisive, because Mr. Pataki will probably propose trimming popular programs to close a projected $3 billion shortfall for the fiscal year that begins on April 1.
The Governor also said he plans to introduce an ambitious package of criminal justice initiatives, including ending parole for all violent felons and repealing court rulings that he contends favor the rights of criminals over prosecutors and victims. The Assembly strongly opposed similar proposals last session.
The Legislature is also expected to take up a proposal to amend the State Constitution to legalize casino gambling outside Indian reservations, in the Catskills, for example. If the measure passes both houses, the proposition would go before voters next November. Though both Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver said they expect the measure to pass in their houses, opponents are gearing up to block it.
Another contentious issue likely to be on the Legislature's agenda is how to change the governing structure of New York City's school system. Though there is broad support for ending patronage hiring by community school boards, Senate Republicans and Assembly Democrats differ sharply on other matters, like whether to expand the mayor's control of the central school board or whether to create five distinct borough boards of education.

HEADLINE: As Latin Leaders Meet, Castro's Attendance Is Questioned

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10

 BODY:
As Latin American heads of state gathered for their annual summit conference here today, a bitter debate erupted over Fidel Castro's presence at the meeting, which is focusing on the expansion of democracy.
The appearance of Cuba's Communist leader at the Ibero-American Summit Conference, which brings together presidents of Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries, has touched off a storm of protest and demonstrations, both pro and con, in Chile. 
 President Castro is visiting Chile for the first time since 1971, when he called on a fellow Marxist, President Salvador Allende Gossens, who died in 1973 in a coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet.
Thousands of leftists, chanting "Castro! Castro!" and carrying signs with a red hammer and sickle, greeted Mr. Castro's motorcade on Saturday and today, while Cuban exiles and right-wing groups held angry rallies outside his hotel.
Mr. Castro has attended past conferences without major opposition, but because the theme of this meeting is democracy and because it is in Chile, his presence seemed to have touched a sensitive chord. Some Latin American leaders and political groups said it was absurd for Mr. Castro to take part in a meeting on democracy while his Government still does not allow free elections.
"No doubt, there is a contradiction on inviting Fidel Castro to a meeting where the main point is democracy," said President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, who has been a vocal critic of Cuba's Government.
"I can't justify any dictatorship -- I've been an eternal victim of the dictatorship my country supported," added Mr. Menem, who was imprisoned by the Argentine military in the 1970's. "But democracy is contagious, and maybe Fidel will catch it."
Asked whether Mr. Castro should have been left out of the conference, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru said, "No, on the contrary, I consider it necessary for all Ibero-American governments to be represented."
"One of the objectives of this conference is to identify the advantages that the democratic system can offer and to look for its expansion and practice between member nations," he said.
After decades of guerrilla warfare and military dictatorships, every nation in Latin America, with the exception of Cuba, has held full democratic elections and is in the process of economic and social reforms.
In Chile, General Pinochet relinquished power to a civilian Government in 1990, but still serves as commander of the army and remains an influential figure. He has accused Mr. Castro of arming and financing leftist guerrillas who wounded the general in an assassination attempt in 1986.
In a major snub to Mr. Castro, General Pinochet and other military leaders, who are widely respected in Chile, avoided the conference and spent the weekend observing military exercises in the northern provinces.
Asked to comment on Mr. Castro's visit, General Pinochet told local journalists: "The Government has invited Lucifer, and he has arrived. If the Government has decided to invite him, then so be it. The Government is the authority to which I submit. I have nothing to do with it."
During the general's 17-year military dictatorship, an estimated 3,200 people, many of whom were Communists, were killed or disappeared at the hands of security forces. And despite his denials, the general's influence is still felt here, as reflected in recent moves to prosecute people who criticized the Government.
Mr. Castro has declined to comment on the debate over his participation in the conference. Today he accompanied family members of Dr. Allende on a visit to his tomb. And in a short speech before other Latin American leaders, he criticized "international economic systems" and "foreign capital and transnationals" that are imposing their "ways" on Latin America.
In what was apparently a reference to the Helms-Burton Act, a new American law to penalize foreign companies doing business with Cuba, he added: "Our culture is being destroyed. Criminal blockades are imposed, and the same force invades our territory intruding into our interior politics. If we close our eyes and don't act united, what's going to happen to our state in the 21st century?"
But even as they debated Cuba's participation in the conference, the Latin American leaders were expected to issue a joint-statement on Monday denouncing the Helms-Burton Act, which President Clinton signed in March.
Helms-Burton allows American citizens and companies to file suit in American courts for restitution from foreign companies that use property taken from the Americans after Cuba's 1959 revolution. The law, which has been widely denounced in Europe, also bars executives of such companies from entering the United States.
While many of the 23 leaders attending the two-day conference have already criticized the Helms-Burton law, Monday's statement would be the first joint declaration of the region and a major victory for Mr. Castro.
"We Latins look upon on Castro as one might look upon a wayward sibling who's trying to reconnect with his family," said a high-ranking diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He is an idealist who is coming of age. An extreme reprimand like Helms-Burton does nothing to help his maturing."
In recent years, most Latin American nations have embraced Cuba as part of a strong drive toward regional integration and in recognition that Cuba had ended its support of leftist terrorist groups in the region. About 30 percent of Cuba's trade is with other Latin American countries.
In an effort to rehabilitate its broken economy, Cuba is starting to privatize state-owned companies and to open its borders to foreign investment. Some investors in countries like Mexico and Argentina are eager to take advantage of accords they have made with Cuba that allow investors to swap shares in Cuban state companies for trade debts.
Some diplomats attending the conference said they hoped the debate over Mr. Castro would not overshadow the meeting's purpose. While the region appears to have moved beyond the era of military coups, its democracies are still very fragile and need stronger commitments to open elections, freedom of speech, equal opportunity and a balance of power, they said.

HEADLINE: Booming Brooklyn

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a historian and a native New Yorker who grew up in Brooklyn, I was delighted with the Nov. 7 editorial "Booming Brooklyn" but cringed at the reference to a site at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues that "has stood vacant" for 40 years. That is not so. My father owned a wholesale packing plant in the Fort Greene meat market that was adjacent to the site. The market was so busy in the 1950's and early 1960's that it was almost impossible to drive near there at noon. Now, only memories fill that vacant lot, memories of the days, 40 years ago, when butchers in bloodied white coats packed those streets and the smell of sawdust permeated the air.
 
RICHARD K. LIEBERMAN
Long Island City, Queens, Nov. 8, 1996
 
The writer is an archives director at La Guardia Community College.

HEADLINE: Oregon's Health Plan Means Good Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to Peter Passell's Nov. 7 Economic Scene column, Oregonians did not reject a business outlook when they approved a ballot measure increasing the tobacco tax to finance Oregon's health plan. 
 The only significant business opposition to this measure came from the tobacco industry. As Oregon has neither tobacco fields nor cigarette plants, the tobacco industry does not speak for any industry in Oregon.
Oregon businesses have supported the plan for strengthening Oregon's Medicaid program, expanding eligibility, reducing costs and improving financing. A goal of the plan was to reduce shifting onto the private sector the costs of caring for the poor; this has been achieved.
Because of its health plan, Oregon is the state with the highest percentage of its population -- 49 percent -- in managed care and has the lowest hospital costs. Oregon employers, who pay more than half the state's health care costs, bank the savings. If health care costs nationally were at Oregon's levels, there would be no Medicare or Medicaid crisis.
To be sure, few businesses have the vision to see that increasing tobacco taxes reduces smoking and thereby reduces the health costs that business ultimately will shoulder. However, the Oregon plan has forged a congruence between the short-range economic interests of business and the long-range health needs of Oregonians.
 
THEODORE C. FALK
Clackamas, Ore., Nov. 8, 1996
 
The writer is vice president and general counsel of PACC Health Plans.

HEADLINE: Debating Use of Iron As Curb Of Climate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
THE idea is to fertilize the sea with iron, creating such a bloom of sea plants that they gulp down tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and curb the buildup of this climate-warming gas.
Long derided as foolish and politically dangerous, the idea has now been put to the test after years of foot dragging and has given strikingly good results, stirring hot debate over whether ecological tinkering might help save the planet from climatic disaster. 
 The test was conducted southwest of the Galapagos Islands in the Pacific Ocean, which is a fairly barren area biologically. Over a region of 28 square miles, a team of scientists slowly poured into the sea 990 pounds of iron, which is thought to be a limiting nutrient in such unproductive regions.
Almost immediately, the waters bloomed with the tiny plants known as phytoplankton, and did so over more than 200 square miles, turning the sea from blue to green.
No scientist has criticized the experiment publicly, but experts are at war over whether the test simply sheds new light on marine ecology or points to an important way to battle the effects of global warming.
Dr. Adam Heller, a chemical engineer at the University of Texas at Austin who has promoted the fertilization idea in Washington, hailed the explosive rise in ocean productivity as "very significant, terribly significant." Dr. Heller said in an interview: "We now have some way to cope with global warming should it become a problem. I wish we had more ways."
But detractors of such global engineering say its prospect offers a false hope that threatens to encourage polluters and undercut international accords meant to curb emissions of carbon dioxide, which is released into the atmosphere by the burning of gas, oil, coal and wood and is considered a main culprit in global warming.
"As a scientific experiment, these results are fascinating," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, chief scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a private group in New York. "But as a potential solution to global warming, they have limited if any value, as far as our current understanding goes."
Fierce side debates are also developing over the cost of a program -- iron is cheap but megatons would be needed -- as well as its possible benefit of stepping up the sea's productivity and enhancing fish harvests.
Both opponents and friends of sea fertilization tend to agree that at best, its widespread use would probably cut atmospheric carbon dioxide by 6 percent to 21 percent, not enough to end the problem but potentially sufficient to dent it.
And all sides agree that the overall impact of an iron-seeding program on the ocean's ecology is riddled with uncertainties, especially for the sea's deeper ecosystems, of which little is known. In short, the cure might turn out to be worse than the disease.
Advocates of the iron-seeding idea say such uncertainties, are no reason to soft-pedal it, especially given the threat of climate change and its attendant upheavals. Years of serious research lie ahead, they say, including exploring the natural history of iron fluctuations in the sea, which some scientists now speculate may be linked to the onset of the ice ages.
"It's much too early to have a policy debate," said Russell Seitz, an associate of the Olin Center for Strategic Studies at Harvard University. "Despite this, the issue seems to been born politicized. Witness the rush to criticize the hypothesis in the early 1990's before the experiment was even done. Given the extent of our ignorance, and the stakes, I'm astonished to see polemics getting the better of science."
Part of the problem lies in the differing agendas of scientists and engineers. In general, scientists devote themselves to studying nature and unraveling its secrets, while engineers use science to rearrange nature in the service of humanity.
Periodically, the two groups have been at loggerheads, the tensions rising steadily in the last few decades as a new kind of visionary has begun to dream of global countermeasures to climatic ills, envisioning huge ecoengineering projects far beyond the engineer's usual domain of making new kinds of computers and space vehicles.
Remarkably, the current battle of the ecoengineering war centers on one of nature's smallest organisms, phytoplankton, which are ubiquitous through the sea, though their numbers vary widely, depending on local levels of nutrients.
In coastal waters rich in agricultural runoff and human sewage, their numbers can swell into the range of 100,000 per drop of water, turning the sea cloudy and brown or soupy green. Far from shore, however, phytoplankton dwindle as low as about 1 per drop, and in consequence these waters are usually deep blue.
Since phytoplankton are the most important of the sea's primary producers, trapping the abundant energy of sunlight and so becoming the foundation of the ocean's food chain, the biological productivity of each region of the sea depends on how many phytoplankton it supports.
A longstanding mystery of oceanography is that of why phytoplankton levels vary so widely, and can be low even in regions rich in nitrogen and phosphorus, the principal nutrients of plants. Seas that are low in phytoplankton but high in primary nutrients account for about 20 percent of the ocean surface.
Beginning in 1986, Dr. John H. Martin, an oceanographer at the Moss Landing Marine Laboratories in California, proposed that low iron levels might account for the poor productivity. His idea was widely dismissed, even though scientists have long known that iron is vital to the health of most animals and plants, and that iron deficiency is a serious problem in many kinds of crops.
Among other things, iron aids photosynthesis by helping to move around the subatomic particles known as electrons, which play a leading role in trapping sunlight's energy.
Despite skepticism, careful experiments in the laboratory and measurements at sea suggested that Dr. Martin's thesis was right. By 1988, with public fears growing because of the threat of global warming, Dr. Martin proposed that the fertilization of unproductive areas of the sea with thousands of tons of iron might fix the climatic problem.
"Give me half a tanker full of iron," he told colleagues, "and I'll give you another ice age."
The idea languished until 1990, when the National Academy of Sciences, which advises the Federal Government, endorsed a test. But financing was slow to materialize, and many scientists and ecologists criticized the idea as an incentive for polluters.
In June 1991, the American Society of Limnology and Oceanography issued a public statement that urged "all governments to regard the role of iron in marine production as an area for further research and not to consider iron fertilization as a policy option that significantly changes the need to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide."
Dr. Sallie W. Chisholm and Dr. Francois M. M. Morel, both of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, commented in an article accompanying the statement, "The 'Geritol Solution' to global warming has been squelched for the time being, but it would naive to think that the issue will not come up again."
Dr. Martin died in June 1993, months before the first experiment that tested his iron hypothesis at sea. That experiment, in the Pacific some 300 miles west of the Galapagos, was ambiguous. A single dose of iron briefly raised phytoplankton levels, but the test ended prematurely when the fertilized patch sank beneath waters of lesser density.
The experiment was redone in May and June 1995 by 37 scientists from the United States, England and Mexico, only this time the iron was dispersed in three infusions over a week to insure a more sustained release into the sea's surface. The test was financed by the National Science Foundation and the Office of Naval Research.
The fertilized patch lay some 800 miles west of the Galapagos and had an area of 28 square miles. As detailed in four reports in the Oct. 10 issue of the journal Nature, the effect was immediate and striking.
The sea exploded in a frenzy of phytoplankton growth and reproduction involving trillions of organisms, with the effect reaching its maximum extent some nine days after the start of the experiment and extending over an oceanic area that had expanded to some 200 square miles. The explosion was monitored mainly by measuring levels of chlorophyll, the green pigment of plants involved in the process of photosynthesis. Over all, the iron produced more than 2,000 times its own weight in plant growth, an impossible feat for any fertilizer on land.
"Within one week, about two million pounds of phytoplankton had grown," said Dr. Kenneth H. Coale of Moss Landing, one the authors.
At the same time, levels of carbon dioxide in the sea water plunged more than 15 percent as the expanding jungle of tiny plants soaked up the gas. Since the atmosphere and the sea constantly trade the gas through mixing and diffusion, the explosive growth had a large effect on that exchange as well.
Scientists say the experiment may have pulled more than 2,500 tons of carbon dioxide from the waters before the fertilized patch was broken up by ocean currents. By comparison, human pollution pumps billions of tons of carbon into the air each year.
Dr. Bruce W. Frost, an oceanographer at the University of Washington in Seattle who commented on the study in Nature, said that an extrapolation of such fertilization to a much larger area would have "only a small effect" on future levels of global atmospheric carbon dioxide.
In contrast, Dr. Kenneth S. Johnson, a chemical oceanographer at the Moss Landing laboratory who participated in both iron experiments, hailed the experiment as basically opening a new chapter in humanity's relationship with the planet.
"This shows that you could cause an ice age, which is a pretty profound statement," he said in an interview. "It has lots of implications."
Ecoengineers focus their musings on the Southern Ocean around Antarctica because it is the largest part of the global sea that exhibits the phenomena of high nutrient levels and low iron. It is already a highly productive region, teeming with krill and the whales that feed on the tiny crustaceans.
But scientists say the Southern Ocean, if enriched with iron, would become even more productive and would also become an enormous sponge for carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere. Such a move would require the dumping of millions of tons of iron into the sea every year, more or less continuously.
Among the hotly debated questions are at what cost, and to what effect. A number of studies have suggested that such enrichment would lower the range of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by 6 percent to 21 percent.
But Dr. David J. Cooper, a member of the experiment team at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, said the 21 percent value was out of date and that most recent studies had found that the drop would be around 10 percent.
Dr. Cooper, an opponent of ecoengineering, accused its supporters of exaggerating the possible effects. "Scientists haven't been honest about it," he said, suggesting that some were playing up the idea as a way to get financing for experiments.
Mr. Seitz of Harvard, on the other hand, accused the experiment team of bending over backwards to play down the test's results, fearful of upsetting global political agendas.
"If this approach proves to be environmentally benign," he said, "it would appear to be highly economic relative to a Luddite program of declaring war against fire globally," a move that might cost many trillions of dollars in lost development and revenue.
Friends and foes of the idea agree that the big "if" in all this is the proposal's ecological impact, which is wholly unknown and vigorously disputed. Some scientists foresee a flowering of the oceanic food chain, ultimately producing more fish, while other see the oceans dying or significantly disrupted.
All agree that more research, perhaps decades of it, would be needed to flesh out the idea's repercussions.
"It's a mine field," Dr. Johnson of Moss Landing said of the topic. "Everybody is stepping gingerly."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops, Then Recovers, As Traders Weigh Yen Policy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell to a one-month low against the Japanese yen before recovering yesterday on lingering concerns that Japan might be changing its foreign exchange policy to stop the yen from weakening further.
The dollar also slipped against the German mark, as European Union finance ministers wrestled with the details of establishing a single European currency by 1999. 
 Trading was light because of the Veterans Day holiday.
In late New York trading, a dollar cost 111.50 yen, unchanged from Friday. The dollar was at 1.4935 marks, down from 1.5053. A British pound cost $1.6464, unchanged from Friday.
The dollar spent most of the day lower, adding to a decline that started Thursday when a senior Japanese official said that the yen's prolonged period of weakness was over. That sent the dollar down 2 percent against the yen, with many traders believing the statement showed a shift in Japanese policy.
Since then, the official -- Eisuke Sakakibara, director of the Finance Ministry's International Finance Bureau -- has tried to allay such concerns, reiterating that Japan's currency policy was unchanged and would remain consistent with that of the Group of Seven industrialized nations.
Traders, however, sold dollars yesterday on continued concerns that Japan may no longer be interested in a weaker yen.
"Japan helped reverse the course of the yen over the last year and a half," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn. "Those remarks indicate something else."
Against the mark, the dollar came under pressure as European finance ministers disagreed over the details of introducing a single currency. Problems include what economic criteria should be used for admission and how to monitor countries once they are accepted.
Squabbling over the single currency propped up the mark, and in turn weakened the dollar, as traders questioned whether such a currency would be as stable as the mark.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, were: 1.2545 Swiss francs, down from 1.2657; 1.3337 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3306; 5.0515 French francs, down from 5.0890, and 1,508.50 Italian lire, down from 1,514.50.

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Walter Gilbert;
Reading the History of Life in the Text of Modern Genes

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
IS it possible to recreate the origin of genes, the first stirrings of life in the mists of time more than three billion years ago? One of the country's leading biologists is certain that with the power of thought and statistical technique those mists can be burned away. He is Dr. Walter Gilbert and he has been working on the problem for nearly 15 years.
In a basement room at Harvard University's science center one morning a few weeks ago, Dr. Gilbert was at the blackboard, describing the puzzle to nonscientists. He noted that the genes in modern animals were stored in the DNA not as nice readable texts but as choppy fragments that the cell's machinery must stitch together. That curious arrangement is one major clue. Another is that some 95 percent of a person's DNA does not code for genes at all. It seems to be just gibberish, or junk DNA. 
 Genes in pieces and huge stretches of junk? "At first glance, it is peculiar," Dr. Gilbert told the bleary-eyed students. "Then, at second glance, it is even more peculiar. I think it's one of the major unsolved mysteries of the basis of life."
Dr. Gilbert and his colleagues have sketched out a theory of how it all may have happened and what the first genes were like. It was he who coined the terms for the interrupted pattern in which genes are stored on the DNA; the working parts he called "exons" and the regions in between, which the cell has to splice out, he termed "introns."
After a period of controversy, then of acceptance, his ideas have come under new challenge. An electronic debate about primordial exons and introns is taking place this week and next on the Internet (at http:// hmsbeagle.com/scripts/web.exe). So now, Dr. Gilbert and his colleagues have done new experiments and written new papers, using extensive computer and statistical analysis, to support his exon theory of genes.
As Dr. Philip Sharp, a molecular biologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, puts it, few scientists are willing to spend time on so vexing a puzzle. "Yes," Dr. Sharp said, "it is very difficult. It may even be unsolvable. That won't stop Wally Gilbert, of course." Dr. Sharp, who shared a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1993 for finding introns, one of the discoveries that set Dr. Gilbert off on this track, said the ideas that Dr. Gilbert put forward "captured the imagination of the field, and still has it, I think."
If Dr. Gilbert's approach is valid, in principle the entire history of life on earth could be inferred from the DNA of modern genes. His theory is an effort to figure out how, in the primordial waters where life began, the earliest genes were assembled. A modern gene is a chemical text with a thousand or more letters. For such a structure to evolve at random would be a lengthy process.
Instead, Dr. Gilbert suggests, the first genetic elements were simple modules, the forerunners of today's exons, and the exons were then mixed and matched to build up the lengthy chains that make longer and longer genes. By analyzing the structure of contemporary genes, it should be possible to discern the ancient modules within.
For the modules to mix and match, Dr. Gilbert believes, they would have needed strips of extra DNA, like the leader on a reel of film, so that two modules could be spliced together without risk of cutting into their genetic message in the process. The introns, the elements interspersed between the coding regions of genes, are in this view related to the ancient leaders that enabled the modules to be assembled. Critics say the theory leaves some awkward issues unexplained. Introns are found in the DNA of plants and animals but not in that of bacteria. So did bacteria lose their introns or never acquire them?
Dr. Jeffrey D. Palmer at Indiana University and a few other experts in molecular evolution suggest that Dr. Gilbert's theory is wrong. They say the introns and the shuffling of genetic modules were mechanisms that did not arise until two billion years after life first began. And, they regard the introns not as clever Tinker Toy construction elements, but as just what they appear to be, pieces of junk DNA left over from billions of years of evolution.
Noting that bacteria, presumably more primitive than plants and animals, do not have introns in their genes, they say it is more reasonable to assume bacteria never had introns than that they had and later lost them.
But bacteria may have streamlined their genetic material by shedding their introns, leading to the "pleasantly perverse" conclusion that humans can be considered as "less evolved" than bacteria, Dr. Gilbert said with a grin. "Maybe we are not in all ways at the pinnacle of evolution, as people like to think," he said. And worse, maybe nature will evolve right past humans and their junk-laden genomes in the future.
Dr. Gilbert grew up in Boston. His father, Richard Gilbert, was a Harvard economist who belonged to Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal "brains trust."
Science has always come naturally for Dr. Gilbert. As Dr. Mark Ptashne, a Harvard colleague, put it: "He would be a scientist no matter what. Put Wally in a room and give him a pencil and a pipecleaner and he will do an experiment."
He won a Westinghouse science fellowship in high school, went to Harvard for a masters in physics, then to Cambridge University in England for a Ph.D. in mathematics. He worked in theoretical physics until 1964. Then he switched to the awakening field of molecular biology, just as did other physicists, like Max Delbruck, Leo Szilard and Francis Crick, who became leading lights of the new subject.
In 1966, Dr. Gilbert and Dr. Ptashne, working down the hall from each other, independently isolated and described the first two "repressor" molecules, chemical switches that keep genes turned off In 1977, he and Dr. Frederick Sanger of England independently devised methods for rapidly reading the "letter code" of DNA. This work later won him the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. At the same time, biology had become a political issue as critics protested the first uses of genetically engineered organisms. The City Council of Cambridge, Mass., threatened to shut down the biological laboratories and the buildings were cleared periodically because of bomb threats.
Dr. Gilbert, now 64, was an advocate of the new genetic techniques and was one of the first scientists to found a biotechnology company. He studied patent law and management issues with the same energy he brought to pursuits like Chinese cooking, a late-life interest in playing the piano and what is perhaps his current chief passion outside science: the study and collection of ancient, mostly Greek, sculpture.
Following his business interest, Dr. Gilbert left academia to become chief executive officer of Biogen Inc. He ran the company for several years, but in a disagreement over management style, was dismissed by the company's board.
He later founded the Genome Corporation, a company whose purpose was to read all of the genes in the human genome. But the company failed after the stock market crash of 1987 and by 1988, perhaps spurred by Dr. Gilbert's challenge, the Federal Government began its Human Genome Project.
After a long career with an array of accomplishments behind him, Dr. Gilbert is now working at Harvard on the most difficult questions in biology. In his laboratory, young scientists like Sandro De Souza and Manyuan Long are carrying out experiments to probe the origin of the genes. If the genes are indeed composed of smaller modules formed at the dawn of life, it may be possible to figure out when each gene evolved. The theory may hold a practical consequence for drug design, because it may allow scientists to recognize, and thus to manipulate, the different working parts within proteins.
Dr. Gilbert and his colleagues have developed interesting evidence in support of the "exon theory of genes." If genes were originally assembled Tinker Toy-style, some signs of the connectors and joints, as well as of the modules, should still be visible. One such sign is that since the genetic information is processed by the cell in groups of three letters at a time, the parts being mixed and matched need to be in phase, since if the processing machinery gets out of step the genetic message will be garbled.
In a paper published last year, Dr. Gilbert and his colleagues reported finding just such evidence. In looking at 11,000 introns, they found that their ends were still most often "in phase" -- so they could snap together just as in ancient days.
Dr. Gilbert believes he has recently found another faint signature of ancient exons in the structure of modern proteins. Many proteins have a complex architecture in which each region or module performs a different biochemical operation. If these modules are exons that have been repeatedly shuffled around in the course of evolution, then in the protein's gene the introns should still tend to be found at the joints between the modules.
In a paper to be published next month in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Dr. Gilbert, Dr. Long and Dr. De Souza say they have found that introns do indeed occur more often at the boundaries between modules, and that these modules seem to have come in four different sizes. The size pattern is what might be expected if the first exons were small, coding for 15 to 20 of the amino acid units of proteins, and if some later fused into double, triple or quadruple exons.
Critics are skeptical about the conclusions, noting that they rely on statistical arguments, and that these may not hold up as more data emerge from genome-sequencing projects.
Dr. Palmer of Indiana University says that genes do get shuffled but that it is not yet known when the shuffling mechanism first appeared. "New genes do arise by mixing and matching parts," Dr. Palmer said. "That part of Gilbert's theory has been borne out wonderfully. But the question is whether this kind of shuffling occurred in primordial times to assemble the first sets of genes. For that, the evidence is not there."
Dr. Gilbert acknowledges that the data are not overwhelming, but notes that the flood of new data from genome sequencing projects will soon allow the theory to be put to a more exact test. "We are going to know the answers," he said tentatively. Then, with more conviction, he declared: "Yes. We are definitely going to know the answers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Walter Gilbert, in his office at Harvard University last Friday, has used extensive computer and statistical analysis to map out a theory on what the first genes were like. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)(pg. C1)
 
Diagram: "How Did Modern DNA Arrangement Evolve? A Theory"
Dr. Walter Gilbert offers an explanation for how human DNA developed into long stretches of nonsense punctuated by actual genes, or codes for useful proteins. To describe these stretches, he coined the terms introns for the nonsense regions and exons for the informational regions.
 
Three to four billion years ago, simple DNA modules provided the code for producing small pieces of protein.
 
In the first organisms with DNA, introns appeared as long regions of DNA holding the modules, or exons, together, making it easy for them to break and rejoin (recombine) to put the genes in new combinations. In the splicing of the RNA copy, pieces of RNA were lost, leaving the codes for a new protein linked together.
 
A protein made of three exon products was now one chain.
 
In modern complex organisms, the genetic structure includes long stretches of genetic material between exons. In the current structure of bacterial genes, these introns have been dropped, Dr. Gilbert theorizes.
 
Labels here. Probably need to decrease pica width.
(Source: Dr. Walter Gilberte)(pg. C9)

HEADLINE: Japan Announces New Plan to Deregulate Financial Markets

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan announced a plan today for sweeping financial change that he said would create a financial center to rival New York and London by 2001.
Though officials gave few details and financial analysts were skeptical, the plan, if carried out, could help eliminate some of the regulation that makes it difficult and costly to do business here. Mr. Hashimoto is hoping to emulate the so-called Big Bang in London 1986, when brokerage commissions were deregulated, freeing financial markets and setting the stage for strong growth. 
 The goal of the Japanese plan is to make markets "free, fair and global," suggesting that the Government intended to ease nearly all major regulations. It mentioned areas already marked for deregulation like brokerage commissions; foreign-exchange controls, and the tax, accounting and legal systems, and it said that it would lower the wall between the securities and commercial-banking businesses.
The political commitment is being endorsed at the highest levels, and it could bring about lucrative opportunities for foreign financial institutions accustomed to competing in open markets.
But the broad measures face great political opposition, which could significantly dilute and delay the changes envisioned.
"Now the issue is whether we do it or not, whether we bring about results or not," said Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, who was named Finance Minister in the new Cabinet announced last week. "Now I am designated as commander in the front lines, with arrows and bullets falling around me like rain. If a bullet hits me, I could be injured, or I could even die. But I accept that."
Drastic financial deregulation would put many small brokerage firms out of business. And more institutions could file for bankruptcy, especially with the Japanese financial industry still trying to crawl out of a crippling banking crisis.
Though the Government has said that it would guarantee the safety of the financial system, a senior Finance Ministry official, who briefed reporters today on the condition that he not be identified, acknowledged that it would be "difficult" for small institutions.
The official refused to give details on specific regulations that would be lifted, and financial analysts expressed caution. The ministry has repeatedly announced various plans to deregulate markets, and there are book binders filled with proposals. While some have been achieved, most have been delayed or confined to the drafting board.
"There's been a lot of talk about deregulation and we haven't seen much, so the markets are in a kind of 'show me' mood," said Elizabeth L. Daniels of Morgan Stanley Japan. "The market has to be shown that actions can follow verbiage and that it's not just a lot of hot air."
Tokyo is sometimes regarded as the world's third-largest financial center, but over the last few years, the highly regulated Japanese environment has chased away business in the stock, currency and other markets, prompting fears of a "hollowing out" of the country's financial markets.
Foreign companies have been delisting themselves from the Tokyo Stock Exchange; Japanese investors have been buying Japanese shares in London to skirt high trading costs in Tokyo, and Japanese companies have been turning to the offshore Eurodollar markets to escape regulations at home.
Mr. Hashimoto had campaigned on a platform of reform, and today's measures seemed an effort to make good on that. The Government also seems to have recognized that it cannot wait any longer. Financial products familiar to individual investors in Britain and the United States are typically unheard of here. Investment trusts, for instance, cannot be listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, but are sold privately by securities houses. And the securities firms cannot list index funds, a small basket of stocks that try to mimic an index, such as the S.& P. 500.
Brokers' commissions are stipulated by the Government. And a costly securities tax means that buying a stock in Tokyo is significantly more expensive than buying the same stock in London.
Some critics said drastic deregulation of by-the-book rules alone would not be sufficient unless there was also a transformation in the way business was conducted.
"There has to be a change in the mind-set of the participants in the market, and a change in the mind-set of regulators," said Brian J. Waterhouse, a financial analyst at James Capel Pacific.
Another big task will be creating a supervisory organization that can oversee a competitive, deregulated and open market, in the way it is done in Europe and the United States. While there are about 10,000 American officials who regulate, oversee and monitor the various financial markets, Japan has perhaps 1,000.
And though officials here are using the term Big Bang, it may be a misnomer. According to the senior Finance Ministry official, various regulations will be lifted in piece-meal fashion, depending upon when ministerial and legislative approval can be obtained. And while in London in 1986, brokerage commissions were deregulated in one day, Japan is trying to lift many major regulations over a period of time.
The first area of change is expected to be the lifting of some foreign-exchange controls, with a proposal submitted for debate at the next session of Parliament in a few months. But in general, the bills for the financial restructuring are not expected to be submitted for passage until January 1988.

Trade Surplus Lower
TOKYO, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Japan's current-account surplus plunged by more than one-third in the first half of this fiscal year despite a weaker yen, the Government said today, confirming that the contentious trade gap was still shrinking, though at a slower pace.
The surplus in the current account -- the broadest measure of trade in goods and services -- plunged 35.3 percent in the six months ending in September, to 3.33 trillion yen -- roughly $29.7 billion -- compared with the period a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said.
The surplus in merchandise trade alone in the six months decreased 32.1 percent from the period a year earlier, to 4.16 trillion yen, or $37 billion.

HEADLINE: Whitewater Counsel Says He Has Found Lack of Cooperation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In a rare news conference and speech, the Whitewater independent counsel complained here today about a general lack of cooperation with his investigations but said he was making substantial progress anyway.
"It would have been very helpful, frankly, if each person with relevant information had simply come forward -- honestly, truthfully assisted the prosecution in seeking to get at the facts, get at the truth," said the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. "We did not meet with that to the extent that I would have liked. They have Fifth Amendment rights against compelled self-incrimination; they have the right to a trial before their peers." 
 Nonetheless, Mr. Starr said, "We have made very substantial progress both in the Little Rock and the Washington phases of the investigation."
Mr. Starr is overseeing a series of inquiries that began with the links between President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton to a failed Arkansas savings and loan. But the investigations have expanded to include the dismissal of the staff of the White House travel office, the White House's improper acquisition of hundreds of Federal Bureau of Investigation files and the business dealings of Mr. Clinton's associates in Arkansas.
While Mr. Starr said repeatedly that a lack of cooperation had slowed his efforts, he refused to say whether he meant these comments as a criticism of the White House under Mr. Clinton.
"I am not going to direct that observation at anyone," Mr. Starr said.
Susan McDougal, a former business associate of Mr. Clinton in the Whitewater project, an unsuccessful real estate development in Arkansas, was jailed on Sept. 9 by a Federal judge for refusing to answer prosecutors' questions about the President before a grand jury.
Asked after his speech whether Mr. Clinton's re-election last week would affect his work, Mr. Starr replied: "I'm not going to comment on the elections in any respect. I have a job to do."
While describing in some detail the convictions of Arkansas politicians and business people that he has already obtained, Mr. Starr declined to comment on any future indictments he might seek or to discuss any specifics of his examination of the President's conduct. Asked whether the investigation might take one more year or five more years, he said he would like to finish in one year.
"I have no reason to think the latter," he said.
During the election campaign, Mr. Starr said very little in public about his investigation. But he spoke today at the Economic Club of Detroit, a group of business executives, civic leaders and teachers who bring in weekly speakers to educate them on public policy. While the club itself is nonpartisan, many members are Republican.
Mr. Starr said at his press conference this morning that part of his job as independent counsel was to engage in public education. When he was asked whether he was more willing to speak out now that the elections were over, he replied, "It is frankly more appropriate for me to get engaged in an educational function at a time when the American people can now turn back to their hockey, professional football and other activities, and to participate in a dialogue in what I hope and certainly would seek to be an appropriate but limited way."
Mr. Starr noted that he had spoken publicly about the process of an independent counsel investigation shortly after taking the job and that he had made some public appearances since then. After his speech this afternoon, he said he had agreed to address the Oklahoma Bar Association in Oklahoma City on Thursday.
Mr. Starr opened his speech to the several hundred club members by defining "civic virtue," a phrase that he acknowledged had "a fusty sound, something out of old age and quill pens." He went on to give a synopsis of the developments in the Whitewater case so far, occasionally criticizing the view that it has become too complicated for many Americans to understand.
"It is, at its origin, about lying, false statements and fraud that contributed to the demise of a Federally insured savings and loan in Little Rock," he said.
"It is, at its base, lying and fraud to secure loans for wealthy and influential people from yet another financial institution," he added.
Mr. Starr said several times that his efforts to investigate the President were not motivated by any partisanship, as Democrats have sometimes suggested.
"The charge is utterly wrong," he volunteered early in his speech.

HEADLINE: Index of Demand for Chips Soars to High for This Year

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded sharply in October, reaching its highest level since last year, a trade group reported today. Analysts had expected a gain, but the actual number exceeded even the most optimistic estimates.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.10, up from a revised figure of 0.98 in September. The ratio compares orders with shipments, so, the reading of 1.10 indicates that for every $100 worth of chips shipped, $110 was ordered. That is considered a sign that the industry is again growing. 
 Analysts hailed the number, which was the largest since 1.12 in December, as the harbinger of a new boom cycle for the chip industry.
The return to a reading above one comes after last week's announcement by the Intel Corporation, the world's largest semiconductor company, that its fourth-quarter results would exceed previous estimates because of a surge of orders from personal computer manufacturers.
The book-to-bill reflected "a real acceleration of microprocessor orders, and that's Intel," Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Montgomery Securities, said.
But he noted that prices had firmed for D-RAM, or dynamic random access memory, chips, the most common type of chips produced by many other manufacturers, which had been in oversupply much of the year. "That's a real healthy sign that we're seeing a reacceleration," Mr. Joseph said.
Chip orders in October rose to $3.74 billion, up $566 million, or 18 percent, from $3.17 billion in September, according to the trade group. Shipments also increased, to $3.39 billion, up $161 million, or 5 percent, from $3.23 billion in September.
The book-to-bill ratio has been the subject of much criticism in recent months, and the association said today that it would stop publishing the number at the end of the year.
In January, the trade group will begin publishing the Global Billings Report, which will reflect sales of chips worldwide; the book-to-bill covers only the markets in North and South America, which account for roughly a third of total chip sales.
"The new program will give industry observers a more accurate picture of trends in the world semiconductor market as business continues to expand and diversify," Thomas W. Armstrong, the association's president, said in a statement. "Instead of focusing on book-to-bill ratios for just one major market, people will get to review sales numbers from all four major markets."
While the addition of Japanese, Asian-Pacific and European data represents an improvement, analysts said, the new report will be subject to some of the distortions that have plagued the old one.
For one thing, the data are tabulated in dollar amounts, rather than in units, so any drops in price can indicate a decline in orders even though volume is actually increasing; such a situation occurred earlier this year.
And because the ratio is based on a three-month moving average, one unusually good or bad month skews the number for the entire period, analysts said.
Dan Niles, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company, said this type of distortion explained the surprising figure for October.
"Part of the reason this number looks so good is they dropped off July, which was just a horrendous month, and they added a phenomenal October," he said. "That's how you get to 1.10 when nobody expected more than 1.03."
Still, Mr. Niles said he was happy with the October number: "For a long time, I've said the summer was the bottom. This is just another indication that was the case."
