HEADLINE: Stocks Rise in Light Day; Dow Up 35.78

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks continued to rally yesterday, sending the the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500 index and Nasdaq composite index to record highs.
Prices gained strength from the opening bell and never flagged, as the Dow industrials rallied 35.78 points, to 6,255.60. It was the Dow's fourth consecutive record close. 
 In the broader market, the S.& P. 500 rose 1.05 points, to 731.87, marking its 33d record of the year.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 5.16 points, to a record 1,262.67, eclipsing a record dating from Oct. 15.
Stock market investors were unable to take their cue from the Treasury bond market, which, along with banks, was closed in observance of Veterans Day.
Because of the holiday, trading volume was much lighter than usual, at 354 million shares.
Investors said they saw no reason to expect anything other than rising corporate profits, moderate economic growth of 2 percent to 3 percent, subdued inflation and low interest rates.
"This market right now is in nirvana," said Philip Schettewi, a money manager who helps oversee $3.8 billion for Loomis, Sayles & Company in Washington. "All the ingredients for a bull market are still there, and it's very potent."
Eastman Kodak led the Dow industrials as investors anticipated rising profits this year and next. The shares benefited from a recommendation from CS First Boston, which named the company its "featured stock of the week." Its shares rose 1 5/8, to 82 5/8.
Semiconductor stocks climbed for a ninth day. After the market closed, a trade association said computer chip makers received $110 in new orders for every $100 of chips shipped last month, the first time this year that the book-to-bill ratio of orders to shipments had exceeded the level of 1.0.
Intel rose 1 5/8. to 123 7/8; Texas Instruments Inc., gained 2 1/8, to 56, and Micron Technology climbed 2 1/2, to 32 1/2.
Shares of Philip Morris up 1 5/8, to 99 3/8, were helped by a decision by College Retirement Equities Fund to reject a shareholder proposal to sell all the fund's tobacco stocks.
UST Inc., maker of Copenhagen and Skoal snuff and chewing tobacco, gained 3/4, to 30 5/8. The company announced plans to buy back as many as 20 million shares after it completes its current repurchase program.
Walt Disney jumped 1 7/8, to a record 70 3/8. The movie studio and theme-park operator raked in $35 million in ticket sales during the first weekend of release for its Mel Gibson blockbuster, "Ransom." Paine Webber Inc. also raised its investment opinion on Disney today to "attractive" from "neutral."
Retail stocks climbed in anticipation of fiscal third-quarter earnings scheduled for release this week from both Gap Inc. and the Woolworth Corporation.
Gap, owner of the Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic chains, rose 7/8, to 32 1/4, while Woolworth, which owns the Foot Locker chain and is part of the Dow industrials, climbed 7/8, to 22 3/4.
Tyson Foods Inc. surged 2 3/4, to 31 1/8. The poultry producer forecast lower grain prices and improved earnings.
Qualcomm Inc. rallied 2 1/4, to 44 3/4. Lehman Brothers repeated to clients that shares in the maker of telecommunications equipment should be bought, and were likely to rise to $65 each.
Loral Space and Communications gained 7/8, to 17 1/2. The satellite maker's Globalstar L.P. unit signed an agreement with China giving it access to the country's telephone and wireless communications networks.
Lockheed Martin Corporation jumped 1 5/8, to 90 1/4.

HEADLINE: New Malta Chief Focuses on Neutrality

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Nov. 9

 BODY:
At a time when countries are lining up to join the European club, along comes tiny Malta -- an island nation in the middle of the Mediterranean with a population the size of Cincinnati's -- and says, "No, thank you."
The results of elections here on Oct. 27 took many by surprise, not least the incumbent Nationalist Party, which after nine years of prosperity had expected a pat on the back for putting the country in line for the European Union's next round of admissions. 
 Instead, victory went to the Maltese Labor Party, and its leader, Alfred Sant, a 48-year-old former diplomat with a doctorate from the Harvard Business School, whose methodical, poker-face style has broken the mold of Malta's high-pitched, sometimes violent political tradition.
For the 370,000 people who live on Malta's three islands, the issues this year had less to do with foreign policy and everything to do with taxes -- in particular a hugely unpopular 15 percent value-added tax that came to be seen as the price exacted from Maltese pocketbooks for European membership.
Then there were Malta's hunters, a small lobby whose protests against recent restrictions on bird hunting added heat to resentments over a perceived invasion of Maltese sovereignty.
It fell to Mr. Sant to take these intensely local issues and couch them in terms of Malta's neutrality -- a clause in the Maltese Constitution written by a previous Labor Government and now held by its heirs to be the safeguard of a sovereignty that withstood sieges by the Ottoman Turks in the 16th century and by the Nazis in World War II.
Within hours of taking office, Mr. Sant withdrew Malta's membership in Partnership for Peace, a NATO military cooperation program that is so loosely defined that its sign-up list now spans the spectrum from Russia to Switzerland. He also says he wants to renegotiate Malta's relationship with the European Union, although he has stopped short of withdrawing its application for full membership.
Mr. Sant says none of those moves should be interpreted as anti-European or anti-American, but simply as the best way of insuring Malta's security.
"We are at the center of the Mediterranean, a region that has to be stable, and we feel that through neutrality, we can help maintain that stability," he said in an interview.
Although the end of the cold war and new advanced weapons have deprived Malta of the strategic importance it had when it was home to a NATO naval base in the 1960's, its location on a volatile north-south dividing line, between the southernmost tip of Sicily and the northern coast of Africa, puts it in a delicate position. Many here see Islamic militancy, already apparent in Algeria, as a major threat to the region.
But as always, it is Malta's relations with Libya, 140 miles to the south, that are the focus of international attention, just as they were during the Labor Governments in the 1970's and early 1980's, when the contacts grew particularly close.
The Nationalist Government, which came to power in 1987, also maintained neighborly relations with Libya, but the main thrust of its foreign policy was northward to Europe, which it regarded as Malta's lifeline for the future.
Mr. Sant talks of improving the Maltese-Libyan commercial relations, although he insisted that Malta would continue to observe the United Nations-sponsored economic sanctions imposed as a result of Libya's refusal to extradite suspects in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
"We would like sanctions to stop because it cramps our economic relations," he said. But he added that Malta had little influence on the issue. "Frankly, if Malta lobbies, no one notices. I am very modest. We would like to see the problem of Lockerbie solved, but it is up to the United States and Libya."
In his first two weeks in office, Mr. Sant has tried to reassure both the United States and Europe that he is not about to make any sharp changes in Malta's policies, or bring back the confrontational style of a former Labor Prime Minister, Dom Mintoff.
The new Maltese Foreign Minister, George Vella, recently opened a special meeting on nuclear nonproliferation and export controls that was attended by several representatives of American Government agencies, while the island's ports have continued to receive visits from foreign naval vessels.
Mr. Sant said he expected to reduce the frequency of those port calls by foreign navies. "We don't want Malta to be an outstation," he said. "Yes to visits, but within certain limits."
Former Prime Minister Edward Fenech Adami, who was ousted in the October election, said he feared that Malta's slackened interest in membership in the European Union would discourage the foreign investors who are crucial for an economy already heavily dependent on Europe.
"There is a big entity next door to us that already exists, and that is Europe," Mr. Fenech Adami said in an interview. "We cannot ignore it, and we cannot afford to be left out."
Foreign diplomats and local political experts, still alert for any signs of the kind of policies that once made Malta an international irritant, say they have been reassured by Mr. Sant's cautious style.
"I am taking it slowly," Mr. Sant said. "Everybody expected me to go chop, chop, chop, and they are surprised I am not doing that."

HEADLINE: Giuliani, 1997 in Mind, Focuses On Education and Attacks Rivals

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
With the Presidential election out of the way, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun to marshal several core elements of his as-yet unannounced re-election campaign, trumpeting the precipitous drop in crime while moving quickly to establish credentials in education. And with growing asperity, he now belittles most of his likely opponents as machine politicians of the past.
For months, the Mayor has basked in the city's growing reputation as a safer place to live and do business, aided by some improvement in the local economy. "New York is in the midst of a renaissance," he said in an interview yesterday, sounding what is expected to become the principal theme of his campaign. 
 But as his Democratic opponents have tried to change the subject, repeatedly pointing to the failures of the public school system, Mr. Giuliani has all but acknowledged that he cannot run on crime-fighting alone.
Thus, after three years of cutting the school system's projected spending by more than $1.2 billion, the Mayor announced on Thursday that growing tax revenues had allowed him to find an extra $70 million to spend on new schoolbooks to replace the system's aging texts, more than doubling the amount already budgeted for schoolbooks.
In three appearances last week to mark National Reading Week, the Mayor appeared before television cameras at schools and public libraries reading to children and talking about the importance of the textbooks he had decided to buy.
He also extolled the performance of the Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, and the relationship of trust the two men have built.
Yesterday, in announcing the appointment of Martin D. Raab, a prominent architect, as president and chief executive of the School Construction Authority, the Mayor stood by as Dr. Crew returned the favor, declaring that the school system had entered a period of "good times."
"These are good times, for obvious reasons," said Dr. Crew, only a few weeks after the headlines were declaring an overcrowding crisis in city schools. "Our children benefited the other day from a major step in the right direction in terms of books that are going to be placed in classrooms, and today signals an opportunity for our children to rejoice over the fact that they will have classrooms, by virtue of the work that Martin will undertake."
Mr. Giuliani has also begun to amplify the harshness of his attacks on his most likely Democratic opponents, linking them explicitly to the administration of David N. Dinkins, whom he vanquished in 1993, and doing his best to remind voters of what life was like during that period.
"All of them have some interesting questions to answer," he said in a telephone interview yesterday. "They have all been perennial parts of the city and state governments for over 20 years and did nothing to change any of this. They are much more the insiders of government than I am. I've done more to change city government in a few short years than they ever did. They just sat by and watched all of this happen and did nothing about it."
The Mayor has been particularly critical of Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, calling her "the most left" of the possible candidates, and of Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, whom he called one of the "machine politicians" of New York City.
Unlike Ms. Messinger, Mr. Hevesi has not yet decided whether to run for mayor, but last week Mr. Giuliani blasted the Comptroller for opposing the planned sale of Coney Island Hospital, saying Mr. Hevesi wanted to "maintain it for the political bosses so they can have jobs."
Though many Democrats privately predict that the Republican Mayor will be re-elected, Mr. Giuliani himself has taken no chances in a city dominated by Democrats, and in which he does not have a strong political organization behind him. He has raised more than $6 million, far more than any of his potential challengers, and has clearly taken note of tepid approval ratings that have hovered in the high 40's and low 50's.
A survey taken by Quinnipiac College last month showed that while 76 percent of those polled said they approved of his handling of crime, only 54 percent said they approved of his overall performance. Only 34 percent of those surveyed voiced approval of his performance on education. A similar poll taken by the Marist Institute in September found that 46 percent of the respondents said they had confidence in the Mayor's ability to improve the city schools, while 54 percent said they were not confident.
"With the concerns people have about schools and the amount of money in the educational budget, it can't help but become a major campaign issue, and appropriately so," said Robert Berne, dean of the Wagner School of Public Service at New York University. "Any mayor and particularly this Mayor has shown that he can influence the system. The challengers will make a case on whether that influence has been the right influence."
The challengers, of course, have already begun to do that. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, said yesterday that the Mayor apparently recognized that he had had a "one-note administration," and had to begin recognizing the concerns of New Yorkers in areas like education and jobs.
Ms. Messinger said much the same yesterday. "People inside the schools are immensely disturbed at the loss of funds, the deterioration of buildings, the lack of serious focus on teaching and learning," she said. "I hope the Mayor starts to listen, and that this week was not an accident."
The Mayor himself says that his record on education has been "excellent," saying Dr. Crew and his staff have done more to revive education in the city than has been done in a long time. With growing sensitivity, he has in particular lashed out at those who have accused him of cutting the school budget, insisting that the city is spending more than ever on the Board of Education.
Some of the budgetary dispute revolves around the Byzantine nature of the board's spending. The Mayor acknowledges that he has cut the amount requested by the board by a total of $1.2 billion, but he says the actual amount the city spends on the school system has gone up. But the City Comptroller's comprehensive annual financial report, long considered the final authority at City Hall on spending, shows that city spending on education has declined each year from 1994, even before inflation is considered.
More important, the amount the city spends per student has unquestionably fallen, because the number of students grows by about 20,000 a year. In 1994, the city spent $2,721 per student; in the fiscal year that ended in July, the city spent $2,424, adjusted for inflation. The amount will further decline this year, according to budget projections.
"To the extent my opponents criticize me for these things, they've had many years to correct them," the Mayor said. "Obviously, if I run for re-election, one of the things I'll be asking is, what have they ever done? What kind of record do they ever have? The condition of the New York City school system did not happen in just a few years; it happened over a long period of time, and these people have been in government just about that long. If you wanted a theme, that's part of the theme."

HEADLINE: Pataki Welfare Plan Would Cut Payments to Families Over Time

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Proposing the biggest changes in the 60-year history of the state's welfare system, Gov. George E. Pataki will offer legislation this week to cut the monthly grants of hundreds of thousands of poor families and end cash benefits for many immigrants and able-bodied childless adults, his aides said today.
The plan, which Mr. Pataki is expected to announce on Wednesday, is intended to bring New York State into compliance with the broad rules laid down in the new Federal welfare law, and represents his opening bid in negotiations with the Legislature. Those talks, which will begin in earnest when Mr. Pataki presents his 1998 budget in January, are likely to be drawn out and bitter, if past years are any guide. 
 The Governor's bill will call for reducing monthly benefits by 10 percent after a family has been on welfare for 18 months. Benefits will then be cut in stages during the next three years, for a total reduction of 45 percent. After five years, families will be dropped from the rolls entirely, as mandated by the Federal law.
If the plan were enacted next year, a family of three living in New York City would see their monthly benefit check shrink to $519 by the year 1999, from the current $577. Their benefits would then decline each year, hitting $317 a month by 2002, a cut of $265 a month from the current level.
The Governor's aides said his plan would offset that cut by allowing families to keep up to $1,080 a month from jobs without losing any of their welfare grant. Currently, the state begins cutting benefits once a household earns more than $667 a month.
In its broadest outlines, the plan resembles legislation the Governor proposed in 1995 and again earlier this year, which called for reducing benefit levels and setting time limits on welfare grants. Both proposals were rejected by the Democratic-controlled Assembly. But Pataki aides say that the revamped Federal law, which sets a host of restrictions on benefits and reduce Federal spending on welfare by $55 billion over six years, will force the Assembly Democrats to accept many of those ideas next year.
"It's different this time," Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications, said today. "We have to be in compliance with the Federal welfare law."
The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, who will be the Democrats' chief welfare negotiator, was out of the country today and could not be reached for comment. But Mr. Silver has in the past strongly opposed cutting benefits for families or individuals, and is expected to do so again.
The Governor's plan does not break new ground among the states, many of which have already ended cash benefits for able-bodied childless adults and have proposed cuts and strict time limits on benefits for families. But New York State has long had among the most generous welfare systems in the nation, so the Governor's proposal, if enacted, would represent a sea change from current policies.
There are 1.4 million people on welfare in New York State, costing $3.8 billion a year, which is divided among the state, Federal and local governments. Total caseloads are down by 200,000 since Mr. Pataki took office in 1995, largely because of new work requirements and tougher screening of applicants in New York City, which accounts for 70 percent of the state's welfare spending.
Though Mr. Pataki's aides could not provide precise estimates of how much his welfare plan would save, it is likely to reduce state spending by several hundred million dollars, money that could be used to close the state's projected $3 billion shortfall for the coming fiscal year.
Mr. Pataki's aides say his proposal is as much about ending welfare dependency as about closing budget gaps. The plan, parts of which were first described in Newsday today, is intended to encourage welfare recipients to work by allowing them to keep more of their earnings from jobs, and to discourage them from remaining on welfare by reducing benefit levels.
The Governor would also allow families to continue receiving Medicaid, the Federal-state health care program for the poor, for up to a year after they find jobs and leave welfare. Under current law, people lose their Medicaid benefits as soon as they go off welfare. Many experts say mothers often stay on welfare instead of taking low-paying jobs because of fears about losing their health insurance.
The plan calls for increasing state spending on day care for welfare recipients and working-poor parents by $130 million in the coming year, to $630 million. It proposes establishing a $150 million fund to help pay for new day care and job placement programs in future years. The Federal law requires states to place an increasing number of welfare recipients in work programs each year, reaching a maximum of 50 percent of the eligible caseload by 2002.
The monthly welfare grant of $577 for a family of three in New York City has not been raised since 1990, despite inflation. And since no allowance is made for inflation in the reductions proposed in the Governor's new plan, the cut in purchasing power would actually be more than 45 percent.
The state's current welfare system is divided into two main areas: Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the Federal, state and local program for families currently serving 1.15 million people; and Home Relief, the state and local program mainly for childless adults, which serves 272,000 people. Both programs are now entitlements that provide cash benefits for as long as a recipient can demonstrate need.
Mr. Pataki's plan would overhaul both programs. Aid to Families with Dependent Children, which would be renamed New York Works, would set a five-year lifetime limit on benefits and require all able-bodied adults to participate in workfare programs in exchange for their benefits.
Home Relief would be replaced by two new programs. Able-bodied, childless adults would be placed in a so-called safety net program that would replace cash benefits with vouchers for food, shelter and clothing. Caseworkers would be given broad authority to determine the value of monthly vouchers, with the power to end payments when a recipient could no longer demonstrate need. Voucher recipients would also be required to participate in work programs.
Home Relief recipients who cannot work because of mental or physical disabilities would be placed in a separate state program paying cash benefits. That program would also be open to the elderly, people with disabled dependents and people with AIDS.
New immigrants would be among the most adversely affected by the combined effects of the Federal law and Mr. Pataki's proposals.
Under the Federal changes, most immigrants who arrived here after Aug. 22 will not be eligible for Federal benefits. The new law also ends Supplemental Security Income, which goes to the disabled and elderly, for most immigrants.
Mr. Pataki's plan would continue to pay cash benefits to immigrant families who arrived in the United States before Aug. 22. But immigrant families who arrived after that date would be treated the same as able-bodied single people: no longer eligible for cash payments, only for the more limited voucher program. Immigrants who lose their S.S.I. payments would also be eligible for vouchers, not cash grants.
Advocates for the poor called Mr. Pataki's proposal to cut benefits punitive, and predicted that it would fail in the Assembly.
"It's an absurd proposition," said Shelly Nortz, director of state policy for the Coalition for the Homeless. "People are on welfare for reasons that have little to do with their purported laziness and everything to do with things like an inability to speak English, mental illness, addictions, asthma. Those are things that cutting benefits 45 percent over four years just is not going to fix."

HEADLINE: Pressing Reform, Child Welfare Commissioner Looks to Los Angeles

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
By her own reckoning, Gloria Jones could hardly have been a worse mother. She was unwed, unemployed and a chronic drug abuser. Discipline often meant a scream and a slap. And she had lost her children to foster care twice because of neglect, and was on the verge of losing them permanently.
That is when Charles Thomas came into her life. Instead of removing Ms. Jones's three daughters again, a judge assigned Mr. Thomas, a social worker and family therapist, to smother her with constant guidance and attention. 
 Since that appointment in late 1995, Mr. Thomas has worked intensely with the family, on call 7 days a week, 24 hours a day. He arranged drug counseling and classes in child care and spiritual life at a local church. He helped bring order to the family's once chaotic and squalid apartment. And he has become her advocate on an array of concrete problems related to poverty, like getting her rent -- which was more than a year in arrears -- paid on time.
This new approach, based on intensive supervision and using networks of neighborhood institutions, is bringing national attention to the Los Angeles County child welfare office and is about to be embraced in New York City. In September, Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of New York's Administration for Children's Services, praised the approach used here, saying that he wanted to replace much of the vast bureaucracy responsible for protecting New York's most vulnerable children with dozens of neighborhood-based networks based on the Los Angeles model.
Under the old model, social workers faced a stark choice: either leave vulnerable children with their parents, with little monitoring, or move them to foster and group homes. Child welfare authorities often let cases slide for years rather than make such a bleak choice.
Now, Los Angeles County, using two dozen neighborhood-based networks of churches, medical centers and social service groups to help children before they suffer serious neglect or abuse, is seen by child welfare experts as having one of the most successful programs in the nation.
Mr. Scoppetta and his aides have traveled to Los Angeles and observed firsthand the program, which began in 1992. But, they say it is too early to tell when a similar program might be implemented in New York.
The idea behind the program is simple: community-based organizations are likely to know more about a child's neighborhood and family environment than a fragmented, complex central bureaucracy. In theory, intervention by social workers familiar with the family itself is also likely to be less threatening than workers from a remote bureaucracy.
So far, the Los Angeles model is proving to be cost-effective. Peter Digre, director of the Los Angeles County Department of Child and Family Services, said the cost of placing a child in foster care or a shelter and of providing care by psychologists and specialists could be $30,000 a year; the neighborhood network cost about half that.
The underlying premise of these intensive family preservation programs is that a community-based caseworker can quickly identify problems and correct them after observing a family at home for several hours a day, several times a week. Free of rigid office schedules and paperwork, caseworkers like Mr. Thomas can be available any time family members need them.
"I like their family preservation program a lot because it takes into account the fact that families cannot function on their own, they can only function in the context of the wider community," said Carole Shauffer, executive director of the Youth Law Center in San Francisco, a public interest firm.
She added, "They also have very high, very specific procedural safety standards that require lots of contact between the family preservation worker and the child to insure that they are safe in homes where there still are some questions about their safety."
Most family preservation programs inject a brief but intensive dose of counseling and social services, typically for six weeks. By contrast, the Los Angeles program is intended to connect a family to a community system for the long term.
"Our approach organizes the churches, schools, mental health centers and numerous other community-based organizations to work with the entire family," said Bruce Rubenstein, the Los Angeles agency's deputy director for community development.
"When public assistance pulls out, the family is still connected to neighborhood organizations, and children are protected by these ongoing connections," he said. "The singular caseworker approach often fails to deal with issues of social isolation. And social isolation is one of the key factors in the most egregious cases of child abuse and homicide."
Before the new program, Ms. Jones said, she had only minimal contact with county child welfare officials, and she resented what she perceived as their heavy-handed efforts to run her life.
"They didn't look beyond what they could see, they didn't try to understand what kind of person I really was," she said.
A year later, the Jones family is still together, and Ms. Jones said she was confident about her new skills as a parent. Chaos at home has been replaced with regular mealtimes, bedtimes and limits, she said, backed by positive discipline.
"Before I got in this program, I'd get mad and go off and cuss and holler if somebody tried to tell me what to do," she said at her modest apartment in South-Central Los Angeles. "But I've learned how to control my temper, my attitude and my mouth. I'm not as quick to go off, and I accept criticism a lot more easier."
She has also quit smoking marijuana, a once-daily habit that she said made her scatterbrained and unreliable.
The strategy now covers about 80 percent of Los Angeles County, an area of about nine million people, more than three million of them children. There are roughly 180,000 reports of child abuse a year. All of the figures are comparable to or exceed those in New York City, yet the department's budget is $830 million, well under New York's $1.2 billion.
Critics suggest the family preservation strategy leaves many children vulnerable. "These programs have been grossly oversold," said Richard J. Gelles, director of the Family Violence Research Program at the University of Rhode Island and the author of "Book of David: How Preserving Families Can Cost Children's Lives." "There is no evidence, using controlled, quality empirical research, that placements are avoided, that costs are saved or that child and family well-being is improved."
Mr. Gelles and other critics also say that child welfare workers and judges often direct prevention services to families who are not on the verge of losing their children to foster care. So while the programs help the families, they do not necessarily save money on foster care.
Moreover, there is no shortage of skeptics who doubt that such a plan could work in New York City. Some suspect it is nothing more than an attempt to privatize another government function. Others believe it will be too costly for a city administration intent on reducing spending.
One of the few in-depth studies of family preservation programs, a 1993 evaluation of 1,600 Illinois families, found no evidence that the program saved money or prevented the splintering of families.
Researchers with the Chapin Hall Center for Children at the University of Chicago concluded that the Illinois family preservation program helped some families cope with concrete problems related to poverty, like an eviction notice or a balky welfare department, but did not fundamentally change family relationships.
Proponents of the Los Angeles model say, however, that the Illinois study is largely irrelevant. For one thing, the assistance offered in Illinois typically lasted three months, compared with six months to a year or more in the Los Angeles program. In addition, the Illinois study involved families that were getting help from a single caseworker; in most instances, the Los Angeles model involves several counselors and agencies working together.
Moreover, while family preservation has sometimes been criticized for its failure to protect children in their own homes, the Los Angeles program requires that both law enforcement officials and social workers visit the family after any report of abuse. And both must agree that the child is safe. Otherwise, foster care is mandated.
Of course, there is no guarantee that providing more services to fragile families will keep children safe. There is always the danger that problems will resurface after the caseworkers leave.
"We're dealing with people who pretty much have had to scheme and connive and manipulate to make it from day to day," Mr. Thomas, the caseworker, said as he sat with Ms. Jones. "And, for whatever reasons, whether they are lazy and unmotivated or got a bad deal from the system, the bottom line is that they're dysfunctional. And it takes a long time to get people to turn around."
As for Ms. Jones, he added: "I believe she knows to watch out for her kids, she's better equipped in terms of knowing what to do to maintain a safe environment. But Gloria likes to party, she's wild and she's still dysfunctional, and a lot of that she doesn't want to change."

HEADLINE: Insurer Plans 1,800 New Jobs in Manhattan

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
One of the nation's largest insurance companies, American International Group, is planning to keep its headquarters in downtown Manhattan for the next 15 years and to add more than 1,800 new jobs in return for tax breaks, city officials said.
The company has agreed to retain 5,180 jobs in New York City, most of them at 175 Water Street, a building the company bought in 1995 from National Westminster Bank after the bank left the city. The company is also projecting that 1,858 new jobs will be added downtown through growth and consolidation of leased properties outside the city. 
 Development officials were quick to praise the city for making the deal, citing it as a sign that efforts to reinvigorate downtown Manhattan are working. The incentives package was first reported yesterday in The New York Post.
"This is a huge deal for downtown and the City of New York," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business improvement district. "A.I.G. is one of the strongest insurance companies in the country. This helps secure downtown as the financial center of the country into the next century."
It is difficult to compare incentive deals directly, those familiar with the process said, because each package blends a host of benefits from the city, the state and utilities. They also noted that all jobs are not equal, with executives providing more tax revenue and other economic benefits to the city than lower-paid workers.
Nevertheless, a total of 7,038 jobs in the new deal and a total incentive of $55.7 million works out to about $7,914 a job. In the city's last big retention deal, with C.S. First Boston in 1995, $50.5 million to keep 3,000 jobs translated into $16,833 per job. At a time of shrinking public budgets, city and state officials have sometimes faced criticism that they are too quick to grant tax breaks to retain employers.
Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, noted that $47.3 million in incentives for American International was earmarked for keeping 5,180 jobs. The remaining $8.4 million is based on the additional 1,858 jobs and is dependent on those jobs moving to or being created in New York.
Real estate executives said the decision by American International is another encouraging sign that the downtown area is slowly improving, after being badly battered by the shrinkage of the securities and related industries in the early 1990's, and the moving of many prominent firms to midtown.
"We are starting to see clear signs of recovery," said Joseph Costabile, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield, a large brokerage. "It's starting to happen, but it is a matter of pace. Downtown will not recover as fast as midtown."
Others in the industry said American International signaled a commitment to downtown when it paid $52.7 million for the 600,000-square-foot building on Water Street, near the South Street Seaport. The company is expected to keep its headquarters at nearby 70 Pine Street, but to use the Water Street building to consolidate workers now in other buildings in New York City and elsewhere.

HEADLINE: Survivor Leads Fight For Lost Holocaust Money;
In Lawsuit Against Swiss Banks, A Hope to Do Justice to a Father's Memory

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
For half a century, Gizella Weisshaus followed a trail of whispers.
She followed it three times to Switzerland, searching for a bank account her father opened there during World War II, hoping his family could escape the Nazis and use the money to rebuild their lives. 
 For Mrs. Weisshaus, who lost everyone and everything in the war, memory was the only proof she had. But Swiss banking officials said that without an account number, they could not help her.
The teen-age girl who survived the Holocaust grew older. She became a mother, and a grandmother. Now Mrs. Weisshaus, 66, says time is of the essence.
"Our people are not getting younger," said Mrs. Weisshaus, who has asked the United States courts to intervene. "I'm considered one of the youngest survivors, so there's going to be nobody left to claim this money. That's why I felt this was the only way to force them to disclose these so-called dormant accounts. We are the survivors, and we are entitled to the money and information."
Mrs. Weisshaus is believed to be the first Holocaust survivor in the United States to sue the banks of Switzerland for unclaimed accounts made by Jews throughout Europe fearing that their assets would be seized by Germany. Many of those Jews later died in the Holocaust. The class-action suit, filed in Federal court last month, accuses Swiss banks of failing to return money and valuables deposited by Jews during World War II, as well as wealth stolen from them by the Nazis.
Since the suit was filed, Mrs. Weisshaus's lawyers say that more than 3,000 survivors have come forward asking to join it. And the case has become the emotional center of a growing furor over Switzerland's dealings with the Nazis during and after World War II.
"These aren't people who say there's a lawsuit, let me go jump on the bandwagon," said Ed Fagan, one of Mrs. Weisshaus's lawyers. "These are people who have for 50 years been trying to get their money."
Swiss Government and banking officials maintain that they have searched exhaustively for such accounts in the past, but are willing to do so again to put the matter to rest.
"The Swiss have pledged that at the end of this process, not one penny will remain in Switzerland that may have belonged to a victim of the Holocaust," Jeffrey Taufield, a spokesman for the Swiss Bankers Association, said.
In the years before and during World War II, many Jews deposited money and valuables in Switzerland, where banking secrecy laws could protect their assets from the Nazis. And soon after the war ended, the battle over abandoned accounts and looted assets left in that country began.
But only in the last year has the issue shifted into the spotlight, partly because documents long classified have been made public and partly because 50th anniversary examinations of the war have fostered a greater understanding of the Holocaust.

A Father Shares A Secret and Vanishes
The Senate Banking Committee, headed by the Republican Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, has held hearings with survivors and says it has found evidence to support claims that Swiss banking authorities withheld many deposits. And a Swiss historian, Dr. Peter Hug, has recently spoken of supposedly secret deals that Switzerland struck with former Communist eastern European countries to use dormant accounts of Holocaust victims to compensate Swiss businesses for expropriated assets.
Equally important, some say, has been the growing willingness of survivors and witnesses to take on a battle that some had viewed as too painful to fight.
"People had come through such a horror and done whatever they had to do to survive," said David Cohen, who accompanied a survivor who was considering joining the lawsuit. "The tiny fraction of dignity they were able to hold on to during the war was worth more than all the money they had in the bank. So if even the thought of being turned down or rejected or treated like a pariah was there, they would have stayed far from it."
But Mrs. Weisshaus felt she had no choice. A black-and-white picture of her with her father rests on a table. "I have to do justice to his memory," she said.
She was born in Sighet, Romania, in 1929, where her father was a prosperous merchant. When the war began, food was harder to come by and fuel was low. "But I had my family," said Mrs. Weisshaus, the oldest of seven children. "And we were happy."
Then "in 1944, about the end of March, the Germans came into our town," Mrs. Weisshaus said. She was 14 when her family was sent to live in one room in a ghetto. Later, her father was arrested.
But he came home once more, to say goodbye, and to share his secret.
"My father came home with a guard to say goodbye to the family," she said. "He spoke first with my mother. And then he took all the children around him and he told us he had money hidden in the walls, and money in a Swiss bank. And that was it. That was the last I saw of my father."
The next day, the rest of her family boarded cattle cars for a three-day journey to Auschwitz in German-occupied Poland. When they arrived, the newcomers were divided into two groups. Mrs. Weisshaus was separated from her family, despite her mother's plea to the guards to let the young girl go with her. "They wouldn't do it," she said, "and they sent me to the other side where I went to work." Mrs. Weisshaus said she was taken to a forced-labor camp. The other group, which included her mother, siblings and grandparents, was killed.
The fighting kept inching closer to the camp, and so the guards forced their prisoners to march, locking them in barns at night. "And so it happened one day that they didn't open the barn," she said. The prisoners banged on the door. It opened, and standing outside were Russian soldiers. "And then we found out it was the end of the war."

From Swiss Banks, Nothing but Rebuff
Mrs. Weisshaus, then 15, returned to her hometown. "I was sure somebody was going to be alive," she said. A great-uncle whom she had never met went to the train station every day to ask people if they knew who had survived. It was there where he learned of his brother's granddaughter, Gizella. He told her to come live with him, that he would take care of her. "I said I have to go home and find my family," she recalled. "I should be there when they come."
But no one ever did. In all, Mrs. Weisshaus lost 55 relatives. She salvaged pictures of her family from her old home, and remembered her father's message that there was money hidden there.
The Russian soldiers who now lived there would drink through the night and sleep during the day, she said. So she would sneak through the backyard and into the attic to search. She scraped the walls and tapped the floor until she finally found the small treasure, hidden in hollowed-out places inside the ceiling's beams. There was more than $1,500 dollars, a gold watch, French coins and small pieces of gold.
With no family left, she sought out a matchmaker who found her a husband, Josef. Mrs. Weisshaus used some of the money she found in the attic to buy cloth for a wedding dress.
"I would give that money away for anybody," she said. "I should have had some relatives survive. I mean most of my friends, they had sisters, or cousins, or aunts or somebody to belong to. I had nobody."
She and her family moved to the United States in 1950, settling among other Satmar Hasidic Jews in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But Mrs. Weisshaus never forgot her father's whispers about the money in Switzerland. She visited different Swiss banks, three times in eight years, and everywhere she went, she was rebuffed.
"I had to have something that is impossible to get," she said of the bank officials' demands for an account number. "And that's why they got away with this for all this time."
Then, earlier this year, the Swiss government appointed an ombudsman to look into the claims of Holocaust survivors regarding the dormant accounts. Mrs. Weisshaus wrote the ombudsman, but her patience wore thin when she read news accounts that said it would take five years for the Swiss to identify all the abandoned assets.
"It made me angry that even now they claim they need five years to find these dormant accounts, as if 50 years wasn't enough," she said.

For a Survivor, Lawsuit Is a Mitzvah
Mrs. Weisshaus's lawsuit seeks disclosure of all assets deposited by Holocaust victims in Swiss banks. The suit also charges that a large portion of the German wealth deposited in Switzerland and used to finance the war effort was stolen from victims of the Holocaust, and seeks compensation for survivors and their families. Lawyers and some Jewish organizations say that with interest and inflation, the assets are probably now worth billions.
In addition to the ombudsman, a special committee set up by the Swiss Bankers Association and the World Jewish Congress, and headed by former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, will bring in auditors to search for unclaimed assets.
Swiss officials say that their country has tried to resolve the issue of dormant accounts before. In 1962, the Swiss Parliament set a 10-year period in which the country's banks were to trace the owners of dormant accounts that apparently belonged to Jewish victims of the Holocaust, said Mr. David Vogelsanger, the Swiss Embassy's political affairs and press officer. Ten million Swiss francs were found, most of which were turned over to the owners or their families, while $2.5 million in francs remained unclaimed, he said. Two-thirds of the remaining money was given to Jewish charities, and the remainder was turned over to the Swiss Refugee Aid Organization.
Last year, Mr. Vogelsanger said, the Swiss banks again searched for dormant accounts and found unclaimed money totaling $38 million in Swiss francs. Officials say, however, that it is unlikely that the money belonged only to Holocaust victims.
But Mrs. Weisshaus says she knows her family's money is there, and she will continue to seek it.
Not so long ago, she set out to find a grave of a great-uncle who had immigrated to America. She was the first member of the man's family to visit his grave in 87 years. Her visits there are a mitzvah, she explained -- a good deed. Just like the filing of a lawsuit on behalf of people who survived the war, in memory of those who did not.
"Why did they choose me?" she said of the Nazi guards who sent her to work while they sent her family to death. "I was the chosen one to keep up the family, and I am doing the right things. There were some people who said they didn't believe in God anymore. But I couldn't think that way. So finding my grand-uncle and filing this lawsuit I had to do. Because of their memory. And because I was chosen to do this."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up as German Officials Say Mark Should Come Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar snapped a four-day slide yesterday to end mostly higher after three officials of the German central bank, including its president, said the dollar's value against the mark was too weak.
Traders who had bet that the dollar could fall further were caught off guard by the bluntness of the message, especially the assertion by Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank's president, that "the dollar is on the way up again." 
 Traders moved quickly to repurchase dollars they had just sold, giving a further lift to the dollar in what is known in the market as a short-covering rally.
"The market was caught the wrong way," said Jim Powers, a vice president at Westdeutsche Landesbank in New York. "It happened pretty quick, too, and maybe more to come."
In late New York trading, the dollar cost 1.5075 marks, up from 1.4935. The pound cost $1.6460, down from $1.6464.
The dollar ended slightly lower against the yen at 111.34, down from 111.50 Monday but above its 110.85 low for the day reached in early Asian trading.
The dollar's turnaround against the mark began late Monday when Hans-Jurgen Krupp, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, suggested that a firmer dollar might be appropriate and that German interest rates might decline if the economy weakened. Lower rates would tend to devalue the mark.
Early yesterday, a Bundesbank council member, Edgar Meister, told reporters that a 1.5000-mark exchange rate for the dollar was not appropriate. Then a few hours later came Mr. Tietmeyer's remarks at a foreign banking conference in Frankfurt, and the dollar shot up.
"It appears the Bundesbank wants a positive tone for the dollar," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at MTB Bank in New York.
The dollar started out weaker in Asia in what traders said was a continuing reaction to a possible shift in Japan's foreign-exchange policy. Despite official reassurances that there has been no change in policy, the market remains skeptical.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 1.2690 Swiss francs, up from 1.2545; 1.3325 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3337; 5.0970 French francs, up from 5.0515; 1,518.50 Italian lire, up from 1,508.50.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Heir to the Throne at Lazard Freres May Not Be Anymore

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Is Edouard M. Stern still the heir to the throne at Lazard Freres? Not according to several current and former Lazard partners and employees at the international investment bank, some of whom contend that he may not even continue to work for the firm.
These people, who all declined to be identified by name, in recent days cited a furious dispute Mr. Stern was said to have in New York last week with Michel A. David-Weill, his father-in-law, senior partner and controlling owner of the three interlocking Lazard partnerships in New York, Paris and London. Mr. David-Weill, 63, is a descendant of the family that took over the investment banking firm when the families of the three Lazard brothers who founded the firm in 1837 ran out of male heirs. 
 Mr. Stern, 41, a partner, has taken an increasingly prominent role at Lazard, running the daily operations of its Paris office. In recent years, Lazard partners and the press have frequently identified Mr. Stern, the scion of a prominent financial family, as Mr. David-Weill's successor.
The family quarrel at Lazard, according to people at and close to the firm, arose from Mr. Stern's management of the Paris office and in particular his tense working relationship with Anne Lauvergeon, the only woman partner at the office.
Ms. Lauvergeon, 37, was a top economic adviser to Francois Mitterrand when he was president of France. Ms. Lauvergeon, who could not be reached for comment, is now preparing to leave the firm after her difficulties with Mr. Stern, according to colleagues at Lazard, and to recent reports in the French press. According to some people knowledgeable about the matter, Mr. Stern had particularly taken exception to an invitation that Ms. Lauvergeon received to join the board of Pechiney, the big French aluminum company. As the emerging head of Lazard's Paris office, Mr. Stern apparently felt that he should serve on the board, these people said.
Kate McDonough, a spokeswoman for Lazard in New York, said that neither the firm nor Mr. David-Weill nor Mr. Stern had any comment on the reported quarrel or on the Pechiney dispute.
Families, of course, are famous for their feuds, and the current quarrel may eventually turn out to be a passing one.
Mr. David-Weill, apparently seeking to smooth ruffled feathers, recently went out of his way to praise Ms. Lauvergeon and the contribution she had made to the firm in a passing reference during an interview with Le Monde. The partners of Lazard, he told the newspaper, were upset by recent press reports. He said the partners wanted to note that "Ms. Lauvergeon's professional and personal qualities, since her arrival at the house of Lazard, have made an appreciable and appreciated contribution to the firm."
Despite the family feuding, this is turning into a spectacular year for Lazard as healthy financial markets and an active merger and acquisition market have brought in fat profits. Lazard, for example, is currently advising MCI Communications on its proposed merger with British Telecommunications. In the Le Monde interview, Mr. David-Weill said it was too early to comment on the firm's international results, but added that this would be "a very good year for Lazard Freres Paris."

HEADLINE: Tone Is Edgy as Mideast Economic Conference Opens in Cairo

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 12

 BODY:
As political and business leaders gathered to celebrate commerce as a bridge across political divides, the subdued mood here spoke to what has changed in the Middle East since their last conclave a year ago.
Noticeably absent was Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, a crucial participant in two previous sessions but, after last spring's change in government, an object of deep Arab enmity. Foreign Minister David Levy was the highest-ranking Israeli official to attend. 
 Those who returned, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher, reported no new progress toward untangling a dispute about the status of the West Bank town of Hebron that last November had seemed settled.
More than 4,000 participants, including 1,500 foreign business leaders, made the gathering the largest of its kind ever held in the Middle East, and its host, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt praised those who attended for having "dared to look beyond the horizon." But even Mr. Mubarak added an edge to his public hopefulness, warning that it might be said "centuries from today, that our countries had peace within their grasp and squandered it."
The last regional economic conference, held in Amman, Jordan, in October 1995, opened less than a month after Israel and the Palestinians reached agreement on a second interim accord. It featured speeches by Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, King Hussein of Jordan, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who portrayed themselves as pillars of a broadening peace. But Mr. Rabin was assassinated a week later by an Israeli Jew opposed to those peace efforts, and the path toward a wider peace has been further obstructed by intransigence on all sides.
Suicide bombings by militant Muslims in Israel last February and March, Israel's offensive in Lebanon in April, and the elections in May that installed Mr. Netanyahu as Prime Minister all rekindled distrust between Israel and its neighbors. Since then, tensions have exploded -- most recently in violent clashes in the West Bank and Gaza this fall -- under the harder line adopted by Mr. Netanyahu's Government.
Until last spring, the main mission of the Cairo conference had been to help integrate Israel into the region's economy. But institutions established for that purpose, including a regional tourist board and a business council, have been dealt a setback since Mr. Netanyahu's election, with their governing bodies riven by renewed Israeli-Palestinian tensions. A Middle East Development Bank promoted by the United States in Casablanca and approved in Amman a year later has yet to win pledges of financial support even from the United States Congress; its doors will not open until at least the end of 1997.
And since the summer, Egyptian organizers switched the focus of this year's gathering to promoting investment in projects with little direct connection to the Israeli economy. At one point this fall, Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, threatened to cancel the gathering unless Israel reached agreement with the Palestinians over Hebron, the West Bank town where Israel has yet to make good on a year-old commitment to redeploy most of its troops. But Cairo relented, in part as a result of months of American pressure.
Mr. Christopher shuttled from meetings with Mr. Arafat, Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Levy, only to report through his spokesman, Nicholas Burns, that he had not made "any specific progress" in resolving the impasse over Hebron.

HEADLINE: Chronic Illness Has Vast Cost, A Study Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Nearly 100 million Americans have chronic diseases or disabilities, and caring for them accounts for three-fourths of the nation's health spending, researchers reported today.
Most people with chronic conditions live normal lives, but they have higher health costs than other people, and they are more likely to be absent from work, the researchers said in a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association. 
The authors said the nation was unprepared for the growing burden that chronic conditions would impose as the elderly population increased.
"Our health care system remains firmly rooted in episodic and acute care, but it is unlikely to continue this way in the next century," said the report, by Catherine Hoffman and colleagues at the Institute for Health and Aging at the University of California at San Francisco. The co-authors were Dorothy P. Rice, a former director of the National Center for Health Statistics, and Hai-Yen Sung, an economist.
Using data from Federal surveys, the researchers estimated that 100 million people had chronic conditions like heart disease, arthritis, cancer, diabetes, ulcers, AIDS, birth defects, schizophrenia and depression.
While 46 percent of Americans reported chronic conditions in 1987, they accounted for 76 percent of the direct medical care costs: $272 billion out of a total of $358 billion, not counting nursing home care.
The study said people who were chronically ill or disabled accounted for "disproportionately large shares of health care use": 96 percent of home care visits, 83 percent of prescription drug use, 80 percent of the days spent in hospitals, 66 percent of doctor visits and 55 percent of visits to hospital emergency rooms.
The authors concluded that "the total prevalence of chronic conditions has perhaps been minimized" or underestimated in the past.
"Chronic conditions affect all ages" they said, noting that 1 in 4 under age 18 has a chronic ailment.
"More than one-third of young adults age 18 to 44 and two-thirds of middle-age adults 45 to 64 had at least one chronic condition," the study said. "While the elderly were far more likely to have a chronic condition than other age groups, they actually accounted for only about a quarter of all people living in the community with chronic conditions. Working-age adults 18 to 64 years old accounted for 60 percent of all noninstitutionalized persons with chronic conditions."
The authors also tried to measure the indirect costs that result from premature deaths and lost productivity. They concluded that chronic conditions "impose a multibillion-dollar burden on the economy," exceeding $230 billion a year.
Who will care for the growing numbers with chronic illnesses is unclear. The demand for care-givers is increasing, Ms. Rice said.
The authors held out little hope that costs could be controlled by providing care to people in their own homes or in the community rather than in nursing homes and other institutions.
"Studies suggest that the provision of community-based services has generally raised health care costs because reductions in institutional care have been more than offset by the increased use of community-based care," they said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: Wrong Way on Welfare

 BODY:
The overhaul of welfare enacted in Washington this year poses a staggering challenge in New York State, where 1.4 million poor people count on the program to survive. It is thus dismaying that Gov. George Pataki has opted to implement the federally mandated welfare changes in a needlessly harsh spirit. The new law's work requirements and aid cutoffs will be difficult enough to manage under the best circumstances. According to reports leaking in Albany, Mr. Pataki will propose sharp cuts in welfare grants beyond what the Federal law requires in an apparent effort to balance the state budget on the backs of the poor and their children.
The Governor plans to unveil details of his welfare proposals today. We urge that he immediately rethink his proposal to reduce welfare payments to $317 by the year 2002, from the current $577. The cut is even bigger than it looks, because in real terms after inflation, it would amount to more than 45 percent. His proposals would slash the resources available to three quarters of a million of New York's children at a time when they already face a perilous future because of the other reductions in the recently enacted law. 
 There are sound elements in the plan. Mr. Pataki is right to incorporate a scheme under which families could keep a certain amount of money earned from work without losing their welfare grants and continue to receive Medicaid benefits for a year after going off welfare. But these worthy ideas do not need to be enacted in the context of his proposed welfare cuts.
Mr. Pataki is also preparing drastic changes in the state's Home Relief program for childless adults. Since this program is financed entirely by state and local tax dollars, there is no requirement to cut it under the new Federal law. But the Governor is clearly worried that poor people cut off from federally assisted welfare aid will take advantage of this longstanding New York program. He wants to scrap the whole idea of giving cash benefits to able-bodied recipients and replace them with vouchers for food, shelter and clothing. Mr. Pataki has not disclosed the value of these vouchers, but in the past he has favored sharp cutbacks in this area.
The Governor must realize that the cuts he is contemplating will be furiously opposed by the Democratic-controlled Assembly and by groups that provide services to the poor. By adopting an extremist approach he may be signaling a desire to use welfare as a political issue to bash Democrats instead of working with them to implement the changes required by the new Federal law. After a campaign year in which those favoring continuation of the safety net swept the voting in New York State, Mr. Pataki's proposals are puzzling and likely to be self-defeating.
Real welfare reform must be accompanied by incentives for people to get jobs, with subsidies for day care, job training and transportation to make it possible for people to work. Mr. Pataki seems ready to increase funding for some of these measures. That is where he and the Legislature need to concentrate their attention so that the arbitrary cutoffs do not punish people who have no other recourse to survive.
The Governor should not balance a looming state budget deficit of $3 billion, which was created because of his ill-advised tax cuts, by eviscerating a program that by itself counts for only about 6 percent of total state-financed expenditures. Done right, welfare reform could bring about some positive changes in social policy, but only if the main objective is to help rather than sacrifice the poor.

HEADLINE: Governors' Group Says States Are in Good Fiscal Condition

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
States are in robust financial condition as they prepare to take greater responsibility for welfare and other domestic programs, the National Governors' Association reported today.
Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association, said: "The fiscal condition of states is good. Surpluses are up. For the third consecutive year, states are generally reducing taxes and fees." 
 The favorable outlook reflects the strength of the national economy and several other factors.
The growth of Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for the poor, had been an immense burden for many states, but it slowed in the last 12 months because of greater use of managed care, a decline in medical inflation and a reduction in welfare rolls.
State officials said they had benefited from the control of health costs in another way, too. For the first time in a decade, the health insurance costs for their own employees are lower.
In the last year, many states reported a surge in tax collections, particularly in capital gains revenue, because of the continuing rise in stock prices, the association said. In the last three years, 23 states have increased cigarette and tobacco taxes, in some cases to generate additional money for health care.
In its "Fiscal Survey of States," a report that is issued twice a year, the governors' association said welfare benefits were likely to remain at the same level in 1997 as in 1996. Four states -- Hawaii, Utah, Vermont and West Virginia -- are reducing welfare payment levels, while Montana is increasing them and the other 45 states are keeping benefits at 1996 levels, the association said.
Mr. Scheppach said that state officials were apprehensive, despite the strong financial condition of most states. State finances will suffer if the economy turns sour or if Congress cuts aid to the states to balance the Federal budget, he said.
Contrasting today's mood with that of the 1980's, Mr. Scheppach said: "In the 80's we saw lots of new state programs, new initiatives and the expansion of existing programs. I don't think we're going to see that next year. The emphasis is on efficiency and austerity."
State legislative actions will reduce state revenue by $4.2 billion, or 1 percent, in the coming fiscal year, the governors reported. New York State, with $2.2 billion in tax cuts, accounts for slightly more than half of the total. In New York and other states, most of the reductions were in personal income taxes. Connecticut, Massachusetts and Ohio were among the 16 states cutting personal income taxes.
After years of trying to control Medicaid costs, state officials said they were pleasantly surprised with their success last year.
Medicaid grew an average of 17 percent a year from 1990 to 1995, and the Congressional Budget Office had been predicting growth of 10 percent a year from 1996 through 2002. But in the 1996 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, Federal Medicaid spending grew just 3 percent.
Mr. Scheppach said that Medicaid growth "will probably go back to the range of 7 percent a year." Medicaid accounts for about 20 percent of all state spending. The Federal Government supplies slightly more than half of the Medicaid money.
The governors' association said that states were accumulating surpluses to help them get through any decline in the economy. At the end of the 1996 fiscal year, states had balances totaling $21.2 billion, or 5.7 percent of spending in that year -- the highest level since 1980. Twelve states had balances exceeding 10 percent of their outlays.
State spending rose 4.5 percent in the 1996 fiscal year and is expected to increase 4 percent in 1997, the report said. By contrast, in the last 15 years, state spending rose an average of 6.8 percent a year.
With no foreseeable increase in Federal aid and with little public support for tax increases, Mr. Scheppach said, state officials have been forced to redesign state government operations to perform more work with the same amount of money.
States have eliminated some agencies, merged others and hired private companies to perform tasks historically done by government. At least 10 states now allow such companies to bid against state agencies for the opportunity to run prisons, hospitals and mental health centers.

HEADLINE: CLINTON SUGGESTS HE MAY NOT RESIST FISCAL AMENDMENT

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Bowing to political reality, President Clinton today softened his opposition to a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, even as he received a polite but noncommittal response from Congressional Republicans to a range of issues on his agenda for the coming year.
"I don't believe that we need it, but if we have it, it ought to be able to be implemented in a way that actually works and gives the country what it needs to manage a recession," Mr. Clinton said of the budget amendment, which seems likely to pass Congress. 
 The President made his comments at a morning White House ceremony where he signed a parks appropriations bill. Later, after a 90-minute meeting in the Oval Office this afternoon, the leader of the Senate's majority Republicans, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said Mr. Clinton "seems to be coming around to the idea that something will happen" on a balanced-budget amendment.
The measure lost by one vote in the Senate last year after Mr. Clinton had lobbied against it. But Republicans gained two Senate seats in the elections last week and now appear to have the votes to pass it and send it to the states for ratification.
If Mr. Clinton's comment was meant to be an olive branch to the returning leaders of the new Congress, it appeared to do him little immediate good. While sounding conciliatory notes, Mr. Lott and Speaker Newt Gingrich made clear that they were in no hurry to act on the President's pending proposals for balancing the budget, overhauling campaign finance laws and establishing a commission to address the long-term solvency of Medicare.
Mr. Clinton has proposed using a bill sponsored by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, as a starting point for new limits on political fund raising. But Mr. Gingrich said that before taking up any such challenge, Republicans would hold hearings to seek answers about recent questionable fund-raising practices, an issue that dogged the Democrats in the final weeks of this year's campaign.
"We need to lay out clearly what are the contours of campaign spending," Mr. Gingrich said as he emerged from the White House meeting. "There was an amazing amount of money this year spent outside the campaigns."
As for Medicare, the chief White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Clinton wanted to include in the budget that he will submit in January a proposal for establishing a bipartisan commission to address questions about the program's long-term stability.
But Mr. McCurry acknowledged that the Republicans, still angry at Mr. Clinton's successful efforts to portray them as too willing to cut Medicare, had shown little immediate enthusiasm for such an idea, instead insisting that Mr. Clinton come forward with his own suggestions.
"The President," Mr. Lott said, "will need to make it clear that we have important and tough decisions we need to make in that area. When he lays out the problem and suggests a solution, we're certainly going to be prepared to work with him."
Finally, Mr. McCurry suggested that the President hoped to lay some groundwork on the outlines of a balanced budget by returning to the points of agreement that Congress and the White House reached before negotiations broke down last winter. He said Mr. Clinton thought this was possible even before Congress reconvenes in January, but acknowledged that the Republicans were cool to that idea, too.
At the same time, the meeting's participants universally praised the tone as constructive, repeated the reigning mantra that the voters preferred cooperation to conflict between the parties and suggested that the White House and Congress might in fact make some progress on the issues that divide them -- before the 1998 midterm election campaigns get under way.
"We all agreed that we have now at least a year where we can turn our attention away from politics and to policy," said the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas.
In his daily briefing for reporters this afternoon, Mr. McCurry went round and round in an effort to explain what Mr. Clinton had meant by his comments on the budget amendment, and whether they really amounted to any change, before finally chuckling and saying, "You won't pin me down on this; you can keep trying."
But Mr. McCurry said of the Republican-led Congress: "It looks like they're going to do it. So the question is how they do it."
The President has no formal role in the constitutional-amendment process; he cannot veto an amendment passed by Congress. But he can exercise his bully pulpit, and did so last year to ultimately defeat the budget measure. Since then, however, he has embraced the notion of balancing the budget by 2002, and accepted the reality that the Republicans can almost certainly pass an amendment.
This morning Mr. Clinton sketched out what kind of amendment he might find most acceptable.
"If it sets a framework and says that in the 21st century in the economy we're going to be living in, other things being equal, we ought always to be balancing our books, I agree with that," he said. But he said it should not be permitted to hem in Congress in periods of economic downturn.
In a recession, Mr. Clinton said, "you would never raise taxes, and you wouldn't throw people who are unemployed through no fault of their own off of health care eligibility because you were trying to balance the budget."
The amendment that failed last year had provisions allowing Congress to override it and run a deficit automatically in time of war, and by a three-fifths vote in other circumstances like a recession. Aides said Mr. Clinton might favor an escape clause like one allowing the requirement for budget balancing to be overridden by a simple majority vote of each house.

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Urged to Seek Waiving of Work Rule to Obtain Food Stamps

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 12

 BODY:
As state officials put the finishing touches on a sweeping overhaul of New York's welfare system today, advocates for the poor called on Gov. George E. Pataki to seek an exemption from new Federal rules requiring thousands of adults to work in exchange for food stamps.
Under the new Federal welfare law, able-bodied childless adults under age 50 are required to work 20 hours a week in either a private or a community service job to receive food stamps. People who do not meet the requirement will be allowed food stamps for only three months over a three-year period. Previously, there had been no time limits and less stringent work requirements for food stamps. 
 But the new Federal law also allows states to apply for waivers from the new work requirements for people who live in regions where the unemployment rate is above 10 percent or where the state can show that there are not enough jobs for people currently on welfare.
Aides to Mr. Pataki hinted tonight that the Governor would not seek the waiver when he releases a sweeping plan on Wednesday to revamp the state's $4 billion welfare system. The bill will call for gradually cutting benefits for families, ending cash benefits for able-bodied childless adults, and imposing a policy known as family cap, where families that have additional children while on welfare do not receive increases in their benefits.
Advocates for the poor have implored Mr. Pataki to apply for the food stamp waiver throughout the state, contending there are not enough low-skilled jobs for welfare recipients. They estimate that 100,000 able-bodied adults receive food stamps now and that many of those people will lose their benefits in the next three months unless Mr. Pataki applies for the waiver.
They further contend that poor communities will be hurt economically if the Governor does not seek the waiver because thousands of small grocery stores depend heavily on food stamp business. The advocates said that seeking the waiver would not cost the state any additional money because food stamps are paid for entirely by the Federal Government.
Liz Krueger, associate director of the Community Food Resources Center, estimated that the state could lose as much as $250 million in Federal food stamp money in the next three years if it did not apply for the waiver. "Why would New York choose to turn down Federal money that we know we need for low-income people we know we have?" she said.
But the Federal law has clearly placed the Pataki administration in an awkward position. Currently, there is no county in the state with unemployment over 10 percent. So to receive the waiver, the administration would have to show that there are pockets of the state where the labor market is too weak to absorb all those on welfare.
But that argument would clash sharply with Mr. Pataki's contention that the state's economy is improving steadily and that there are jobs available to most people who want them. Indeed, it is a cornerstone notion of the Governor's welfare plan that with the right incentives and punishments, most of the approximately 500,000 adults on welfare will be able to find work.
For that reason, Pataki aides suggested today that it was unlikely that Mr. Pataki would apply for the waiver now. "There is no way the Governor is going to go out and say there are not enough jobs, because there are," said one aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
