HEADLINE: U.S. Examines Ex-Trade Official's Conduct

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The inspector general at the Commerce Department has begun a review into a series of contacts between John Huang, a former trade official, and the large Indonesian financial group for whom he had once worked, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Huang was a trade official at the Commerce Department from the summer of 1994 until the end of last year, when he became a senior fund-raiser at the Democratic National Committee. He was suspended from that post last month after reports that he had solicited several large questionable contributions. 
 In a statement today, the Commerce Department said that Government documents "appear to present questions concerning the conduct" of Mr. Huang when he was a deputy assistant secretary for international economic policy.
"All documents which may be relevant have been turned over" to the inspector general's office, it said.
The statement did not elaborate. But officials who insisted on not being identified said the documents included toll records of a pattern of telephone calls that were made from Mr. Huang's office at the Commerce Department to executives of the Lippo Group. Before arriving in Washington, Mr. Huang was a senior American executive of the company.
The Lippo Group is controlled by the Riadys, a prominent Indonesian family with longstanding ties to President Clinton. Associates of the Riadys, including Mr. Huang, have raised millions of dollars for the Democratic Party.
But the toll records under review do not indicate the content of the telephone calls and the inspector general will try to determine whether they were proper or involved confidential information or any work Mr. Huang may have done on behalf of his former employer.
The records are not the same ones as the papers made available to news organizations under various Freedom of Information Act requests. Those papers show that, contrary to the Administration's initial portrayal of Mr. Huang, he was involved in meetings at which Indonesian trade issues were discussed. They also show that Mr. Huang had access to classified information about a variety of issues that the Lippo Group might have an interest.
In a deposition taken in a civil lawsuit last month, Mr. Huang said he avoided any contact with executives of the Lippo Group when he was at the Commerce Department. Mr. Huang has declined repeated requests for interviews, and today one of his lawyers, Ty Cobb, declined to comment about the inspector general's review.
The Justice Department is considering a request to seek the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate Mr. Huang, and nearly a dozen Congressional committees have begun inquiries into Mr. Huang's work at the Democratic Party and at the Commerce Department. Since it would be illegal to solicit money from foreign citizens, investigators are also examining a fund-raising trip that Mr. Huang took earlier this year to Taiwan.
Justice officials said today that they had denied a request for the appointment of an independent counsel on campaign contributions, although another is being considered.
The decision, made as President Clinton weighed whether Attorney General Janet Reno would stay on, was the second time in less than a week that the Justice Department had decided against the appointment of an outside prosecutor to investigate Mr. Clinton's campaign fund raising.
Justice Department officials said in the letter today that an Oct. 11 request for an independent counsel by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, did not pose specific allegations of criminal wrongdoing, the same grounds cited to deny a complaint by the group Common Cause last week.
Today's decision did not mean that the Justice Department had stopped the issue of overseas fund raising from going to an independent prosecutor. Ms. Reno is still facing complaints raised in a second letter sent on Oct. 28 by Mr. McCain and five other Republican lawmakers. The second complaint details many more specific charges, among them the propriety of fund-raising activities by Mr. Huang.
In recent weeks, the Democratic National Committee has returned donations of $250,000 from a South Korean company and $325,000 from a man who later claimed to have no assets. Both donations were solicited by Mr. Huang, who party officials say had raised about $2.5 million in his tenure at the committee.
At a news conference today, the national chairman of the Democratic National Committee said he had made the decision to hire Mr. Huang.
The chairman, Donald L. Fowler, said he had accepted responsibility for what he called "mistakes in the process of fund raising" and said that he had implemented a system for reviewing all donations of more than $10,000.
"We at the Democratic National Committee have made mistakes, and we have set out to correct them," Mr. Fowler said at a stormy news conference. "While we have made mistakes, they have been mistakes of process and not of intent. They are, nonetheless, serious, and we know this. We have taken and are continuing to take appropriate steps to correct them. Never has there been any desire, plan or intent to evade requirements of applicable laws and regulations."
Other associates of Mr. Huang have raised money for the Democrats. Arief Wiriandinata, an Indonesian who lived briefly in Virginia and whose father-in-law was a senior executive who worked for the Riadys, gave the party an additional $450,000. Mr. Fowler said that after reviewing that contribution, the committee had decided to keep the money because the donation was lawful.
Asked why Mr. Wiriandinata, who cannot vote because he is an Indonesian citizen, would want to give so much money to the Democrats, Mr. Fowler said that it was because "the President had expressed concern about one of his relatives who was ill."
The relative was Hasjim Ning, Mr. Wiriandinata's father-in-law. White House officials have said when Mr. Ning was ill, he was sent a 21-word note in June 1995 that bore the President's signature but was actually signed by a machine used to send letters from the White House. Mr. Ning died last year.
At a news conference last Friday, President Clinton pointedly suggested that any problems in fund raising were the fault of the Democratic National Committee, and other officials said the fund-raising issue may have ultimately cost the President enough votes to deprive him of a victory by a majority of those who voted. Today Mr. Fowler accepted blame, although he insisted he was not being made a skapegoat.

HEADLINE: Trying to Construct A Mirror of Manhattan;
Coliseum Proposals Attempt To Reflect City's Direction

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
And now for Round 2 of the Battle of the New York Coliseum.
City and state officials must settle two questions. The first is old and nettlesome: What should a new building in one of the city's most famed public spaces look like? The second may be more of a surprise: What's an appropriate use? 
How about a multiplex movie house, a high-technology amusement park or a health spa? Perhaps a condominium hotel, the headquarters of a large media company or a studio for television production would make more sense.
Should it be a new home for the Museum of American Folk Art, the North American headquarters for the Sotheby's auction house or a beachhead for a department store chain that somehow survived as an icon of American business without setting foot in Manhattan?
"Our problem has been finding the right site, and we think this would be the sweet spot of the island for Sears," said Arthur C. Martinez, chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company.
His company's plan, for a Sears department store rising four floors over Columbus Circle that would be larger than its stores in all but handful of suburban malls, is contained in one of nine proposals submitted under a Nov. 1 deadline to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, owner of the Coliseum building.
Coming from some of the nation's largest real estate companies, the proposals have radically changed the nature of New York City's most contentious development debate. No longer an issue of the project's size, it has become one of character.
At stake is a site of unfulfilled grandeur at the southwest corner of Central Park that has attracted a series of ill-fated development schemes since William Randolph Hearst wanted to make it the center of New York City commerce in 1904. Hearst proposed a 40-story office building and a 555-foot-high clock tower, but the site has evolved since World War II into a congested traffic circle surrounded by some of the city's most abrasive architecture.
The assortment of new plans offers an opportunity for New Yorkers, both bureaucrats and ordinary residents, to think through the consequences of their architectural choices.
"It could prove a very good thing that market forces are forcing us all to address the issues of where we have come as a city," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society. "Now, if we could only step back and think intelligently about what we want one of the most important corners of Manhattan to become."
During the 1980's, when the current push for a new development began, it seemed all but assured that any new structure on the Coliseum site would be for corporate offices or high-priced apartments, and the only questions revolved around height, bulk and architecture. Now, the possibilities for the unused exhibition space erected in 1956 seem endless.
Will it resemble Madison Avenue or Herald Square? Will its place in the city economy be as a corporate center, tourist attraction, neighborhood shopping center or mecca for high-technology entertainment? And what criteria will be used to decide?
"If this is a problem, it's the kind I'd like more of," said Charles Millard, president the city's Economic Development Corporation and a senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is known to have veto power when the transportation agency makes its choice.
The array of proposals, Mr. Millard said, "are simply a reminder that New York's economic health does not come from just one place, and that the private sector often thinks more creatively than the government."
But outside planners and some neighborhood groups are less than sanguine about the latest batch of ideas.
Mr. Sexton said the risk was that officials of the transportation authority, which must forge a consensus among city and state officials, would give short shrift to the diversity of ideas, squandering the opportunity to piece together the best of them. What is needed, he said, is extensive public scrutiny and comment, even if that means pushing back the timetable of the development plan.
The transportation authority anticipates culling the nine proposals to a smaller group of finalists by February and making its selection in the spring. The agency seems unlikely to alter its timetable and seek extensive public comment, having already received approval to proceed with a project as long as it conforms to certain height and design requirements.
The agency is under pressure to move quickly as well because of losses sustained in both money and prestige during the failed development effort of the last decade.
That plan was abandoned in 1993 when Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the developer and publisher of The Daily News, walked away from his scaled-down plan for two office and condominium towers -- victims of the city's real estate recession. An earlier, far larger version of his plan had already been thrown out amid a torrent of lawsuits.
Now, although limits on the size of a Coliseum site development appear to have been resolved, the transportation authority must decide how to weigh various criteria, including how much the developers are willing to pay for the site, financial viability and economic impact. But the agency declined to say what would figure most heavily.
The transportation authority may encounter difficulty in forging agreement between city and state officials on the best development plan. The current round of proposals was delayed for months while advisers to Mayor Giuliani and Governor George E. Pataki were at a standoff over a city proposal, ultimately dropped, to dedicate a large part of any new development to exhibition space. City officials had argued that there was a shortage of space for Manhattan conventions.
"Things must have seemed much easier when they just wanted the best price for the site," said Bruce Ratner, a large developer in downtown Brooklyn and Times Square, who is heading the development team that has proposed the Sears store in a complex that would also include two apartment towers. "This time around, the process is better, but it is not going to be easier."
Like the other developers, Mr. Ratner declined to say how much he and his partners had offered for the Coliseum site.
Most of the developers have begun the competition trying to win the imagination of government authorities and the public. Some, stretching the imagination, have elicited the disdain of competitors.
"Big-box retailers belong in the suburbs, not on Columbus Circle," said Edward Minskoff, a Manhattan developer whose proposal resembles, as much as any other, the variety of uses contemplated for the site in the 1980's.
Working with the Lefrak Organization, another large New York City real estate concern, he would build two towers, one for a hotel and condominiums and the other for offices.
At the base of Mr. Minskoff's complex would be space for a new headquarters of Sotheby's, which is known to have been in discussions with several of the development teams that are bidding for the Coliseum site. The Minskoff complex would also include what he called "town house style retail space that would resemble Madison Avenue."
But others maintained that neither Madison Avenue nor New York City tradition was the right model.
"This should be the symbol of the next century for New York," said Stephen Ross, chairman of the Related Companies, who has proposed two towers that would include a television and movie studio, a hotel, a cineplex movie house and a restaurant enclosed in a huge globe across from the entrance to Central Park.
Mr. Ross said his combination of proposed uses closely reflected the broad shift in the city economy in the last five years in which the growth in entertainment and tourism has outpaced that of banking, insurance and other industries.
The most offbeat of the proposals was submitted by a group that includes David Plattner, a Manhattan executive with little experience in real estate development. He has nonetheless been joined by two development companies with broad United States holdings, Gerald Hines Interests and the Simon Property Group, in what he calls a "futuristic amazement place."
Mr. Plattner's idea is to renovate the entire Coliseum building and existing office tower above it for a shopping center, science museum and entertainment complex complete with a doomed rooftop swimming pool that would produce body surfing waves.
Whatever proposal is selected "is bound to make some people angry," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at New York University. "This is a site where a new public library would provoke protests because all its books were not politically correct."
But because of the wide variety of ideas from which the city and state must now choose, the new round in the Coliseum debate "reflects the ongoing magic of New York," he said.
"What these proposals reflect is the re-emergence of Manhattan as a place where people want to visit, shop, be entertained and have fun," he said.

HEADLINE: Bishops Affirm Economic Principles That Raised a Storm in the 80's

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Ten years after the nation's Roman Catholic bishops issued a lengthy pastoral letter challenging Reagan-era enthusiasm for an unrestrained market economy, they have reasserted their moral convictions about economic life, but now boiled down to a few hundred words.
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops, which has been meeting here since Monday, approved a 10-point "Catholic Framework for Economic Life" today. The statement declares that economic life must be subject to moral principles and that people have a right to basic necessities like food, shelter, education, health care and a safe environment. 
 The 280 or so bishops here, who approved the brief statement in a voice vote without dissent, see it as a tool to reassert the themes of "Economic Justice for All," a document that stirred heated debate when its first draft was made public in November 1984 just after President Ronald Reagan's sweeping re-election victory.
Focusing on unemployment and poverty, and reaffirming a role for government in guiding the economy, that letter offered a temporary life raft for many liberals who felt swamped by the swelling tide of pro-market and anti-government sentiment. A group of prominent Catholic lay people, mostly Republicans and supported by the financier William Simon, tried to counter the pastoral letter with their own document.
The earlier letter appeared as a 200-page paperback after its final draft was approved in 1986. In contrast, the anniversary statement issued today is only 636 words long. The bishops' conference plans to distribute it, in English and Spanish, on posters and 3-by-8-inch cards starting in January.
The statement affirms, "All people have a right to economic initiative, to productive work, to just wages and benefits, to decent working conditions as well as to organize and join unions or other associations."
In keeping with Catholic tradition, the brief statement then outlines a corresponding set of duties: to work, to provide for one's family and to contribute to the broader society.
"Free markets have both clear advantages and limits," the statement says, adding that government and voluntary groups, too, have distinct and irreplaceable roles.
Without addressing more specifically the relationships among these sectors, the statement appears to be simply warning against an overemphasis on any one of them.
"A lot has changed in the decade since our pastoral," Bishop William S. Skylstad of Spokane, Wash., said in introducing the statement for discussion on Monday, but "we are still haunted by how the 'least among us' are faring."
"We live in an economy of paradoxes," said Bishop Skylstad, chairman of the bishops' Committee on Domestic Policy. "Profits, productivity and the stock market grow, while many workers' incomes and sense of security decline."
Today the Bishop anticipated criticism. "Some ask," he said, " 'Why can't you just stick to what they call religious issues?' We need to be very clear. Our defense of the poor, our pursuit of economic justice, is fundamentally a work of faith."
The earlier letter was criticized as beyond the competence of bishops, and the notion of a right to food, shelter, health care and other necessities remains controversial today. Still, the bishops, although they have grown more conservative and shy of controversy during the last decade, did not seem at all hesitant about reiterating the claim.
The bishops' meeting opened on an emotional note on Monday morning when Bishop Anthony M. Pilla of Cleveland, the conference's president, read a letter from the absent Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, who is dying of cancer, asking for the bishops' prayers.
The entire assembly appeared frozen, the bishops soundless and motionless, while Bishop Pilla read the letter and his own response. For 30 years Cardinal Bernardin has led the bishops "through the most difficult of moments," Bishop Pilla said. "I know of no other bishop who has given so much for so long so willingly and lovingly."
Then, with many bishops dabbing at their eyes, the assembly broke into a prolonged standing ovation.
Much of the bishops' meeting has been devoted to internal church matters like the adaptation of funeral ceremonies in instances of cremation -- a practice that the church now permits while continuing to discourage -- and a new plan for improving ministry to young adults.
But the unfolding tragedy of dying refugees in central Africa imposed itself on the gathering when Auxiliary Bishop John Ricard of Baltimore, chairman of Catholic Relief Services, the American church's agency for overseas aid, gave its annual report.
"Tens of thousands are dying," Bishop Ricard said, urging the bishops to back their leaders' demands for American and international initiatives to allow the movement of refugees and relief workers in Zaire.
The bishops stood in support of that request, and of his further plea for the conference to continue pressing the Clinton Administration to increase foreign aid rather than cut it.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yield Lowest In 8 Months On Long Bond

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday to its lowest level in eight months as sentiment grew that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting and perhaps not in the coming months.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 26/32, to 100 26/32 for a yield of 6.44 percent, down from 6.50 percent on Friday. The yield was the lowest since it fell to 6.38 percent on March 5. The bond market was shut Monday for the Veterans Day holiday. 
 A mixed report on auto sales led to some modest profit taking early in the session, but bargain hunters seeking cheaper securities turned the momentum and limited the fall.
The market is awaiting this morning's release of the Producer Price Index for October and the results of the Federal Reserve meeting in the afternoon.
The market was helped by a stronger dollar and by overseas investors. Dave Shabelman, a market analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, said President Clinton's meeting with Congressional leaders yesterday afternoon in which they discussed a balanced budget gained the attention of the market.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, a New York market research and analysis firm, said he hoped that the Government would cut the budget deficit to make government securities more attractive to foreign investors.
Mr. Palash said some positive comments by German officials talking up the dollar added to the positive tone of the market.
"All in all," Mr. Palash said, "the market is calm ahead of the F.O.M.C. meeting and inflation data tomorrow, with most everyone expecting the central bank to keep monetary policy steady and with most expecting the inflation number to be benign."
The consensus is for the Producer Price Index to rise three-tenths of a percent, but with core rate at a more modest one-tenth of a percent gain. "My own estimate," Mr. Palash said, "is lower, unchanged over all, with the core down one-tenth of 1 percent. There is some sentiment out there that the next Fed move will be an easing. I am not inclined to go along with that because some wage pressures, from the tight labor market, are already noticeable. Also I believe the economy's pace will pick up by itself early next year."
Yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills was not as strong as some had expected, but still acceptable.
The average discount rate at auction for the three-month bill was 5.02 percent, down from 5.04 percent last week, with the bid-to-cover ratio of bids compared with the total amount being auctioned this week at 3.33 to 1. Traders had expected the ratio to be 4.3 to 1. For the longer-maturity six-month bill, the average rate at auction was 5.07 percent, down from 5.08 percent a week ago. The bid-to-cover ratio was better at 3.83 to 1, compared with the expected ratio of 4 to 1.

HEADLINE: Dow Struggles to Reach Yet Another High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrials struggled to a record high for the fifth consecutive session yesterday, even as investors booked profits in some highflying sectors like technology and sent many broad indexes lower.
The Dow closed up 10.44 points, to 6,266.04, topping its previous high every trading day since last Wednesday. The Dow slipped 16 points in early trading, recovered to show a gain of more than 20 points, then slipped back a second time before rallying into the close. 
 The Dow average is up 256 points, or more than 4 percent, in the four weeks since closing above 6,000 for the first time on Oct. 14.
"It's had a huge run," said Peter Anderson, chief investment officer at IDS Advisory Group in Minneapolis. Investors are "simply cautious given what's happened in the last several sessions," he said.
Big Board volume was robust at 472.9 million shares, up from Monday's quiet Veterans Day pace of 354 million.
But advancing issues led decliners by a weak 13-to-11 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, and, more concerning to some, the broad market showed signs of fatigue.
"The Dow is outperforming the Standard & Poor's," said John Church, chief investment officer at Glenmede Trust Company in Philadelphia. "Typically that happens at the end of a bull market, so there are some signs of concern."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.31 points, to 729.56; the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.65 point, to 386.18, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.14 points, to 1,256.53. All three set records on Monday.
Stocks trimmed their midday gains even as bonds built on theirs. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 26/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, to an eight-month low of 6.44 percent.
Semiconductor stocks rose in the morning after the leading industry group said orders for computer chips jumped nearly 18 percent in October, lifting the book-to-bill ratio to 1.10 from a revised 0.98 in September. The preliminary figure means manufacturers got $110 in new orders for every $100 worth of semiconductors they shipped. The ratio has been below 1.0 -- the dividing point between market growth and contraction -- since January.
But computer chip stocks finished mixed after a bout of afternoon profit taking, and amid talk that demand for personal computers was waning. On the Big Board, Motorola shares rose 2, to 52, but Texas Instruments fell 7/8, to 55 1/8, and LSI Logic slipped 7/8, to 31 1/4. I.B.M. fell 1 1/4, to 133 1/4.
Investors also took profits ahead of a raft of economic data due out later this week, including a report today on producer prices. Later in the week, the Government will report on consumer prices, retail sales and industrial production.
Westinghouse Electric shares gained 5/8, to 20 5/8, on expectations that the company would soon spin off its industrial operations, with revenue of $5 billion a year, creating a company distinct from its fast-growing broadcast empire.
AT&T advanced 1 1/4, to 38 3/8, after the Supreme Court refused to set aside a Federal appeals court order that temporarily put on hold new rules intended to increase competition in telephone markets.
Anchor Gaming tumbled 8 7/8, to 30 1/8. The company announced that it was reconsidering plans to expand a Colorado casino, raising questions about Anchor's growth strategy.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Spur Beijing on Trade Group Entry

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to tell Chinese leaders, in high-level meetings starting in 10 days, that it is ready to speed up talks on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, although it will not drop demands for a series of market openings that China has so far resisted, Administration officials said today.
President Clinton plans to raise China's entry into the trade organization -- which has become an increasingly contentious issue between the two countries -- when he meets the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, in the Philippines two weeks from now. Secretary of State Warren Christopher will pave the way with a visit to Beijing next week, only the second in his four-year tenure. 
 "We are looking for ways to get the relationship unstuck and this may be a very concrete sign that we can work together," a senior official said earlier this week. But he noted that China had yet to indicate whether it was ready to agree to a a broad set of market openings for foreign companies that President Clinton will insist upon. "We won't sign a bad deal, and so far we're not sure that the Chinese are ready to move," the official said.
Just how much flexibility to show in negotiating with China appears to once again be a subject of division within the Administration.
Many State Department officials view China's entry into the World Trade Organization as a diplomatically useful symbol and a concrete example of how the two powers can work together on economic disputes, despite continuing differences over arms proliferation and human rights. The trade organization is the arbiter of global rules, and membership insures reduced tariffs for products traded around the world and provides that disputes are handled by panels of international judges.
The State Department officials hope to reach an agreement next year, when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang are expected to make state visits to each other's capital.
However, the United States trade representative's office tends to take a far more hawkish view, insisting that China take radical steps to open its economy on what it calls "commercially acceptable terms," and that its concessions must be "commercially meaningful."
"It's fair to say that the tone of the discussions has improved," said Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, and one of several Cabinet members who attended a meeting at the White House late last week to set the agenda for Mr. Christopher's trip and the subsequent meeting between President Clinton and President Jiang. "But the key to accession for China will be the substantive obligations they are willing to undertake."
One of the big mysteries Administration officials hope to resolve in the coming meetings is whether Mr. Jiang has the willingness and the mandate to strike a deal that could result in a far-reaching opening of China's market.
"It's hard to predict," said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, who has been pressing for China's inclusion. "Some Chinese leaders may conclude that they have plenty of investment pouring into the country already, and the pain of opening up state-run industries to competition is simply too much."
For Mr. Clinton, it may also be a politically delicate maneuver. Two weeks ago, China sentenced a prominent dissident, Wang Dan, to a lengthy prison term. Even for an American Administration that has formally separated trade benefits and human rights, an official acknowledged recently, "it's painful to reward that kind of behavior with talk of letting China into the ultimate club of trading nations."
Moreover, there could be trouble in Congress. Already there are rumblings from some Democrats and Republicans that any United States decision to agree to Chinese entry should be subject to Congressional approval. Currently, the Administration is free to make such decisions without the involvement of Congress.
Lurking over the whole business is China's growing trade surplus with the United States. The surplus is expected to exceed $35 billion this year, and in some ways it is more worrisome than the larger, but declining, deficit with Japan. Experts believe that a large part of the imbalance with China is a result of its huge barriers to foreign products and some types of foreign investment; in Japan's case, trade barriers are viewed as only one of several causes of the deficit.
The European Union's top economic official, Sir Leon Brittan, is visiting China this week. Over the weekend he said the Europeans favored China's membership in the trade organization, though he did not say under what conditions.

HEADLINE: CSX Puts Off Making a Higher Offer to Acquire Conrail

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Despite intense pressure to match a $10 billion all-cash bid from the rival Norfolk Southern Corporation, the CSX Corporation has decided for now not to raise its offer for Conrail.
CSX concluded that it made no sense to fuel the bidding war with Norfolk Southern by sweetening the stock portion of its offer before it could reinforce its position by acquiring 19.9 percent of Conrail's shares later this month, according to two people familiar with the negotiations between Conrail and CSX. 
 Directors from both Conrail and CSX, who had announced a merger agreement on Oct. 15, had been meeting Monday night and again on Tuesday to work out a response to Norfolk Southern's bid of $110 a share. CSX's latest offer is for cash and stock valued at $93.69 a share, based on yesterday's closing stock price.
Conrail, which is based in Philadelphia, urged its partner to increase its bid and CSX submitted a new, tentative offer to the Conrail board, the two people familiar with the negotiations said. But the two sides were unable to agree on economic issues, as well as the timing of the new offer and related governance issues. CSX decided it did not have to respond so quickly.
"We're still trying to come up with something that both sides can support enthusiastically," one person close to the negotiations said.
After rising to almost $98 on expectations that CSX would raise its offer, Conrail closed at $96.875 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, up 34.375 cents.
Conrail is expected to reaffirm its commitment to its strategic merger with CSX today and to recommend that Conrail shareholders reject the latest, more lucrative offer from Norfolk Southern.
Both Conrail and CSX declined to comment last night.
CSX had cloaked its merger agreement with Conrail in protective armor: a $300 million break-up fee and more than $100 million in stock options granted to CSX by Conrail. More important, Conrail operates under anti-takeover statutes in Pennsylvania that permit companies to ignore richer, hostile offers.
Many Conrail shareholders, however, have found Norfolk Southern's offer enticing, a sentiment many have conveyed to Conrail's directors.
For its part, Norfolk Southern called on Wall Street and Conrail shareholders to support its offer for Conrail.
"Let them know that you are troubled that the CSX-Conrail plan could be pushed through, depriving Conrail shareholders of the best offer," David R. Goodes, Norfolk Southern's chairman, told investors and analysts yesterday at a conference sponsored by Salomon Brothers.
Norfolk Southern is scheduled to go into Federal District Court in Philadelphia on Monday to seek a preliminary injunction blocking the Conrail-CSX merger.
But at least for now, CSX is proceeding with its plans. Under its merger agreement, CSX is offering $110 a share for 40 percent of Conrail's outstanding shares. CSX currently is attempting to acquire 19.9 percent of Conrail's stock by Nov. 20, the date its tender offer expires. If it is successful, CSX could then vote at a December meeting of Conrail shareholders in favor of an exemption allowing the railroad to acquire the remaining shares. But CSX is offering to swap its stock for the final 60 percent of Conrail shares in a deal that currently values the shares at only $82.83 a share.
In recent days, according to people familiar with the negotiations, CSX resisted Conrail's advice to increase the back end of the offer immediately, wanting to wait until it acquired 19.9 percent of Conrail, rather than give Norfolk Southern another opportunity to raise its bid.

HEADLINE: Rome Talks To Examine Aid to Hungry

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 12

 BODY:
At a moment when relief agencies are scrambling to get food to an estimated 1 million people trapped in refugee camps in eastern Zaire, the World Food Summit -- which opens here on Wednesday -- does not have to search far for an example of how hunger still plagues a planet that is producing more food than ever.
At a news conference this morning, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said United Nations agencies have the food aid they need to feed the Rwandan refugees in Zaire who have been stranded by recent fighting. The problem, he said, is in getting them to the hungry. 
 In many ways, Africa's latest food emergency is a snapshot of the challenge raised by this week's summit meeting at the headquarters of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization here in Rome.
"The problem is not production," said Dr. Kay Killingsworth, secretary general of the summit meeting, in a recent interview. "Agricultural production has basically kept pace with population growth over the last 50 years, and at the moment there is enough food to go around. It's just inequitably distributed -- with the result that food does not reach the needy."
The five-day meeting is expected to attract 100 heads of state and several thousand other participants, but several major industrial countries including the United States will be represented only by low-level delegations.
Participants are expected to adopt a declaration pledging to reduce by half the number of people in the world suffering from chronic hunger -- estimated at 840 million -- by the year 2015. But the document, criticized by many groups as vague, lacking in ambition and silent on many important food issues, carries no legal weight and makes no financial commitments.
Still, organizers hope that the event itself will push into the international limelight the need to insure an adequate food supply for a growing world population, and to keep up pressure on rich and poor countries alike to match the successes of the past without repeating the mistakes.
The last international conference on world hunger, in 1974, took place in a more charged atmosphere as experts warned of a pending global food shortage. As it turned out, the world food supply increased -- largely as a result of the so-called "green revolution," which helped a number of countries become self-sufficient.
Those successes have reduced the proportion of chronically hungry people in the world to the current 840 million, or 13.7 percent of the world's population, from the early 1970's figure of 920 million, or 24.4 percent. But a pledge made at the 1974 conference that in 10 years no child would go to bed hungry has become a mockery: according to statistics released by the World Food Program, 11,000 children die every day -- one every eight seconds -- from malnutrition.
According to the meeting's organizers, the challenge in coming years will be to continue to increase food production while avoiding some of the social, economic and environmental disruptions caused by the green revolution. But the most critical issue, they say, will be to keep pace with a population that by the year 2030 is expected to increase by 3 billion people. According to the United Nations agency's estimates, food production will have to increase 75 percent if those people are to be fed adequately.
In the face of persistent food emergencies, some man-made like the one now unfolding in Zaire, food experts note with concern a drop in global food reserves, which recently fell below minimum levels as a result of high prices and poor harvests in some parts of the world.
Food aid levels from donor countries have also declined in recent years. And as food aid levels drop, an increasing proportion, about 30 percent today compared with about 10 percent in the 1970's, is going toward emergency relief situations like the one in Zaire.
The map of world hunger is also changing. Today half , or 420 million, of the world's hungry live in Asia, although experts expect that number to decrease. In contrast, sub-Saharan Africa remains one of the few regions where the percentage of people suffering from hunger, now 40 percent of the population, has not declined in recent years.
Compared with the 1974 conference, this meeting has more modest goals, a consequence of what many see as a worldwide lowering of expectations of what governments, and international organizations, can do.
"We are in a very different world," said Dr. Killingsworth, noting that this conference will be looking for greater involvement by the private sector and by civic organizations. "We have come to understand that agriculture does not have all the solutions, that governments cannot solve problems by themselves."

HEADLINE: Two Airliners Collide in Midair, Killing All 351 Aboard in India

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Nov. 13

 BODY:
All 351 passengers and crew appeared to have been killed on Tuesday night when a Saudi Arabian jumbo jet collided shortly after takeoff with a Kazak Airlines plane approaching the New Delhi airport, Indian aviation officials said. The death toll made it the third-deadliest air crash and the worst mid-air collision in aviation history.
Rescue teams searching by the light of burning wreckage reported at first that there were no survivors from the Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and the Kazak Airlines Ilyushin 76, which collided at 6:40 P.M. Tuesday New Delhi time (8:10 A.M. Eastern time), as night was falling in the area. 
 Officials at the scene said at midnight Tuesday local time that villagers had reported "three or four" people alive in the wreckage immediately after the impact, and that all but one of them had died before rescue teams arrived. According to these unconfirmed accounts, the lone survivor was taken to a local hospital. But a later survey of local hospitals turned up no survivors.
The Press Trust of India, citing a passenger list, said those killed aboard the Saudi aircraft were mostly Indians, and also included 17 foreigners, including two Americans. Other foreigners aboard were said to have included nine Nepalese, three Pakistanis, and one each from Bangladesh, Britain and Saudi Arabia.
Kazak officials told Reuters that the Ilyushin, arriving from the southern Kazak city of Chimkent, had been chartered by a company in neighboring Kyrgyzstan and that most of the passengers aboard were Kyrgyz.
The pilot of a United States Air Force C-141 transport plane who was bringing in supplies for the American Embassy in New Delhi said he had seen the immediate aftermath of the collision.
"We noticed out of our right hand a large cloud lit up with an orange glow from within the clouds," the pilot, who declined to give his name, said in a telephone news conference with reporters at the Pentagon. The glow increased in intensity, he said, and then he saw "two fireballs" emerge from the cloud and explode into a field of fire when they hit the ground about a minute later.
By midnight Tuesday, the police said they had recovered 275 bodies from a wreckage path that was spread over an area six miles wide near the village of Charkhi Dadri, in a thickly populated farming district west of New Delhi in the state of Haryana. But there were no reports of any casualties on the ground.
There was widespread speculation about a possible failure in air traffic control procedures at Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, of a misunderstanding of controllers' instructions or a misreading of an altimeter by one of the pilots.
But at a news conference about three hours after the crash, H. S. Khola, the Indian director of civil aviation, said: "We are ourselves not in full possession of the facts. Nobody knows exactly what happened as of now. We will get to the bottom of this and find out who was responsible."
Mr. Khola said the collision occurred when the Saudi plane, bound for the Saudi cities of Dhahran and Jidda, was climbing after takeoff with 312 passengers and crew. About seven minutes after takeoff, he said, the Saudi aircraft collided with the Kazakstan Airlines plane, an aircraft configured for cargo that had flown from Chimkent with 39 passengers and crew. Another Indian official said that air traffic controllers noticed "two blips merging on the radar screen but not separating" before both blips disappeared.
Mr. Khola said the Saudi aircraft, carrying large numbers of Indians traveling to jobs in Saudi Arabia and Indian Muslims making pilgrimages to Mecca, had taken off at 6:33 P.M.
"It was asked to climb to 14,000 feet, as per air traffic control information, and the Kazak aircraft was asked to descend to 15,000 feet," Mr. Khola said. "At about 6:40 P.M., radar blips of both aircraft were lost."
Although there are more than four million takeoffs of civilian aircraft around the world every day, midair collisions are extremely rare, and until Tuesday there was no midair collision on the list of the world's 10 worst air accidents.
Aviation experts said improvements in air traffic control had vastly cut the risk of midair collision since the worst incident of its kind in the United States, the collision on Dec. 16, 1960 of a Trans World Airlines Super Constellation and a United Airlines DC-8 in fog over New York harbor. That crash, which sent one of the aircraft plunging into the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, killed 134 people.
Indian and international aviation officials said one factor that might have contributed to the crash was that all takeoffs and landings to the airport occur along a single flight corridor. For years, Indian pilots and air traffic controllers have said that the absence of other routes into the airport creates hazards, with incoming and outgoing aircraft sometimes flying in opposite directions on the same path with an airspace separation of as little as 1,000 feet.
Mr. Khola said the 1,000-foot separations met international flight safety standards. But the Indian Air Traffic Controllers' Guild issued a statement saying the collision "could have been averted if only there were separate arrival and departure routes at Delhi airport."
The statement said that the controllers had been "making requests for a very long time" for separate corridors, but that the Indian Air Force, which uses one side of the airport for a military airfield, had resisted the proposal. "The air force headquarters is not willing to open up more sky for civil aviation," the guild's statement said.
The controllers' statement said that the Saudi and Kazak planes had been "under radar control" at the time of the accident and had been advised of each others' respective positions. But international aviation experts said that outdated radar equipment is still in use at the New Delhi airport while new equipment is being installed, and that it is possible that as a result controllers would not have had a continuous readout on their screens of the altitude, direction and velocity of each aircraft.
"The problem with Delhi is that the radar is antiquated," said Eric Moody, a retired pilot who was a Boeing 747 captain with British Airways.
Mr. Moody and other aviation experts who were interviewed on the British Broadcasting Corporation's satellite television network cited two other factors that might have contributed to the collision. One was the possibility that the Soviet-built Ilyushin 76 had an altimeter demarcated in meters, not feet. Mr. Moody said that pilots of those aircraft flying into airports outside the old Soviet bloc often had to convert the altitudes given to them in feet by air traffic controllers into meters by reading from a conversion chart, and that a mistake could have resulted.
He said another possibility was that there had been a language mix-up between the Indian controller and one or both of the airliner pilots, who would have been communicating in English. Pilots with international airlines flying into Indian airports say that it is often difficult to understand the instructions radioed to them by controllers.
The collision jolted the Indian Government, which ordered a judicial inquiry. The crash came at a time when Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda's five-month-old coalition Government is coming under criticism for its failure to act decisively to regain momentum in India's faltering program of economic reform, which has not attracted the flows of foreign investment and technology it had hoped for, partly because of India's slowness in upgrading its outdated roads, ports and airports.
Indian aviation officials countered criticism by noting that some steps have been taken in recent years to improve what was, in the 1970's and 1980's, one of the world's worst air safety records. A new law four years ago allowed the creation of private airlines to compete with the monopolies held by state-owned Air India and Indian Airlines, and the dozen private carriers that have sprung up have spurred vastly improved service. Large sums have been spent on upgrading major airports, including New Delhi, although much of the work remains incomplete.
But the system remains accident-prone. In May 1994, a Boeing 737 operated by Sahara Airways, a private carrier, skidded off the runway during pilot training and crashed into an Aeroflot airliner parked at the international terminal at New Delhi, killing 22 people.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Should Pitch 'Values' to Real Families

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In her critique of Bob Dole's campaign as insufficiently Reaganite, Lisa Schiffren (Op-Ed, Nov. 9) says it is "shameful" that the Republican nominee didn't explain that a tax cut strengthens family values because it would allow "a mother to forgo working and to rear her own children."
This was not an effective selling point for Mr. Dole not because he didn't say it (he did, several times) but because it bears no relation to the real lives of working families. 
 My wife and I both work, and we have one child. We had a taxable income of about $54,000 last year, which means we owed some $10,000 in Federal taxes. The 15 percent Dole tax cut would have reduced our tax liability by about $1,500.
With that money, we might be able to put a down payment on a new car. Or buy a new home computer. But it's not enough to allow either one of us to drop out of the work force, which would cut our family income in half.
Reduced child care expenses wouldn't make up for the loss in our standard of living, nor would a 15 percent tax cut (the value of which would fall along with our income).
Ms. Schiffren, like Mr. Dole and others who contend that Uncle Sam is strangling family life, puts the tax-collecting cart before the income-generating horse. Soccer moms and dads feel economic pressure these days not because the Government is taking too much out of their paychecks, but because employers aren't putting enough in.
A real "family values" economic policy would address the gap between employee compensation, which has been stagnant for years, and employee productivity, which is growing nicely enough to feed an unprecedented boom in corporate profits. That boom has produced record results on Wall Street, but a lot more wealth will have to trickle down to the rest of us before we can afford to work less and spend more time with our families.
 
ROGER KERSON
Evanston, Ill., Nov. 10, 1996

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid to Russia Can't Rein In Mobsters

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stephen Handelman's Nov. 9 Op-Ed article contains a simplistic interpretation of the roots of Russia's mafia, and his remedies to combat the corruption miss the mark.
While Russians were indeed trained to see private entrepreneurs as "enemies," forcing business people to seek protection from racketeers instead of the police, the Kremlin had already realized that its command economy could not deliver consumer goods. So, crackdowns occurred only when large-scale larceny, like trainloads of goods disappearing, took place. A party functionary, but not a member of the inner circle, was often the fall guy. This modus operandi persists, except that the Potemkin village is a different color. 
 Given that the former Communists are the new capitalists, it is delusory to think, as Mr. Handelman does, that United States aid to Russian law enforcement can rein in the mafia.
The power structure, with its interests to protect, is linked with the corruption. It is through this structure that tens of billions of dollars reaped by the nouveau riche flow into foreign banks, rather than being invested in commercial development. As long as this continues, foreign entrepreneurs will have to take risks beyond those taken on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
ILVI J. CANNON
Bolton, Conn., Nov. 10, 1996

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
From Drought to Dissent in the Western Plains

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

BAD LAND
An American Romance
By Jonathan Raban
Maps. 324 pages. Pantheon Books. $25. 
 In the present-day West he explores so engagingly in his new book, "Bad Land: An American Romance," Jonathan Raban meets many people hostile to the Federal Government. These dissenters are not only extremists like the members of the Militia of Montana who refuse even to look at him as he eats breakfast in the Landmark Cafe, "evidently the regimental mess," in Noxon, Mont.
They are also mild-mannered ranchers disdainful of Washington bureaucrats who, they say, think of the West as an empty space in which to practice their naive environmental experiments.
 Mr. Raban seems in general to disapprove of such outlooks, remarking at one point that "ranchers and farmers, with their wheat subsidies and grazing rights, had more tax- dollars in their pockets than any other single group of Americans, not excluding, say, single teen-age black mothers on welfare."
Yet, he writes, if one were looking for evidence to support the idea that the Federal Government was capable of dishonesty, one had only to remember the Enlarged Homestead Act, passed by Congress in 1909, which guaranteed 320 free acres in the Plains of Montana and the Dakotas to anyone willing to farm them.
Through the promotional efforts of railroad and mining interests, Americans and Europeans were persuaded that it was possible to farm what Mr. Raban refers to as "the Great American Desert," an expanse of land "which looked suspiciously like the surface of the moon." In one of his blunter passages, Mr. Raban calls the dryland homestead scheme "this cruel hoax, this shoddy, obvious piece of scam artistry."
To make his history palpable to the reader, Mr. Raban steps into the Montana moonscape, creates a feeling of its intimidating immensity and then walks through a ruined homestead, picking up and examining its abandoned contents. One item is the famous pamphlet that inspired so many settlers, "Campbell's Soil Culture Manual," in which Hardy W. Campbell, an evangelical farming expert, described what he saw as a revolutionary new system for farming semi-arid land.
As Mr. Raban sums up the system: "You'd need to buy a Campbell Sub-Surface Packer to compact the soil at the root-level of your crops. You'd also need a disk harrow to break up the topmost layer into a fine, loose mulch. The pulverized surface soil would collect the rain; the packed soil would store the moisture for future use."
If there was rain.
There was, at least for the first three summers after the settlers arrived, 1911, 1912 and 1913. Mr. Raban recreates the spirit of the time by introducing actual families and showing how their hopes soared, their bankers rejoiced, interest rates sank, credit expanded and debt mounted. And then, as Mr. Raban writes: "The weather broke. It had not been cured, as the optimists claimed. It had only been in remission."
Here Mr. Raban outdoes himself. To feel the cold of the Montana winters, he walks nine-tenths of a mile at night in minus-35-degree weather. "I had never felt my bones as bones before -- the dry clacking of the joints of the skeleton. My kneecaps, thin and brittle as sand-dollars, came to my attention first, followed by my wrists, knuckles, shoulder blades and ankles. I rattled as I walked, my trouser-legs flapping round bare white shinbones."
To sense the terror of the Great Plains lightning, he gets caught driving in a thunderstorm. Mere eloquence serves him to experience secondhand the hailstones, the tornadoes and the clouds of grasshoppers blotting out the sun.
Most ruinously, drought hit in 1917. Wheat production fell, and along with it wheat prices. One of Mr. Raban's witnesses recalls his father's telling him that "his haunting memory of this time was the sight of his mother, on her knees every day, crying and praying for rain."
The war in Europe and the drought in Montana "collapsed into a single catastrophe." Some homesteaders gave up, abandoned their farms and moved farther west. Others stayed, only to be hit by the Depression and the Dust Bowl of the "Dirty Thirties." Today a few farms remain in the Montana Plains along with a residue of cynicism extending all the way west to Seattle, the self-named Emerald City where the most intrepid of the settlers ended up.
What is the point of this vivid reconstruction of the past, besides making readers feel firsthand the awful futility of fighting nature at its most malevolent? In the last third of "Bad Land," Mr. Raban travels back and forth between eastern Montana and his home in Seattle, trying to see what became of the homesteaders and their descendants and trying to understand the legacy of their experience.
His conclusions are complex, reflecting the contradictory nature of a community made up of individualistic people who wanted to succeed on their own terms. The failure of the homesteaders was reflected for him in a pathetic effort by Ismay, a Montana town in the heart of the Plains, to rename itself Joe and thereby share the glory of the pro football hero of the same name.
This gimmick proved not to be even as profitable as the hoopla surrounding the arrest of Theodore Kaczynski, accused of being the Unabomber, nine months later at Lincoln, at the western end of the state. More promotional T-shirts were sold in Lincoln than in Joe. In Mr. Raban's West, violent apartness sells better than heroic team play.
The puzzle that remains is why the author, an English expatriate now settled in Seattle, was attracted to the homesteaders' story. He writes at the outset of "Bad Land" that "lacking an American past of my own, I hoped to find someone else's castoff history that would fit my case," and that in the Plains of Montana he had found "the point of connection" he had been searching for. "I was certain of it."
But this doesn't really explain the restless curiosity that has enabled him to enliven remote experiences in books like "Arabia," "Old Glory" and "Hunting Mr. Heartbreak: A Discovery of America." One can only trust that his search for connections will continue and yield more books as entertaining and instructive as this one.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jonathan Raban (Jean Lenihan/Pantheon Books)

HEADLINE: Mexico Is Evolving Into a Plural Political System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A review of today's Mexican reality reveals a far different picture from the alarmist one you paint in "Foreign Danger Zones" (editorial, Nov. 10). To talk of a country that has "stunted its politics" is to ignore that our society is building a plural political system. The Mexican congress is ruled by four political parties, and many states, towns and cities are governed by different political parties. 
 Mexico is a country in which ambitious political reform was recently approved by consensus after healthy debate on financing of political parties and equal access to the news media. The same day your editorial appeared, peaceful, contested state elections were held in various parts of the country.
Mexico is not, as you state, a "crisis waiting to happen." All economic indicators are showing dramatic improvement. Mexico's handling of the post-devaluation crisis has shown our desire to base progress on firm ground, in a sustainable way.
It is naive to imagine that political and economic change will depend on America's will. Our reforms will continue to be promoted internally by our own people and for our own interest. Fortunately for both the United States and Mexico, our relations are too complex for your call for pressure to have any resonance. Such tactics can only backfire.
 
JORGE PINTO
Consul General of Mexico
New York, Nov. 12, 1996

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Remarks by Treasury Official Suggest Strong Dollar Policy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the Japanese yen and steadied against the German mark yesterday after a Treasury official reaffirmed the commitment of the United States to a strong currency for the first time since the elections.
But the dollar ended mixed against other currencies and briefly touched a four-year low against the British pound, which surged on data pointing to a stronger British economy and the likelihood of higher interest rates. Rising British rates would increase returns on investments in pound-denominated assets. 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 111.79 yen from 111.34 on Tuesday. The dollar was unchanged at 1.5075 marks.
Traders said there was little reaction when the Federal Reserve, as expected, left interest rates unchanged.
Traders said Jeffrey Schafer, Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, set off a round of dollar-buying in the afternoon by telling reporters in Washington that "our exchange rate policy hasn't changed," and that a strong currency was in America's interests. His remarks temporarily quelled fears among traders about the currency's direction in President Clinton's second term.
"I think the United States, by reaffirming its position, still is looking for a stronger dollar," said Stephen Flanagan, a currency trader at the New York branch of Credit Agricole.
Fears that the dollar's 19-month strengthening against the yen had peaked began to grow last Thursday, when Eisuke Sakakibara, an influential Japanese finance official, suggested that the yen's period of weakness was over.
The conspicuous absence of a United States response to Mr. Sakakibara's assertion had raised further speculation of a policy change and sent the dollar tumbling against the yen.
The pound rose as as high as $1.6604, the highest since mid-October 1992. before settling in New York at $1.6525, up from $1.6460 on Tuesday.
The pound strengthened sharply after the British Government reported a larger-than-expected decline in the October unemployment rate, to 7.2 percent from 7.4 percent in September, as well as higher labor costs.

HEADLINE: Pope Tells U.N. Group Population Control Is No Cure for Hunger

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 13

 BODY:
In an opening address at the World Food Summit here, Pope John Paul II injected a hint of old controversies today as he chided those who link hunger with overpopulation.
"We must renounce the sophist view which holds that 'to be many is to condemn ourselves to be poor,' " the Pope said, returning to the issue of population control that had pitted the Vatican against the United States and other Western countries at earlier conferences sponsored by the United Nations. 
 But the World Food Summit, a five-day conference that is expected to draw more than 50 heads of state by week's end, has been billed from the start as a noncontroversial gathering, where delegations from 173 countries are expected to adopt a document prepared beforehand that will avoid any late-hour clashes.
Convening in the shadow of the unfolding crisis in central Africa, delegates were urged from all sides not only to come to the rescue of those who have been made hungry by war and disaster, but also to work to give them what they need to sustain themselves.
"At the very moment this summit is taking place, over a million starving, frightened refugees are wandering helpless in the mountains and forests of eastern Zaire," the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said. He called on all nations to take part in "collective action" in the region.
One of the guiding principles of this conference -- where governments will take a nonbinding pledge to halve the number of hungry people by the year 2015 -- is not to re-open debates over issues like population control and abortion that had dominated previous United Nations conferences at Cairo and Beijing.
Still, Pope John Paul II, who has strongly reaffirmed the Roman Catholic Church's ban against artificial birth control, took the opportunity to challenge those who argue that population control is a major weapon in the fight against hunger.
"It would be illusory to believe that an arbitrary stabilization of the world population, or even its reduction, could solve the problem of hunger directly," he said.
Instead, the Pope urged leaders to close the "intolerable" gap between "those who lack the bare necessities and those who squander freely."
The Pope, whose expected meeting with President Fidel Castro of Cuba has given the summit conference its main element of suspense, also criticized the developed world indirectly, by pointing to the "sometimes stifling burden of international debt" on poorer nations, and to the excess use of economic embargoes.
The Vatican has been a persistent critic of embargoes, like the American action against Cuba, which it says hurts ordinary people more than their governments.
Jacques Diouf, director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, the host of the conference, today echoed the Pope's tone when he warned delegates that issues of food and water could lead to conflicts in the next century if world leaders do not pay heed.
Mr. Diouf, who is from Senegal, pointed out that the annual budget for the United Nations food agency is "less than what nine developed countries spend on dog and cat food in six days and, listen to me, less than 5 percent of what the inhabitants of one developed country spend each year on slimming products to counter the effect of overeating."
The heads of state, who are expected to start arriving on Thursday night, are coming mostly from the developing world, while most industrialized countries will be represented the cabinet level. The American delegation is headed by Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman.

HEADLINE: Michael Moynihan, 68, Free-Trade Champion

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Michael W. Moynihan, an advocate of free trade who served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Tuesday at his home in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 68.
Mr. Moynihan, a brother of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, suffered from prostate cancer, although the cause of death has not been determined, his family said. 
 From 1980 to 1990, Mr. Moynihan worked for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, based in Paris, a group that aims to coordinate the economic policies of more than 20 of the world's wealthiest nations. He served first as the organization's director of information and later became its representative in Washington.
After his retirement in 1992, he became a consultant, working in support of United States approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, both of which ultimately won ratification by Congress.
Much earlier, during the Kennedy Administration, Mr. Moynihan was the spokesman for the new White House Office of the President's Special Trade Representative. Then, in the Johnson Administration, he served as director of the information service of the Agency for International Development.
Later he was director of public affairs for the Port of New York Authority, and then from 1967 to 1980 was the president of his own public affairs consulting firm, with offices in New York and Washington.
It was at one point in this period that critics questioned his representing a Saudi delegation that visited Washington in 1977 to meet with President Jimmy Carter. But Mr. Moynihan rejected the critics' suggestions that he might influence his elder brother, Senator Moynihan, a New York Democrat and staunch supporter of Israel, by saying, "I wouldn't want to work for anyone who is so dumb that he thought I could get favors out of my brother."
Mr. Moynihan was born in Teaneck, N.J., and grew up in Manhattan and the Long Island City section of Queens. He received a bachelor of science degree in social studies from the City College of New York in 1951 and a master of arts degree from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, administered by Harvard and Tufts, in 1952.
He is survived by his wife, the former Helena Ferris Smith; two sons, Michael Jr., of Washington, and Eamon, of Brooklyn; a daughter, Mary Schmandt of Chevy Chase, Md.; a grandchild, and two brothers -- the Senator, and Thomas Stapelfeld of Canton, Conn.

HEADLINE: Investments in Stock Mutual Funds Declined 25% in October

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Cash flows to equity mutual funds fell 25 percent in October, to $13 billion, a trade group said, as uncertainty over the strength of the economy and over the outcome of the fall elections tempered investors' long-running love affair with stocks.
The estimate, released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, confirmed anecdotal evidence supplied last week by the FMR Corporation's Fidelity Investments, the country's largest fund company, and Charles Schwab & Company, the biggest discount seller of funds. Both saw investors' appetites fall sharply last month. 
 But just as stock prices roared ahead after the elections, so too did inflows to mutual funds. Independent analysts who track mutual fund flows reported that fund companies received a resurgent wave of fresh cash in the first half of November.
Investors remained cool toward bond funds last month, withdrawing an estimated $500 million, according to the Investment Company Institute. While bond funds attracted $2 billion in net inflows in September following three consecutive months of net withdrawals, that optimism now appears to have faded.
John Rea, chief economist for the mutual fund trade group, which released the estimates yesterday, said that anecdotal information indicated that the slowdown in October stock fund flows seemed to be concentrated among domestic funds. Those funds, which invest primarily in stocks of United States companies, accounted for about 80 percent of net inflows to stock funds in August and September.
While October's result is down sharply from the approximately $17 billion that stock funds have taken in during each of the last two months, it hardly represents a disaster. Before last year, stock fund inflows exceeded $13 billion in a single month on only a handful of occasions. And in 1990, net inflows for the entire year fell just short of $13 billion. So far in 1996, however, inflows have topped that level in nine of 10 months.
In addition, October's short-term nervousness appears to have passed, said Charles Biderman, president of Trim Tabs Financial Services, a Santa Rosa, Calif., company that tracks fund flows. In the days immediately following Election Day, when the stock market began its latest upward march, equity funds took in money at the fastest rate since January, he said. Since the beginning of November, net inflows to stock funds have proceeded at a monthly rate of more than $20 million.
A four-week moving average of stock fund inflows tracked by AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif., which measures fund flows on a weekly basis, turned upward in the week ended Nov. 6 after falling for four consecutive weeks.
Some of the weakness in bond funds, meanwhile, could be coming from the municipal bond sector, which has had a lackluster year. At Schwab, municipal funds suffered net outflows for each of the last two months, while taxable bond funds took in close to $100 million monthly.
Schwab investors added $358 million to domestic growth stock funds in October, down from more than $1 billion in September; international stock funds, however, took in $188 million, up from $174 million the previous month.

HEADLINE: Justices Weigh Suits Over Going Too Far to Protect Environment

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
An unusual environmental case that was argued before the Supreme Court today found the Clinton Administration struggling to defend its view that people can sue the Government for doing too little to protect endangered species, but not for doing too much.
Like many other environmental laws, the Endangered Species Act includes a "citizen suit" provision that permits "any person" to sue officials of the Interior or Commerce Departments for failing to carry out their responsibilities under the law. 
 Typically, such suits are brought by environmentalists complaining about lax enforcement or underregulation. The question for the Court today was whether this provision and the others like it are, in effect, double-edged swords: whether people whose economic interests are harmed by action taken to protect endangered species can sue to stop what they view as overregulation.
"The citizen suit provision is designed to advance the purposes of species protection," Deputy Solicitor General Edwin S. Kneedler told the Court.
The provision, Mr. Kneedler said, was limited to suits over "actions that would harm a species" rather than those that would harm private economic interests.
The Justices were openly skeptical of what several called a "one-way construction" of the citizen suit provision. "You just read resource-user protection out of the act," Justice Anthony M. Kennedy told Mr. Kneedler, adding that "we should be very cautious" about departing from "the normal rule of neutrality" in the legal system.
The case was brought by a group of ranchers and irrigation districts in Oregon, seeking to stop the Interior Department from limiting the release of water from the reservoirs of the Klamath Irrigation Project near the Oregon-California border. The plaintiffs have contracts with the Government to use the water from the project. In 1992, the Fish and Wildlife Service issued a report warning that the reservoirs needed to keep higher water levels, with less water to be released for irrigation, to protect the habitat of two endangered species of fish, the Lost River sucker and the shortnose sucker.
This report was the first step in a procedure under the Endangered Species Act that could lead to a formal action setting new water levels in the reservoirs. The lawsuit sought to have the report withdrawn on the ground that its scientific judgments were incorrect and that the agency had failed to consider the economic impact of its proposed action.
Two lower courts, the Federal District Court in Eugene, Ore., and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, dismissed the suit on the ground that people seeking to stop a regulatory action did not have standing to bring a citizen suit. "Only plaintiffs who allege an interest in the preservation of endangered species fall within the zone of interests protected by the Endangered Species Act," Judge Stephen Reinhardt wrote for the appeals court in a 1995 opinion.
In urging the Supreme Court to uphold the Ninth Circuit's judgment, the Administration did not embrace Judge Reinhardt's broad language, instead offering the Court a series of procedural and technical reasons why the ranchers' suit should not be permitted to proceed. The plaintiffs had sued the wrong official, Mr. Kneedler said; the Fish and Wildlife Service's report was simply advisory and did not commit the Interior Department, of which the service is a part, to final action.
But despite these efforts to deflect the Court's interest, the Justices appeared quite eager to get to the merits of the case and grapple with the meaning of the citizen suit provision.
Gregory K. Wilkinson, arguing for the plaintiffs, told the Court that the Ninth Circuit's decision would lead to "discrimination against economic-based claimants" and "one-sided enforcement of the Endangered Species Act." Mr. Wilkinson said the value of his clients' land had dropped sharply because of the threat to the water supply.
The case, Bennett v. Spear, No. 95-813, has attracted considerable attention not only because the question is a novel one for the Court, but also because the Court's interpretation could affect citizen suit provisions under the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act and other environmental laws.
Environmental groups have been particularly wary of the implications of the case. They are usually on the side of trying to persuade a reluctant Supreme Court to maintain access to court, under legal doctrines governing who has "standing" to bring a lawsuit, for those who want to challenge Government regulatory action that affects the environment. But in this case, the groups' interests are served by a narrower rather than broader interpretation of standing.
Faced with this problem, environmental groups filed no briefs in the case. There were several briefs on the ranchers' side, including one from California and 13 other states. A brief from the National Association of Home Builders and other organizations in the building industry argued that the Ninth Circuit's decision would result in "stripping regulated parties of any means to defend themselves" while leaving "free rein to environmental groups to encourage and, indeed, to force the Endangered Species Act's expansion."
