HEADLINE: Interest Rates Not Changed By Fed Panel

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted to keep interest rates unchanged today, as the Government's report on producer prices provided the latest evidence that inflation remained quiescent despite a surge last month in food and energy costs.
With both the Fed and financial markets scrutinizing data for signs that inflation may be infecting the economy, the Labor Department's Producer Price Index showed that prices at the producer level actually fell by three-tenths of 1 percent last month when food and energy, which are notoriously volatile, were excluded. The decline in the so-called core component, while driven in part by technical factors, was the steepest in two years. 
 Including food and energy, the index told a very different story: a rise in producer prices for finished goods of four-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest increase since March. But food prices are already showing signs of leveling off after surging in recent months, and the outlook is for energy prices to continue increasing but at a more moderate pace. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
Indeed, the markets, many economists and presumably the Fed concentrated on the decline in the core rate to conclude that despite steady growth and low unemployment in the sixth year since the end of the last recession, the economy is showing no sustained signs of slipping into the kind of upward wage-price spiral that typically derails expansions.
"Those folks who are ever vigilant against inflation could certainly point to the 0.4 percent increase in the overall number, and those who think inflation is benign are going to seize on the 0.3 percent drop in the core," said Veronika White, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Philadelphia. "The truth lies somewhere in the middle. It's a benign environment, but I don't think inflation is falling."
Despite signs that inflation is still largely contained, bond prices ended slightly lower. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer and corporate interest rates -- edged up to 6.45 percent from 6.44 percent. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
With the economy's growth rate having decelerated in the third quarter, and with few signs that it is overheating in the current quarter, the Fed's decision to leave monetary policy unchanged had been widely anticipated. Economists said the continuing lack of evidence of an inflationary threat suggested that the Fed would keep rates unchanged at its last policy-making meeting of the year, on Dec. 17, and perhaps well into next year.
The Fed, as usual, gave no explanation of its decision or any details of its vote. Economists said the only question was whether the Fed's Federal Open Market Committee had voted to remove from its policy the formal bias toward raising rates that it adopted this summer, when fears of an overheating economy were more acute.
The Fed has held rates steady since January, when it trimmed its Federal funds target rate to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent and dropped its discount rate by a quarter-point to 5 percent.
Some economists remain convinced that the tight labor market will eventually lead to a rise in wages sharp enough to cause an acceleration of inflation. The Fed has reported anecdotal evidence of strong wage increases in various regions for months. But there is some evidence that workers, still worried about their jobs in an era of downsizing, are reluctant to push hard for higher wages, and that companies that do raise wages are absorbing the costs rather than trying to pass them along to consumers.
Today's upbeat if somewhat muddied news about inflation in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was matched at earlier stages in the production chain. For intermediate goods, prices were flat, and excluding food and energy, they were down one-tenth of 1 percent. For crude goods -- the very beginning of the production pipeline -- prices were down six-tenths of 1 percent, the second consecutive monthly decline. Excluding food and energy, however, the crude goods index was up three-tenths of 1 percent.
"Taken at face value there's really no inflation to worry about at the finished goods level or really any other level for that matter," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Much of the decline in the core index for finished goods came from a decline in automobile and truck prices. Those price drops -- down 1.6 percent for cars -- primarily reflected a statistical anomaly relating to the way the Labor Department accounts for new-model-year introductions each October.
As a result, economists said, the core index is unlikely to show a drop of the same magnitude for this month. On the other hand, they said, the overall index is unlikely to show such a sharp increase in producer prices since food and energy price increases appear to be cooling off. As a result, the unusually large gap between the core index and the overall index will probably narrow in coming months, they said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Bond Prices Hold Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government bond prices were little changed yesterday, despite relief that the Federal Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged.
The benchmark 30-year bond was off 3/32, to a price of 100 23/32, for a yield of 6.45 percent. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, was up from 6.44 percent on Tuesday. Prices of some securities with shorter maturities rose slightly. 
 Prices generally fell in early trading, despite a favorable report on producer prices for October, which would normally help the bond market. That hesitation, before today's report on consumer prices and retail sales, left many market participants wondering what it would take for bond prices to continue their recent move higher. Yields have been at their lowest levels since March.
The October Producer Price Index showed that the core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, down three-tenths of 1 percent, after analysts expected it to be up. The overall index was up four-tenths of 1 percent, more than expected. Traders said the market nevertheless elected to focus on the core inflation rate instead.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed-income activities and senior fund manager at the Private Bank of the Bank of Boston, said he thought that traders saw the higher energy prices as a sign of inflation. Still, he said, companies might have to absorb those higher prices, rather than passing them on to customers, thus helping keep consumer prices stable. "While oil prices are indeed higher," he said, "we see it more as a tax than an inflation factor."
Mr. Ablin said the dollar strengthened in the afternoon, probably because of some Japanese buying. The strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Government securities attractive to foreign investors.
The economy for the most part has not given the Open Market Committee, the policy-setting body of the Federal Reserve, any reason to raise rates, because it is still expanding at a moderate pace and inflation seems to be under control.
Lou Brien, an analyst with Finacor Vendome Inc., a Chicago brokerage firm, said that the market had assumed that the Fed would leave rates unchanged yesterday. Still, he said, the announcement relieved traders and helped spur some buying after the early weakness. Mr. Brien said that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had been correct in predicting in testimony to Congress in July that the economy would slow toward the end of the year. "The steady policy has thus been justified in the summer and now," Mr. Brien said. "I think the next rate move, even though it might be several months from now, will be down. The bottom line for the Fed is that inflation is at or below the trend."
Mr. Brien said analysts were expecting a three-tenths of 1 percent gain in the overall consumer price index, with the core rate up two-tenths of 1 percent. He said they expected a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it would auction $30.75 billion in new two-year and five-year notes next week that will raise a combined $2.425 billion in new cash. Following are the results of the Treasury's sale of 34-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
G.O.P. Quest To Narrow Gender Gap

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI recasts himself as the Education Mayor. Gov. George E. Pataki embraces the environment. And Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, former Whitewater buff, pledges to focus henceforth on "the things people want" (presumably after he cures breast cancer with a bond act).
Welcome to the era of the 52 percent special-interest group. Women. 
 The way women voted last week had a lot to do with Bill Clinton's victory and Bob Dole's defeat. And the way women vote is likely to influence strongly whether Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato win re-election in 1997 and 1998. Because as never before, the Gender Gap is influencing election results.
In 1980, men were 8 percentage points more likely to support Ronald Reagan than women were. Last week, according to a poll by the Voter News Service, the gap between men and women was 11 percentage points, with 43 percent of the men voting for Mr. Clinton, compared with 54 percent of the women. Women gave Mr. Dole only 38 percent of their votes, while 44 percent of the men supported him. Mr. Clinton did best with younger women, single women and black women.
New York's exit poll results on the Presidential race were similar and included signs of trouble for local Republicans. For instance, Mr. D'Amato's approval rating was 8 points lower among women than men; Mr. Pataki's was 7 points lower among women than among men. The poll did not ask about Mr. Giuliani.
WHAT is going on? It is not exclusively the abortion issue. The gap held even in Massachusetts, where Senator John Kerry and Gov. William F. Weld, his Republican rival, both backed abortion rights. Nor is it that women are innately more sympathetic and liberal than men -- stereotypes that many women find offensive.
To sociologists and political scientists, what cuts across all lines is that most fundamental of ballot-box issues: economics.
"It's a mistake to interpret the gender gap as some fundamental or essential difference between women and men -- a feminine versus masculine outlook," said Kathleen Gerson, professor of sociology at New York University. "It is rooted in the different social positions men and women occupy -- in self-interest."
Federal statistics show that 59.5 percent of American women 16 and over are in the work force. Women are more likely to be responsible for caring for children and aging parents, so are more involved with education and health care. Many women, then, look on government as a necessity, not a wasteful incursion into their assets.
"When men hear less government, they hear less taxes," said Kathleen Severin, a Republican media strategist. "When women hear less government, it's the equivalent of hearing downsizing. They think: 'Oh my God, less services, less stuff that I need. Less Medicare means I have to pay more for my mother's care. Less education means I may not be able to send my kids to college.' "
IN the New York exit poll, 54 percent of women wanted government to do more, compared with 45 percent of the men. Only 41 percent of the women wanted less government, while 51 percent of the men did. Asked what issue mattered most to them, twice as many men as women cited the deficit, while twice as many women as men said education. "It's about government making their lives work," said Ethel Klein, president of EDK Associates, a public opinion research firm. "They don't see government services as a handout."
New York Republicans acknowledge their vulnerability, in terms that make them sound like the flip side of Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker whose popularity plummeted the more passionately he pledged to shrink government.
"The public wants to know what government is going to do for families," said Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester District Attorney. Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island says her party has to explain better how it is "responsive to people's needs." Peter J. Powers, who will run Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign, says Republicans have to take on child care, preferably through tax credits: "If you want to talk family values, you'd better address child care."
Mr. Giuliani himself, long at odds with the Board of Education, has just found an extra $70 million for textbooks. No surprise, and no coincidence, either. Women, who rate education as the most important issue, accounted for 52 percent of the national vote last week. But in the last mayoral race, they cast 57 percent of the vote.

HEADLINE: Guessing Game in the Capital: Future of Attorney General

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON and TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Three years after Attorney General Janet Reno emerged as a surprise star of the Clinton Cabinet, she has skidded to a stop at an unexpected career crossroads. She has said she wants to stay on at the Justice Department, but President Clinton has pointedly passed up opportunities to say he would keep her.
While there is no indication that Mr. Clinton plans to dismiss Ms. Reno, his unwillingness to endorse quickly her stewardship reflects longstanding strains between the White House and the Justice Department that have eroded her standing within Mr. Clinton's inner circle even as she retains her luster outside Washington. 
 Some Presidential aides expressed disappointment that Ms. Reno had failed to take political heat for Mr. Clinton and said they felt she had been too willing to refer cases involving the President's close associates to independent prosecutors. But they acknowledged that Mr. Clinton could face a blast of protest from Republicans if he tried to demand Ms. Reno's resignation now, while she is mulling their requests for an independent counsel to examine Democratic fund-raising.
Among White House aides, the gripes about Ms. Reno seem to be generalized and specific, clearly detectable but publicly untraceable to any particular senior official. In recent days, when several top Clinton advisers were asked to sum up objections to her, all did so only on condition of anonymity and only while insisting that they were repeating the complaints they had heard from others, not offering their own.
The complaints have not led to a decision to find a successor, said officials who predicted that Mr. Clinton would reluctantly extend Ms. Reno's tenure.
"My personal conviction is that the President's not going to be in a position to do what he wants to do," which is replace her, one senior White House aide said this week.
Instead, the White House appears content to let Ms. Reno dangle embarrassingly without an immediate decision on her future. The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, has told colleagues that Ms. Reno's fate will be chronologically one of the last questions to be addressed in the transition of forming the new Cabinet, with no decision until at least December. Of course, that will only have the effect on increasing the attention on any decision the President might make, since Ms. Reno would not be among a batch of appointees resigning at once.
Ms. Reno's aides said they had heard nothing from the White House. They added that her publicly stated position on her tenure -- that she likes the job and would stay if the President desired -- was meant as a candid expression of her thinking and was not intended to suggest that she was campaigning for the job. But to the chagrin of Ms. Reno's supporters, some White House aides have interpreted her comments as an effort to tie Mr. Clinton's hands.
Presidential aides do not see the strapping, idiosyncratic Attorney General, who relishes her outsider image, as one of their own. Mr. Clinton, who might turn to Education Secretary Richard W. Riley to jawbone about politics or to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin for a chat on economics, rarely, if ever, turns to Ms. Reno for serious discussions about the law or criminal justice matters.
Still, Attorneys General have long since transcended their one-time role as Presidential confidants. The rapid expansion of the Justice Department in the past two decades into a 90,000-employee agency increasingly focused on crime-fighting has made the job too managerially demanding for a mere crony. But within the Clinton White House, it is not Ms. Reno, but her deputy, Jamie S. Gorelick, who is perceived as the official who makes the trains run on time.
While the White House complaints over Ms. Reno's early emphasis on crime prevention and children have abated with her uncritical embrace of Mr. Clinton's emphatically centrist anti-crime agenda, irritations linger over specific judgment calls Ms. Reno has made to seek the appointment of independent counsels.
Some Presidential aides say she has trivialized the role of an independent counsel by seeking them in relatively routine cases, like whether Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros was truthful in a background inquiry about the size of payments to a former mistress.
Others were infuriated last month when Ms. Reno authorized Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, to investigate the truthfulness of statements made at a Congressional hearing by Bernard W. Nussbaum, the former White House counsel and ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton. Presidential aides contended that Ms. Reno could have legally defended a decision to keep the issue out of Mr. Starr's hands. But Justice Department officials said she had little choice under the law.
So far, Ms. Reno has sought the appointment of four independent counsels, and is considering complaints that could lead to a fifth to investigate whether Democrats illegally funneled overseas money into their campaign coffers. Her first appointment, in the Whitewater affair, came at the request of the White House. Later she sought counsels to investigate Mr. Cisneros, former Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy.
Ms. Reno may not set a record. President Ronald Reagan's three Attorneys General, referred a total of eight cases to independent counsels during Mr. Reagan's two terms.
In recent days she has shown signs that she is willing to take a more steely posture, rejecting as too vague two requests for the immediate appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign financing. Ms. Reno's aides said her decision had nothing to do with her job status but were statutory judgments that she was obliged to make under the independent counsel act.
But Justice Department lawyers are still evaluating a more detailed request by Senator John McCain of Arizona and several other Republican lawmakers that she must decide by the end of the month.
In part, however unhappy the White House is with Ms. Reno's handling of independent prosecutors, she may be untouchable simply because she is considering yet another one. To drop her now would almost certainly be attacked by Republicans as a self-protective maneuver by the President; any replacement in those circumstances would be attacked as a political pasty.
Ms. Reno's job security also seems enhanced by the absence of strong candidates to replace her. And beyond that, any successor would face the near certainty of a bruising confirmation battle in the Republican controlled Senate.
Outgoing Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, who was once widely regarded as a contender for the Attorney General's job, withdrew from consideration having concluded that no close partisan of the President should even seek the job.
Some in the White House, including George Stephanopoulos, had urged Mr. Clinton to demand undated resignation letters from all Cabinet members after Election Day, as an easy means of replacing those he wanted to. Some Presidents have done that, but Mr. Panetta was said to believe it would be disruptive and preferred instead to let members know quietly of the President's preferences.

HEADLINE: Hartford Plan Aims to Help Pay for College

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The State Treasurer proposed two programs today to encourage parents to save for their children's college education, including a tuition prepayment plan similar to those in 11 other states, including Massachusetts.
The prepayment plan would let parents pay all or a part of a child's tuition at current rates, with a guarantee that the payment would cover the child's education cost regardless of inflation or later tuition increases. The other plan would allow parents, through the state, to invest in mutual funds to save for college without having to pay taxes on the interest. 
 State Treasurer Christopher B. Burnham said some taxes would be due when the money was withdrawn for college, but at the student's tax rate. "It is a wonderful program which I think is going to help our residents save for their children's college education," he said.
Both proposals require approval by the State Legislature, and Democrats, who in January will control both houses of the Legislature, said today that they were willing to support a college savings program.
But State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, the Democratic Senate leader, said he was concerned the prepayment program might leave public colleges in 10 or 20 years with a debt they could not handle, if tuition costs have risen more than the interest on the original tuition payment.
The House Education Committee chairman, Cameron C. Staples, a Democrat, said he preferred a program that gives parents more flexibility and security. In a prepayment program, parents sign up only for Connecticut colleges that decide to participate. The prepayment program would work this way: if the University of Connecticut tuition was $10,000 a year and a parent invested $1,000, the parent would be credited with 10 percent of whatever the tuition was when the student enrolled.
Mr. Burnham said several colleges have expressed interest, although spokesmen at two colleges reached this afternoon, Yale University and UConn, said it was too early to say if they would participate. In 1994, Yale eliminated a similar program of its own that let parents pay for four years at the freshman-year rate.
Scott Brohinsky, director of university and governmental relations at UConn, said the university must look at the financial implications for the school. But he applauded the Treasurer and the state for addressing the problem of paying for college.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Westinghouse to Spin Off Industrial Businesses
After months of prodding from Wall Street, Westinghouse said that it would spin off its remaining industrial businesses to shareholders and focus on its radio and television operations.
But investors, who had bid up the price of Westinghouse shares by about 20 percent over the course of the last week on reports that a sweeping reorganization was in the offing, chose to sell on the news. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Stocks Rise on Fed Inaction
Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged and investors looked to corporate earnings for their cues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.20 points, to 6,274.24, its sixth consecutive record close, on higher than average volume. [Page D8.]
 
But retail stocks endured a second day of pounding, with some companies paying for the weak earnings of their peers. Dillard Department Stores announced disappointing earnings and Federated Department Stores had healthy profits, yet both stocks fell. The Standard & Poor's retail index fell 1.7 percent, to 382.75. [D3.]
 
Bond traders were relieved by the Fed's decision, but prices barely budged. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.45 percent from 6.44. [D15.]
 
Stock Funds Draw Less Cash
Cash flows into equity mutual funds fell by 25 percent in October, to $13 billion, a trade group said, as uncertainty over the strength of the economy and over the outcome of the November elections tempered investors' long-running love affair with stocks. [D24.]
 
Another British-U.S. Utility Deal
Dominion Resources, continuing an American invasion of the British utility industry, agreed to acquire East Midlands Electricity for about $2.15 billion. [D4.]
 
Drug Helps Prevent Heart Attacks
A study has found that a blood thinner called clopidogrel is more effective than aspirin in warding off heart attacks and strokes in people who have clogged arteries. Clopidogrel is being jointly developed by Sanofi and Bristol-Myers Squibb. [A18.]
 
Tougher Nasdaq Standard Proposed
The Nasdaq stock market, after being embarrassed by scandals that involved penny stocks, is proposing stricter listing standards that it said could cause hundreds of companies to be dropped from its listings. [D2.]
 
I.B.M. in Educational Software Deal
I.B.M. took its first big step toward becoming a major seller of educational software to schools and homes, saying it would buy Edmark for about $110 million. [D3.]
 
Pepsi Returning To Venezuela
Pepsi is coming back to Venezuela, five months after its bottler and distributor switched to Coke. Pepsico formed a venture with a brewer to bottle and distribute Pepsi, which had been the dominant soft drink in Venezuela before Coke's coup. [D5.]
 
Growth, Not Inflation, Is Up in China
China's chief banker said that the Government had achieved what few economists thought it could: high growth and low inflation. [D4.]
 
Limit on Workweek Is Rejected
Prime Minister John Major has plunged Britain into another clash with its 14 European Union partners by rejecting a court ruling that mandates a maximum workweek of 48 hours, including overtime. [A7.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 606 words

HEADLINE: The First Turnaround

 BODY:
It may be remembered as President Clinton's first post-election flip-flop, but he was right to let Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin correct his tactical error on the balanced-budget amendment. It was probably just a hangover from triangulation that caused Mr. Clinton to say Tuesday that he could live with the balanced-budget amendment if the Republicans in Congress pushed it through. The Wednesday morning headlines about Mr. Clinton's rush to surrender cleared everyone's thinking, and with White House blessings, Mr. Rubin said yesterday that the Administration will fight the Republicans' foolish passion for this paralyzing amendment. It is a fight worth making, because common sense has a chance to prevail.
Mr. Clinton's basic instincts are correct. He told reporters on Tuesday that the amendment is unnecessary. But in an excess of his habitual pliability, he added that the amendment could be acceptable if it included an "escape hatch" during recessions. The problem with this formulation was that it ripped the political cover that a President fresh from an electoral landslide can offer to Democrats and renegade Republicans brave enough to vote no on this popular yet harmful proposal. Mr. Clinton helped defeat it last year, and now that Mr. Rubin has stiffened his spine, he could win again this year despite the Republican control on Capitol Hill. 
 In its current form, the amendment would require the Government to balance the budget unless three-fifths of the House and Senate vote to run a deficit. Mr. Clinton seemed to suggest that a simple majority override would suit him. Such an approach would not really address the economic and legislative problems that the amendment will bring. Its goal, a zero deficit, represents dangerous overkill. The United States runs smaller deficits, relative to the size of its economy, than nearly any other industrialized country. There is good reason to keep deficits low, but there is no compelling reason to hit zero. The Federal budget makes no distinction between spending on paper clips and spending on long-term investments, like mass-transit systems. A zero-deficit target will compel Congress to cut expensive items first rather than tackle 1,000 different constituencies by going after small items. The process will squeeze out public investments on which the future health of the economy depends.
The amendment would also break a crutch that helps prop up a sagging economy. When incomes fall, tax revenues fall and government spending -- for example, for unemployment insurance -- rises. But with an arbitrary deficit target, Congress will be required to make mindless cuts in spending or raise taxes, thereby smothering an already weak economy. Even with the majority-vote escape clause mentioned by Mr. Clinton, the reality is that Congress rarely knows the economy has turned down until it is too late to take corrective action.
By speculating about an amendment, Mr. Clinton was recognizing the fact that a President cannot veto a constitutional amendment, which requires a two-thirds majority in each house. But his tactic of hinting at compromise was wrong. The amendment carried the House two years ago by only a dozen votes. It then failed in the Senate by one vote. The November elections brought more proponents to the Senate, but fewer to the House. More important, as Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, admitted earlier this week, some Democrats who voted yes two years ago are likely to change sides if their vote would alter the outcome. Mr. Rubin has reminded the President that this battle can be won, if he will stand and fight.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Aides See Windfall In Revenues

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides said last night that because of rising profits on Wall Street, the city would take in $450 million more in taxes this fiscal year than had been projected, allowing the Mayor to increase spending and scale back budget cuts as he begins his re-election campaign.
The aides said the Mayor would announce today that he would use the extra revenue to raise spending by $270 million. Some of the new revenue will be allocated for recycling programs to help the city meet its goal of closing the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island by 2001, Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said. 
 The Mayor had trimmed more than $25 million for recycling in his original $33 billion budget, which was approved by the City Council in June, stirring criticism from environmental groups. Mr. Mastro declined to say how much the Mayor would restore to the recycling budget, saying only that it would be in the millions of dollars.
More than $100 million of the additional revenue will go to cover growing overtime and other expenses arising from the Police Department's crackdown on drug dealing. The $270 million in new spending also includes $70 million for books for the public schools, a plan Mr. Giuliani first presented last week. The Mayor's aides said the Mayor would reveal today how he would spend the remainder of the $270 million.
The Mayor will use the rest of the projected extra revenue, about $180 million, to patch holes that have opened up in his budget since the fiscal year began on July 1. Those shortfalls stemmed from what bond-rating agencies and others who monitor the city's finances said were overly optimistic assumptions about revenue from sources other than taxes.
Mr. Mastro and the Mayor's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, said that because of the improving local economy, the Mayor was also reducing the size of budget cuts that he ordered in August, after the fiscal year had already started. Mr. Giuliani had told his agency heads then to come up with plans to cut a total of $500 million from their spending for the year, but now they will only have to find $180 million in savings, Mr. Mastro said. Administration officials have not disclosed where those cuts will be made.
Since Mr. Giuliani became Mayor in 1994, the slumping economy has repeatedly depressed tax revenues, forcing him to make new cuts. The proposal that he is to present today is the first that will give him the chance to reap the political benefits of a relatively stable economy.
The Mayor's Democratic rivals have often said they planned to paint him as a leader who has brazenly slashed the budget, threatening the most vulnerable members of society. In recent days, he has sought to repel those attacks by, for example, allocating the $70 million for schoolbooks.
While the city's job growth still lags behind that of the nation as a whole, it has begun to recover somewhat since the dark days of the recession, when the city lost 361,000 jobs.
The City Council, in fact, believes the Mayor's projection of $450 million in new revenues may be conservative. The Council says the number is closer to $525 million.
The Mayor's announcement today comes a few weeks after City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said tax revenues in the first quarter of the 1997 fiscal year alone were running $289 million higher than projections. Mr. Hevesi also said the city's economy had grown at an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the first half of the 1996 calendar year, faster than it had in the first half of any year since 1988.
Asked if Mr. Giuliani felt fortunate that the economy was rebounding just as he approached his re-election campaign, Mr. Mastro replied, "I see this as evidence that the Mayor's economic policies are working."
The city still faces serious long-term fiscal problems, mostly because expenses continue to rise faster than revenues. The Mayor's own budget analysts predict large budget gaps in the next four years that have alarmed fiscal monitors.
Mr. Mastro and Mr. Lhota emphasized that the Mayor was relying on some of the new revenues to revamp parts of the current budget that the monitors had attacked. For example, the budget had originally called for the city to earn more than $300 million from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to pay for back rent at the two city airports.
Mr. Giuliani contends that the authority has shortchanged the city over the years, and the two sides are in arbitration over the matter. The fiscal monitors had said that it was foolish for the Mayor to expect the dispute to be resolved this year, and in the proposal, he acknowledges that he will not get most of that money. Roughly speaking, in place of that $300 million in revenue from the Port Authority, the Mayor will substitute $180 million in revenues from the extra taxes and about $120 million from the savings he has ordered department heads to find. He is also planning to wipe away another risky assumption in the budget, one that calls for the city to reap $32 million from the sale of the city-owned United Nations Plaza Hotel.
These actions will affect the projected gap in the budget for the next year. It should drop from $1.7 billion to $1.2 billion, Mr. Mastro said.
"This is a plan that the bond-rating agencies and the fiscal monitors should love," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers U.S. Troops to Help Refugees in Zaire

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton gave initial approval today to the deployment of several thousand United States troops as part of a Canadian-led mission to avoid a human catastrophe and bring food and water to hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees in Zaire, where aid supplies have been cut by recent fighting.
The White House announced that if certain conditions were nailed down in the next few days, the troops would take part in a four-month long effort involving as many as 15,000 troops from a dozen nations and led by a Canadian commander with a United States officer as his deputy. 
 "The President has decided that the United States is willing, in principle, to participate in a limited fashion in this mission as long as certain conditions are stipulated to," Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said at a mid-day briefing.
The announcement cleared the way for the United Nations Security Council to work on a resolution, already drafted by Canada, to authorize the international mission, perhaps by week's end. The statement was issued after a morning phone call between Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada and a night of consultations between Canadian and American officials at the White House.
Mr. Clinton is expected to make a public statement about the Zaire deployment, as well as the role the United States plans to play in Bosnia next year, by midday Friday when he leaves for a trip to Australia and Asia, built around an Asian economic summit conference.
[In another matter related to the use of American troops abroad, NATO's Secretary General said he came away from a meeting with Vice President Al Gore with the conviction that the United States would keep some troops in Bosnia after the current mandate ends. Page A10.]
Administration officials said United States forces sent to East Africa would secure the airfield at Goma -- at the heart of relief operations in war-ravaged eastern Zaire -- as well as a three-mile corridor from Goma to the Rwandan border. The mission is intended to encourage the refugees, Hutu who fled Rwanda when a Tutsi-led Government won power in 1994, to return home.
They would also assist in the airlift of other troops to the region. American officials said that about 1,000 United States troops would be stationed in Zaire and an additional 2,000 to 3,000 troops would be based in neighboring countries like Kenya and Uganda.
Mr. Clinton's national security team has been quietly consulting with world leaders for weeks about the crisis in Zaire.
Administration officials said the caution and reserve with which the United States has approached an intervention force was not related to Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign but to a desire to avoid a repetition of the American experience in Somalia in 1993, when a similar relief mission conducted during a chaotic civil conflict drew American forces into the fighting there.
Mr. McCurry said today that under the conditions set by the United States, the international mission in eastern Zaire would be "very clearly defined" as an effort of four months' duration to enable civilian relief organizations to deliver aid to hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees who have been cut off by fighting between Zairian rebels, the Zairian Army and Rwandan Hutu militias.
He said the force would also help the voluntary return of refugees to Rwanda, using relief supplies as a magnet. In Kinshasa, Zaire's capital, the Canadian special United Nations representative, Raymond Chretien, said food and clinics would be set up in Rwanda or along the protected corridor to encourage people to head home.
But how successful such an effort would be is a major question. Hutu guerrillas living among the refugees have used propaganda and intimidation during the last two years to prevent them from returning home, and many refugees fear reprisals by the Tutsi-led Rwanda Government.
Attacks on Rwanda by Hutu guerrillas based in the huge refugee camps near the border were a factor leading to the recent eruption of fighting. But the tentative plans for an international relief mission do not appear to include steps to prevent re-establishment of such camps.
Mr. McCurry said that the international force would not disarm the militias and would not force its way into the refugee camps or police them.
He said that the force would follow "very robust rules of engagement." Defense Secretary William J. Perry said the American decision to take part in the force was contingent on securing commitments by African countries involved, principally Zaire and Rwanda, not to interfere with the mission. He said contact would also have to be made with rebel forces in the area. "Our assumption is that we would have their acquiescence and cooperation," Mr. Perry said.
The Defense Secretary said an infantry battalion and armored helicopter gunships would be sent to Zaire to insure that the American mission was protected. American forces would report to an American general who would be deputy commander of the international force serving under Lieut. Gen. Maurice Baril, a Canadian officer.
Diplomatic efforts led by Richard Begosian, a special American envoy, were under way to secure the permission of the governments in the area to allow the international force in.
"We are talking about a dangerous environment," said Glyn Davies, a State Department spokesman, "and that means that the work over the next couple of days on the ground has to be impressing upon the militias the importance of ceasing their fighting and cooperating with the international effort that's to be mounted."
But there were many signs that numerous difficulties remained. In an indication of the resistance the international forces might encounter, two teams from the Agency for International Development were turned back by Zairian rebels, Mr. Davies said.
Anthony Lake, the White House national security adviser, as well as Under Secretary of Defense Walter Slocombe and Lieut. Gen. Peter Pace, an Air Force officer who is the director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are to be sent to the United Nations on Thursday to put the final touches on the mission with the Canadians, officials said.
Mr. McCurry said the President was also awaiting word from a Pentagon assessment team in Central Africa and a diplomatic team working in the region.
The President "reserves the right to review" the final plans, Mr. McCurry said, although he affirmed that Mr. Clinton "agrees that U.S. participation in this important humanitarian mission is vital."
American officials said troops could begin flying into Zaire as early as next week. A Pentagon official said the 1,000 American troops bound for Zaire would include about 600 soldiers from the 1st Battalion, 508th Airborne Infantry Regiment, based in Vicenza, Italy. The official said that about 150 Air Force personnel would set up a refueling base at the Goma airport.
Congressional leaders expressed concern for the plight of the refugees in Zaire, but said their support for the mission hinged on the Administration setting specific goals and a specific strategy for removing American troops.
"We're just waiting to get a briefing from the White House about their goals and time line," said Lauren Sims, a spokeswoman for Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, the Speaker of the House.
Susan Irby, a spokeswoman for Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the majority leader, said Mr. Lott was taking a "wait-and-see attitude" until the questions are resolved.
But at least one influential legislator, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, raised objections to paying for the American deployment with money from the Pentagon's operations budget, the same account that pays for operations like pilot training.
"If they don't find an alternative funding source, then they'll have a lot of trouble here," said Marc Thiessen, a spokesman for Mr. Helms, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "This smells like Somalia all over again."

HEADLINE: Indian Officials Gather Evidence on Midair Collision

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: CHARKHI DADRI, India, Nov. 13

 BODY:
As scores of bereaved relatives and friends wandered through twin crash sites on the dusty Indian plain, struggling to absorb the tragedy, Indian officials today began reconstructing what caused the worst midair collision in aviation history.
Among the suspects in the collision Tuesday night, which killed all 349 people aboard a Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and a Kazak airliner, are the air-traffic controllers at Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, where the Kazak plane was headed and the Saudi plane had just left. 
 But Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda, who spent 20 minutes today walking grim faced through the charred wreckage of the Saudi plane, said that an inquiry ordered by the Government within hours of the crash would not be blunted by any cover-up of the kind detected by critics of some previous Indian air-accident inquiries.
"We will spare nobody," he said.
Kazak officials revised the number of people aboard the Kazak plane, reducing the death toll that was announced on Tuesday night by 2, to 349. The revised list also showed that three Americans, not two, were aboard the Saudi plane. At the State Department in Washington, offficials said that the names of the American victims were being withheld pending notification of their families.
The revised toll made the accident the fourth worst in aviation history, and left Indians, and all who fly into India's airports, with pressing questions about the causes of the collision and the role, if any, that was played by lapses on the part of India's air-traffic control system or the two flight crews.
A major step toward finding answers was taken this morning when recovery teams announced that they had found the flight data recorders, or so-called black boxes, from both planes, as well as the cockpit voice recorder from the Kazak aircraft. Indian aviation officials said the recoveries meant that they should be able to reconstruct everything about the flights of the two planes that could have caused the collision.
The country's top civil-aviation officials appeared to have gone at least part way to vindicating the air-traffic controllers by calling a news conference and making public a transcript of the last exchanges the controller had with the two pilots.
The transcript appeared to support a chronology given by Indian officials immediately after the crash, when they said that the controller had instructed the Saudi plane, climbing out of the airport on a flight to the Saudi cities of Dhahran and Jidda, to ascend to 14,000 feet and hold at that level, while instructing the Kazak aircraft, on its landing approach on a flight from the Kazak city of Chimkek, to descend to 15,000 feet and hold there.
Because landings and takeoffs at the New Delhi airport are made along the same flight corridor, the two planes were in effect heading toward each other on the same aerial highway, though supposedly at different altitudes.
But while the transcript showed the Saudi plane's pilot confirming that he had reached 14,000 feet and would remain there pending further instructions, and confirmed that the Kazak plane's pilot had reported reaching 15,000 feet on his descent, it did not show the Kazak pilot confirming that he would remain at 15,000 feet.
Indian and international aviation experts have listed other possible causes of the collision as the airspace restrictions around the New Delhi airport that require all civilian aircraft to fly along one corridor, and the airport's outdated radar equipment, which does not show the altitude and airspeed of aircraft on the controller's screen.
Indian officials have said that they are in the process of a $100 million upgrade of the radar systems at New Delhi and Bombay, but that the changes have run into technical problems.
As he toured the Saudi crash site, Mr. Deve Gowda seemed particularly affected by the scattered evidence of the passengers' role as breadwinners abroad. Many of those who died on the Saudi plane, including 215 Indians and 40 Nepalis, had jobs in Saudi Arabia. Although one of the bodies still lying in the wreckage when the Prime Minister arrived was that of an Indian doctor with his stethoscope still poking out of his charred jacket pocket, most of those on the plane were heading for jobs as drivers, cooks and housemaids.
"These were people going abroad for jobs," Mr. Deve Gowda said as he paused by a crater 30 feet deep and about 200 feet long that was carved out of a mustard field by the Saudi plane. Workers with face masks were poking through the smoldering debris, searching for the bodies of the 312 people aboard the plane.
In a cotton field about five miles away, beside the blackened fuselage of the Kazakstan Airlines Ilyushin-76, a similar lament was being offered for what Kazak officials, revising an earlier tally, said today were 37 passengers and crew members, almost all ethnic Russians.
A 43-year-old Russian woman who gave only her first name, Alla, wept as she spoke of her friends aboard the plane, who were headed for a week of buying in the bazaars of the Indian capital that has become a mainstay of the post-Soviet economies in the newly independent republics of Central Asia.
"It could have been me," said Alla, clutching her friend Tatyana, 42, as the two women stood gazing at torn suitcases stacked beside the mangled cockpit of the Kazak plane that had spilled out a sad jumble of underwear and toothpaste tubes and diaries recording past buying trips to Bangkok, Beijing and New Delhi. On Tuesday night, the two friends, along with 30 ethnic Russians who had bought jute bags full of sweaters and jeans and dresses for sale in the markets of Bishkek, their hometown in Kazakstan, had checked in for the Kazak plane's return flight at the New Delhi airport when they were told that the plane had crashed here about 50 miles west of the capital.
At about the same time, Raji Pk, a 33-year-old clerk in a New Delhi garment factory, was learning of the crash from the evening news bulletin on India's state television network. Only hours before, his wife, Sosamma Oommen, a 30-year-old nurse, had bade a weeping farewell to Mr. Pk and the couple's 2-year-old daughter and boarded the flight to Jidda. There, on a two-year contract at a Saudi Arabian hospital, she hoped to earn enough to allow the family to buy a house in their home state of Kerala, on India's southwest coast.
This morning, friends from the New Delhi Bible Church packed into a minibus with Mr. Pk and drove to the crash site, then to a makeshift morgue at a hospital in the regional center of Rohtak, where recovery crews had taken the bodies of about 250 of the crash victims. After an agonizing hour pulling back sheets from horribly burned and mangled corpses laid out on blocks of ice, Mr. Pk found his wife by recognizing fragments of her blouse. He collapsed into the arms of a friend.

An article yesterday about the air collision this week in India referred incorrectly to the hometown of two women who had been waiting in New Delhi to board one of the two planes involved. The city, Bishkek, is in Kyrgyzstan, not Kazakstan.

HEADLINE: FISCAL AMENDMENT WON'T BE BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton appeared to open the door to a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, his Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, slammed it shut again today, declaring that the Administration would "actively oppose" the adoption of any such amendment.
In an interview, Mr. Rubin dismissed a possibility that Mr. Clinton held out on Tuesday: that the amendment could be written with an escape hatch that "gives the country what it needs to manage a recession." Mr. Rubin said any balanced-budget amendment would be "a dangerous thing to do," because "you can't protect against the unforeseen." 
 The Treasury Secretary's remarks had apparently been cleared by the White House, which later today began echoing him.
Mr. Clinton's comments on Tuesday had been widely read as an acknowledgment of the political reality that a balanced-budget amendment was likely to be approved in 1997 by a more conservative Senate, where the measure failed by only one vote last year.
But today the President's economic team, apparently fearful that those comments would prompt Democrats who had opposed the amendment to switch their votes, began walking back Mr. Clinton's remarks. Some of them suggested that his message had been garbled in the delivery.
Mr. Rubin said that after Mr. Clinton made his public comments, the President was asked by his chief economic advisers during a meeting at the White House whether he was still opposed to a balanced-budget amendment.
"He said, 'Absolutely,' " Mr. Rubin recalled. "The bottom line is that he is opposed to a balanced-budget amendment, and remains so."
The chief White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, who later on Tuesday told reporters inquiring about Mr. Clinton's position that "you won't pin me down on this," said today that Mr. Rubin's view was also the President's.
"The President and his economic team have not dropped their opposition to a balanced-budget amendment," Mr. McCurry said. "There is no difference of view there."
He said Mr. Clinton's earlier remarks had simply been an acknowledgment that "some portions of Congress want to go ahead with this." The President himself, Mr. McCurry said, "doesn't believe they can come up with a way that doesn't threaten the economy."
Economists who argue against the balanced-budget amendment maintain that it would hamstring Congress or the executive branch in times of economic downturn, since deficit spending has customarily been a way of spurring a laggard economy.
Mr. Clinton, though, has long found it politically uncomfortable to argue that he is for balancing the budget but against a constitutional stricture that would require such balance. He stepped around the issue several times during the recent election campaign, and his chief opponent, Bob Dole, never pressed the matter during the two Presidential debates.
The President actually has no formal role in the constitutional-amendment process. He cannot veto any amendment passed by Congress, and cannot reject its subsequent ratification by the states. All he can do is use his bully pulpit to denounce a proposed amendment as bad policy, and the reason Mr. Clinton's economic aides were upset is that he declined several opportunities on Tuesday to do so forcefully.
Responding then to a question at a bill-signing ceremony, the President talked about a balanced-budget amendment in terms that left unclear whether he was truly moving away from his own opposition to it or instead was just resigned to its eventual passage in a Senate where Republicans picked up two more seats, for a total of 55, in the elections last week.
"My problems with a constitutional amendment were always more a question of how to manage the larger economic problems of the country," he said. "The nation's budget is different from a state, and I just want to make sure that if we have one, it needs to be clear in terms of how -- and it needs to really give us the possibility of dealing with a recession.
"You don't want to wind up with a Congress some day in a recession raising taxes or throwing unemployed people off health care because they're trying to get to a balanced budget. Then you could actually wind up making the deficit worse."
At another point, Mr. Clinton said, "I don't believe we need it." But then he talked at length about creating an "escape hatch" clause, and added, "If the escape hatch is good, then we'll manage it the best way we can."
Today Mr. Rubin insisted that there was no such thing as a good escape hatch.
"The problem is that you are trying to protect against everything you can see, and against the unforeseen," the Secretary said. "And you can't protect against the unforeseen. It seems to me extremely unlikely you can draft something that will give you an effective escape hatch."
Mr. McCurry said today that this was also the President's view.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
A Radical Change

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
Anyone who thought the 1996 election was a victory for centrist policies should think again. It is quickly threatening to bring on the most radical change in the structure of the United States Government since 1789: the so-called balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.
The idea of a balanced budget is venerated in this country as in no other. But enshrining it in the Constitution would be very different from talking about it in political speeches. I suspect that many advocates of the amendment do not really understand what its consequences would be. 
 The amendment does not actually require balanced budgets. It provides, rather, that except in time of war a decision to spend more than expected Federal revenue in any fiscal year must be approved by three-fifths of the whole membership of the House and Senate.
That would drastically alter the majoritarian elements of the republic designed by James Madison and the other Framers of the Constitution. Most bills before Congress require funding. So under the amendment, a minority -- one more than 40 percent of the members of either house -- could block action on nearly every piece of legislation.
But what if a deficit is forecast and Congress cannot agree on action to prevent it? Some members want to cut defense spending, some want to cut entitlements, some want to raise taxes, some want to let the budget be unbalanced -- and there are not enough votes for any course of action.
That scenario, a likely one, raises the possibility of action by other branches of government to do what the amendment commands and Congress has not accomplished: balance receipts and expenditures. The President, for example, might impound funds appropriated for this program or that, claiming that the amendment gives him power to override statutes forbidding impoundment.
The courts may get into the act, too. Assistant Attorney General Walter Dellinger, now the acting Solicitor General, testified last year that members of Congress and taxpayers might have standing to sue over the new budget process.
Robert H. Bork, the former judge, saw this prospect in a balanced budget amendment:
"The result . . . would likely be hundreds, if not thousands, of lawsuits around the country, many of them on inconsistent theories and providing inconsistent results. By the time the Supreme Court straightened the whole matter out, the budget in question would be at least four years out of date and lawsuits involving the next three fiscal years would be slowly climbing toward the Supreme Court."
Even if Congress overcame all the hurdles and approved a balanced budget, tax receipts might fall short of predictions. Presumably the amendment would then require both houses to go through the tormenting process again.
Congress, frustrated, might come to treat the amendment as merely hortatory -- like the provisions of some countries' constitutions that promise everyone adequate housing and jobs. But starting down that road would be a devastating blow to the principle that the guarantees in our Constitution are enforceable.
The substantive economic impact of a balanced budget amendment would be as dangerous as the procedural chaos it would cause. The notion that all debt is bad is, to put it mildly, out of date. The American economy, that great capitalist engine, is built on debt: consumer credit, mortgages, corporate debt. The Government, too, needs to borrow from time to time for wise purposes.
Of course Government borrowing can get out of control, as it did in the Reagan years. But we have a device to deal with that: politics. The reaction against huge deficits has been so strong that both parties are now pledged to move toward a balanced budget -- and are doing it. The country is better positioned to control the deficit today than it has been in decades.
If we have faith in reason, we must believe that more members of the House and Senate can be persuaded to oppose this flawed proposal. That is what made President Clinton's seeming abandonment of the fight so troubling. It is time to take a stand for the structure of government that over 200 years has made this country great.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Shoe Company, With 1,250 Jobs, Is Moving to White Plains

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Taking advantage of this city's glut of office space, Nine West Group Inc. is consolidating its Cincinnati and Stamford, Conn., operations and moving its headquarters here.
The move will bring 1,250 jobs to New York State, Gov. George E. Pataki said at a news conference here. The company, a leader in women's shoes, started at 9 West 57th Street in Manhattan and grew over the years into a publicly traded company with $1.3 billion in annual revenues. 
 "We've seen Swiss Re come to Westchester," Mr. Pataki said. "We've seen I.B.M. stay in Westchester. We've seen Oxford Health bring in 1,000 jobs to Westchester. But we're just extremely pleased that a company that was started in New York by New Yorkers will be coming back and growing and succeeding right here in Westchester County."
The 1,250 jobs cited by Mr. Pataki are actually Nine West's projection for 1998. Next year, the company expects to bring close to 1,000 jobs to Westchester, about 200 of which will come from Cincinnati, said Noel Hord, Nine West's president. None are manufacturing jobs, he said.
Nine West doubled in size last year when it acquired U.S. Shoe's footwear group. U.S. Shoe was based in Cincinnati, and Nine West in Stamford. The consolidated company is to occupy a glass-sheathed building on Westchester Avenue, which is to be vacated by Nynex. Nine West has signed a 25-year lease.
The company expects to begin refurbishing the 377,000-square-foot building in March and to start moving in employees in July.
Both Connecticut and New York courted Nine West. To woo the company, the Empire State Development Corporation offered it more than $1.6 million in grants. Also, the state will waive $1.2 million in sales taxes that Nine West would otherwise pay for goods and services it buys.
Governor Pataki said, "We are winning these fights, not all of them, but we are winning more than our fair share because we're in there competing and working hard every day to match incentives, lower taxes and lower worker's comp rates."
But regional economic experts and Mr. Hord said that what ultimately sold Nine West on New York was the availability of the Nynex building, which would allow the company to save money by not having to construct a new building in Fairfield County. "Both states in the last several months worked very aggressively to keep us in Connecticut and to attract us to New York," Mr. Hord said. "It came down to the difference between constructing a new building and signing a long-term lease."
Michael Siegel, executive director of the Edward S. Gordon Company, a real estate brokerage concern with offices in New York and Connecticut, said: "Nine West wanted to relocate to a space in excess of 300,000 square feet. There's is a scarcity of space of that size in lower Fairfield County."
About 24 percent of the office space in in Westchester County is vacant, according to the Rostenberg-Doren Company, a corporate real estate company.

HEADLINE: The Election Changes Little; Business Can Live With That

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
In the days since the election, business leaders have concluded that the results amount to nothing much -- and are quite pleased by the prospect.
Encouraged by what seems a friendlier White House but skeptical about the chances for sweeping changes, American business is focusing on a push for modest victories on Capitol Hill next year. 
 Although the Senate may be a bit more conservative because of the way the Republicans solidified their majority, the House is likely to move toward the center. And, since the Government was almost closed by the budget stalemate and the fervor over the Contract With America has deflated, lobbyists and corporate spokesmen see a mood that is unfriendly to grand solutions.
"We think this will be a Congress of bipartisan, incremental legislation," said Donald A. Danner, a vice president of the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business powerhouse that played a big role in defeating President Clinton's ambitious health care initiative. Only joint effort by both parties can produce results, he said, citing the flurry of bills passed toward the end of the 1996 session. Cooperation probably still cannnot be mustered for such wholesale changes, he said.
The federation, in a post-election booklet, called on its 600,000 members to support a five-item agenda: making health care available and affordable to small businesses, cutting and simplifying taxes, easing regulation, balancing the budget and ending "legal nightmares."
Indeed, the business community is hearing some unusually welcome words, now that the Administration is pledged to balance the budget -- even going so far as to soften its opposition to doing so by constitutional amendment -- and has supported a cut in the capital gains tax for home sellers.
Noting the increased number of centrists in the next House, Barry K. Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, observed, "I think this can be good for moving the ball."
R. Bruce Josten, senior vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, which represents companies of all sizes, took a similar view, even as he declared that the chamber's first priority "has been and remains overwhelmingly" a balancing of the Federal budget and what the chamber regards as the necessary accompaniment, reform of entitlement programs like Social Security.
"Incrementalism is probably the order of the day," Mr. Josten said. A principal strategist in business's campaign to counter organized labor's stepped-up political efforts of this year, he specifically cited the issue of regulatory overhaul, which is of central concern to business. "The omnibus approach to that is probably not legislatively salable," he said.
Perhaps slightly more ambitious is Mr. Rogstad's group, the American Business Conference, which comprises rapidly growing medium-size companies. Mr. Rogstad described the national economic agenda as "almost a blank slate." He said he doubted that pledges of budget balance and studies of ways to overhaul Social Security and other entitlement programs would soon reach fruition. He contended, for example, that entitlement issues such as the privatization of Social Security were so intertwined with the tax system that attempts to overhaul either would quickly fail.
"The current wisdom is that the best thing we'll see is tinkering at the margin," Mr. Rogstad said. He said his own agenda involved a "focus on the core stuff," such as creating greater protection from product liability suits and expanding trade agreements to include Central and South America.
The biggest companies are especially interested in environmental and other regulation and in trade, as well as issues related to their own industry. The tobacco industry, for example, may go to Congress to fight new regulations against selling cigarettes to children, while the oil industry wants the Government to ease restrictions on where it can drill.
Business leaders seem of a single mind, however, in praising Mr. Clinton's appointment of Erskine B. Bowles to succeed Leon E. Panetta as White House chief of staff.
Among the most enthusiastic was Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, who issued a news release to say: "The President has selected a small-business owner, one who has personally signed the front of a paycheck and who knows what it takes to run a small business." In addition, Mr. Josten added that Mr. Panetta, a former member of Congress, had been a formidable opponent for Republicans there, and that his departure would be "a major loss" for White House strategists.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Lower-priced co-ops sell again in once-troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan.

BYLINE: By Rachelle Garbarine 

 BODY:
BELIEVING that the market for affordably priced cooperatives in New York City boroughs outside of Manhattan is beginning to improve, some developers who have taken over troubled buildings are selling apartments again.
Indicative of this willingness to return to the market are the activities of three separate development groups that have worked out the financial problems at six different buildings, with nearly 600 apartments, in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Over the next year they will put on the market some 150 residences -- studios to three-bedroom apartments -- under $100,000 and often with financing in place for buyers. 
 Sales of such co-ops are being nudged along by several factors, brokers said. The housing market in general and Manhattan's in particular are improving, they said, while rents are rising and mortgage interest rates are stable.
For the last two and a half years, large co-ops in neighborhoods nearer to Manhattan, like Park Slope in Brooklyn, have been selling well, said Christopher D. Thomas, vice president at the Brooklyn offices of William B. May, a Manhattan-based real estate firm. In the last six months, the activity has spread to smaller apartments and into neighborhoods farther away, he added.
Mr. Thomas said people would buy if the monthly cost to own was comparable to the cost of renting. "Prices may change from neighborhood to neighborhood, but the dynamics of the decision stay the same," he said.
Gerald S. Migdol, executive vice president of the GFI Management Services division of the GFI Capital Resources Group, a Manhattan-based real estate company, said that prices for low-end co-ops in boroughs outside of Manhattan had fallen by as much as than 50 percent since the market's downturn in 1990, but have now stabilized. Co-ops at the low end of the market sell on average for $25,000 for a studio to $75,000 for a three-bedroom apartment, Mr. Migdol said. His firm has sponsored or taken over sponsor positions at 25 co-ops with 2,000 apartments throughout the city.
The market is viable if apartments are realistically priced and share loans are offered to purchasers, he said.
The latter is especially important if the percentage of apartments sold in the building is fewer than what lending institutions now require. Frequently, lenders stipulate that 50 percent of a building's apartments be sold before they will grant such loans, and some banks prefer a high level of owner-occupancy.
Sales are under way at 3311 Shore Parkway, a 96-apartment co-op in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn. The building was converted in the late 1980's and sold 40 apartments before the market collapsed. Last year the JMJ Realty Company -- a Bronx-based real estate firm -- bought the building's underlying mortgage. And in a negotigated settlement with the co-op corporation, which was on the brink of foreclosure, it restructured the loan and took over the 56 unsold studios-to-two-bedroom apartments.
In the three months since sales started, 13 of the 17 vacant apartments, which were renovated at an average cost of $6,000, have been sold or are under contract to be sold for $23,000 to $45,000, said Joseph Yasgur, a principal at JMJ.
"We saw an opportunity that the building, once stabilized, could be a viable co-op," he said, adding that the 39 rented apartments would be put on the market as they become available.
Soon GFI will begin sales at 50 Lefferts Avenue, a 95-apartment co-op in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Sales halted in 1989 after 15 of the apartments, studios to two-bedroom residences, were sold.
GFI took over the 80 unsold apartments six months ago as part of a negotiated settlement with the co-op corporation. The settlement included buying the underlying mortgage and revising it, which kept the co-op out of foreclosure.
To start, the 15 vacant apartments will be renovated at an average cost of $4,000, and sold for $25,000 to $45,000; or rented for $650 to $750 a month with an option to buy at the end of the one-year lease, said Allen I. Gross, GFI's president. He said that in the next few months his company would also offer tenants leasing the 65 other unsold apartments -- 25 of the leases expire this summer -- a chance to buy at discounted prices. And because renters outnumber owners at the building, share loans will be offered to buyers, he said, adding that "the key is to keep the apartments affordable."
The company is planning the same program at 700 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn, where 25 of the 66 apartments, with one and two bedrooms, will be on sale by this summer.
By early next year Pelham Realty Associates, based in Manhattan, plans to begin sales at four buildings, together totaling 305 one- to three-bedroom apartments on Kruger and Holland Avenues in the Pelham Parkway area of the Bronx. The company took control of the 240 unsold apartments one and a half years ago when it bought and refinanced the underlying mortgages on the four buildings, averting a foreclosure.
The 135 vacant, unsold, unregulated apartments have been renovated and leased over the last year for $650 to $1,000, said Leonard H. Krim, a principal of Pelham Realty and a Manhattan lawyer. The way to fully restore the building "is for us to sell our units," he said, adding that financing will be offered to buyers.
He said the apartments would be sold to tenants first and then to outsiders. Prices for the apartments, though not set, will be "considerably less" than the $56,000 to $80,000 they originally sold for, Mr. Krim said.

HEADLINE: Bosnia Foes Told to Make Peace in 2 Years or Lose Economic Aid

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The United States and the European countries overseeing the still-fragile peace in Bosnia gave formal notice today to leaders of all three of the war-ravaged country's ethnic groups that economic aid would end two years from now at the latest if peace has not taken hold completely by then.
The three parties reached a new agreement today to carry out the requirements of the peace plan signed in Paris 11 months ago. The agreement drew up guidelines for strengthening democratic institutions, a market economy, and the rule of law over the next two years. 
 Fresh from the most serious military clash this year between Bosnian Serbs and Muslims who were trying to return to their former homes in northeast Bosnia, the country's top elected leaders pledge to allow refugees to return to their homes and carry out the rest of the peace agreement. But doing one thing on the ground while promising in the diplomatic salons of Europe to do something else entirely has been standard procedure in Bosnia since war broke out.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said that the United Nations Security Council could impose economic sanctions against Bosnia if it did not carry out the agreement.
International diplomatic leverage may also be growing weaker along with the outside military presence. Despite considerable diplomatic pressure from Mr. Christopher, for example, the three elected Bosnian leaders could not even come to agreement here on naming a Council of Ministers, though after their own election two months ago they said they would put a Government in place by Nov. 1.
The future of international involvement in Bosnia was on the table in Washington tonight when Mr. Clinton's top foreign-policy officials met to discuss options. Mr. Clinton is expected to announce his decision on American participation in a follow-on force on Friday morning, before he leaves for vacation.
The White House Press Secretary, Michael McCurry, said today that Mr. Clinton had made no decision, but "we've said all along that we would be looking at ways of preserving the gains in Bosnia."
The NATO Secretary General, Javier Solana, told a news conference in Washington today that he confidently expected Mr. Clinton to agree to provide 7,000 to 8,000 troops to a follow-on force of up to 30,000, which would include troops from France, Britain, Germany and Russia.
In Washington, the official consensus was growing around a two-phased plan for the new force, an Administration official said today. The first phase would put a total of 25,000 and 30,000 troops into Bosnia -- including possibly 8,000 Americans -- for another year to deter any new outbreak of fighting and to help insure freedom of movement among civilians, resettle refugees, back up the police and support elections.
After the much-delayed municipal elections, now expected by July, many of those troops could leave Bosnia. Some soldiers could return home; others could be stationed "over the horizon," outside Bosnia, as a rapid-reaction force should major fighting recur. European and American officials gathered here said that there was little likelihood that a new NATO peacekeeping force would have a mandate to go after those indicted by the war-crimes tribunal.
Past practice for Bosnian Serbs, and to some extent for Bosnian Croats, was simply to disregard obligations to cooperate with the tribunal and comply with its orders, as the peace accords specified. The tribunal has indicted 78 people so far, most of them Serbs.
"We're trying to building something which is sustainable," a senior American official said. "We've always argued that while dealing with war crimes and criminals is very important, that does not mean that major military actions to get one or two people will solve the problem -- it could just create new problems."

HEADLINE: '95 Hondas Recalled For Air-Bag Defect

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The American Honda Motor Company said today that it was recalling nearly half of the 1995 Accords sold in the United States because of complaints that air bags in some of the cars deployed unexpectedly.
The voluntary recall of 164,139 Accords came after an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Car owners will be notified by mail and offered free replacements. 
 The safety agency had announced in March that it was investigating 17 complaints of dual air bags unexpectedly deploying in 1995 Accords because of the faulty control device.
No serious injuries have been reported, but the inflation of an air bag can bruise the hands, arms and face, or cause more serious injury if a driver or passenger is not seated properly.
Eight Accord owners said air bags deployed while the car was moving, even though they had not struck anything. One driver said his air bag inflated after he struck a parking lot sign while traveling at 5 miles an hour. Five drivers complained that the air bags deployed after a minor incident, like a flat tire or striking a small animal.
A Honda spokesman, Art Garner in Torrance, Calif., said Honda sold 341,384 of the 1995 Accords in the United States. The defective device was made by Denshi Gaiken, a Japanese supplier, he said.
