HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Move Higher On New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday after three Government reports indicated continued subdued economic growth and little inflation. The reports appeared to validate the Federal Reserve's decision on Wednesday to leave interest rates unchanged.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 yesterday, to 1013/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.42 percent, from 6.45 on Wednesday. 
 Traders said the market was aided by short-covering, in which investors who had sold borrowed securities, betting on a price drop, were forced to buy back bonds to cut their losses. These investors apparently expected that the reports would show signs of stronger growth or inflation, which alarms the bond market.
"Technicals are in place for a further rally," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston. "And the immediate upside target for the bond yield is about 6.35 percent.
"I wouldn't be surprised if that move toward the target unfolds quickly by the end of the month," she said, adding that the long-term outlook for the market was strong, too.
In its reports, the Government said the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of a percent in October, while the core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy prices, was a smaller-than-expected two-tenths of a percent. And retail sales increased two-tenths of a percent last month, while the weekly number of first-time jobless claims dropped by 4,000 to a seasonally adjusted 328,000 last week.
Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said the Consumer Price Index was in line with expectations, while the small increase in retail sales might have signaled little pickup after a third-quarter slowdown in economic growth. Market expectations were for a gain of four-tenths of a percent in retail sales and a rise of 5,000 in the jobless claims.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that unlike the Producer Price Index, which was reported on Wednesday and showed a big increase in energy prices, the consumer index conformed to market expectations in all respects.
"But market focus was centered more on the retail sales statistics, as retail spending is more of a current indicator and can provide clues as to future consumer price inflation," he said. In addition, the retail sales figure is considerably more volatile than the consumer index on a month-to-month basis, which results in a lower level of confidence in market forecasts and a greater probability of market surprises.
"Retail sales in October rose slightly less than expected, with modest upward revisions to both August and September," Mr. Fine said. Still, he added, the October sales figure was stronger than the third-quarter average, indicating a fourth-quarter lift in consumption patterns, though not big enough to reignite inflation fears.
In when-issued trading, the soon-to-be-auctioned two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.63 percent, while the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.93 percent, down four- and five-hundredths of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
It's Time For Redskins To Exit

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
SPORTS teams in America, and environs, insist on nicknames, for some reason. This has been going on for a hundred years. Most of the nicknames are so dumb they are beyond the pale of rational discussion. Why, for example, anyone would want to go around calling himself a Raptor, or a Net, or a Heat -- or, for that matter, a Blue Devil or a White Sock or, in the case of the Scottsdale (Ariz.) Community College athletes, an Artichoke -- ought to be fodder only for a psychiatrist's couch.
But some nicknames have taken on a different hue in modern times, and have come to offend people, and not just those who have a soft spot in their heart for a Raptor, et al. They are the nicknames associated with American Indians. 
 I received in the mail the other day a "Message to Miamians," from the president of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. President James C. Garland wrote a letter to alumni, of which I am one, saying that the Miami Board of Trustees had agreed to seek a new nickname for its sports teams, that the name, the Redskins, was inappropriate for use by an institution of higher learning.
This has been years in coming, since many people associated with the university were dead set against change. Some said it was part of school tradition to retain that name, others said the university had more pressing issues to deal with. Others added that Redskins was a name that held in high esteem the Miami Indian tribe that once lived in the region, for which the university was named. The Miami tribe, which now lives in Oklahoma, sent a formal letter to the university seeking the change, and the university, to its credit, is honoring it.
But other schools with tribal references have already changed. Stanford, for one, went from the Indians to the Cardinal, and Marquette from the Warriors to the Golden Eagles.
Professional teams like the Washington Redskins, the Atlanta Braves, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Cleveland Indians have resisted name alterations, even though there have been numerous protests by various groups over the years. The political and economic clout of these tribes has been underwhelming, and the fans still come to the game in feathers and war paint, carrying rubber tomahawks, with their mindless chopping and chanting, much to the delight of the owners of these organizations.
A few years ago, St. John's University changed the nickname of its athletic teams from the Redmen to the Red Storm.
"Sure, some people hated the change, but some people hate any kind of change," said Lou Carnesecca, the former St. John's basketball coach. "But it wasn't our posture to offend anybody, even if it's one person. And I know we did.
"I once got a call from an athletic director of an Oregon high school which was on an Indian reservation. He told me, 'Coach, I love to see your team play, but it makes me very uncomfortable to see the mascots go around scalping people, and that kind of thing.'
"And I thought, 'What kind of message are we sending, and this being a university?' Few people seem to care anymore that the name has been changed."
Miami is now seeking suggestions for a new athletic nickname. Some of the several hundred entries by alumni that have been sent to Dr. Phillip R. Shriver, head of this search committee, have sought to maintain the "red" and the "skin" appellations. Thus the Red Bricks, the Red-Skinned Potatoes and, inevitably, the Sun Burns. Someone suggested Feather Heads, which seems unbookish, while Climbing Ivies seems unsportsy.
One that probably stands little chance of acceptance is Miami Vice.
Most school and professional nicknames reflect the animal kingdom, from Horned Frogs and Mighty Ducks to Tigers, Lions and even Anteaters (California-Irvine), but where are those college names with learning aspirations, such as the Intellectuals or the Literati or the Bibliophiles?
Nor do current nicknames reflect what these sporting groups are supposed to be all about. Badgers, Hoosiers, Avalanche. They make absolutely no sense. I considered sending this entry to Dr. Shriver: the Miami Nothings. But some feelings in Oxford might be hurt. So I've settled on a name simple but resonant, a name strong with purpose and studious vigor, a name unique in the annals of sports nicknames. I propose: the Miami Team.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Against Mark, But at Another Low vs. Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a new four-year low against the pound but rallied to end mostly higher yesterday after the head of Germany's central bank said he hoped that the United States currency would strengthen.
The remarks by the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, were the second this week calling for a higher dollar. They were regarded as the clearest indication yet that economic policy makers in Germany were worried over the recent strength of the mark, which could threaten economic recovery there. 
 Mr. Tietmeyer, asked by foreign journalists in Bonn whether he would like a stronger dollar, replied, "I wouldn't be unhappy if it went a little further."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar traded at 1.5089 marks, up from 1.5075 on Wednesday. It also finished higher against the Swiss franc, French franc and Italian lira. But the dollar ended lower against the Japanese yen at 111.22 yen, down from 111.79 yen.
The pound rose to $1.6625, from $1.6525 late Wednesday, the highest level since October 1992. Sterling surged for the second day after the British Government reported that the underlying inflation rate was 3.3 percent in October, well above expectations. The report reinforced a view that the Government of Prime Minister John Major would soon have to raise interest rates again to reduce inflationary pressure.
The dollar has strengthened against the mark for much of the year and has helped German exporters compete more effectively by lowering the cost of German-made goods sold abroad. But on Monday, the dollar fell below 1.50 marks for the first time in more than a month.
It weakened against the yen on a report in The Journal of Commerce that C. Fred Bergsten, an influential economist and former Treasury Department official known for advocating a weaker dollar, might be tapped by President Clinton as the new Commerce Secretary or United States trade representative.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Wednesday, included 1.2754 Swiss francs, up from 1.2711; 5.0995 French francs, up from 5.0930, and 1,516.50 Italian lire, up from 1,515.00. The Canadian dollar eased to 74.84 cents, from 74.99 cents on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Making Good From Alaska's Native Riches;
Indigenous People Are Creating A Far-Reaching Capital Base

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

DATELINE: NOME, Alaska

 BODY:
One day before he was scheduled to fly 3,000 miles from Washington to close a deal with a native Alaskan company called the Arctic Slope Regional Corporation, Andrew Kho, a banker, was told to hold off his trip. Jacob Adams, Arctic Slope's boss, was out whaling in the icy seas off Alaska's northern coast.
"Jake had forgotten his cellular phone and couldn't be reached," said Mr. Kho, a vice president with the National Cooperative Bank. "This turned out to be a pretty comical event. I would call every couple of days, and the folks at Arctic Slope would respond that Jake was still out whaling." It would be three weeks before he finally flew to Portland, Ore., to approve a $15 million loan for Arctic Slope to buy a maker of plastics parts for high-tech companies. 
 The episode did more than just expose a cultural divide between the button-down American banking establishment and the rough-and-tumble Alaskan frontier. It also highlighted a quandary that Alaska's 87,000 natives have been wrestling with for 25 years: How does a geographically isolated group, with a heritage of living off the land and sea, figure out the smartest way to invest a multibillion-dollar windfall?
In 1971, the Federal Government ceded $962 million in cash and 44 million acres of Alaskan land, including mineral and timber rights, to the state's native inhabitants to help integrate them into the modern economy. The spoils were spread around 12 regional corporations like Arctic Slope and 220 much smaller village companies, which ever since have paid out a portion of their earnings as annual dividends to their stockholders.
The money has been a godsend for some natives in small villages, who are as likely as not to be in shacks without plumbing. But for the village leaders in charge of the companies, managing the wealth has been an unending ordeal. They have had to learn the ins and outs of modern investing, mastering concepts like poison pills and derivatives. They have had to coax reluctant boards into taking investment risks. And they have had to weigh their responsibility to make their portfolios grow against the need to spend much of their profits on social welfare and against the clamor of their constituents for more cash.
Now, though, their efforts finally seem to be paying off. While they have made missteps, the native corporations are diversifying their portfolios as never before. Many are moving aggressively to profit from the stock market boom. Some are buying major stakes in American corporations, or even starting their own ventures in the Lower 48 states.
The investment record of the Sitnasuak Native Corporation, which represents the 2,400 native Alaskan residents of this Bering Sea hamlet, is a striking example of the progress. You cannot travel from one end to the other of Front Street, Nome's main thoroughfare, without putting a nickel in its coffers. The Sitnasuaks (pronounced SIT-nah-socks) control virtually all the prime businesses, from the supermarket and the Napa auto parts store to the heating and rental-car companies, and own seven apartment buildings.
But like the bosses of more conventional companies, Robbie Fagerstrom, the company's chief executive, is under pressure to increase the return on his shareholders' assets. Mr. Fagerstrom avoided trouble by leading his balky directors into the stock market, amassing a $13 million stock and bond portfolio that last year generated 20 percent of the company's operating profit.
"We wanted part of our assets to bring in a steady income regardless of what was happening with our businesses here," said the 49-year-old Mr. Fagerstrom, who grew up in Nome and whose training for the chief executive's post included running his own janitorial business. Now, he says, he wants to move from passive ownership of stocks to active control of businesses in the Lower 48. "If we could get into building construction or rental management, it would make us less dependent on our local economy," he said.
Yet, the Sitnasuaks would have missed out on the current bull market had it not been for Mr. Fagerstrom's determination to beat down his directors' resistance to opening a stock portfolio. Because they complained they could not fathom Wall Street lingo, he talked them into taking a course on reading financial reports. Then he waited three years as analysts from the Dean Witter Reynolds Anchorage office molded their class lectures into the right mix of the Harvard Business School and Field & Stream magazine.
"You have to put it in terms they can understand," Keith Rivera, senior vice president with Dean Witter Reynolds in Anchorage, said of his clients. "For example, if they were to go out and experience bad storms while fishing, they wouldn't always turn around and go back. They stick it out."
Today, the Sitnasuaks' portfolio consists mostly of brand names, with AT&T, Procter & Gamble, Eastman Kodak and Hewlett Packard topping the list. Their directors, who remain very conservative, not only continue to take investment classes, they alsofeel confident enough to help Mr. Rivera with an occasional stock suggestion. Through the end of September, their stock picks were up 21.8 percent for the year.
"Over the next few years, we really hope to increase the amount of money we have in the market," Mr. Fagerstrom said. "It's crucial that it generate a steady income for us."
Other native Alaskan companies are also spreading their investments "Outside" -- local lingo for the 48 contiguous states. Among them are these examples:
*Cook Inlet Region Inc., based on Alaska's southern central coast, recently formed a joint venture with BellSouth of Atlanta to peddle cellular phones and pagers in the Carolinas. CIRI also acquired and later sold majority positions in network television affiliates in Hartford and Nashville, and it plans to buy several Southwestern resort properties and a manufacturing company in Washington later this year. More than half of the company's $56.65 million in operating earnings last year came from its broadcasting and communications holdings in the Lower 48. By contrast, it earned just $2.55 million, after distributions, from oil and gas production and mining.
*Sealaska, a timber-rich native corporation in Alaska's southeastern tip, plans to buy three manufacturing companies in the Lower 48 this year to position itself as a parts supplier to I.B.M. and Motorola Inc. It also has $100 million in cash earmarked for additional acquisitions.
*The Nana Regional Corporation, whose shareholders are primarily whale and seal hunters along the north Bering Sea, signed up with Marriott International Inc. last year to provide housekeeping and food services to Marriott hotels in Alaska and, potentially, in other states. The contract yielded $951,000 in profits last year, almost half the company's total. "The partnership is generating a lot of cash," Shelby Stassy, Nana Regional's vice president for finance, said.
Alaska's native corporations are using several strategies in their heady migration south. The largest hire investment firms to seek out potential acquisitions. CIRI has five full-time executives who only peruse listings of resort properties for sale. Leo Barlow, the chief executive of Sealaska, recently began surfing the Internet for possible deals. But the most common way has been to set up a minority contracting company eligible for jobs set aside by the Government for economically disadvantaged ethnic groups.
Most of the contracts involve grueling work, from sweeping out military bases to refueling jet fighters, but the pay is good. Chugach Alaska, a regional corporation near Prince William Sound, went bankrupt in 1991 but bounded back by landing $300 million in minority contracts with the Army. "It's been absolutely amazing how we were able to turn ourselves around," Michael Brown, Chugach Alaska's chief executive, said. "The key is that we diversified out of Alaska to stretch from Washington to Honolulu."
To be sure, some investments have misfired. The Bristol Bay Native Corporation, based along Alaska's southwestern coast, snapped up a 10 percent share in the United Bank of Alaska in the late 1970's. But hammered by bad real estate loans, the bank collapsed in 1986, leaving Bristol Bay with a $2 million loss.
And many companies continue to be plagued by the inexperience of their managers, many of whom have never worked in companies with more than 30 employees. When the Aleut and Nana corporations started a minority contracting subsidiary last year in Charlotte, N.C., for example, they could not find any of their colleagues to accept a top management position at the new venture. The job remains unfilled.
And the Aleut Corporation, hobbled by its board's timidity, allocated only half of its $3.7 million portfolio last year to stocks, with the rest tied up in Treasury and municipal bonds. The portfolio eked out an anemic 7.8 percent gain for the fiscal year ended March, compared with 29 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The Aleuts have since raised their stock holdings in hopes of notching a higher return.
"At a native corporation, any sort of decision -- including investing -- requires an awful lot of hand holding," said Dean Parisian, president of Native American Advisors Inc., a money-management firm in Alpharetta, Ga., which advises Indians and Alaska natives. "Very few of them have college degrees. Most don't know the difference between a preferred stock and livestock," neither of which figures much in life in the icy north, he adds. "That takes some time to overcome."
Native corporations also face pressure from shareholders to deliver quick cash hits rather than long-term growth. When CIRI's lines of businesses performed exceptionally well last year, shareholders were quick to ask for a greater dividend. CIRI obliged, shelling out $63 million. Stockholders who owned 100 shares, the typical amount, received $10,112.
Further draining profits, companies spend huge amounts on social programs like scholarships and alcohol rehabilitation. Even in bad years, many native Alaskans demand their dividend checks. Especially for those who live in remote villages and get most of their food from hunting and fishing, the money can make the difference between near squalor and reasonable comfort.
"We can live without the dividends," said Percy Nayokpuk, who sells ivory necklaces to tourists in the coastal village of Shishmaref, near the Arctic Circle. "But that extra money makes a tremendous difference in what you can do to improve your house or buy clothes for your children."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Russians Are Coming, to Big Board Trading

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
A piece of the new Russia goes on sale today on the New York Stock Exchange. Russia's leading cellular telephone company, Vimpel-Communications A.O., is set for a roughly $90 million initial public offering as the first Russian company to be listed on the Big Board. When trading begins, investors will be able to buy part of a young company run by former Soviet military scientists who, according to the prospectus, have been making money hand over cellular handset.
Vimpelcom, as the company is known, is also a case study of leveraging political connections into cash in the Wild West business atmosphere of today's Russia. 
 "It's a very strong company," said Alexander Kabanovsky, an analyst at Pyramid Research in Cambridge, Mass., which tracks emerging wireless-telephone markets. "They are one of the military companies that has done a very good job of retooling itself for the new market economy."
Underwritten by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and RC Securities, the Vimpelcom offering involves 5.24 million American depository receipts that represent 3.93 million shares of common stock, or 0.75 share each. That amounts to about 20 percent of Vimpelcom common stock and would value the entire company at roughly $450 million.
That may be a puny figure by the standards of next week's Deutsche Telekom offering, which is expected to raise about $12 billion. But Vimpelcom reports profit margins on a scale that a company of any size might be happy with.
Last year the company posted a profit of $27.6 million, or $1.58 a share, on revenue of $100.9 million, up from 1994 profit of $9.5 million, or 58 cents a share, on revenue of $28 million. For the first six months, it reported $18.8 million in net income on revenue of $84.4 million.
"On the very short term, I think investors will be interested in the stock," Dirk M. Bout, a European telecommunications analyst for Northern Business Information in London, said of the Vimpelcom A.D.R.'s. "After that the market will realize it's dealing with a very high-risk stock."
Vimpelcom has won 59 percent market share from its two competitors in Moscow, the locus for most of its business. Vimplecom's 45,000 Moscow customers, mostly professionals and high rollers frustrated by Russia's antiquated land-line telecommunications networks, spend an average of $374 a month on cellular service -- nearly seven times the average monthly cellular bill in the United States.
But if Vimpelcom sounds like a veritable ruble machine, consider that the same inside connections that helped Vimpelcom assume its market dominance could someday prove a liability.
"We're telling our clients that this is a deal where there is a tremendous amount of risk," said Linda Killian, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, a research firm on initial public offerings in Greenwich, Conn. "If these people fall out of favor, or if there's a new government that is less market-oriented, that would negatively affect a lot of business operations."
Vimpelcom will not only be the first Russian company to trade on the Big Board; it will also be a company that trades only in the United States. There are no plans to list the shares in Moscow. (Gazprom and Lukoil, two big Russian energy companies, have American depository receipts, but those do not trade on any American exchanges.)
Vimpelcom was founded in 1992 as a subsidiary of the Vimpel Corporation, a military contractor. Its president and chief executive, Dmitri B. Zimin, and several other senior executives were until a few years ago officials at a Vimpel-controlled research institute that developed advanced radio systems and missile defenses for the old Soviet Union.
In late 1992 and early 1993, one Vimpelcom director, Konstantin S. Kuzovoy, served simultaneously as Vimpelcom's executive vice president and head of military conversion programs at Vimpel. Other directors include a former Russian prime minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, and Oleg G. Belov, the general director of Rostelekom, Russia's government-controlled long-distance giant.
Given such connections, few were surprised when Vimpelcom ended up with almost twice as much cellular-network radio spectrum as each of its competitors.
"The people running that company have very close connections to the Russian establishment," said Frank Miller, chairman of Moscow-based BSD International, which owns four research-and-development companies in Russia. "That, in the long run, gives them an advantage over people who don't."
And perhaps in the short run, as well. After the generous cellular license was issued to a joint venture of Vimpelcom and the Government-owned Moscow-region telephone authority, in 1993, Vimpelcom bought all but 5 percent of the venture -- and control of the license -- for the modest sum of $36,000.
To complement its conventional cellular network, Vimpelcom is building an alternative wireless network for personal communications services, or P.C.S. -- technology similar to the new systems going into operation in this country. Last month, Vimplecom acquired the P.C.S. licensee, KB Impuls, which received its license, free, from the Russian communications ministry in mid-1995.
It is difficult to escape the impression that Vimpelcom has profited greatly from its close association with Russian officialdom. But what are the officials getting in return?
Immediately following the initial public offering, Vimpelcom is obligated to issue an additional 2.26 million shares of preferred stock to "entities controlled by Dr. Zimin," according to the preliminary prospectus. This will allow the Vimpelcom chief executive to effectively control almost 59 percent of Vimpelcom's voting stock.
The prospectus only parenthetically discloses that both Vimpel, the military contractor, and Sistema, a holding company widely believed to have ties to the Moscow government, are Vimpelcom shareholders. The prospectus leaves the current ownership of about 10 percent of Vimpelcom unaccounted for.
"Who really owns what there is not so easy to figure out," Mr. Miller said. "Legal form is less important that personal relationships."
Which makes the company's ticker symbol particularly apt: VIP.

HEADLINE: Stocks Set Records, With Dow Over 6,300

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose to records yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average past 6,300, as inflation and retail sales reports bolstered investors' perception of a low-inflation economy. Computer shares led the advance.
"The inflation picture looks good, and there is a feeling the economy is in reasonable shape," said Dirk van Dijk, chief equity strategist at C. H. Dean & Associates. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.76 points, to 6,313.00, led by Philip Morris Companies, I.B.M. and Allied Signal Inc. It was the Dow's seventh consecutive record high and first close above 6,300. The index closed above 6,200 and 6,100 for the first time last week.
Stocks benefited from a drop in bond yields to eight-month lows after a smaller-than-expected increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in October retail sales cast doubt that the holidays would bring a rebound in the economy. The report, together with others showing tame inflation, signaled to investors that the Federal Reserve was no longer under pressure to raise interest rates to keep the economy from overheating.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 4.75, to 735.88, its 34th record of the year. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 9.64, to a record 1,270.36, led by the Microsoft Corporation and the Oracle Corporation.
"The fundamentals are still in place, and this morning's reports reinforced the slow growth picture that the market likes," said John Niedenberger, money manager at Advanced Investment Management, with $3.5 billion in assets.
Computer-related shares led the rally amid optimism that earnings would be better than expected.
I.B.M. gained 2 1/8, to 136 7/8; the Microsoft Corporation surged 4 5/8, to 149 5/8; Advanced Micro Devices Inc. jumped 3 1/8, to 24 3/4, and Oracle jumped 1 7/8, to 47 3/8. The Digital Equipment Corporation rose 2 1/8, to 33 3/8, after its chairman said he believed the company could exceed analysts' earnings estimates for the fiscal year ending in June.
Bank shares rallied, spurred by bond yields, which fell after the economic reports. Bank profits are closely tied to interest rates as lower rates mean wider profit margins.
Citicorp rose 2 1/8, to an all-time high of 104 1/8; BankAmerica Corporation rose 2 3/4, to 96; Chase Manhattan Corporation gained 2 to 88 3/4, and First Chicago NBD Corporation rose 1 1/4, to 55 1/8. Shares and options of GTE Corporation, the biggest local phone company in the United States, soared amid speculation that the company could announce a merger or alliance in coming days. Traders said AT&T Corporation could be a possible partner or buyer.
GTE shares rose 1, to 43 3/4, in trading of 1.69 million shares, beating its three-month average daily volume of 1.47 million.
Lands' End Inc. shares rose 2 1/4, to 24 7/8, after the retailer said third-quarter earnings rose to 19 cents a share from 5 cents a year earlier. Analysts expected it to earn 10 cents.
Du Pont Company fell 61/64 to 92, after saying it would invest $750 million in its nylon business while eliminating 15 percent of the unit's 19,000 jobs. Nokia Oy led an advance in cellular phone shares. The Finnish phone maker's American depository receipts soared 7 1/4, to 58 1/4, after the company said third-quarter pretax profit rose 14 percent, its first quarterly rise this year, as it recovered from cost and inventory problems. Motorola Inc., gained 2 5/8, to 54 1/2, while A.D.R.'s of Swedish rival LM Ericsson rose 1 7/8, to 31 1/2.

HEADLINE: Mayor Details Plan for Fiscal Windfall

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formally presented a plan yesterday for using an unexpected $450 million windfall in tax revenues, drawing praise from some independent budget analysts and attacks from his Democratic rivals, who asserted that new spending would not make up for his earlier cuts.
After nearly three years of unrelentingly gloomy news about the city's finances, Mr. Giuliani for the first time benefited from a modest upturn in the local economy as he issued adjustments to the $33 billion budget for the fiscal year that began on July 1. 
 Most of the new tax revenues result from surging earnings on Wall Street. They have bolstered the city's growth rate, though it still is not as strong as that of the nation.
With the mayoral election a year away, Mr. Giuliani moved quickly to use some of that money to increase spending for law enforcement and education, areas that are expected to be hotly debated in the campaign.
Mr. Giuliani's aides maintained that the projected new tax revenues were evidence that his fiscal agenda was spurring the economy.
"The Giuliani administration's policies are working," Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations, said at a news conference.
But the plan they released yesterday was not all upbeat: it also contained $180 million in new cuts and demonstrated that the city will still face large projected budget gaps in the next three years.
And buried in the lengthy budget proposal were some fiscal maneuvers that will put new stresses on the budgets of three agencies over the next few years: the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the Housing Authority and the City University.
Detailing how the Mayor would allocate the $450 million in projected new revenues, aides said he would spend $143 million for overtime in the Police and Correction Departments that results from a continuing crackdown on drug dealing in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Those programs have led to so many arrests that the population of the city's jails has swelled by more than 2,000 people, to about 21,000, officials said.
The Mayor will also allocate an additional $70 million for new textbooks for the public schools, an initiative he has often cited in recent days to parry criticism from Democratic opponents that he has cut too much in projected spending from the Board of Education's budget.
Mr. Mastro pointedly noted that the administration plans to raise the city's recycling budget by $6 million, with the goal of cutting the amount of garbage carted to Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, to insure that the city can close it. That is an important issue in a borough that strongly supported Mr. Giuliani in 1993.
In his original budget that the City Council approved in June, the Mayor reduced money for recycling by more than $25 million, scaling back pickups of recycling materials in many neighborhoods from once a week to once every two weeks.
The Mayor's aides said the extra $6 million would not be enough to resume the weekly pickup schedule. They maintained that the amount of recycling hauled away by the Sanitation Department had not dropped on the reduced schedule.
After spending $270 million, the administration will use the rest of the $450 million to fill holes that have appeared in the budget. In the original plan, the Mayor made a number of risky fiscal assumptions, many of them involving revenue sources that were in doubt even when the budget was adopted last spring. In his new plan, the Mayor acknowledges that the money will not materialize this year.
The extra $450 million in projected revenues was disclosed in a budget adjustment that the administration is required to do every autumn. When the budget is approved in June, officials estimate how much they believe the city will earn in revenues for the year.
One of the largest cuts disclosed yesterday will hit the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the quasi-independent agency that runs the public hospital system. In 1997 and 1998, the agency's $3.2 billion budget will be cut by more than $150 million, which is almost four times as large as the $38 million cut the agency had been told to expect in July.
The Mayor's proposal also shifts some labor costs over the next four years from the city budget to that of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, Housing Authority and City University, which have their own budgets.
Fiscal monitors said the Mayor was right to not spend all of the $450 million. "The Mayor acted very prudently in his plans for the increased revenues," said Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office.
Democrats who are expected to run for Mayor had a different view of the Mayor's budget changes.
"I'm not surprised that he found new revenue," said Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn. "It's a typical re-election ploy that mayors squirrel money away so they can improve services in an election year."

LENGTH: 486 words

HEADLINE: Messinger Ads Criticize Store Plan and Mayor

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
As the City Council prepares to hold hearings next week on a zoning plan for suburban-style superstores, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, plans to run a series of radio commercials this weekend that harshly criticizes the effort and its most prominent advocate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The Mayor's plan would allow the superstores in manufacturing areas throughout the city, prompting fear in many neighborhoods that the stores would sap business from local merchants. 
 And though Ms. Messinger's 60-second commercials tap into that opposition, they also represent a spirited response to recent indications that the Mayor is preparing his re-election campaign. Ms. Messinger has said that she intends to run for Mayor next year.
"Apparently, Rudy Giuliani doesn't care what you think," Ms. Messinger says in one ad.
"He's pushing hard for his plan to let bureaucrats run roughshod over your neighborhood. If he gets his way, you won't have a single thing to say about it."
Ms. Messinger will pay for the $7,400 in ads out of her Borough President's account, according to Leland T. Jones, her senior adviser. "The Borough President is merely exercising her charter responsibilities over planning issues," he said.
Ms. Messinger has said that she believes the city needs more megastores but that the Mayor's plan does not allow enough community input into where the stores would go. Calling the hearings "our chance to stand up for our neighborhoods," Ms. Messinger says in the commercial, "Mayor Giuliani may not care what you want for your neighborhood, but if you make your voice heard, the Council will."
The hearings are scheduled for 9:30 A.M. Monday and Tuesday in the City Council chambers.
Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, called the ads dishonest and irresponsible.
"I can only assume that this is Ruth pursuing some political agenda that has nothing to do with sound land-use policy and has nothing to do with the facts," Mr. Rose said. "This kind of demagoguery is not in the best interest of the city."
The proposal would allow up to 57 warehouse-style stores to be built in the city's manufacturing zones without public hearings or the soliciting of neighborhood views.
The administration has said that the proposal would correct obsolete rules that permit some large stores while prohibiting others.
"This proposal protects communities while also allowing for growth in the city's economy," Mr. Rose said.
A divided City Planning Commission approved the plan last month after 21 community boards and all five borough boards recommended a no vote.
Council officials have said for some time that the proposal would face heavy opposition from Council members who have been lobbied by local business owners who fear competition from megastores and by neighborhood leaders who dread the traffic that the stores would bring.

HEADLINE: College Idealism Was Fertile Soil for Fringe Group

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Jennifer Kling left Williams College here to join the National Labor Federation in Brooklyn with dreams of organizing the poor to create a more just world.
Instead, Ms. Kling found herself trapped in a cramped, tense apartment building, unable to walk outside. Every second was charted. During the day, she filed papers, wrote articles and worked a phone bank, selling advertisements in the organization's publications. In the evenings, she was required to attend political lectures that would often go until 4:30 A.M., when she was finally allowed to collapse into sleep in a small room with five other women. 
 Six hours later, at 10:30, the wake-up call would come over the loudspeaker, and Ms. Kling and about 50 other members of the group, which has been called a cult, would start the cycle all over again.
"They didn't encourage idle chatter," she said. "Time was precious. Every minute was pre-scheduled. They kept you so busy that you didn't have time to think about leaving."
It took a terrified Ms. Kling weeks to build up the courage to sneak out of the building one morning last year and take a bus home to her family in Missouri.
This was the odd world of a fringe group that had remained relatively unknown and hidden until Monday night, when the police entered their Brooklyn headquarters, a cluster of buildings that group members called "the cave," and discovered a small arsenal of guns and explosives.
The group, which at different times called itself the National Labor Federation and the Provisional Communist Party, was established by Eugenio Perente-Ramos, who billed himself as a radical labor organizer, though the police and experts on cults have called him a cult leader. Experts familiar with the group say Mr. Perente-Ramos, who died last year, had a following of several hundred in the Brooklyn complex and around the nation in rigidly organized satellite groups, known in his jargon as "entities."
While the group's stated aim was to mobilize the poorest workers to challenge the fundamental economic system, it appears to have achieved little in that arena. What has perhaps drawn the greatest attention to the group is its recruiting efforts among a very different target audience: idealistic college students.
Ms. Kling, now 21, was one of many Williams College students who were approached by a front group, Western Massachusetts Labor Action, that had strong ties to the Brooklyn office. The group has recruited at other schools in Massachusetts and Vermont, but its efforts have come under particular scrutiny at this elite private school of 2,000 students in this small Berkshires town.
For about 20 years, the local group, based nearby in Pittsfield, relied on volunteers from Williams. Although only three students, including Ms. Kling, joined the federation as full-time volunteers, a steady stream of Williams students helped canvass surrounding towns for new members, chopped firewood for the poor and attended meetings, among other tasks.
Indeed, Western Massachusetts Labor Action became almost an institution on campus and enjoyed a reputation as a sort of Salvation Army with a political edge, a place where socially conscious students could go to work with the poor. Its connection to Mr. Perente-Ramos was not readily apparent, and the local group's lead organizer was invited to economics and political science classes to lecture on the region's social conditions.
When the school held its annual community volunteer fair, Western Massachusetts Labor Action had a table there. One former student, Michelle Kang, noted that a class that involved doing community service included the group as one of the ways to meet the requirement.
"I remember getting phone calls all the time from them, even in my senior year, trying to get me to help," said Ms. Kang, who graduated two years ago. She got on the group's phone list after taking the community service class as a sophomore.
Yet what the group was doing with this help is unclear.
Kurt P. Tauber, a retired political science professor who sponsored the group on campus and helped it raise money, said its organizing work had been a disappointment to him. He said the group was obsessed with forms and bureaucratic detail -- with precise instructions about where to put pencils and erasers.
While Dr. Tauber described the group as having a muddled, almost nonexistent political ideology, he noted that its bible was an organizing handbook that gave precise instructions on how to do everything from knock on a door to set up a desk. Dr. Tauber, who met Mr. Perente-Ramos in Brooklyn 13 years ago, said he was not impressed by him and did not like how he barked orders at people.
Yet Dr. Tauber, like others at Williams, saw the goals of the organization as admirable and continued to support it. And he admired the dedication of the unpaid organizers, who worked seven days a week, had no homes of their own and appeared to survive on doughnuts and coffee.
The group's standing, however, plummeted last year when Ms. Kling's experience became known and an expose in the campus newspaper, The Williams Record, publicized the local group's connections to the Brooklyn office, suggesting it was more cult than political group.
Since then, the college has moved to discourage the group from coming onto campus and tried to educate faculty members and students about its questionable background. In the last few months, the group's lead organizer has left, and its presence on campus has diminished.
On campus Wednesday night, a random survey of a dozen people revealed that most had not even heard of the group. Those who were familiar with it regarded it as something of a joke.
"They were a pretty weird bunch," said Yamelin Castillo, who graduated in June and is working here. "No one took them seriously."
The group continues to work from its storefront office in Pittsfield, occasionally distributing leaflets here. A man who answered the group's office phone today denied any connection with the Brooklyn group.
Yet there appears to be little doubt that the groups are linked. Peggy Uman, who started working with Mr. Perente-Ramos in the early 1970's, said she moved here in 1975 to establish the group, having first cleared it with him. Then, until she left the group seven years later, she filed daily reports about her activities, she said.
Ms. Kling, despite her experience, remains ambivalent about her break with the group and was upset to read that five of her former comrades had been arrested on weapons charges, including Dianne Garrett, her sponsor. "She's a compassionate, caring person," Ms. Kling said. "She really cares about the poor. She would never use a gun."
Ms. Kling objected to the characterization of the group as a cult, and said that no physical force was ever used to keep her there. But, she said, she does not want to go back.
In the first three months of 1995, Ms. Kling said, she was cloistered in Brooklyn. When her father was visiting from Missouri and wanted to spend the day with her, the group told her that she should not leave. Instead, he came to visit, and they were never left alone, she said.
The building was filled with bright people -- including a number of lawyers -- but it also was a tense place. Some recruits were clearly mentally ill, she said, and screaming arguments erupted regularly.
Dissatisfied with the life she was leading, Ms. Kling spent weeks plotting her escape. On that dark morning in March, alone in New York for the first time in her life, she wandered the streets of Brooklyn and tried to find a subway station.
"It was scary," she said, "but it felt wonderful to breathe the air of New York."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer Kling left Williams College to join the National Labor Federation, which some have called a cult. (David Bruneau for The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Changes Planned for Leading Indicators

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Seeking to sharpen an important tool for predicting the economy, the Conference Board said today that it would drop two components of its Composite Leading Index and replace them with a gauge of interest rates.
Beginning with the November reading, the price of sensitive materials and the volume of unfilled orders for manufactured durable goods are being removed because they "rank much lower" as predictors than the other nine components, the research group said. 
 The new indicator is the yield curve, the difference between long-term rates as measured by the 10-year Treasury bond and short-term rates as measured by the Federal funds rate.
The last time the index components were changed was in 1989 when the Commerce Department, which compiled it until late 1995, added the durable goods backlog, which is to be dropped with the University of Michigan's gauge of consumer expectations. These replaced business and consumer credit and manufacturing and trade inventories.

HEADLINE: Boycotts Rarely Have Impact on Bottom Line

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
In the early 1970's, a group of black, left-leaning students called for a boycott of Gulf Oil to protest the company's operations in Angola, which had been fighting to win its independence from Portugal. Protests were held on college campuses, investors were urged to sell Gulf stock, posters of Portuguese soldiers holding up the severed head of a black African under the words, "Boycott Gulf" adorned the walls of many black students' rooms.
But in the end, the boycott had little effect on Gulf's bottom line. 
 "Oil companies are so vertically integrated that it makes it difficult to attack them," said Randall Robinson, who was the leader of the student protests and is now the director of the TransAfrica Forum, a black lobbying organization.
Still, a boycott is not necessarily a wasted effort, he added. The Gulf boycott served as an important organizing tool and helped increase the public's knowledge of issues related to southern Africa.
"We saw Gulf more as a tool than a target," Mr. Robinson added. "Did we put a dent in Gulf? No."
As was the case with the black students in the 1970's, black leaders, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, have again called for a boycott of an oil company, Texaco. In taking on the company, Mr. Jackson and others hope to settle a discrimination lawsuit brought by black employees. But Mr. Jackson also sees the Texaco campaign as the beginning of a shift in emphasis for the civil rights movement from elective politics and government policy to protests against private companies.
"For too long we have focused almost exclusively on the public sector and electing officials," Mr. Jackson said in a telephone interview. "There must be renewed focus, research and confrontation with the private sector."
In changing tactics, Mr. Jackson and others are choosing a method with a long and checkered history in the civil rights movement. As early as 1910, blacks across the South boycotted street cars, hoping to force the operators to provide them equal -- albeit separate -- seating.
In recent years, boycotts have been threatened against companies like Denny's and Shoney's, restaurants that had been accused of refusing to serve blacks or of discriminating against black employees. But so far no big national boycott by civil rights groups has been pressed.
"There have been attempts over the last couple of years to threaten boycotts, but I don't know that they've ever grabbed hold," said Julian Bond, a board member of the N.A.A.C.P. who also teaches history at the University of Virginia.
Historians and economists say that boycotts have often been useful in publicizing a cause, or as an organizing tool. Targeted companies generally say they have not been affected by such tactics, but have settled with the protesters to avoid continued bad publicity.
Even the most celebrated economic boycott by blacks -- the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott which started the civil rights career of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. -- failed to win the objectives sought by the protesters, according to a historian.
J. Mills Thornton, a professor of history at the University of Michigan, said the boycott did little harm to National City Lines, a Chicago-based company that owned the local bus company in Montgomery. The withdrawal of black ridership crippled the bus line, but the Montgomery company was such a small part of the parent company's operations, it hardly mattered.
"The boycott's importance was entirely psychological in the black community," said Mr. Thornton, whose research included a review of the company's internal documents. "It created a sense of common enterprise and united blacks across the class barriers and gave them all a sense they were engaged in a common struggle. All that was very important. But that's all the boycott did. It had no effect on the city and the management of the bus company."
King and the Montgomery Improvement Association, which he headed, succeeded in integrating Montgomery's buses only by suing. The suit led to a 1956 Supreme Court ruling that the bus lines' segregation was unconstitutional.
Sometimes the tactics have caused near disasters for civil rights organizations. In 1980, the Mississippi Supreme Court directed the N.A.A.C.P. to pay $1.25 million in damages to businesses in the town of Port Gibson, Miss., ruling that the commercial establishments had been damaged by a boycott organized by a local chapter of the civil rights organization. The damage award threatened to bankrupt the N.A.A.C.P., but was overturned by the Supreme Court two years later.
During his time as the head of Operation PUSH in the 1970's and 1980's -- a position he recently returned to -- Mr. Jackson called for boycotts against a number of high- profile brand name companies, including Coca-Cola; Anheuser-Busch; Philip Morris; Ford Motor; Burger King, a unit of Grand Metropolitan; Quaker Oats, and Nike.
Generally, the threat of a boycott was sufficient to force the company to reach an agreement with Mr. Jackson to increase minority hiring, purchase more supplies from black vendors, appoint women or minorities to positions on the board or make contributions to organizations like the United Negro College Fund, according to Frank Watkins, Mr. Jackson's former lieutenant at PUSH.
"We didn't have to boycott most of them," Mr. Watkins said, now the press secretary for Mr. Jackson's son, Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., a Chicago Democrat. "Most of them we were able to negotiate an agreement with. The only companies nationally that we had to boycott was Coke for a month and Anheuser-Busch for a year."
In 1981, Coca-Cola ended the boycott by increasing black-owned distributorships, advertising more in black-owned newspapers and setting a goal of having blacks make up 12.5 percent of its management force.
A year later, Mr. Jackson called for a nationwide boycott against Anheuser-Busch, which he accused of having too few black distributors. The boycott caused some divisions among black organizations, especially groups in St. Louis, which felt that the beer company had been a generous contributor to local causes.
In 1983 the boycott ended when the beer company made pledges similar to those of Coca-Cola.
But Anheuser-Busch signed no agreement and some executives later said the company already was embarking on many of the things it pledged to do.
 Indeed, as the boycott wound down, Mr. Jackson released a statement saying that his view of Anheuser-Busch's lack of commitment to minority advancement "may have been attributed to a failure of communication."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Rev. Jesse Jackson sees a shift in emphasis by the civil rights movement to the private sector. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: MAINE REPUBLICAN IS SEEN AS LEADING FOR DEFENSE POST

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
As the jockeying intensifies over President Clinton's choices for his national security team, William S. Cohen, the retiring Republican Senator from Maine, has emerged as the leading contender for Secretary of Defense, Administration officials said today.
But the question of who will be Secretary of State remains far more unsettled, senior officials said. George J. Mitchell, a former Democratic Senator from Maine, is still considered the leading candidate, but a strong faction in the Administration is pushing for Richard C. Holbrooke, the former Assistant Secretary of State who negotiated the Bosnia peace accords. 
 Mr. Clinton considers the assembly of his national security team as "the first and most urgent task that he sees in the transition itself," his press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said today. The focus on that particular group of officials was also accelerated by the White House retirement ceremony for Secretary of State Warren Christopher, 71, two days after Mr. Clinton's re-election.
Officials cautioned that the President liked to mull over decisions and that Mr. Cohen, a moderate Republican who had emerged as a possible candidate for several posts, did not yet have the defense position wrapped up. But one senior Administration official said, "It's going to come down to that -- I think it already has come down to that."
Another official said that while Mr. Cohen was the front-runner now his chances could diminish if too much time passed without an announcement.
Senior White House officials said they did not think Mr. Clinton would announce any appointments on Friday before he leaves for a nearly two-week trip to Hawaii, Australia and Asia for an economic summit meeting. Several officials said he might wait until after Thanksgiving to announce the entire national security team at once.
Kathryn Waters Gest, Mr. Cohen's press secretary, said the Senator had no comment.
Assembling the President's national security team has become a complicated puzzle, as Mr. Clinton and his transition advisers examine how the candidates would mesh.
"The President is struck by how well that team has worked together in the past to advance America's foreign policy objectives and how important it is to have a team that continues to work in that fashion as we look to the next four years," Mr. McCurry said. "Getting a right individual here affects decisions about the right individual there, and he will make those announcements as he sees fit."
So, for example, there is even the question of how it would look if the Defense and State Departments were both run by former Senators from Maine.
Mr. Clinton has emphasized that in an effort to reach out to Republicans he would like to have members of their party in his Cabinet. But other possible Republican contenders have fallen away in recent days.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, who was considered a possible candidate for Secretary of State, announced that he was not interested. And Colin L. Powell, the retired general and former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is considered an unlikely prospect because of the political threat he might pose as a challenger to Vice President Al Gore in the year 2000.
Mr. Gore has been one of the closest advisers to Mr. Clinton as he selects his new team, and one adviser familiar with the Vice President's thinking said he had raised questions about both Mr. Lugar and General Powell.
Mr. Cohen, 55, is widely regarded here as an intelligent, independent centrist. He announced earlier this year that he was not seeking a fourth term and that he needed new challenges after 24 years in Congress.
He made his initial mark in national politics as the anguished Republican newcomer in the House who broke ranks with his party and voted to impeach President Richard M. Nixon in 1974. He was elected to the Senate in 1978, and he has come to be recognized as a respected voice on military and intelligence matters.
While Mr. Cohen has moved into the lead to run the Defense Department, the search for Secretary of State remains more unsettled, officials said, with the four candidates said to be Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Holbrooke, retiring Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, and Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative to the United Nations.
Mr. Mitchell, a senior Administration official said, is the clear leader but he is "not across the line yet." Mr. Holbrooke, whose strong views and brash personality have won him both defenders and detractors, is now said to be Mr. Mitchell's main challenger. The State Department, officials said, is split over Mr. Holbrooke and Mr. Mitchell, who is known to be Mr. Christopher's preference.
Several officials said that a possible problem for Mr. Mitchell is that he could emerge as an irritant rather than an asset in relations with Congress. Leading Republicans have let it be known that they considered him an extremely partisan Senate majority leader and that they might return the favor, though they would not block his confirmation.
An additional question in assembling the national security team is whether Anthony Lake will remain as national security adviser. He and Mr. Holbrooke have had a long, up-and-down relationship going back to the days when they were Foreign Service officers in Vietnam.

NEW YORK
 
Fringe Group Enlisted Students
While the stated aim of the National Labor Federation was to mobilize workers to challenge the fundamental economic system, it appears to have achieved little in that arena. What has perhaps drawn the greatest attention to the group is its recruiting efforts among a very different group: idealistic college students at an elite school in Massachusetts. The group's odd world remained relatively unknown until the police discovered an arsenal at its headquarters in Brooklyn. [Page A1.]
 
Tensions flared between the group and the tenants who live alongside it in Crown Heights. [B4.]
 
Passing Along Welfare Controls
Just as the Federal Government has turned over to states major responsibility for running welfare programs, Governor Pataki is proposing to transfer to local governments broad new powers to decide what necessities to give many of the state's poorest people, and for how long. [B1.]
 
Kinder Riders (Laugh Here)
The Transit Authority wants to make better people out of New Yorkers, sensitive souls who step aside on subway platforms, who do not pile in the moment the doors open. Lots of luck. While New Yorkers usually come through like champs at the extremes of good or bad, it is in daily life that their manners head south, especially on the subway. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]

Niki Barkoutsis, 23, of Queens stepped forward as one of the winners of the $45 million Lotto jackpot. Her father is the owner of several outlets of the fast-food eatery Chirping Chicken. [B1.]
 
Guilty Verdict in Murder
A Brooklyn man was found guilty of kidnapping and murder for setting afire last year a 20-year-old college student he once professed to love like a sister. Joshua Torres, 23, sat unmoved, as he had for most of the two-week trial, while the verdict was read: guilty on all but one of seven counts in Kimberly Antonakos's abduction and death. [B3.]
 
Jogger Raped in Prospect Park
A 30-year old jogger was raped and sodomized in broad daylight in Prospect Park, the police said. The woman was jogging along a bridle path near the Quaker cemetery when the unarmed attacker grabbed her and dragged her into a wooded area, the police said. [B3.]
 
How to Spend a Windfall
Mayor Giuliani formally presented a plan for spending an unexpected $450 million windfall in tax revenues, drawing praise from some independent budget analysts and attacks from his Democratic rivals, who asserted that new spending would not make up for his earlier cuts. [B3.]
 
Gang Indicted in Drug Case
Eighteen members of a violent, multimillion-dollar crack gang, including a former New York City housing police officer, were indicted on racketeering charges that included 11 murders and drug dealing that terrorized Harlem and Bronx neighborhoods for the last decade, the authorities said. [B4.]
 
2 Charged in Embezzlement
A married couple who operated a home for mentally retarded adults in Queens were arrested and charged with embezzling an estimated $500,000 in Medicaid funds provided for running the home, where a state commission had found squalid conditions. [B4.]
 
Leading U.S. in Bypass Surgery
The chance of dying from cardiac bypass surgery in New York State is lower than that reported in any other area of the country and is the lowest since the state began surveying the results of the operation five years ago, health officials reported. [B5.]

Medical investigators have identified another victim of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, reducing the number of missing victims to 15 out of the 230 people who perished. The smorgasbord of kosher foodstuffs jockeying for attention in the Meadowlands Exposition Center is dizzying, from kosher-for-Passover unleavened taco shells to fleecy tufts of kosher cotton candy; kosher bonbons made in Belgium, kosher baby food made in France, kosher ravioli. Kosherfest '96 is a window into a brave new kosher world, marked by relentless innovation and keen competition, that isn't just for Passover, or Jews, anymore. [B1.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Dow Tops 6,300 On Signs of Slow Growth
Stock prices again rose to records, as reports on consumer prices and retail sales added evidence that the economy is growing slowly, with little inflation.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.76 points, 6,313.00, led by I.B.M., Philip Morris and Allied Signal. It was the Dow's seventh consecutive record close. [Page D6.]
 
The Treasury market was also strengthened by the economic reports. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.42 percent from 6.45. [D16.]
 
Two Valujet Founders Sell Shares
Two of the four founders of Valujet airlines each sold one million shares of stock, the first time either had cashed in his original investment in the carrier, which saw spectacular success before a deadly crash in the Florida Everglades. The sale -- at more than $2 below the market price -- came after the company said it expected to default on its loan agreements by the end of the year. [D2.]

Motorola Elevates an Heir
Motorola named Christopher B. Galvin, the grandson of its founder, as its next chief executive. The ascension of the 46-year-old Mr. Galvin, now the company's president and chief operating officer, was no surprise but came sooner than expected. [D2.]
 
A Russian I.P.O. on the Big Board
Russia's leading cellular telephone company, Vimpel-Communications, is set for a roughly $90 million initial public offering as the first Russian company to be listed on the Big Board. When trading begins, investors will be able to buy part of a young company run by former Soviet military scientists who -- according to the prospectus -- have been making money hand over cellular handset. [D6.]
Suit Seeks to Block Blue Cross Deal
The Texas Attorney General filed a lawsuit seeking to block the merger of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, a nonprofit corporation, and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois, a mutual insurance company. The suit said Texas Blue Cross was a charitable asset that could not be removed from the state. [D16.]

BT Earnings Fall Slightly
British Telecommunications said that its earnings fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in the fiscal second quarter as it reduced prices to meet regulatory requirements and faced increased expenses for staff cuts. [D2.]
 
Credit Card Data Company Sold
Great Universal Stores, a British retailer, said that it would acquire the Experian Corporation, an American credit-card data company, for $1.7 billion. TRW sold most of Experian, which provides credit and marketing information, to two buyout companies two months ago for $1.01 billion. [D2.]

Consolidation for Turner Film Units
Time Warner is rapidly revamping the unwieldy film operation it inherited in the merger with Turner Broadcasting. It said it would fold Turner Pictures, a small production company, into Warner Brothers, and it is proceeding with plans to sell New Line Cinema. Several recent New Line films have been box office disappointments, including "The Long Kiss Goodnight." [D5.]
 
Shoe Company Shifts Operations
Nine West is consolidating its Cincinnati and Stamford, Conn., operations and moving its headquarters to White Plains. The move by the shoe company will bring 1,250 jobs to New York State. [B5.]

HEADLINE: October Retail Sales Weak; Price Index Up 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Consumersspent a bit more money last month but only because of inflation.
Retail sales rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in October as weak automotive sales prevented any increase at all for goods intended to last for several years, the Commerce Department reported today. The broad retail sales numbers raised questions about the expectations of a significantly improved Christmas shopping season, but department stores sales were up more strongly. 
 At the same time, the Labor Department found that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month. The results marked the first increase in energy prices since May, but that reassured analysts that inflation posed little threat.
"It looks like inflation is pretty well held in check," said John Park, an economist at Sanwa Securities in New York. On Wednesday the Labor Department said that prices at the wholesale, level posted their biggest decline in two years when the erratic food and energy components were excluded.
Over all, the latest figures portrayed an economy that continues to expand at a moderate pace and without generating anything near the pickup in inflation that has typically flared at such a mature stage of the business cycle. The economy has expanded without significant interruption since the end of the latest recession in March 1991.
The meager retail sales figures pointed up the biggest question looming over the economy: whether consumers, who this summer finally reined in their strong spending and borrowing, have temporarily paused or are in serious retrenchment.
Yet another set of figures today showed that first-time applications for unemployment benefits eased 4,000 last week, to 328,000, with the four-week average now standing at 330,250. Despite such a buoyant job market, consumers raised their savings during the third quarter and did not spend very freely last month.
In fact, merchants selling furniture and equipment for the home suffered a 1 percent sales decline despite a strong real estate market. Automotive sales were down three-tenths of 1 percent but the other major category of durable goods -- building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes -- showed a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent to leave overall sales of durables unchanged.
Sales were up three-tenths of 1 percent for nondurables but mainly because of a sharp jump at food stores that appeared mainly to reflect higher prices, not extra volume.
Still, analysts noted, department stores and others selling general merchandise managed an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent and drugstores posted a 1 percent October sales gain.
"This is a good sign for the holiday season," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, a New York research firm. He also noted that the department revised its sales totals for August and September up by one-tenth of 1 percent each.
The advance estimate released today for October retail sales, $206.6 billion, is an extrapolation based on just one-third of the outlets in the Commerce Department's monthly survey. Since October 1995, total sales climbed 5.2 percent, the report also showed, while consumer inflation over this 12-month period was 3 percent.
The report on consumer prices, which is generally viewed as a backward-looking rather than predictive indicator, reflected sharp increases for food and energy, items that for most of the last five years have tended to moderate overall price movements but are the source of this year's acceleration.
The Consumer Price Index has advanced at a 3.3 percent pace over the first 10 months compared with a 2.5 percent pace for all of 1995.
Without food and energy, which gyrate without much relation to business conditions, the price advance was a benign two-tenths of 1 percent for October and 2.6 percent over the latest 12 months.
In fact, food prices have likely peaked after plentiful grain harvests and oil prices have also eased, analysts said.
"The worst may be over on both fronts," said Bruce Steinberg, a Merrill Lynch economist.
Dairy products and fresh fruits and vegetables accounted for over three-quarters of the jump in food prices last month while household fuels contributed to a slight pickup in the cost of housing, which makes up 41 percent of the C.P.I.
Apparel prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month but this followed a period in which prices were statistically depressed by a slower than usual introduction of new autumn and winter merchandise.
The transportation index rose only negligibly last month as spurts in gasoline and airline fares were offset by lower prices for new and used cars and the first decline in automobile finance charges since February.
Today's figures were likely the last before a special commission studying the accuracy of Consumer Price Index issues its final report, due Dec. 1. The panel and most other economists believe that the index overstates inflation by a substantial amount.

HEADLINE: Officials in St. Petersburg Call Racial Unrest 'Calculated'

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 14

 BODY:
City officials said today that the second bout of disturbances to erupt here after a white police officer fatally shot a black teen-ager was a "calculated event" by groups of youths. The officials added that the young people had been partly incited by a black militant group that threatened violence if the officer was cleared of criminal charges.
Mayor David J. Fischer and the Chief of Police, Darrel W. Stephens, told City Council members at a meeting today that in recent days city cleanup crews had stumbled upon six tons of rocks and bottles that had been stockpiled around the black neighborhood where the disturbances occurred. The first was on Oct. 24, when Officer James Knight, 34, shot Tyron Lewis, 18, after stopping him for speeding, and the second was on Wednesday night, after a Pinellas County grand jury found that the shooting was justified. 
 Chief Stephens said the "caches" had been found near the headquarters of the National People's Democratic Uhuru Movement, a black group known for its fiery oratory advocating more power for blacks. The group recently held a "tribunal" that found the Mayor, the Chief and two officers involved in Mr. Lewis's death all guilty of murder and demanded their execution.
The Uhuru are led by Omali Yeshitela, 55, who founded the African People's Socialist Party in 1972. The group advocates black self-determination and recently called for black workers to strike in protest of their treatment here. Black residents account for about 19 percent of St. Petersburg's population of 245,000. At a news conference today Mr. Yeshitela characterized his tribunal's call for the execution of city officials as an expression of anger.
"The black community is incensed about that murder," he said, "and that was what was expressed in the rendering of the panel of judges."
At a 1993 hearing on racial and ethnic tensions, the city's Uhuru branch president, Alvelita Waller Donaldson, told the United States Commission on Human Rights, "I think conditions will breed that kind of thing, that we'll have rebellions, uprisings inside the community if conditions do not change."
The commission has scheduled hearings here next month. Bobby Doctor, the commission's Southern region director in Atlanta, said that despite "strides in the right direction," like rehabilitating housing and seeking financing for job programs to ease high unemployment rates in the black population, "it's very clear that there are deep-seated problems in St. Petersburg as there are in many urban areas."
"We're talking about a lack of significant economic development, problems with community relations," Mr. Doctor said. "There's a tremendous amount of mistrust between the police department and members of the black community. Any spark can lead to a major eruption. That's what took place."
The grand jury, which heard from 49 witnesses, said in a nine-page report on Wednesday that the death of Mr. Lewis was justifiable homicide because the officer had been "in reasonable fear of imminent death" when he fired three times as Mr. Lewis's car lurched toward him.
But on the day that the grand jury issued its finding, a police review board determined that the officer could have avoided the use of force. It suspended him for 60 days for placing himself "in a position of disadvantage and danger" when he moved in front of the vehicle after Mr. Lewis refused to exit the car.
Within hours, violence erupted in the area south of downtown that is home to most of the city's black population. An estimated $5 million in damages had resulted from about 30 arson fires. One police officer was shot in the leg, and a Pinellas County sheriff's deputy who was piloting a helicopter narrowly escaped a bullet as what the Mayor described as "small roving bands" of youths in their teens and early 20's took to the streets with rocks, bottles and Molotov cocktails.
Chief Stephens said the level of gunfire was unprecedented for this city. About 300 officers responded, he said, blocking off streets and firing tear gas canisters to disperse crowds. But they were met with such resistance, the chief said, that "there were several instances when officers were pinned down behind cars, having to take cover from gunfire."
Over 100 arson fires were reported Wednesday night, but by today fire department officials had confirmed only about 30, mostly in houses and stores. City officials said that the violence subsided by midnight and that today was calm. Officials have no firm damage estimates. The police said nine people had been arrested.
Chief Stephens himself came under attack today when residents of the arson-scarred neighborhoods accused him of worsening tensions, after the grand jury issued its report, by ordering the arrest of several members of the Uhuru Movement for outstanding warrants on misdemeanor charges, mostly traffic related.
He told reporters today that his officers had planned to arrest three members of the group to prevent them from joining in any violence.
But Wilson M. Carter, 54, who lives on a street where two houses burned down, had a simple explanation for the disturbances that have visited his neighborhood.
"They didn't have to kill that man," Mr. Carter said of the officers. "That's what it all boils down to."
