HEADLINE: Treasury Prices in Retreat As Investors Take Profits

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday, as investors chose to take profits on this week's market run-up.
The selling presssure increased after economic reports that suggested that consumers might begin to spend more, touching off a rebound in economic growth and causing inflation to accelerate. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32 , to 10019/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.46 percent, from 6.42 percent on Thursday. A week ago, it was 6.50 percent.
Traders said bonds seesawed through the session as the Federal Reserve and the Commerce Department released reports on factory use and business inventories.
The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial production fell by half of 1 percent -- much weaker than what the market expected. Bond prices rose on the news, but the gains soon eroded as it became evident that much of the weakness was production lost as a result of a strike against General Motors.
"After investors sifted through the details they were unable to get too bullish since most of the lost strike- related production would be made up in future months," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio.
Losses widened after the University of Michigan's preliminary report on consumer confidence in November showed a jump to 98.9 in the index reading, from 96.5 percent in October, traders said. It was the highest reading in 10 years, raising expectations that the holiday sales will be robust. The unversity's survey is released only to paying subscribers.
Another report, on business inventories, was in line with expectations. "With this latest information, the overall composition of third-quarter real growth G.D.P. will look a lot stronger going into the fourth quarter," Mr. Chan said.
Bond prices were further weighed down by a drop in the dollar, making dollar-denominated investment vehicles like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
Next week, the market will have few economic reports to digest. "With little data on tap for next week, investors are likely to use the housing starts data on Tuesday to speculate on whether the slowdown during the third quarter is real or temporary," Mr. Chan said.
Supply may also be a factor next week, as the Treasury gets set to auction $30.75 billion in new two- and five-year notes, along with the $28 billion in bills at the regular weekly bill auction. In when-isssued trading, the yet-to-be-sold two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent and the five-year note, 5.95 percent.

HEADLINE: Fed Minutes Show Little Dissent Over Policy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Despite widespread speculation that there had been a rift within the Federal Reserve at its September meeting over the issue of whether monetary policy needed to be tightened, minutes of the session released today showed that a strong majority saw no compelling case for raising rates at a time when the economy was slowing from its overheated pace earlier in the year.
Saying they were wary about an outbreak of inflation, but finding little evidence that it was occurring, members of the Fed's policy-making body voted 11 to 1 to hold interest rates steady at the Sept. 24 meeting, the minutes said. 
 The decision appears to have been proved the right one by a series of subsequent reports showing that growth has moderated to a sustainable pace and that there continues to be little upward pressure on prices. The Fed again voted to leave rates unchanged at a meeting on Wednesday; minutes of that meeting will be released on Dec. 20.
Before the September meeting, a rare news leak, apparently from a Fed official, disclosed that 8 of the 12 Federal Reserve Bank presidents were pushing for an increase in the discount rate, one of two interest rates controlled by the Fed, and that a consensus was forming in favor of an increase in the more important Federal funds rate, the target rate for overnight lending between banks.
But the minutes, while showing some differences of opinion about the immediacy of any inflation threat, disclosed no concerted challenge to those within the Fed, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman, who were calling for a wait-and-see posture.
"A few members indicated that they could vote for some slight tightening in policy, although they did not feel any urgency about such a move," the minutes said. "They observed that the decision was a close one for them, and in light of the uncertainties that were involved, they were willing to join the majority and wait for further evidence bearing on the outlook for inflation."
In the end, the only member of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee to vote for higher rates was Gary H. Stern, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Mr. Stern had also dissented on his own at the two previous meetings, in July and August, and had made no secret of his view that low unemployment and signs of rising wages would set off inflation.
"Given prevailing pressures on resources, especially labor, Mr. Stern was concerned about the distinct risk of an acceleration of inflation," the minutes said. "Should this acceleration occur, he believed it would prove disruptive to the favorable performance of the economy, and he preferred to begin to address this risk promptly."
The minutes outlined a discussion about whether the available statistics were giving an accurate view. In particular, Fed members questioned whether measurements of productivity were reflecting increases in the ability of companies to absorb prices increases through greater efficiency.
In the end, the minutes showed, the group decided to leave in place its formal bias toward raising rates if new evidence of inflation was to appear. But members remained somewhat puzzled about precisely what was happening in the economy.
"The members generally agreed that while the risks were greater that price inflation would rise than that it would fall, higher inflation was not a foregone conclusion and most believed that the uncertainties in the outlook made it prudent to hold monetary policy on a steady course and await further developments," the minutes said.

HEADLINE: October Output Off 0.5%; First Decline in 7 Months

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The output of the nation's factories fell in October for the first time in seven months as strikes at General Motors slowed production while some businesses were trimming inventories.
The Federal Reserve said today that industrial production fell by half of 1 percent, largely because of the ripple effect of the strike at the Canadian plants of General Motors and later disputes that closed some G.M. assembly lines in the United States. 
 Even with auto plants excluded, output at factories, mines and utilities was down two-tenths of 1 percent, with most industries sharing in the loss.
"Producers are responding to the pickup in inventories last summer," when consumer spending waned, said Mark M. Zandi, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
By matching inventories with slowing sales, businesses are setting the stage for higher production as demand strengthens, he added.
"It suggests the economy will continue to expand moderately next year," he said.
A separate report today, from the Commerce Department, showed that growth in business inventories slowed to one-tenth of 1 percent in September, from three-tenths in August and five-tenths in July.
At the same time, business sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September after slipping two-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
Many analysts say sales will continue to grow moderately as the Christmas shopping season approaches.
The Fed report offered no sign of inflation, saying industries were operating at 82.7 percent of capacity in October, down from 83.4 percent in September. Analysts generally consider a capacity utilization rate of more than 85 percent to be potentially inflationary, opening the possibility of production bottlenecks that can lead to shortages and higher prices.
The decline in overall production was the first since an identical drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in March. Many analysts had predicted that output would remain unchanged in October.
The production of durable goods -- products like cars that are expected to last more than three years -- fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in October.
"Motor vehicle assemblies dropped more than 7 percent from their September level," the Fed report said. "This falloff resulted largely from shortages of parts made at strike-affected plants in Canada and from a strike that had shut down some domestic assembly plants late in the month."
Output of nondurable goods like chemicals and clothing slipped two-tenths of 1 percent. Output at utilities was unchanged, but mining production fell 1 percent after slipping one-tenth of 1 percent the previous month.
Against the lower trend, the computer and office equipment sector posted a 2.1 percent increase.
In its report, the Commerce Department said the inventory-to-sales ratio dipped to 1.39, from 1.40. The September figure matched the May and July levels, which were the lowest since the Government began tracking the data in 1982. The number means that 1.39 months would be required to exhaust stockpiles at the September sales rate.

GRAPHIC: Table: "Industrial Production" shows and index of total industrial production from May 1995 to Oct. 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The State Department this week released the names of 20 outstanding American religious leaders and scholars who will form a new Advisory Committee on Religious Freedom Abroad.
The formation of the committee is a milestone in the battle against religious persecution. 
 Or it is a charade.
The State Department's action reflects a long overdue recognition that religion, no less than geography and trade, must be an important consideration in American foreign policy.
Or the action pays lip service to growing demands that the United States respond forcefully to persecution of Christians around the world while submerging that concern in a sea of other issues and assigning it to the very bureaucracy that is being challenged.
Those are two views of a committee created after a whole year's fierce maneuverings in private and in public, in Government circles and among various church groups.
The first view is that of John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, who will be chairman of the new advisory committee.
The second view is that of Michael Horowitz, a former Reagan Administration official and now a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute in Washington.
Mr. Horowitz is a Jew who became virtually obsessed with combatting persecution of Christians overseas after volunteering to help several evangelical victims obtain asylum in the United States, and discovering bureaucratic resistance to such requests from the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
For a year, he has been badgering everyone from the White House and the State Department to the Christian churches themselves to put the spotlight not on mere discrimination or lack of religious freedom but on the killings, torture, mob looting, imprisonment and even enslavement that have been meted out to Christians, especially evangelical Christians, primarily by authorities in Communist nations like China, North Korea and Vietnam or by militant Islamic forces, official or unofficial in Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Egypt and elsewhere.
Mr. Horowitz and his allies see such Christians as the most persecuted religious group in the world. He calls them "the Jews of the 21st century in much of the world," referring not to the singular and systematic destruction of the Holocaust but to the centuries of exclusion, persecution and pogroms that preceded it.
In many regions, Christians, like Jews before them, he argues, are viewed as outsiders, branded as agents of a corrupting West and a disruptive, modernity, made into scapegoats by unscrupulous leaders who need to cement their own power.
In this view, the defense of Christian freedom from persecution is in effect a defense of minimal democracy and even a defense of the moderate, tolerant elements that exist in Islam and other world religions.
Not surprisingly Mr. Horowitz's model for remedying this situation is the Campaign for Soviet Jewry, the 1980's agitation that put the muscle of the United States behind demands that the Soviet Union allow Jewish emigration to Israel.
The centerpiece of that campaign would be a Special Adviser to the President who could advocate giving the plight of persecuted Christians a priority in the nation's foreign policy instead of the indifference and even hostility with which Mr. Horowitz and his allies characterizes the current approach of the State Department and the immigration service.
Early this year, the Administration nibbled at this proposal and then backed away. Undoubtedly it ran into longstanding misgivings about making rights a prime objective of foreign policy, especially when that would complicate security concerns or economic advantage.
Beyond that were a serious question whether the problem of anti-Christian persecution was more complicated than the campaigners acknowledged. Although it might be politically galvanizing to lump all the forms of anti-Christian oppression into a single, escalating, global problem, was that really productive of sound analysis and skillful diplomacy?
And why focus on Christians alone or even primarily? Did that enhance the cause or undermine its credibility?
The advisory committee, which will address the persecution of all religious groups, is the Administration's response. It is about as distinguished a group as one could hope for. It includes the Rev. Don Argue, president of the National Association of Evangelicals, and Nina Shea, a conservative interested in human rights issues whom Mr. Horowitz and others were promoting for the Special Adviser job.
It includes the Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky, an Orthodox priest and former officer of the National Council of Churches, and Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark. Both have long records of involvement with the problems of persecuted Christians in the Soviet bloc.
It includes scholars like Dr. David Little of the U.S. Institute of Peace and Dr. Diana L. Eck, who teaches world religions at Harvard. There are Jewish, Muslim, Baha'i and Mormon officials and scholars as well.
Mr. Horowitz and his allies are not impressed. The panel, said Dr. Richard D. Land, president of the Christian Life Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, will be "a wholly owned subsidiary of the State Department" that will be staffed and directed by the very people whose policies out to be under review.
They have little patience with the contention of one Administration official that placing the committee in the State Department was the only realistic way of giving it clout and a budget.
Sometimes Mr. Horowitz and Dr. Land sound as though the American Government is as much the enemy as any of those that persecute Christians. Their appeals for a special adviser sound more like demands for a special prosecutor.
If one assumes that this problem is really a bit more complicated than Mr. Horowitz and Dr. Land indicate, or that some good will and genuine concern about human rights and religious persecution actually exist in the Government, then the advisory committee makes more sense.
But can a committee that will meet two or three times a year for two years and be entirely reliant on State Department personnel who have other responsibilities really do this job? Can even a wonderful cross section of the best and the brightest in American religion suddenly function as a team?
Mr. Shattuck has described the committee's goals in notably soft terms: to provide information about religious persecution to the Government, to "foster dialogue" between religious groups and the Government about Washington's efforts on behalf of religious freedom overseas.
At the same time, he has handed them an additional topic -- how to turn religion into a peacemaking rather than divisive force in areas like Bosnia -- that is even broader that combatting persecution. In a phone conversation on Thursday, he repeatedly stressed that the committee would not be "action-oriented."
At this point, what exactly it will be rests heavily on the shoulders of its 20 eminent members.

HEADLINE: Go Slow on Digital TV

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission is poised to issue standards for transmission of digital television -- broadcasts with the picture quality of movie theaters and the sound quality of CD's. The standards, in draft form, are backed by the broadcasters but opposed by parts of the computer industry. Most commissioners -- only the chairman, Reed Hundt, resists -- have lined up behind the broadcasters even though the staff has been flooded with conflicting technical and economic studies submitted by the industries whose financial fortunes will be dictated by the commission's decision.
This is more than a mud fight between corporate behemoths. Every American household will be affected. The broadcasters may have the better of the argument. But it will take an independent panel of experts to resolve key technical issues before the commission can be sure. 
 Some commissioners are rushing to get digital television going before the Europeans and others take control of the industry. But the Japanese rushed ahead, adopted the wrong standard and wasted billions of dollars. The task is to make the right choice for the next several decades.
The commission's mandate is to issue standards so that broadcasters, equipment manufacturers and consumers can know what they need to do to bring digital television into homes. The broadcasters favor a standard that would allow them to choose any of 18 video formats. Some of the video formats, for example, provide for extra-high resolution and "repaint" screens fast enough to capture high-speed live action, such as sports. It is assumed that new television sets and computers would be built to receive most, if not all, of these formats.
The computer-industry proposes a standard that would impose just one format on every broadcaster. Broadcasters could then create other formats by building features onto the standard format. That way, every television and computer could receive the basic signal, but consumers would need to buy additional equipment to capture extra-high resolution or other features.
There are three key unresolved issues in deciding whose standard works better. The computer industry says its proposal will permit the most innovation because it does not lock broadcasters into 18 formats. Besides, they say, the broadcasters want a system that would allow the industry as a whole to veto innovations by individual broadcasters. The broadcasters retort that their system would allow for as much experimentation as the computer industry's. This issue is key, since Federal regulators have no idea what format will prove best next year, let alone 10 years from now.
A second issue is cost. By indirectly requiring television sets and computers to accommodate 18 video formats, the broadcasters' plan will cost more. The question is how much. Technical studies by the broadcasters show the cost would be modest, even as low as $5 per set. The computer industry says the cost will be upward of $250 per set. Here is where an independent panel of experts could pin down plausible estimates.
Finally, the broadcasters accuse the computer industry, by favoring a single format, of trying to rig the market in favor of a technology that is best for the computer industry. The broadcasters' standard, by comparison, includes several formats, thereby accommodating the technical needs of both industries. It may appear that the broadcasters win this argument handily. But the commission must satisfy itself that, given the option of many formats, the broadcasters will not be able to lock in their preferred format -- thereby rigging the market in favor of a potentially inferior technology.
The commission does not have the facts at hand to resolve the issues of innovation, cost and market access. Mr. Hundt seems to want more time to make the correct choice. He is right to ask for it.

HEADLINE: A Distant Departure From Bosnia

 BODY:
Common sense dictates that after a year of imperfect peace, Bosnia is not ready for NATO forces to go home on Dec. 20, as originally planned. But Americans ought to have no illusions about what can be accomplished by prolonging their stay, nor should they accept President Clinton's facile assertion yesterday that he was announcing a new and different military mission. Mr. Clinton delayed America's exit from the current mission. To assure that further delays do not develop, the Administration should sharpen the withdrawal strategy Mr. Clinton outlined. It must also obtain Congressional approval for the extended American presence.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, United States forces, originally 20,000, would be reduced to 8,500. Overall NATO force levels would be cut from the 60,000 the mission began with to just over 30,000. The new target date for total withdrawal would be moved ahead to June 1998, with partial withdrawals along the way based on progress reviews every six months. 
 This so-called "follow-on force" will be doing the same things the current military force has been doing since it finished separating the rival ethnic armies some six months ago. That means, primarily, deterring a return to open ethnic warfare. It also means providing security for the civilians trying to rebuild Bosnia's economy and institutions.
In theory, these tasks could be accomplished by European forces alone. But an important consideration in apportioning military responsibilities in Bosnia has been Washington's desire to maintain unity and American leadership in NATO. That legitimate concern argues for the United States to continue providing between one-quarter and one-third of the forces in Bosnia, as it has for the past year.
A year of NATO supervision has halted the pitched battles and urban sieges that ravaged Bosnia during 43 months of war. But smaller armed skirmishes have continued, including one this week that forced American soldiers to separate the combatants. National elections have been held, but municipal voting has been postponed until spring. Institutions like a national presidency and parliament have been established but not made to function. The hope of eventual reunification is fading, replaced by the reality of hardening partition.
In these circumstances, the best NATO forces can hope to accomplish is to contain the violence, protect the municipal elections and perhaps reinforce habits of peaceful ethnic coexistence. By keeping their troops on the ground, participating countries can also press Balkan leaders to honor their commitments under the Dayton peace agreement, including the arrest of war crimes suspects. What outsiders cannot do is force Bosnians to live together or cooperate in rebuilding their country.
That is why the withdrawal schedule Mr. Clinton proposes is unacceptably vague. A drawn-out timetable with periodic reviews could become an excuse for staying indefinitely rather than withdrawing as soon as practicable. NATO planners must also be careful not to thin their forces so far as to invite harassment and attack. It would make more sense to set a target for total withdrawal by next summer or fall and not be deflected from it.
Congress approved a one-year assignment of American troops to peacekeeping in Bosnia. Mr. Clinton must present his extension plans, with tightened withdrawal deadlines, to the new Congress for approval in January. Until then, he should seek the consent of the Congressional leadership.
Compared with the pessimistic predictions so common a year ago, the NATO mission in Bosnia has been a clear, if limited success. That success warrants a brief extension. But the Administration still must guard against the danger of open-ended timetables and unrealistic expectations.

HEADLINE: Gold Diggers of 1996;
Nevada Mining Shifts Underground to Get the Deep Ore

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN 

DATELINE: CARLIN, Nev.

 BODY:
More than a thousand feet below the snow-covered hills of northern Nevada, miners toil alone or in pairs in sweltering tunnels separated by absolute darkness. They are digging for gold.
Tom Huhta and Dale Spring work the day shift at the Barrick Gold Corporation's Meikle mine. On a recent morning, sweat poured off their faces as they lifted a traditional two-man jackleg drill to install a metal brace to keep loose rock from falling on them. They were tunneling toward a huge pocket of ore estimated to contain 6.6 million ounces of gold. Steam whistled from cracks and fissures in the 140-degree rock walls. "It's like an oven," Mr. Huhta said. 
 Gold mining in Nevada, which accounts for 60 percent of the gold produced in the United States, is going underground. For 30 years, mining companies have scoured the desert landscape with open pits -- a dozen huge ones have been scooped out of the mountains around Carlin, which is midway between Reno and Salt Lake City.
 But now the companies are returning to the techniques of old because lots of gold lies beneath the hills of Nevada -- more than 100 million ounces, according to the Nevada Mining Association.
The working conditions are tough, but the rewards are high for miners who have the skills and stamina to labor in tunnels 14 feet wide and hundreds of feet below the surface. The rewards are also high for the companies that hire them.
Underground mining has environmental advantages over surface mining because it tears up less land.
But the most striking development is that it is now a seller's market for workers who for decades have roamed the American West in search of work. Mining companies are scrambling to recruit people like Mr. Huhta, 46, who has 28 years of experience in underground mining, and Mr. Spring, 43, with 25 years experience mining uranium, silver and gold.
Now it is recruiters from Barrick, which is based in Toronto, who roam the West, competing for workers with underground mines operated by Newmont Gold, a unit of the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver; Independence Mining, a unit of Minorco (U.S.A.) Inc. of Englewood, Colo., and the Getchell Gold Corporation, also based in Englewood, as well as two new mines opening next year in Nevada. "More than half the mining jobs in Nevada will be underground within 5 to 10 years," said Michael Brown, a Barrick spokesman.
"Wherever there's mining, you go," Debbie Ogden said. A single mother with three daughters, Ms. Ogden drives a front-end loader through the dark tunnels. She moved here from Yuma, Ariz., after the gold mine she had worked in shut down, and hopes to stay here for a while. "The money's good," she said. "And I'm tired of moving around. I got kids in high school, and I want them to graduate."
And Steve Long, the mine supervisor and a fourth-generation miner, said: "Nobody has worked just one place. Typically they've been all around the West." According to the Labor Department, there are 7,467 people employed in underground metal mines and 18,086 working in surface mines, extracting gold, silver, copper and iron. The Gold Institute says around 3,000 are employed in 12 underground gold mines in Alaska, Arizona, Montana, Nevada, South Dakota and Washington. Meikle has 200 of those workers.
Brent Myles, a miner at work with his brother Ernie mucking out a tunnel 1,025 feet down in the Meikle mine, said, "They're all looking for miners." The Myles brothers left northern Idaho two years ago to "hit the mines together" in Nevada after the silver mine where they worked had shut down. Brent Myles worked for Independence, Getchell and Newmont before coming to Barrick.
Underground miners, Mr. Brown said, "can pretty well write their own tickets." Average annual wages for miners in Nevada are $46,000, nearly twice the state's average wage. Surface miners make about $17.50 an hour, but underground miners make $3 to $5 an hour more.
Barrick also offers what Mr. Brown calls a "gold-plated benefits package," which includes full health, dental and vision insurance, 401(k) and pension plans, college scholarships and summer work for children of employees, and for some workers, a chance to buy discounted homes built by the company in nearby Elko. And contrary to mining's image as a high-risk calling, the recent safety record is excellent.
Barrick produces more gold than any other company in the United States, with its open-pit mine a mile from the underground mine turning out two million ounces last year. The Meikle mine is expected to produce 400,000 ounces a year for at least 15 years. The estimate of its reserves comes from a computer model that is based, among other things, on a number of sample drillings.
But gold companies must do more than produce gold to thrive on Wall Street. They must also keep finding new reserves to demonstrate that they can keep on producing it. That is why companies are going ever deeper at existing operations and exploring overseas in search of new mines. The new underground mines in Nevada, as well as discoveries and acquisitions of gold mines in South America, will help the stocks of companies like Barrick and Newmont Mining, said Amy Gassman, metals and mining analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. "Although the ups and downs in the share prices of both companies have roughly followed the vagaries of the price of gold over the last three years," she said, "we think they will continue to add to production," and she rates them both as "market outperformers."
The price of gold has hovered between $350 and $400 an ounce for more than a decade. So in evaluating gold stocks, Ms. Gassman said, analysts watch whether companies are maintaining profitability and "doing better than replacing their reserves with successful discoveries." Underground mines are more expensive to operate per ton of rock moved, she said, but the higher-grade ore found deep down more than makes up for that, actually lowering the per-ounce production costs at some underground mines.
At the Meikle mine, for instance, a ton of ore yields 0.683 ounce of gold, compared with 0.204 ounce at Barrick's Betze-Post open pit next door. As a result, production costs at Meikle are expected to be around $125 an ounce, compared with $149 at Betze-Post. In the first half of this year, the average cost of production for gold mines in the Western world was $272 an ounce.
Because it has been mining here for 10 years, since it bought the property in 1987 for $26 million, Barrick has already built the operations it needs for processing, including a mill and giant ovens for roasting the ore. The company has invested $180 million of the proceeds from its open-pit mine in the Meikle mine.
To ease working conditions underground, the company has installed a $19 million air-conditioning system, Mr. Brown said. That is, he added, "enough to cool 3,000 homes in Las Vegas in the summer" and to try to keep the sauna-like heat at a tolerable 70 degrees.
Back on the surface in an administration building after a trip underground, Andre Bourget, a senior geologist, wrote "ORE" in bright red letters on a bulletin board, indicating that miners had struck gold in a tunnel 975 feet down.
"Here on the Carlin Trend, you can't see the mineralization," Mr. Bourget said, referring to gold deposits within the ore. Although the ore in the Meikle mine is considered high grade, the gold is still invisible to the eye. So samples from the ore are tested daily, and the findings displayed for workers to see. "For the underground worker, muck is muck," Mr. Bourget said. "That's why we use this bulletin board."
About 6.7 million ounces of this "microscopic gold" are mined in Nevada each year, enough to make a solid gold cube seven feet on each side, while the 110 million tons of ore that was taken from the ground to produce that gold would make a cube longer on every side than the Empire State Building is tall. An additional 200 to 300 million tons of waste rock with little or no ore are also removed from open pits each year. That is the main reason even environmentalists agree that returning to old underground mining practices makes sense.
"The impacts are going to be substantially reduced," said Dr. Glenn Miller, a professor of environmental and resource sciences at the University of Nevada in Reno. The mines will no longer create open pits that will eventually fill with water and become sterile or contaminated lakes.
Water, however, will remain a problem in the desert, Dr. Miller said, because the underground mines must still pump ground water away to keep the tunnels from flooding. "That water has to come from someplace," Dr. Miller said, "and that will lower surface-water springs and creeks."
Less than 10 percent of American gold now comes from underground mines, said Dr. John Dobra, an economist and director of the Natural Resource Industry Institute at the University of Nevada in Reno. "But that percentage is going to go up substantially," he said.
That is good for the economy as well as the environment, Dr. Dobra said. "You're disturbing a lot less land, and it's creating high-paying jobs. A lot of people think extractive industries such as mining are a thing of the past. They may be. But while they're here, they're good for the economy."

HEADLINE: House Freshmen Label Themselves Pragmatic

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Remember the last House of Representatives? The one whose Republican Speaker branded Democrats "the enemy of normal Americans?" The one whose Democrats seized the Speaker's chair one night and decorated it with his caricature, clad in a diaper?
Well, never mind. A new class of freshmen legislators, 74 of them at last count, came to Washington this week and declared the war over. They say voters have told them to get along with each other. They pledge to do just that. 
 Revolution, they say, is out. The new buzzwords are "bipartisan" and "pragmatic."
"There are a bunch of things to be done, and let's get on with it," said Christopher Cannon, a Utah Republican and steel-mill entrepreneur elected to his first public office.
"Go up there and make the right decisions for the country," echoed Kay Granger, the former mayor of Fort Worth and Republican claimant of a House seat once held by a Democratic Speaker, Jim Wright.
Some skepticism is permitted. Ms. Granger and Mr. Cannon, along with a vast majority of the newly elected legislators, finished their victory celebrations only last week and took their first steps on the indigo carpet on the House floor just this afternoon. They are assembling in Washington this week and next for a cram course on law-making and survival in the fishbowl of national politics. None of them will try to make a real law until sometime next year.
Still, students of Congress say the deal-cutting attitude of the newest Representatives should not be taken lightly. The last freshman class fairly exuded conservative populism, and it swept Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Congressional elders into a showdown with the White House over spending. This class, of roughly equal size, could exert as much influence in the other direction.
"The kinds of people that were motivated to run two years ago were those who wanted to turn Government upside down; they were angry for same reason voters were angry," said Norman Ornstein, the legislative analyst at American Enterprise Institute. "This time, it takes a different kind of motivation to run. Some of it comes from deeper roots."
In fact, Mr. Ornstein said his own quick study of the new freshman class shows it to have more political experience than the class of 1994, roughly half of whom had never held elective office.
For better or worse, the new class is largely made up of people steeped in more traditional politics -- people like John Peterson, a Republican veteran of 19 years in the Pennsylvania state legislature and an expert on welfare and medical issues, and William J. Pascrell Jr., the Democratic Mayor of Paterson, N.J., and Anne Northup, a Republican in the Kentucky General Assembly.
In an interview today, Mr. Peterson said Republicans in the new class agree with their firebrand predecessors on an agenda of smaller government, lower taxes and less Federal involvement in what is called family issues.
Mr. Peterson did not run as a slash-and-burn budget cutter, though, but as a "thoughtful downsizer of the Federal Government."
"I don't really disagree with the goals of the first Republican Congress," he said. "There just may have been more on their plate than the public could understand."
Mr. Peterson said the freshmen were likely to take things more slowly and with less rancor. He said that the Medicare program was in imminent economic danger and that he supported, in concept, the last Congress's proposal to cut costs and make the system more competitive.
Unlike some Republican leaders who are embittered by President Clinton's attacks on the Republican proposal this campaign season, though, Mr. Peterson said he would solve the problem by letting a bipartisan commission draft a solution that both sides can agree on. If that lets Mr. Clinton off the political hook by relieving him of responsibility for making cuts, he said, so be it.
Ms. Granger agrees. "I'm for solving it," she said of the Medicare financing problem. "Is our goal to find a solution, or is it to hold people accountable?"
One outside expert on Congress's fiscal politics, Robert Reischauer of the Brookings Institution, said he was optimistic enough about the prospects for compromise on such issues that to put the odds of a bipartisan agreement on a plan to balance the Federal budget at three out of four.
"The planets are all aligned," he said.
It evokes memories of another House that painted rosy prospects for harmony, and whose Speaker called on both parties to work together to "do things better and to reach out and to break through the bureaucracy."
"I believe there are grounds for us to talk together and work together, to have hearing together, to have task forces together," the Speaker, Newt Gingrich said, in his first speech as leader of the House, on Jan. 4, 1995.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Interview With Clinton: 'Global Economy' and the U.S.

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton by The New York Times on Thursday, as recorded by the White House:
Q. You've made American engagement with Asia a very high priority in your first term, and certainly today the United States plays a much larger central economic role in the region than it did four years ago. But the flip side of that engagement, as we've seen in the past few weeks, is that the American political process has become a much greater source of interest to Asian business leaders, and much more of a target of their influence. Many of them, of course, see their future prosperity much more tied to decisions that you're making here. Does that increase in foreign contributions that we've seen concern you? And how could you really attempt to stop them at a time that, as you said yourself, the distinction between foreign corporations and domestic ones is almost meaningless? 
 A. I think that if we took the position that adults who can't vote in America shouldn't contribute -- I said that I would support amending the McCain-Feingold bill to include that -- and then either we should say that wholly owned subsidiaries of foreign corporations shouldn't be able to contribute, or at least they could only contribute out of money earned in America, out of their American earnings -- either one of those two options, I think that would reassure the American people on that score. But there are a lot of Asians who do business here who have businesses here, and who have become American citizens. And there are, just like in the case of European businesses that are heavily involved in America, there are a lot of connections and communications in an increasingly interconnected global economy. And that's the world we live in, and that's the world that I want to see America triumph in. . . .
When I became President, what I was concerned about was that, No. 1, America make the most of its relationships with Latin America -- which was the second-fastest growing part of the world, next to Asia -- our neighbors, which is why I was for Nafta and for the Summit of the Americas. And No. 2, I wanted to make sure that we did not get shut out of the emerging markets in Asia or the increasingly unified market of Europe. So that's why I supported the GATT round -- you know, the GATT agreement, and why I worked very hard to set up this Asian Pacific Economic Council as a leaders meeting, not just a ministers meeting, and why I tried to sort of increase American involvement in Asia. And so all of this kind of flows out of that. And there are a lot of people who are international business people that I have either come to know since I've been President, some that I knew before I became President, and those are folks that I met in the course of pursuing this policy.
Q. One of those people is, of course, James Riady. Do you recall, since your election as President, having any conversations with him that would be fair to call policy-related conversations? And if you did, did they touch on China or Indonesia? And did he ever bring up specific business projects or concerns like that with you in meetings since you've been elected?
A. I've seen James briefly a few times since I've been President. And I can tell you what I remember about them. I don't have any notes or anything from the conversations, but I think I have reasonable memory of it. To the best of my memory, he never talked about any specific project that he was involved in. But I knew that he was -- that his business was involved not only in Indonesia but also in China, in other parts of Asia and, of course, in the United States. I mean, I just knew that. I knew it was a big global business. I remember -- really, I've tried to think of this, you know, since all these questions came up -- I remember two things that I think you could fairly call policy related. I saw him briefly in 1993 -- I think he was just through here. You know, we had thousands of people through here in the first six months after I became President, you know, stop and say hello. And I believe he was one of a number of people who encouraged me to see President Suharto when I went to Japan. I'm not positive of it, but I think he must have been if I saw him, because there were a lot of people who were saying that, you know, you ought to see Suharto since you're going over there, since Indonesia is such a large country, and since he was at that time the head of the nonaligned nations. . . .
So I remember that I made a decision that I wanted to see -- that Suharto was going to be in Japan and I wanted to see him and have a bilateral. And a number of people urged me to do it, and I can't imagine that he was not one of them if, in fact, I saw him before that time, and I believe I did.
Then I remember he came back -- then I saw him a couple times after that. He brought his family here once to a radio address. We have, you know, any given year we have hundreds of families come in here and sit at the radio address and have their kids having pictures in the White House and all. He was in town once and did that, but we didn't have any conversation then that I remember.
And I saw him at the APEC meeting in Seattle briefly. And I saw him at the APEC meeting in Indonesia briefly, when I dropped by a reception he was having, I think for some people from the University of Arkansas Medical School, I think who were at the same time, because he kept up his Arkansas contacts. But there was no policy discussion there. Then he came here this year sometime -- just a couple months ago, I think. And we had a talk, a brief talk. I think he stayed here, I don't know, maybe 10, 15 minutes and ----
Q. Here in the Oval Office?
A. Yes. He came by and we talked, and he said that he thought I had done the right thing to extend M.F.N., and that was the right policy, and he urged me to intensify my efforts in China. He said that he thought that the only way to keep China as a constructive player in the future of Asia and to make sure it was integrated with the rest of the world, instead of in opposition or building another power bloc, was for the United States to build a working, constructive partnership. And he pointed out something that I have heard from countless other Chinese-American business leaders, which is that whether this large community of Chinese business people who are located in the United States, in Taiwan, in China, in Indonesia and a lot of other places around the world -- whether they basically identify more with Taiwan or with China in the differences between them, virtually 100 percent of them believe that the United States can do more for the cause of freedom and more for the cause of civility and more for the cause of prosperity by being engaged in China than by being isolated. . . .
Q. Has he served as a go-between between you and the Indonesian Government or the Suharto Government, or with China?
A. Not to my knowledge, no. I don't believe he has. I have conversations with hundreds of people, and I always assume that whatever I say to them they might say to someone else.
Q. But you never asked him to undertake such a liaison?
A. No, not to my knowledge. No, I mean, I did not ask him to do that. He has -- but if I said to him -- let me give you an example. I want to just -- if I said to him, I want a good, strong, positive relationship with China, and my objective is to engage China, not to isolate it -- which is something I have said to many people, mostly American citizens who do business in China, knowing that they might have contacts with people in the Chinese Government -- it would be clear to him and everyone else -- or if I said to him, I want to continue to pursue this relationship and make it ever better, I mean, it wouldn't surprise me if he said that to somebody the next time he was in China because I expect that to be done by -- I mean, a lot of times I do that deliberately knowing that it would be communicated. But that's not any different than I've done with scores of other people in similar situations involving other countries. But he's never sort of become any kind of a, you know, unofficial envoy or something like that.
Q. Your Administration decided two years ago to suspend its investigation of worker rights in Indonesia, after the Indonesian Government made some guarantees to you about improvements. There are very serious questions now about whether a number of those improvements they promised have actually been acted upon. In retrospect, do you think you were too light on Indonesia?
A. I can't answer the question in the sense that I haven't had any kind of report from that from our people over there. What I did on that was I took the recommendations of the N.S.C. They worked it through and I took their recommendations on it. When we came in the one thing I was determined to do was to find a way to promote better relations with a lot of these countries and keep those markets alive for American economic reasons -- and also for political reasons because I thought it would reduce the chances of bad things happening in that part of the world -- without abandoning America's position on human rights.
And I know that, for example, in the East Timor situation, we changed our weapons sales policy to Indonesia and we sponsored -- co-sponsored the United Nations resolution on human rights in East Timor, because I wanted us to be seen as taking a stronger position than the United States had in the past. But I wanted to do it in a way that would maximize our influence and maximize a good outcome over the long run, instead of undercut it. Now, on this particular issue I have received nothing from the N.S.C., nothing coming up through the governmental channels, to indicate that we were in error when we made the decision we made. . . .
Q. Could I ask for your judgment on the topic of whether you wished you had pressed harder in hindsight for campaign finance reform with the Congress during your first term, and whether you share the view of some of your political advisers, at least, that questions about John Huang and the D.N.C. that came to dominate the end of the campaign may have helped keep you below 50 percent in the popular vote, or keep the Democrats from winning the House back?
A. I'm absolutely certain it didn't have anything to do with winning the House back. What kept them from winning the House back is Republicans raised $150 million more than the Democrats. Apparently, they've largely escaped scrutiny for doing it, and that is -- in addition to that they had this huge number of independent expenditure communities who all raised a very disciplined coordinated effort, and we don't know how much more independent expenditure money they had than we do. . . .
In most of these close cases our candidates were outspent three to one in the last five or six days, plus they had the impact of the Christian Coalition. And they're very good in the last week anyway, their base gets out. I think that -- we can digress on the election -- I think the thing that seems to me to have depressed the turnout, one thing is that voters didn't believe that there was a race for President in which the outcome was in doubt, and that seems to have depressed turnout. . . .
In our surveys, our private surveys, I was always at 49 or 50 percent, and for like the last two months. And our people who were doing these surveys said to me, you can get over 50 percent for sure, but to do it you'll have to go to the big states you know you're going to win, but that's where the votes are, and go to these places where you generate a large turnout. For example, I went to Massachusetts, which would have a pretty good turnout anyway because the Kerry-Weld race was very much in doubt. And we went back there because we were asked to go for the Senate race. I went back to Ohio because we had a couple of House races there and because Ohio is always -- almost always the closest big state between Democrats and Republicans if it's a close race. And I wanted to make sure we won. And we increased my margin there from four years ago from two to six points.
But I stayed out of -- like I wanted to -- I stayed out of going back to Missouri, for example, where the Christian Coalition had done a lot of work and the Republicans had done a lot of work and cut our margin there. And instead, I went to New Hampshire, to Maine, to Iowa, to South Dakota. And Mark Penn told me, he says, if you do this, you run a serious chance that you could drop below 50 because in the last two days Senator Dole will be in all these states, and big states. . . .
Q. In the sense of just giving the Republicans an opening, do you regret the other part? I mean, that you didn't have a campaign finance bill in your quiver when you set out for this election?
A. Well, I regret I didn't push harder. Let me remind you, in the first two years, we passed a major budget reform which brought back the economy. We passed a major crime bill and we passed the Nafta trade bill, and we debated health care for several months. There are four huge things.
We had -- now, let me remind you -- we had a vote on a campaign finance bill in the Senate which Senator Dole and the Republicans filibustered and killed. Now, what the Democratic leaders in the House said to me was at that time, in '93 and '94, we're not all that hot for this, but we'll do this, we'll go on and do this even though any bill will probably discriminate against our members who come from very poor districts. That's what they were concerned about. But there's no point in asking us to go to the trouble and do this with all these major issues out there if you can't get by the Senate filibuster.
I mean, everybody has forgotten the fact that the Republicans were not going to permit this to become law. Senator Dole had six filibusters. And it's amazing to me that some people keep saying, if only Bill Clinton had supported these bills more, we could have passed them. No one has explained to me -- I couldn't break a filibuster on the little-bitty -- what do you call it -- the stimulus package at the beginning of our Administration when we had a Democratic Senate in Congress.
So maybe the people who believed as I do on campaign finance reform would have felt better about me -- maybe the press would have -- if I had raised more Cain about in a consistent way, you know, like once a month had a major event about it. But I don't think there is the remotest chance that this bill could have passed in '93, '94, '95 or '96. . . . I mean, I'm prepared to make any effort to pass a good bill, but the Republican Senate now has 55 members and 41 of them can cause a filibuster. So it is up to the leadership of the Senate. I do believe we can now -- I do believe now there's enough play and sort of evenness in the House of Representatives that we could pass a good bill there. I do believe we can do it. But the issue is where it has always been from the day -- at least from the day I took the oath of office and, frankly, for a few years before: Will the Senate let this bill pass, or will it be filibustered. . . .
I hope that Senator Lott and the others and Speaker Gingrich will help us on this. They did not completely shut the door in our conversations with them. I brought it up more than once in our meeting here. And I understand they have some concerns of their own, but I do believe we all have a responsibility to do more. And I'll tell you what I have determined to do. I at least am going to keep bringing this up and bringing it up and bringing it up so that the American people will know how it is being dealt with.
If I made an error in the first two years, I think it was in not just keeping it on the front burner of the debate to at least make it more difficult for them to keep filibustering it. I can do that and I will do that. I thought we had -- I really believed we were going to get a bill when Speaker Gingrich and I shook hands in New Hampshire. I thought we would get it then. But I do think now we're in a position where we can pass a bill in the House, it would be a good bill, and I think that it's now a question of whether we can stop the Senate filibuster. I think it's also incumbent on those of us who believe in this, though, to level with the American people.
The two Supreme Court decisions, Buckley against Valeo 20 years ago and this decision I guess earlier this year, weaken our ability to do what really needs to be done now, because Buckley v. Valeo says you can't limit how much people spend and you can't limit how much an individual spends on his or her own race. We can deal with that to some extent by saying that you get free air time if you adhere to certain spending limits and if you don't spend more than x-amount of your own money on a race. You can write a bill that does that, and you can do what McCain-Feingold does -- you can say you get free air time. And then, if your opponent goes above the spending limits by a certain amount, you can raise a little more; that will be better. I, frankly, don't know what the answer is to this independent expenditure problem.
In terms of the international element here, you know, whether you're talking about European cigarette companies or Asian business leaders, I think it's important -- you can measure the policies of the parties, these are all party contributions -- you can measure the policies of the parties and draw your own conclusions and report that to the American people and they can draw their own conclusions about whether the contributions are having any impact or not, or whether the contributions are just following pre-existing policies. But the really important thing here I think is to clean up the campaign finance system so that the contributions don't have to be so vast. . . .
Q. John Huang, who you had described in L.A. at your fund-raiser, was a very good friend, went to Taiwan at one point to raise money earlier this year. It was at a time that the U.S. was still in the midst of this confrontation between China and Taiwan. Do you think it's appropriate for fund-raisers from either party to be soliciting donations from overseas?
A. No. I didn't know about that. I would have counseled against that and I would have told the Democratic Party not to do it, had I known about it. Now, there are a lot of people from Taiwan that have businesses in America. They may have legitimate operations here. They may have corporations here that could legally give. But I think, and I can assure you, that none of that had any impact on what I did in the crisis.
Q. Actually, it came after the crisis and it raised the question of whether it was playing off of what you had just done.
A. Oh. See, I didn't know that. But in any case, I just don't think that's wise. And if the Republicans did it, I don't think they should have done it. I just think that we ought to finance our campaigns in America and we ought to recognize that it's a good thing we have so many Americans who are from other ethnic groups, and when they're citizens I think we ought to encourage them to contribute. I have been, as I've said before, discouraged a little bit and disappointed in the general sort of anti-Asian tenor of a lot of the rhetoric that's come out of this affair, because this country is a better country because of the Asian-American immigrants, and most of them work hard and give more than they take to any endeavor.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Texaco Agrees to Settle Discrimination Suit
In the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case, Texaco agreed to pay more than $140 million to resolve a suit brought by employees. It also agreed to make changes in the way it does business, including a plan to turn over authority for revamping its personnel operations to a committee chosen largely by outsiders.
The settlement came after two weeks of furor following the disclosure that executives had been taped planning to destroy documents demanded in the suit and disparaging minority groups. The Rev. Jesse Jackson said that the settlement was an important first step but that for now his call for a boycott of Texaco remained in effect. [Page 1.]
 
Time Warner Seeks to Halt Satellite
Time Warner is taking its feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to the skies. Time Warner is urging the F.C.C. to withhold approval of MCI's application for a license to operate a satellite in its direct broadcast TV venture with the News Corporation. [39.]
 
Time Warner is also moving into the Times Square skyline. The company's Warner Brothers unit said it would lease One Times Square, the tower that anchors Manhattan's theater district and serves as a national symbol of New Year's Eve revelry for its stroke-of-midnight ball-drop. A retail store is planned for the lower floors. [25.]
 
Industrial Production Drops
The output of the nation's factories fell by half of 1 percent in October, the first drop in seven months, as strikes at General Motors slowed production while some businesses were trimming inventories. [38.]

A Fidelity Fund Executive Resigns
Fidelity Investments, which has seen its market share stop growing and has faced investor unrest over the lagging performance of some of its top mutual funds, has lost another senior executive. Neal Litvack, who for four years had charted the rapid growth of Fidelity's retail fund business, has quit. [39.]

Near Unanimity by Fed on Rates
At their September meeting, members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making body voted 11 to 1 to hold interest rates steady, saying they were wary about an outbreak of inflation but finding little evidence that it was occurring, the minutes showed. [38.]

Bond Traders Take Gains
The Treasury market weakened as investors took profits after the strong gains this week. The 30-year bond's yield rose to 6.46 percent from 6.42 percent on Thursday. A week ago the yield was 6.50 percent. [41.]
 
Copper prices surged as a decline in stockpiles at the London Metal Exchange muted speculation that copper in unregistered Dutch warehouses would flood the market. [40.]

The dollar fell against the yen, dropping to 110.88 yen from 111.22 on Thursday, amid doubts that Japan and the United States are committed to a stronger dollar. The drop came despite comments by American, Japanese and German officials in support of the dollar. [40.]
 
Honda Sales and Earnings Surge
Honda said its earnings soared nearly 300 percent in the fiscal first half. Sales in the United States were so strong that Honda ran out of one model, the Civic, and will temporarily import Civics from Japan to augment North American production. Another Japanese auto maker, Mazda, reported improved results, too, although in its case that meant only a slim profit. [50.]
 
California Rule on Strain Injuries
California regulators approved the nation's first law intended to curb repetitive strain injuries, which afflict workers in fields from computer programming to meat packing. The measure requires many employers to provide injured workers with special training, to alter their work routines and to change their work stations or tools, if necessary. [12.]
 
New Airline Fire Rules Sought
The Transportation Department has decided to seek new rules requiring fire safety equipment in all airline cargo compartments, on the eve of hearings into the May crash of a Valujet DC-9 that some investigators say could have been prevented by such equipment. [13.]

HEADLINE: U.S. READY TO KEEP A FORCE IN BOSNIA 18 MONTHS LONGER

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Saying Bosnia still reaps "a bitter harvest of hatred," President Clinton announced today that the United States was prepared to keep thousands of troops in the shattered Balkan nation for an additional 18 months.
Nearly one year after telling the American people that United States troops would serve in Bosnia for about one year, Mr. Clinton said he was informing the NATO alliance that "in principle, the United States will take part in a follow-on force in Bosnia" to protect the fragile peace. 
 "Quite frankly, rebuilding the fabric of Bosnia's economic and political life is taking longer than anticipated," he said. "Economic activity is only just resuming. Its pace must be quickened and its reach extended." [Excerpts, page 7.]
Mr. Clinton said this NATO mission would initially require 8,500 United States troops. He said that by the end of 1997, he expected the force to be reduced by about half, with full withdrawal envisioned for June 1998.
A year ago, 20,000 United States troops were sent to Bosnia, and the American contingent of the NATO force there now numbers 14,000.
In a White House appearance today before embarking on a 12-day trip to Hawaii, Australia and Asia, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the continued stay in Bosnia -- as well as his separate offer to contribute troops for a relief mission to Central Africa -- would not be without risk.
"I will do everything in my power to minimize the risks by making sure both missions are clear and achievable before I give the green light," he said.
He also deflected a question about his failure to name appointees to national security positions before leaving Washington. He said he wanted time to assess the full team "because it is the team that will rise or fall and will advance America's cause."
Today, with Congress out of session, the reaction on Capitol Hill was muted, although there was some criticism from both parties.
Senator Daniel R. Coats, an Indiana Republican, accused Mr. Clinton of mounting a "seat-of-the-pants, reactive foreign policy" with ill-defined goals. But he said lawmakers, who provide funds for the mission, probably would not oppose the continued Bosnia deployment.
Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Wisconsin Democrat, said, "The United States continues to be drawn deeper and deeper into a situation from which we appear unable to extricate ourselves."
In an appearance before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Oct. 3, Defense Secretary William J. Perry rejected charges from skeptical Republicans that the Administration was delaying until after the Presidential election a decision to deploy more American troops to Bosnia for an extended period.
Apparently in anticipation of today's announcement, the chairman of the House National Security Committee, Representative Floyd D. Spence, issued a statement on Thursday accusing Mr. Clinton of having always planned to extend the United States deployment.
"After spending the better part of the year evading the question," said Mr. Spence, a Republican from South Carolina, "the Clinton Administration appears ready to finally own up to the fact that it was never serious about its commitment to limit U.S. involvement in Bosnia to one year."
He said conditions there suggest "the presence of significant military forces will be necessary for years."
United States officials had quietly acknowledged for weeks that the Administration was prepared to take part in some kind of continuing NATO force in Bosnia. But drawing criticism from Republicans that he was dodging the issue, Mr. Clinton made no effort to prepare the American public for this in the weeks leading up to Election Day.
Mr. Clinton said today that part of the reason he had not discussed further troop deployments to Bosnia during the campaign was because his opponent, Bob Dole, had ultimately supported the troop deployment last year. "There was not a difference of opinion on it," he said."I think it did not become more hotly debated in the campaign, and therefore it maybe wasn't focused on by as many people."
He also said NATO planning for the new mission was not complete at then. "I couldn't agree and describe a mission that had not yet been developed by NATO military planners or recommended to us," he said.
Critics of the original Bosnia deployment had said the Administration had no clear exit strategy and would be bogged down in Bosnia far longer than the year the President had promised. Mr. Clinton contended today that the original NATO force in Bosnia had fulfilled its mission of maintaining the cease-fire and allowing elections and would pull out, as scheduled, on Dec. 20.
The new force, he said, would have a more limited mandate and require fewer troops because it would not be charged with separating two hostile armies but only with keeping a stabilizing presence in Bosnia.
"The new mission's focus should be to prevent a resumption of hostilities so that economic reconstruction and political reconciliation can accelerate," he said.
Mr. Perry summed up the situation more succinctly. "The operation was a success, but the patient is still in danger of dying," he said at a Pentagon briefing.
Mr. Perry also acknowledged that the original estimate of a one-year mission had been an "error in judgment." He said the Pentagon had been correct in estimating the resistance that troops would meet and in minimizing casualties.
But he added, "I was wrong, particularly in my belief that having done those tasks, we would have established the conditions which would allow us to leave Bosnia."
He noted that war refugees had not been resettled, that municipal elections have not been conducted and that an issue left hanging in the Dayton peace accord -- the final status of the Serbian-held town of Brcko -- had not been resolved.
Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the AMerican troops would be part of a multinational force of 31,000 troops, 5,000 of them stationed outside of Bosnia. The 8,500 American troops would all be within Bosnian borders.
After one year, the general said, the international force would be reduced to 13,500 troops stationed inside Bosnia and 9,000 in neighboring countries who could move in if needed. The United States troop contribution would drop to 5,500. The goal would be a complete withdrawal by June of 1998. General Shalikashvili said the situation in Bosnia would be assessed every six months.

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ADMITS HE AND INDONESIAN HAD POLICY TALKS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton has acknowledged in an interview that he twice discussed policy about Indonesia and China with James T. Riady, the Indonesian financier, Democratic contributor and longtime friend of Mr. Clinton who is at the center of several inquiries into the influence of foreign money in Washington.
In a 30-minute interview in the Oval Office on Thursday evening, Mr. Clinton said Mr. Riady had never influenced policy decisions. But he also said it had been a mistake for the Democratic National Committee to send John Huang, a former employee of Mr. Riady, and, until last year, a midlevel Commerce Department official, to Taiwan to raise money for the 1996 campaigns. Mr. Huang's visit came several months after Mr. Clinton sent two aircraft carriers to protect Taiwan from Chinese military harassment earlier this year, and there has been speculation that he sought to capitalize on Mr. Clinton's action to protect the island nation. 
 Mr. Clinton said he had not known about that trip by Mr. Huang before it took place. "I would have counseled against that," he said.
Mr. Clinton's description of his relationship with Mr. Riady was his first detailed response to the accusations of influence peddling and improper campaign contributions that flared up in the last weeks of the campaign. A month ago, the White House described Mr. Riady's visits as purely social. Later, it corrected that to suggest that there had been some general discussion of China.
Today, just hours before Mr. Clinton departed for Hawaii, Australia and a summit meeting of Asian leaders in Manila, the White House released a flood of details about visits to the White House by Mr. Riady, Mr. Huang and others involved in the inquiries under way at the Justice Department and on Capitol Hill. The information, mostly about entry logs kept by the Secret Service, was released as part of the Administration's effort to quell questions of possible improprieties. The logs, the White House said, suggest that most of the visits were for briefings, receptions or meetings with midlevel officials with little connection to Asian policy issues. [Page 10.]
But the White House also said that at a meeting between Mr. Clinton, Mr. Riady and Mr. Huang in September 1995, Mr. Huang said he could better serve the President by leaving the Commerce Department for the Democratic National Committee. He did exactly that three months later, and he solicited several major donations the Democrats have since had to return because of suspicions that they came from foreign sources.
A bit more than a week after his decisive defeat of Bob Dole, and with the benefit of time to reflect on how he will deal with Republican majorities in both chambers of Congress, the President seemed somewhat sardonic when he turned the discussion to Republican fund raising. He was irked that contributions to the opposing party had "escaped scrutiny."
He disagreed with the analysis, offered by some of his own aides and Cabinet members, that news accounts of the Democratic National Committee's return of several hundred thousand dollars in illegal funds from abroad had deprived him of a popular vote of 50 percent or more and that it had cost him a Democratic majority in the House.
"What kept them from winning the House back," he said of his own party, "is Republicans raised $150 million more than the Democrats."
Looking relaxed but choosing his words deliberately as he sat in front of the fireplace in the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton seemed on several occasions to be searching his memory to recall several encounters with Mr. Riady, whom he first met when the Indonesian businessman moved to Arkansas more than a decade ago. Today, from its corporate headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, Mr. Riady's family runs the Lippo Group, which has banking, energy and real estate interests in Indonesia, China and the United States.
Mr. Clinton described two social encounters with Mr. Riady at summit meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. But he recalled in particular a visit to the Oval Office soon after he took office. Mr. Riady, he said, was among those "who encouraged me to see President Suharto" of Indonesia at a summit meeting in Tokyo in 1993, when Mr. Suharto was still the head of the nonaligned nations.
That meeting ushered in warmer relations between the two countries, and Mr. Clinton said he wanted "to reach out to the whole nonaligned movement and especially to the Islamic nations in it who had not given over to fundamentalism and extreme anti-Americanism."
The President said Mr. Riady had requested the meetings and brought up the policy issues himself. Interviews with Mr. Riady's associates and competitors in recent weeks suggest that the meeting may have also helped solidify Mr. Riady's standing back home with the Suharto Government, which often viewed with suspicion the conglomerates run by ethnic Chinese that control much of the nation's wealth.
At another Oval Office meeting two months ago, Mr. Clinton said, Mr. Riady congratulated him for his policy toward China, including the decision to separate China's trading privileges from human rights concerns, and he "urged me to intensify my efforts in China." The Administration will be doing that next week, in meetings between several Cabinet officials, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, and senior Chinese officials. Those meetings will culminate in Mr. Clinton's meeting with President Jiang Zemin in Manila next weekend.
Mr. Clinton did not discuss Mr. Riady's possible motives in raising policy questions, though he said he was fully aware that the financier's corporate empire spanned many of Asia's fastest-growing economies. He said he had never used his friend as a liaison to the Indonesian or the Chinese Governments.
In the next breath, though, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that if he said to Mr. Riady "my objective is to engage China, not to isolate it, which is something I have said to many people," it was with the expectation that Mr. Riady might relate the discussion to Chinese leaders.
"I mean, a lot of times I do that deliberately knowing that it would be communicated," he said. "But that's not any different than I've done with scores of other people in similar situations involving other countries."
Asked about whether his Administration had dealt too lightly with Indonesia -- especially in the areas of workers' rights and the suppression of dissent on East Timor -- Mr. Clinton responded that he had restricted the kinds of weapons sold to Mr. Suharto's armed forces and "co-sponsored the United Nations resolution on human rights in East Timor because I want us to be seen as taking a stronger position than the United States had in the past." But he said he was unaware of growing concerns among human rights groups that Indonesia had not fully complied with several commitments to the Administration about the treatment of Indonesian workers.
"Nobody has said anything to me," he said.
Mr. Clinton talked at length about the last days of the campaign, asserting that he could have reached 50 percent of the popular vote if he had chosen to campaign differently. "Our people who were doing these surveys said to me, You can get over 50 percent for sure, but to do it, you'll have to go to the big states you know you are going to win" to insure a larger turnout, Mr. Clinton said. Instead, he said, he chose to visit places where there were close House races.
He said, "I regret I didn't push harder" for campaign finance reform in the first term, though he quickly insisted that "everybody has forgotten the fact that the Republicans were not going to permit this" to become law. "If I made an error in the first two years," he said, "I think it was in not just keeping it on the front burner of the debate to at least make it more difficult for them to keep filibustering it." But he said he would use his office to keep returning to the issue in his second term.
Mr. Clinton suggested two approaches to dealing with foreign corporate contributions: banning the American subsidiaries of foreign companies from all political donations or forcing them to "contribute out of the money earned in America." The first would result in some oddities: AT&T would be able to contribute, for example, but not M.C.I., at least if its planned acquisition by British Telecom is completed.
The second condition -- contributions from American earnings -- is roughly the current law.
Mr. Clinton said the Democratic Party needed to have "a tighter screen and checking this money as it comes in." In fact, it had such a screen in the last campaign, and it apparently abandoned the system when it was overwhelmed with contributions this year.
Mr. Clinton's harshest words for his own party came in relation to Mr. Huang's trip to his native Taiwan, which Mr. Huang said was intended to get contributions from Taiwanese-Americans doing business in both countries. "I just think we ought to finance our campaigns in America," Mr. Clinton said, "and we ought to recognize that it's a good thing we have so many Americans who are from other ethnic groups, and when they're citizens, I think we ought to encourage them to contribute."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
