HEADLINE: A CHRONOLOGY;
One Times Square: Historic Highlights

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:

1904 -- The building, known as Times Tower, is completed by The New York Times at the south end of Long Acre Square, which is renamed Times Square. The Times boasts that its building is the tallest in New York City, which is true only if several subbasements extending far underground are counted.
 
1905 -- At midnight, The Times sponsors a New Year's Eve celebration at the base of its new building. It becomes an annual rite, growing in popularity and boisterousness. 

1913 -- The Times moves its headquarters and begins transferring other operations to a larger building on West 43d Street, which it still occupies. (The company continues to own Times Tower until 1961.)
 
1928 -- The world's first Motogram, later known as the Zipper, begins operation, delivering five-foot-high flashing messages around a 360-foot-long track around Times Tower.
 
1945 -- On Aug. 14, at 7:03 P.M., with thousands crammed into Times Square, a Times electrician, Jim Torpey, embellishes one of the most historic messages to be sent along the Zipper, adding three stars -- for the United States Army, Navy and Air Force -- before and after the five-word phrase, "OFFICIAL TRUMAN ANNOUNCES JAPANESE SURRENDER."
 
1965 -- A new owner, the Allied Chemical Company, renames the building the Allied Chemical Tower, obliterates its elegant terra cotta exterior and sheaths the tower in white marble, with only the Zipper retained as a reminder of its past. Many are appalled, but supporters describe the change as the first step in the renewal of Times Square.
 
1986 -- City and state economic development officials, preparing to condemn dozens of buildings along 42d Street, Broadway and Eighth Avenue as part of the redevelopment of Times Square, consider taking title to One Times Square and tearing it down. They decide to let it stand.
 
1990 -- The Jumbotron, an oversized television screen, is hung from the north face of the building, and operates until June 1996. (A larger version is to be installed by Dec. 31.) THOMAS J. LUECK

GRAPHIC: Photos: The lighting of the new sign atop Times Tower, 1951. The Times Tower on New Year's Eve, 1953. One Times Square, 1996. (Photographs by The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Chronology

HEADLINE: Remarks by President on Bosnia and Central Africa

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Clinton's statement on Bosnia and Central Africa made at the White House today:
One year ago in Dayton, the leaders of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia turned from the horror of war to the promise of peace. Their historic decision came after nearly four years of horrible bloodshed, the bloodiest conflict Europe has seen since World War II; after a quarter-million deaths, after 2 million people were made refugees, after countless atrocities that shocked the conscience of the world. 
 When the Balkan leaders chose peace, I asked the American people to help them by supporting the participation of our troops in a NATO-led implementation force to secure the Dayton agreement. I promised the mission would be carefully defined with clear and realistic goals. I said it would be completed in about a year.
IFOR has succeeded beyond our expectations. As a result, its mission will end as planned on Dec. 20, and every single item on IFOR's military checklist has been accomplished. It has maintained the cease-fire and separated the parties along a new demilitarized zone.
It has monitored the placement of thousands of heavy weapons in holding areas, overseen a massive troop demobilization and the transfer of hundreds of square miles of territory from one side to another, and allowed the people of Bosnia to vote in free national elections.
That has been a remarkable achievement. In the process, we have seen how important and effective the NATO alliance remains, and we have seen the possibilities for cooperation with Russia and the other members of the Partnership for Peace.
Today the Bosnian people are far better off than they were a year ago. Their prospects for a future of peace and freedom are much brighter. Already the change in the day-to-day lives of the people there is dramatic. Marketplaces are full of life, not death. More people have roofs over their head, food on their tables, heat and hot water.
The routines of normal life -- going to work, coming home from school -- are slowly becoming a reality. Bosnia's bitter harvest of hatred, however, has not yet disappeared. For the last 12 months, the killing has stopped. And with time, the habits of peace can take hold.
This success we owe to IFOR, but its achievements on the military side have not been matched, despite all our efforts, by similar progress on the civilian side. Quite frankly, rebuilding the fabric of Bosnia's economic and political life is taking longer than anticipated. Economic activity is only just resuming. Its pace must be quickened and its reach extended.
The presidency, the parliament, the constitutional court created by the elections are still in their infancy. They need time to work. Civilian police forces must be better trained. We must complete training and equipping the Bosnian Federation military so that a stable balance of power can take hold and renewed aggression is less likely. And municipal elections remain to be organized and held.
Let me emphasize that the Bosnian people, with the help of international civilian groups, will be responsible for all this work, but for a time they will need the stability and the confidence that only an outside security force can provide.
NATO has been studying options to give them the help that time will provide by providing a new security presence in Bosnia when IFOR withdraws. That study is now complete. I have carefully reviewed its options, and I have decided to instruct the United States' representative to NATO to inform our allies that in principle the United States will take part in a follow-on force in Bosnia.
For my agreement in principle to become a commitment, however, I must be satisfied that the final recommendation NATO adopts and the operational plan it develops are clear, limited and achievable.
The new mission's focus should be to prevent a resumption of hostilities, so that economic reconstruction and political reconciliation can accelerate. That will require a strong but limited military presence in Bosnia, able to respond quickly and decisively to any violations of the cease-fire.
The new mission will be more limited than IFOR and will require fewer troops. It will not face the fundamental military challenge of separating two hostile armies, because IFOR has accomplished that task. It will be charged with working to maintain the stability that IFOR created. It will discourage the parties from taking up arms again, while encouraging them to assume full responsibility for their own security as quickly as possible. . . .
Our military planners have concluded that this new mission will require fewer than half the number of troops we contributed to IFOR -- about 8,500. There will be an American commander and tough rules of engagement. Every six months we will review the stability -- whether the stability can be maintained with fewer forces.
By the end of 1997, we expect to drawn down to a much smaller deterrent force about half the initial size. And we will propose to our NATO allies that by June of 1998 the mission's work should be done and the forces should be able to withdraw.
The United States cannot and should not try to solve every problem in the world. But where our interests are clear and our values are at stake, where we can make a difference, we, we must act and we must lead. Clearly, Bosnia is such an example.
Every American should be proud of the difference the United States has already made in Bosnia -- ending a terrible slaughter, saving thousands of lives, securing countless futures. We have a responsibility to see that commitment through. . . .
Earlier this week, I also decided that in principle the United States should take part in an international humanitarian effort to be part of a relief force that Canada will lead in Zaire. Two years ago, following genocide in Rwanda, more than a million Rwandans fled for Zaire. Recently their plight has worsened as fighting among militant forces has driven them from their camps. Violence has begun to spiral out of control, preventing relief agencies from providing food and medicine to the refugees, who are now vulnerable to starvation and to disease.
The world's most powerful nation must not turn its back on so many desperate people and so many innocent children who are now at risk. The mission Canada proposes to lead, and that I believe America should take part in, would provide security for civilian relief agencies to deliver the aid these people must have and to help the refugees who so desire to return home to Rwanda. . . .
Neither the new security force in Bosnia nor the humanitarian relief effort in Zaire will be free of risk, but I will do everything in my power to minimize the risks by making sure both missions are clear and achievable before I give the green light.
American leadership places a special burden on the men and women of our armed forces and their families. We ask a lot from them, and without fail, they deliver for us.
Now as we contemplate calling on them again, I ask us first of all to remember the astonishing job that they have done remarkably free of violence in Bosnia, and I ask that every American keep them in their thoughts and prayers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Texaco to Make Record Payout In Bias Lawsuit

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
In the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case, Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to pay more than $140 million to resolve a Federal lawsuit brought by its minority employees.
The company also agreed to adopt a number of changes in the way it does business, including a plan to turn over authority for revamping its personnel operations to a new committee largely appointed by outsiders. Plaintiffs' lawyers in the case valued the cost of those concessions at an additional $35 million. 
 The settlement of the suit, which had been in Federal court for more than two years, came after two weeks of intense furor following the disclosure that senior company executives had been caught on tape planning the destruction of documents demanded in the suit and disparaging minority groups.
Since then there have been widespread calls for a boycott of Texaco, including one earlier this week by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Jackson yesterday called the settlement an important step, but did not cancel the boycott. He said that he would be talking to other civil rights leaders and that a decision about proceeding with the effort could be announced as soon as today.
Civil rights leaders praised the settlement yesterday, but stressed that Texaco still had much work to do to resolve its difficulties with the minority community.
"By settling this longstanding discrimination case, Texaco has met our first demand in moving toward resolution of this matter," said Kweisi Mfume, president and chief executive of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "But I caution this is only a first step on a long path toward racial reconciliation."
Some supporters of the boycott said the settlement should be seen as an important sign of good faith.
"I think giving Texaco a little room to maneuver is appropriate," said the Rev. Charles Stith, head of the Organization for a New Equality, a national civil rights group based in Boston. "But we don't need to go to sleep and celebrate yet."
In a statement, Peter I. Bijur, Texaco's chairman, said that the company's reform efforts would not stop with the settlement. He said its goal was to become a model of equal opportunity for employees.
"Texaco is committed to developing and instituting specific, effective policies that will insure that discrimination is wiped out wherever it may be, and that will expand the positive economic impact we can have on the minority community," he said. "These policies will be clearly defined and achievable -- with measurable goals set out with specific timetables."
Employment lawyers and civil rights advocates hailed the outcome as an important precedent, one that was likely to be held up in the future in efforts to push corporations toward developing effective affirmative action and diversity programs.
"We think we have reached another historic landmark in the struggle for equal employment opportunities for minorities," said Michael Hausfeld, a lawyer for the plaintiffs.
Lawyers outside the case agreed. "This is obviously a very significant settlement, and one that should have an extremely positive impact on corporate America," said Barry Goldstein, an employment lawyer. "Unfortunately, the way to get the attention of a lot of companies to insure that they remain committed to equal employment opportunities is to have the club of a very significant judgment hanging over their head."
The settlement touches on almost every element of the company's relationship with its minority employees.
Of the cash portion, $115 million will be paid into a pool for the benefit of Texaco's minority employees. The company will also grant pay increases of about 10 percent to those employees; plaintiffs' lawyers estimated that would cost about $26.1 million over five years.
Those figures are before legal fees, so the total amount that will be received by each of Texaco's almost 1,500 minority employees cannot yet be calculated.
The company will also establish a task force to revise Texaco's human resources policies. Over a period of five years, the task force will have the authority to evaluate employment policies and practices and to develop new procedures on hiring and promoting minority workers.
Among the first efforts to be overseen by the task force will be aiding in the adoption of a diversity and sensitivity-training program, as well as a mentoring program. Diversity performance will be included in management objectives and used in determining compensation for managers. National job postings will be required for certain senior positions to insure that minority employees have the opportunity to apply.
The task force will also supervise the scrapping of a number of policies that were at the heart of the discrimination case, including practices for evaluating employees and the use of secret lists to designate which employees had the potential to be senior managers. Those policies were criticized in the lawsuit as subjective impediments to the advancement of minority employees.
"This is a task force with teeth," said Daniel Berger, a plaintiffs' lawyer. "I think it's unprecedented."
Mr. Berger said the settlement negotiations began last week, one day after The New York Times disclosed the existence of the tape recordings of senior executives discussing document destruction and criticizing nonwhite employees. The tapes were secretly recorded by a Texaco executive, who turned them over to the plaintiffs after he was forced out of the company in August.
Plaintiffs expressed deep satisfaction at the outcome. "I feel relieved," said Beri-Ellen Roberts, a senior financial analyst at Texaco. "I feel justice has been served. We have been validated."
Sil Chambers, also a senior financial analyst, said the tapes underscored the reality faced by minority employees at Texaco.
"The tapes showed there was a lot more going on at Texaco than people thought," he said.
The settlement is subject to approval by the Federal District Court in White Plains. One other potential roadblock remains: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which enforces affirmative action programs, said on Thursday that it, not the plaintiffs' lawyers, was the representative of Texaco's minority employees and had sole power to reach a settlement.
While both sides discounted that position, the agency's chairman expressed annoyance that it was not included in the negotiations.
"Any settlement reached on behalf of the class requires court approval, and only the E.E.O.C. represents the public interest here," said Gilbert F. Casellas, chairman of the agency. "We have to weigh in; we are a critical player. And we have not been a party to the critical discussions."
Officials also said that regardless of what happened with the suit, the agency was not precluded from taking its own action against Texaco. "The interests of the agency are independent of the private interests," said Claire Gonzales, an agency spokeswoman. "So we could still file our own suit separate from the private action."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 18, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about the settlement in the racial discrimination lawsuit against Texaco Inc. misstated the surname of one plaintiff in some editions. A picture caption with the continuation of the article repeated the error in some editions. The plaintiff is Sil Chambers, not Roberts.

HEADLINE: The New Science

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb is a member of the editorial staff of The Economist. He is writing a history of Western philosophy.

 BODY:

THE SCIENTIFIC REVOLUTION
By Steven Shapin.
Illustrated. 218 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $19.95. 
 "There was no such thing as the Scientific Revolution, and this is a book about it." With this arch opening to his masterly essay, Steven Shapin wastes no time in telling us where he is coming from. He is, or so it would seem, a full member of the hip-revisionist school of historians of science. This is a gang of sociologists and near sociologists -- now somewhat mellowing with age -- who investigate science as a cultural and political phenomenon, and who sometimes leave the impression, or even explicitly assert, that it is nothing more than that. The idea that science also happens to uncover truths about nature is, by the lights of this school, distinctly uncool. And so, therefore, is the idea that science began to uncover them at a rapidly accelerating rate in the late 16th and 17th centuries, the period that conventional historians know as the Scientific Revolution.
But the hip-revisionist stance is only a pose for Mr. Shapin, a professor of sociology at the University of California, San Diego, and he does not strike it for very long. It soon emerges that he does not believe his own first sentence and that he is in fact quite happy with the idea that Galileo and Newton took part in what can fairly be described as a revolution. The revisionist influence leaves its mark only in an occasional turn of phrase (as when he speaks of some scientific facts as being "made" rather than discovered) and in his inclusion of some background material that a more austere generation of historians regarded as scientifically irrelevant. Nowhere does Mr. Shapin follow the more extreme of his colleagues in allowing a sociological perspective to distort the story he has to tell. Instead, that perspective enriches it.
As Mr. Shapin notes, it was not until the late 1930's that historians began to speak of "the Scientific Revolution." He cites several reasons for believing that this coinage was a misnomer. The gist of the revisionist argument on this point is that close examination reveals no precise, datable event when the world changed, no one "essence" of the supposedly new way of investigating nature and no well-defined subject area at the time that could be called "science." All true, and all economically established in this book. But so what? Anyone who infers from such considerations that there was no such thing as the Scientific Revolution is open to the charge that he cannot see the forest for the trees.
Actually, Mr. Shapin can see the forest all right; he is just sometimes curiously unwilling to call it one. For example, although he insists that what is called a revolution had no "essence," his concluding section focuses on a theme "that has run throughout this narrative and that connects our understanding of the Scientific Revolution" -- whoops, he said it -- "to some fundamental categories and evaluations of our present-day culture." This theme is the "depersonalization" of nature, which he earlier glosses as "the growing separation between human subjects and the natural objects of their knowledge, especially as evinced in the distinction between mundane human experience and views of what nature 'is really like.' " As Mr. Shapin explains, this idea of science as the reliable product of disinterested and dispassionate inquiry went hand in hand with the idea that such knowledge could be a tool for improving the human lot. This new way of looking at science and the world began to flower in the 17th century, and it marks the biggest difference between modern science and its ancient and medieval antecedents. If you are not too fussy, you might call it the essence of the Scientific Revolution.
Mr. Shapin's narrative picks out four related aspects of what at the time was often referred to as "the new philosophy." First, the conception of nature as a machine. Second, the conception of natural knowledge as something more objective than everyday experience. Third, the effort to make science methodical and impartial. Fourth, the hope that it could thereby serve beneficial social and political ends. His first chapter, entitled "What Was Known?," is a crisp encapsulation of the mechanistic science of Galileo and his successors in the 17th century, ranging from Galileo's assault on the Aristotelian world picture to Newton's attempts to paint a new one. This is well done, and always useful to be reminded of. How many readers of today's popular-science books, uncomprehending in the latest speculative arcana of physics, have a grasp of the basic historical foundations of the subject? They are unlikely to find a better-informed or more digestible crash course in what they need to know than Mr. Shapin's first 50 pages here.
HIS next chapter -- "How Was It Known?" -- deals with the methods of acquiring and establishing scientific knowledge. This nuanced account draws partly on the materials of Mr. Shapin's earlier academic studies, which covered Boyle's vacuum experiments and the question of why fellow scientists and some laymen were content to trust their colleagues' report of such work. Delving into the details of how experimental results and new theories were put together and then evaluated by others can be dangerously misleading. It can easily give the erroneous impression that such results are necessarily less impersonal and objective than they pretend to be. But when skillfully done, as it is here, this style of historical writing is benign and fascinating.
The final chapter -- "What Was the Knowledge For?" -- mostly tells us about how the advocates of the new science saw their creation and what they hoped to get out of it. Much of this part of the story is tied up with religion in one way or another. We see the new institutions and practices of 17th-century science eating into the fabric of the church-dominated educational structures left over from medieval times. We see the discredited idea that nature acts for a purpose become transformed into the idea that nature is a machine that, although acting blindly itself, was nevertheless designed by a God for His own purposes. And we see wild new hopes that man is on the brink of restoring the dominion over nature that he lost at the Fall of Adam and Eve. Most readers will conclude that there was indeed something dramatic enough to be called the Scientific Revolution going on, and that this is an excellent book about it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: SCIENTIFIC REVOLUTION, THE (BOOK)

HEADLINE: The Big Man Can Deal

BYLINE: By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg is a contributing writer for the Magazine. Her last article was about Burt Reynolds.

 BODY:
MICHAEL JORDAN, DRESSED IMPECCABLY in a gray suit, royal blue polo sweater, no socks and two-tone loafers, is sprawled elegantly in a chair at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan. He appears to be back-lit -- he has that movie-star glow. The usual all-pro assortment of people (trainer, friend from college, family member, Ahmad Rashad) are milling about, and David Falk has just arrived. Falk is Jordan's agent, as well as the agent for Juwan Howard, Patrick Ewing, Alonzo Mourning and a dozen other National Basketball Association stars, including the latest college sensation to enter the pros before finishing college, the 76ers' Allen Iverson. Falk, 46, is tall, though not N.B.A. tall, and looks like some sort of very determined bird. He seems to be concentrating -- surveying the terrain, considering the options. "I went over to see my best friend this morning," Falk says.
"What did she look like?" Jordan jokes. 
 "No, really," Falk persists. Jordan just smiles.
Jordan is in New York to promote his fragrance, a joint venture with the designer Bijan. There are bottles all around the room. This cologne, named simply Michael Jordan, is a longtime dream come true, one of Falk's many nonbasketball business deals for the basketball players he so successfully represents. Obtaining multimillion-dollar contracts for your clients is the foundation of any sports agent's job, and Falk is known to be a tough negotiator, with both the N.B.A. and, off the court, with Nike, Reebok and others. Like Leigh Steinberg, the football agent who does the bidding for nearly every quarterback in the N.F.L. (and who is the model for Jerry Maguire, the sports agent Tom Cruise will play in the movie of the same name, opening next month), Falk has market share. Since he controls a large block of top players, he can, in many ways, dictate the structure and the economics of the entire league. Falk is considered the second most powerful person in the N.B.A., after its Commissioner, David Stern.
"Falk has massive leverage," says the general manager of one N.B.A. team who didn't want his name used for fear of angering Falk. "If he just had Michael, he would be considered a marketing genius, which he is. But David represents so many players that he is a major force. He pretty much gets what he asks for."
Falk has used the big contracts he has secured for Jordan and others to lure younger players like Iverson. But it's the off-the-court deals that separate him from the pack. With Jordan, Falk redefined the marketing possibilities for an athlete. "Michael has transcended sport," Falk likes to say. "He is an international icon."
More than anything else, Falk understands potential. He can look at a player or a company and see the possibilities. His timing is also good -- Jordan's emergence as a basketball god coincided with the rebirth of the N.B.A. as the game to watch. One fed the other and Falk seized the opportunity. "In my business," he says, "I'm not a point guard, I'm a shooter. My job is to be aggressive. I'm going to make the shot. I may miss three or four in a row but I'm going to make the shot. It's hard to decompress from that and be 'aw shucks.' That's just not who I am.
"I spent seven years talking to people about cologne," Falk continues. Falk knew that cologne was an extremely lucrative business. The scent itself costs very little to produce; the main expense and hard work is in the marketing. Falk didn't have trouble convincing Jordan. "I've always had ambitions about doing this," Jordan says. "I take fragrance and fashion very seriously."
Falk nods. "It was hard," he says. "It was exactly like when he came out as a rookie and we tried to sell him to McDonald's. The cologne people would say, 'I know he can sell shoes and hamburgers, but he's not a designer: he can't sell cologne.' I said: 'Why not? The guy's an arbiter of fashion.' "
Jordan smiles. "I told him I didn't believe he could do it," he says. "A lot of things he believes he can do and I don't believe him."
Falk laughs. "Michael knows how competitive I am," he says. Competitive, but careful. For years he kept Jordan away from the movies. "We got piles of scripts," he says. "But they didn't fit Michael Jordan. He can't really act. And you have to know your limitations."
Falk himself came up with the idea of Bugs Bunny and Jordan teaming together in a feature film and then sold Warner Brothers on the concept. The result was "Space Jam", which opened this weekend. The deal was complicated. Falk didn't really know anyone in the movie business, but he was friendly with Dan Romanelli, the head of Warner Brothers' worldwide consumer-products division. Romanelli walked Falk through the studio hierarchy until he met with the studio heads, Bob Daly and Terry Semel. At the end of 1993 they hosted a party for Jordan and the deal for the movie was set in motion. "It was all based on a relationship," Falk says. "Michael gives you access to so many worlds. The challenge is in marrying entertainment and sports. It's not just talking about synergy and all the theoretical B-school mumbo jumbo."
Jordan smiles. He knows this is Falk's favorite theme -- how his game is bigger than basketball. "Does that mean I can tell Jerry Reinsdorf you won't be making my deals anymore?"
Falk laughs. "Just wait. I've got some ideas"
Jordan smiles. "No doubt," he says. "No doubt."
 FALK'S OFFICE IS IN WASHINGTON, A hotbed of sports agents, and is filled with mementos of his deals: autographed balls and Wheaties boxes and Patrick Ewing's size-13 sneakers and a framed poster for "Space Jam." It's around 4 on a July afternoon, a few days before the N.B.A. free-agent signing period is set to begin, and Falk, who is snappily dressed in a gray suit, a crisp white monogrammed shirt, tasseled loafers and a bright orange patterned tie, is on the phone with Bernie Bickerstaff, the owner of the Denver Nuggets, trying to explain -- calmly, persuasively -- why Dikembe Mutombo, Denver's star center but now another Falk free agent, is worth $55 million.
Of course, Falk doesn't exactly say this number. He hints at it, he talks around it. To negotiate before the signing period in any way would be illegal, but there's no harm in creating a mood, an expectation. "Protect your assets," Falk says into the receiver. "You've got to protect your assets." Falk knows that Bickerstaff will be able to decipher his barely coded message.
On the phone with Bickerstaff, Falk is at his most convivial. To him, this is a big game. He vehemently opposes the N.B.A. salary cap system, which gives each team a set amount of money with which to pay their players. From that total, they can allocate funds in any configuration. There is one big exception to the cap rule: under the so-called "Bird Rights" (named for Larry Bird, the Boston Celtics great who forced the issue), a team is allowed to pay any of their own players any size salary increase without affecting the cap. Meaning, Bernie Bickerstaff and the Denver Nuggets can pay Dikembe Mutombo a fortune -- say, $55 million -- if they so desire. Or, in all likelihood, they will lose him to the open market.
"I'm a nut about loyalty," Falk says into the phone. "Protect your assets," he repeats. "That's the cardinal rule."
Falk then decides to tell Bickerstaff a story, a kind of parable. "Last week, we went to Chicago to see Michael," he begins. "He can't really go out to a restaurant, and we wanted to talk, so we rented a suite at the hotel for dinner so there would be privacy. Michael looked at the wine list and he said, 'There's no good wine on this menu.' The most expensive bottle of wine was $150 a bottle. So we call for the wine list from the restaurant downstairs, and Michael orders two bottles of wine. That wine cost $650 a bottle. We had dinner, talked, it was great. Now, that meal and the room and the trip probably cost me $5,000. You might say that's a lot for dinner, but it was worth it. I spent the money, which is a lot of money, because you always protect your assets."
After hanging up, he says, "I like Bernie very much, but it's very hard to be friends with people when you're asking them for millions of dollars." Falk smiles slightly.
Falk prides himself on planning carefully and getting it done right. He inherited this, he says, from his mother, who died in 1988 of cancer. She was, in many ways, the driving force behind Falk's ambition. "She was a perfectionist," Falk recalls. "She expected excellence." His parents were an odd match; Falk's father owned two butcher shops on Long Island and his mother had two master's degrees and spoke six languages. "They were oil and water," Falk says.
In 1972, Falk graduated from Syracuse with a degree in economics. While attending law school at George Washington University, he started working at ProServ, a large Washington-based sports agency. ProServ, which is still run by its founder, Donald Dell, is mostly known for representing tennis players. Basketball, 25 years ago, was a minor part of ProServ's business; it was a team sport and even the stars of the game were not considered appropriate as spokesmen for non-sports-marketing campaigns. That was for the McEnroes and Nicklauses. With a basketball player, ProServ, like most sports agencies, would typically negotiate the N.B.A. contract, maybe get a shoe company involved and pretty much leave it at that. "The teams were famous," Falk explains. "There were great players, but basketball was perceived by companies to be about the team. Not the individual."
When Falk met Michael Jordan, he decided to change the landscape. What seems so ridiculously obvious today -- that Michael Jordan is one of the greatest cross-cultural, international, megawatt stars of all time -- was not nearly as clear in 1984. Jordan went third in the draft when he graduated from North Carolina; he was playing for the Chicago Bulls, then a mediocre team, and he wasn't white, which made him a harder sell to companies. "It wasn't easy," Falk says. "That was the challenge. It's hard to sell an Afro-American. A few years ago, Doug Williams was quarterback of the Washington Redskins, the first Afro-American quarterback to win a Super Bowl. I called him to see if we could represent him. He said he didn't need an agent, that he'd wait for the offers to come in. He's still waiting. Very few companies call for athletes, and even fewer call for black athletes.
"When Michael was a rookie, I would approach companies and they would say, 'David, what on earth are we going to do with a black basketball player?' And I said, 'Don't black people use your product?' "
Falk pushed. It was Falk who came up with "Air Jordan" and took the idea to Nike, eventually convincing them of it. Still, Nike insisted on several outs in its initial contract with the player. The shoe line could be dropped if certain sales figures weren't met and if he didn't make the All-Star team in his first three years. In 1985, the Air Jordan sneaker earned Nike $100 million. After that, everything changed.
"With Michael, I've created a Frankenstein of sorts," Falk claims. "In 1984, Rod Thorn, the general manager of the Bulls, said: 'What are you trying to do? Make this guy a tennis player?' And I said, 'Exactly.' He's not just another one of 12 homogenous guys. He's different. And now everybody wants to be like Mike."
Falk's marketing plan for Jordan attracted other players. He was a magnet and, like all sports agents, Falk receives 4 percent of a client's salary and an agreed-upon percentage, usually greater than 4 percent, of the player's marketing revenues (at ProServ, Jordan gave 20 percent). Sports agents, unlike Hollywood agents, also function as business managers.
But like Hollywood, sports is a business based on reputation and relationships. Agents need to be on good terms with the top college coaches. For instance, it was Donald Dell, Falk's boss at ProServ, who arranged the Jordan signing. Dell, a former tennis player who is smooth where Falk can be abrasive, had a close relationship with the also-smooth Dean Smith, Jordan's coach at North Carolina. (Just as John Thompson, the coach at Georgetown and a Falk client, urged Patrick Ewing, Alonzo Mourning and Allen Iverson to sign with Falk). "David did most of the talking at that first meeting," Jordan recalls. "But, quite honestly, he didn't talk about marketing. There was really nothing to talk about. That was the beauty of it -- there weren't any parents to follow."
By 1992, Falk, who had always clashed stylistically with Dell, decided to leave ProServ. It was a messy divorce. Falk arranged a leveraged buyout of ProServ's basketball division, which he ran, and started FAME (Falk Associates Management Enterprises). There were those who questioned Falk's management skills -- he can be abrupt and overly aggressive -- but there was never any question about his prowess as an agent. "I know I'm an acquired taste," Falk says. "But when I'm signing someone, I always say: 'Do you want me to massage your ego? Or you want me to massage your wallet?' And most of the time, they'd rather you'd massage their ego. But, in the end, it's their wallet they really care about."
Leaving ProServ seemed to further motivate Falk. All his clients, including Jordan, joined him at FAME, and he started to reinvent himself. He was underpaid at ProServ, he says; at FAME his income soared. ("I'll pay more in taxes this year than I earned working at ProServ for 17 years combined," he says.) Falk repackaged himself -- upgrading his wardrobe (Jordan likes to tell a story of a thief breaking into Falk's rental car, when he worked at ProServ, rifling through the bags and stealing everything but his clothes) and renting a posh suite of offices. He always had a master plan; sneaker deals are nice, but just as Jordan is no longer perceived as simply the best basketball player in the world, Falk wanted to be viewed as more than just an agent. As he sees it, he has recast the sport. "Now the N.B.A. is like having corporations on the court," he says. "And that's my contribution. No one even steps up and says: 'You're a pioneer. We owe you a debt of thanks.' I say that to David Stern, but nobody says that to me. There's always something to criticize -- I have too much power or too many clients. I scoff at that. Think about it: If you lived on a block with $300,000 houses and you sold yours for $2.5 million, your neighbors would thank you. But in my business they don't. That used to make me angry. Now I'm just amused."
 T'S THE DAY. THURSDAY, JULY 11, 1996. THE biggest ever free-agency signing period has begun, and having reached an agreement about Jordan's new contract quickly ($30 million for one year), the main drama is whether or not Juwan Howard will remain with the Washington Bullets. The Bullets are a young team, led by its two forwards, Chris Webber and Howard, a solid second-year player vital to their lineup. Unfortunately for the Bullets, Howard is arguably the most sought after free agent in the N.B.A. Two years ago, he was forced, as all rookies are, to sign with the team that drafted him. It was a low-ball contract, Falk felt, but it had a two-year escape clause. "The Bullets stripped Juwan of his dignity," Falk says. "And that's something you should never do."
So the Howard negotiation is, in many ways, payback. Falk made it clear in the media that he believes Juwan is worth at least $15 million to $20 million a year. Due to the Bird Rights, the Bullets can pay him any amount, without affecting the salary cap. "We'll see if they do the right thing," Falk said before the negotiations began. "Juwan is theirs to lose."
The previous morning, the Bullets had staged a parade ("We Love You Juwan") on the street below Falk's office and a week earlier had taken out an ad in The Washington Post soliciting donations to Howard's charitable foundation. As a courtesy, the Bullets were the first team to pitch to Howard. On paper, Washington lacks certain "intangibles" that Falk and his associates favor. The team doesn't have a private jet for the players; they are building a new arena, but it isn't ready yet, and they aren't in a state with no state taxes, like the Miami Heat. But Howard has made roots in the Washington community, and he and Chris Webber played together at the Univerity of Michigan. "Juwan wants to stay," Falk says before the negotiations begin. "This is his home."
So, today, Juwan put on a suit and sat on the blue-leather couch in Falk's office, and he and his agents listened to the Bullets' proposal. "I listened and I wanted to cry." Howard said later. "I kept thinking, Why does this keep happening to me?" The Bullets offered $11.2 million a year, far below the $15-$20 million Falk had earlier suggested to a Washington Post reporter. "That was a channeled communication to the Bullets," Falk says. "And they ignored it."
Howard was hurt, but there were other pitches to console him. The Knicks talked about corporate opportunities and reaffirmed their allegiance to Ewing, but they didn't want to be used as a strongman to make anyone else's deal and wouldn't give a number. Pat Riley, the Miami coach, talked about winning ("The man is consumed by winning," Falk says with awe) and about Alonzo Mourning, the Heat's outstanding center. Miami is a very rich club, with lots of "intangibles" to dangle. Riley's pitch reflected that sense of largess and generosity. Detroit made a presentation, and other teams were phoning with proposals for Howard, but he was still interested in the Bullets. "We decided to give them another chance," Falk says.
On Friday, while Riley waited in his D.C. hotel room (conveniently located in the same mall-office complex that houses FAME), Falk, his partner, Curtis Polk, and Howard drove up to the home of Abe Pollin, the Bullets' owner. They sat and talked and Pollin disappointed Howard again. "Not that much changed," Falk says. "If you look at the whole scenario -- the parades and the press -- the Bullets provided a lot of sizzle but no steak. They made another low offer. That made the decision easy."
Early Saturday morning, not long after midnight, Howard decided to play for Miami. Falk had his own competition going -- he wanted Howard to be the highest-paid player in his rookie draft class. In the end, he made it look easy: Howard signed a $101 million contract for seven years. "I had numbers in my mind for months," Falk says. "What I supplied was the vision. I translated Juwan's efforts into this deal."
It's a huge contract. The next-closest players in Howard's rookie class are Glenn (Big Dog) Robinson, who will receive $68 million over 10 years from the Milwaukee Bucks, and Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons, who is earning $54.6 million for nine years. There's some history there: Grant Hill is the one player to turn pro in the last few years that Falk really wanted to sign but couldn't quite entice. "Grant Hill is the one who's most like Michael," he says, rather remorsefully. "He had the most potential to be Michael the second time around. His agent, Tom George, told me, 'We basically copied the Jordan blueprint.' It's ironic that Hill didn't pick the guy who created the blueprint! But he didn't opt to."
When the Howard deal is set, Falk is clearly pleased. Unlike everyone else in his office, he looks crisp and rested. "He thrives on this stuff," says Polk. "When I go home, I go home. When David goes home, he's still working."
There is little time to celebrate. Atlanta is calling every few hours about signing the Nuggets' Mutombo, and there are 10 or so other deals pending. But Falk can't resist. "Juwan is the highest-paid forward in the history of basketball," Falk says, while the phones ring. "He's making more money than David Robinson. He's making more money than Olajuwon."
Polk, who is listening, laughs. "He's making more money than God!"
Falk smiles. "Oh no, not yet," he says . "We'll save that for Michael."
 FOUR DAYS LATER, JUWAN HOWARD, WHO sports a Vandyke beard and mustache combination and is unflaggingly polite ("You look lovely as always," he coos to Falk's receptionist, taking her hand) bounds into Falk's office, looking for a change of clothes. He is not alone. Howard has shown up with an entourage of three. They are all wearing baggy sweats or baggy jeans. "I need my suit," Howard tells Falk, who embraces Juwan. "Gotta dress up for Riley."
Falk and Polk and Howard are flying down to Miami in an hour. The Heat have sent their private jet and a news conference is scheduled for later this afternoon. Falk is pleased. Nearly all the big deals are set: Alonzo Mourning re-signed with the Miami Heat for $105 million; Kenny Anderson, another client, is set to leave the Charlotte Hornets and sign with the Portland Trail Blazers for just under $50 million, and Dikembe Mutombo left Denver, who did not make the offer Falk had hoped, and signed a deal with the Atlanta Hawks for $55 million. "It's a great feeling," Falk says. "It's been an incredible six days."
While Howard is preparing to address the media, Rex Chapman, another Falk client, is sitting at home in Kentucky, waiting for the phone to ring. The son of a pro basketball player, Chapman was known as the "Boy King" when he played for the University of Kentucky. "He could have run for governor," Falk says, "and he probably would have won." He went pro in 1988 after his sophomore year and immediately signed with Falk. "I wanted somebody who would take care of the business part of my career," Chapman says. "I didn't want a baby sitter. If that's what you're looking for, Falk is the wrong person. He has a lot of clients and he's very busy."
Chapman's first contract was with the Charlotte Hornets for $2.6 million, and then in 1994 he was traded to the Miami Heat. "He played very well last year," Falk says. "There was no reason why they wouldn't sign him to a new contract."
But cap economics got in the way. After the Howard and Mourning deals were done, Riley felt he had to nail down other players, including Tim Hardaway of the Heat for $10 million. In all the signings, Rex Chapman's new deal was ignored.
"Things got very screwed up in Miami," Chapman says. "They told me they wanted me back. They made a couple of offers prior to Juwan signing, and I turned them both down."
Falk had felt that Riley was making low-ball offers to Chapman and encouraged him to wait. "Sometimes," Chapman says, "to get what you want you have to walk away from it." He pauses. "My situation is a prime example of how this salary cap is a bad deal. The league knows that I can play. And yet I'm still not signed."
Falk was frustrated and angry over Chapman's situation. He had spoken to Riley before the free-agency signing period began and the coach had assured him that the team wanted Chapman. "Out of respect for Riley, we didn't leverage a deal," he says. "He gave me his word that he would take care of Rex. If he hadn't, we would have said, 'We don't want to talk about Juwan until we do Rex's deal.' But out of respect for Pat, we didn't do that and we didn't exercise the maximum leverage we could have brought to bear. We understood what our leverage was and we didn't exploit it. And I regret that we didn't exploit it."
It could be argued that this is a drawback of signing with an agent who represents so many top players; their deals will always take precedence over more modest contracts. Back in Kentucky, Chapman worked out every day and watched and waited while players like Oliver Miller, the veteran center, left $2.8 million on the table, played the free-agency market and came away without offers. Miller eventually signed with Toronto for the league minimum, $247,500. Walt Williams, another veteran center, "got out of a two-year deal worth $6 million and will probably end up with the minimum," Chapman reports. "Once the team's cap dries up, they just don't have the money."
Just today, an hour ago, Riley made Chapman another offer. It was still low. "Riley felt that Rex wouldn't have his heart in the team," Falk says. "There's so much scar tissue. This is hard. We're not going to create Air Chapman at this point. Or get him a rap record. We just want to get him a job."
Falk stares a second. Howard is in Falk's office changing clothes and Falk has retreated to a conference room. He's just hung up with Chapman, who turned down Riley's latest offer. Falk hates this situation. He has genuine affection for Chapman and he feels he let a team get the best of him. It's a power move he lost, and Falk is as competitive as his players. "You have to get over the tug of war inside of you," he says. "You're great at what you do but, at the same time, you want these people to like you. And it doesn't work. In hindsight, I should have put on the gloves and leveraged Miami to death because of Alonzo and Juwan. I think I let Rex down."
 IN MID-JULY, WHEN THE first round of free-agency signing was over, Falk took his wife, Rhonda, and two daughters, Daina and Jocelyn, on a four-week trip to Europe and Israel. The trip was a bat mitzvah present for Daina, and even when the league delayed first once and then twice the start of the free-agent signing, Falk maintained that he was leaving for Europe on July 19, whether the deals were finished or not.
A couple of weeks into the trip, Falk received a call from Curtis Polk saying that there were problems with Juwan Howard's contract with the Miami Heat, that the league had questions about the deal. The N.B.A. felt that there wasn't room under the cap for Miami to sign Howard for $101 million. Suddenly, Juwan was a free agent again.
It was complicated. Polk, who sprang into action, immediately checked to see if Howard was, technically, still part of the Bullets' organization. If so, his Bird Rights could apply -- the Bullets could make Howard another offer, over and above the cap. Falk decided to stay in Europe, and Polk had Howard, who was upset at suddenly finding himself without a contract or a team, fly to Washington. The weekend of Aug. 10, Howard and Polk sat in front of the TV watching rhythmic gymnastics while the N.B.A. officials came to a decision about his free-agency fate.
It was probably smart to have Polk handle the Heat-Howard-Bullets mess. The heads of the N.B.A. resent and, in some cases, actively dislike, David Falk. They view him as opportunistic, self-serving and boastful, and they like to needle him when they can. "Last year, at the All-Star Game, we gave Falk really bad tickets," says one N.B.A. executive. "Stern knew about it and he thought it was funny."
The N.B.A. feels Falk has a disproportionate amount of power. He controls a block of players and those players can make or break a team. The N.B.A. would like to own that right; they do not want any one entity to have Falk's muscle.
This conflict became particularly virulent a year ago when Falk and a group of "dissident players," made up of top Falk clients like Jordan, Ewing and Mourning, challenged the collective bargaining agreement reached by the players' union and the league, of which the salary cap is a key component. Falk and company sought to decertify the union, thereby abolishing the agreement.
To counteract Falk, the league filed charges of unfair labor practices against him. The Commissioner, Stern, was angry; he felt Falk was overstepping the boundaries of an agent. If the Falk side had won, if the union had been decertified, it might have delayed the start of the N.B.A. season. Falk maintains that he did not initiate the attempted coup. "I didn't in any way suggest it or recommend it," he said at the time. "But once it was put on the table, it seemed like a brake on a railroad train that was speeding through the station and was going to run over the players."
Eventually, the N.B.A. prevailed and the salary cap was passed. Falk was disappointed. He still respects David Stern, but the two men keep their distance. Polk, meanwhile, has less history with the heads of the N.B.A. The financial whiz behind FAME, Polk manages the players' portfolios and helps them stick to a budget, as well as negotiating deals. Polk has a straightforward, almost blunt manner that is oddly comforting. "Curtis will always tell you the truth," says Michael Jordan. "I'm like the doctor with a terrible bedside manner," Polk says. "I'll cut through all the junk and say: 'Sorry. You had a bad year. You are not getting a job in the N.B.A.' "
Polk was considerably gentler with Howard, who was worried about where he would end up. And for how much. "Based on what was transpiring with Miami and Washington," Polk says, "we had the most leverage of anyone in the history of sports. When the Bullets lost Juwan, the publicity was so intense. If they got the rights back and didn't sign him because of money, the league would have been angry and the city would have been angry. They had to step up."
And they did. In the end, the Bullets agreed to $105 million for seven years. But there was a struggle. Before the weekend of Aug. 10, Miami got an injunction against Howard and the league. "That was very bad,"Polk says. "For a team to sue the league goes against everything that the N.B.A. stands for."
Yet, by 2 P.M. on Monday afternoon, Howard and the Bullets had come to an understanding. When it looked like they had a deal, Polk excused himself from the meeting and called Riley. "I said, 'Pat, we're going to sign a contract with the Bullets.' He was upset. And I know there will be a point where I'm going to really need the Heat to sort of err a little bit in our favor and they're going to bludgeon me over the head with what happened with Juwan. But, that's our business."
Riley was furious and loud. With the loss of Howard, he saw a championship slip away, and he was not quiet about his rage. "I spent the weekend at my proctologist's trying to remove the N.B.A.'s 17-foot pole out of my rear end," he said on ESPN. His anger mostly centered on the N.B.A. -- after all, it had pulled the strings -- but Riley also took issue with Howard's agents. Shouldn't they have been loyal to their initial deal? "We're pro-player," insists Polk. "We work for Juwan Howard. Not the league. Not the teams. We always make the best deal for the player."
So, on Aug. 12, a month after he flew to Miami and shook Pat Riley's hand and said how thrilled he was to be a member of the Miami Heat, Juwan Howard addressed the media in Washington. He thanked God and said how he had always wanted to stay with the Bullets and how lucky he was to receive another chance. "I did not want to make it a money issue," he said later. "I wanted to see that I was appreciated."
IT'S 10 ON A THURSDAY morning in October, and Allen Iverson, 1996's No. 1 college draft pick and now a Philadelphia 76er, has just arrived at Reebok headquarters in Stoughton, Mass., outside Boston. Iverson is six feet tall and slight, with beautiful almond-shaped eyes, a sweet, telegenic smile and a tattoo on his left biceps that reads, "The Answer." He has a large diamond in his left ear and a thick gold chain with an equally thick cross hanging around his neck, and he is dressed in head-to-toe black-and-white Reebok athletic wear.
During the two years Iverson played for Georgetown, he averaged 23 points a season. He is small but fast; he set a school record with 124 steals. Iverson has a cloudy history. Three years ago, when he was 18, he was convicted of three felony counts of mob violence in a bowling-alley fracas that took place in his hometown of Hampton, Va. He was sentenced to five years in prison but was furloughed after four months by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder with the rather major stipulation that he not play basketball in his senior year of high school. Two years later, an appeals court overturned Iverson's conviction on the basis of insufficient evidence. At Georgetown, he cleansed his reputation. Iverson was a model citizen, humble and utterly devoted to the game.
Today, he is visiting Reebok for an all-day planning session. As Iverson walks through the doors, hundreds of Reebok employees are waiting to welcome him. The entrance of this nondescript building is a three-story atrium and employees are standing on every balcony. There are banners and balloons and a camera crew to record the event. When Iverson arrives -- Falk is already upstairs, having driven to Reebok with the president of the company -- the crowd breaks into applause. Iverson autographs some balls and a few pictures, and then Roger Best, a senior vice president of Reebok, makes a speech. "Allen, I think they like you," he says to a roar of applause.
Iverson heads upstairs to a conference room that overlooks the parking lot. There is an Asteroids video game in the corner, and Falk and various Reebok representatives are gathered around a blond wood table. They are here to strategize, to map out Allen Iverson's persona for the next 10 years. This is Falk's favorite arena -- he loves marketing. "I don't feel like I'm a plumber," he says. "I want to be an artist. I want to change the landscape. Marketing is creative.
"I don't want to manufacture Allen Iverson; I want to shape him. There's a talent to understanding where it has to go and how it has to fit together. That is our role." Falk has made this clear to the Reebok executives, and they have enthusiastically embraced his vision.
Falk is not so keen on Nike these days. Despite Jordan, there's some tension. Nike was displeased with the number and range of Jordan's endorsements; it felt he was diluting the Air Jordan image that it had so carefully cultivated. Nike reacted by signing athletes to overall management contracts. Meaning that the agent will negotiate for the player on the court and Nike will control the rest. "It puts all your eggs in one basket," says Falk, who only has one player with Nike Sports Management, Alonzo Mourning. (While good-looking and appealing, he has a very slight nonsports profile, thanks to Nike's poor marketing.) "Nike wants to be the captain of the ship," Falk continues. "They want to decide how many destinations you stop at. And my job is to be captain of the ship. And there can only be one captain of the ship."
Reebok is thrilled to let Falk chart the course. It signed Iverson before the draft for more than $40 million and view him as the company's salvation. Reebok currently has Shaquille O'Neal on its roster, but for reasons Reebok cannot explain, he hasn't really helped sales. Iverson strikes them as the everyman superstar. He's of average height and build, but speedy and tough. "Kind of like a sneaker," says Tom Carmody, the senior vice president of strategic planning, as he takes a seat next to Falk.
Iverson sits on Falk's other side. As he finds his place, Carmody hands out commemorative Olympic watches. Iverson studies his closely. "Who is your watch company?" Falk asks, always inquisitive about the business aspects of any situation. Carmody shakes his head. "Can you find out?" Falk says. "I'd like to know."
The meeting starts. It is, technically, Reebok's meeting, but it is the Falk show. He is dazzling. "We're here to talk about who Allen is," Falk begins. "The single most important thing is to manage his image. It gets so diffuse. Every company wants to be Fellini and control the guy's image. It cannibalizes the guy's appeal and it confuses the audience."
Everyone agrees, and Iverson sits quietly, listening. "How do you feel about that?" Falk asks Iverson. He thinks a minute. "I would be more into it," he replies slowly, "if I could be myself."
"Well," says Falk. "With him, I have a penchant to do it differently. It doesn't work to do the same stuff that Jordan did in 1984. It would be as if Allen Iverson wore Michael Jordan's custom-made clothes from 1984. They wouldn't fit and they'd be out of style."
Carmody and the Reebok executives nod. Any time there's a Jordan reference, they're happy. "Our idea, Allen," Carmody says, "is speed and innovation. That's how we look at you." Iverson stares. "Would you say speed and innovation work for you?" Falk asks Iverson. There is a long silence. "I would say creativity," Iverson says, finally. Everyone nods.
A Reebok brand manager named Henry (Que) Gaskins walks in with a dozen basketballs, a pile of trading cards and some pens. He is Iverson's Reebok guy -- he will travel with Iverson, attend every game he plays with the 76ers and help coordinate Reebok events. He hands Iverson a ball to sign. Iverson considers himself artistic and his signature is full of flourishes.
Falk, who is all-gears-clicking-into-place alert, watches Iverson, who may be fast on the court but does everything else in a kind of underwater slow motion, carefully take the top off a fat gold marker. "He's an artist," Falk says, an idea hatching. "What if he had poster ideas? What if he had a poster that said, 'I on the Game.' Like, eye -- the shape of an eye -- on the game. Or posters in the shape of an eye." The Reebok crew nods. "What about that, Allen?" Falk asks.
"That would be really cool," Iverson says, signing his second basketball.
Falk tries to engage him. "What motivates you to sketch?" he asks. A long pause. "I'm bored," he replies. "Well," Falk says, "I'll give you the games -- Vancouver. . . . " Iverson and the Reebokers laugh. "I just like to draw," Iverson says, autographing another ball. "Wow," says Carmody. "That's a talent."
An assistant passes around the Iverson logo. It is a large I with, for some reason, a small 3 next to it. The I is stylized -- it tilts and has a zigzag cut out on one side. "It looks like an Interstate sign," Carmody says. "It says there's no limits, there's no schedule."
The logo is placed in triangles, in circles and in a square. Falk is immediately troubled by the square. "I think something that's square is a square," he says. "What about a diamond? He's a rookie and he's like a diamond in the rough, so a diamond would be good." Carmody shakes his head.
There are so many things to consider: Falk wants a fan club ("from Day 1"), a web site, a charity, a guest spot on a TV show ("I like 'Martin,' 'Living Single' or 'New York Undercover,' " Iverson says, perking up), a live Internet interview after every game. "But I don't want to get too far ahead of myself," Falk says, after a burst of ideas.
Iverson smiles. "Can I see the shoe?" he asks.
Gaskins brings in the Iverson shoe. It is white and padded and has a clear sole and circular honeycombed panels along the base of the shoe. Iverson looks at the shoe intently, turns it over, tracing his finger along the base. "The Answer is clear," Falk enthuses. Iverson likes this line. The sole of the shoe is clear; he's the Answer -- it works for him. "I don't know how you come up with this stuff," he says.
The next presentation is by two guys in their 30's who are from Leo Burnett, the ad agency that will be doing the Iverson-Reebok commercials. They set up an overhead projector at the end of the room. As they begin their presentation, Falk interrupts. "Can I give you a really corny idea?" he asks. "I like acronyms. My company is an acronym. What if we come up with an acronym for Allen? Speed. Creativity. Innovation. S.C.I. The Science of footwear. The Science of --." Falk stops midthought. His mind is racing. "Wait," he continues. "There Is No 'I' in Team.' You know, coaches always say there is no 'I' in the word team. Play for the team and all. Well, we could do, 'Who Said There Is No 'I' in Team?' Or 'The SCIence of Allen Iverson.' This is a science. We are trying to create a whole new approach. We're combining SCIence." Falk stops. "I'm sorry," he says. "This is me."
The ad guys don't really know how to respond, and they begin again. More than Falk, they are interested in meshing Iverson's identity with Reebok. "We want that link forged," they repeat again and again. "When people see him, we want them to see Reebok."
They put on a foil that reads "Positioning Road Map." It is a chart that projects Iverson's career evolution to the year 2000. By then, Reebok believes, he will be in the N.B.A. finals, have a two-minute commercial during the Super Bowl and play in the Olympics. By then, they hope he will be Jordan. He will be playing basketball to maintain his brand name and making the real money off the court.
Falk studies the chart. "At the end of '98 and '99, he becomes a free agent, and that's very important," he says. He ponders their schedule. "Allen will have phases," he adds. "The menu of companies change. You wouldn't want to do a financial services company now, but in nine years, when he's 30 and he's making $150 million, that might be appropriate."
Iverson looks up at this point. "$150 million?" Falk is still considering the chart. "Overnight delivery, sports, drinks, apparel -- they are a good fit," he says, reading. "Cereal, fast food, computers, automobiles, those are a bad fit?" Falk thinks a second. "I think about Grant Hill doing General Motors and I think: What were they thinking? Grant Hill is Ferrari." Everyone laughs. "What products do you like?" Falk asks Iverson.
Iverson takes a minute. He puts down the pen and stares at the graph. "Benz," he finally says. "I like Benz. Or Lexus." Falk seizes upon this. "The relentless pursuit of perfection," he exclaims. "Lexus fits his style as a player. It's a perfect fit. It reinforces you. It reinforces them."
There is some concern that Iverson's lack of education (he left college after only two years) and criminal record will affect the range of his endorsements. Falk isn't concerned: "He had some things in his life that weren't perfect. He should be hip, but not avant-garde. Hip, but not hop."
The Leo Burnett team then act out a potential commercial for Iverson. It involves a train ("Can I ask you, why a train?" Falk inquires) and some animation. The idea is O.K., but it lacks the distinctive clarity and innovation of most Nike advertising. The concept is just too obvious, and Falk knows it.
But he lets it go. He is polite but not overly enthusiastic. Iverson has a plane to catch, and the Reebok guys still want to show him a roomful of new products he can put his name on. There's not much time, and Falk has a good sense of how far he can push.
The only real question is, Can Iverson excel in the pros? When Jordan was a rookie in 1984, his brain wasn't clogged with marketing plans to the millennium. "Quite honestly," Jordan says, "I only knew about the basketball aspect. Until we actually started to do it, I didn't know about marketing. And then I learned. No one could have told me that the marketing of an athlete would grow to this magnitude."
From the jump, Jordan was brilliant on the court. The marketing went hand in hand with his playing. Iverson has not played one preseason game and he is already being positioned as "The Answer." "Today," Jordan says, "the marketing of an athlete sometimes exceeds the potential of that athlete. Back then, the potential of the athlete built the marketing. Now, it isn't as important."
Jordan may question this reversal, but he and Falk set the standard. After all, no one can play like Jordan, but they can play the part. Which is why Falk, who realizes there probably won't ever be another Jordan, is anxious to secure Iverson's marketing well before he sets foot in the arena.
"Allen Iverson doesn't have to play great," he tells the Reebok executives. "He has to be a great personality on the court. He's going to be a fantastic performer." Iverson hears this, but he doesn't look up. He just keeps signing his name.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
CYBERSCOUT

BYLINE: By L.R. SHANNON 

 BODY:

BILL GATES EXPRESS
Microsoft Expedia
http://expedia.msn.com/ 
 Microsoft's Expedia is a slick, easy-to-use travel service. That the leading maker of software for personal computers has produced an accessible Web site shouldn't come as a surprise, but Microsoft has stumbled in the past.
Expedia is at least as simple to operate as the handful of other cybertravel services I have dipped into, but, since no one knows how many agencies are on line, it would be unfair to call it the best. It would also be premature: the service is less than a month old.
There are five major sections: Travel Agent, where flight, hotel and auto reservations can be found and made; Travel Central, a library of guidebooks; Connections, where travelers exchange information; News Point, late-breaking news, weather and exchange rates, and Mungo Park, for virtual adventure travel, the safest kind.
All this is free, except for what you or your company or school pays for an Internet connection. Expedia is also available on the Microsoft Network, its own on-line service.
The Microsoft "campus" is in Redmond, Wash., so I decided to take a virtual vacation in the Seattle area. I signed in and filled out a form on the screen: name, E-mail address, member i.d., password, country (only the United States at this time). Then, with a cheery "Welcome Larry Shannon," Expedia said that its "wizards are ready to find the flights, rental cars and hotel rooms that are perfect for you." Wizards are the helpful aides in such software as Microsoft Windows 95 and Microsoft Publisher. And they are certainly smart.
Next, I went into the Travel Agent Flight Wizard. The defaults are round trip and coach class, which would be fine for most travelers. (One way or multiple destinations, and business class or first class are options.)
There were many options for airlines and other preferences. The most sensible, such as lowest price, were what you got unless you specified otherwise. Under Expedia's simple interface is Worldspan, a computerized reservation service used by professional travel agents. But you don't have to know, for instance, that Newark is EWR; the software knows.
Then I was given a choice of flights, and picked the least expensive one. I then went into the Travel Agent Car Wizard, and was offered class of car (economy, for me) from one of nine rental car companies. Again, the defaults made sense. Unless you specify otherwise, you are directed to rental agencies at the airport you will arrive at and depart from.
In the Travel Agent Hotel Wizard, you can select chains, price ranges and amenities (nonsmoking, swimming pool and such) and whether the hotel is in town, near the airport or near a local attraction. For many of the hotels, a mouse click brings up a map of the area with the hotel highlighted, and photographs and descriptions of the establishment. All of this is exceptionally fast for the Web, although it may slow down when it draws more users.
As always on the Web, this is not objective information. It is supplied by the individual companies. You can book all these things on line or call a toll-free number. Microsoft makes a point that it uses leading-edge electronic security to protect credit card numbers and other personal information.
I also dipped into the sequence World Guide-North America-United States for background information about Seattle. There were 20 sites in the United States listed alphabetically from Anchorage to Washington, D.C., but not Washington state. There were also options for Background, six categories including geography, and arts and culture, and Travel Essentials, eight categories such as food and drink and money and measurements. These are not especially helpful when you are traveling in your own country, but invaluable for foreign trips. According to Microsoft, the World Guide contains information on more than 50 countries and 200 cities, with 150 maps and 4,000 pictures.
There were nine forums for exchanging messages, divided into geographic areas and such themes as family. In the North American forum there were about 30 messages. They ran from exchanges about the Grand Canyon and Disneyland to a request for information on finding a good bed and breakfast in New York.
Microsoft became a travel agency to start Expedia. Earlier this year, the software company applied for membership in the American Society of Travel Agents, and even hung out a sign to submit a photograph of it with the application. If the software business goes bad, Bill Gates has something to fall back on. L. R. SHANNON

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 5; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 286 words

HEADLINE: Blaming the Elderly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It should not be necessary to explain simple concepts to an economist as distinguished as Paul Krugman. Unfortunately, his review of two recent books on entitlement programs for the elderly (Oct. 20) shows he is as susceptible to prevailing misconceptions in this area as the rest of the nation's pundits. 
 Mr. Krugman comments approvingly on "Will America Grow Up Before It Grows Old?," by Peter G. Peterson, which purports to show that the elderly are going to bankrupt the nation. Mr. Krugman, like Mr. Peterson, lumps Social Security and Government health care programs for the elderly together. But the issues are completely different.
In the case of Social Security, according to the trustees' report, it will be possible to meet all scheduled benefit payments over the next 75 years with relatively minor tax increases (2.2 percent of payroll, if done tomorrow). These increases would allow future generations to enjoy substantially higher after-tax income than workers do at present. The main reason taxes will have to rise at all is not the retirement of the baby boom generation, but the fact that people are living longer.
The Medicare and Medicaid projections are indeed a nightmare, but this is because of underlying projections in the cost of health care more generally. The Health Care Financing Administration's projections show that private sector health care spending will be nearly $4,000 per person by the year 2005. This means that a family of four at the median income will be spending approximately 30 percent of its before-tax income on health care. That is a crisis, but it has nothing to do with entitlement programs for the elderly.
 
Dean Baker
Washington

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 6; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Blaming the Elderly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Following the lead of welfare reformers, the authors and Paul Krugman would force all Americans to work longer and have less access to health care. They seem unaware of compulsory "early retirements" with small pensions, of the bipartisan policy of maintaining high unemployment to control inflation and even of the history of entitlements. All of them were designed to take people out of the labor force, because jobs were not available. They also seem unaware of the increasing reports that H.M.O. systems, designed for healthy workers, not for the old and poor, are moving us back toward the 19th century, when poverty and malnutrition produced faster death. 
 They should admit that their definition of the problem is that we have too many old people and, by extrapolation, too many poor people, and that these herds must be culled if society is to survive. The 19th-century "science" of eugenics is reappearing in new garb.
 
Frederick C. Thayer
Pittsburgh
