SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1316 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
The Accidental Violist

BYLINE: By K. ROBERT SCHWARZ; K. Robert Schwarz is the author of "Minimalists."

 BODY:
PERHAPS STARDOM IS AS much preordained as painstakingly achieved. A few artists are born with the talent and charisma needed to capture the imagination of the public. Only the means by which they will win fame remains to be determined.
Take the 43-year-old violist Yuri Bashmet, who will perform with the Moscow Soloists on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall and play Alfred Schnittke's Viola Concerto with the New York Philharmonic next month at Avery Fisher Hall. As a young musician growing up in Lvov, Ukraine, Mr. Bashmet clearly possessed stellar gifts. He studied violin at the Lvov Conservatory and was, in his own words, "the best violin player in the school." He was also the lead guitarist of a rock band that played Beatles and Rolling Stones tunes, and the teen-age idol of Lvov. 
 But why, at 14, did he switch from the violin, an instrument with built-in star potential, to the viola, a self-effacing vehicle perennially relegated to an inner voice?
"When I was given the possibility of changing to viola, I asked the advice of one of my friends," Mr. Bashmet said recently from his dacha outside Moscow. "He told me: 'Listen, if you play the viola, you will spend less time learning technical things, so you will have more time for your guitar.' "
But three years later his double musical life ground to a halt, in part because of the rising influence of Jimi Hendrix. "When Hendrix's music arrived in Lvov," Mr. Bashmet said, "I felt that as a guitar player, I couldn't do this abstract, psychedelic improvisation." He quit the guitar, and pop music, forever. "It was almost a tragic moment," he said in dead earnest.
There was still the viola, of course, but no instrument would have seemed a less likely solo vehicle. Lost in the shadows between the brilliant violin and the resonant cello, the viola, with its gravelly, melancholy voice, has a skimpy repertory of concertos. And though history has acknowledged a few great violists, none devoted an entire career to solo performance.
Unfazed, Mr. Bashmet pursued the instrument with relentless intensity and boundless self-assurance. He may also have had useful connections, for as the dying Soviet Union staggered toward perestroika, Mr. Bashmet's career took off. He toured with the pianist Sviatoslav Richter and traveled freely to the West.
By the time the Soviet Union collapsed, Mr. Bashmet had achieved the impossible. He was, in the words of the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich, the first violist to attain "a gigantic solo career on an instrument that no one considers the equal of the violin."
Not that the road wasn't bumpy. Managers, agents and concert promoters all doubted that any violist, however skilled, could have a major career. "I began to feel like a pioneer," Mr. Bashmet said. "People told me it had never been done before, and they were afraid to book a solo recital, because, after all, they had to sell tickets."
But he persevered, and today his schedule is crammed with as many bookings as that of any violinist. As soloist with orchestra or in recital, he plays more than 100 concerts a season; as the leader of his own chamber orchestra, the Moscow Soloists, he gives 50 more. In fact, his success has been so great that up-and-coming violists can now contemplate a solo career. "I'm very happy that younger players now have a better chance." he said. But, he added immodestly, "nobody has the same career as I do."
He has achieved that career by means of a musicianship so intense that it would have found expression no matter what instrument he had chosen.
"Great artists often seem so outstanding that you don't even ask which instrument they play on," said Kurt Masur, the music director of the New York Philharmonic. "He is a great soloist who happened to land on the viola. The sensibility of this instrument gives him the possibility to whisper, to shout, to love, to be full of poetry. He has the ability to make you believe that he creates the piece at that moment. It's not only passionate playing but almost like improvising."
Since the Schnittke Viola Concerto (1985) was written for Mr. Bashmet, he identifies with it to an extraordinary degree. The composer is critically ill, and Mr. Bashmet is acutely aware that any performance of this concerto could become a memorial.
"When I play Schnittke's music, I am like a dramatic actor from a Shakespearean tragedy," he said. "I am not only a musician. Because his music tells us about basic human categories, like life and death, good and bad. And for once the viola is a hero. Here Schnittke makes the instrument grow very strong."
This is one of 36 concertos, mostly by Russian composers, written for Mr. Bashmet. To that astonishing number will be added a concerto by Sofia Gubaidulina, scheduled for next year. Like the violist Kim Kashkashian, Mr. Bashmet commissions new works both because he loves contemporary music and because so few top-notch concertos have been written for the instrument.
"In quantity there is enough music," he said. "Stamitz, Hoffmeister, thousands of names like that. In quality there is not enough. And that is also the reason I founded the chamber orchestra. Because I can't play third-class music all the time. Maybe second-class, but not third."
IN 1986, MR. BASHMET founded the Moscow Soloists as a vehicle with which to perfect his latest passion, conducting. But in 1992 the entire chamber orchestra emigrated to the West, a decision with which Mr. Bashmet strongly disagreed, and it eventually disbanded. Mr. Bashmet remained in Moscow and soon assembled a new Moscow Soloists.
Of most interest in the group's Carnegie Hall program is Mr. Bashmet's transcription of Brahms's Clarinet Quintet for solo viola and string orchestra. "I'm jealous of violinists and pianists, because they have concertos by Brahms, and I have not," he said. "The problem is that I perform music I love much better than music I like. So the idea was to prepare for myself this piece, since I love Brahms very much."
Mr. Bashmet exudes a childlike enthusiasm when he ponders the new horizons offered by conducting. In a surprisingly offhand manner, he admitted that he could conceive of a future in which conducting, not viola playing, would be his primary activity. "Honestly," he added hastily, "I have not decided yet where I am for real."
Today, Mr. Bashmet appears to be among Russia's economically privileged elite, earning income not only from performances and recordings but also as a professor at the Moscow Conservatory and the host of a nationally televised cultural talk show. His dacha, 40 minutes from Moscow, is situated in what he calls "the Russian Beverly Hills," the same community where Prokofiev once lived. Not for a moment does he seem to regret his decision to remain in Russia.
The pianist Alexander Slobodyanik, who grew up with Mr. Bashmet in Lvov and moved to the United States seven years ago, believes that the post-emigration demise of the first Moscow Soloists reinforced Mr. Bashmet's determination not to emigrate.
"He saw that it was unsuccessful for his first orchestra to leave the Soviet Union," Mr. Slobodyanik said. "They fell for materialistic things, real garbage. They dropped their holy goal to work for music and for Yuri Bashmet and just became nothing."
Mr. Bashmet does not speak charitably of those players either. "Those were the first years of perestroika, so it was a very difficult time in Moscow," he said. "And there was a big, strong virus for musicians to leave the Soviet Union."
He claims not to have suffered under the Soviet regime. "Nothing bad happened with me," he said. "I had my life going in the right way. Today I like to be at home, and besides, from whom could I get a better job than the one I have already?"
And indeed, where else could this violist, conductor and talk-show host enjoy the same degree of stardom?

INDUSTRY: SIC7922 THEATRICAL PRODUCERS (EXCEPT MOTION PICTURE) & MISCELLANEOUS THEATRICAL SERVICES (58%); 

COUNTRY: RUSSIAN FEDERATION (90%); UNITED STATES (88%); UKRAINE (57%);

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (90%);

HEADLINE: County Sees a Resurgence in Office Space

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE forlorn steel skeleton of 287 Corporate Plaza, a visible symbol of the recession from Exit 5 of the Cross Westchester Expressway, is now in the process of being transformed into a 133,000-square-foot, state-of-the-art office building more than a decade after the original work began.
"The site work began in 1985, when Westchester was one of the hottest suburban markets in the nation," said Guerrino Savio, the owner-developer and president of SCI Real Estate Development in Manhattan, which also owns and operates office buildings in Texas, Massachusetts and Connecticut. "However, by 1990, when the steel work went up, the boom years in Westchester were over." Mr. Savio recalled. "The tide had turned. The recession set in, and the office market collapsed. At that point, I decided to hold up on construction of 287 and wait until the market turned around." 
 And now is the hour, Mr. Savio said. Five months ago, workers began pouring cement and closing the sides of the three-floor steel framework. "The exterior of the building should be completed by next month," he said. "Ironically, the delay has been valuable in one sense. The original modern exterior designed by architect Renato Severino has been retained, but the construction design has been upgraded to accommodate all the state-of-the-art technological changes that have occurred over the last couple of years. This will not only be the first new office building to come on the market in Westchester in nearly 10 years but the first high-tech building constructed for the 21st century."
Eighteen months ago, before the decision was made to complete 287 Corporate Plaza, SCI retained the services of Carl Austin, head of Austin Corporate Properties, a commercial real-estate brokerage and marketing company in White Plains. Mr. Austin, who spent several months analyzing the prospective Westchester office market, concluded that the time was right to resume construction of a new office building.
"Why?" he said in answer to a question. "For starters, the regional economy has definitely improved; large blocks of contiguous office space are scarce in Westchester. Plus the chance to create new high-tech space on the last zoned piece available to us for office development."
Saying that the site was originally bought because it was one of the best in the region, Mr. Austin added, "It's a strategic location, bridging the east and west sections of the county, a major asset, symbolizing the county's coming of age."
Mr. Savio continued, "Although we are seeking a major tenant, thebuilding can easily be divided into two equal parts with customized interior configurations to tenants' specifications."
No leases have been signed, Mr. Austin said, "but a major insurance company is looking with serious intent, and the building is on everyone's must-see list."
The third quarter of 1996 was a slow one, according to a report from the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a corporate real-estate brokerage, management and consulting concern with offices in Purchase and Stamford.
"Although third quarter statistics point to a relatively quiet office market, there are a number of major deals in the works involving key office properties," said William V. Cuddy Jr., senior vice president of Rostenberg-Doern. By year end, Mr. Cuddy said, many leases for key office properties should be signed, leading to a surge in leasing activity and a decline in the countywide vacancy rate of 24 percent to about 20 percent.
"Until recently, the Westchester office market was driven by companies looking to relocate primarily for economic reasons," Mr. Cuddy said. "But now that rents have stabilized and the economy has recovered, companies are basing their leasing decisions on the fact that they need more space to grow their businesses. This is a positive and healthy sign for the market."
Observing that the market for Class A space is tightening, especially in downtown White Plains where there are only three office buildings with 30,000 square feet of contiguous space available for lease, Mr. Cuddy said, "Large blocks of prime space in the city's better buildings are becoming more difficult to find."
The survey of Westchester's five market areas showed that in the central business district -- downtown White Plains -- the city's vacancy rate rose to 28.3 percent from 26.6 percent at midyear, having been adversely affected by downsizing by Nynex and the New York Power Authority. Some major leases were signed, however, by Divney Consulting and Teachers Insurance.
In the eastern half of the county, including Purchase, Rye and Harrison, the office market bounced back, benefiting from expansions and relocations from within the county. Major transactions included Allstate, First Translife Insurance, Headquarters Companies, R. H. Donnelley, Transamerica and Zeus.
The office market in the western half of the county, which is made up primarily of Tarrytown and Elmsford, reported the lowest vacancy rate, declining at midyear to 12.8 percent from 14.7 percent. Major transactions here were CNA, Liberty Mutual, Westchester County and ZREX
The vacancy rate in the northern half of the county fell to 15.6 percent from 16 percent, with the Mid-Westchester Executive Park in Hawthorne reporting excellent leasing activity. Major transactions: Cityscape, Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, Lucent Technologies and Nextwave.
There was little leasing activity in the southern part of the county, an area that includes Yonkers, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon. The vacancy rate rose at midyear to 17.6 percent from 15.4 percent. Major transactions: Pico Electronics.
"Most recently, within the past two months, we've seen a healthy surge of interest leading to leasing transactions from companies in the financial services industry based in Manhattan," Mr. Cuddy said. "They are shopping for space in the White Plains area, citing lower rents, proximity to Manhattan and an improved quality of life as their chief reasons for relocating. It bodes well for the future."

HEADLINE: The View From: Farmington Canal;
As Greenways Expand, So Do Uses

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
JOANNE G. FEENEY of Glastonbury normally uses her Rollerblades along a highway or in a cemetery, but she's a bit apprehensive in both places. "In cemeteries you feel uncomfortable because it's not a playground, and on the road it's just not safe," she said.
So on a recent sunny Saturday morning Ms. Feeney made the half-hour trip to Farmington, where she honed her skating skills along a two-mile section of asphalt through the woods off Brickyard Road, along an old railroad line. The trail sides are bordered with wildflowers, and a few feet from the edge are bittersweet and grapevines draped over birch, maples and oak. She shared the trail with bikers, hikers, joggers and baby carriages; in the winter there will be cross-country skiers as well. And soon there will be more to the trail itself. Six towns in northern Connecticut received a $2.6 million grant this year to develop a 22-mile greenway along the Farmington Canal Heritage Trail, which will include the existing piece in Farmington, running south from the Massachusetts border to the Farmington River in Farmington. 
 "We're hopeful that by the year 2000 we're going to have a total connection -- someone will be able to hike, bike or skate from Massachusetts to Long Island Sound," said Leonard D. Tolisano, the Simsbury town planner who is coordinating the project. "The only glitch will be if the Federal Government decides to stop funding these projects. It is fairly expensive stuff."
Nancy H. Bostwick, executive director of the Farmington Canal Rail to Trail Association, said Cheshire and Hamden have about six miles done, and other towns along the Farmington Canal corridor have completed their own small greenways. "In the next few years, you could see a lot more built, linking these sections together, if we can just maintain the momentum," Ms. Bostwick said.
Advocates of the national "Rail to Trails" movement say it is part of a new fitness and recreation philosophy sweeping the United States. "The American culture is ready to get back outdoors," said William D. O'Neill, a principal in the Manchester engineering firm Fuss & O'Neill and the governor's appointee to the Connecticut Greenways Council.
At the urging of Gov. John G. Rowland, the New England Governors Council has endorsed the idea of a greenways tour of New England next May, Mr. O'Neill said. Side trips to greenways in New York and Montreal are also planned. And he is working with Amtrak on the concept of a biking package, in which people and their bikes could board in East Coast cities, travel to Hartford, then pick up the train somewhere else on the trail for a return trip.
"The Farmington Canal greenway is very high profile right now, because it sits right on a trail that people eventually hope will link Maine to Florida," Mr. O'Neill said. "We should be taking advantage of that attention."
The first sections of the Farmington Valley Greenway were paved in Simsbury and Farmington in 1994 and 1995. Then this year, the State Department of Transportation approved a $2.6 million grant under the Federal Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act to develop 22 miles of the trail through Avon, East Granby, Granby, Farmington, Simsbury and Suffield. "Bikeways are specifically stipulated in the law," said a Transportation Department spokesman, William E. Keish. "It gives the state a little flexibility in the use of the funds."
"People do bike to work," Mr. Keish said. "A lot of people even walk to work. According to the 1990 census almost as many people walk to work as take a bus or train."
Mr. Tolisano, the Simsbury town planner, said he has been surprised at how quickly the sections of greenway become well used.
"When we paved one section of the rail in Simsbury, people were literally following the paving machine," Mr. Tolisano said. "The blacktop was still steaming, and people were walking on it. On a nice weekend, these things are mobbed."
There have been some problems to overcome. The Simsbury section of the greenway runs right through the Ensign Bickford property, an explosives factory, so it was necessary to divert the trail almost four miles for safety purposes.
There will be other problems as the trail progresses farther south, into heavily developed areas around New Britain and New Haven. In Plainville, some of the old Farmington Canal trail is in the 80-acre Norton Park, but there are no plans for further development of greenways.
"Portions of the rail line are still active in Plainville, as well as in Cheshire," said Plainville Town Planner Mary M. Hughes. "I don't think the railroad would be too keen on having people walk along the tracks."
She said there is also occasional talk about instituting commuter rail service to Hartford from the suburbs, and there might be a need to retain some of the right of way for that purpose.
Ms. Bostwick of the Farmington Canal Rail to Trail Association said she understands why Plainville might hesitate to commit more of the right of way to recreation. "We've never advocated abandoning active rail corridors -- but if they are abandoned, we want to see them available for use by the public," she said.
There are also occasional concerns from neighbors, particularly in residential areas. In Avon, people in one neighborhood would not agree to the trail unless about 700 feet of fence was installed.
"Even there, there were some people who loved the greenway and fought the fences, but unfortunately there were more people who wanted the fences and the Town Council decided to build them," Mr. Tolisano said. "I guess it's better to argue about whether or not to build the fence than to argue about whether to build the greenway."
Along already-completed sections of the greenway, there are few complaints from neighbors. In fact, there are well-worn paths leading from residential areas to the trails that are done.
At Steve A. Guarino's home on Rosewood Drive in Farmington, the trail runs within 15 feet of a tool shed and garden in the back of his property. "I love it," said Mr. Guarino, who moved to the house in 1984, when the railroad was still operating. "There haven't been any problems with the people. Everyone is very nice, quiet. And it's given me a chance to meet new people. You can't talk to a train going by."
Mr. O'Neill said rural greenways have become popular, including East Bay Path in Rhode Island, as have urban ones, like the Minuteman Trail in Boston. Oregon has bike lockers for people who use their trails, and Colorado, Florida and California are all in the forefront of developing the paths. "We're just starting to catch up with some of these ideas in this part of the country," Mr. O'Neill said. In addition to the Farmington Canal trail, other paths under consideration are the Airline Trail from Windham to Middletown and the Charter Oak Trail from Plainfield to Hartford.
"It's typically a very grassroots kind of effort," Mr. O'Neill said. "More and more towns are seeing the value of it." In fact, greenways can generate some cash for a community. Mr. O'Neill said he has met with the State Department of Economic and Community Development to promote greenways -- studies show tourists to popular greenways spend $50 to $100 a day on their visits, primarily for food and lodging.
"There's a tremendous return on investment," Mr. O'Neill said. "A greenway can pay for itself in a few years. A greenway should not be considered a cost. It's an investment."
Ms. Bostwick said there are also some long-term issues to be resolved. Who. for example, will take care of the trails once they are linked? Most associations would like to see consistent standards along the entire path.
"At this point, as particular sectors are developed, the town where it is located takes it over, usually under its parks and recreation department," Ms. Bostwick said. "What we'd like to do is develop some sort of mechanism for regional management and maintenance."

HEADLINE: Confronting High Birth Rate For Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
TAKIMA GONZALEZ, a high school senior here, grew up long before she wanted to. For her, turning Sweet 16 had less to do with parties and pretty dresses than it did with a baby daughter called Shy-Nel and a boyfriend who was a father in name only. Instead of dreaming as other young women often do about college and a family someday in the future, this young woman struggles in the present to balance motherhood and schoolwork and loneliness.
"Life stopped short for me, just like that," Ms. Gonzalez, who is now 18, said recently. "Becoming a mother meant I couldn't hang out with my friends any more or go to parties or even have a regular conversation without worrying about whether the baby needed a clean diaper." 
 Her story is not an unusual one. Every year in the United States, 1.2 million teen-age girls bear children. While those numbers have dropped slightly in recent years, at 56.9 births for each 1,000 young women between 15 and 19 in 1995 -- nearly 6 percent -- America has by far the highest teen-age pregnancy rate for any industrialized democracy.
The incidence is startlingly higher in the neighborhood where Ms. Gonzalez is raising her daughter. Here, in a mostly business district with poor, predominantly minority residential areas, the numbers are 201 births for each 1,000 young women or 20 percent, which is the sixth-highest birth rate for teen-agers in the state. In Rochester, the rate is 37 percent, the state's highest, and in the central Harlem district of New York City, it is 32 percent.
The outlook for most teen-age mothers like Ms. Gonzalez is not promising, although she said she hoped to beat the odds. Statistics show that more than half of teen-age mothers drop out of school after having a baby, and they are more likely than older mothers to seek public assistance.
Ms. Gonzalez, however, is not on welfare, and she said she is determined to earn her diploma and graduate in June along with her classmates. When she is not studying or caring for 2-year-old Shy-Nel, she works as a photographer's assistant at a portrait studio in a nearby mall. Her grandmother, with whom she lives, and her mother, who lives nearby, help care for the child, and the father, who is unemployed, visits his daughter once a month and occasionally contributes to the expenses of raising her. Ms. Gonzalez said she had refused to marry him "just because I had his baby."
In Yonkers, where the teen-age pregnancy rate is 17 percent, Jesenia Rodriquez shares a similar story, although she receives some public assistance.
Now 18, Ms. Rodriquez lost a year of school when her son, Joshua, now 11 months, was born, and she is completing her graduate equivalency diploma and beginning college studies for a degree in social work through a program offered at an extension unit of Mercy College.
But she shares none of the student camaraderie that she had hoped for at college, and like Ms. Gonzalez, she is alone much of the time. Ms. Rodriquez spends most of her days with Joshua in their small basement apartment, which is decorated with hand-me-down furniture and photographs of the toddler's first year.
Increasingly, stories like these young women's have become the focus of an intense political debate. The welfare reform bill signed into law by President Clinton on Aug. 22 will mean stricter work requirements and less public support for young women and their children.
"We consider it a very punitive law," said Bob Hochman, coordinator of the Yonkers-based Teen Linkage Program of the Westchester County Department of Health, which helps pregnant teen-agers, teen-age mothers and young women considered at high risk of becoming pregnant. "The message is that you guys are on your own and that if you're going to get pregnant, we're not going to support you."
Donna M. Butts, executive director of the Washington-based National Organization on Adolescent Pregnancy, Parenting and Prevention, a nonprofit group, called it "an abstinence only" measure.
She said that under the law, states with programs that teach teen-agers to prevent pregnancy by abstaining from sex will be eligible for $250 million in matching block grants.
Citing statistics showing that 70 percent of teen-agers have sexual experiences before they leave high school, Ms. Butts said, "Hope, not abstinence, is the best form of birth control."
She said that teen-age pregnancy is linked to low socioeconomic conditions, lower intellectual and academic achievement, unemployment, child abuse, drinking and drugs.
Ms. Rodriquez, who works as a peer counselor for the Teen Linkage Program, said some girls choose to have a baby because "they need someone to be with who won't leave them."
In counseling other young women, she is quick to tell them that having a baby is a lot of hard work: "I met one girl in a class who said: 'Oh, babies are so cute, it's so easy to take care of them. You just give them milk.' But I told her babies have tantrums and they want to get picked up all the time."
Ms. Rodriquez's case is unusual in that she has continued her relationship with the baby's father, who visits the family every day and contributes to Joshua's support.
"Before I met him, I hung out with street guys, with hoodlums," she said. "I grew up in the projects, and that was my view of the world. Maybe I thought I couldn't do better."
Ms. Rodriquez said the baby's father works after school and gives her $300 a month -- and "if Joshua needs sneakers or something else, he gives me more."
Ms. Butts and other social workers are worried that the new welfare law is unduly harsh and will cause hardships for many mothers like Ms. Rodriquez and Ms. Gonzalez.
"Everyone agrees that we needed some type of welfare reform, but this bill has unfairly targeted adolescent mothers," she said. "There are young women who are succeeding, who are doing everything to be a good mother and make a better life, and we need to give them credit and recognition."
The new welfare law, in addition to promoting abstinence, limits the time young mothers can spend on public assistance to two years. And it requires that teen-age mothers return to school or enter a job-training program within 12 weeks after the birth of their babies.
Also under the law, mothers younger than 18 are required to live with a responsible adult, although some social workers fear that that requirement could return many young women to abusive homes.
Norman Shaw, a spokesman for the county's Department of Social Services, said his department had not yet assessed the full impact of the new Federal law on the 700 or so new teen-age mothers each year in Westchester. "We are waiting like everyone else in the state to see exactly what the rules and regulations are," he said.
Meanwhile, some programs in the county are trying to address the problems of teen-age pregnancy. In White Plains, the city's Youth Bureau is recruiting bilingual women who were teen-age mothers to serve as mentors, said Deveira Searcy, a youth specialist. The department also oversees weekly meetings of a newly formed Young Women's Empowerment Group. More information on those programs can be obtained by calling Ms. Searcy at 422-1277.
At the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains, Evelyn Sadler, program director for the School-Based Adolescent Parenting Program, said her organization is trying to reduce the school dropout rate for young mothers.
The Y.W.C.A. runs a weekly support group for mothers and provides day care for babies and young children "with the requirement that their mothers stay in school," said Ms. Sadler, who can be reached at 949-6227.
The number for Mr. Hochman at the Teen Linkage Program in Yonkers is 966-6611.
Planned Parenthood in White Plains has programs for teen-age mothers and fathers, and that group's number is 467-7300.
To get in touch with Home Health Services of Westchester Jewish Community Services, which runs a Mother Child Home Program, the person to call is Terry Lanigan, program director, at 949-0788, extension 238.
But Marie C. Wilson, president of the New York City-based Ms. Foundation for Women, said the need was for more programs that emphasized young women's potential and their strengths, because "too often when we focus on girls, we look only at their problems."

HEADLINE: When the Bills Are Over the Top

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THREE layoffs in in the past six years left the Litchfield County man with a mountain of debt that forced him into bankruptcy. The job he holds now as sales manager for a small contracting supply business grows more uncertain every day as the company's sales dwindle. The 35-year-old man and his wife, who have two young children, have put their home up for sale.
For several years during the early 1990's, the man and his wife, a regional manager for a retail store, earned a combined income of $90,000 a year. Confident about the future, they enjoyed trips to Europe and Disney World. They took day excursions and went out to dinner often. But the good times were short-lived, and the third layoff came last year. 
 The family's expenses -- a $150,000 mortgage on a new home, a second car, day care, taxes, loans and clothes for the children -- piled up. Soon, they were using credit cards to make the mortgage payment and buy necessities like diapers. Their card balance eventually rose to $28,000.
"We lived day by day and didn't care about tomorrow," the man said. "Then, all of a sudden, tomorrow was different, and we didn't plan. We grasped at whatever life preserver was there."
While Connecticut's economy slowly gained strength, personal bankruptcy filings between 1990 and 1995 increased by 74 percent, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute in Alexandria, Va. Last year, there were 8,884 filings, compared with 5,099 in 1990. This year, personal bankruptcies reached 5,000 in the first six months alone.
These figures reflect a nationwide trend, said Paul Getman, president and economist for Regional Financial Associates of Westchester, Pa., an economic consulting and forecasting firm. "Bankruptcy is rising at a very strong rate all across the United States," Mr. Getman said. "What's puzzling is that it's rising not only in places like Connecticut, that are growing slowly, but also in states where the economy is fairly healthy." Speculation on the causes of the bankruptcies in the state ranges from a decline in real estate prices to excessive spending and high credit card debt. Most people in Connecticut file for bankruptcy after losing high-paying jobs in once-thriving industries like military contracting, aircraft manufacturing and insurance. With new jobs that pay considerably less, they depend on credit to maintain their life style, said Donald Klepper-Smith an economist and president of DataCore Partners Inc., an economic analysis firm.
"Getting ahead hasn't been part of this economic recovery," said Mr. Klepper-Smith. "My concern is that when the next recession arrives it is going to claim a lot of people who are living on the margin."
Another contributing factor is that banks and other financial companies have made borrowing easier. Prompted by recent losses, however, some have begun to tighten their credit requirements, said Mr. Getman. In the future, he added, financial companies will be making fewer offers of credit at low interest rates.
There are two types of personal bankruptcy under the Federal bankruptcy code. Chapter 7 involves liquidating most assets and being freed from debts except for child support, student loans, most taxes and secured loans. Chapter 13 allows people who are employed to keep their possessions while paying off their debts under a three- to five-year payment plan.
Kenneth Crone, vice president in charge of risk management for Visa U.S.A., declined to comment on whether or not Visa relaxed its standards for credit card applicants and in doing so, took some bad credit risks. Mr. Crone said each financial company in Visa's membership establishes its own borrowing requirements and level of risk.
However, Visa advised its members in a report dated July 1996, to educate cardholders about the negative aspects of bankruptcy and the option to file under Chapter 13, the wage-earner's repayment program, rather than Chapter 7, under which a person is freed from most debts.
Visa and MasterCard are testing radio, print and television advertisements encouraging consumers to obtain financial counseling before filing for bankruptcy. The report stated that some financial companies had already begun programs to persuade cardholders either to seek an alternative to bankruptcy or to exclude their credit card debt when they file. Restoration of card privileges is offered as an incentive to those who agree to pay off their balances.
While consumers spent extravagantly during the 1980's, the clients who turn to financial counseling now are not doing so because they have been irresponsible with their money, said Beverly Tuttle, president of Consumer Credit Counseling Services of Connecticut Inc., a firm with offices in Hartford, Groton, Danbury and Milford.
Most clients, having worked hard all their lives, never expected to lose their jobs, she said. They are accustomed to using their credit cards for unplanned expenses like car and home repairs. But still unemployed after several months, they have gone through their savings. The average client owes about $16,000 in credit card debt, Ms. Tuttle added.
"As we get closer to the holidays, how are we going to grow the economy when people are tapped out?" she asked.
On a sunny October morning, 63 people sat waiting for their bankruptcy hearings in a room in a building across from New Haven Green. The group included an older couple whose supplemental insurance failed to cover heavy medical bills and a student who charged unexpected college expenses to her credit cards and then fell behind in her payments. Also waiting was the owner of a cleaning service, whose main customer closed and moved from the state.
Alan Sibarium, a private lawyer in Farmington and a bankruptcy trustee, called each person to a table at the front of the room, where he sat surrounded by stacks of files. Acting on behalf of the bankruptcy court, he examined each person's statement of assets and liabilities and asked a series of questions: "Have you given any money or property to anyone in the past year? Where are your bank accounts? Is anybody holding any property for you? Have you given any financial statements out?"
If there are no assets, which is true in most personal bankruptcies, the case is closed, and the person is notified in several months that the debts have been discharged. Despite reports that bankruptcy has lost some of its stigma, Mr. Sibarium said the people he meets at hearings find the experience emotionally draining. "You're stripping yourself naked," he said. "It means exposing yourself as a failure."
As the Litchfield County man said: "I kept it a big secret from my employer, my friends and my family. I told my parents only a few weeks ago. It's almost as if you have the plague."
Consumer Credit Counseling, started in 1980 with a staff of three, currently employs 47 counselors. Two work full time running education programs on credit and family budgeting. "A lot of people don't hear about us until it's too late," Ms. Tuttle said. "If they have the opportunity, most people will choose to work out their debts."
Clients who begin paying their bills in small but regular monthly installments can be free of debt in three or four years, Ms. Tuttle said. "We find out how they got into trouble and how to avoid it in the future," she said. "We work out a living budget they can stick with, but we hand them scissors and have them cut up their credit cards."
Although bankruptcy offers a chance to start over, it does not change the fact that many people cannot live on a budget, Ms. Tuttle said. "I'm in my 60's. When I was a little girl, we saved for things. That's a notion people have forgotten."
The Litchfield County man is philosophical about his financial problems. The experience has taught him and his family to live more modestly, he said. Instead of vacation trips and dinners out, they hike and go camping. At Christmastime, they plan to exchange homemade gifts. They learned the importance of long- and short-term goals.
"It's not a disaster. There are reasons for this," he said. "We know how to deal with money now. We know when to say no to the kids. And I'm wearing my $15 Wrangler jeans."

HEADLINE: New Britain Tries to Cope With Drug Traffickers

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
DAWN broke over the Mount Pleasant housing development in New Britain as the police teams swept through. A few minutes earlier, more than 50 state and city police officers had entered three apartments, searching for people wanted on drug charges. Now, with a half-dozen suspects locked away in a confinement van, investigators were combing through hallways and alleys, hunting for stragglers.
Capt. Dennis Beatty, in charge of the New Britain Police Department's investigations division, stood on a road between the targeted apartments, watching the proceedings stoically. He noted that Mount Pleasant has a reputation that belies its name. Earlier this year, a man was killed on a street corner a few yards away in what Captain Beatty called "a drug deal gone bad." 
 "It's a housing project," he explained. "Because of the density of the population, it's tougher. They've been dealing a lot of drugs out of here for a long time. Lots of calls for service here."
A knot of young residents watched the show, recognizing friends and acquaintances as they were led away in handcuffs. One of the spectators, Jose Angel Felix, 21, complained that the police had rushed into his family's apartment and rousted him naked from his bed.
"They said: 'Open the door.' They didn't say who they were or nothing. We see the State Police coming in, saying they got an arrest warrant for Angel Felix, my brother. I told them I wasn't him. They asked if I got I.D. Then they took my brother away."
Police officers said that many of those arrested were members of the Hilltop Posse, a drug gang that operates in the 240-unit housing complex. Mr. Felix and his companions disputed the existence of the organization, although in somewhat contradictory terms. Suddenly, from a dark enclosure, a bald, husky man darted out, with a pair of police officers in pursuit. The group of spectators cheered the fugitive on.
"Is that Montana?" one of the young women asked her friends. It was Montana Kelly, 28, one of those for whom the police had a warrant, for misrepresentation of a controlled substance. To the onlookers' disappointment, Mr. Kelly's flight was soon cut short, and he was led into the van.
Not everyone in Mount Pleasant was rooting against the police. Kay Davis, president of the Mount Pleasant Residents Council, later said "it's about time the police did something." If she had it her way, she added, the police would station officers here, rather than just sending patrols.
Police officers later said they confiscated a few "dime bags" of marijuana during the bust. The seven or eight residents who cheered Mr. Kelly acknowledged that marijuana use was common at Mount Pleasant. All but Mr. Felix admitted to using the drug themselves.
"It's not fair," said one young man. "The drug laws are too strict. You look at alcohol. If you drink and drive a car, you're driving a deadly weapon. With pot, you're not going anywhere."
A young woman characterized marijuana use as an innocent enjoyment. "Who I hang with, me, my friends, we smoke," she said. But she added she wouldn't want to see the drug legalized. She regarded crack cocaine with greater concern. "I don't appreciate it," she said. "I got my son out here to worry about."
New Britain has been dealing with street gangs for decades, but in recent years they have taken on a more sinister character. "Before, it was like those gangs in 'West Side Story'," Captain Beatty said. "It was kids just hanging out together, getting into fights. Then rock cocaine came in."
A 23-year veteran of the city force, Captain Beatty sounded almost wistful as he continued: "Gangs used to be about love, honor and companionship. Now all that's gone. It's just about the money." Within 24 hours, police officers said all but one of 15 people sought had been netted.
"The objective of the operation was to arrest street-level dealers in Mount Pleasant," said Lieut. Edward Kasche, commander of the State Police Statewide Cooperative Crime Control Task Force. "It went very well," he said.
Nevertheless, it was a small operation by recent standards. Earlier in the year, the target had been the Jungle Brothers, a less geographically confined gang. Last May, 22 people were arrested following a racketeering investigation of that gang by New Britain Police and another arm of the State Police, the Statewide Narcotics Unit.
By comparison, the Hilltop bust "is maintenance work," said Christopher L. Morano, a prosecutor with the Gang and Continuing Criminal Activity Bureau. The objective, he added, is to get drug dealers off the streets and send the message that the police are aware of what is going on.
At a time when gang activity is reportedly in decline throughout Connecticut, New Britain stands out as bucking the trend. In addition to the Jungle Brothers, reportedly still active although reeling from the May operation, there are two other major gangs: Los Solidos and Netas.
Mr. Morano said the problem in New Britain seems to be related to law enforcement successes in larger cities like Hartford. "As heat was pressed into the big cities, for some reason we're finding that many gang members would go to New Britain," he said. "They either started up many of the same gangs with the same names, or they created coalitions with other transient gang members."
"I would call New Britain the United Nations of gangs in Connecticut," he added. "There are more potential trouble spots there than anywhere else in the state."
Chief among them may be North and Oak, a downtown section in the north-central part of the city that reportedly remains one of the few open-air drug markets left in Connecticut. "You can stand there and see them deal," said Richard Lopes, a coordinator with the Neighborhood Housing Services, which serves New Britain housing developments.
Other areas of the city are quieter, though, and more indicative of a trend for the better. "The police have done a great job," Mr. Lopes said. "Drug dealers are always going to be there, but they're trying to get them out of public view, from destroying the character of the neighborhood."
It could be worse, and, in fact, it has been. There have been two murders this year attributed to gang violence, not including the Mount Pleasant killing. That's down from 10 reported in 1995. Gang violence reached its peak in November of 1993, when an 18-year-old student and member of the Latin Kings gang was fatally shot outside New Britain High School. City officials agree the situation has been steadily improving since then.
Yet the drugs remain. In the Jungle Brothers sting operation, which followed seven months of investigation, the police said they seized $40,000 in cash and close to three pounds of crack cocaine.
In other undercover purchases, Mr. Morano said, the police made small buys. "Here," he said, "we were able to make large, large buys, ounces, multi-ounces of cocaine, which in the scheme of things is a good size. They're going for thousands of dollars a shot."
One reason New Britain is so attractive to gangs is mobility. The city is a nexus for several important highways, including Interstate 84 and Route 9.
"We are a corridor," said Police Chief William J. Sencio. "We have folks from New York that show up. Because we got started late, word got out that New Britain was fertile ground."
Such factors have helped the city further cultivate an already tough reputation. Not everyone feels it is completely deserved.
"New Britain is not the gang capital of central Connecticut," Mayor Lucian Pawlak said. "Most of it is image, with a definite sprinkling of reality."
It is an image New Britain cannot afford, not with an 11 percent unemployment rate and only one local business, Stanley Tools, that employs more than 1,000 people. Mayor Pawlak pointed out that the budget for law enforcement is tight, which is why outside aid like the State Police task force and grants from the state and Federal Government are especially appreciated.
"Our biggest objective is to use all the tools available," he said. "We're still looking for state and Federal help. But ultimately, when you're fighting the drug culture, policing can only go so far. You can't make real headway without education."

HEADLINE: Nathan Hale's Schoolhouse, Looking for a Home Again

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
NATHAN HALE, Connecticut's official state hero, was hanged by the British as a spy on Sept. 22, 1776. His schoolhouse, however, goes marching on . . . and on . . . and on . . .
The one-room shingled schoolhouse, with a chimney at the back, has been moved so many times around the little city of New London (7.3 square miles, about 30,000 people) that a common local jest is that it should be on wheels, or roller skates. And now there are two separate plans to move the schoolhouse one more time -- presumably the last time -- within the old whaling city. 
 The saga of the wandering schoolhouse dates to 1774 when Hale was hired as its schoolmaster. He arrived at the little building, Union Grammar School on State Street, with good credentials. A native of Coventry, he had been educated at Yale College in New Haven and then spent one school year teaching school in East Haddam.
The proprietors of the New London school were happy with the new teacher, and he with his job. But after a year, he quit, explaining his rationale in a letter: "School-keeping is a business of which I was always fond, but since my residence in this town everything has conspired to render it more agreeable. I have never thought of quitting it but with my life, but at present there seems an opportunity for more extended public service."
He joined a Connecticut regiment for service in the Revolution. In little more than a year, he would be dead, and immortalized by the words: "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country."
The schoolhouse survived as a memento of his life, and a tie to a time when Connecticut was a British Colony, but it too has seen its share of danger.
A chronology of the schoolhouse, supplied by the Connecticut Sons of the American Revolution, which owns the building, reveals that it remained on State Street for more than half a century after Hale's death, then was moved to Union and Golden streets in 1830, to be used as a private home.
Thus it remained until just after the turn of this century when the S.A.R. bought it and moved it to the city's burial ground on Huntington Street. It was there until 1966 when it was moved again, to Crystal Avenue, next to the old town mill. In 1975 it was shifted again because the new Gold Star bridge, spanning the Thames River from New London to Groton, was perched above it.
Back went the schoolhouse to State Street, this time squeezed in between City Hall and a church, and State Street wasn't even State Street, officially, anymore. It had been converted into a pedestrian mall and renamed Captain's Walk, a big hope for the redevelopment of New London's downtown.
It was at this time that Robert C. Weller, president of Mitchell College and a scholar and authority on Nathan Hale, led a movement to move the schoolhouse to the college campus a few miles away.
It appeared to be a done deal when the S.A.R. offered to sell the schoolhouse to the college for one dollar and the college trustees voted $30,000 for the move. Mitchell, a junior college, even erected a statue of Nathan Hale and named one of its buildings Nathan Hale Hall in anticipation of the move.
It never became a reality, however, because of last-minute political pressure to keep it where it was. The fear was that the absence of the schoolhouse would hurt the chances for success of Captain's Walk.
Eventually, Captain's Walk failed anyway, the idea of a pedestrian mall was abandoned, and State Street became State Street again, open for cars. Now, suddenly, the old school was in the way again. So it was moved again in 1988 by the city, but only a few hundred feet to a little plaza down State Street near the railroad station.
There it has remained, an 18th- century school, no longer open to visitors, near a late-20th century parking garage. And now, rather quietly, two separate plans have been advanced to take it elsewhere, a possibility that has met with some interest by officials of the Sons of the American Revolution, which still owns the building, and who think the city has not treated it well.
Howard Dodd of Groton Long Point, the property steward of the S.A.R., said the city did a "terrible job" when it last moved the schoolhouse. Instead of a footing, non-conpacted rubble was used as a foundation for the chimney, he said. The chimney is now being propped up by wood and the back part of the building is sagging, he said. Also, he added, the city refused to give a 99-year lease on the State Street site, contending that it could not guarantee what a future council might do.
John A. Ricketts of Norwich, the state president of the S.A.R., said he does not like the present site. "It's out of place in that setting," he said. The governing body of the S.A.R. voted months ago to look into the possibility of "turning the building over to a worthwhile organization."
However, Mr. Ricketts cautioned, the building is fragile. Much work would have to be done just to get it into condition for a move, the move itself would be costly and, very important, his organization does not have money for that.
One of the two new proposals is from Frederick L. McGuire of Orange, Calif., an ex-Naval officer and retired professor of medical psychology at University of California.
Mr. McGuire is a native of New London and knew the old schoolhouse as a boy. "I used to play inside it when it was in the old cemetery," he said. He is also a l948 graduate of Mitchell College, very active in its alumni association, and became intrigued by the possibility of having the Hale schoolhouse on the campus after talking to the college's retired president, Mr. Weller, who had nearly been successful claiming it two decades ago. "The more I thought about it, the more angry I got," said Mr. McGuire.
For months, Mr. McGuire has been writing letters and running up a huge telephone bill pleading his case in Connecticut. He hopes that the 50th reunion of his class, in 1998, would vote to raise enough money to do that, but says there has been no real commitment yet. "We want what's best for the schoolhouse and best for the college," he said.
In any case, he believes that the college would provide a safe haven for the schoolhouse and allow it to be open to the public. It would also provide a centerpiece for the study of American history, he said, and enhance the reputation of the college.
He has been backed by the long-retired Mr. Weller who fears for the physical safety of the school where it now stands. "Sooner or later, there's going to be an accident there," he said. One time, he added, he saw the building set on fire by a vandal but fortunately the blaze was quickly extinguished.
The second schoolhouse offer came in October from Dr. Dorothy Leib, a former member of the New London City Council and chairwoman of the city's 350th anniversary celebration this year. She would like to relocate the schoolhouse to property of the Hempsted houses, two historical homes owned by the state Antiquarian and Landmarks Society about half a mile away from the present site. This would involve using close to $20,000 left over from the anniversary celebration to help finance the move.
"It would be where people could look at it," she said, "and it wouldn't be shaken all the time as it is now, from vibrations from trains and heavy traffic."
City officials and others interested in the schoolhouse have mixed reactions about moving it, and where.
Mayor William Satti's reaction was, "Here we go again." He said he would not want the school to be moved -- "It's a beautiful spot and hundreds of thousands of cars go by it each year."
The New London City Manager, Richard M. Brown, said he believes that Mitchell College is a little out of the way as a home for the school. However, he added, there is talk in the city of a trolley to take people around to local historical attractions and the argument could be made that the college is close to another attraction, Monte Cristo Cottage, the boyhood home of the playwright Eugene O'Neill.
"Absolutely wonderful," said Louise Showwalter about relocating the school on the college campus. She is the director of the nation's oldest custom house, now a museum on Bank Street, another of the attractions that could be tied together by a trolley. The college, she said, "would be most appropriate for the schoolhouse; Nathan Hale was a schoolteacher."
Some of the S.A.R. members seem to be in favor of a move to the Mitchell campus. "I think it's great," said Fillmore Buchanan of Gales Ferry, a former president of the state association. "The college would make a beautiful location."
Stephen Lee, a former president of the local S.A.R. chapter, also said he would favor moving it. "It may inspire college students," he said.
But New London's historian, Sally Ryan, said she would hate to see the schoolhouse far away from the center of town, as did John W. Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Commission. "It takes it out of context," Mr. Shannahan said. "It's like moving Mount Vernon out to Baltimore."
He also questioned the idea of having such an important historical building on a college campus. "The mission of an educational institution is education," he said, not historical preservation.
The only sure bet is that something is going to happen with the old schoolhouse, either a move somewhere else or major rehabilitation work, although where the money for that would come from is anyone's guess. The schoolhouse is in precarious shape and members of the organization that owns it think the city of New London has done them wrong. In a larger sense, it seems that the old schoolhouse deserved more respect from a lot of people in the more than two centuries that have passed since a 20-year-old schoolteacher walked away from it, and into history.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Nathan Hale schoolhouse at its present site, a busy corner in downtown New London. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
The Growing Nonprofit Partnership With For-Profits

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
TROUBLE not of their making has made partners of Carlton Collier and Martin Horwitz, one from the nonprofit world, the other a private owner.
They are working together on a rehabilitation project in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn that illustrates the new ties forming between the nonprofit and for-profit sectors as public subsidies for low-income housing development shrink. 
 These cutbacks mean that public assistance that benefits low-income people must concentrate on preserving the existing, occupied housing stock. The nonprofit organizations that heretofore concentrated on developing tax-foreclosed buildings that the city had owned are now joining in the process of upgrading occupied buildings that have never been in city ownership.
In the process, the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development is demonstrating the flexibility of its participation loan program, through which public and private loans are used to finance the modernization of buildingwide systems that all properties periodically require.
But even preservation work in occupied buildings in low-income neighborhoods -- much less costly than city takeover and eventual conveyance to new ownership after reconstruction at public expense -- is being set back by the cessation in new commitments for Federal housing subsidies under the Section 8 program.
These subsidies are rent supplements that pay the difference between an affordable rent -- 30 percent of income -- and the economic rent that a rehabilitated property needs to meet its expenses.
Carlton Collier is the project manager of a nonprofit entity called Community Assisted Tenant Controlled Housing, known as Catch, a citywide mutual housing association financed by the Parodneck Foundation, based in Manhattan. Martin Horwitz is a principal in MFA Construction Inc., of Great Neck, L.I. He and his partner, David H. Schwartz, own and manage 16 properties with 1,100 apartments in New York City.
In Crown Heights their two organizations are partners in the resuscitation of three side-by-side buildings known as Balfour Court, on Sterling Place along the long block between Utica Avenue and Rochester Avenue. These old walk-ups -- Nos. 1470, 1484 and 1480 -- acquired a certain local infamy under a former ownership. A crack factory prospered in one building, a tenant was caught running a veritable store for stolen goods and police officers of the 77th Precinct became constant visitors.
Balfour Court never fell into city ownership. Instead, a bankruptcy court appointed a receiver to run the building, while Catch sought to buy it through the bankruptcy proceedings. But for a project of the size of Balfour Court the nonprofit needed a financial and construction partner.
The Brooklyn office of the Community Preservation Corporation, a bank consortium that lends for housing rehabilitation, led the nonprofit to MFA Construction, which has a record of rehabilitation success. Now Catch is handling the community work, tenant relations and renting-up at Balfour Court, and MFA is overseeing the construction and management.
The financing for the job also illustrates partnership: The equity of $1.8 million was provided through the New York Equity Fund, the entity that raises tax-credit financing from the corporate world for the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the Enterprise Foundation, two organizations that work with nonprofit community groups to develop low-income housing.
At Balfour Court, tax-credit financing is being utilized for the first time in the rehabilitation of a privately owned building that has remained partially tenanted. "In the past, tax-credit financing was mainly used for doing vacant buildings," said William R. Frey, director of the New York office of the Enterprise Foundation. "Now there's a need for financing for preserving occupied buildings."
About half of the 60 nonprofit organizations that have acquired development financing through the Enterprise Foundation are now using private companies for management purposes, Mr. Frey said. Some relationships have evolved to the point where the two entities are considering joint development, he said. "The community groups are finding it makes economic sense," Mr. Frey said. "It's healthy for the development world."
Less healthy are the prospects of bringing these partnerships to bear in buildings like Balfour Court without Section 8 subsidies.
I N the old days, Section 8 would be available to tenants who could not afford the post-rehabilitation restructured rents," said Mr. Schwartz, a partner in the development group. Now, instead, the city must provide more low-interest long-term financing, the equity subsidy from the sale of tax credit must be higher, or the rents for vacant apartments must be higher in order to make a project work. At Balfour Court, all three techniques were used.
The total development cost is projected at $6,050,000, or $63,000 per apartment, Mr. Schwartz said. That includes an acquisition cost of about $1 million, plus a sizable amount of work, costing $33,000 per apartment in pure construction costs for buildings in severe distress. Seventy-seven percent of the total development cost has been supplied through public programs -- low-interest loans, a Federal grant and tax-credit financing. A conventional loan came from the Community Preservation Corporation.
All of this has created an opportunity for 21-year-old Tanika Bullard. An assistant to the owner of a small publishing company in Manhattan, she has rented a third-floor two-bedroom apartment for herself and her 9-month-old son, Tyshaun. The rent is $605 a month.
"This will be my first move away from home," said Ms. Bullard. She has lived with her mother and grandmother in a rented apartment in a brownstone in the Clinton Hill area of Brooklyn all her life.
Another new tenant will be Ethel Smokes, 44, coming from a much smaller two-bedroom apartment on Franklin Avenue, eight blocks from her new apartment, with her 20-year-old son, Don Browne. Ms. Smokes is a nurse's aide working in a private home. At $603 a month for her fourth-floor two-bedroom, her new rent will be less than her present $655 a month.
"It's worthwhile renting this apartment if you qualify," said Ms. Smokes. "Not everyone qualifies."
The more conventional projects that use participation loan financing do not need the supplemental financing that Balfour Court required. The level of work is less comprehensive, and the rent-paying capacity of the tenants is higher.
In Washington Heights, Lemle & Wolff, a Bronx-based owner-manager, is about to close on a loan for work at 530 Audubon Avenue, a five-story walk-up. In Inwood, in northern Manhattan, it is in construction on improvements to a 20-unit walk-up at 54 Vermilyea Avenue. No tax-credit financing was required for either job. The city is putting up half the financing needed. No rent restructuring is expected.
At 1740 Grand Avenue in the Morris Avenue section of the Bronx, PWB Management Company, headed by Peter Bourbeau, is doing about $2.2 million in work with a participation loan. In this case, tax-credit financing was required.
"Every year I will have to go door-to-door to ask tenants their income," said Mr. Bourbeau. Enough tenants have earnings low enough to qualify the property for this financing, which makes a rent restructuring, and Section 8 assistance, unnecessary.
Gloria Blakeney, a licensed Head Start teacher, and her husband, Hazel, a bus driver, are among the beneficiaries. Their two-bedroom apartment is so large that Mrs. Blakeney can handle five preschoolers every day from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M.
But as a 13-year resident, their rent is only $532 a month. "They're doing a lot of renovation now," Mrs. Blakeney said. "We're getting a modern stove, a larger refrigerator, and new sinks and vanities in the bathrooms. Our rent is going up $25 a month in our new lease. I'm willing to pay for all the things I'm getting."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
As Old Offices Languish, the New in Newark Lease

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IT was once a prestigious corporate address in downtown Newark. But in the last five years, as the operator's lease wound down, there was a marked decline in capital investment in the classic, 1930's office tower at 744 Broad Street, leading tenants to move out and more than doubling the building's vacancy rate to about 70 percent, brokers and the owner say.
Because of this, the wedding cake-style, 543,548-square-foot structure -- at 35 stories one of the tallest in the state -- is now on the market. It is part of the city's ample supply of vacant secondary office space. 
 The building's high vacancy rate underscores the widening gulf between older and newer buildings that make up the 11-million-square-foot downtown office market, which crumbled as the middle-class exodus and a poor economy vacuumed commerce from the downtown core in the 60's and 70's.
The vacancy rate for the 4.6 million square feet of prime space -- much of it in the four-building, 2.5 million-square-foot Gateway office and hotel complex where the last structure was complete a decade ago -- is 4.4 percent. For the 6.6 million square feet of secondary space, centered in the Military Park and Broad Street areas, it is 32.6 percent, according to the Newmark Partners brokerage in Mountainside, a subsidiary of the Manhattan-based Newmark & Company. It is the exclusive marketing agent for 744 Broad Street.
The dichotomy, in many ways, reflects what is happening throughout the 11-county northern New Jersey marketplace, where there is a dwindling supply of Class A space. The difference is that while the lack of such space has caused activity in other markets to filter to secondary buildings the same has not happened so far in Newark.
But the sellers of 744 Broad Street, like city officials and some industry observers, are hoping that will change as new projects to stoke the area's revival are realized. Among them are a proposed sports complex along the Passaic River waterfront and a monorail linking the downtown more directly to Newark International Airport.
The key part of the strategy, however, is the $200 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the state's response to New York City's Lincoln Center, whose first phase is now rising on 12 acres between Park Place and the Passaic River.
Although the first phase, including a 2,700-seat multipurpose hall with a 500-seat studio theater, is to open next October little tangible impact has been felt so far. Whether it will create the street life needed to facilitate the recovery of the nearby Military Park and Broad Street submarkets remains an unanswered question, said Robert J. Rudin, executive director of the Edward S. Gordon brokerage offices in Saddle Brook.
As was the case with the area around Lincoln Center, it could take two decades before a full downtown economic transformation can occur, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy and Planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "There is no easy answer for Newark," he said.
Still, some nearby landlords are encouraged by the new construction under way and in the offing. One landlord, the local Berger Organization, bought the old Hahne's department store on Broad Street to convert it into a retail and office complex.
"It is part of an overall amenities package," said Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation, referring to the arts center. Corporations have asked why they should come to Newark, Mr. Faiella noted, adding: "Short of sending cab fare, we have now given them a reason to come."
TO be sure, memories of the 1967 rioting, the city's perceived image of crime and a Federal investigation of Newark officials, including Mayor Sharpe James, portend a continued uphill climb for Newark and its downtown office market.
The fact that all major highways, railroads and flight paths lead to Newark has helped fill its new office towers, like those at the Gateway complex, where safety concerns are eased by over-the-sidewalk-bridges that connect it to Pennsylvania station.
The demand is coming mostly from companies already in the city as well as from state, county and Federal agencies. There have been a limited number of outside firms evincing interest.
A big space user these days is the Prudential Insurance Company, which has its headquarters here. As part of its restructuring the insurer has over the last year relocated some 878 employees to the city and taken 129,000 additional square feet, said Rick Matthews, a spokesman, adding the process will continue into 1997.
Much of the new space was in Gateway Center I and II, the latter the only one of the four buildings in the complex that Prudential does not own. The Townsend Company of Towson, Md., is under contract to buy that 783,000-square-foot building from AT&T, underscoring the stability of the Class A market commercial brokers said.
"There have been little pinches in the arm enabling the Class A market to hold its own," said Richard S. Baumstein, an executive director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage. But, he added, there is no significant growth in the marketplace from outsiders.
Given that, Mr. Baumstein said, the demand is not yet there to absorb the abundance of secondary space on the market.
Many buildings in the Broad Street and Military Park areas were built before 1977. Besides 744 Broad Street, 33 Washington Street, the half-vacant, 380,000-square-foot former headquarters of Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey is also for sale. The health-care provider now occupies nearly 800,000 square feet of space at 3 Penn Plaza East here, as well as a small amount of space at 33 Washington.
"If there was a demand you would see people jumping at the building," said Richard Travaglini. He is executive vice president at Tri-Enterprise, a division of TMC Services, a real estate services firm in Livingston that is working with Blue Cross/ Blue Shield. The private sector still perceives risks in investing in Newark, he said.
Projections are that the supply of secondary space will grow in response to corporate downsizings and mergers. For instance, Mutual Benefit Life, which was seized by state regulators after it collapsed in 1991 and is under a rehabilitation plan, will announce more cutbacks in February, said Mary Ann Green, a company spokeswoman. The goal is to reduce the company's 879-member staff by 30 percent. At that time "it may make sense" to lease some of the space at the company's 400,000-square-foot headquarters at 520 Broad Street, she said.
Meanwhile, the First Union Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C. -- which last year acquired First Fidelity in Newark, the state's largest bank -- is to move its regional headquarters to Summit. As now planned, the move would pull out 350 administrative jobs from of the city, but 1,100 other employees would remain, said Paul Levine, a bank spokesman. He added that fewer people would mean the need for less space.
Brokers expect that to mean that some 150,000 of the 500,000 square feet of space that the bank now occupies would be returned to the market. But many say the bank's future moves remain a big question mark.
C ORPORATIONS want offices of the 21st century and if they can't get that in Newark they will go elsewhere," said Dean Hughes. There is also competition from suburban sites that are approved and easier to develop, he said, noting that some of the older buildings here might be put to alternative uses, such as housing.
Mr. Faiella of the city's Economic Development Corporation said that "residential re-use has to be looked at." But older buildings, given the proper capital investment, can also compete for their share of office tenants, he said.
The building at 744 Broad Street is owned by Newark Building Associates, whose general partner is Peter L. Malkin. Mr. Malkin, chairman of the Wien Malkin & Bettex law firm in Manhattan, has extensive holdings that include investments in the Lincoln, Graybar and Empire State Buildings.
Thomas N. Keltner Jr., a partner in the law firm, which represents the owners, said that since the owners continued to receive a fixed rent from the building they were "not legally entitled to interfere with its operation or cancel the lease of the operators," Investment Properties Associates of Manhattan. The general partners of that company are Harry B. Helmsley and Irving Schneider.
Mr. Keltner said the owners would either sell 744 Broad Street for "somewhere between $8 million and $10 million" or lease it to another operator. The Investment Properties lease expired last June.
