HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
For Third Quarter of '96, a Housing-Closing Record

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER real estate offices reported a record 2,572 closings during the third quarter of this year, a 17 percent increase over the previous high of 2,205 set in the third quarter of 1994.
That means that 1996 could surpass 1994 as the busiest sales year in the county's history, according to P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, which reported the findings. But prices remained flat or declined. 
 "So far, the fourth quarter looks like an average quarter," Mr. Mercurio said. "But in conjunction with the other quarters, the year is in contention to be a record-breaking year."
The third quarter has traditionally been the charm for home sales in Westchester. "It's a lagging indicator," Mr. Mercurio explained. "It represents sales that took place in the late spring and early summer. They usually show up in the fourth quarter because it takes a couple of months to get to the closing."
Mr. Mercurio attributed the sales spurt to increased confidence in the local economy. "I think people have the sense that the downsizing hemorrhaging has died down somewhat," he said. "Now they're hearing that companies are coming into the county. Also income levels are higher and retail sales are up. There's a growing sense of job security."
Several years ago, it was not unusual for a sales transaction to be scrapped at the 11th hour because "someone would come in and say her husband had just lost his job," said Savo Fries, president of the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. "That hasn't happened in a long time."
Brokers all over the county reported increased sales activity, particularly in the summer months. "We were very, very busy all summer until the end of August," said Carol Mele, a sales agent with Prudential Ragette, of Eastchester.
"Then things dropped off for about a month and a half," she added. "I think the election affected people. They wanted to know what was going to happen."
More than 70 percent of all sales were for single-family homes. The balance was for condominiums, co-ops and multifamily dwellings.
In the third quarter, a total of 1,835 single-family homes were sold, a 12 percent increase over the 1,637 in the same period in 1994.
"We have certain categories of houses that just fly out the door," said Ms. Fries, who is also manager of Coldwell Banker's Somers office. "Anything in new construction under $500,000 is extremely popular, and resales in the price range of the mid- to high-$200,000's are always hot."
Jamie and Jim Hasl, who were relocating from Maine, looked for about five months in Westchester and Connecticut before finding a four-bedroom colonial in a new subdivision in Somers. "We weren't looking specifically for new construction," Ms. Hasl said. "But we wanted something relatively new. We had done old before where you're remodeling the bathrooms and kitchen. We didn't want to do that again."
Incremental increases in interest rates, which took place between March and June, also helped pull people into real estate offices, according to Ms. Fries. "When the rates go up a little, it can be good for us," she said. "It's like a tease."
THE condominium market hit its highest mark in sales activity ever with a total of 361 sales in the third quarter. That exceeded by 29 percent the previous record of 280 set during the third quarter of 1994.
"Condominiums track what happens in single-family homes," Mr. Mercurio said. "They appeal to nearly the same broad range of people. You can get any price category from inexpensive to luxury."
Jennie Giannotta and her husband, Pat, decided it was time to make the move to a condominium after shoveling snow during the harsh 1995-6 winter. They had owned a house in the Bronx.
"Our children were no longer at home," Ms. Giannotta said. "There was no one else around to do all the shoveling. I said, 'Enough. I want to live someplace where I don't have to worry about this.' " In August, the couple moved into a two-bedroom condominium in Yonkers, near the Village of Bronxville.
COLDWELL BANKER'S Somers office handles most of the resales at Heritage Hills, in Somers, the county's largest condominium complex. It has more than 2,000 units so far, and is scheduled to go as high as 3,000. "I think that will be modified because of wetland and steep-slope restrictions," said Marti Lowenfeld, an associate broker with the office.
"In the last three months," Ms. Lowenfeld said, "there has been more activity in sales there than in the previous five years. I had four closings at Heritage Hills in one week."
Similarly, the sale of co-ops in the third quarter reached a level not seen since the late 1980's before the 1990 recession, according to the Board of Realtors. There were a total of 258 sales, a 25 percent increase over the 205 in the third quarter of 1994.
"I sold quite a few co-ops," said Ms. Mele. "But most of them were on the low end. We got a lot of singles, young marrieds and older people who were looking to scale down. And a lot of them were looking for bargains."
In all this frenetic sales activity, sale prices in all categories of housing have either remained flat or gone down in the third quarter.
The median price of a detached house, for example, remained fairly steady at $297,000, compared to $295,000 in the third quarter last year and $288,000 in 1994.
The median price of condominiums was $161,000, compared to $160,000 last year and $168,000 in 1994. And the median price of co-ops fell to $60,000 from $65,000 last year and $74,000 in 1994.
"People are beginning to realize that all this good sales activity doesn't mean an escalation in prices," said Ms. Fries. "I think buyers have finally succeeded in educating sellers. If you don't price your house competitively, even in a good market, it will not sell."
All this frustrates Charles Zambrano, president of the Prudential Notas agency, in Somers. "This really creates problems for me," he said. "People read about the great housing market in Westchester and say, 'If you're such hot shots why should I have to be conservative in my price?' I can't answer that question."
One reason may be that the record number of sales have not made much of a dent in the housing available, according to the Board of Realtors. Inventory of single-family homes at the end of the third quarter was 5,569, about 7 percent below last year's level during the same period.
According to the board's report, "vigorous sales activity sometimes has the effect of stimulating more properties to be listed, as owners observe encouraging results by others who have sold properties in the neighborhood."
End-of-quarter condominium inventory was 1,031, 6 percent less than last year. And the co-op inventory of 1,882 actually increased 3 percent from last year's level in spite of the high number of sales.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 18; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1420 words

HEADLINE: 20 YEARS: ROAD AND RAIL;
Stores and Cars: A Dubious Model of Change and Growth

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
Imagine that it is 1976, the year of the Bicentennial, the year the Oldsmobile Cutlass was America's best-selling car. Say you are driving up Route 17, approaching the Route 4 interchange. There are two lanes of traffic in either direction, separated by a grass median. There are mom-and-pop stores galore. Gas station after gas station. Woods in the distance.
Now imagine that you get stuck at the interchange for -- and let's exaggerate just a bit here -- say, 20 years. You would see, through the use of time-lapse photography, the woods disappearing; empty lots giving birth to stores; mom-and-pop operations being replaced by big-box retailers like Barnes & Noble, Comp USA and Home Depot. And you would see more cars, which, like yours, are still stuck in traffic. 
 "We're pretty much fully developed now," said Cliff Gennarelli, the Mayor of Paramus, taking a reporter on a tour and -- what else? -- getting stuck at the Route 4 and 17 interchange. "The shame of it is that most people think Paramus is an old Indian word for shopping center, when we know that it's an old Indian word for traffic."
Mr. Gennarelli's quip makes the point: In any language, Paramus's image is wedded to shopping. But even more, it is home to the worst chronic traffic jams in the state.
In many ways, what has happened on Route 17 in the past 20 years is a snapshot of the region, the country, really: a drive-through laboratory for the way people plan, build, shop and work. From the grass medians of the 1970's to the dubious distinction of being part of the most dangerous interchange in the state, Route 17 has been there, done that.
"It's a paradigm of the rest of the country's experience, but it is probably as intense a paradigm as you could find anywhere," said Chester P. Mattson, Bergen County's director of planning and economic development. "I always think of it as the distillation of the most powerful period of growth in the country's history, and also as a picture of the future, because Route 4 and 17 offer a continuously changing landscape."
The road, originally called Route 2, was built between 1927 and 1934, stretching 27.5 miles between Kearny and Mahwah and bisecting some towns, including Paramus. In the beginning, drivers would pass good hunting spots for pheasant, rabbit and fox and good farmland for celery, tomatoes and corn, said Fritz Behnke, whose family has owned Behnke's Paramus Building Company on Route 17 for many years.
In the 1950's and 60's, residential areas popped up and retailing began to flourish. At the Route 4 interchange, for instance, the Garden State Plaza opened in 1958, occupying land that was vacant, except for a popular drive-in movie theater. In Paramus, planning was basically laissez-faire, as borough officials granted businesses freedom to follow market conditions as long as they did not encroach on residential areas.
Drive up and down Route 17 a few times with old hands like Mr. Behnke and Mr. Gennarelli, and you can begin to sense the scope of that change over the last two decades.
At the Route 4 and 17 interchange, the southeast corner used to contain a strip of small stores like JR Tobacco (they also had great candy, aficionados say), Alba Contractors, a billiards hall and a place that made barstools. Less than a decade ago, the stores were torn down and eventually replaced by a Bradlees, Comp USA and Petsmart.
At the southwest corner, the Garden State Plaza expanded by 750,000 square feet last year, making it the state's biggest mall. On the northeast corner sits Paramus Plaza IV, a 10-year-old office building that replaced several homes. Alexander's department store, on the northwest corner, has been abandoned for almost a decade.
Other stretches of Route 17 have also changed dramatically. Nothing used to be on the site of what is now Levitz. Same with Kids "R" Us. Staples used to be a small restaurant. Filene's Basement expanded about 10 years ago. Soon, Bergen Bluestone will be replaced by an Office Depot. Only a handful of longtime establishments remain.
Since the 1960's, Paramus's population has barely risen beyond 26,000, and its tax rate -- $1.99 per $100 of assessed value -- is among the lowest in the county.
But office and retail space has expanded enormously.
In 1970, Paramus -- whose main business corridors are Routes 17 and 4 -- had 288,000 square feet of office space; by 1996, it was 3.47 million. In 1977, Paramus generated $716.1 million worth of retail business; in 1992 (the last year for which figures are available), it was $1.926 billion, according to the Bergen County Planning Department.
But the number of retail establishments in Paramus increased much more slowly, from 553 in 1977 to 723 in 1992, suggesting that bigger stores were doing more business. That real estate prices have risen from $3 or $4 a square foot 20 years ago to $30 today has made it even tougher for smaller stores, said Peter Wells, director of the Paramus Building Department.
All this has meant more traffic. In 1981, an estimated 88,000 vehicles a day passed through the Route 4 interchange; in 1992, that number was 126,000. And though the Paramus Police Department says the number of reported accidents hasn't changed much in 20 years, the interchange is still the worst in the state. There were 581 accidents recorded there from 1992 to 1994, 534 of which were fender-benders involving cars going in the same direction. This means that many attempted merges failed, said John Dourgarian, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation.
Perhaps the reason those numbers aren't higher is that Route 17 has undergone substantial improvements as well, Mr Dourgarian said. In the last 15 years, the state has spent $60 million doing, among other things, the following:
* Removing the 10-to 12-foot-wide grass barriers and replacing them with concrete barriers, thereby preventing those dangerous, wait-in-the-middle-of-the-road U-turns.
* Adding a third lane north of Paramus.
* Removing the Lake Street traffic signal in Ramsey and replacing it with an overpass.
* Adding about four miles of sound walls in Ridgewood, Saddle River, Ho-Ho-Kus and Allendale.
More change is planned, including, most significantly, the Department of Transportation's $115 million project to redo the Route 4 and 17 interchange, which would demolish Alexander's and some smaller stores on the northwest corner to accommodate flyover ramps. It could begin in late 1998, and finish four years later.
To manage these changes, the borough now regulates the size of signs and prefers that new or renovated stores be further set back from Route 17, with some shrubbery as an aesthetic buffer. But no one doubts that Route 17 and Route 4 will be different 20 years from now.
 
First, Dinosaurs; Later, Bradlees
 The southeast corner of the Route 4 and 17 interchange is typical of the change that has taken place at sites along Route 17 in Paramus. Here is a look at what is and what was:
 
1996 Bradlees, Comp USA, Petsmart, DSW Shoe Warehouse
 
1980's Small office building for Stern's department store's credit operations, and a strip of small stores.
 
1960's AND 70's Fewer mom-and-pop stores, including a fortune teller, a furniture store, a law office, an electronics store. An empty lot where Bradlees now sits. And a heavily wooded area between Route 17 and Farview Avenue to the east.
 
1940's and 50's Even fewer mom-and-pop stores, and a gas station where Bradlees now sits.
 
1930's Completion of the interchange in a formerly wooded area.
 
EARLY 1900's Wooded, owned by people with houses on Farview Avenue.
 
1878 Map shows area was basically empty, except for a house owned by August Gruloth in what was called New Barbardoes Township.
 
1778 Map shows area was likely in the "deep swamp," between Zabriskie's Mill, near present-day Paramus Road, and Sluckup, near present-day Farview Avenue. (The name Sluckup apparently refers to some farmland owned by a Dutch settler whose cow "sluck up," or ate, the shirt he had left on a bush.)
 
1664 Part of a sale of land from Indians to Dutch settlers. Peremes is derived from a Lenni Lenape tribe whose name means "land where wild turkey abounds."
 
WAY BACK 20,000 years ago: standard cycle of vegetation renewal, after the final glaciation of the Ice Age.
 
WAY, WAY BACK 180 million to 230 million years ago: Flat, swampy lands in the Newark Basin, fit for dinosaurs. DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: 20 YEARS: PEOPLE

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
They did things that mattered. Some had their hands on the levers of power, and some were found to have had their hands in the till.
Some of them were big people doing big things, and others were ordinary people suddenly doing extraordinary things. Some were people caught up and swept along by events. 
 In whatever ways, the people below touched their times. There are others who could have been named, but the ones below earned their niches, for good and bad. They are some of the reasons New Jerseyans can look back a year or a decade or 20 years and say, "Sure, I remember."
 
1976
 
RICHARD J. HUGHES
Education and Taxation
There were lingering doubts that Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes, a former two-term Governor used to negotiation and compromise, was decisive enough to be the state's top judge.
The doubts were dashed in the summer of 1976, when the New Jersey Supreme Court concluded that the State Legislature had failed to provide enough money to meet standards of the Public School Education Act passed the year before. That act was passed to comply with a court ruling that heavy reliance on local property taxes discriminated against poorer school districts.
Under Chief Justice Hughes, the court ordered the schools closed and issued an injunction against spending of state and local money for education until the lawmakers did something.
They got the message. The Legislature passed a state income tax, an issue it had fought over for a decade. Gov. Brendan T. Byrne signed it, and the schools reopened.
The only man to be both Governor and Chief Justice in New Jersey, Richard Hughes retired from the bench in 1979 and was a lawyer in private practive until his death on Dec. 7, 1992, at 83.
 
1977
 
BRENDAN T. BYRNE
The Comeback Kid
Brendan T. Byrne defined the year, and the year defined him.
In the spring, the incumbent Governor seemed to be fumbling and vulnerable. He had spent his political capital backing a state income tax that he said was necessary for schools and other things. But it did not go down well, and his opponents said it amounted to a broken campaign promise.
Not yet a lame duck but certainly a wounded one: that was the perception of the Governor in the spring, when a reputable poll put his approval rating at 17 percent and nine members of his own party challenged him in the Democratic Primary. The Governor won renomination, only to find himself 10 points behind his Republican opponent, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, who hammered him again and again over the tax issue.
What else do you have to hit me with? That was the question Mr. Byrne hurled back at his challenger.
The voters heard. They re-elected Governor Byrne comfortably. After his second term, which ended in 1981, Mr. Byrne became a lawyer in private practice.
 
1978
 
BILL BRADLEY
He Shoots, He Scores
Bill Bradley turned 35 in the summer of 1978, old for a professional athlete, which he had stopped being just a year before, and young for a United States Senator, which he very much wanted to be.
He had been an all-America basketball player at Princeton (and a history major and Rhodes Scholar) and had played a decade for the Knicks, helping them win two championships. He also found time to earn a master's degree from Oxford University in politics, philosophy and economics.
The venerable Clifford P. Case, a moderate Republican, was running for re-election in 1978. Looking ahead to the fall, Mr. Case committed a sin that is unpardonable, in sports or politics. He was overconfident. And so he lost in the primary to a little-known conservative, Jeffrey Bell.
Mr. Bradley won easily in November, becoming the youngest member of the Senate. For the next 18 years, he would be known as a moderate Democrat, one of the better minds in the Senate, an expert in (what else?) history, politics, philosophy and economics. Not to mention foreign policy, taxes -- and civility.
When he retires from the Senate in a few weeks, Bill Bradley will be 53.
 
1979
 
THE GAS STATION ATTENDANT
Running on Empty
When a motorist pulls into a gas station and says, "Fill 'er up," he doesn't want the guy at the pump to laugh.
But for several months in the spring and summer of 1979, people in New Jersey and across America couldn't be sure where their next gallon was coming from. There were sales on odd-even days, there were limits on how much could be bought, and there were lines way down the street.
It was all a disturbing reminder of the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, and of the vulnerability of a nation that usually took oil for granted.
With the pro-American Shah's ouster from Iran and the ascendancy of an anti-American fundamentalist government, oil from Iran stopped coming to America. Nervous oil companies limited their shipments to suppliers, who in turn limited what went to the gas stations.
There were dark suspicions that the oil companies were not altogether unhappy about the whole thing, that they found an excuse to charge a lot more. The companies denied any conspiracy, and some independent analysts said the oil companies had only followed Energy Department advice when they stockpiled supplies.
Eventually, the crisis eased, and there was enough gasoline (although at higher prices) to go around.
Until the next time.
 
1980
 
HARRISON A. WILLIAMS Jr.
Where Is Thy Sting?
As the year began, Harrison A. Williams Jr. was, unofficially, New Jersey's Senator for Life. A Democrat, he had been in the Senate for more than two decades and was a friend to the Kennedy family.
Then his life disintegrated under circumstances that sounded like the plot line of a bad novel. Word leaked out in February that the Senator and various other officials had been implicated in an undercover operation featuring Federal agents posing as Arab sheiks and businessmen on the lookout for politicians who could be bought.
Senator Williams was said to have agreed to use his considerable political influence to help a longtime friend obtain government contracts for a titanium mine in return for a piece of the action.
The bizarre scandal was known as Abscam. Before it was over, Senator Williams, 6 Congressmen and 13 other people had been convicted of various crimes of greed. Harrison Williams was the fourth Senator in American history to be convicted of crimes while in office. He lost his seat and was sentenced to three years in prison. When he got out, he became a legislative analyst for the New Jersey Building and Construction Trades Council. He will be 77 on Dec. 10.
 
1981
 
THOMAS H. KEAN
Squeaker to Laugher
"The people have elected Tom Kean," Representative Jim Florio, a Democrat from Runnemede, said in conceding the race for Governor to his Republican rival.
What was unusual about the concession was its timing: 27 days after the election. Mr. Kean, a 46-year-old Republican from Livingston and a former Speaker of the State Assembly, won by fewer than 1,800 votes out of 2.3 million cast.
Mr. Kean was a political and social blueblood (there were Roosevelts in his ancestry), but he was quick to smile, hard to dislike.
But would he be just a one-termer? After all, the election was the closest in state history, and Mr. Florio's concession came after a recount. And the Democrats still controlled the Legislature.
Four years later, riding a wave of prosperity, he crushed his Democratic opponent, Peter Shapiro, by a margin of more than 2 to 1 and helped Republicans take over the Assembly. After leaving office in 1989, he became president of Drew University.
 
1982
 
MARSHA STERN
Come In, Secaucus
Since the black-and-white days of Kukla, Fran and Ollie, New Jersey had not had its own VHF commercial television station. By the early 1980's, it was one of two states so cursed. The other was Delaware, with less than one-tenth the Garden State's population.
If New Jersey had its own station, the theory went, the state would no longer be seen as a tank-lined strip of concrete between Big Apple and Brotherly Love.
The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting had been trying since its inception in 1971 to get a VHF license for the state. Spurred by the coalition's executive director, Marsha Stern, a communications teacher at Rutgers, the Federal Communications Commission pressured New York and Philadelphia stations not to ignore New Jersey, and Senator Bradley won passage of a bill granting an automatic five-year license renewal to any station that switched its license to New Jersey or Delaware.
RKO General, which ran WOR-TV Channel 9, was in trouble because its parent company had been accused of illegal political contributions. Facing F.C.C. review, it agreed in 1992 to move from New York to Secaucus.
 
1983
 
ROBERT. N. WILENTZ
Building Open Doors
Oddly enough, the New Jersey Supreme Court's most important ruling of the year did not exactly break new ground. Rather, it shored up old ground.
Eight years earlier, the court headed by Chief Justice Hughes had issued its Mount Laurel ruling, decreeing that suburbs could not use zoning to close their doors to the poor.
By 1983, Robert N. Wilentz had been Chief Justice for four years, and he was convinced that some suburbs were finding creative ways to evade the ruling.
So under his guidance, the court held unanimously that suburbs that did not have their "fair share" of the poor had to allow for construction of low-cost housing, seek government subsidies for it and offer tax breaks for builders.
Prodded by the ruling, the Legislature adopted a compromise plan that did not please everyone. But in one sense, it was fitting. Some who followed Justice Wilentz's his career said he had been a good Chief Justice partly because he understood the relationship between the law and politics, how the engines of the latter had to drive the theories of the former.
Justice Wilentz died last July 23, a few weeks after announcing that inoperable cancer had forced his retirement seven months before he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70.
 
1984
 
THE YUPPIE
I <heart> MY BMW
In a sense, they were the very essence of New Jersey. Their parents conceived them just after World War II, and these offspring became a great force. Baby boomers, they were called -- one in three New Jerseyans.
When they grew up, they wanted to live in houses, or town houses, or condominiums. They wanted to live near a Great City but not in it. They wanted to live in the suburbs. Heck, they were the suburbs, as their parents had been.
They were Yuppies. (Wasn't that word originally a quasi-acronym for young upwardly mobile professionals?) They were still young in 1984, or at least they had not crossed the Rubicon of 40.
Many of them felt upwardly mobile because they were. The recession of the early 80's was a distant memory, and the stock market nose dive and real estate slowdown of the late 80's was still over a far horizon.
Shopping malls, lawns, porch decks, pools, barbecues. These were the trappings of Yuppiedom. The Yuppies drove the marketplace and drove to the marketplace. They loved cars. Come to think of it, didn't we see these people at the gas station lines back in 1979?
 
1985
 
KAREN ANN QUINLAN
Death 'With Dignity'
She never knew. Her fate was debated for years by lawyers and doctors, clergymen and parents, but she never knew.
Karen Ann Quinlan was 21 on April 14, 1975, the day she swallowed a combination of Valium and alcohol that put her in a coma from which many doctors said she had no hope of emerging.
Or was it a coma, exactly? And was there really no hope? At least one doctor said she showed some minimal brain activity and occasional voluntary muscle movement.
Karen's adoptive parents, Joseph and Julia Quinlan of Roxbury Township in Morris County, petitioned a court for permission to remove her from life support so she could die "with grace and dignity." The state opposed the move, saying removal would be tantamount to homicide. The attending physician said he opposed removal. The hospital in Denville asked for immunity from prosecution.
The law was not ready to deal with medical advances that could prolong breathing and heartbeat long after consciousness had ceased.
On March 31, 1976, the New Jersey Supreme Court issued its landmark 7-0 ruling: The constitutional right to privacy encompassed a person's decision to forgo life-sustaining medical treatment in certain circumstances. The court said Karen's father could decide for her.
After she was disconnected from a respirator, she confounded the experts. She remained unconscious, she withered to 65 pounds, but she breathed on her own. She breathed until June 11, 1985, when she died at a nursing home in Morris Plains.
Her case had begun the right-to-die movement. But she never knew.
 
1986
 
PHIL SIMMS
Greatness, at Long Last
For much of his eight years with the Giants, a lot of fans said he wasn't good enough to take the team all the way. He had been bedeviled by injuries, including a season-ender when he smashed his hand on an opponent's helmet in an early game.
But Phil Simms was nothing if not tough. He was 30 years old in 1986, and he had not been making the commute all those years from his home in Bergen County to Giants Stadium for nothing.
Everything clicked for Simms and the Giants in 1986. He completed 259 of 468 passes in the regular season for nearly 3,500 yards and 21 touchdowns. The Giants won 14 games, losing only two, and crushed the San Francisco 49ers and the Washington Redskins in the playoffs.
Oh, yes. In the Super Bowl, the Giants routed the Denver Broncos, 39-20. Simms completed 22 of 25 passes for 268 yards and was named the game's most valuable player.
Said Coach Bill Parcells, "This dispelled for the last time any myth about Phil Simms." No one disagreed.
But just before the 1994 season, the Giants decided they couldn't afford to pay $2.325 million to an aging signal-caller and put him on waivers, ending his career. Since then, he has been a color commentator for ESPN and has been a spokesman for Amerihealth, a health maintenance organization.
 
1987
 
BABY M
Mother, Meet Mom
For many months in 1987, she was known as Baby M, and she was anything but an unwanted child.
The year before, Mary Beth Whitehead, a housewife married to a sanitation worker, had accepted $10,000 from William and Elizabeth Stern of Tenafly to bear them a child. The Sterns, unable to have one, hired Ms. Whitehead, who was artificially impregnated with Mr. Stern's semen.
Ms. Whitehead, who already had children, decided after giving birth that she wanted to keep the little girl after all. The Sterns sued.
The monthlong trial caused a sensation. The case wasn't just a breach-of-contract issue, or one of custody, it brought up issues of social class. The Sterns were a professional couple (he was a biochemist and she a pediatrician) who lived an existence light-years from that of Baby M's natural mother.
In March 1987, a judge upheld the validity of the $10,000 surrogacy contract, ruled that Mrs. Stern could adopt the baby, whom the Sterns called Melissa, and stripped Ms. Whitehead of any parental rights.
But the next year, while letting the Sterns keep Melissa, the New Jersey Supreme Court declared that Ms. Whitehead was not only the natural mother "but also the legal mother, and is not to be penalized one iota because of the surrogate contract," which the court held to be illegal in any event.
The Supreme Court court ruling was the first by any state high court arising from a surrogate mother's fight to keep a child. Ms. Whitehead was granted visiting rights, which were broadened after a hearing in a lower court.
The Sterns were termed "extraordinarily good parents" by one judge. But Ms. Whitehead, whose marriage collapsed after the ordeal, had won a point, and a point of law: She was the mother.
 
1988
 
JOE CLARK
Miscreants' Anathema
By 1988, Joe Clark had been principal of Eastside High School in Paterson for six years. He had made a lot of admirers as a tough disciplinarian, and he had cultivated more than a few enemies. It was easy to see why he had plenty of each.
"Leeches, miscreants and hoodlums" he labeled one batch of students as he tossed them out of school.
Mr. Clark had setbacks (he had to readmit the leeches, miscreants and hoodlums, because only the school board has authority to expel), but many students and parents liked his bullhorn-and-baseball-bat corridor discipline. Eastside High, with almost 3,000 students, most of them poor, was no longer a "caldron of terror and violence," as one report termed it.
Education Secretary William J. Bennett praised Mr. Clark as an example of what strong leadership could do, and early in 1988 he was offered a job in the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Clark didn't take it. He stayed at Eastside through 1988, when a movie about his exploits was filmed. The next year, he took a job with Essex County. Now he heads the Essex County Youth House, supervising youths charged with serious crimes.
No one has suggested he isn't tough enough for the job.
 
1989
 
JIM FLORIO
Hat in the Ring
Whether one liked him or not, no one could deny that Jim Florio was a fighter. His razor-thin loss to Thomas H. Kean in 1981 must have been at least as painful as the punches from his youthful boxing days that left a dent in his face.
Mr. Florio bided his time, working hard in Congress on his pet issues: toxic-waste disposal, transportation and the environment.
Not that hard work was new for him. A high school dropout who joined the Navy, he later earned his equivalency diploma, went to college, then to law school while working at night as a janitor to support his family.
Tough, driven, not socially easy like Tom Kean -- that was Jim Florio, 52 years old in 1989. "My philosophy has always been, I have one pair of shoes because I have one pair of feet," he once said.
He had had eight years to study his 1981 defeat. In 1989, on his third try for the Governor's mansion, he was elected over Representative Jim Courter. And he won the way he did few other things: comfortably.
Since his narrow defeat to Christine Todd Whitman in 1993, he has been a lawyer in private practice. He is contemplating yet another run for Governor.
 
1990
 
JOHN BUDZASH
Days of Rage
Once in a great while there comes a towering figure who changes the direction of government, perhaps of history. Oliver Cromwell, Abraham Lincoln, John Budzash . . .
Who?
John Budzash was a 39-year-old postal worker in Howell Township. Like a lot of New Jerseyans he detested the $2.8 billion in new taxes that Governor Florio had pushed through the State Legislature. He decided to form a grass-roots organization, Hands Across New Jersey.
On a radio call-in show, he vented his rage and proposed a demonstration.
And so, on July 1, the day New Jerseyans began paying new taxes on telephone calls, toilet paper and a whole lot more, about 2,000 cars and more than 6,000 people clogged the roads leading to the state capital for an anti-tax rally. The protesters had long since rejected Mr. Florio's explanation: that he was trying to clean up a financial mess left by Tom Kean, and that the taxes were needed for education.
Mr. Budzash's organization continued to fan the anti-tax flames. That fall, Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat, almost lost his seat because of spillover resentment. His opponent was Christine Todd Whitman.
 
1991
 
GERALD McCANN
Keep the Change
Gerald McCann was never accused of being a dishonest Mayor of Jersey City. It was what he did when he wasn't Mayor that got him into trouble.
Between the end of his first term, in 1985, and his re-election in 1989 Mr. McCann was a development consultant. A savings and loan institution in Boca Raton, Fla., became his partner in a development firm, and Mr. McCann promoted a plan to build a marina at Liberty State Park.
The bank put up $300,000 in February 1986, six months before the marina proposal was due. Mr. McCann missed the deadline and never did submit a proposal, so the bank lost most of its investment. Mr. McCann was guilty of bad business judgment, his lawyer said. Federal prosecutors said he was guilty of fraud and income-tax evasion for diverting the bank's money to his own consulting company and spending it on a Mercedes, furs, jewelry and other luxuries.
A jury preferred the prosecutors' version. On Dec. 17, 1991, Mr. McCann was convicted of 15 counts of fraud and tax evasion. He was sentenced to more than two years in prison. As a convicted felon he was removed from office. Now back in Jersey City, Mr. McCann is said to be considering another campaign for Mayor.
 
1992
 
GARY SPATH
Teaneck Shattered
The lives of Gary Spath and Phillip Pannell intersected one April night two years earlier. Mr. Spath was a 29-year-old Teaneck police officer when he and a partner responded to a call that a black youth had been seen with a gun near a school.
Officer Spath's partner brushed his hands across the youth's jackett, said he thought he had a gun. The youth ran, the officers followed. They said he turned toward them twice with his hand in his jacket pocket.
Office Spath fired twice. The first bullet missed. The second struck Phillip in the back. He fell to the ground, dead at 16. The next night, a candlelight vigil for the dead youth erupted into violence as marchers attacked the Teaneck police station and broke windows.
A grand jury declined to indict Mr. Spath, but state Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo ordered a second investigation, citing errors in the medical testimony heard by the first grand jury. The second jury indicted Mr. Spath on manslaughter charges.
In a five-and-a-half week trial early in 1992, the state tried to prove that Phillip had his hands in the air and was trying to surrender when he was shot. The jury rejected that theory and acquitted Mr. Spath.
Months later, the Pannell family accepted a $195,000 settlement in a suit against Teaneck. Mr. Spath left the police force, went into construction work, and later worked for a short-lived law enforcement magazine in South Jersey.
 
1993
 
TONI MORRISON
Poetic, and Prized
Her first novel, "The Bluest Eye," was published in 1970. Set in her Ohio hometown, it described a black girl's painful coming of age in a white-dominated society. In five subsequent novels, she established herself as one of the finest novelists in America. No, one of the finest in the world. In 1993, she won the Nobel Prize in Literature for a body of work "characterized by visionary force and poetic import."
Toni Morrison was the eighth woman and the first black woman to win the prize. Interviewed at Princeton University, where she had taught creative writing since 1989, she called the honor "a palpable tremor of delight" and said she was totally surprised.
Perhaps she shouldn't have been. Five years earlier, her novel "Beloved" won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. In 1996, she would win the National Book Foundation Medal for her contribution to American letters.
 
1994
 
EMILY MANN
Tony Express
It was as though Broadway were extended south and west, all the way to Princeton and the McCarter Theater.
There are a few prizes and awards whose prestige is such that their names are instantly recognizable: Nobel, Pulitzer, Oscar, Tony. In 1994, the McCarter received a Tony Award for outstanding regional theater. Many thought the McCarter's Tony should have been dubbed the Mann award, after Emily Mann, the McCarter's artistic director since the 1990-91 season. [Page 26.]
An accomplished director and playwright and a specialist in documentary theater before she came to the McCarter, Ms. Mann wanted to shake things up.
Safe, steady, established, comfortable in the bosom of a university town. That was how many theater lovers had come to think of the McCarter before the curtain went up on Ms. Mann's tenure.
Ms. Mann loves energy and electricity, hates boredom and barriers. Her productions were not just on topically hot subjects like Winnie Mandela, anti-Semitism and white supremacy. She also put on plays by Shakespeare, Chekov and Tennessee Williams.
 
1995
 
CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN
Taxes Down, Profile Up
It was not a bad Fourth of July for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. She marched in a parade in the little Middlesex Borough of Milltown, and then she signed into law the second half of her promised 30 percent income tax reduction.
"This will build a stronger New Jersey," she declared, echoing not only the Republican Party mantra but the sentiments that led to her 1993 upset of Jim Florio, whose $2.8 billion tax package had been widely detested.
Some critics said the income tax cuts would merely drive up local taxes, because the money for governing had to come from somewhere. And they said it was a bit misleading for her to boast in mid-1995 that she was ahead of schedule in meeting her promise of a 30 percent tax cut in three years, since the reduction she signed in July would not take effect until Jan. 1, 1996.
But this was not debatable: She had seized the tax issue. She had come close to unseating Senator Bill Bradley with it in 1990. In the 1993 campaign, she won the Governor's office with it and attained a national profile.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 17, 1996

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1370 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Deductions Coming For Long-Term Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
LOOKING to a future where far more people will require long-term care, the Government is beginning to encourage Americans to pay for it themselves. The carrot being offered is a tax deduction for individuals and employers on the purchase of long-term-care insurance. The stick is criminal penalties for some people who, instead of financing their own long-term care, try to become eligible for Government-paid care by shifting assets to family members or trusts.
Officials and health care economists said the new incentives, which take effect on Jan. 1, herald sweeping changes in public policy. The Federal Government and states face daunting growth in entitlement programs like Medicaid that will soon be overrun by graying baby boomers and their parents. 
 "With this legislation, Congress is saying there are not going to be any new Government programs for long-term care," said Guenther Ruch, enforcement chief of the Wisconsin Insurance Commission.
Glenn Pomeroy, the Insurance Commissioner of North Dakota, added, "Congress is directly encouraging the private marketplace to play a greater role."
The insurance industry, which had lobbied for the tax incentives for years, is delighted with the legislation, which was tucked into the Kassebaum-Kennedy health-insurance law. The industry says millions of middle-class people will be able to receive long-term care without additional help from the Government, and big insurance companies say they are already getting a surge of requests for information about long-term care from employers and labor unions.
Under the new rules, employers will be able to deduct from their taxes the cost of providing long-term-care coverage for employees, just as they already do if they provide medical benefits. And individuals buying policies on their own will be able to deduct part of the premiums from Federal taxes if the total costs of medical and long-term care exceed 7.5 percent of income. People 51 to 60 years old can deduct $750 of their premiums from their taxes; those over 60 up to $2,000, and those over 70 up to $2,500.
 "The really well-off can self-insure," said Doug Bates of Washington, a lawyer for the American Council of Life Insurance, a trade group. "This really helps those who can't."
But the carrot may not be sweet enough and the stick may not be big enough to persuade people to buy the insurance. Only about five million Americans, or 6 percent of all taxpayers, took the medical deduction in 1994, the latest year for which data are available. And the deduction often does not amount to much. A person with an adjusted gross income of $30,000 who bought a long-term-care policy for $1,400, the typical price for an individual in his mid-60's, would need another $950 of medical expenses to get even a $100 deduction.
Younger workers, already struggling to save for their retirement and their children's education, may also balk at paying premiums, especially for insurance they may never need.
And few advocates for the elderly believe that the Government will really start throwing senior citizens in jail for transferring their assets in order to qualify for Medicaid.
Under the law, people would qualify for reimbursement from the insurance policies if a doctor or other licensed health care provider certified that they could no longer handle two daily activities like bathing, eating, using the toilet, dressing or moving from a bed to a chair. But that and other provisions in the law set more stringent guidelines than those of several states, Mr. Pomeroy, the North Dakota commissioner, said. In Kansas, for example, just a general diagnosis by a doctor that long-term care is necessary is enough to require the insurer to make payments to the policyholder.
Gail Shearer, a policy analyst with Consumers Union, an advocacy group, urged purchasers of the insurance to look closely at the policies, comparing the benefits and costs. "It's caveat emptor," she said.
 Still, the insurance industry has been preparing for an expected surge in sales. About 400,000 individual long-term-care policies were sold last year, and GE Capital Assurance, one of the largest sellers, projects a 10 to 15 percent increase in industrywide sales next year. So last year, it bought Amex Life Assurance, the long-term-care unit of American Express.
Conseco Inc. recently bought several insurers, including the American Travellers Corporation, which agreed last month to market long-term care policies jointly with the American International Group. And in September, Metropolitan Life said that in 1998 it would take over the long-term-care business sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons.
Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Connecticut Democrat who worked on the bipartisan legislation, said that encouraging people to buy long-term-care insurance would help protect elderly people's savings from the high cost of care and reduce the bill to Medicaid for long-term care, which is projected to climb to $67 billion by 2006, from about $30 billion in the fiscal year that ended on Oct. 1. "Both are clearly in the national interest," she said.
David Kingsbury, 73, a retired General Motors employee in Berlin, Conn., recently bought a long-term-care policy for his 70-year-old wife, June, for $1,200 a year. He was rejected for his own policy because of high blood pressure. "I wasn't too anxious to do it," he said, "but I felt that it was kind of a hedge."
Joshua Wiener, an expert on long-term care at the Urban Institute, said he did not think the new law would sharply cut the bill to Medicaid. He said that older people who could afford the insurance were unlikely to end up on Medicaid anyway, and that younger purchasers often let the policies lapse. He said it might take 25 years before private insurance had a measurable effect on Medicaid costs.
He also said the tax deduction -- projected to cost the Treasury $10.84 billion in reduced tax receipts over 10 years -- represented a wrongheaded diversion of scarce public funds to corporations and relatively affluent people. "The tax benefits will largely go to an upper-income group," Mr. Wiener said.
Also coming under criticism is the provision that threatens a $10,000 fine and up to a year in prison for some people who transfer assets to qualify for Medicaid. Mr. Wiener estimates that people who had used up or transferred assets to qualify for the program cost taxpayers about $4.3 billion last year.
Lawyers who call themselves "elder care" specialists say such asset transfers amount to Medicaid estate planning. They say many middle-class people would not be able to afford nursing home care, which can cost $100 to $200 a day, without the help of Medicaid. But after reports that the wealthy were passing estates to their children and then getting taxpayers to help pay for their nursing home care, Congress passed a law in 1993 that extended the waiting period for those who transfer assets. For example, if people transfer assets -- to, say, a child -- they must wait at least 36 months before applying for Medicaid to help pay for their nursing home care.
Some patient advocacy groups, financial planners and lawyers are already lobbying to eliminate or soften the penalties, and a spokeswoman for the Clinton Administration said it would support such changes.
Stephen McConnell, senior vice president for public policy at the Alzheimer's Association in Washington, which wants the provision repealed, said, "This is like using a sledgehammer for something that requires a much finer instrument."
Steve Moses, research director of LTC Inc., an insurance marketing company, said the penalties were "arguably unenforceable," adding, "They are not about to throw Grandma in jail."
And Craig Hartung, an executive with the California Public Employees Retirement System, said the people who might be at risk were "the financial planners, advisers and lawyers" who set up asset transfers for clients.
Enforced or not, the law's penalties will have an effect, said Mark R. Meiners, a University of Maryland expert on the economics of care for the elderly. "People won't want to be the one who finds how it will be enforced," he said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NORTHERN BROOKLYN;
. . . While Men Of Philosophy Market Pillows

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
There was a time when Stephan Shaw couldn't even find work flipping burgers at a fast-food restaurant. Perhaps the recession was to blame. Perhaps it was because he was a philosophy major.
Whatever the case, Mr. Shaw and his brother David, who had also majored in philosophy and was miserable in a temporary office job, turned to Adam Smith for inspiration. One night in 1989, around the time the Berlin wall fell, they baked a pan of clay earrings -- maps of Germany, East and West, to be dangled, either unified (in one ear) or not (in both). The next day, they sold them all on a SoHo street corner at $5 apiece. 
 The brothers moved on to pins, made of a resin and clay composite and with the faces of their favorite philosophers, including Immanuel Kant (they sold one such pin in three years), Soren Kierkegaard (sold maybe two) and Aristotle (not very popular either). But Friedrich Nietzsche proved lucrative: "He's seductive," explained Stephan Shaw, 28. "He's contemporary." Karl Marx was in demand the year the Soviet Union collapsed. And Freud has always been hot.
This year, the Unemployed Philosophers Guild, the company Mr. Shaw now runs from a fifth-floor loft under the Manhattan Bridge overpass, has sold 5,000 Singing Sigmund Freud pins; with the flip of a switch, the father of psychoanalysis plays the old classic "Try to Remember." His brother has moved to California for a film career, leaving him and a cadre of friends -- mostly artists, formerly unemployed -- responsible for designing new products.
Pillows are the most profitable items. The Mona Lisa pillow giggles when pressed. Vincent van Gogh's "Starry Night" glows with little Christmas lights.
"I always thought people would be offended that I was commodifying these people," Mr. Shaw said, shuffling through a drawer of not-so-popular pins, including a young Walt Whitman (no one recognized him) and William the Conqueror. "But they weren't. They want more."
Last year, the guild sold 12,000 pillows, along with thousands of pins, and grossed about $150,000. Its goods are sold by catalogue and in a handful of boutiques in New York.
For the most part, the guild pilfers art and images already in the public domain. "We are stuck in the past," Mr. Shaw said. "Also because living people could sue." SOMINI SENGUPTA

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
With Elections Over, The Board Races Begin

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

 BODY:
THE 1996 elections are barely over, but another race is already on for many losers, retirees and defectors from the Clinton Administration, and it ends in the corporate board room. A few companies have put out the word that they would like political insiders on their boards -- despite investor questions about such celebrity directors -- executive recruiters say.
And some of the newly unemployed in Washington are actively seeking such positions. 
 Many companies' wish lists include Colin L. Powell, despite his willingness so far to join just one board, that of Gulfstream Aerospace. And Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the National Economic Council, seems to be the "most wanted." "People believe she was a positive influence even if they don't agree with her politics," said Roger M. Kenny, head of Boardroom Consultants. "And women with a financial background seem to be in demand."
Age blocks some people who might otherwise be hot, including Bob Dole, 73, and Warren Christopher, 71, the departing Secretary of State. Many corporate bylaws require directors to step down at 70 or 72.
William J. Perry, the departing Defense Secretary who turned 69 last month, might squeak through. Some companies allow directors to stand for election until they reach 70 or 72 and then finish out their term, and Mr. Perry's geopolitical knowledge and experience in military contracting make him attractive.
Among other Cabinet members, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has floated his availability to some recruiters via intermediaries, with mixed reviews. "He is a brilliant guy, but he's not an attractive board candidate" because he has antagonized corporate America with attacks on those who have shrunk their work forces, said one recruiter who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mr. Kenny, however, said, "Government has mellowed him, and he'd probably be more attactive now than before his Government service."
Recruiters said companies might make room for Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, but would be less likely to do so for Federico F. Pena, the Transportation Secretary, and Hazel R. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, whose tenures are seen as lackluster.
Who else is a contender?
One recruiter who insisted on anonymity was intrigued by recent entreaties from an agent of former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
Ted Jadeck, a partner at Heidrick & Struggles, says Kenneth D. Brody, who stepped down as chairman of the Export-Import Bank in January, has prospects. "He ran a good-sized operation there, and he was on the management committee at Goldman, Sachs before," he said.
Mr. Kenny said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming "is interesting," and pointed to his expertise on health care and the environment.
Jack Kemp is expected to retake some of the six board seats he vacated to become Mr. Dole's running mate, the Oracle Corporation most prominent among them. Mr. Kemp, some recruiters say, might be able to trade up to bigger boards if he does not begin his own Presidential run.
The demand for politicians is not what it used to be, though. Pendleton E. James, a top recruiter who was once President Reagan's personnel chief, said his clients were "looking for substantial background in a given field, rather than public service."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2501 words

HEADLINE: In China, a Taste Of Buy-Me TV

BYLINE: By JON HILSENRATH 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
WHEN JINGWEN has a symbol of China's rising affluence tucked away near the dinner table in his two-bedroom apartment just outside Beijing.
It is an Ab-Rotor, a stomach exerciser he bought in September through a new television home shopping program for about $24, more than one-fifth of his monthly salary. 
 Mr. Chen, 33, a Communist Party member who works as a youth league organizer, reported just one glitch on his path to a trimmer stomach: he did not have a telephone to order the contraption. So instead of buying the product on impulse from home, he had to wait a day and make the call from his office.
"My next plan is I want to buy a jogging machine or a stationary bicycle, if the price is fair," said Mr. Chen, dressed in a new yellow warm-up suit and running shoes as he headed home after work to do some stomach crunches.
Hot on the heels of economic change, home shopping has come to China, with infomercials for mainly Western products -- some less than essential -- reaching into millions of living rooms like Mr. Chen's.
The Government is encouraging the incursion, seeing it as another opportunity to learn about Western marketing. The country's state-run television stations are helping foreign infomercial makers set up operations to peddle their imported wares. But through its state-run newspapers, China is also trying to protect local producers, urging consumers to buy domestic goods.
Some Western onlookers think the Government has good reason to be ambivalent. In a recent speech, Colin Powell, the retired general, said the rise of home shopping was a sign of Communism's fragility, "because there is no way Communism can compete with a salad shooter for $9.95."
Clearly, Chinese consumers highly prize Western goods.
"In the old days, they wore Mao outfits; today, they shop at Benetton," said Louis Tong, the managing director of SRG China, a division of A. C. Nielsen that takes surveys of Chinese consumers and monitors their television habits. "The whole economic scene has changed."
It is not yet clear, however, whether China is ready for this type of marketing. Shopping programs here face many hurdles that QVC or the Home Shopping Network never faced in the United States -- for example, the scarcity of two crucial elements of the home shopping formula: telephones and credit cards. On top of that, much of the telephone system is primitive, making it hard to get orders by phone. And even after the orders come in, the distribution system often consists of making deliveries by scooter in congested city traffic.
There are also consumer complaints that prices, pushed up by import tariffs, are too high. A Miracle Mop sold via infomercial will cost a Chinese consumer close to $40, while a mop made in China can be had here for less than a dollar.
"This is all at an extremely early stage of development," said Christopher K. B. Brotchie, the executive chairman of the Barings Communications Equity (Asia-Pacific) fund, "We're in a wait-and-see mode." His $60 million private investment fund invests in privately held Asian companies that are seen as having a chance to go public.
Still, the allure of the Chinese market -- 1.2 billion consumers, with incomes growing at double-digit rates -- makes investors and home shopping operators eager to connect with the likes of Mr. Chen.
"There are 809 million television homes in the world; 250 million of them are in China," said Mark Hershhorn, chief executive of the National Media Corporation, which plans to enter the Chinese infomercial market by the end of the year. "For us, it is a key market."
Elsewhere in the world, home shopping is booming, gobbling up television time. NIMA International, an infomercial marketing association in Washington, estimates that of $8.2 billion in global home shopping sales in 1995, $3.1 billion came from outside the United States In this respect, China is among the latecomers to the home shopping party.
Interwood Marketing of Canada, for instance, is now peddling its DiDi Seven stain removers in 107 countries worldwide -- including, most recently, Russia, India and China. Full-time home shopping channels like QVC, meanwhile, are popping up abroad as well. In just the last year, new channels started operating in Australia and in Hong Kong, where they are even trying to sell real estate.
In China, the appeal is clear -- especially in the cities, where incomes have risen at nearly a 20 percent annual rate for a decade and are fast approaching $1,000. By Western standards, of course, the incomes are still tiny. But with housing and health care costs low and with the consumer market still largely undeveloped, many Chinese workers save voraciously -- by most estimates, close to 40 percent of their incomes -- and some have enough stashed away to splurge on a bit of Western luxury or frivolity.
To be sure, home shopping in China is still mostly an urban phenomenon, touching only a slice of the potential market. Still, that slice could be big business: more than 300 million people live in China's cities.
THE effort is now dominated by infomercial operators, usually working with Chinese partners or others who understand the system; the programming generally consists of 10-to 20-minute segments that are broadcast between regular shows. America's 24-hour home shopping networks -- including QVC and the Home Shopping Network -- say they are staying out of China until the market develops. But TVSN, an Australian venture that sells everything from Vidal Sasson shampoo to Cobra golf clubs, is beaming 24-hour home shopping programming into some five-star hotels and expatriate compounds in big Chinese cities, and it hopes to expand.
Among the first infomercial entries, in December 1995, was China Shop-A-Vision, a Shanghai concern whose sole investor is Transpac Capital Ltd., a $500 million fund management company based in Singapore. The operator broadcasts 10-minute infomercials, most of them produced by Interwood Marketing.
The managing director of China Shop-A-Vision, Margaret Au-Yeung, a Hong Kong native who attended the School of Visual Arts in New York, says she plans to expand the programming into 10 more cities in coming months, and expects the venture to have sales of $10 million in its first year. Already, the program has more than 20,000 "TV Shopping Club" members, who are promised free delivery on their orders and services like free cooking lessons when they buy a Swiss cooker, Ms. Au-Yeung says.
Because they are not yet sure what Chinese consumers will want to buy, the handful of infomercial operators are trying to sell everything from exercise equipment and kitchen appliances to spray-on hair and rub-on ointments purported to reduce fat. One program has even offered a few waterbeds; they sold out.
The infomercials are often recycled Western versions, featuring enthralled American audiences, marveling at the likes of wonder mops, and ebullient hosts, dubbed in Chinese, enthusiastically creating messes on floors and magically wiping them away.
OF some staples of Western households are scarce in China, television sets are not -- especially in the cities. In Beijing, for example, 97 percent of households have TV's, though only 49 percent have telephones and fewer than 6 percent have home computers, according to SRG, the survey company.
And the reservoir of advertising time is enormous. The national programmer, China Central Television, offers only eight channels, but the country is home to more than 1,000 registered cable operators, many of which run their own channels locally. There are also hundreds of city and provincial channels that offer local advertising time. All this gives infomercial ventures plenty of opportunities to promote their goods.
For Chinese consumers, the infomercials provide a taste of Western products and the chance to shop without having to battle the traffic that chokes the roads of many coastal cities.
"There is incredible promise for home shopping," said Susan Schoenfeld, president of AIM Asia, a consulting firm based in Hong Kong. "There is a lot of pent-up demand in these markets, and they are interested in the kinds of products that are being offered."
Consider the buying potential of Gwan Zhi Bin, who quit a dead-end factory job four years ago and set up the Bin Bin Hair House, a small hair salon, on a busy street in downtown Beijing.
Mr. Gwan, 37, a thin man with thick, dark hair, says he now pulls in more than $7,500 a year -- a princely sum here -- and he weaves through Beijing traffic in his small Chinese-made van, with a beeper and cellular phone at his side. He bought bottles of hair highlighter for his business through an infomercial operator, convinced that Western sprays were better than domestic ones.
"Dyeing hair is popular now," Mr. Gwan said, adding that the hair sprays gave him an advantage over a competitor down the street.
One recent morning, he said, he colored the hair of three brides. "It made them look like a flower," Mr. Gwan said.
But if Mr. Chen's stomach exerciser and Mr. Gwan's hair spray are signs of China's rising affluence, the tale of the shopping program that sold them the products is a reminder that the transition has been rough.
Both men ordered from the International Shopping Network, the creation of John Wang, who has been struggling for nearly three years to build China's first nationwide home shopping network.
The concern's main China office sits on the edge of Beijing, not far from Mr. Chen's home. It overlooks a road where a stream of trucks and bicycles negotiate blackened, rain-filled potholes, as smokestacks puff in the background.
 MR. WANG was only 3 years old when his father, a fighter pilot with the Kuomintang army, was driven by the Communists to Taiwan with the rest of China's nationalist forces in 1949. The family moved to the United States in 1958, and Mr. Wang now logs frequent-flier miles between Beijing and his home in Solana Beach, Calif.
Today he is working closely with the state-run enterprises that grew up after his family left. Mr. Wang has agreements with China Central Television and with China International Television, the national cable programmer, to broadcast his 15-minute shopping programs throughout the country.
Because China Central is the only national television broadcaster, Mr. Wang's agreement gives him the broadest potential reach of any home shopping operator in China.
When Mr. Wang started the programs in early July, he was still working out how he was going to take orders from customers throughout the country -- the concept of toll-free telephone numbers was still new.
He was also trying to arrange to take payments in a country where fewer than 10 percent of the population have credit cards, even in a big city like Beijing. Like most other operators, he was taking cash on delivery, but he had a hard time getting the fragmented and disorganized postal service to collect the money outside Beijing.
For Mr. Wang, who had been importing automobile accessories and other goods from China since 1978 but had never built and run a business here, it was a herculean effort.
"We have taken on a very, very difficult task," Mr. Wang said from his warehouse in September. "There is still a lot of work ahead of us."
By that time, customers like Mr. Gwan were complaining that they were finding it hard to have the products delivered. And Mr. Wang was having trouble managing inventories when he didn't know which products would appeal to consumers. Surprisingly, there were strong sales for expensive products like waterbeds and a computer mouse shaped like a pen. (Consumers found they could use the mouse to write Chinese characters.) But other products that he expected to be hits, like a cheap headset, did poorly.
In late September, he gave control of the day-to-day operations to Lawrence Lien, a former project manager for the Bechtel Corporation in China and elsewhere. Mr. Lien had spent the last eight years as an independent consultant setting up joint ventures, largely in China.
By mid-October, the International Shopping Network had generated only $80,000 in sales and was running on just a few million dollars of invested capital. The network pulled its programs off the air in mid-October while it put together a plan to regroup.
"We are pressed for capital for both inventories and operations," Mr. Lien said from the network's California office. He said he still hoped to generate $60 million in sales by next August, after the programs went back on the air. Just a few weeks earlier, though, Mr. Wang was talking about more than $100 million in sales. Mr. Lien recently acknowledged that the venture needed capital and that "we'll struggle for a couple of weeks."
THE International Shopping Network is not alone in encountering obstacles. Shanghai Television Station, which runs two channels in the city, helped China Shop-A-Vision set up a telephone system, but Ms. Au-Yeung has had to come up with a variety of ways to distribute her Interwood products. Many of her customers must now pick up their products at department stores, wiping out some of the convenience of home shopping. She also has a crew of delivery men in Shanghai carrying products on scooters -- a less-than-perfect solution.
"The traffic in Shanghai is hopeless," she said.
Nelson Tan, a managing director of TV Media, an infomercial operator based in Singapore, said his biggest challenge in China was convincing consumers that it was safe to accept goods by delivery. TV Media sells its products in the southern province of Guangzhou and in Qingdao, a port city in eastern China.
"They are not used to this kind of idea," Mr. Tan said. "They'd rather come in and touch the product, see the product, before they do the purchase."
 Consumers have hurdles of their own, like finding phones through which to place orders. Some problems are a little more complex, like learning that Western production may not always be synonymous with quality.
CONSIDER what happened to Wang Rhenzang, a retired officer from the People's Liberation Army who has watched the dark hair on the crown of his head disappear steadily for 15 years. His son told him about spray-on hair after seeing it promoted on a television infomercial. Intrigued, Mr. Wang called the advertised number and ordered a can, shelling out $12, one-tenth of his monthly income.
 The purchase was a disaster. The directions were all in English, so he didn't know how to apply it. And when he tried using what he saw on the infomercial as a guide, the black ooze had no salutary effect on his hair. It did, however, get all over his clothes and rub off on his hands when he touched his head.
Asked whether he planned to return the product, Mr. Wang, confused and disappointed by his foray into modern consumer culture, said, "Can I return it?"
Call it growing pains -- for Wang Rhenzang, and for the new hordes trying to reach into his living room.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Parenthood: The Eighth Financial Wonder of the World

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
KIDS, cars and gifts get heavy play in the December crop of personal-finance magazines.
Smart Money's special issue on children -- "Your Biggest Investment" -- is an exhaustive financial guide for parents. It covers about every conceivable aspect of the endeavor, from buying baby formula to paying for college to estate planning. 
 The magazine says the cost of rearing a child and getting him or her through college is now in the neighborhood of $200,000, depending on whose figures are used. To drive the point home, Smart Money provides a list of typical child-rearing expenses and compares them with what you might have bought for yourself with the money had you decided to forgo parenthood. Instead of four years of Harvard tuition and expenses, you could have had a 1997 Mercedes E420, a Denon Home Theater and a Tiffany bezel-set diamond bracelet. A live-in nanny equals a gold Rolex watch, and those braces could be a week at a fancy resort. Clip the chart. It might be good ammunition against a plea for the latest $500 designer bicycle seat.
Another article in the special issue, "The New Math: Home vs. School," by Nellie S. Huang, is a good guide to the relationship between real estate values and the quality of school districts. It also offers some sound advice on judging schools, from class sizes to test scores.
On a more somber note, Money magazine investigates the dangers that children can face from common vaccines. The magazine contends that safer vaccines exist, but they are more expensive and are not promoted strongly enough by drug companies, doctors and Federal regulators.
According to Money -- which uses data from the Institute of Medicine and the National Vaccine Information Center -- DPT shots to prevent diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough) and tetanus cause brain damage at the rate of 1 case for every 62,000 immunized children and kill at least 2 to 4 people a year. And the number of deaths could be in the hundreds, including a great number misclassified as victims of sudden infant death syndrome. Money says the problem could be virtually eliminated by using a so-called acellular vaccine that has been used in Japan since 1981; it costs $19.43 a dose, $9 more than the vaccine most widely used in the United States.
 
THE ONCE AND FUTURE CAR Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine, Smart Money and Individual Investor all have articles on cars. Kiplinger's five-article buyer's guide takes readers through all aspects of getting a car -- from sticker shock to insurance. It also rates cars in categories like "best in class" and "most fuel efficient."
Individual Investor, which seldom wanders from its more narrow focus on investing, looks at cars through that prism. The emphasis is on the future of the auto industry and companies in which investors might consider putting their money. In addition to discussing the auto giants, the magazine provides financial highlights on smaller companies that are designing, building and supplying parts for today's automobiles and those of the not-so-distant future.
Smart Money, meanwhile, stresses good leasing deals, including some for sport utility vehicles.
 
SEASONAL ADVICE Everyone, it seems, is on the holiday gift-recommendation bandwagon. Kiplinger's stresses presents with a health-and-fitness angle. Individual Investor goes for investment aids, like "Richer Than the Pharaoh," a CD-ROM game that teaches financial concepts through role-playing. Worth, Money and Smart Money go for the usual upscale gift assortment, including a $1,000 cellular phone, a $6,500 watch and -- for a mere $10,250 -- a flight in a MIG-29 with a Russian test pilot. (Subsonic airfare to and from Moscow is extra.)
 
A PRINCIPAL WARNING On Jan. 15, the Government will begin selling those inflation-indexed bonds, whose principal value will be adjusted according to changes in the Consumer Price Index. Worth (in its combined December-January issue) and Kiplinger's remind potential buyers that any gain in principal will be taxed the year it is credited, even though the bond's owner may not see the cash for years. If inflation picks up, an investor in a high tax bracket could wind up paying more in taxes on the principal than is earned in interest in a given year.
A QUIET MUTUAL FUND Smart Money peeks into the Retirement System Emerging Growth fund, a small-company fund managed by Putnam Investments. It seems the fund, despite a five-year average return of 28.3 percent, has gone out of its way to discourage publicity and investors. According to Smart Money, a spokeswoman even denied that the fund was sold in the retail market when the prospectus says otherwise and lists a toll-free number for individuals with an initial investment of as little as $2,500. The reason for the secrecy remains a mystery.
 
BITS AND PIECES Money has a special section on using economic news to perk up your portfolio. Worth's Jim Rogers, author of "Investment Biker," offers guidance in international investing. And Smart Money is bullish on the cable industry.
