HEADLINE: Size of Texaco Discrimination Settlement Could Encourage More Lawsuits

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Texaco's decision to settle a Federal discrimination lawsuit provides evidence of how vulnerable consumer-oriented corporations can be to bad publicity and outside pressure as they deal with employee accusations of racial or sexual bias.
The settlement reached on Friday with Texaco's minority employees exceeds $140 million, making it the largest in a racial discrimination case. The size of the settlement could encourage other discrimination suits against companies and is bound to capture the attention of executives, who may want to review their companies' employment practices. 
 While there is little evidence that the Texaco boycott that was called by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other civil rights leaders put a dent in Texaco's profits, lawyers who handle discrimination cases say the publicity and the potential for future losses put increasing pressure on Texaco to settle the suit, which was filed in early 1994, rapidly.
Despite the settlement, Mr. Jackson said today that the boycott of Texaco products would continue and that demonstrations were planned at the company's refineries and gasoline stations in cities in Connecticut, California, Florida and other states. At a news conference in Chicago, Mr. Jackson announced that his organization, the Rainbow PUSH Action Network, planned to buy $1,000 in Texaco stock to get a voice in the company and that it would study the affirmative action policies of other big companies that share directors with Texaco, like Gillette, Johnson & Johnson and Campbell Soup.
In Brooklyn, the Rev. Al Sharpton led about 20 protesters with signs at a Texaco station. " Now we must deal with corporate structure, board makeup, contracting, advertising and franchises," Mr. Sharpton said.
Lawrence Z. Lorber, a Washington lawyer who represents big corporations in discrimination suits, said: "If you are a consumer-product company, you're quite vulnerable. If you're an Exxon, or an American Express, or a Texaco, it's a big exposure. If you're a chemical company and people don't know what you make, you're really not subject to any real intervention."
The Texaco case was unusual in that it was thrust into the public arena two weeks ago after The New York Times disclosed the existence of tape recordings of several of its executives discussing the possible destruction of evidence and making disparaging comments about blacks. In most discrimination cases, such talk -- if it occurs -- never emerges from behind closed doors and so the public is never engaged, or outraged.
"If these tapes hadn't appeared," said a Federal official familiar with the case, speaking on the condition on anonymity, "this would have been the typical race discrimination case where one side says there was discrimination and the other side says there wasn't, and both would have hired $400-an-hour lawyers and fought this till kingdom come."
The Texaco case and its settlement also signal how much the landscape of employment discrimination has changed. The suit was filed by six black Texaco employees on behalf of 1,500 others, asserting that the company systematically discriminated against minority employees in promotions and had fostered a racially hostile environment.
Lawyers who handle such suits say this type of case more commonly involves allegations of sexual discrimination, mainly because it has been easier to make a case. Statistically, they say, it has been easier to show that there are large numbers of qualified white women being passed over for promotion than blacks and other minority employees.
The Texaco case indicates that blacks are finally gaining enough white-collar jobs to make these types of glass-ceiling suits possible.
"You've had, certainly since the late 1970's and the 1980's, a significant influx of African-Americans into white-collar jobs," said Mr. Lorber, the lawyer. "Now, years later, you have a whole lot of folks ready to be promoted to middle- and senior-management jobs."
Peter I. Bijur, Texaco's chairman, said after the settlement: "Texaco is committed to developing and instituting specific, effective policies that will insure that discrimination is wiped out wherever it may be, and that will expand the positive economic impact we can have on the minority community. These policies will be clearly defined and achievable, with measurable goals set out with specific timetables."
Under the settlement, Texaco will pay $115 million into a pool for the benefit of its 1,500 minority employees. It will also give pay increases of about 10 percent to those employees. Lawyers estimated that it would cost about $26.1 million over five years.
But other elements of the settlement could prove to be even more important than the amount of cash Texaco has agreed to pay. The company agreed to a number of terms that effectively redesigns its entire affirmative-action program. Indeed, under the settlement, control of many elements of the program will be turned over to a committee largely appointed by outsiders.
Civil rights leaders and employment lawyers said such terms could be significant in the future.
"We hope that we are able to structure a model for other corporate entities to emulate," said Kweisi Mfume, president and chief executive of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which is continuing to negotiate terms of an action plan with Texaco.
Still, there could be complications ahead for corporate affirmative-action programs, especially after the passage of a California ballot initiative earlier this month, banning the state from extending any preferences based on race, ethnicity or sex. Indeed, there has been speculation that affirmative-action programs for minorities and women might not be around much longer.
That prospect causes concern among some corporations, whose executives believe that affirmative-action plans can forestall discrimination suits or be used as a defense if such a suit is filed, some lawyers said. If such plans are banned, the lawyers said, these companies might find themselves more vulnerable to large class-action lawsuits brought about by the racist or sexist conduct of lower-level managers.
"One of the reasons that there has always been significant support by large companies for affirmative action, especially at the top of the companies, is because the people at the top often understand the difficulty they have in getting decision-makers on the shop floor or in the accounting department to actually change their conduct," said Barry Goldstein, a lawyer in Berkeley, Calif., who specializes in employment discrimination cases. "People have certain stereotypes and prejudices that they have grown up with, and how do you get people to change their way of acting? One answer that companies come up with is to have clear measurements of progress. That's called affirmative action."
With the size of the Texaco settlement, lawyers also expect an escalation in the amount plaintiffs will sue for and in the price of a settlement. "Plaintiffs say our situation is comparable to Texaco and those 1,500 people at Texaco got $140 million," Mr. Goldstein said. "Why should we take less than $100 million?"
And with the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, the ability of plaintiffs' lawyers in discrimination cases to ask for larger damage awards has increased. Much of the debate over that bill centered on whether it would force companies to establish rigid quotas.
But some business groups like the Business Roundtable were more concerned over provisions in the act that for the first time allowed plaintiffs who proved intentional discrimination to seek up to $300,000 per person in compensatory and punitive damages. Previously, plaintiffs could win only back pay. Some lawyers say that when it comes to the size of the award, the Texaco case might be a harbinger of things to come.
"I'm not aware of any other major settlements since the 1991 act went into affect," said John Relman of the Washington Lawyers Committee for civil rights, "certainly not of this magnitude."

HEADLINE: November 10-16;
Unbalanced Budget Talk

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
The last time Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had to haul his boss up short, the ever-loquacious President talked too much about the dollar -- and briefly sent the markets haywire. Last week Mr. Clinton did the same to Congress. In an overlong answer to a short question, he seemed to accept that the Republican majority in the Senate would pass a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
Rather than denounce this as vigorously as he had in the past, Mr. Clinton started talking about building "escape hatches" that would allow the Government to spend more in recessions, when the economy needs stimulation. 
 Mr. Rubin feared that Democrats in Congress, seeing Mr. Clinton waffle, would abandon the Administration and vote for the popular amendment. So in the Oval Office, and then in a rare public correction of his President, Mr. Rubin argued that it is impossible to build an escape hatch for unforeseen economic events. The way to balance the budget, he says, is to cut spending, not mess with the Constitution.
Exactly what the President meant to say, the White House quickly echoed. And Mr. Rubin, it added, will be around for a second term. DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Honda Prelude;
When One Good Turn Deserves Another

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

DATELINE: PHOENICIA, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE sky is blue, the few remaining leaves are brown and the passenger is quickly turning green.
The car I am enthusiastically driving is emphatically red, a 1997 Honda Prelude Type SH, and I have spent the afternoon flinging it around every curve and corner in a swath of the northern Catskills, trying to determine if it is possible to flap this seemingly unflappable sports coupe. 
 Up treacherous Platte Clove Road from Saugerties, down winding Route 23A to Kaaterskill Falls, then out toward Hunter Mountain. Along lovely, curving Route 214 to this village on Esopus Creek, then off to Woodstock on 212, a splendid road where precise control is desirable lest you top a hill and encounter a deer -- or nearly as likely, a slow-mo VW Microbus plastered with stickers envisioning Ralph Nader in the White House.
The redesigned Prelude, which went on sale last week, is made for roads like these, and for tight Interstate ramps and urban traffic in which only the nimble can be quick. The handling is so flat and neutral that normally cautious drivers may find themselves taking corners faster than they ever dared, trying to find the Prelude's limits and wondering if the 16-inch tires will squeal before a queasy companion does.
Lest any Naderites get the wrong impression, it should be noted that the point of this Prelude is not reckless abandon but exquisite control. The double-wishbone suspension is solid and stable, and the test car had a stability control that Honda calls the Active Torque Transfer System. It helps in cornering by monitoring the front wheels' speed, the angle of the steering and the various forces involved in making a turn, and it directs power from the wheel on the inside to the one on the outside. The process is akin to a rower's steering a boat by paddling harder with the outside oar.
The stability control made the Type SH feel go-kart responsive on a test track set up by Honda, but its benefits are less obvious in everyday driving. You'll probably not engage it when leaving your driveway or dodging ruminants in the road. Since it works mainly when the car accelerates, neutralizing the tendency of a front-wheel-drive car to plow ahead when the driver wants to turn, a trait known as understeer, it will thrill owners who race their cars on weekends.
The torque transfer system, which comes only on the top-line SH, is just the latest of several technical innovations that Honda has tried first in Preludes. In 1983, there was the double wishbone; in '88, anti-lock brakes, and in '92, the highly efficient VTEC engine, which offers spirited response, remarkable fuel economy and a throaty growl. Another Prelude first, four-wheel steering in '88, was discarded because its cost and complexity outweighed its slight benefit.
Another new-for-'97 feature is a four-speed automatic transmission that can be shifted manually, like those offered by Porsche, Chrysler and the Prelude's stepbrother, the Acura NSX sports car. But unlike the NSX's Formula One-style fingertip controls, the Prelude's Sequential Sport Shift has a shifter in the console that moves in an "H" pattern. By pulling the lever to the left, you can push or pull it to shift to higher or lower gears, no clutch required.
The trick transmission is available only on the base car (all SH's are manuals) and I'd be inclined to pass on it. The Prelude's precise five-speed stick is too much fun.
And if you don't like to have fun at the wheel, this fifth-generation Prelude is not for you. As the sporty coupe market has gone into a free fall in the last decade, people who bought them only for the image have moved on, often to sport utility vehicles. Honda figures that mostly die-hard enthusiasts, a lot of them a few years either side of 30, are left in the market, and it has tailored the new car to them. The responsive VTEC is the only engine, and at 195 horsepower it is more powerful than before but still not very thirsty.
Driven back to back with the '96 model on the test course, the '97 is noticeably more rigid, the suspension is stiffer and the steering is quicker. But poseurs may find the ride too harsh and the styling too minimalist.
In a sense, the Prelude has gone back to its roots after straying in 1992-96 to a flashy design with an anachronistic instrument panel that swept from door to door. The simple new dash is classic Honda, with big gauges and excellent controls.
Over all, the styling is conservative and understated, except for oversized headlights stacked under a plastic cover. First with the '96 Civic and now with the Prelude, Honda seems to have decided that big, oddly shaped headlamps can be a styling theme.
From the rear, there is an obvious resemblance to the third-generation Preludes of 1988-91. And the no-nonsense interior is spare, even Teutonic. (But, hey, if German interiors can become more Japanese, with cup holders and loose-fitting leather, why can't the Japanese go the other way?)
There is more space for cargo and passengers, and the cabin, while cozy, is not claustrophobic, thanks to big windows and a dashboard that angles down from the windshield. A two-part storage box under the center armrest has a shallow tray, and below that, a deep bin. A new security system disables the car unless the proper key transmits the proper digital signal.
The base Prelude ($23,595 including delivery) is nicely equipped, with power windows, locks, mirrors and sunroof; cruise control; air-conditioning, and a CD player. And even without torque transfer, you get the feeling that if you tried to macarena, it would follow every move. Along with the torque system, the Type SH ($26,095) gets different wheels and a rear spoiler.
The front seats are firm, with an adjustable bottom cushion and side bolsters that hug you tight on turns. The upholstery is understated fabric, and fashion victims take note: Honda will not give you slippery cow skins even if you're willing to pay extra. This is not a car for Ricardo Montalban.
The Prelude is not quite perfect, but it has few glaring faults. The horn is controlled by buttons (big ones, to be sure) on the steering-wheel hub, rather than by the hub itself; you expect Honda to do better. The latch protrudes menacingly from the open trunk lid. The back seat, though ostensibly bigger, is still punishing. Road noise intrudes.
But this remains one of the few models that have plenty of legroom for tall drivers. From the feel of the seats to the positions of the wheel, the pedals and the shifter, this car feels as if it were made just for me.
Indeed, I've owned three Preludes, and still have an '85. It is rarely driven these days, but it still feels as solid, with an engine that purrs as smoothly, as some new cars I've driven lately. And its 100,000-plus miles have been virtually trouble-free.
Would I make the hard-charging new car Prelude No. 4? Probably not, though I like it. My needs have changed, as have those of many other sporty-coupe alumni, and I've come to value the all-wheel-drive security of a sport utility that makes regular runs into the mountains. And truth be told, as nice as the new Type SH is, it doesn't look like $26,000 to me.
But for the younger and more restless, and those who aspire to the Acura NSX but can't write the check for $87,000, that may be a small price for some richly rewarding turns at the wheel.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A Formula One appetizer for a party of four.

HEADLINE: Earning Power;
Global Forces Batter Politics

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT much of the world today, politics lags behind economics, like a horse and buggy haplessly trailing a sports car. While politicians go through the motions of national elections -- offering chimerical programs and slogans -- world markets, the Internet and the furious pace of trade involve people in a global game in which elected representatives figure as little more than bit players. Hence the prevailing sense, in America and Europe, that politicians and ideologies are either uninteresting or irrelevant.
Bill Clinton has understood this better than most. His political style, stressing flexible management over firm policy, adapts itself to the economic winds and technological advances that are changing the way people communicate and think faster than any political doctrine ever could. If you can't fight globalization, he intimates, you may as well join it. Elsewhere, though -- especially here in France, where there has always been a conviction that political planning should prevail over the whims of the market -- the powerlessness of politicians has contributed to a profound malaise.
 
 
 
Dissatisfaction
 
 "Throughout Europe, to a greater or lesser extent, we have rampant dissatisfaction because politicians are elected on promises they can't deliver because the market is global," said Jonathan Eyal, director of studies at the United Services Institute, a London think tank.
In France, unemployment has soared to 12.5 percent, the highest rate in Europe, and the Government can do little to help because it is bound by strict spending curbs mandated by European economic integration -- itself partly a response to the competitive demands of the global marketplace.
 
 
 
Menacing Ghoul
 The uncontrollable forces of the global village, with their daily mockery of domestic political agendas, have coalesced, for the French, into a menacing ghoul, loosely made up of the American architects of cyberspace, Wall Street currency traders and German central bankers. The new catch-phrase is "L'horreur economique," and the economic horror in question is not some Zola-esque child-labor network but the array of supranational forces that have abruptly given the French the discomfiting sense that they no longer control their destiny.
In America, however, Mr. Clinton has successfully preached that free trade offers immense opportunities to American industries willing to compete in a Disney-like "small, small world" of English-speaking, Big Mac-chomping computer nerds. With no cold war to fight, American diplomats have been widely recast as international salesmen.
Mr. Clinton was re-elected partly because this campaign has worked. The diatribes of Patrick J. Buchanan and Ross Perot against the North American Free Trade Agreement had a limited impact on a nation where the global economy has proved more boon than burden. Even American fears about competing with Japan now seem remote.
Still, even in Mr. Clinton's America, the changes wrought by globalization can be troubling. Corporate downsizing, undertaken to insure international competitiveness, has hurt many Americans. Other effects are less evident. They involve politics catching up with economics.
As imports have more than doubled over the past two decades, and the American economy has become increasingly international, foreign companies have come to have a much bigger stake in the American political system. That truth has an abstract air about it until it is embodied in the person of somebody like John Huang.
 
 
 
Blurring the Line
 Just what Mr. Huang was up to, and whether it was illegal, remains unclear. But the activities of this Indonesian-American Democratic Party fund-raiser -- including his coaxing of a $250,000 contribution from a South Korean conglomerate -- have raised questions about whether American foreign policy in Indonesia, and Southeast Asia generally, was in any sense for sale. Mr. Clinton last week for the first time acknowledged having met with Mr. Huang and James Riady, the Indonesian billionaire for whom Mr. Huang once worked, but the President denied that they had influenced policy decisions. Still, their entree to the White House -- with roots in Mr. Clinton's days back in Arkansas -- appears to blur the line between national politics and global commerce.
This trend may be inevitable, for if the economy is global, politics can hardly ignore the fact. The difference between America and Europe appears to lie in how threatening the changes wrought by the global marketplace are perceived to be. Mr. Huang may have transgressed, but his actions suggest that the constituents of the American President are now global. His comings and goings raise ethical questions, but they affirm rather than impugn America's power.
Conversely, in a France entirely lacking America's current confidence, a psychosis over lost sovereignty is growing. Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Perot strike a chord with some Americans, but in the end they remain marginal. Bob Dole's complaints about the surrender of American power to the United Nations go largely unheeded. (Look at Mr. Clinton's commitment of thousands of American troops to a United Nations force in Africa last week.) But in France, the xenophobic National Front of Jean-Marie Le Pen has advanced implacably, winning control of big French cities like Toulon and Orange.
The specters Mr. Le Pen is able to exploit are manifold. France, like other nations of the European Union, faces an imminent surrender of much of its sovereignty. A European currency, the "euro," is to be introduced in just over two years, and control of the fiscal policies that back it will reside essentially with a European Central Bank.
The ability of national politicians to set economic policy will thus be severely curtailed. While in the United States the Federal Reserve's power is balanced by a powerful federal government, there will be no European government acting as a counterweight to a European Central Bank in which Germany's influence is almost certain to be dominant.
 
 
 
Surrendered Sovereignty
 Mr. Eyal said this development would exacerbate Europe's disenchantment with politicians who are powerless to deliver. "We are going to have unelected bureaucrats, distant from any public accountability, running a bank board that will essentially set everything in economic terms in Europe. The results could be explosive."
As Gary Burgless of the Brookings Institution pointed out, France and Germany are now operating like California and New York State, but without a federal government in Washington to redistribute resources between them and without the labor mobility of the United States. "If there was 12.5 percent unemployment in New York," as there is now in France, he said, "you'd have money pouring in and people pouring out. But that doesn't happen in Europe."
Of course, the euro has been advanced by France and Germany in part to counter the perceived American domination of the global economy. But this long-term aim -- a strong European currency for a more united Europe less dependent on the United States -- may not produce fruits quickly enough to head off the seething discontent that the likes of Mr. Le Pen are exploiting.
The mood in France has been captured recently by anger at the proposed sale of the state-owned Thomson Multimedia consumer electronics company to Daewoo of South Korea. Veiled racism appears to lurk behind dark tales of the ruthless methods of Daewoo and laments about the sale of a French "national jewel" to an Asian competitor. With rumors circulating that layoffs are at hand, the National Front has been furiously distributing leaflets at Thomson plants.
It is notable that no such outburst has accompanied British Telecom's proposed purchase of MCI, the American long-distance phone company. Americans are simply better disposed toward a global market whose benefits they now sense. In fact, a substantial part of Thomson's vaunted technology in digital television and satellite systems is developed at plants in the United States, acquired when Thomson bought RCA in the 1980's. James Harper, a spokesman at these plants in Indiana, said, "There has been no hue and cry over the Koreans running things rather than the French."
 
 
 
Contrasting Reactions
 The differing reactions to Daewoo at Thomson in France and in the United States reveal two things. The first is that America's more open, more flexible society copes more easily with the rapid flux of an increasingly frontierless world. The second is that globalization, however it is caricatured, is not merely Americanization. Thomson has major interests in the United States. Many Japanese cars are largely American-made. American sneakers are made in Asia. CNN has instant worldwide recognition, but so, too, do BMW and Chanel.
Still, the rapid, American-led change of civilization headed by the likes of Microsoft and Intel is bound to produce a political reaction. Their technology destroys borders, sweeping them away like quaint vestiges of an old world. Not everyone likes this. For every Riady courting American favor, there is someone courting resistance to America and globalization. Benjamin R. Barber of Rutgers University has called this global conflict "Jihad versus McWorld."
In France, the anxieties over the global theme park exploited by Mr. Le Pen are more widespread than his movement. Similarly, in Asia, the forces of Japanese and Chinese nationalism are stirring. To use Benedict Arnold's phrase, the "imagined communities" gathered behind national flags will not be abandoned without a fight.
Mr. Le Pen now says, "We are for a revolution, but a French one" -- that is, a revolution, but for people of French blood, whoever they may be. The French revolution of 1789 had a different theme: the forging of a nation of citizens, irrespective of ethnicity, whose rights gave them a stake in the country. Therein lay its universal appeal. Today, however, universal ideas appear overwhelmingly American, and the French, among others, are groping for a response.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the political effects of global economic forces referred incorrectly to the originator of the idea of "imagined communities," referring to the conceptions people have of nationhood. He is Benedict Anderson, professor of government at Cornell University; the mention of Benedict Arnold was inadvertent.

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
The Magical Touch Of Marcel Carne

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
MARCEL CARNE'S FATE was melancholy indeed: he outlived his productive career by 45 years, and new ways of looking at movies diminished the reputation of some of his best work even before it could become decently dated. Yet Carne, who was 90 when he died in a Paris suburb on Oct. 31, was the man who made "Les Enfants du Paradis" (1945), widely regarded as a masterpiece and the most critically acclaimed, most popular French film of all time.
"Les Enfants du Paradis" ("The Children of Paradise") was also one of those European films that after World War II first turned many Americans on to the possibility that there was an entirely different kind of life to be found in movies made outside of Hollywood. 
 For me, it was love at first sight in 1947. Without warning, I was swept into its tumultuous series of interlocking tales set in the Paris theater world of the early 19th century, never to be quite the same again. Watching it was to have an out-of-body experience long before such phenomena had been identified.
The film seemed to possess a mysterious but leisurely vitality, an almost tactile black-and-white beauty and a robust frankness about sex that were at a far remove from anything that Louis B. Mayer would have approved. The fact that one spent as much time reading the movie as simply looking at it might also have added to its cerebral cachet. MGM films didn't need subtitles: if you knew how to keep your eyes open, you were home free.
My reaction on seeing "Les Enfants du Paradis" a couple of decades later was quite different: mostly surprise that I had originally been taken in by its ornate melodrama, its talk of fate and moonlight's magic and other kinds of romantic nonsense that were then being lumped together as poetic realism.
Thus I was unprepared when, looking at it once more a few days ago, I was suddenly astonished all over again by its abundant, teeming images, the richness of its unabashedly literary (if sometimes overripe) dialogue and its now quaint but grandly operatic fatalism. Movies, unlike old friends, don't change with time; instead, knowing the worst, we change with time to accommodate movies as we would old friends.
Carne lived long and was still trying to make a film four years ago, a project that was abandoned only when he became ill 10 days into the shooting. It's just as well that fate stepped in. His best films were made in the brief 10-year period that reached its peak with the production of "Les Enfants du Paradis" in 1944-45. All but one of these early films ("Hotel du Nord") were written by Jacques Prevert, known and respected as a poet as well as a screenwriter. Carne and Prevert completed their last film together in 1946, "Les Portes de la Nuit" ("The Gates of Night"), a failure, some said, because it had been prepared for Jean Gabin and Marlene Dietrich and, instead, was made with Yves Montand, then new to movies, and Nathalie Nattier.
It seems equally probable that, even then, time was overtaking Carne. Just how out of touch he was to become can be seen in "Les Tricheurs" (1958), released here in 1961 as "The Cheaters": a tale about heedless, overprivileged French youth, couched in the superior, moralistic terms that helped to make Carne's name a joke among members of the New Wave.
THERE WERE THOSE WHO attributed his postwar decline to his dependency on Prevert. Yet Prevert, with the exception of his screenplay for Jean Renoir's "Crime de M. Lange" ("The Crime of Monsieur Lange") (1935), never had the success with other directors that he attained with Carne. The work of both men was rooted in the pre-war France that produced the left-wing, socially conscious Popular Front, when the fashion was to romanticize the despair of proles trapped in a world they did not understand and could not fight.
Witness "Quai des Brumes" ("Port of Shadows") (1938), in which Jean Gabin, as an Army deserter, is forced to commit murder to save the honor of the beautiful, very young Michele Morgan, and is shot down for his efforts in a rain-splattered street. The same formula is used in "Le Jour se Leve" ("Daybreak") (1939), in which a good-hearted, inarticulate factory worker (the iconographic Gabin again) gives up his life so that the naive young woman he loves can be free of her aging seducer.
Carne and Prevert don't blame political or economic systems. Instead, there's much talk about destiny and fate accompanied by a total lack of irony, which, in these circumstances, might pass for humor. Carne and Prevert were committed to messages about man's unholy condition, which resulted in films that are perfectly planned, elegant looking but never for a minute spontaneous.
"Le Jour se Leve" opened in June 1939, but the French military censor found it to be so demoralizing that it was banned when the war started in September. "Quai des Brumes" and "Le Jour se Leve," each designed by the great Alexandre Trauner, who did most of Carne's films, are drenched in the atmosphere of romantic despair: rain, fog, gritty streets, cheap hotels and smoky bistros. They are living testimonials to the technical expertise of the prewar French studios where they were filmed.
Noteworthy, too, is "Les Visiteurs du Soir" ("The Devil's Envoys"), made in 1942 during the occupation. Set in medieval France, it's about two doomed former lovers (Arletty and Alain Cuny) sent to earth by the Devil (Jules Berry) to disrupt a nobleman's wedding and buy a few souls. This is Cocteau territory, but without Cocteau's genius for fantasy. Instead, it has the flawless symmetrical beauty of Arletty to bewitch the beholder, as well as much solemn talk about fate, destiny and the redemptive power of love. James Agee was not far off the mark when he described it as " 'Aucassin and Nicolette' translated into Middle High Marshmallow." After the war, Carne defended it as an allegory about a France ruled by Hitler.
The same sort of message was trotted out to explain the production of "Les Enfants du Paradis," though the finished work is the only explanation needed. Whether or not it is an authentic masterpiece, "Les Enfants du Paradis" is a gorgeous evocation of a particular time and place. It is also superbly performed by its stars: Arletty, Jean-Louis Barrault, Pierre Brasseur and the often overlooked Marcel Herrand, who plays Lacenaire. Based on the real-life French murderer and fringe literary figure, Lacenaire is as seriously eccentric as the Marquis de Sade and as uncompromising as Jean Genet. He is also the most authentically modern character in all of the Carne-Prevert collaborations.
Most important, "Les Enfants du Paradis" is a celebration of the kind of traditional, literary, high-quality French film making that was soon to be all but demolished by Francois Truffaut and the other Young Turks of the French New Wave.
In 1954, five years before he made his own first feature, Truffaut wrote the brazenly insulting manifesto in Cahiers du Cinema attacking "la tradition de la qualite." His targets were Jean Delannoy, Claude Autant-Lara, Rene Clement and Carne, directors who seldom were responsible for their own screenplays but devoted themselves to illustrating the work of literary writers. Truffaut accused the writers of being "contemptuous of the cinema by underestimating it." It was time, he said, for film makers to move out of the studios into the streets, to write their own screenplays, to establish eye contact with their characters and not to look down on them as if from some privileged, detached position far above.
Carne was not destroyed by the attacks of the New Wave critics -- time and his own particular limitations did that. Yet he was grievously hurt in the crossfire and nursed his wounds for the rest of his life. Truffaut, possibly aware of the damage he had caused, later made a courtly gesture, not of reconciliation but of appreciation. In his introduction to "The Films of My Life" (1973), he recalls having first seen Carne's "Visiteurs du Soir" twice on the same day when he was 10 years old. He writes that he liked it a lot the first time he sat through it. The second time: "I realized how fascinating it can be to probe deeper and deeper into a work one admires, that the exercise can go so far as to create the illusion of reliving the creation."
Every generation of film makers builds on the work of the generations that precede it. Eventually, the in-fighting is forgotten, but the films remain. They accumulate. In a video store on Manhattan's Upper West Side, "Les Enfants du Paradis" rests just a couple of cassettes down the shelf from "L'Enfant Sauvage."

HEADLINE: Columbia's Tuition

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The news that Columbia University has streamlined the process for obtaining private student loans (news article, Nov. 14) is a mixed blessing. I paid my Columbia loans, but current students will have to assume greater debt, repaid often over longer periods. Since my enrollment at Columbia 12 years ago, the cost of tuition there has doubled. Instead of easing students into deeper debt, Columbia's administration should examine its own costs, especially when its tuition increases have outpaced the rate of inflation.
 
CHRISTOPHER BROWNE
Providence, R.I., Nov. 14, 1996
